description: CompTIA and the Linux Professional Institute (LPI) have worked in conjunction to create the CompTIA Linux+ certification. The certification covers the basic knowledge required of a junior level Linux administrator. Candidates are expected to be able to work competently across a wide array of environments and skill sets. Unlike many certifications, candidates who complete the Linux+ exams (LX0-103 and LX0-104) are awarded with not one, but three certifications: the CompTIA Linux+ certification, the LPI LPIC-1 certification and SUSE Certified Linux Administrator (CLA). That makes this an excellent starting point for people interested in working with Linux as you gain essential base knowledge as well as fill out your resume.

episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:07.665
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:07.665 --> 00:00:08.925
>> In this segment,

3
00:00:08.925 --> 00:00:14.899
we're gonna give you a brief overview
of the Linux+ LXO-103 and 104 exams.

4
00:00:14.899 --> 00:00:15.407
>> [LAUGH]
>> Yes,

5
00:00:15.407 --> 00:00:17.804
there are two of them
available from CompTIA.

6
00:00:17.804 --> 00:00:19.368
And joining me today is Don.

7
00:00:19.368 --> 00:00:23.291
He's gonna give us a help here and give us
a good overview of what we can expect and

8
00:00:23.291 --> 00:00:24.711
see in the upcoming series.

9
00:00:24.711 --> 00:00:26.256
So Don, take it away.

10
00:00:26.256 --> 00:00:28.187
What can we expect from this series?

11
00:00:28.187 --> 00:00:31.568
>> Well, the CompTIA Linux+ certification
is a great certification for

12
00:00:31.568 --> 00:00:33.549
people just getting started with Linux.

13
00:00:33.549 --> 00:00:35.953
You don't have to know one
single bit about Linux, and

14
00:00:35.953 --> 00:00:38.356
we start with running through
how to get it installed,

15
00:00:38.356 --> 00:00:40.721
some of the different
distributions to choose from.

16
00:00:40.721 --> 00:00:43.221
And then once it's installed,
how to support and operate it.

17
00:00:43.221 --> 00:00:47.043
The goal of the CompTIA Linux+
certification is to prove that you have

18
00:00:47.043 --> 00:00:49.701
the knowledge to support
Linux workstations and

19
00:00:49.701 --> 00:00:51.734
servers in a business environment.

20
00:00:51.734 --> 00:00:56.195
And that's a pretty important thing to be
able to do these days as Linux usage is

21
00:00:56.195 --> 00:00:57.423
raising every year.

22
00:00:57.423 --> 00:00:59.310
Seeing more and
more server deployments and

23
00:00:59.310 --> 00:01:01.709
even a few more desktop
deployments that are out there.

24
00:01:01.709 --> 00:01:04.331
Now, a couple of neat things
about the certification.

25
00:01:04.331 --> 00:01:06.889
It is two exams, like Daniel mentioned.

26
00:01:06.889 --> 00:01:08.963
So it divides the topics in
half which is kind of nice.

27
00:01:08.963 --> 00:01:12.513
Makes it where you have a smaller set
of data to deal with for each exam, but

28
00:01:12.513 --> 00:01:16.237
the other thing is CompTIA developed
this in partnership with the LPI, and so

29
00:01:16.237 --> 00:01:18.207
you'll see like on their website here.

30
00:01:18.207 --> 00:01:24.728
Let me pull up CompTIA's website where
it's the CompTIA Linux+ powered by LPI.

31
00:01:24.728 --> 00:01:28.100
Now LPI, they're an organization
that makes Linux certifications.

32
00:01:28.100 --> 00:01:30.749
And when you get your CompTIA Linux+,

33
00:01:30.749 --> 00:01:35.089
you actually get your LPIC-1
certification at the same time.

34
00:01:35.089 --> 00:01:39.498
You get two certifications at once, and
so that's a neat little benefit here.

35
00:01:39.498 --> 00:01:42.689
It's the same set of exams, and
you kind of get double certifications.

36
00:01:42.689 --> 00:01:47.638
Now, the exams themselves are the LX-103
and 104, and those divide up the content

37
00:01:47.638 --> 00:01:50.650
like I said, and
they divide it up in a pretty neat way.

38
00:01:50.650 --> 00:01:52.703
Let me bring up the objectives here.

39
00:01:52.703 --> 00:01:55.710
So here's the exam objectives for
the LX0-103.

40
00:01:55.710 --> 00:01:58.844
It's the first part that
we cover in the series, and

41
00:01:58.844 --> 00:02:01.561
it focuses on introducing
you guys to Linux.

42
00:02:01.561 --> 00:02:04.135
So if you've never worked
with Linux before,

43
00:02:04.135 --> 00:02:06.254
it starts with system architecture.

44
00:02:06.254 --> 00:02:07.372
What is Linux?

45
00:02:07.372 --> 00:02:08.205
How does it work?

46
00:02:08.205 --> 00:02:09.485
What's going on under the hood?

47
00:02:09.485 --> 00:02:10.906
How does this thing even function?

48
00:02:10.906 --> 00:02:13.893
What is it that makes Linux Linux?

49
00:02:13.893 --> 00:02:17.043
And then it moves on to installation and
package management.

50
00:02:17.043 --> 00:02:21.533
How do I install the operating system,
and how do I add software on top of that?

51
00:02:21.533 --> 00:02:25.109
Because it's not gonna be terribly useful
unless I have some good software on there.

52
00:02:25.109 --> 00:02:28.217
Then we learn about our standard GNU and
Unix commands.

53
00:02:28.217 --> 00:02:29.939
So as we work with
the command line utilities,

54
00:02:29.939 --> 00:02:32.423
we've got a ton of programs we need
to know, we learn about those.

55
00:02:32.423 --> 00:02:36.791
And lastly, we talk about our hardware,
our file systems, devices, the hierarchy,

56
00:02:36.791 --> 00:02:39.046
how it kind of arranges
things in the system.

57
00:02:39.046 --> 00:02:41.223
So this is a fairly low level course,

58
00:02:41.223 --> 00:02:45.440
really focusing on the operating
system itself, getting it running on

59
00:02:45.440 --> 00:02:49.814
your computer and all the different
ways it interacts with the computer.

60
00:02:49.814 --> 00:02:52.772
Everything you need to know
to get started with Linux,

61
00:02:52.772 --> 00:02:56.903
that's the focus of the 103 exam,
and it's all divided fairly evenly.

62
00:02:56.903 --> 00:03:00.384
The command line is really where
the majority of the exam is based, and

63
00:03:00.384 --> 00:03:01.446
that's important,

64
00:03:01.446 --> 00:03:05.295
cuz we need that for the second exam where
we start to use all these utilities.

65
00:03:05.295 --> 00:03:10.049
Now, the second exam is the 104 and
let me just pull that up real quick.

66
00:03:10.049 --> 00:03:13.824
Here's the 104, and the exam
objectives are a little different here.

67
00:03:13.824 --> 00:03:16.993
Now, it shifts from how does Linux work?

68
00:03:16.993 --> 00:03:19.920
How do I get Linux running
to how do I use it?

69
00:03:19.920 --> 00:03:22.459
Now that I got it up and
running, what do I do with it?

70
00:03:22.459 --> 00:03:24.024
So how do we use the shell?

71
00:03:24.024 --> 00:03:26.359
How do we write scripts
to automate things?

72
00:03:26.359 --> 00:03:28.006
How do we manage our data?

73
00:03:28.006 --> 00:03:30.810
What kind of user interfaces and
desktops are available?

74
00:03:30.810 --> 00:03:33.165
What are my end users going to see?

75
00:03:33.165 --> 00:03:37.665
What are standard administrative tasks I
need to do keep Linux running smoothly and

76
00:03:37.665 --> 00:03:38.509
efficiently?

77
00:03:38.509 --> 00:03:41.598
That's where we make our money
by supporting these systems.

78
00:03:41.598 --> 00:03:44.685
Then essential system services,
this is where it deviates.

79
00:03:44.685 --> 00:03:46.839
It stops talking about Linux and

80
00:03:46.839 --> 00:03:50.680
starts talking about the services
we run on top of Linux.

81
00:03:50.680 --> 00:03:52.121
Do you want to run a web server?

82
00:03:52.121 --> 00:03:52.934
We talk about that.

83
00:03:52.934 --> 00:03:53.971
Want to run a mail server?

84
00:03:53.971 --> 00:03:55.007
A file server?

85
00:03:55.007 --> 00:03:56.895
We hit each of those kind of critical,

86
00:03:56.895 --> 00:03:59.496
essential services that
a company is going to need.

87
00:03:59.496 --> 00:04:00.980
Then we do networking.

88
00:04:00.980 --> 00:04:04.292
If you're deploying Linux, it is a network
operating system under the hood.

89
00:04:04.292 --> 00:04:07.264
So we need to understand how to get
those systems to talk to each other, so

90
00:04:07.264 --> 00:04:08.355
we spend some time there.

91
00:04:08.355 --> 00:04:12.927
And then lastly, what's probably
the most important section is security.

92
00:04:12.927 --> 00:04:15.262
How do we make sure that our
Linux installs are safe?

93
00:04:15.262 --> 00:04:19.774
The desktops are always pretty safe, but
the servers, those are big attack targets.

94
00:04:19.774 --> 00:04:22.170
There's hackers out there that
want to get into your system.

95
00:04:22.170 --> 00:04:23.897
So how do we make sure
that doesn't happen?

96
00:04:23.897 --> 00:04:27.630
And we talk about how to secure the files
and the networking on our systems and

97
00:04:27.630 --> 00:04:28.632
get those secured.

98
00:04:28.632 --> 00:04:34.330
So the second exam, the 104, is much more
about using Linux than the 103 exam is,

99
00:04:34.330 --> 00:04:37.570
which is more about getting Linux up and
running.

100
00:04:37.570 --> 00:04:40.545
But by dividing it in half like this,
it makes it easier for

101
00:04:40.545 --> 00:04:42.568
you to focus in on one particular area.

102
00:04:42.568 --> 00:04:43.990
Take that exam and pass it and

103
00:04:43.990 --> 00:04:48.035
then change your focus without having to
be distracted by too many crazy things.

104
00:04:48.035 --> 00:04:51.245
Now if you pass one exam,
you do not get a certification.

105
00:04:51.245 --> 00:04:54.962
You have to pass both exams to
get the Linux+ certification.

106
00:04:54.962 --> 00:04:58.477
And when you pass them both,
you also get the LPIC-1 certification.

107
00:04:58.477 --> 00:05:01.567
So you do have to pass both,
don't think you can just do one.

108
00:05:01.567 --> 00:05:04.564
They really are a pair, and
that's why here on ITProTV,

109
00:05:04.564 --> 00:05:08.008
you'll notice that our show is both,
the 103 and the 104.

110
00:05:08.008 --> 00:05:09.023
Now, we cover them in that order.

111
00:05:09.023 --> 00:05:12.070
We do divide it in half, but
we know you're gonna watch both.

112
00:05:12.070 --> 00:05:13.956
So we grouped them together,
you'll see them,

113
00:05:13.956 --> 00:05:16.397
you kind of move through them all and
then go and pass that exam.

114
00:05:16.397 --> 00:05:16.966
>> Awesome stuff.

115
00:05:16.966 --> 00:05:19.614
Now when you are ready to
take the exam should I say,

116
00:05:19.614 --> 00:05:23.938
you covered all the material, you watched
our videos, you think, you know what?

117
00:05:23.938 --> 00:05:25.339
I think I got this guy down.

118
00:05:25.339 --> 00:05:28.753
Don, what do we got to do to get signed
up for that exam so we can take it?

119
00:05:28.753 --> 00:05:32.653
>> Well, CompTIA uses Pearson VUE for
their testing exclusively.

120
00:05:32.653 --> 00:05:35.213
So you need to go to a Pearson VUE
center to be able to take that.

121
00:05:35.213 --> 00:05:37.834
Fortunately, they've got
centers all over the world.

122
00:05:37.834 --> 00:05:43.259
If you wanna find one, the website to
go to is vue.com, and it's V-U-E.com.

123
00:05:43.259 --> 00:05:45.392
And so I've got their
website pulled up right here.

124
00:05:45.392 --> 00:05:48.460
So this is Pearson Vue's website,
V-U-E.com.

125
00:05:48.460 --> 00:05:50.857
It actually redirects to pearsonvue.com.

126
00:05:50.857 --> 00:05:55.733
But once you're here, you can see this
link here that says, For test takers.

127
00:05:55.733 --> 00:06:00.027
And so you can go to the test taker web
page, and on the test taker web page,

128
00:06:00.027 --> 00:06:04.809
they've got where you can come in and pick
the program that you're looking for and

129
00:06:04.809 --> 00:06:06.908
then find a location to take a test.

130
00:06:06.908 --> 00:06:10.894
So if I come in and say that I'm
looking for a CompTIA exam, and

131
00:06:10.894 --> 00:06:15.428
it takes me to the official CompTIA
page and starts to tell me about it.

132
00:06:15.428 --> 00:06:17.967
And over here,
it gives me the chance to sign in and

133
00:06:17.967 --> 00:06:20.873
create a free account to then go and
sign up for the exams.

134
00:06:20.873 --> 00:06:22.009
Now, the exams are not free.

135
00:06:22.009 --> 00:06:24.697
When you login, it will tell you how
much they cost, cuz it's different for

136
00:06:24.697 --> 00:06:27.354
different countries, but the most
important part is this guy right here.

137
00:06:27.354 --> 00:06:28.978
Find a test center.

138
00:06:28.978 --> 00:06:33.591
You can choose that and find
a Pearson Vue testing center near you.

139
00:06:33.591 --> 00:06:36.659
So let's think of a city.

140
00:06:36.659 --> 00:06:37.451
>> Cincinnati.

141
00:06:37.451 --> 00:06:38.832
>> Cincinnati, you had to pick
one I don't know how to spell.

142
00:06:38.832 --> 00:06:42.164
>> [LAUGH]
>> Cincinnati, that's what Ohio?

143
00:06:42.164 --> 00:06:42.835
>> Yep.

144
00:06:42.835 --> 00:06:43.851
>> Cincinnati, Ohio.

145
00:06:43.851 --> 00:06:46.330
So we'll go ahead and search for
that, which I'm sure I spelled wrong.

146
00:06:46.330 --> 00:06:47.671
There we go.

147
00:06:47.671 --> 00:06:50.100
So here it pulled up Cincinnati, Ohio, and

148
00:06:50.100 --> 00:06:54.050
there's five Pearson Vue testing
centers right there in Cincinnati.

149
00:06:54.050 --> 00:06:57.053
And you can even pick small towns like
we're here in Gainesville, Florida, and

150
00:06:57.053 --> 00:06:58.743
Gainesville, Florida is a very small town.

151
00:06:58.743 --> 00:07:01.585
And so if I do a search for
Gainesville, Florida,

152
00:07:01.585 --> 00:07:05.935
you'll see that there's actually more
than one testing center here also.

153
00:07:05.935 --> 00:07:07.419
And so that's convenient.

154
00:07:07.419 --> 00:07:09.390
Actually, there's four
testing centers here.

155
00:07:09.390 --> 00:07:12.866
You'll find that a lot of
community colleges and

156
00:07:12.866 --> 00:07:18.898
even just private training companies will
have testing centers available for you.

157
00:07:18.898 --> 00:07:22.046
So there's just a lot of opportunity to
find one that's nearby, you can go and

158
00:07:22.046 --> 00:07:22.677
take the test.

159
00:07:22.677 --> 00:07:25.988
You don't sign up for
the test at the testing center.

160
00:07:25.988 --> 00:07:28.142
Don't go to the testing
center expecting to sign up.

161
00:07:28.142 --> 00:07:31.260
Make sure you go to the VUE website and
sign up there and

162
00:07:31.260 --> 00:07:34.114
then pick your testing center and
go and take it.

163
00:07:34.114 --> 00:07:39.104
And when you pass the exam, the testing
center sends those results up to CompTIA,

164
00:07:39.104 --> 00:07:44.110
and then CompTIA gets you a certificate
that shows you are now Linux+ certified.

165
00:07:44.110 --> 00:07:48.234
Now keep in mind that there are continuing
education requirements for Linux+ that you

166
00:07:48.234 --> 00:07:52.258
need to recertify every two years, or you
need to do continuing education credits.

167
00:07:52.258 --> 00:07:54.221
You continue to watch shows and

168
00:07:54.221 --> 00:07:59.064
attend other courses to get CE credits
to keep your certification current.

169
00:07:59.064 --> 00:08:02.031
You can't just take it once and forget
about it, you do need to maintain it.

170
00:08:02.031 --> 00:08:02.877
>> Awesome.
Now Don,

171
00:08:02.877 --> 00:08:06.284
is there anything else that we need to
know about the Linux+ certification exams

172
00:08:06.284 --> 00:08:09.609
specifically, or our series coming up
that you'd like to tell the audience?

173
00:08:09.609 --> 00:08:12.567
>> So the series, we cover all
the objectives for the 103 and

174
00:08:12.567 --> 00:08:14.018
the 104 certifications.

175
00:08:14.018 --> 00:08:15.053
So we knock them all out.

176
00:08:15.053 --> 00:08:17.736
We cover everything you need to know
to get in there and pass that exam.

177
00:08:17.736 --> 00:08:20.511
You may choose to supplement your
studies with a book if you want,

178
00:08:20.511 --> 00:08:22.285
there's plenty of great ones out there.

179
00:08:22.285 --> 00:08:25.970
Sybex has a wonderful Linux+ book you
can use, really good content there, but

180
00:08:25.970 --> 00:08:29.435
our video is designed to be pretty
all-inclusive to cover all those topics

181
00:08:29.435 --> 00:08:31.143
and to make sure that you're ready.

182
00:08:31.143 --> 00:08:34.927
We do have practice exams
available on the website,

183
00:08:34.927 --> 00:08:38.376
so we do practice exams
through Transcenders.

184
00:08:38.376 --> 00:08:39.311
There we go, I almost forgot.

185
00:08:39.311 --> 00:08:42.209
So you can get practice exams to make
sure that you're ready for it, but

186
00:08:42.209 --> 00:08:43.821
it's a pretty straightforward exam.

187
00:08:43.821 --> 00:08:45.284
There's no trick questions on this one.

188
00:08:45.284 --> 00:08:46.808
You either know the commands,
or you don't.

189
00:08:46.808 --> 00:08:47.680
You learn the content.

190
00:08:47.680 --> 00:08:48.899
You get in there and pass it.

191
00:08:48.899 --> 00:08:49.915
Definitely a great one.

192
00:08:49.915 --> 00:08:54.211
Once you're Linux+ certified,
if you wanna move beyond Linux+,

193
00:08:54.211 --> 00:08:57.109
it's a good idea to check
out the LPI website.

194
00:08:57.109 --> 00:08:59.525
The LPI guys, they have a ton
of other certifications too.

195
00:08:59.525 --> 00:09:03.975
CompTIA just has the Linux+ which again,
you really don't have any prerequisites.

196
00:09:03.975 --> 00:09:06.215
You don't need to have any
prior experience with Linux,

197
00:09:06.215 --> 00:09:07.942
you can just jump right in and
get started and

198
00:09:07.942 --> 00:09:10.010
learn everything that you
need to know to deploy it.

199
00:09:10.010 --> 00:09:11.310
It's really good stuff.

200
00:09:11.310 --> 00:09:12.082
>> Excellent, Don.

201
00:09:12.082 --> 00:09:13.646
Well, thank you so much for that synopsis.

202
00:09:13.646 --> 00:09:15.170
Hopefully, that worked out for you.

203
00:09:15.170 --> 00:09:19.237
And if Linux+ sounds like something
that's exciting, and it's entertaining or

204
00:09:19.237 --> 00:09:21.094
something you need to do, well then,

205
00:09:21.094 --> 00:09:23.723
we look forward to seeing
you in our upcoming series.

206

episodes.description: In this episode, Don and Daniel explain the basics of the Linux command-line interface (CLI) and some of the built-in CLI commands. They explain what a shell is and even give you some tips for maneuvering around your command history. Also discussed is the Linux manual pages (man pages) which are a set of basic help documents for CLI programs.

So I know I can get that list, and I know
I can pipe that into the rm command.

475
00:24:17.190 --> 00:24:21.534
And, I could maybe even add a little
more to that like -f to force it just in

476
00:24:21.534 --> 00:24:23.940
case they're re-homing or whatever.

477
00:24:23.940 --> 00:24:27.310
So if I were to run this it'll
delete all those files, and well,

478
00:24:27.310 --> 00:24:29.020
I'll get an error for that directory.

479
00:24:29.020 --> 00:24:30.420
I can't delete ./.

480
00:24:30.420 --> 00:24:31.990
But it can delete all these other ones.

481
00:24:31.990 --> 00:24:33.930
And it would delete those out and
wipe them out and

482
00:24:33.930 --> 00:24:36.280
that would be the end of this.

483
00:24:36.280 --> 00:24:42.406
Maybe a little more specific and
say that the name is file*.

484
00:24:42.406 --> 00:24:45.370
So I wanna delete any file that
starts with the word file that's

485
00:24:45.370 --> 00:24:48.100
also owned by dpezet, delete it out.

486
00:24:48.100 --> 00:24:50.990
Well, this command will work cuz there's
only a handful of files there, but

487
00:24:50.990 --> 00:24:53.530
if this is a script that
runs once a night, and

488
00:24:53.530 --> 00:24:58.980
then one day I have millions of files cuz
maybe I compiled my own Linux kernel.

489
00:24:58.980 --> 00:25:01.870
So you generate tons of
files when you do that.

490
00:25:01.870 --> 00:25:05.320
So, I run this and
the output from the find command,

491
00:25:06.430 --> 00:25:11.620
exceeds the size that the input for
rm can be well, that's a problem.

492
00:25:11.620 --> 00:25:14.700
So, I can leverage xargs to fix that.

493
00:25:14.700 --> 00:25:19.450
I can come in and I can say, I'll make
a little more room on my screen here.

494
00:25:19.450 --> 00:25:25.898
I can pipe that into xargs and then I
can say that I wanna do something like,

495
00:25:25.898 --> 00:25:30.150
well, I can just xargs rm -f.

496
00:25:30.150 --> 00:25:35.474
And if I do that, now, what it's gonna
do is xarge is gonna say go through,

497
00:25:35.474 --> 00:25:37.427
I don't really need the f.

498
00:25:37.427 --> 00:25:41.785
It's gonna say,
take the output from find, and

499
00:25:41.785 --> 00:25:47.111
run it once for line one, so
it'll run rm for file5.txt.

500
00:25:47.111 --> 00:25:52.680
And then it'll run rm again for show.sh,
and then it'll run rm again for file3.txt.

501
00:25:52.680 --> 00:25:54.910
It'll delete each one individually.

502
00:25:54.910 --> 00:25:58.530
So if you're worried about that memory
size, or maybe it's not even memory size,

503
00:25:58.530 --> 00:26:02.260
maybe you've got a command that
won't accept multiple files at once.

504
00:26:02.260 --> 00:26:05.931
I was telling Daniel before the show,
I had to write a script like this

505
00:26:05.931 --> 00:26:10.300
a few months ago that would convert text
files to PDFs, and that command would only

506
00:26:10.300 --> 00:26:14.070
accept one input file at a time cuz it
only did one output file at a time.

507
00:26:14.070 --> 00:26:17.868
So I couldn't just send 100
files to this PDF converter.

508
00:26:17.868 --> 00:26:20.690
I had to send it one file at a time and
I used xarg to do it.

509
00:26:20.690 --> 00:26:23.690
So it would feed it through and
run it once per file.

510
00:26:23.690 --> 00:26:26.800
Then when it runs, it goes through and
deletes them and that's the end of it.

511
00:26:26.800 --> 00:26:30.520
Now, I do need to tell xarg how
to know the difference between

512
00:26:30.520 --> 00:26:32.060
one line and the next.

513
00:26:32.060 --> 00:26:34.700
And you do that by
denoting the deliminator.

514
00:26:34.700 --> 00:26:41.130
And the deliminator, in my case is /n,
which is the new line symbol.

515
00:26:41.130 --> 00:26:44.980
So after each file there's a new line
symbol where it moves to the next line.

516
00:26:44.980 --> 00:26:47.870
And that's how it knows how to
separate the values that we're gonna

517
00:26:47.870 --> 00:26:48.620
be providing to rm.

518
00:26:49.620 --> 00:26:50.930
So I need to provide that.

519
00:26:50.930 --> 00:26:53.210
That should be all I need.

520
00:26:53.210 --> 00:26:57.470
And that right there should wipe
out any file that I own and

521
00:26:57.470 --> 00:27:01.040
let's see paths must proceed
expression file2.text.

522
00:27:01.040 --> 00:27:03.140
Apparently, I've got
a typo in here somewhere.

523
00:27:03.140 --> 00:27:05.080
So let's see.

524
00:27:05.080 --> 00:27:05.800
What did I do wrong?

525
00:27:05.800 --> 00:27:09.723
That's probably my file* notation.

526
00:27:09.723 --> 00:27:11.314
Let's just go with that.

527
00:27:11.314 --> 00:27:12.172
There we go.

528
00:27:12.172 --> 00:27:16.339
So I got an error when
it tried to remove ./.

529
00:27:16.339 --> 00:27:18.117
So you can't remove that.

530
00:27:18.117 --> 00:27:20.821
That's like a virtual or a logical entry.

531
00:27:20.821 --> 00:27:22.342
But everything else is gone.

532
00:27:22.342 --> 00:27:24.072
See all my files are gone?

533
00:27:24.072 --> 00:27:27.423
It found every file owned by Don Pezet,
and it went through and

534
00:27:27.423 --> 00:27:28.658
knocked each one out.

535
00:27:28.658 --> 00:27:30.736
But it didn't run rm just once.

536
00:27:30.736 --> 00:27:35.072
It ran rm once for every single file
individual, so it ran it about 12,

537
00:27:35.072 --> 00:27:37.860
13 times, however, many files are there.

538
00:27:37.860 --> 00:27:38.661
>> Very cool.

539
00:27:38.661 --> 00:27:41.747
Now there seems like there's a lot of
power behind these tools, so even though

540
00:27:41.747 --> 00:27:44.767
their very simple in their application,
you can do a lot of stuff with them.

541
00:27:44.767 --> 00:27:45.423
That rm command,

542
00:27:45.423 --> 00:27:48.586
you imagine running that against the root
directory with the super user privileges.

543
00:27:48.586 --> 00:27:50.785
>> [LAUGH]
>> You might be rebuilding a server at

544
00:27:50.785 --> 00:27:53.648
that point, so should be careful
with them as you implement them.

545
00:27:53.648 --> 00:27:57.445
Well, Don, I think we've about covered our
bases with streams and redirectors today.

546
00:27:57.445 --> 00:27:58.583
Anything else?

547
00:27:58.583 --> 00:27:59.385
>> Nah, I think that's about it.

548
00:27:59.385 --> 00:28:00.185
>> I think that's about it.

549
00:28:00.185 --> 00:28:03.122
Well, I guess that comes to
another great show by ITProTv.

550
00:28:03.122 --> 00:28:04.318
I hope you guys have enjoyed it.

551
00:28:04.318 --> 00:28:05.745
I've been your host, Daniel Lowery.

552
00:28:05.745 --> 00:28:06.824
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

553
00:28:06.824 --> 00:28:07.824
>> And we'll see you next time.

554
00:28:07.824 --> 00:28:12.758

WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000

2
00:00:32.993 --> 00:00:37.760
All right everyone, greetings and welcome

3
00:00:37.760 --> 00:00:40.460
I'm your host, Daniel Lowrie, and
here with me today is Don Pezet.

4
00:00:40.460 --> 00:00:41.270
How are you doing today, Don?

5
00:00:41.270 --> 00:00:41.960
>> I'm doing great.

6
00:00:41.960 --> 00:00:42.830
How about yourself, Daniel?

7
00:00:42.830 --> 00:00:43.960
>> Man, I cannot complain.

8
00:00:43.960 --> 00:00:47.830
We are jumping into this Linux+ class
that we're trying to teach you guys,

9
00:00:47.830 --> 00:00:49.950
get you schooled up in THE Linux cuz,
well,

10
00:00:49.950 --> 00:00:52.470
it does seem to be a bit of
a mystery to a lot of people.

11
00:00:52.470 --> 00:00:56.920
So hopefully we'll dispel a lot of that,
get you ready for that Linux+ exam, maybe,

12
00:00:56.920 --> 00:00:59.420
if you're trying to school yourself up for
that.

13
00:00:59.420 --> 00:01:01.880
And then jump in right
into that command line.

14
00:01:01.880 --> 00:01:05.300
That's a place where we gotta be from time
to time, especially if you're working in

15
00:01:05.300 --> 00:01:10.420
Linux you're gonna be a lot of seat
time behind that CLI, as it were.

16
00:01:10.420 --> 00:01:14.650
That being said, now we do need to
process some text every now and then.

17
00:01:14.650 --> 00:01:17.630
You're gonna always see a lot of text,
especially if you're in that CLI.

18
00:01:17.630 --> 00:01:18.270
Right, Don?

19
00:01:18.270 --> 00:01:21.040
>> Yeah, if you've been watching our
episodes in order you've already seen some

20
00:01:21.040 --> 00:01:22.330
of our command line episodes,

21
00:01:22.330 --> 00:01:25.840
and in Linux, part of the power that
you get with it is that it's so

22
00:01:25.840 --> 00:01:28.840
easy to administer your servers and
workstations from the command-line.

23
00:01:28.840 --> 00:01:31.460
You can write scripts to do all
sorts of phenomenal things.

24
00:01:31.460 --> 00:01:35.250
And the really cool part is when we
take the output of one command and

25
00:01:35.250 --> 00:01:38.180
feed it as the input to
another command you chain your

26
00:01:38.180 --> 00:01:41.860
commands together into a pipeline to
perform all sorts of cool actions.

27
00:01:41.860 --> 00:01:47.240
The problem is sometimes the output of
one command is not exactly the way we

28
00:01:47.240 --> 00:01:50.685
need it for that second command to receive
it, so we need to manipulate it a bit.

29
00:01:50.685 --> 00:01:52.445
And that's what this episode is all about.

30
00:01:52.445 --> 00:01:55.825
We're going to talk about how to
manipulate files in their content and

31
00:01:55.825 --> 00:01:58.785
command output to put it
into the right format for

32
00:01:58.785 --> 00:02:00.875
what we need for performance or action.

33
00:02:00.875 --> 00:02:03.905
Now, there's a ton of
commands that are built into

34
00:02:03.905 --> 00:02:07.085
darn near every Linux distribution
that can provide this functionality.

35
00:02:07.085 --> 00:02:08.675
Most of it is very, very old.

36
00:02:08.675 --> 00:02:10.520
It was created back in the Unix days.

37
00:02:10.520 --> 00:02:13.900
So some of this stuff we're going
to see is still on the exam and

38
00:02:13.900 --> 00:02:15.530
not necessarily relevant anymore.

39
00:02:15.530 --> 00:02:19.410
But a lot of it is stuff you'll use on
a regular basis to form that output.

40
00:02:19.410 --> 00:02:22.781
>> Yeah, a lot of times when you're
bumping around in the Linux in

41
00:02:22.781 --> 00:02:26.930
the CLI that output shows up on your
screen and you're like whoa there buddy.

42
00:02:26.930 --> 00:02:30.360
That's a lot of stuff,
how can I pare this down.

43
00:02:30.360 --> 00:02:32.640
How can I make it a little
easier to digest.

44
00:02:32.640 --> 00:02:36.850
Or maybe I just want to take that output
and not have it jump to my screen, or

45
00:02:36.850 --> 00:02:40.920
I need it to go to my screen into a file,
or put it into another command.

46
00:02:40.920 --> 00:02:43.080
Like Don was talking about,
grep it into something else,

47
00:02:43.080 --> 00:02:48.400
or just our pipe operator being able to
push that output into another command.

48
00:02:48.400 --> 00:02:52.100
Can become very helpful but
we gotta know how to do that, right Don.

49
00:02:52.100 --> 00:02:53.000
>> Yeah.
Now you are already

50
00:02:53.000 --> 00:02:56.330
technically manipulating text a little
bit whenever you run any command.

51
00:02:56.330 --> 00:02:58.425
So for example, let me just show you here,

52
00:02:58.425 --> 00:03:01.600
we'll bring up my little Linux box
that I have got on my machine here.

53
00:03:01.600 --> 00:03:04.550
When you run a command like LS
to pull up a directory listing,

54
00:03:04.550 --> 00:03:08.020
right, what it's doing is it's
pulling up a list of files and

55
00:03:08.020 --> 00:03:12.660
then it takes that list, it formats it
a certain way, and then it displays it to

56
00:03:12.660 --> 00:03:18.010
what's called the standard outer, STD out
and that's what you see on the screen.

57
00:03:18.010 --> 00:03:21.800
Now it looks like I haven't really
manipulated this text at all but

58
00:03:21.800 --> 00:03:24.160
the system has for me,
like it colorized it.

59
00:03:24.160 --> 00:03:27.350
See how it made my directories blue,
they're not normally blue,

60
00:03:27.350 --> 00:03:28.840
it's just done that for us.

61
00:03:28.840 --> 00:03:32.690
So Linux is always processing the text and
the output that we get.

62
00:03:32.690 --> 00:03:34.455
We can do the same thing
with files though.

63
00:03:34.455 --> 00:03:40.660
So for example in my documents folder
I've got a file called first, right?

64
00:03:40.660 --> 00:03:45.130
So here's this file called first,
and if I do more first.txt,

65
00:03:45.130 --> 00:03:49.330
I can see the contents of that file and
it's just data from the first file.

66
00:03:49.330 --> 00:03:53.740
And if I do more second.txt,
I can see it's got well,

67
00:03:53.740 --> 00:03:55.710
data from the second file, right?

68
00:03:55.710 --> 00:04:01.130
What if I wanted to combine the text
from those two files into one, well,

69
00:04:01.130 --> 00:04:02.690
combined file, [LAUGH] right?

70
00:04:02.690 --> 00:04:05.430
Well, we can do that
using the cat command.

71
00:04:06.440 --> 00:04:09.660
Cat, not like the animal,
it's short for concatenate.

72
00:04:09.660 --> 00:04:13.440
What it'll let you do is combine outputs
from more than one source to create

73
00:04:13.440 --> 00:04:14.920
a single output.

74
00:04:14.920 --> 00:04:21.530
So I can run cat first.txt second.txt.

75
00:04:21.530 --> 00:04:24.750
And that cat command is gonna
just combine those two together.

76
00:04:24.750 --> 00:04:29.540
And now I get data from first file, data
from second file as if it was one file.

77
00:04:29.540 --> 00:04:30.230
Right.
So quick,

78
00:04:30.230 --> 00:04:35.230
easy way to combine text like this and
it's doing it vertically, right?

79
00:04:35.230 --> 00:04:38.720
So I get the first file output, and
then the second file output, and

80
00:04:38.720 --> 00:04:40.240
if I had more, third file,
fourth file, and

81
00:04:40.240 --> 00:04:44.070
so on, they would each be just added right
there, vertically, one after another.

82
00:04:44.070 --> 00:04:45.580
So, cat, it's a good command.

83
00:04:45.580 --> 00:04:50.200
>> Now, there's another couple commands
that we can use to kind of try to get some

84
00:04:50.200 --> 00:04:53.160
things put together, like join,
that's also another good one for

85
00:04:53.160 --> 00:04:56.180
doing kind of what we're right here,
put those things.

86
00:04:56.180 --> 00:04:59.860
>> Yeah, join is really similar except
it's got a little bit of a variation.

87
00:04:59.860 --> 00:05:03.451
Notice I've got a few other files in
here that's like listing 1.1.text and

88
00:05:03.451 --> 00:05:04.270
listing 1.2.

89
00:05:04.270 --> 00:05:06.560
Let me show you what's in those.

90
00:05:06.560 --> 00:05:11.043
So if I look at listing1.1.text, right.

91
00:05:11.043 --> 00:05:12.450
I guess I have to spell it right?

92
00:05:12.450 --> 00:05:13.190
Oh, yeah.

93
00:05:13.190 --> 00:05:14.030
Periods instead of commas.

94
00:05:14.030 --> 00:05:14.820
There we go.

95
00:05:14.820 --> 00:05:18.000
I can see that it's got some employee
phone numbers and names, right?

96
00:05:18.000 --> 00:05:19.715
So here's my employee names,
their phone numbers.

97
00:05:19.715 --> 00:05:22.900
If I look at listing1.2.text.

98
00:05:22.900 --> 00:05:25.550
It's got the phone numbers and
what their status is,

99
00:05:25.550 --> 00:05:28.590
whether they're an unlisted number or
a listed number.

100
00:05:28.590 --> 00:05:34.020
Now if I were to cat these,
if I do a cat listing1.1.txt and

101
00:05:34.020 --> 00:05:37.445
1.2.txt It does it vertically.

102
00:05:37.445 --> 00:05:40.915
It displays the first file and
then the second file.

103
00:05:40.915 --> 00:05:45.815
But if I want to do it horizontally where
listing 1.1 text is on the left and

104
00:05:45.815 --> 00:05:48.647
listing 1.2 text is on the right.

105
00:05:48.647 --> 00:05:50.007
Cat can't do that, right?

106
00:05:50.007 --> 00:05:52.867
But I can use the join command,
and the join command can.

107
00:05:52.867 --> 00:05:54.687
It can do this horizontally.

108
00:05:54.687 --> 00:05:59.327
The join command is a little more complex,
actually it's not really all that complex.

109
00:05:59.327 --> 00:06:04.105
If we basically take these and feed

110
00:06:04.105 --> 00:06:08.810
them in just like I did just
a moment ago like that.

111
00:06:08.810 --> 00:06:09.950
See what it did?

112
00:06:09.950 --> 00:06:12.220
How now I've got it on the left and

113
00:06:12.220 --> 00:06:16.140
then on the right, and
now they're listed in order, okay?

114
00:06:16.140 --> 00:06:18.490
Now, I say that join is
a little bit more complex, but

115
00:06:18.490 --> 00:06:21.580
I ran it kind of the same way as cat.

116
00:06:21.580 --> 00:06:23.550
Well, notice there is a little variation.

117
00:06:23.550 --> 00:06:26.735
See how I've got phone numbers in the
first file and I've got phone numbers in

118
00:06:26.735 --> 00:06:29.734
the second file, but down here,
I've only got the phone numbers once.

119
00:06:29.734 --> 00:06:33.377
What the join command does, is it
actually looks at the data and is says,

120
00:06:33.377 --> 00:06:37.460
let me look at the very first field of
data, and that's what I'm gonna join on.

121
00:06:37.460 --> 00:06:40.360
That's the common, the unique value for
each of these entities.

122
00:06:40.360 --> 00:06:42.640
So it is actually doing some
field mappings in there.

123
00:06:42.640 --> 00:06:44.850
And that's why my phone
number only shows once.

124
00:06:44.850 --> 00:06:48.110
And if you look at
the join help file you'll

125
00:06:48.110 --> 00:06:52.570
see there's actually a ton of alternate
things that we can do in here with join

126
00:06:52.570 --> 00:06:55.220
to indicate what field we wanna map on.

127
00:06:55.220 --> 00:06:56.570
And how we wanna format that output.

128
00:06:56.570 --> 00:06:58.270
It's a very powerful command.

129
00:06:58.270 --> 00:07:02.790
But for the exam, basically what
you need to remember is that cat

130
00:07:02.790 --> 00:07:05.530
can join files vertically,
one after the other.

131
00:07:05.530 --> 00:07:10.460
Join can combine them horizontally,
one beside the other.

132
00:07:10.460 --> 00:07:14.224
And that's really useful for building
things like CSV files for bulk imports and

133
00:07:14.224 --> 00:07:15.061
stuff like that.

134
00:07:15.061 --> 00:07:17.745
>> Yeah.
Now, another similar command to the join

135
00:07:17.745 --> 00:07:21.983
and the cat is also paste as well, where
it actually puts in a tab delimiter, or

136
00:07:21.983 --> 00:07:25.570
something like that,
to kinda separate it out a little more.

137
00:07:25.570 --> 00:07:28.460
>> Yeah, it's one of those [LAUGH]
commands that I never really use.

138
00:07:28.460 --> 00:07:29.250
I'm aware of it.

139
00:07:29.250 --> 00:07:32.270
If you wanted to create
a tab separated values file,

140
00:07:32.270 --> 00:07:35.390
as opposed to like a common
separated values, you could do that.

141
00:07:35.390 --> 00:07:39.450
But very similar,
if we were to run paste, and

142
00:07:39.450 --> 00:07:42.730
then feed our files into it,
it would just combine those together.

143
00:07:42.730 --> 00:07:48.753
So if I take listing 1.1, and listing 1.2
and use paste, notice that it's got them.

144
00:07:48.753 --> 00:07:50.622

00:34:05.460 --> 00:34:10.230
I wanna look for either one of those and
give me that information back.

624
00:34:10.230 --> 00:34:13.700
And so now when I run it,
I was able to match both.

625
00:34:13.700 --> 00:34:16.610
And now that ifconfig command
normally just gives me a ton

626
00:34:16.610 --> 00:34:19.330
of visual output to deal with,
I get something much more simple.

627
00:34:19.330 --> 00:34:21.110
I get just the data that I need.

628
00:34:22.280 --> 00:34:24.920
So if I want to know what MAC
address is tied to what adapter,

629
00:34:24.920 --> 00:34:29.150
I can quickly spot that right here without
having to sift through everything else.

630
00:34:29.150 --> 00:34:30.394
And that's just one example.

631
00:34:30.394 --> 00:34:34.180
There's plenty of other ways that you can
use it, really kinda sky's the limit.

632
00:34:34.180 --> 00:34:35.977
For example, here I was looking for eno.

633
00:34:35.977 --> 00:34:39.340
So if I had more than one of those
network adapters, they would all return.

634
00:34:39.340 --> 00:34:42.040
Maybe I just want one that is eno16.

635
00:34:43.690 --> 00:34:45.670
And so I could come in and

636
00:34:45.670 --> 00:34:51.320
I could say I just wanna find lines
that have eno16 and that's it.

637
00:34:51.320 --> 00:34:53.686
And that's not much of a regular
expression right there.

638
00:34:53.686 --> 00:34:55.450
I'm not even using anything special.

639
00:34:55.450 --> 00:35:00.730
So I might wanna say only find eno16 when
it's at the beginning of the line, so

640
00:35:00.730 --> 00:35:03.192
any adapter that starts with eno16.

641
00:35:03.192 --> 00:35:06.080
And then there it is.
It finds it and it gets me that data back.

642
00:35:06.080 --> 00:35:08.170
And actually here's a great example for
us.

643
00:35:08.170 --> 00:35:11.935
See how I got my adapter is eno16777736.

644
00:35:11.935 --> 00:35:13.540
I've got repeating 7s.

645
00:35:13.540 --> 00:35:16.420
Let me show you that wild
card we talked about earlier.

646
00:35:16.420 --> 00:35:22.080
If I look for eno16*, anything that

647
00:35:22.080 --> 00:35:27.160
has the beginning of the line that's eno
followed by 16 and then an asterisk.

648
00:35:27.160 --> 00:35:30.320
If I run that, look at what it matches.

649
00:35:30.320 --> 00:35:33.910
So it matches eno16 and that's it.

650
00:35:33.910 --> 00:35:37.019
It doesn't match all this
other stuff that's over here.

651
00:35:37.019 --> 00:35:39.756
It's not lit up in red, so
I know it didn't match it, but

652
00:35:39.756 --> 00:35:41.020
it matched that eno16.

653
00:35:42.730 --> 00:35:44.851
So when I ran that,
it matched the base number.

654
00:35:44.851 --> 00:35:46.810
It didn't match the extended values.

655
00:35:46.810 --> 00:35:52.644
If I were to change that to
eno167 followed by a star.

656
00:35:52.644 --> 00:35:54.020
So eno167.

657
00:35:54.020 --> 00:35:58.726
Now it's looking for eno167 and
any repeating instances of that 7.

658
00:35:58.726 --> 00:36:03.140
Now it comes in, and
see how it matched all the 7s?

659
00:36:03.140 --> 00:36:05.350
That shows how it's the repeating 7s.

660
00:36:05.350 --> 00:36:08.102
And then if I run it again, and
I'll just stick a dot before it.

661
00:36:08.102 --> 00:36:15.130
So now I'm saying look for eno16,
I'll get rid of that 7, eno16.*.

662
00:36:15.130 --> 00:36:19.488
So I'm just gonna look for that, which
means eno16 followed by any character, and

663
00:36:19.488 --> 00:36:22.490
then it can repeat as
many times as it wants.

664
00:36:22.490 --> 00:36:25.740
And when I run that, see how it
matched the whole line that time?

665
00:36:25.740 --> 00:36:27.360
The whole line is lit up red.

666
00:36:27.360 --> 00:36:29.070
So it's just not repeating 7s.

667
00:36:29.070 --> 00:36:31.860
It's repeating any character and
the whole line matches.

668
00:36:31.860 --> 00:36:33.740
So that's that wild card
I mentioned earlier,

669
00:36:33.740 --> 00:36:35.630
kinda see it in action right here.

670
00:36:35.630 --> 00:36:36.850
>> Very cool stuff, Don.

671
00:36:36.850 --> 00:36:39.310
Now grep,
obviously a very powerful tool and

672
00:36:39.310 --> 00:36:41.800
something you're probably
gonna use quite a bit.

673
00:36:41.800 --> 00:36:45.460
But also another tool that regular
expression uses quite oftenly,

674
00:36:45.460 --> 00:36:46.692
which is sed, right?

675
00:36:46.692 --> 00:36:49.252
>> Yeah, Daniel, there's plenty
of commands to integrate this.

676
00:36:49.252 --> 00:36:51.150
I know I showed you guys
Sublime Text earlier, but

677
00:36:51.150 --> 00:36:54.840
even in the UNIX command line,
we've got things like sed.

678
00:36:54.840 --> 00:36:57.526
Sed, it stands for stream editor.

679
00:36:57.526 --> 00:37:00.970
It's a utility that's used to, well,
basically to edit text files, but

680
00:37:00.970 --> 00:37:04.350
not like what we normally think of,
where we have an interactive editor and

681
00:37:04.350 --> 00:37:05.700
we're the ones doing the editing.

682
00:37:05.700 --> 00:37:09.970
There's times where you might wanna write
a script and have a script open up and

683
00:37:09.970 --> 00:37:13.270
modify a text file or create a text
file and write things to it, and

684
00:37:13.270 --> 00:37:14.390
sed can do that.

685
00:37:14.390 --> 00:37:15.940
Sed can open up files and work with it.

686
00:37:15.940 --> 00:37:18.104
It's an editor that can be automated.

687
00:37:18.104 --> 00:37:21.010
We can have a stream of commands that we
throw at it and it can modify that text,

688
00:37:21.010 --> 00:37:23.430
and it doesn't really even care
where the text comes from.

689
00:37:23.430 --> 00:37:25.019
Sed's pretty powerful.

690
00:37:25.019 --> 00:37:27.902
There are entire books that
are written on sed, but

691
00:37:27.902 --> 00:37:30.930
just to give you guys kind of
a quick primer on it here.

692
00:37:30.930 --> 00:37:35.610
If you ever just run sed, it'll give
you some of the introductory syntax.

693
00:37:35.610 --> 00:37:38.710
But I find that this file doesn't
really show a lot of what we need.

694
00:37:38.710 --> 00:37:39.960
Because what you're gonna do,

695
00:37:39.960 --> 00:37:42.680
when you run sed you need to
provide some options for it.

696
00:37:42.680 --> 00:37:45.312
And let me tell you some
of the most common options.

697
00:37:45.312 --> 00:37:48.490
-i is probably one of the most common,
cuz you're inserting.

698
00:37:48.490 --> 00:37:50.462
And there's -a which is append.

699
00:37:50.462 --> 00:37:53.295
So -a, we wanna add something
to the end of a text file.

700
00:37:53.295 --> 00:37:55.977
-i, we wanna insert
something inside of it.

701
00:37:55.977 --> 00:37:59.285
We're actually editing the file and we can
go anywhere inside of it that we want, and

702
00:37:59.285 --> 00:38:00.290
so very powerful.

703
00:38:00.290 --> 00:38:02.310
And that's why we see
those two the most often.

704
00:38:02.310 --> 00:38:05.040
I usually use -a,
because I might have a script

705
00:38:05.040 --> 00:38:07.400
where I'm wanting to create a log file for
that script.

706
00:38:07.400 --> 00:38:09.550
And so I'll have various sed
commands throughout the script

707
00:38:09.550 --> 00:38:12.540
that are just appending to a log file and
writing you hey, I'm at this stage,

708
00:38:12.540 --> 00:38:13.910
I'm at this stage, I'm at this stage.

709
00:38:13.910 --> 00:38:16.010
And I get a record of that.

710
00:38:16.010 --> 00:38:17.394
So -i and -a are the most common.

711
00:38:17.394 --> 00:38:19.918
Some of the other ones
you might see out there,

712
00:38:19.918 --> 00:38:23.893
-r which is where you take the output
from one file and add it to another.

713
00:38:23.893 --> 00:38:26.000
You're basically combining files.

714
00:38:26.000 --> 00:38:30.169
You can use concatenate to do that also,
or cat, the cat command,

715
00:38:30.169 --> 00:38:31.518
but sed can do it too.

716
00:38:31.518 --> 00:38:34.243
And then we've got c,
which is to change text,

717
00:38:34.243 --> 00:38:36.790
which would be like a search and replace.

718
00:38:36.790 --> 00:38:42.180
And there's also s which is substitute,
where you can change text.

719
00:38:42.180 --> 00:38:43.580
They kind of sound the same, right?

720
00:38:43.580 --> 00:38:46.310
Well, s is the one that uses
regular expressions, and so

721
00:38:46.310 --> 00:38:48.260
that's the one that we're
normally going to use.

722
00:38:48.260 --> 00:38:50.890
If I want to open up a text file,
search for

723
00:38:50.890 --> 00:38:54.400
one string to replace it with another
string, I can use sed to do that, and

724
00:38:54.400 --> 00:38:57.580
I can make it part of a script and
it can just run and be done.

725
00:38:57.580 --> 00:39:03.640
So for example, here in my home directory,
I've got this little file called cal-2015.

726
00:39:03.640 --> 00:39:09.187
And if I look at what's in it,
it's a list of holidays from 2015.

727
00:39:09.187 --> 00:39:14.680
You'll see New Year's Day, January 1st,
Independence Day, July 4th, and so on.

728
00:39:15.720 --> 00:39:18.350
I might want to update these for
2016, but hey,

729
00:39:18.350 --> 00:39:20.480
these are holidays that
always occur on the same day.

730
00:39:21.640 --> 00:39:25.570
July 4th is always on the 4th of July or
Independence Day.

731
00:39:25.570 --> 00:39:27.200
New Year's Day is always January 1st.

732
00:39:27.200 --> 00:39:28.960
Halloween is always October 31st.

733
00:39:28.960 --> 00:39:30.870
So all I really need to do
is to take this file and

734
00:39:30.870 --> 00:39:33.820
swap out anywhere there's
a 2015 with a 2016.

735
00:39:33.820 --> 00:39:35.700
And I can do that myself.

736
00:39:35.700 --> 00:39:40.561
But maybe I want this to happen at
exactly 12:01 AM on January 1st,

737
00:39:40.561 --> 00:39:43.602
I want it to generate
this new calendar file.

738
00:39:43.602 --> 00:39:47.602
I could write a script and schedule it
with a cron job to run at that time.

739
00:39:47.602 --> 00:39:52.450
And in my script, I could use
the sed command to update that file.

740
00:39:52.450 --> 00:39:54.977
The syntax that I'm gonna use
here is pretty straightforward.

741
00:39:54.977 --> 00:39:59.262
What I'm gonna do is I'm gonna say sed and
then I'm gonna follow that with a -i,

742
00:39:59.262 --> 00:40:01.612
because I'm inserting text into the file.

743
00:40:01.612 --> 00:40:05.040
And then I need to tell it
what I'm gonna be doing.

744
00:40:05.040 --> 00:40:09.503
And the command I'm gonna run inside of
the editor is s, the substitute command,

745
00:40:09.503 --> 00:40:14.700
and I'm gonna look for anywhere there's
2015 and I'm gonna replace that with 2016.

746
00:40:14.700 --> 00:40:17.970
Now if I stop right here,
it's only gonna do the first occurrence.

747
00:40:17.970 --> 00:40:20.980
So I need to add a slash g to
the end to make that global.

748
00:40:20.980 --> 00:40:24.227
That way it'll get every instance
of if throughout the file.

749
00:40:24.227 --> 00:40:28.666
And the only other thing I need to
it is what file I'm working with,

750
00:40:28.666 --> 00:40:30.830
which is cal-2015.txt.

751
00:40:30.830 --> 00:40:32.770
And so when I run that it's
gonna crack open that file.

752
00:40:32.770 --> 00:40:35.040
It's gonna look for 2015 and swap it out.

753
00:40:35.040 --> 00:40:38.740
And because I did an s,
it allows me to use a regular expression.

754
00:40:38.740 --> 00:40:40.394
So I could've searched for anything.

755
00:40:40.394 --> 00:40:44.945
I could've done like 201 dot or
201 in a square bracket and

756
00:40:44.945 --> 00:40:48.130
then 0-9 in a closed square bracket.

757
00:40:48.130 --> 00:40:53.720
So now I'm looking for 2010 all the way
through 2019 and I swap that out.

758
00:40:53.720 --> 00:40:59.561
But when it's done,
that file now shows 2016.

759
00:40:59.561 --> 00:41:01.758
So it edited it,
opened it up, and changed it.

760
00:41:01.758 --> 00:41:05.697
So sed is another utility that's out there
that we can use regular expressions with

761
00:41:05.697 --> 00:41:06.428
and automate or

762
00:41:06.428 --> 00:41:10.100
script changes in our system without
us having to use an interactive editor.

763
00:41:10.100 --> 00:41:11.200
It's pretty powerful stuff.

764
00:41:11.200 --> 00:41:12.550
>> Yeah, very, very cool stuff too,

765
00:41:12.550 --> 00:41:15.400
because otherwise you would have
to open something like vi or

766
00:41:15.400 --> 00:41:19.490
nano or any of the other text
editing software, make the changes.

767
00:41:19.490 --> 00:41:23.790
It's starting to get a little processy.

768
00:41:23.790 --> 00:41:25.380
You have to go through a process.

769
00:41:25.380 --> 00:41:28.920
Here you just got one line, nice little
script there, using the sed editor,

770
00:41:28.920 --> 00:41:31.590
goes in there and makes your changes,
gets out, and you're done.

771
00:41:31.590 --> 00:41:33.776
Very, very simple, straightforward, and

772
00:41:33.776 --> 00:41:37.065
you can use the regular expression
to kinda do the hard work for you.

773
00:41:37.065 --> 00:41:40.487
You don't have to say we gotta look for
every version where there's 2015 and

774
00:41:40.487 --> 00:41:41.410
change that out.

775
00:41:41.410 --> 00:41:44.420
It does that for
you just by adding the regular expression.

776
00:41:44.420 --> 00:41:46.520
Don, a lot of cool stuff
when it comes to Regex.

777
00:41:46.520 --> 00:41:51.273
Again, we understand that it is a little
complex, it gets much more meaty.

778
00:41:51.273 --> 00:41:55.470
But what you've shown us today will
definitely serve anyone that's

779
00:41:55.470 --> 00:41:59.950
using a Linux platform, UNIX platform,
and very well, I would say.

780
00:41:59.950 --> 00:42:00.811
So thank you [CROSSTALK] for that.

781
00:42:00.811 --> 00:42:02.490
Is there anything else we
need to know about this?

782
00:42:02.490 --> 00:42:03.140
>> I think that's about it.

783
00:42:03.140 --> 00:42:06.350
I mean, just keep in mind that we barely
scratched the surface of the iceberg on

784
00:42:06.350 --> 00:42:08.460
this one, or the tip of the iceberg.

785
00:42:08.460 --> 00:42:12.460
There's a huge amount of information
here in Regex as well as in sed and

786
00:42:12.460 --> 00:42:14.430
other utilities like that,
so do your research on them.

787
00:42:14.430 --> 00:42:16.910
For the exam they want you to
have basic operating proficiency,

788
00:42:16.910 --> 00:42:18.640
which is what we've seen right here.

789
00:42:18.640 --> 00:42:22.140
But in real life land, you'll find that
you can do some really crazy stuff.

790
00:42:22.140 --> 00:42:22.700
>> All right, Don.

791
00:42:22.700 --> 00:42:24.940
Well, thank you so much for
explaining this to us.

792
00:42:24.940 --> 00:42:26.270
And thank you guys for watching.

793
00:42:26.270 --> 00:42:27.190
I hope you got a lot out of it.

794
00:42:27.190 --> 00:42:28.550
We're gonna go ahead and sign off.

795
00:42:28.550 --> 00:42:31.010
For ITProTV,
I've been your host Daniel Lowrey.

796
00:42:31.010 --> 00:42:35.175
>> And I'm Don Pezet.
>> And we'll see you next time.

00:00:15.074 --> 00:00:18.257
I'll be your host today, Daniel Lowry, and

5
00:00:18.257 --> 00:00:19.209

6

It's another wonderful
episode of CompTIA Linux+.

And in today's episode, we're gonna

9

of near and dear to my heart,
which is the vi editor, right?

10
00:00:29.231 --> 00:00:31.267
We're gonna take a look at creating and

11
00:00:31.267 --> 00:00:34.010
editing text documents
using the vi editor.

12
00:00:34.010 --> 00:00:38.756
And if you're not familiar with vi, it
is a command line editor that we can use

13
00:00:38.756 --> 00:00:43.297
that has been a part of the Linux and
Unix world for a very, very long time.

14
00:00:43.297 --> 00:00:46.424
It's not the original editor, right,
cuz there was Evelyn, and Ed, and

15
00:00:46.424 --> 00:00:47.128
all those guys.

16
00:00:47.128 --> 00:00:51.261
But it really is kind of
the defacto standard today.

17
00:00:51.261 --> 00:00:55.510
And I want to make sure I don't make
a mistake like we did in a previous show.

18
00:00:55.510 --> 00:00:57.298
Vi has been around a long time.

19
00:00:57.298 --> 00:00:59.411
It's not the most user
friendly of editors.

20
00:00:59.411 --> 00:01:00.781
I'll say that right now.

21
00:01:00.781 --> 00:01:04.020
Some voodoo magic that goes
into getting it to work.

00:01:04.020 --> 00:01:08.200
But, you can pretty much count
on it always being there.

23
00:01:08.200 --> 00:01:13.032
When you go from Distro to Distro, when
you go from CentOS, to Ubunto, to Mint,

24
00:01:13.032 --> 00:01:17.531
Arch Linux, whatever, you don't know
what editor's going to be there.

25
00:01:17.531 --> 00:01:18.877
Some of them have Nano.

26
00:01:18.877 --> 00:01:20.108
Some of them have Jed.

27
00:01:20.108 --> 00:01:22.987
Some of them have just
straight up EMACS or whatever.

28
00:01:22.987 --> 00:01:24.660
They have different ones.

29
00:01:24.660 --> 00:01:27.090
We can pretty always
count on vi being there.

30
00:01:27.090 --> 00:01:29.252
I used to say you can always
count on vi being there, and

31
00:01:29.252 --> 00:01:32.228
we had a viewer write in and say,
well, Don, that's not always the case.

32
00:01:32.228 --> 00:01:34.110
And sure enough, he was right.

33
00:01:34.110 --> 00:01:37.475
There's a couple of Distros that don't
package vi in, which is unfortunate.

34
00:01:37.475 --> 00:01:39.190
>> It'll be bad distribution.

35
00:01:39.190 --> 00:01:41.790
[LAUGH]
>> I wouldn't say they're bad.

36
00:01:41.790 --> 00:01:46.700
Sometimes, when they create distributions,
they try and provide you with the minimum

37
00:01:46.700 --> 00:01:51.142
software necessary for your need, and vi
or a text editor in general might not be

38
00:01:51.142 --> 00:01:54.654
needed, or they go ahead and
just stick with the old editor, or

39
00:01:54.654 --> 00:01:59.350
a really hardcore Distros that wants
to stick with the old unit standards.

40
00:01:59.350 --> 00:02:00.700
But I'll tell you,

it's a rare, rare day that I come

00:02:04.170 --> 00:02:08.110
Whereas, it's very common for me to run
across a system that doesn't have Nano or

43
00:02:08.110 --> 00:02:09.240
some other editor.

44
00:02:09.240 --> 00:02:11.498
So it's a good one to learn, right?

45
00:02:11.498 --> 00:02:13.648
Vi is very useful to learn.

46
00:02:13.648 --> 00:02:15.343
It's very integrated into the systems.

47
00:02:15.343 --> 00:02:17.316
A lot of the tools make use of it.

48
00:02:17.316 --> 00:02:20.145
So if you're gonna learn
only one text-based editor,

49
00:02:20.145 --> 00:02:22.322
vi is generally one that's recommended.

50
00:02:22.322 --> 00:02:25.956

00:13:56.167 --> 00:13:57.480

00:13:57.480 --> 00:14:02.770

00:14:02.770 --> 00:14:07.460

00:14:11.720 --> 00:14:14.330
Now, originally I just

00:14:14.330 --> 00:14:17.790

00:14:27.420 --> 00:14:32.730

00:14:42.640 --> 00:14:46.720
If I don't wanna use the command prompt

00:14:46.720 --> 00:14:50.600

00:14:50.600 --> 00:14:53.560
So if I wanna get rid of,

00:14:53.560 --> 00:14:58.550
I can just highlight that line and

00:14:58.550 --> 00:15:01.830

00:15:01.830 --> 00:15:03.260

00:15:03.260 --> 00:15:07.450

00:15:07.450 --> 00:15:08.460

00:15:14.450 --> 00:15:18.450

00:15:18.450 --> 00:15:23.540

00:15:33.260 --> 00:15:36.570

00:15:36.570 --> 00:15:38.700
>> Yeah, so basically you're

00:15:38.700 --> 00:15:42.710
If I just wanna that one single command,
I jump up, I do the dd or

00:15:42.710 --> 00:15:43.970
any other commands that work that way.

00:15:43.970 --> 00:15:48.070
But if I need to put some commands
together, maybe I want to delete a line,

00:15:48.070 --> 00:15:49.620
then save that and quit.

00:15:49.620 --> 00:15:53.157
I can do dwq or dx and

00:15:53.157 --> 00:15:54.419
>> Yeah, absolutely.

00:15:54.419 --> 00:15:57.506
Now, let's say that I'm
working with a file And

00:15:57.506 --> 00:16:00.836
I'm really just wanting to

00:16:00.836 --> 00:16:03.936
And I'm thinking about making a change and

00:16:03.936 --> 00:16:05.641
I really don't wanna make that change.

339
00:16:05.641 --> 00:16:07.801
So here I've deleted some lines
out of this file and I've said,

00:16:07.801 --> 00:16:11.700
you know I really don't want to make those

341
00:16:11.700 --> 00:16:14.530
Well, you can do :q.

342
00:16:14.530 --> 00:16:16.170
That's q to quit.

343
00:16:16.170 --> 00:16:19.558
But if I run that it gives me a warning,
No write since last change,

344
00:16:19.558 --> 00:16:23.100

345
00:16:23.100 --> 00:16:24.390
Now I've got a choice here.

346
00:16:24.390 --> 00:16:28.820
I can save and exit, but

347
00:16:28.820 --> 00:16:31.790
So what I need to do is I

00:16:31.790 --> 00:16:33.400
And notice how it says I can override it.

00:16:33.400 --> 00:16:36.030
I can add an exclamation

00:16:36.030 --> 00:16:42.670
If I do :q!, that means exit and don't

351
00:16:42.670 --> 00:16:44.560
So I'm gonna run that and now I'm out.

352
00:16:44.560 --> 00:16:47.480
I didn't save changes and
the file's back to the way it was.

353
00:16:47.480 --> 00:16:49.935
If I go and edit it again,

354
00:16:49.935 --> 00:16:54.998
It's a quick easy way to kind of revert
