355
00:16:54.998 --> 00:16:57.980
A couple of other neat little
tricks that we could do with vi.

356
00:16:59.180 --> 00:17:01.770
We've seen getting into insert mode and
getting out of it.

357
00:17:01.770 --> 00:17:05.500
We've seen saving the document or
canceling our changes.

358
00:17:05.500 --> 00:17:06.980
We've seen a couple of those.

359
00:17:06.980 --> 00:17:08.710
A few other things that we can do.

360
00:17:09.980 --> 00:17:11.580
Oh, with insert mode.

361
00:17:12.680 --> 00:17:15.780
In this file,
when I went into insert mode,

362
00:17:15.780 --> 00:17:17.590
my cursor was always at
the beginning of the line.

363
00:17:18.920 --> 00:17:21.490
If you move all the way out here, and

364
00:17:21.490 --> 00:17:26.050
you press that lowercase i,
I'm in insert mode, and I'm right here.

365
00:17:26.050 --> 00:17:28.460
Insert mode makes you insert
wherever your cursor is.

366
00:17:29.670 --> 00:17:33.210
If you enter the insert mode
by pressing a capital I,

367
00:17:33.210 --> 00:17:36.590
though, see how it jumped me
to the beginning of the line?

368
00:17:36.590 --> 00:17:39.420
Lowercase i is wherever your cursor is.

369
00:17:39.420 --> 00:17:43.390
Capital I is the beginning of
the line that your cursor is on.

370
00:17:43.390 --> 00:17:47.030
So that makes life a little bit easier to
be able to jump to a particular place in

371
00:17:47.030 --> 00:17:48.250
the line.

372
00:17:48.250 --> 00:17:51.195
Speaking of jumping to
a particular place in the line,

373
00:17:51.195 --> 00:17:53.699
have you ever run a script and
you get an error.

374
00:17:53.699 --> 00:17:57.330
It says error on line 53, blah blah blah.

375
00:17:57.330 --> 00:17:58.930
So you say, all right, well,
I need to go figure that out.

376
00:17:58.930 --> 00:18:01.360
Let me edit the script file and
let me find line 53.

377
00:18:01.360 --> 00:18:03.510
Well, how do I find line 53?

378
00:18:03.510 --> 00:18:04.452
You can take your cursor-
>> You count.

379
00:18:04.452 --> 00:18:06.500
[LAUGH]
>> You can count.

380
00:18:06.500 --> 00:18:07.960
There's a few different ways.

381
00:18:07.960 --> 00:18:09.730
Counting is the only one
you can ever count on.

382
00:18:09.730 --> 00:18:11.042
>> [LAUGH]
>> See what I did there?

383
00:18:11.042 --> 00:18:13.929
[LAUGH] So
it's the only one you can count on.

384
00:18:13.929 --> 00:18:15.330
But it would take a long time.

385
00:18:15.330 --> 00:18:22.395
If it's telling me line 612,
that's a lot of lines to count.

386
00:18:22.395 --> 00:18:27.410
Well, in vi, down here at the bottom right
of the screen notice these little numbers.

387
00:18:27.410 --> 00:18:28.714
Mine's got 2,1.

388
00:18:28.714 --> 00:18:31.610
That means I'm on line 2, character 1.

389
00:18:31.610 --> 00:18:34.640
Now I'm on line 3, character 8.

390
00:18:34.640 --> 00:18:39.765
That's a quick way to find out
where you are if something's

391
00:18:39.765 --> 00:18:45.212
telling you Expected an argument
at line 507 character 9.

392
00:18:45.212 --> 00:18:50.000
Now you can quickly go and find that and
save a little bit of time.

393
00:18:50.000 --> 00:18:51.780
There's a few other things we can do.

394
00:18:51.780 --> 00:18:53.320
You can turn on line numbers.

395
00:18:53.320 --> 00:18:55.960
By default,
vi doesn't display line numbers.

396
00:18:55.960 --> 00:19:01.650
But if you type :, I had to hit Esc
to get out to command mode again,

397
00:19:01.650 --> 00:19:04.890
hit : and type set number.

398
00:19:04.890 --> 00:19:08.490
Set number, when you do that,
see how it added the line numbers?

399
00:19:08.490 --> 00:19:10.400
That's kind of a neat feature to have.

400
00:19:10.400 --> 00:19:14.465
Now if it tells me there's
an error on line 53,

401
00:19:14.465 --> 00:19:18.750
I can jump right to line
53 thanks to having this.

402
00:19:18.750 --> 00:19:21.217
Let me give you another example.

403
00:19:21.217 --> 00:19:23.087
Whoops, let me get out of this file.

404
00:19:23.087 --> 00:19:29.034
Let's take something that has a lot of
output, and pipe that into a text file.

405
00:19:29.034 --> 00:19:30.219
There we go.

406
00:19:30.219 --> 00:19:34.396
And I'm gonna edit this file real quick.

407
00:19:34.396 --> 00:19:37.652
All right, so here's my dmesg output, and

408
00:19:37.652 --> 00:19:41.610
you'll see this file has
a lot of lines in it.

409
00:19:41.610 --> 00:19:46.060
Well, if I do a set number,
now I get the line numbers.

410
00:19:46.060 --> 00:19:48.890
And as I scroll through,
if I'm looking for a particular line,

411
00:19:48.890 --> 00:19:50.260
I know how to find it.

412
00:19:50.260 --> 00:19:55.470
But what if this thing has thousands
upon thousands of lines, and

413
00:19:55.470 --> 00:19:58.240
I need to jump to line 600?

414
00:19:58.240 --> 00:20:00.240
Well, I don't wanna sit here and
scroll through.

415
00:20:00.240 --> 00:20:04.010
Even using Page Up and Page Down,
it still takes forever to find 600.

416
00:20:04.010 --> 00:20:09.438
So what you can do is when you edit
a file, as a parameter if you say

417
00:20:09.438 --> 00:20:14.580
+600 like that, it's gonna say open
up dmesg.txt and jump to line 600.

418
00:20:14.580 --> 00:20:19.240
So we can tell vi exactly where
we wanna go in that file.

419
00:20:19.240 --> 00:20:22.210
And then if I turn on my set number

420
00:20:22.210 --> 00:20:25.225
I can see that my cursor is
indeed right here on line 600.

421
00:20:26.370 --> 00:20:27.680
Great for troubleshooting.

422
00:20:27.680 --> 00:20:30.161
You know you've got an error on line five,
jump right to line five.

423
00:20:30.161 --> 00:20:32.398
This is a great way to do it.

424
00:20:32.398 --> 00:20:34.725
All right,
I talked too long on some things so

425
00:20:34.725 --> 00:20:37.020
I'm running a little short on time.

426
00:20:37.020 --> 00:20:39.680
So let's talk about a few other things
that we can do while we're in here.

427
00:20:39.680 --> 00:20:41.450
Maybe we don't know what line we need.

428
00:20:41.450 --> 00:20:44.690
Maybe we want to jump to a line but
we don't know where it is.

429
00:20:44.690 --> 00:20:47.860
I'm trying to sift through
my dmesg stuff here and

430
00:20:47.860 --> 00:20:49.780
I'm trying to find some ACPI stuff.

431
00:20:50.990 --> 00:20:55.000
Well, what I could do is I
could edit that file and

432
00:20:55.000 --> 00:20:59.140
I could use the inline
search to find ACPI.

433
00:20:59.140 --> 00:21:01.850
The way you do an inline search
is you type a forward slash.

434
00:21:01.850 --> 00:21:05.200
When you type a forward slash,
it takes you to a special prompt.

435
00:21:05.200 --> 00:21:06.820
Colon would take me to the command prompt.

436
00:21:06.820 --> 00:21:09.460
Slash takes me to a slash prompt.

437
00:21:09.460 --> 00:21:11.630
And in the slash, we can do a search.

438
00:21:11.630 --> 00:21:15.030
And I can type ACPI and it's gonna jump me

439
00:21:15.030 --> 00:21:19.680
to the first instance of ACPI in that
file, so there it jumps right to it.

440
00:21:19.680 --> 00:21:23.760
And had I turned my numbering on I
would see I just skipped to line 604.

441
00:21:23.760 --> 00:21:27.410
I skipped way ahead in
the queue here to find this.

442
00:21:27.410 --> 00:21:32.420
And then I can type the letter
n to move to the next one, and

443
00:21:32.420 --> 00:21:35.050
n, so I'm just moving forward, n, n, n, n.

444
00:21:35.050 --> 00:21:39.240
If I do a capital N, it takes me to the
previous one, so I can scroll backwards.

445
00:21:39.240 --> 00:21:40.834
See how I'm searching backwards now.

446
00:21:40.834 --> 00:21:43.950
So you can go backwards and
forwards using the N key.

447
00:21:43.950 --> 00:21:46.950
Lowercase n to go forward,
capital N to go backwards.

448
00:21:46.950 --> 00:21:48.750
And that slash is what
let me do the search.

449
00:21:49.900 --> 00:21:51.670
We can also do replaces.

450
00:21:51.670 --> 00:21:53.138
Let me do another example here.

451
00:21:53.138 --> 00:21:56.650
All right, so here's a little
bit of Shakespeare for us today.

452
00:21:56.650 --> 00:21:58.450
We're going to be high
culture on this show.

453
00:21:58.450 --> 00:22:00.900
To be or not to be, that is the question.

454
00:22:00.900 --> 00:22:04.710
Let's say that I want to
replace every instance of

455
00:22:04.710 --> 00:22:08.800
the word to with T-W-O instead.

456
00:22:08.800 --> 00:22:10.648
You can do a search and replace.

457
00:22:10.648 --> 00:22:15.848
And if I want to do a search and
replace, the easiest way to do

458
00:22:15.848 --> 00:22:20.951
it is if you do :s/, or
I'm sorry, that's the search.

459
00:22:20.951 --> 00:22:23.879
When I did a / to search,
if I searched for the word to,

460
00:22:23.879 --> 00:22:26.653
that's actually shorthand for
running :s/to.

461
00:22:26.653 --> 00:22:29.615
It's really the same thing.

462
00:22:29.615 --> 00:22:31.765
They both work the same way.

463
00:22:31.765 --> 00:22:35.672
Actually, that just replaced my text,
there we go.

464
00:22:35.672 --> 00:22:38.662
But we can search and
replace things, and find them.

465
00:22:38.662 --> 00:22:41.402
When we do the slash notation
like I was just writing,

466
00:22:41.402 --> 00:22:44.152
we normally provide what
we want to replace it with.

467
00:22:44.152 --> 00:22:47.490
So if I wanted to replace
that text with T-W-O,

468
00:22:47.490 --> 00:22:49.230
I can provide a slightly longer command.

469
00:22:49.230 --> 00:22:53.760
I'm going to type :s/ and
I'm going to search for

470
00:22:53.760 --> 00:22:58.740
the word to, and then a slash, and
I'm going to replace it with T-W-O.

471
00:22:58.740 --> 00:23:03.058
Running this will search the entire file
for any instance of the word T-O and

472
00:23:03.058 --> 00:23:04.555
replace it with T-W-O.

473
00:23:04.555 --> 00:23:09.050
This is really handy if you're searching
for network configs that eth1,

474
00:23:09.050 --> 00:23:10.940
you want to change it to eth0.

475
00:23:10.940 --> 00:23:14.470
You can search and replace them and
when you run it, it's gonna get those.

476
00:23:14.470 --> 00:23:20.570
Now notice how it only changed the second
one, and the reason is where my cursor is.

477
00:23:20.570 --> 00:23:24.960
The default is it searches from
where your cursor is, forward.

478
00:23:24.960 --> 00:23:26.460
It doesn't go backwards.

479
00:23:26.460 --> 00:23:30.576
If we want it to go backwards too, we need
to add a little bit more to that command.

480
00:23:30.576 --> 00:23:36.119
We need to say %s/to/two.

481
00:23:36.119 --> 00:23:41.325
That % says search the whole file,
not just from where my cursor is.

482
00:23:41.325 --> 00:23:44.985
Let me repeat that example, and
I'm gonna move my cursor way down here so

483
00:23:44.985 --> 00:23:48.297
that you guys will see that
that's actually what's happening.

484
00:23:48.297 --> 00:23:51.535
%s/to/two.

485
00:23:51.535 --> 00:23:57.843
So search the whole file for any instance
of the word T-O and replace it with T-W-O.

486
00:23:57.843 --> 00:24:01.976
And there it goes, it replaces the whole
thing, so pretty neat way to go about it.

487
00:24:01.976 --> 00:24:04.720
What that percent is, is actually a range.

488
00:24:04.720 --> 00:24:08.580
Almost all of the vi
commands support ranges, so

489
00:24:08.580 --> 00:24:11.420
when you type colon,
even before you type the command,

490
00:24:11.420 --> 00:24:14.730
you can type a line range that
command is going to apply to.

491
00:24:14.730 --> 00:24:16.240
So if I wanted to do a search and

492
00:24:16.240 --> 00:24:19.630
replace and only have it apply
to a certain range of lines.

493
00:24:19.630 --> 00:24:20.940
Let me get back out.

494
00:24:20.940 --> 00:24:21.630
We'll do this again.

495
00:24:22.720 --> 00:24:26.580
I could come in here and say set number,
so I could see my lines.

496
00:24:26.580 --> 00:24:30.210
And maybe I just wanted to apply
the lines four through six.

497
00:24:30.210 --> 00:24:38.159
I could say :4,6 s/to/two.

498
00:24:38.159 --> 00:24:41.300
Now it's only gonna look
at lines four through six.

499
00:24:41.300 --> 00:24:43.230
And in lines four through six
if it finds the word T-O,

500
00:24:43.230 --> 00:24:46.400
it'll replace with T-W-O, and there we go.

501
00:24:46.400 --> 00:24:48.120
So those ranges are a great
way to limit it.

502
00:24:48.120 --> 00:24:50.680
And I did it with search and replace
cuz that's the way I normally do it.

503
00:24:50.680 --> 00:24:52.720
But it really works with
any of the commands.

504
00:24:52.720 --> 00:24:59.098
If you wanna delete some lines,
you could say :8,10d.

505
00:24:59.098 --> 00:25:02.560
Now it's not just gonna delete one line,
it's gonna delete lines eight through ten.

506
00:25:02.560 --> 00:25:05.440
So quick, easy way to delete ranges,
anything.

507
00:25:05.440 --> 00:25:06.580
You can insert ranges.

508
00:25:06.580 --> 00:25:08.480
You can do all sorts of
crazy stuff with it.

509
00:25:08.480 --> 00:25:09.420
It's a pretty powerful command.

510
00:25:11.020 --> 00:25:11.540
Let's see.

511
00:25:11.540 --> 00:25:14.270
What else do I wanna tackle here in
the last few moments that we've got?

512
00:25:15.860 --> 00:25:20.490
We saw deleting lines, oh, so, I've had
to run that set number more than once.

513
00:25:21.780 --> 00:25:25.551
If there's something like that, that you
want to keep permanent inside of vi.

514
00:25:25.551 --> 00:25:29.110
Unfortunately, those set commands,
they get wiped out every time you exit vi.

515
00:25:29.110 --> 00:25:31.292
Vi does keep a configuration file.

516
00:25:31.292 --> 00:25:35.340
If I get out of this and
go back to my home directory.

517
00:25:35.340 --> 00:25:37.772
So, here I am in /home/dpezet.

518
00:25:37.772 --> 00:25:41.270
If you poke around in your home directory,
there's a lot of hidden files.

519
00:25:41.270 --> 00:25:45.974
And, there might be a file called .vimrc.

520
00:25:45.974 --> 00:25:49.385
And that's the vi editor's
configuration file.

521
00:25:49.385 --> 00:25:53.020
And you can put commands in
there that will be a part of vi,

522
00:25:53.020 --> 00:25:55.555
that'll actually happen
every time that you run it.

523
00:25:55.555 --> 00:26:00.120
So if I want this set number
to always be present.

524
00:26:00.120 --> 00:26:02.284
I can edit that file and
I'll use vi to edit it.

525
00:26:02.284 --> 00:26:06.673
So I'm gonna edit tube /.vimrc,
and the file doesn't exist, so

526
00:26:06.673 --> 00:26:12.140
I'm effectively creating it, and I'm just
gonna type in there, set, number, so

527
00:26:12.140 --> 00:26:17.376
that it'll know, hey, every time you run,
I want you to display line numbers.

528
00:26:17.376 --> 00:26:19.680
And we'll go ahead and save that.

529
00:26:19.680 --> 00:26:22.120
Now, vi will use that
configuration file and

530
00:26:22.120 --> 00:26:23.680
it's been a while since I've done this.

531
00:26:23.680 --> 00:26:26.170
So I can't remember if it takes
affect without logging out.

532
00:26:26.170 --> 00:26:28.260
Some of these things, you have to
log out and log back in for it.

533
00:26:28.260 --> 00:26:29.930
Let's do a test.

534
00:26:29.930 --> 00:26:34.860
So, I'll get back into my documents and
I'm gonna edit that Shakespeare file.

535
00:26:34.860 --> 00:26:36.230
Didn't have to log out.

536
00:26:36.230 --> 00:26:37.960
Line numbers are automatically there.

537
00:26:37.960 --> 00:26:41.580
So, if you wanna tweak the behavior of vi,
you can do that.

538
00:26:41.580 --> 00:26:44.430
It's easy enough and
you can set that in your vimrc file and

539
00:26:44.430 --> 00:26:46.930
that'll take place every
time you run the editor.

540
00:26:46.930 --> 00:26:50.940
>> Yeah, obviously vi is a very powerful
tool giving you a lot of options.

541
00:26:50.940 --> 00:26:52.670
You get a wrangle on this thing.

542
00:26:52.670 --> 00:26:56.670
You're definitely gonna be really set for
editing text files, doing HTML,

543
00:26:56.670 --> 00:27:00.130
any kind of long form stuff,
this is really gonna be helpful.

544
00:27:00.130 --> 00:27:01.120
And when you're working in Linux,

545
00:27:01.120 --> 00:27:05.530
you tend to write scripts a lot, that's
really when it shines and shows its color.

546
00:27:05.530 --> 00:27:08.400
So, that being said, it's an awesome tool.

547
00:27:08.400 --> 00:27:14.240
>> Yeah, and I tell you, if you're working
on like a Linux server in Amazon EC2,

548
00:27:14.240 --> 00:27:17.790
and it's got no GUI, and
you just SSH into the thing,

549
00:27:17.790 --> 00:27:20.840
you're gonna need to rely on some
kind of command line text editor.

550
00:27:20.840 --> 00:27:22.390
You will have to use it.

551
00:27:22.390 --> 00:27:24.160
I encourage you to learn vi.

552
00:27:24.160 --> 00:27:25.100
There's other ones out there,

553
00:27:25.100 --> 00:27:28.880
like nano's really prevalent these days,
but vi is the one you can count on.

554
00:27:28.880 --> 00:27:31.380
So if you have to pick one this is
the one that I encourage to use.

555
00:27:32.650 --> 00:27:34.860
It's just a really good skill to have.

556
00:27:34.860 --> 00:27:38.680
So, in this episode,
we saw some of the basic commands.

557
00:27:38.680 --> 00:27:40.510
This stuff can be basically proficient.

558
00:27:40.510 --> 00:27:42.460
Open a file, search and find text,

559
00:27:42.460 --> 00:27:46.590
replace if you need it, edit the text,
save the file and get out of the thing.

560
00:27:46.590 --> 00:27:50.640
That's really the bare minimum you
need to know to get around in vi, but

561
00:27:50.640 --> 00:27:52.230
there's a ton more out there so

562
00:27:52.230 --> 00:27:55.630
if you wanna learn more go out there's
a ton of web tutorials that are out there.

563
00:27:55.630 --> 00:27:58.143
We should do a video series
just on vi at some point.

564
00:27:58.143 --> 00:27:59.637
We say that about a lot
of technologies though.

565
00:27:59.637 --> 00:28:01.090
>> Yeah, we do.
[LAUGH]

566
00:28:01.090 --> 00:28:02.750
>> There's only so much time in the day.

567
00:28:02.750 --> 00:28:05.190
But for what we need to know for
the Linux+ exam,

568
00:28:05.190 --> 00:28:07.680
I think we've seen the basics and
that's a pretty good wrap up.

569
00:28:07.680 --> 00:28:08.310
>> Yeah.

570
00:28:08.310 --> 00:28:08.900
All right, Don.
Well,

571
00:28:08.900 --> 00:28:11.250
it looks like we've come to
the end of another great show.

572
00:28:11.250 --> 00:28:14.870
Signing off for ITProTV,
I've been your host Daniel Lowery.

573
00:28:14.870 --> 00:28:15.760
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

574
00:28:15.760 --> 00:28:16.945
>> And we'll see you next time.

575
00:28:16.945 --> 00:28:22.740
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode, Don and Daniel continue with their showcase of the vi(m) text editor in Linux. They pick back up by exploring some other common commands and features intrinsic to the vi(m) editor. This includes things like searching and navigating text, appending and deleting, and saving changes.
episodes.title: Editing Files with vi Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.399 --> 00:00:16.321
All right, greetings everyone, and welcome
to another great episode of ITProTV.

3
00:00:16.321 --> 00:00:19.090
I'm your host, Daniel Lowrie,
and in today's episode,

4
00:00:19.090 --> 00:00:21.880
we are continuing on
with our Linux+ series.

5
00:00:21.880 --> 00:00:24.540
Joining me in the studio today is
our good friend, Mr. Don Pezet.

6
00:00:24.540 --> 00:00:27.050
Don, welcome back to the show sir,
how are ya?

7
00:00:27.050 --> 00:00:27.730
>> Doing great Daniel.

8
00:00:27.730 --> 00:00:29.220
Thanks for having me back and

9
00:00:29.220 --> 00:00:34.690
ready to continue our adventure of
working with the vi Unix editor.

10
00:00:34.690 --> 00:00:37.530
The command line editing
we can always count on.

11
00:00:37.530 --> 00:00:38.550
I say we can always count on it.

12
00:00:38.550 --> 00:00:41.780
It's available in most distros that we
can use to open up and our work files.

13
00:00:41.780 --> 00:00:45.200
We spent the last episode kinda
introducing you to it, showing you a lot

14
00:00:45.200 --> 00:00:48.910
of the commands, really everything you
need to get by on a day to day basis.

15
00:00:48.910 --> 00:00:50.920
But in this episode I wanna
go a little bit further and

16
00:00:50.920 --> 00:00:53.660
show some more commands that
might turn up on the exam.

17
00:00:53.660 --> 00:00:54.920
Some of these you may use a lot.

18
00:00:54.920 --> 00:00:56.160
Some of these you may never use.

19
00:00:56.160 --> 00:00:58.610
But we need to cover them just to make
sure that you're prepared for the exam.

20
00:00:58.610 --> 00:01:00.430
So we're gonna get a chance
to see those here.

21
00:01:00.430 --> 00:01:02.310
So more vi action coming up.

22
00:01:02.310 --> 00:01:05.220
>> That's right,
the vi editor is a great editor.

23
00:01:05.220 --> 00:01:09.830
I guarantee if you poll nine out of
ten Linux users that are probably

24
00:01:09.830 --> 00:01:14.990
at least vi proficient if not vi
endorsers, like yeah, vi is the way to go.

25
00:01:14.990 --> 00:01:15.680
There's been Emacs.

26
00:01:15.680 --> 00:01:18.190
There's been others as well, and there's
some new ones coming down the pipe.

27
00:01:18.190 --> 00:01:19.130
I like Nano.

28
00:01:19.130 --> 00:01:20.210
But vi?

29
00:01:20.210 --> 00:01:20.860
It's always there.

30
00:01:20.860 --> 00:01:22.130
It's a tried and true friend.

31
00:01:22.130 --> 00:01:26.470
Like Don said, on almost every
distribution that you install or use, it's

32
00:01:26.470 --> 00:01:30.260
probably going to have vi there waiting
for you like an old comfortable blanket.

33
00:01:30.260 --> 00:01:31.280
Just wrap it around you.

34
00:01:31.280 --> 00:01:33.300
That being said we did talk
about some of the basics but

35
00:01:33.300 --> 00:01:34.580
now we got to take it up a level.

36
00:01:34.580 --> 00:01:39.260
We need to bump it up so that you can
be that proficient user of vi itself.

37
00:01:39.260 --> 00:01:40.560
So Don, where do we begin?

38
00:01:40.560 --> 00:01:43.300
>> All right, well let's start with
a little bit of search technique.

39
00:01:43.300 --> 00:01:46.020
So when we open up a file in vi,

40
00:01:46.020 --> 00:01:49.460
sometimes we're going in to edit
a particular line or a particular entry.

41
00:01:49.460 --> 00:01:52.270
And so we wanna search and
find that so we can get to work.

42
00:01:52.270 --> 00:01:53.530
So let me show you that.

43
00:01:53.530 --> 00:01:54.060
So here I am.

44
00:01:54.060 --> 00:01:56.270
I'm on a CentOS 7 box.

45
00:01:56.270 --> 00:02:01.500
Well let me make sure I'm not lying to you
that I am indeed on a, yeah, CentOS 7.2.

46
00:02:01.500 --> 00:02:05.800
And I've got vi installed, and
I'm going to be jumping in here to

47
00:02:05.800 --> 00:02:09.470
basically just kinda see
the contents of a file.

48
00:02:09.470 --> 00:02:11.970
I've got the Raven by Edgar Allen Poe.

49
00:02:11.970 --> 00:02:14.270
I'm going a little literary classic here.

50
00:02:14.270 --> 00:02:19.450
That I'm gonna open up, and
it's kind of a decent sized file.

51
00:02:19.450 --> 00:02:22.920
There's a lot of stuff kinda
spread out through here, and

52
00:02:22.920 --> 00:02:28.260
I want to basically look in here and find
something so I can edit it or change it.

53
00:02:28.260 --> 00:02:33.020
So if you've ever read this poem, it's not
the most enlightening and uplifting poem,

54
00:02:33.020 --> 00:02:37.540
but there's a lot of stuff in here and
I want to look for Lenore.

55
00:02:37.540 --> 00:02:40.120
He's always talking about this
Lenore old lady, whoever she is.

56
00:02:40.120 --> 00:02:41.980
So I wanna look in here and find it.

57
00:02:41.980 --> 00:02:45.200
Well, you can hit the forward slash key.

58
00:02:45.200 --> 00:02:48.140
So right now, I've got the file open and

59
00:02:48.140 --> 00:02:51.590
I'm in command mode where
I can type commands in.

60
00:02:51.590 --> 00:02:53.520
And we know that there's three
different modes that we've got.

61
00:02:53.520 --> 00:02:56.740
We've got the insert mode,
where we're actually inserting text and

62
00:02:56.740 --> 00:02:57.980
working with the system.

63
00:02:57.980 --> 00:03:00.635
And then we've got the first command mode
which is what I'm in right now where

64
00:03:00.635 --> 00:03:03.230
you can just type a single letter and
something happens.

65
00:03:03.230 --> 00:03:04.600
Or you can type a colon,

66
00:03:04.600 --> 00:03:07.850
and you go into the second command mode
where you can do the advance stuff.

67
00:03:07.850 --> 00:03:11.730
Well searching is just a simple command so
I can just be in the regular mode, and

68
00:03:11.730 --> 00:03:14.390
I can type a forward slash and

69
00:03:14.390 --> 00:03:17.400
my prompt updates down here
to show that forward slash.

70
00:03:17.400 --> 00:03:19.400
And now I can type in a word to look for.

71
00:03:19.400 --> 00:03:21.970
So I can look for Lenore.

72
00:03:21.970 --> 00:03:24.800
Now when I do that, it's gonna start
from wherever my cursor is, and

73
00:03:24.800 --> 00:03:26.970
it's gonna search past that.

74
00:03:26.970 --> 00:03:30.800
And it is case sensitive, so
I'm looking for Lenore with a capital L.

75
00:03:30.800 --> 00:03:33.960
And it's gonna go out and
try and find that.

76
00:03:33.960 --> 00:03:38.260
And I'll see that my cursor has
now jumped to right here, and

77
00:03:38.260 --> 00:03:40.440
it's found the first instance of Lenore.

78
00:03:41.450 --> 00:03:45.210
Now I can see there's another
instance of Lenore right after that.

79
00:03:45.210 --> 00:03:48.520
And if I wanna keep searching, maybe
this isn't the one I was looking for,

80
00:03:48.520 --> 00:03:49.920
I'm looking for a different one.

81
00:03:49.920 --> 00:03:55.470
What I can do is I can just do
a forward slash and press enter.

82
00:03:55.470 --> 00:04:00.340
And see how every time I do forward slash
it just continues to search for Lenore.

83
00:04:00.340 --> 00:04:02.690
I'm not typing the word Lenore again.

84
00:04:02.690 --> 00:04:03.980
I'm just hitting forward slash and enter,

85
00:04:03.980 --> 00:04:06.790
and it knows to repeat
the search that I just did.

86
00:04:08.010 --> 00:04:11.260
Now that forward slash searches forward.

87
00:04:11.260 --> 00:04:12.940
If I want to search backward,

88
00:04:12.940 --> 00:04:15.763
well you'd think a backslash would be
a really cool short cut, but it's not.

89
00:04:15.763 --> 00:04:16.409
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

90
00:04:16.409 --> 00:04:17.380
>> If I want to search backwards,

91
00:04:17.380 --> 00:04:19.320
it's actually a question mark.

92
00:04:19.320 --> 00:04:21.640
So if I know that it's
something that occurred before.

93
00:04:21.640 --> 00:04:24.160
So maybe I want to look for the word lamp.

94
00:04:24.160 --> 00:04:26.520
And I know the word lamp
occurred before this.

95
00:04:26.520 --> 00:04:30.200
I can do a question mark,
and type in lamp.

96
00:04:31.500 --> 00:04:33.030
And now it's going to search backwards.

97
00:04:34.030 --> 00:04:36.790
And I continue to type question mark and
press enter, and

98
00:04:36.790 --> 00:04:40.500
it's gonna continue to search
backwards until we hit the top.

99
00:04:40.500 --> 00:04:42.710
So here it says it hit the top, and
now it's continuing at the bottom and

100
00:04:42.710 --> 00:04:43.810
starting over again.

101
00:04:43.810 --> 00:04:47.990
So forward slash to search forward,
question mark to search back.

102
00:04:47.990 --> 00:04:51.230
Quick and easy way to find what it is
you're looking for inside of a document.

103
00:04:51.230 --> 00:04:53.090
>> Yeah,
obviously that's going to be very helpful,

104
00:04:53.090 --> 00:04:56.510
especially with documents that
have a lot of content in them.

105
00:04:56.510 --> 00:04:59.740
You need to be able to find something,
[COUGH] excuse me, really quickly.

106
00:04:59.740 --> 00:05:02.740
Searching forward or
back is gonna be your go-to item.

107
00:05:02.740 --> 00:05:05.860
But that's not the only way we can
navigate throughout the vi system.

108
00:05:05.860 --> 00:05:07.780
There is other ways we can navigate on.

109
00:05:07.780 --> 00:05:09.990
>> Yeah.
Now I use the arrow keys a lot.

110
00:05:09.990 --> 00:05:12.340
So the arrow keys on my keyboard,
if I start pressing them,

111
00:05:12.340 --> 00:05:16.480
I can hit the up arrow to move my
cursor up, the down arrow to move down,

112
00:05:16.480 --> 00:05:18.800
right arrow to move right,
left arrow to move left.

113
00:05:18.800 --> 00:05:22.180
And if you're sitting at a terminal or
if you're SSH'd in,

114
00:05:22.180 --> 00:05:24.690
that's normally not a problem.

115
00:05:24.690 --> 00:05:28.180
But if you're connected to a server
by a serial cable for example, or

116
00:05:28.180 --> 00:05:30.560
if you're going through some
kind of terminal emulator,

117
00:05:30.560 --> 00:05:33.580
there's a lot of times where
your arrow keys may not work.

118
00:05:33.580 --> 00:05:36.470
And if the arrow keys don't work,
if you're not able to move up, down, left,

119
00:05:36.470 --> 00:05:39.650
right using the arrow keys,
there's actually keyboard shortcuts you

120
00:05:39.650 --> 00:05:42.665
can use that are tied to letters instead
because the letters always work.

121
00:05:42.665 --> 00:05:45.640
Then so we've got H, J, K, and L.

122
00:05:45.640 --> 00:05:49.370
If you're on a US keyboard and you look
at the keyboard, you'll see H, J, K,

123
00:05:49.370 --> 00:05:51.836
and L are all lined up
right next to each other.

124
00:05:51.836 --> 00:05:55.470
And if you press them,
you'll see they go different ways.

125
00:05:55.470 --> 00:05:59.710
So H and L, H is left, L is right.

126
00:05:59.710 --> 00:06:03.500
And so I'm just tapping H and
L on my keyboard to mover left and right.

127
00:06:03.500 --> 00:06:07.450
And then we've got J for
down and K for up.

128
00:06:07.450 --> 00:06:10.630
And so
I can use these letters to navigate around

129
00:06:10.630 --> 00:06:13.080
just like the arrow keys that we use.

130
00:06:13.080 --> 00:06:17.430
So there's no difference in function
except some terminals don't support

131
00:06:17.430 --> 00:06:20.340
the arrow keys, and
that's why we need to have these letters.

132
00:06:20.340 --> 00:06:23.960
Now remember,
vi was created a long time ago.

133
00:06:23.960 --> 00:06:26.740
And back then, keyboards were not as
consistent as they are today, and

134
00:06:26.740 --> 00:06:29.440
plenty of people had keyboards
that did not have arrow keys.

135
00:06:29.440 --> 00:06:32.370
It just wasn't even on the physical
keyboard, and so this is useful there.

136
00:06:32.370 --> 00:06:34.770
But then terminal emulation
software also got in the way.

137
00:06:34.770 --> 00:06:36.850
And I see this with serial
port connections all the time.

138
00:06:36.850 --> 00:06:38.690
If you're connected on a serial TTY,

139
00:06:38.690 --> 00:06:42.230
you may not have arrow keys so
definitely a useful one.

140
00:06:42.230 --> 00:06:45.040
>> Very cool.
That's a very handy thing to know,

141
00:06:45.040 --> 00:06:47.600
because hey,
you never know when you're serialed in.

142
00:06:47.600 --> 00:06:50.270
We do this quite often,
especially with Linux type systems.

143
00:06:50.270 --> 00:06:52.440
You tend to do things
the old way because well,

144
00:06:52.440 --> 00:06:54.450
it's still very useful
inside of that system.

145
00:06:54.450 --> 00:06:57.570
So it's good to have a backup
plan in case your keyboard or

146
00:06:57.570 --> 00:06:59.480
whatever is not working
the way you expect it.

147
00:06:59.480 --> 00:07:03.470
Now also, here's something that I've
found that can be a little frustrating.

148
00:07:03.470 --> 00:07:06.630
It's all about where
the characters are being inserted.

149
00:07:06.630 --> 00:07:08.970
You're trying to put text into, and

150
00:07:08.970 --> 00:07:12.600
sometimes it puts the character behind
the cursor, or it puts it before, or

151
00:07:12.600 --> 00:07:15.900
it puts it in the, there's all different
ways in which these things happen.

152
00:07:15.900 --> 00:07:17.640

But if you're in keyboard mode only or
if you want something consistent,

377
00:18:21.750 --> 00:18:22.950
there's keyboard shortcuts for it.

378
00:18:22.950 --> 00:18:25.760
Now in the VI world,
they don't call it copy.

379
00:18:25.760 --> 00:18:28.290
We're not copying the text,
they call it yank.

380
00:18:28.290 --> 00:18:29.558
We're yanking the text.

381
00:18:29.558 --> 00:18:33.797
I want to yank a copy of that text, and
then apply it somewhere else, right?

382
00:18:33.797 --> 00:18:36.120
To paste a copy and to have it.

383
00:18:36.120 --> 00:18:40.280
So if I want to take my old roses are red
here and copy that, there's a few

384
00:18:40.280 --> 00:18:43.720
different ways that we can do it and
it's all set around the Y command.

385
00:18:43.720 --> 00:18:47.830
Okay, so the Y command is
very similar to like C and D.

386
00:18:47.830 --> 00:18:50.540
When you type Y, nothing happens.

387
00:18:50.540 --> 00:18:51.820
It's expecting a follow up command.

388
00:18:51.820 --> 00:18:55.790
And if I want to copy this whole line,
I just press y again, okay.

389
00:18:55.790 --> 00:18:58.590
So if I do y y, that copies the line.

390
00:18:58.590 --> 00:19:00.860
I just yanked a copy of this line.

391
00:19:00.860 --> 00:19:05.016
And then I can go somewhere else and I can
paste it, or technically VI, it's put,

392
00:19:05.016 --> 00:19:05.630
not paste.

393
00:19:05.630 --> 00:19:08.591
So I yank, and I put,
right, not copy and paste.

394
00:19:08.591 --> 00:19:10.066
But the functionality is the same.

395
00:19:10.066 --> 00:19:14.600
So I can come in here and I can just
hit p and it's going to paste it.

396
00:19:14.600 --> 00:19:19.680
And I can do it over, and over, and
over again right, I'm copying and pasting.

397
00:19:19.680 --> 00:19:22.150
And you've got variations this like YW for

398
00:19:22.150 --> 00:19:25.240
yanking a word versus YY which
yanks the whole sentence.

399
00:19:25.240 --> 00:19:26.880
And you could go when
you can paste this in.

400
00:19:26.880 --> 00:19:29.272
So its copy and
paste that's built into the editor, so

401
00:19:29.272 --> 00:19:32.300
you're not dependent on your
terminals functionality.

402
00:19:32.300 --> 00:19:36.440
>> Awesome stuff, let's see here, what
else can we do with the VI terminal, Don?

403
00:19:36.440 --> 00:19:39.572
>> So as far as working in the terminal,
I think at this point

404
00:19:39.572 --> 00:19:44.012
we've covered all the commands that you're
going to see on the exam, except for

405
00:19:44.012 --> 00:19:45.271
a few with exiting VI.

406
00:19:45.271 --> 00:19:49.180
When we exit, in the last episode
I covered a few things right.

407
00:19:49.180 --> 00:19:53.960
I covered how to save If I wanna save my
document, I just made some changes to it.

408
00:19:53.960 --> 00:19:57.370
I can do a colon followed by a W, right?

409
00:19:57.370 --> 00:20:01.745
That means write, I want to get out
of this document and I want to save,

410
00:20:01.745 --> 00:20:03.490
well sorry.

411
00:20:03.490 --> 00:20:06.140
Right, doesn't get me out of my document,
right, it just saves it.

412
00:20:06.140 --> 00:20:07.630
When I do :w it saves it.

413
00:20:07.630 --> 00:20:09.330
It tells me that it wrote the file,

414
00:20:09.330 --> 00:20:14.180
it wrote 6700 characters and
there we go, it's written.

415
00:20:14.180 --> 00:20:15.990
But I'm still in it.

416
00:20:15.990 --> 00:20:18.550
If I want to get out,
I've got to do colon q.

417
00:20:18.550 --> 00:20:21.620
Colon q is quit and
that's going to take me out.

418
00:20:21.620 --> 00:20:24.680
And I can combine the two,
I can do colon wq.

419
00:20:24.680 --> 00:20:26.830
And when I do that it will write and
then quit, and

420
00:20:26.830 --> 00:20:28.780
I'll get out of the document, right?

421
00:20:28.780 --> 00:20:32.230
But what if I have unsaved changes, right?

422
00:20:32.230 --> 00:20:36.510
So I've got, a little extra here, so

423
00:20:36.510 --> 00:20:39.600
I'll put that in, and
I haven't saved my changes yet.

424
00:20:39.600 --> 00:20:43.640
If I do colon q to quit, I get an error.

425
00:20:43.640 --> 00:20:46.070
It tells me no write since last change.

426
00:20:46.070 --> 00:20:49.290
I can't get out because I
have unsaved changes, right?

427
00:20:49.290 --> 00:20:52.130
So there's modifiers to the quick
command as far as what we want to do.

428
00:20:52.130 --> 00:20:54.770
And there's modifiers for
the write command also.

429
00:20:54.770 --> 00:20:58.510
So when I go and start working
with a file and I want to get out,

430
00:20:58.510 --> 00:21:03.450
colon w to save, colon q to quit,
colon wq to save and quit.

431
00:21:03.450 --> 00:21:09.965
But some of the variations that we might
have, there's, let's see, there's zz.

432
00:21:09.965 --> 00:21:12.840
Right if you do, don't get into the colon,

433
00:21:13.840 --> 00:21:18.860
just do capital z capital z,
and it will save and exit.

434
00:21:18.860 --> 00:21:19.610
Just real quick,

435
00:21:19.610 --> 00:21:23.440
you don't have to do colons just
capital z, capital z, saves and quits.

436
00:21:23.440 --> 00:21:27.130
And so now, when I go back into the Raven,
I can go in here and

437
00:21:27.130 --> 00:21:28.990
I'm going to look for all roses.

438
00:21:28.990 --> 00:21:31.220
There we go, and I can find,
there's all my stuff, nice and

439
00:21:31.220 --> 00:21:33.800
safe, all in here, okay.

440
00:21:33.800 --> 00:21:37.426
So, if I make a change,
now I kind of get back to this part,

441
00:21:37.426 --> 00:21:41.672
where if I want to quit, I can't quit,
because now I made changes.

442
00:21:41.672 --> 00:21:45.050
All right, capital z, capital z,
saves and quits all at the same time.

443
00:21:45.050 --> 00:21:48.860
Now what if I made some changes, but
I don't like them or it was an accident.

444
00:21:48.860 --> 00:21:50.090
Maybe I was just trying to view a file.

445
00:21:50.090 --> 00:21:53.370
I don't actually want to save anything,
I just want to get out, right.

446
00:21:53.370 --> 00:21:57.040
Or what will happen to me
is I'll edit a file and

447
00:21:57.040 --> 00:22:00.580
forget to use Sudu, so
I'll edit like a network card file and

448
00:22:00.580 --> 00:22:03.260
I forget to use Sudu and so
I'm editing it just as myself.

449
00:22:03.260 --> 00:22:04.200
And then when I go to save it,

450
00:22:04.200 --> 00:22:06.040
it won't let me save because
I don't have permissions.

451
00:22:06.040 --> 00:22:07.120
I get permission denied.

452
00:22:07.120 --> 00:22:09.719
But I can't quit,
because I haven't saved my changes, right?

453
00:22:09.719 --> 00:22:13.712
So what you can do is, q!.

454
00:22:13.712 --> 00:22:15.930
And exclamation point is like an override.

455
00:22:15.930 --> 00:22:19.220
It says I don't care what error message
you're giving me, just do this.

456
00:22:19.220 --> 00:22:23.060
So I know that if I try and quit,
I can't because I haven't saved anything.

457
00:22:23.060 --> 00:22:26.010
But if I do q!, that says I don't care.

458
00:22:26.010 --> 00:22:28.210
Quit, throw my changes away,
I'm okay with that.

459
00:22:28.210 --> 00:22:29.850
Right, just get rid of the changes.

460
00:22:29.850 --> 00:22:31.280
So q exclamation point.

461
00:22:31.280 --> 00:22:36.890
Same thing with w, if I'm editing
a file and I change the file name and

462
00:22:36.890 --> 00:22:39.870
I try and save over an existing file,
I'll get an overwrite message.

463
00:22:39.870 --> 00:22:42.560
It'll say warning you're
about to overwrite a file and

464
00:22:42.560 --> 00:22:43.660
I might not want that right.

465
00:22:43.660 --> 00:22:44.960
So I get a warning about it.

466
00:22:44.960 --> 00:22:49.693
While I can do :w!, and that says I
don't care that the file already exists,

467
00:22:49.693 --> 00:22:52.734
just overwrite the darn thing,
and it will do it.

468
00:22:52.734 --> 00:22:56.720
So q!, is quit without saving.

469
00:22:56.720 --> 00:22:58.565
w!, is overwrite.

470
00:22:58.565 --> 00:23:01.940
Just overwrite whatever file already
exists, let's just get it done.

471
00:23:03.050 --> 00:23:05.730
Now I mentioned like
switching to another file.

472
00:23:05.730 --> 00:23:06.638
How do we do that?

473
00:23:06.638 --> 00:23:10.440
I'm editing raven.txt.

474
00:23:10.440 --> 00:23:11.740
I might want to work
with another file now.

475
00:23:11.740 --> 00:23:15.900
Okay, and if I want to work with
another file, I could quit out of I and

476
00:23:15.900 --> 00:23:18.010
then relaunch it with
the different file name.

477
00:23:18.010 --> 00:23:21.430
But I can also just do :e, and

478
00:23:21.430 --> 00:23:25.410
when you do :e,
it let's switch to another file, right?

479
00:23:25.410 --> 00:23:28.200
But when I switch to another file
it just goes back to the raven,

480
00:23:28.200 --> 00:23:30.590
because I did not give it a file name,
right?

481
00:23:30.590 --> 00:23:37.156
So we can follow that up with a file name
and now I'm in a new file, file.txt.

482
00:23:37.156 --> 00:23:38.450
And I can start editing it and saving it.

483
00:23:38.450 --> 00:23:41.340
So I don't actually have to leave
the editor to create a new file.

484
00:23:41.340 --> 00:23:45.960
And now I can start working with
this one and continue with my

485
00:23:45.960 --> 00:23:50.899
literary excellence and
work on my roses are red file and,

486
00:23:50.899 --> 00:23:56.880
I'm going to win like a Nobel prize for
literature or something for this stuff.

487
00:23:56.880 --> 00:23:58.077
Bring peace the world.
>> That's right.

488
00:23:58.077 --> 00:24:01.271
>> So now I have to start working,
so colon e followed by a file name,

489
00:24:01.271 --> 00:24:04.892
that will take you into a new file and
And the file minority exist, right?

490
00:24:04.892 --> 00:24:08.433
So you can go full path on that to point
to some file that already exists and

491
00:24:08.433 --> 00:24:13.040
get in there and start to edit that so
you're easily able to switch through.

492
00:24:13.040 --> 00:24:16.430
What if though, this is a throw away file
for me, I don't care about this file.

493
00:24:16.430 --> 00:24:20.820
So, I wanna go back to the Raven and
I don't wanna save this one, okay?

494
00:24:20.820 --> 00:24:24.090
Well, if I try and switch files and I
haven't saved them I'm gonna get an error.

495
00:24:24.090 --> 00:24:26.310
It's going to tell me you
have unsaved changes, but

496
00:24:26.310 --> 00:24:27.310
I don't want to save this one.

497
00:24:27.310 --> 00:24:28.860
I want to throw it away.

498
00:24:28.860 --> 00:24:35.500
So instead of :e by itself,
what I can do is :e!.

499
00:24:35.500 --> 00:24:37.830
And that says I want to
switch to another file, and

500
00:24:37.830 --> 00:24:40.940
I don't care if you save this one or not.

501
00:24:40.940 --> 00:24:44.234
So I'm going to jump back to raven.text.

502
00:24:45.700 --> 00:24:49.494
And when I do that, it jumps right back
over, and it didn't save the file that I

503
00:24:49.494 --> 00:24:52.484
had, so :e followed by a file
name to switch to another file,

504
00:24:52.484 --> 00:24:55.302
:e!, followed by a file name
to switch to another file,

505
00:24:55.302 --> 00:24:58.207
and don't bother saving the one
that you're in right now.

506
00:24:58.207 --> 00:25:04.660
So the key thing to remember here for
the exam, w!, q!, e!.

507
00:25:04.660 --> 00:25:08.230
All three of those are ways
to get out of a file and

508
00:25:08.230 --> 00:25:12.845
not worry about saving it, or in the case
of w!, to override an existing file.

509
00:25:12.845 --> 00:25:16.585
>> Kind of a forceful, I want to quit,
or I want to write, or

510
00:25:16.585 --> 00:25:18.185
I want to go to another file.

511
00:25:18.185 --> 00:25:21.245
It's adding emphasis to the fact
that that's what you want to do,

512
00:25:21.245 --> 00:25:24.375
and I don't care if you block about it,
that's fine for you.

513
00:25:24.375 --> 00:25:26.890
Do what I tell you to do, because
I'm the almighty god of the system.

514
00:25:26.890 --> 00:25:28.525
[LAUGH]
>> Yes, that's basically it.

515
00:25:28.525 --> 00:25:29.685
There are times.

516
00:25:29.685 --> 00:25:32.476
For me, it's almost always when
I'm editing a file I don't have

517
00:25:32.476 --> 00:25:33.248
permissions to.

518
00:25:33.248 --> 00:25:37.571
Cuz it'll let you do that If you're logged
in as a regular user and you forget to use

519
00:25:37.571 --> 00:25:41.750
sudo, there's plenty of files that
you can view, but you can't edit.

520
00:25:41.750 --> 00:25:44.390
And so I'll pull up a config file,
I'll put in my change,

521
00:25:44.390 --> 00:25:46.970
and then I'm like I can't save,
I don't have permissions.

522
00:25:46.970 --> 00:25:49.510
And there's no way to change
permissions once you're in vi.

523
00:25:49.510 --> 00:25:52.820
You've gotta get out and sudo it,
and so you're just kinda stuck.

524
00:25:52.820 --> 00:25:55.490
You gotta override to get out, so
definitely keep those in mind.

525
00:25:55.490 --> 00:25:57.050
They may turn up on the exam.

526
00:25:57.050 --> 00:26:01.250
>> I start seeing why people like to login
as route when that kinda thing happens.

527
00:26:01.250 --> 00:26:02.020
That's a bad idea.

528
00:26:02.020 --> 00:26:04.150
Don't make a habit of logging as route.

529
00:26:04.150 --> 00:26:06.500
But you can see why that might
be a very tempting thing to do.

530
00:26:06.500 --> 00:26:11.390
With that being said, Don,
even though it's a very old system, it

531
00:26:11.390 --> 00:26:15.210
is kind of antiquated in the way that we
use it and the way that we work with it.

532
00:26:15.210 --> 00:26:17.760

especially when you're working with

533
00:26:17.760 --> 00:26:21.100

have a mouse, or that's an older type,

534
00:26:21.100 --> 00:26:24.575
you're just terminalling in,
this is really gonna be helpful for you.

535
00:26:24.575 --> 00:26:27.420
Don, is there anything else that we
need to know about for this episode?

536
00:26:27.420 --> 00:26:28.460

00:26:28.460 --> 00:26:32.390

00:26:32.390 --> 00:26:33.250

00:26:35.740 --> 00:26:36.780

541
00:26:36.780 --> 00:26:38.060
So that's really what's important.

542
00:26:38.060 --> 00:26:41.140
But there are more out there,
so definitely jump in and

543
00:26:41.140 --> 00:26:42.340
read the manual for vi.

544
00:26:42.340 --> 00:26:45.180
It's not the most fun read,
but there's a ton there.

545
00:26:45.180 --> 00:26:48.180
There's plenty of authors that have put
out entire books on using the editor.

546
00:26:48.180 --> 00:26:49.130
It is a great editor.

547
00:26:49.130 --> 00:26:51.860
It's not super intuitive
cuz of all the shortcuts.

548
00:26:51.860 --> 00:26:54.570
But once you learn it,
it's what I use all the time.

549
00:26:54.570 --> 00:26:57.980
Even when I have newer editors like Nano
available to me, I still go back and

00:26:57.980 --> 00:27:00.420

kinda what I've gotten used to and

551
00:27:00.420 --> 00:27:01.710
I know it's always gonna be there for me.

552
00:27:01.710 --> 00:27:03.480
>> Yeah.
Hard to get away from that familiarity.

553
00:27:03.480 --> 00:27:06.910
And it's a great system to be familiar
with because, like we said before,

554
00:27:06.910 --> 00:27:10.120
it's almost invariably going to be found
on just about any system you log into.

555
00:27:10.120 --> 00:27:12.360
So it's good to have
a working knowledge of it.

556
00:27:12.360 --> 00:27:15.300
Don, thank you so much for
joining us today, and explaining the vi.

557
00:27:15.300 --> 00:27:19.590
And giving us some of the higher level
functions that we can use with that.

558
00:27:19.590 --> 00:27:21.130
We thank you guys so much for joining us.

559
00:27:21.130 --> 00:27:22.850
We're going to go ahead and

00:27:22.850 --> 00:27:24.710

This one's marked out.

492
00:22:54.670 --> 00:22:58.570
In other words don't go straight to
CentOS go to the mirror instead.

493
00:22:58.570 --> 00:23:01.560
Then whether or not we check for
a digital signature with that provider.

494
00:23:01.560 --> 00:23:03.650
A lot of these packages
are digitally signed so

495
00:23:03.650 --> 00:23:05.395
we can tell if they've been tampered with.

496
00:23:05.395 --> 00:23:08.875
And so this one's got it turned on and
it's saying here's where that key is.

497
00:23:08.875 --> 00:23:12.735
So when we download a file use this key to
verify that it hasn't been tampered with.

498
00:23:12.735 --> 00:23:14.905
And if it's successful then go ahead and

499
00:23:14.905 --> 00:23:17.825
install it but if it's been
tampered with don't install it.

500
00:23:17.825 --> 00:23:22.591
Now the neat part here is this is a URL
and so when I did YUM install links.

501
00:23:22.591 --> 00:23:26.515
Which was back in my history or
somewhere or whatever or Wireshark for

502
00:23:26.515 --> 00:23:27.660
that matter Right?

503
00:23:27.660 --> 00:23:30.150
I don't have the Wireshark
files here on my system.

504
00:23:30.150 --> 00:23:33.020
It looked at the servers then said hey is
there a package out there named Wireshark?

505
00:23:33.020 --> 00:23:36.540
Let me find that and op,
there it is okay let me install that.

506
00:23:36.540 --> 00:23:38.540
And it gets all the information
right there from the server.

507
00:23:38.540 --> 00:23:41.130
We don't have to download stuff ourselves.

508
00:23:41.130 --> 00:23:42.120
What if though?

509
00:23:42.120 --> 00:23:46.570
What if you want to install software like
Webmin that's not in the repository right?

510
00:23:46.570 --> 00:23:51.290
If I do Yum list Webmin, right?

511

Webmin's not in the repository.

512
00:23:52.806 --> 00:23:55.100
No matching packages to list.

513
00:23:55.100 --> 00:23:58.791
Earlier in the show I installed it from
a copy I downloaded right here to my

00:23:58.791 --> 00:23:59.343
machine.

00:23:59.343 --> 00:24:02.854
YUM is looking to the repositories though,
and it doesn't exist there.

516
00:24:02.854 --> 00:24:05.650
It's not on red hat servers.

517
00:24:05.650 --> 00:24:09.883
So if I wanna install it, I can manually
download and use RPM like we did a minute

00:24:09.883 --> 00:24:13.478
ago or that software developer
might have their own repository and

00:24:13.478 --> 00:24:15.298

00:24:15.298 --> 00:24:16.952
If you're buying software for

00:24:20.540 --> 00:24:24.390

00:24:24.390 --> 00:24:26.340

if we look in the documentation for

00:24:33.620 --> 00:24:38.270
how to get it installed or whatever,

00:24:38.270 --> 00:24:39.180

00:24:41.500 --> 00:24:43.580
That's gonna take me

00:24:43.580 --> 00:24:46.820
In here somewhere they've actually got the

00:24:46.820 --> 00:24:50.750

531
00:24:50.750 --> 00:24:52.008
So if I wanna do that.

00:24:52.008 --> 00:24:54.210
If I wanna pull it from their repository,

00:24:54.210 --> 00:24:56.190
what I need to do is
create a repo file for it.

534
00:24:56.190 --> 00:24:57.020
And I've actually done that right here.

535
00:24:57.020 --> 00:24:59.170
I've created a repo file.

536
00:24:59.170 --> 00:25:01.720
And if we take a look at that file

537
00:25:05.600 --> 00:25:08.830
put a name for it,
I called it webmin distribution neutral.

00:25:08.830 --> 00:25:12.860
And then a base URL,
download.webmin.com/download/yum,

00:25:12.860 --> 00:25:15.520
this is tied to yum.

00:25:15.520 --> 00:25:18.350
And then the mirror list,
where it can get its mirrors from.

541
00:25:18.350 --> 00:25:22.440
So now, whenever I do a search for
new packages,

00:25:22.440 --> 00:25:26.210
instead of just searching the CentOS ones,

00:25:26.210 --> 00:25:27.764

00:25:27.764 --> 00:25:31.497
Now, my search failed a minute ago

00:25:31.497 --> 00:25:34.109

00:25:35.350 --> 00:25:38.850
And now, when I search for a package,
it's gonna look at that repository.

00:25:38.850 --> 00:25:43.050
So up here I ran yum list webmin,

548
00:25:43.050 --> 00:25:49.710
Now, I'm gonna run yum list webmin, and

549
00:25:49.710 --> 00:25:53.800
Right there.
Webmin no architecture version 1.740-1.

550
00:25:53.800 --> 00:25:58.056
The cool part here is when an update comes

00:26:01.250 --> 00:26:05.170
So now, if I do a sudo yum install webmin,

554
00:26:09.270 --> 00:26:10.610
We'll bring that in.

555
00:26:10.610 --> 00:26:12.910
And it's gonna download it and
it's gonna install it.

556
00:26:12.910 --> 00:26:18.100
And once that's done in the future,

557
00:26:18.100 --> 00:26:22.270
Now, actually I gotta failure right there,

00:26:22.270 --> 00:26:24.860

00:26:24.860 --> 00:26:26.115
So I got two choices here.

560
00:26:26.115 --> 00:26:28.895

00:26:28.895 --> 00:26:31.625
file I could put in there gpg check
equals zero, and knock that out.

562
00:26:31.625 --> 00:26:34.035
Not a great idea though.

563
00:26:34.035 --> 00:26:37.595
The better thing would be to get the key
from that developer and he's got one.

564
00:26:37.595 --> 00:26:38.487
Do I have the?
>> Yep.

565
00:26:38.487 --> 00:26:39.277
>> I got it.

566
00:26:39.277 --> 00:26:41.805
Let me get that real quick.

567
00:26:41.805 --> 00:26:44.027
So I'm gonna download the key from him.

568
00:26:44.027 --> 00:26:46.855
You wanna make sure you download
the key directly from the developer not

569
00:26:46.855 --> 00:26:47.565
from a mirror.

570
00:26:47.565 --> 00:26:49.465
If you get it from a mirror it
could have been tampered with.

571
00:26:50.530 --> 00:26:52.800
So I'm gonna pull it right from him.

572
00:26:54.050 --> 00:26:58.549
And it's just jcameron-key.asc.

573
00:26:58.549 --> 00:27:01.390
So I'm gonna get a copy of that.

574
00:27:01.390 --> 00:27:05.380
And then we actually do have to use
the rpm command to import that key.

575

YUM doesn't let us import it so

576
00:27:10.610 --> 00:27:11.225
Same thing.

577
00:27:11.225 --> 00:27:11.991
Whoops!

578
00:27:11.991 --> 00:27:13.663
It's the same thing if I type it right.

579
00:27:13.663 --> 00:27:15.811
>> [LAUGH]
>> And we're gonna import that one in.

580
00:27:15.811 --> 00:27:17.704
And we'll specify that key.

581
00:27:19.642 --> 00:27:21.987
And oh, I need to sudo.

582
00:27:21.987 --> 00:27:23.610
I don't have permission,

583

584
00:27:24.710 --> 00:27:26.040
Now, I've got the key.

585
00:27:26.040 --> 00:27:31.450
So now, if I do sudo yum install webmin,
it's gonna search all of the repositories,

586
00:27:31.450 --> 00:27:35.230
it's searching CentOS repositories
as well as the web in repositories.

587
00:27:35.230 --> 00:27:40.160
It finds it, I go in to install it,
after it downloads it will do

588
00:27:40.160 --> 00:27:43.430
the gpg check which should pass
this time because I have this key,

589
00:27:43.430 --> 00:27:46.040
I can verify it hasn't been tampered
with and then it'll install.

590
00:27:47.470 --> 00:27:48.410
Assuming I didn't screw it up.

591
00:27:48.410 --> 00:27:49.098
>> Yeah.
[LAUGH]

592
00:27:49.098 --> 00:27:49.818
>> There's always room for that.

593
00:27:49.818 --> 00:27:51.165
>> Yeah, it happens from time to time.

594
00:27:51.165 --> 00:27:53.938
>> [LAUGH]
>> Now, this is really cool though because

595
00:27:53.938 --> 00:27:57.484
of I was running a business or
maybe we're an IT support team where

00:27:57.484 --> 00:28:01.804
we've got a bunch of Linux servers and

00:28:01.804 --> 00:28:06.150
we could set one server to have all those

00:28:06.150 --> 00:28:09.140
Maybe if we're building our own packages,

599
00:28:09.140 --> 00:28:12.840
Set up a Linux server, put all that

00:28:12.840 --> 00:28:15.230
And then they could just pull right from

00:28:15.230 --> 00:28:17.740
they can do all this stuff very,
very handle idle.

00:28:17.740 --> 00:28:18.800
>> Yeah, those repositories.

00:28:18.800 --> 00:28:21.582
They're just like FTP or web servers,

They just have all

Amazon did it.

They have their own repository so

00:28:38.520 --> 00:28:41.810

00:28:41.810 --> 00:28:45.200

612
00:28:45.200 --> 00:28:50.747
Now, I am noticing that in

This is the highest evolution

Very cool.

I love that we can just

rpm can get kind of convoluted from time

00:29:26.370 --> 00:29:31.160
stuff from source is definitely a little

629
00:29:32.655 --> 00:29:34.610
>> Yeah, and
you say it's the next generation.

It won't be on the exam unless you

00:29:38.240 --> 00:29:38.860

episodes.title: Using Debian Packages
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.032 --> 00:00:15.091
All right everyone, greetings and welcome
to another great episode of ITProTV.

3
00:00:15.091 --> 00:00:16.650
I'll be your host, Daniel Lowry.

4
00:00:16.650 --> 00:00:19.451
Here with me today, my good friend and
colleague, Mr. Don Pizet.

5
00:00:19.451 --> 00:00:20.540
How you doing today, Don?

6
00:00:20.540 --> 00:00:23.340
>> I'm doing just swell, Daniel,
I'm kind of excited about today's episode,

7
00:00:23.340 --> 00:00:26.950
because it's sort of a part two
to an episode we did earlier on

8
00:00:26.950 --> 00:00:28.340
package management in Linux.

9
00:00:28.340 --> 00:00:32.380
If you've been watching our episodes in
order, we did an episode on using RPM,

10
00:00:32.380 --> 00:00:34.070
the Red Hat package manager.

11
00:00:34.070 --> 00:00:38.640
And that's great if you're on a centOS or
a Red Hat-based operating system,

12
00:00:38.640 --> 00:00:40.330
distribution that's based on that.

13
00:00:40.330 --> 00:00:43.290
But a lot of distributions
today like Ubuntu,

14
00:00:43.290 --> 00:00:46.305
which is one of the most popular
they're based on Debian, and

15
00:00:46.305 --> 00:00:49.415
Debian doesn't have RPM and
yum and those utilities.

16
00:00:49.415 --> 00:00:53.085
They have a completely different set of
package management utilities available,

17
00:00:53.085 --> 00:00:55.735
and so that's what we're gonna be
taking a look at in this episode,

18
00:00:55.735 --> 00:00:58.682
all the other things that we used
when we're on a Debian-based system.

19
00:00:58.682 --> 00:01:02.572
And Daniel, I was thinking Ubuntu and,
well, Debian itself, but

20
00:01:02.572 --> 00:01:03.492
there's plenty others, right?

21
00:01:03.492 --> 00:01:05.372
>> Yeah, there's Knoppix,
I think is one of them.

22
00:01:05.372 --> 00:01:09.756
Uses that live distribution that
you used to get a lot of playtime.

23
00:01:09.756 --> 00:01:13.176
Also Mints, I use Mints as well,
it's a Debian-based operating system.

24
00:01:13.176 --> 00:01:15.396
I really like it a lot,
it does really well for me.

25
00:01:15.396 --> 00:01:18.346
>> So if you sit down on the computer and
you run yum update and nothing comes back,

26
00:01:18.346 --> 00:01:21.146
then you're like well, all right,
maybe I'm on a Debian-based distro.

27
00:01:21.146 --> 00:01:22.386
So in that scenario,

28
00:01:22.386 --> 00:01:25.043
you've got two other commands that
you really need to be familiar with.

29
00:01:25.043 --> 00:01:27.183
It's really very similar
to the Red Hat world.

30
00:01:27.183 --> 00:01:32.613
First off, we have a utility called DPKG
which is the Debien package utility.

31
00:01:32.613 --> 00:01:37.490
DPKG was the original utility that was
just designed to install a package and

32
00:01:37.490 --> 00:01:38.470
that's really all it did.

33
00:01:38.470 --> 00:01:40.930
It didn't do dependency checking or
anything else crazy,

34
00:01:40.930 --> 00:01:43.220
just straight up install and
uninstall packages.

35
00:01:43.220 --> 00:01:48.490
Very similar to the RPM utility under Red
Hat and it's actually run the same way.

36
00:01:48.490 --> 00:01:50.880
If you wanted to install software,
first off you'd go out and

37
00:01:50.880 --> 00:01:53.290
you'd download a Debian package.

38
00:01:53.290 --> 00:01:55.150
Then, you'd DPKG to install it.

39
00:01:55.150 --> 00:01:57.050
Now the Debian package, it's just a file.

40
00:01:57.050 --> 00:02:01.200
It's an archive, and it ends in
.deb traditionally, and inside of

41
00:02:01.200 --> 00:02:04.150
that archive it's got all of the files
that are related to a particular program.

42
00:02:04.150 --> 00:02:06.000
So, for example, in the other episode,

43
00:02:06.000 --> 00:02:09.590
I was installing a web-based server
management utility called webmin.

44
00:02:09.590 --> 00:02:12.470
Let's say I wanted to install
that here on a Debian box, right?

45
00:02:12.470 --> 00:02:15.360
So, first off I'd go to
that vendor's website.

46
00:02:15.360 --> 00:02:16.930
So here I am on the Webmin website.

47
00:02:16.930 --> 00:02:19.900
And they've got instructions for
installing on Debian right here.

48
00:02:19.900 --> 00:02:22.564
The very first one is just
download the Debian package.

49
00:02:22.564 --> 00:02:24.364
The package for Webmins.

50
00:02:24.364 --> 00:02:27.742
So here's Webmin version 1.750_all.

51
00:02:27.742 --> 00:02:32.420
That _all, that's talking about
the architecture this is designed for.

52
00:02:32.420 --> 00:02:37.420
You might see AMD64 if it's designed for
Intel or AMD64-bit systems.

53
00:02:37.420 --> 00:02:43.460
You might see I386 if it's designed for
non-64-bit or 32-bit systems.

54
00:02:43.460 --> 00:02:45.743
Then you might see all if it
has no architecture dependence.

55
00:02:45.743 --> 00:02:47.891
There's ARM7.

56
00:02:47.891 --> 00:02:49.114
There's a few others that might show

57
00:02:49.114 --> 00:02:50.830
up depending on the type
of processor you have.

58
00:02:50.830 --> 00:02:53.910
And then .deb lets me know
that's a Debian package.

59
00:02:53.910 --> 00:02:56.100
So I can then install it using DPKG.

60
00:02:56.100 --> 00:02:59.993
Gee, they give that example right there,
dpkg --install and

61
00:02:59.993 --> 00:03:02.930
then the package that you wanna install.

62
00:03:02.930 --> 00:03:06.240
So, I've already downloaded that here.

63
00:03:06.240 --> 00:03:06.900
Oops.

64
00:03:06.900 --> 00:03:08.290
So there's my file.

65
00:03:08.290 --> 00:03:12.810
And so if I run dpkg, I'll just pull
up the help file real quick, and

66
00:03:12.810 --> 00:03:15.050
you can see all the different
syntax attached to it.

67
00:03:15.050 --> 00:03:17.991

If I go into /etc/app/apt.conf,
the file's kind of sparse,

524
00:24:51.170 --> 00:24:54.780
it's only got a little bit in it, but
in this examples file that's tucked away

525
00:24:54.780 --> 00:24:59.670
in /user/shared/doc/app/examples.

526
00:24:59.670 --> 00:25:00.336
>> Really hiding it.

527
00:25:00.336 --> 00:25:03.091
[LAUGH]
>> Dave actually got a whole bunch of

528
00:25:03.091 --> 00:25:07.350
options in there that are documented
out so you can see them.

529
00:25:07.350 --> 00:25:10.395
And you can specify a lot of
really interesting things.

530
00:25:10.395 --> 00:25:14.475
Like with Aptget, you can set it by
default then download packages only but

531
00:25:14.475 --> 00:25:16.155
not install them, right?

532
00:25:16.155 --> 00:25:18.535
So that gives you a chance
to maybe test them out or

533
00:25:18.535 --> 00:25:20.735
set up your own repository
if that's what you want.

534
00:25:20.735 --> 00:25:23.625
You can set the number of
retries if it fails to connect.

535
00:25:23.625 --> 00:25:26.115
You can set whether it's
going to clean things.

536
00:25:26.115 --> 00:25:29.465
When you remove something, a lot of times
it can leave files behind, clean can clear

537
00:25:29.465 --> 00:25:34.410
that up, but also when Apt installs
a package It caches the package file.

538
00:25:34.410 --> 00:25:35.470
It holds onto it.

539
00:25:35.470 --> 00:25:39.480
And if you uninstall the package, it still
has a copy of the package file itself

540
00:25:39.480 --> 00:25:42.430
cached and Kaleen can get that out of
there, and that's set to auto, but

541
00:25:42.430 --> 00:25:45.300
you can change that to set to prompt or
always, and

542
00:25:45.300 --> 00:25:49.145
even deep EPKG whether it
does borst overwrite or not.

543
00:25:49.145 --> 00:25:53.735
These are all things we can tweak and
modify inside of those config files.

544
00:25:53.735 --> 00:25:56.840
Most of us will never have to work
with these, but they are there.

545
00:25:56.840 --> 00:26:03.063
/etc/app is where we have it's
configurations, and then /etc/.

546
00:26:03.063 --> 00:26:04.471
Is it dpkg?

547
00:26:04.471 --> 00:26:05.173
Yeah.

548
00:26:05.173 --> 00:26:09.352
/etc/dpkg is where we have
the similar config files for

549
00:26:09.352 --> 00:26:11.302
dpackage, the old utility.

550
00:26:11.302 --> 00:26:13.842
And so you'll see that kind of in there.

551
00:26:13.842 --> 00:26:16.602
And you're really specifying in there
whether you want to do signature

552
00:26:16.602 --> 00:26:17.882
checking and so on.

553
00:26:17.882 --> 00:26:19.779
Those are all options we can kinda tweak.

554
00:26:19.779 --> 00:26:20.840
>> Very cool.

555
00:26:20.840 --> 00:26:23.880
All right Don,
well we've covered the app get command,

556
00:26:23.880 --> 00:26:26.382
which is definitely going to
give you a lot of functionality,

557
00:26:26.382 --> 00:26:29.360
going to help you out a lot as you
work with these Debian type systems.

558
00:26:29.360 --> 00:26:31.020
>> Absolutely.
>> Have we missed anything?

559
00:26:31.020 --> 00:26:31.980
>> I think that's it.

560
00:26:31.980 --> 00:26:36.745
I, there are the true GUI update
utilities, but those aren't on the exam.

561
00:26:36.745 --> 00:26:41.055
In real life, you can fire up a synaptic
package manager or whatever if you want,

562
00:26:41.055 --> 00:26:42.395
and those are a lot easier.

563
00:26:42.395 --> 00:26:43.235
But from the command line,
>> [LAUGH]

564
00:26:43.235 --> 00:26:44.545
>> These are the guys that we have.

565
00:26:44.545 --> 00:26:46.740
>> That's right, never know when
you're going to be in that sea alone,

566
00:26:46.740 --> 00:26:49.120
that's what you've got to work with,
so that being said,

567
00:26:49.120 --> 00:26:51.030
hopefully you guys have
learned a lot today.

568
00:26:51.030 --> 00:26:54.150
That's about all we have for today's show,
though, so signing off for IT Pro TV,

569
00:26:54.150 --> 00:26:56.200
I've been your host, Daniel Lowry.

570
00:26:56.200 --> 00:26:57.240
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

571
00:26:57.240 --> 00:27:00.105
>> We'll see you next time.

572
00:27:00.105 --> 00:27:04.260
