episodes.title: Managing Shared Libraries
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.742 --> 00:00:10.629
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:10.629 --> 00:00:14.354
>> All right, greetings everyone, and
welcome to another great episode of

3
00:00:14.354 --> 00:00:17.970
ITProTV with your host Daniel Lawry and
here with me today is Don Pezet.

4
00:00:17.970 --> 00:00:19.190
How you doing today Don?

5
00:00:19.190 --> 00:00:20.250
>> I'm doing great Daniel.

6
00:00:20.250 --> 00:00:22.940
We are jumping back into another
episode of Linux plus and

7
00:00:22.940 --> 00:00:26.800
in this episode we're taking
a look at shared libraries.

8
00:00:26.800 --> 00:00:30.460
Now shared libraries are one of those
things that happened behind the scene,

9
00:00:30.460 --> 00:00:33.330
most of us never have to deal with,
really just don't care about.

10
00:00:33.330 --> 00:00:35.758
>> That's how you get books from
other [LAUGH] libraries, right?

11
00:00:35.758 --> 00:00:39.170
>> Yeah, yeah, [LAUGH] you're gonna have
your library card, you gotta have your ID,

12
00:00:39.170 --> 00:00:41.575
maybe be homeless, I don't know, but.

13
00:00:41.575 --> 00:00:43.530
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] It's one of the things we

14
00:00:43.530 --> 00:00:44.900
don't normally have to worry about.

15
00:00:44.900 --> 00:00:46.370
So, you might ask yourself,

16
00:00:46.370 --> 00:00:48.620
if we don't have to worry about it,
why the heck is it on the exam?

17
00:00:48.620 --> 00:00:51.590
And the reason is unfortunately from time
to time we do have to worry about it.

18
00:00:51.590 --> 00:00:53.560
And when you do you need to
have that base knowledge.

19
00:00:53.560 --> 00:00:55.240
And end users never
have to deal with this.

20
00:00:55.240 --> 00:00:56.850
Now let's.
I'm getting ahead of myself.

21
00:00:56.850 --> 00:01:00.160
So let's start with what
the heck is a shared library?

22
00:01:00.160 --> 00:01:02.980
When you run a program,
whatever your program is.

23
00:01:02.980 --> 00:01:08.150
Maybe it's like Open Office or
the Gimp Graphic Editor or whatever.

24
00:01:08.150 --> 00:01:09.650
When you run those programs.

25
00:01:09.650 --> 00:01:12.050
There's a lot of components
in there that are not new.

26
00:01:12.050 --> 00:01:13.490
They didn't just invent, right.

27
00:01:13.490 --> 00:01:17.310
So if your software has a button on
the screen the code to generate that

28
00:01:17.310 --> 00:01:19.100
button is not unique to that program.

29
00:01:19.100 --> 00:01:20.610
They could have written it that way,
they could have written it

30
00:01:20.610 --> 00:01:22.670
from scratch saying we're going
to generate our own buttons.

31
00:01:22.670 --> 00:01:25.208
But instead a lot of
them depend on libraries.

32
00:01:25.208 --> 00:01:28.600
These libraries already have
things like buttons to find or

33
00:01:28.600 --> 00:01:32.320
how to talk to a serial port or
how to encode a JPEG file.

34
00:01:32.320 --> 00:01:34.220
>> They are already written
in these libraries.

35
00:01:34.220 --> 00:01:36.820
So if you're going to write a graphics
editor, instead of having to reinvent

36
00:01:36.820 --> 00:01:41.630
everything from scratch, you can just
rely on these other library files.

37
00:01:41.630 --> 00:01:45.010
So it definitely cuts
down on code development.

38
00:01:45.010 --> 00:01:47.420
It shrinks the size of programs, and

39
00:01:47.420 --> 00:01:51.560
when you have five programs that all need
to display a JPEG, they can all rely

40
00:01:51.560 --> 00:01:54.760
on the same library as opposed to having
five different sets of libraries doing it

41
00:01:54.760 --> 00:01:58.085
five different ways, taking up five
times the space on your hard drive.

42
00:01:58.085 --> 00:02:01.090
>> [SOUND]
>> So, that's what developers do.

43
00:02:01.090 --> 00:02:06.360
They rely on external libraries and
they can share them with other programs.

44
00:02:06.360 --> 00:02:10.530
Now, there's good sides to that and
there's bad sides to that.

45
00:02:10.530 --> 00:02:13.935
In the windows world,
we have this term called DLL hell, right?

46
00:02:13.935 --> 00:02:16.420
[LAUGH] In Windows they call
them Dynamic Link Libraries,

47
00:02:16.420 --> 00:02:19.420
in Lynx they're just shared libraries,
but it's the same concept.

48
00:02:19.420 --> 00:02:22.130
That you can have all these
different libraries and different

49
00:02:22.130 --> 00:02:26.910
versions of the same library, so maybe
there's that JPEG rendering library and

50
00:02:26.910 --> 00:02:29.610
you got five different versions of it, and
different programs depend on different

51
00:02:29.610 --> 00:02:32.950
versions and
it really make it a nightmare to manage.

52
00:02:32.950 --> 00:02:37.480
Well, in the Linux operating system and
the way the Linux kernel handles this,

53
00:02:37.480 --> 00:02:41.010
we have these shared libraries
that try to solve that problem.

54
00:02:41.010 --> 00:02:42.130
So I wanna show you how it works.

55
00:02:42.130 --> 00:02:46.905
I'm gonna show you some examples here with
how it works on just a normal system.

56
00:02:46.905 --> 00:02:51.675
And then we'll talk about what we might
have to do if we have to get in there and

57
00:02:51.675 --> 00:02:52.785
get involved with it.

58
00:02:52.785 --> 00:02:53.355
All right?

59
00:02:53.355 --> 00:02:56.425
Now, when I say if we have to get in and
get involved with it,

60
00:02:56.425 --> 00:03:00.800
the only time we have to get involved
is if we're missing a shared library?

61
00:03:00.800 --> 00:03:01.320
Right?

62
00:03:01.320 --> 00:03:04.310
And missing a shared library doesn't
really happen anymore because we use

63
00:03:04.310 --> 00:03:08.970
things like the Yum or
AppGet package managers.

64
00:03:08.970 --> 00:03:12.110
And when they install software,
they install all the dependencies.

65
00:03:12.110 --> 00:03:13.460
If the library's already there, great.

66
00:03:13.460 --> 00:03:15.190
If it's not there, it adds it in.

67
00:03:15.190 --> 00:03:17.980
Right, so
we don't really have to worry about it.

68
00:03:17.980 --> 00:03:20.770
But if you're manually installing
software, if a developer comes to you and

69
00:03:20.770 --> 00:03:22.850
says, here's the software
I wrote specifically for

70
00:03:22.850 --> 00:03:25.320
your company, here's five sets
of shared libraries you need.

71
00:03:25.320 --> 00:03:28.690
You gotta know how to load those in,
right, and how to get them present and

72
00:03:28.690 --> 00:03:31.800
recognized in this system, so that's what
we're gonna take a look at here in this

73
00:03:31.800 --> 00:03:33.310
episode, and kinda see how that works.

74
00:03:34.630 --> 00:03:37.890
All right, first off, let's talk
about where the libraries are stored.

75
00:03:37.890 --> 00:03:43.570
The libraries, they're just files, and
they usually end in a .so file extension,

76
00:03:43.570 --> 00:03:47.890
which I think it stands for shared object,
but it's these library files.

77
00:03:47.890 --> 00:03:51.310
And they can actually be stored
in a few different places.

78
00:03:51.310 --> 00:03:55.180
The most common place for them,
I'll just pull up my Cento S7 box here.

79
00:03:55.180 --> 00:03:58.208
The most common place for
them is /usr/lib.

80
00:03:58.208 --> 00:04:00.710
All right, /lib is short for library, and

81
00:04:00.710 --> 00:04:03.660
that's kind of where you'd
expect library files to be.

82
00:04:03.660 --> 00:04:04.190
And in here,

83
00:04:04.190 --> 00:04:08.580
I can see, not a bunch of files that
end in .so, but a bunch of folders.

84
00:04:08.580 --> 00:04:09.590
Right.

85
00:04:09.590 --> 00:04:13.558
Each one of these are folders and if you
look, you can see all these different

86
00:04:13.558 --> 00:04:17.898
programs that I've got, like good old Java
right there and I can change into my Java

87
00:04:17.898 --> 00:04:21.184
folder and apparently I don't
actually have Java installed?

88
00:04:21.184 --> 00:04:21.939
That's fun.

89
00:04:21.939 --> 00:04:24.880
So let's try Python instead.

90
00:04:24.880 --> 00:04:28.790
And we can go in there and
we got another folder of site packages,

91
00:04:28.790 --> 00:04:30.530
and eventually, there we go.

92
00:04:30.530 --> 00:04:34.240
We can start to get in and start to
find true actual library files, right.

93
00:04:34.240 --> 00:04:37.270
So, well even these are mostly directory
[LAUGH] so if we dig deep enough,

94
00:04:37.270 --> 00:04:38.700
I picked a nice complex one.

95
00:04:38.700 --> 00:04:41.809
[LAUGH] Let's pick one that's a little
more simple, I'm forgetting something.

96
00:04:42.940 --> 00:04:46.340
I'm in the /user/lib folder, right?

97
00:04:46.340 --> 00:04:47.940
So that's where I'm at.

98
00:04:47.940 --> 00:04:52.240
If you're on a 64-bit system,
you may have 64-bit libraries also, and

99
00:04:52.240 --> 00:04:54.940
so you may have libraries in more
than one location based on that.

100
00:04:54.940 --> 00:05:01.130
If I go /user/lib64,
now I'll see 64-bit libraries.

101
00:05:01.130 --> 00:05:03.830
I'm on a 64 bit system,
there's all my stinking libraries,

102
00:05:03.830 --> 00:05:05.230
that's why I wasn't seeing them.

103
00:05:05.230 --> 00:05:06.630
So I can see a lot of stuff.

104
00:05:06.630 --> 00:05:09.140
And I mentioned JPEG rendering.

105
00:05:09.140 --> 00:05:13.330
I can see libjpeg.so.62, right there.

106
00:05:13.330 --> 00:05:17.826
Well, right after it I've
got lib.jpeg.so.62.1.0.

107
00:05:17.826 --> 00:05:20.170
Why do I have two libraries?

108
00:05:20.170 --> 00:05:21.140
Well, I don't.

109
00:05:21.140 --> 00:05:22.900
I've actually got one library.

110
00:05:22.900 --> 00:05:25.900
But in Linux they do software linking.

111
00:05:25.900 --> 00:05:30.240
And it's the linking that happens between
these files that helps to eliminate a lot

112
00:05:30.240 --> 00:05:32.870
of the conflicts that we had in the past.

113
00:05:32.870 --> 00:05:36.030
When you look at a library file what
you're going to see is the name of

114
00:05:36.030 --> 00:05:36.820
the library.

115
00:05:36.820 --> 00:05:41.738
So like libjpeg, this is my library for
doing jpeg rending and generation.

116
00:05:41.738 --> 00:05:43.870
And then .so, right?

117
00:05:43.870 --> 00:05:44.850
That's shared object.

118
00:05:44.850 --> 00:05:46.640
It is a shared library.

119
00:05:46.640 --> 00:05:47.790
And then 62.

120
00:05:47.790 --> 00:05:49.760
62 is the major version.

121
00:05:49.760 --> 00:05:54.040
This is the major version, 62,
for this particular library.

122
00:05:54.040 --> 00:05:57.280
Now if I have ten programs
that all depend on that, and

123
00:05:57.280 --> 00:06:01.910
then a new version of libjpeg comes out,
I don't wanna have to update

124
00:06:01.910 --> 00:06:05.700
all five programs to point to
this new version of the library.

125
00:06:05.700 --> 00:06:07.420
So when a new version comes out,

126
00:06:07.420 --> 00:06:11.500
instead of constantly changing this
one file it leaves this file alone.

127
00:06:11.500 --> 00:06:16.920
And then it adds the new version and
it links it to this name.

128
00:06:16.920 --> 00:06:20.310
This name is actually a link
that points to this longer name.

129
00:06:20.310 --> 00:06:24.450
So right now I can say I'm
actually running 62.1.0.

130
00:06:24.450 --> 00:06:27.758
Let's say a hot fix comes out,
and it's 62.1.1.

131
00:06:27.758 --> 00:06:32.830
Well, that 62.1.1 file
will be listed here and

132
00:06:32.830 --> 00:06:35.680
this link will just be
redirected to point at it.

133
00:06:35.680 --> 00:06:40.770
So now my software can
always call libjpeg.so.62

134
00:06:40.770 --> 00:06:43.890
regardless of what minor version
is underneath it, right?

135
00:06:43.890 --> 00:06:46.950
So you'll always see these twice but
it's not actually two files.

136
00:06:46.950 --> 00:06:51.040
One is a link that points to
the other to hide the minor versions.

137
00:06:51.040 --> 00:06:53.670
Now major versions will show
up more than once, right?

138
00:06:53.670 --> 00:06:59.230
So you might see something like let's see,
do I have any that are duplicated in here?

139
00:06:59.230 --> 00:07:01.220
I might not have any.

140
00:07:01.220 --> 00:07:05.101
But you may, well, lib ISO 9660.

141
00:07:05.101 --> 00:07:09.720
Well, those are different ones,
plus plus versus regular.

142
00:07:09.720 --> 00:07:10.220
Well anyhow,

143
00:07:10.220 --> 00:07:13.030
you might see some where there's more
than one major version in there.

144
00:07:13.030 --> 00:07:16.120
You might have software
that depends on libjpeg 61,

145
00:07:16.120 --> 00:07:20.310
and it hasn't been updated
to support 62 yet.

146
00:07:20.310 --> 00:07:23.920
And so you might have both 61 and
62 right there in your libraries, right.

147
00:07:23.920 --> 00:07:24.980
That may happen.

148
00:07:24.980 --> 00:07:28.490
But for the minor versions, those
are just being linked to that name and

149
00:07:28.490 --> 00:07:31.800
they have that one common name
that the software ties into.

150
00:07:33.100 --> 00:07:35.200
Now, all of this stuff
can be really confusing.

151
00:07:35.200 --> 00:07:36.850
There's a lot of junk in here.

152
00:07:36.850 --> 00:07:39.620
So there's a few commands that
we can use to help kind of

153
00:07:39.620 --> 00:07:42.540
figure out what libraries are in place and
what we even care about.

154
00:07:43.760 --> 00:07:48.380
So the majority of this is
managed by a library daemon.

155
00:07:48.380 --> 00:07:51.698
There's this library daemon that's keeping
track of all the libraries on your system

156
00:07:51.698 --> 00:07:54.845
and what's linked where and what software
depends on what, and it's called LD.

157
00:07:54.845 --> 00:07:58.847
And LD and the LD configuration
is all stored inside of /etc, so

158
00:07:58.847 --> 00:08:01.532
it's got a record of all these libraries.

159
00:08:01.532 --> 00:08:03.306
And we can register libraries or

160
00:08:03.306 --> 00:08:06.601
deregister libraries to get
them out of our system System.

161
00:08:06.601 --> 00:08:08.760
Normally we don't have to.

162
00:08:08.760 --> 00:08:13.070
Normally Yum or AppGet or whatever,
they're taking care of it.

163
00:08:13.070 --> 00:08:21.730
So if I install some software,
let's say I do yum install mySQL-server.

164
00:08:21.730 --> 00:08:22.298
All right.

165
00:08:22.298 --> 00:08:25.040
So I wanna become a SQL server.

166
00:08:25.040 --> 00:08:27.050
And what have I done wrong here?

167
00:08:30.130 --> 00:08:34.840
Oh, shoot.
It's mariadb, now under sent OS.

168
00:08:34.840 --> 00:08:35.540
There we go.

169
00:08:35.540 --> 00:08:37.580
So if I want to install it,
it goes to install it and

170
00:08:37.580 --> 00:08:40.750
it it looks to see if I have
any missing dependencies.

171
00:08:40.750 --> 00:08:42.200
Right?
See where it says dependencies

172
00:08:42.200 --> 00:08:43.120
resolved here?

173
00:08:43.120 --> 00:08:44.980
And this one doesn't
have any dependencies.

174
00:08:44.980 --> 00:08:47.120
That means I either don't
have any dependencies, or

175
00:08:47.120 --> 00:08:49.970
I've already got them installed and
it's happy.

176
00:08:49.970 --> 00:08:54.570
But if I pick a software package
that I'm missing dependencies for,

177
00:08:54.570 --> 00:08:58.410
it'll recognize that, and
it'll go to install them and add them in.

178
00:08:58.410 --> 00:09:00.822

Okay?

00:20:15.770 --> 00:20:18.180
And when I run that,
it's going to create the link.

410
00:20:19.440 --> 00:20:22.910
And now, see how it's in blue and
it's got the pointer to the file?

411
00:20:22.910 --> 00:20:26.050
And that's because soft
link's linked to a path.

412
00:20:26.050 --> 00:20:30.350
If I were to move this file,
the link breaks, right?

413
00:20:30.350 --> 00:20:33.880
But in exchange for that one weakness,
I can now link to directories,

414
00:20:33.880 --> 00:20:38.610
I can link to files on other file systems,
I get a ton more flexibility.

415
00:20:38.610 --> 00:20:40.610
And so you will usually see these, right?

416
00:20:40.610 --> 00:20:42.210
Because they know that it's a library and

417
00:20:42.210 --> 00:20:45.500
you're not going to go moving a library
around, use the Softlink instead.

418
00:20:45.500 --> 00:20:48.370
>> Now they're also called like Symlinks
or Symbolic Links, right, as well.

419
00:20:48.370 --> 00:20:50.820
It's kind of the same nomenclature.

420
00:20:50.820 --> 00:20:53.270
>> Yes, it's some gestures
use different terminology

421
00:20:53.270 --> 00:20:55.720
Symbolic link is the right term.

422
00:20:55.720 --> 00:20:58.080
The one you use, Daniel's like,
I should be saying that.

423
00:20:58.080 --> 00:20:59.790
But yeah, a symbolic link.

424
00:20:59.790 --> 00:21:04.960
When we talk about a hard link, or a soft
link, those are types of symbolic links.

425
00:21:04.960 --> 00:21:08.490
And symbolic, right, it's just a symbol
that being stored in the file systems,

426
00:21:08.490 --> 00:21:12.440
that actually points to a file
being stored somewhere else.

427
00:21:12.440 --> 00:21:15.669
If you ever have to add
your own shared libraries,

428
00:21:16.700 --> 00:21:20.790
you can copy your library to one
of the existing library paths, and

429
00:21:20.790 --> 00:21:23.360
then you can add that soft
link in like I just did.

430
00:21:23.360 --> 00:21:25.480
And then you're in business.

431
00:21:25.480 --> 00:21:29.465
If you need to add it to your own path,
to somewhere else on the hard drive,

432
00:21:29.465 --> 00:21:32.915
that's when you have to go to that config
file that I showed you inside of /etc.

433
00:21:32.915 --> 00:21:35.065
And you've got to add an include
statement on there so

434
00:21:35.065 --> 00:21:37.225
that it'll link to your
folder to see that library.

435
00:21:37.225 --> 00:21:39.135
So a couple of extra steps to go through.

436
00:21:39.135 --> 00:21:41.879
But otherwise that's kind of
how we get them in there.

437
00:21:42.900 --> 00:21:48.140
You might have a situation where there's
an updated version of the library out, but

438
00:21:48.140 --> 00:21:50.620
whatever distro you're using
hasn't grabbed it yet.

439
00:21:50.620 --> 00:21:52.910
Great example of this would be CentOS,
right?

440
00:21:52.910 --> 00:21:56.650
With CentOS, when new libraries come out,
they don't adopt them right away.

441
00:21:56.650 --> 00:22:00.640
What happens is that Red Hat adopts them
>> And then Red Hat publishes the code,

442
00:22:00.640 --> 00:22:04.260
and then CentOS get that code and
incorporates it into theirs.

443
00:22:04.260 --> 00:22:06.150
They can be a few days behind.

444
00:22:06.150 --> 00:22:08.050
Well, if this is something critical
that you've been waiting on,

445
00:22:08.050 --> 00:22:09.700
you don't want to wait a few days.

446
00:22:09.700 --> 00:22:15.823
So, maybe CentOS's repositories
have libdonlibrary.so.5.1.2,

447
00:22:15.823 --> 00:22:19.812
but you need libdonlibary.so.5.1.3.

448
00:22:19.812 --> 00:22:22.930
Well you could go and download 5.1.3, and

449
00:22:22.930 --> 00:22:28.730
all you have to do is delete this link,
and then re-link it to the new version.

450
00:22:28.730 --> 00:22:35.170
So, I could come in here and, let's say
that I've got, where's my, here we go.

451
00:22:35.170 --> 00:22:38.502
So I get version 5.1.3 in, right?

452
00:22:38.502 --> 00:22:41.960
And so now when I look at it,

453
00:22:41.960 --> 00:22:46.820
I've got libdonlibrary.so.5
is pointing to 512.

454
00:22:46.820 --> 00:22:48.900
But I went out and
manually downloaded 513.

455
00:22:48.900 --> 00:22:52.410
It's not in my repositories yet,
I downloaded it myself.

456
00:22:52.410 --> 00:22:57.050
Well from here I can remove the simlink,
right?

457
00:22:57.050 --> 00:23:00.880
So I'm just going to remove that file,
and then I can relink it.

458
00:23:00.880 --> 00:23:06.080
And when I relink it,
I'll just point to 5.1.3 this time.

459
00:23:06.080 --> 00:23:10.160
All my software's still pointing at .5,
so they don't change.

460
00:23:10.160 --> 00:23:13.990
And now I've got this new library that my
software is able to use even though my

461
00:23:13.990 --> 00:23:15.650
distro doesn't support it yet.

462
00:23:15.650 --> 00:23:19.743
And now when I look at my links, sure
enough that parent is pointing to 5.1.3.

463
00:23:19.743 --> 00:23:23.480
I still have 5.1.2 in case I screw
something up I can flip back to it, right?

464
00:23:23.480 --> 00:23:25.230
But hopefully I don't have to.

465
00:23:25.230 --> 00:23:27.900
>> Is there ever an instance where you
might need both for the same piece of

466
00:23:27.900 --> 00:23:30.540
software and you have to link to
both of them, or anything like that?

467
00:23:30.540 --> 00:23:31.795
>> Yeah that is a real challenge.

468
00:23:31.795 --> 00:23:34.860
>> [LAUGH]
>> At Java is a great example of that.

469
00:23:34.860 --> 00:23:39.050
And that's why you rarely see Java
software linked to just the Java library.

470
00:23:39.050 --> 00:23:40.780
In fact, did we see that earlier?

471
00:23:40.780 --> 00:23:42.310
That was in one of my folders.

472
00:23:42.310 --> 00:23:43.190
Oh, this folder right here.

473
00:23:44.290 --> 00:23:49.950
If we look at my directory output,
see how there is a Java folder, right?

474
00:23:49.950 --> 00:23:54.970
But then right after that I've got
Java1.5, Java1.6, Java1.7, Java1.8.

475
00:23:54.970 --> 00:23:58.500
Well, each of those are considered
major versions of Java, so

476
00:23:58.500 --> 00:24:00.100
you've got all these different ones.

477
00:24:00.100 --> 00:24:03.840
The subversions, they don't break out,
so when we talk about Java,

478
00:24:03.840 --> 00:24:08.670
we usually leave the 1 off, and so Java
Runtime Library 6, or Java 7, or Java 8.

479
00:24:08.670 --> 00:24:12.560
Well, I know with like Java 8,
there's Java 8.1, all the way through 8.,

480
00:24:12.560 --> 00:24:15.650
seems like they're up to 53 now,
or something like that?

481
00:24:15.650 --> 00:24:16.840
They're pretty high.

482
00:24:16.840 --> 00:24:19.630
So, those you don't normally run
into a situation where you need.

483
00:24:19.630 --> 00:24:24.050
You might have some software tied to 8.22,
and some software tied to 8.53.

484
00:24:24.050 --> 00:24:25.890
But it does happen, and if that happens,

485
00:24:25.890 --> 00:24:28.140
there's really not a good
way to deal with that.

486
00:24:28.140 --> 00:24:30.140
And so the software that you're running,

487
00:24:30.140 --> 00:24:34.410
you may have to run it with like
manually specifying library paths.

488
00:24:34.410 --> 00:24:36.830
It's a pain in the butt,
but you can do it.

489
00:24:36.830 --> 00:24:40.310
But as far as major versions, you can
maintain more than one major version.

490
00:24:40.310 --> 00:24:44.910
I might of instead of donlibrary five,

491
00:24:44.910 --> 00:24:48.800
I might also have donlibrary
four sitting around.

492
00:24:48.800 --> 00:24:50.710
That's a major version that's easy.

493
00:24:50.710 --> 00:24:54.220
But for the minor versions it
becomes far more difficult, yeah.

494
00:24:54.220 --> 00:24:58.750
And I've seen a lot of software where
you don't just run the program itself,

495
00:24:58.750 --> 00:25:02.595
you run a script first that overrides
the library mappings before it runs.

496
00:25:02.595 --> 00:25:06.165
You can certainly do that and
that'll tie it to a particular one.

497
00:25:06.165 --> 00:25:06.895
>> Very cool.

498
00:25:06.895 --> 00:25:08.845
>> So, hopefully you don't
have to deal with that.

499
00:25:08.845 --> 00:25:09.623
That's always a mess.

500
00:25:09.623 --> 00:25:10.355
>> [LAUGH]
>> Yeah.

501
00:25:10.355 --> 00:25:11.745
Yeah.
>> Usually, if it's that case,

502
00:25:11.745 --> 00:25:13.165
you reach out to the vendor and
say "Hey guys,

503
00:25:13.165 --> 00:25:14.505
are you going to update your software?"
>> [LAUGH]

504
00:25:14.505 --> 00:25:15.656
>> It's kind of important.

505
00:25:16.817 --> 00:25:19.737
Well Don,
have we basically covered the libraries,

506
00:25:19.737 --> 00:25:22.637
it's very informative should I say.

507
00:25:22.637 --> 00:25:23.817
>> Yeah if you're a developer,

508
00:25:23.817 --> 00:25:25.737
you're probably thinking gosh Don
you didn't cover anything here.

509
00:25:25.737 --> 00:25:26.937
This was worthless.

510
00:25:26.937 --> 00:25:29.137
But that's fine,
this isn't a developer exam.

511
00:25:29.137 --> 00:25:31.827
As an administrator,
those are the basics you need to know.

512
00:25:31.827 --> 00:25:36.607
We saw what the libraries were, where
they reside, and we saw how to add or

513
00:25:36.607 --> 00:25:40.050
modify our own if we need to
to put in different entries.

514
00:25:40.050 --> 00:25:44.540
One word of caution, sometimes these
changes don't actually take effect until

515
00:25:44.540 --> 00:25:48.420
you reboot or reload the software that
you're running, so be careful with that.

516
00:25:48.420 --> 00:25:51.390
But normally we just change our links,
and we're in business.

517
00:25:51.390 --> 00:25:52.770
>> Awesome.
Well, good stuff, Don.

518
00:25:52.770 --> 00:25:56.750
It looks like we've wrapped up another
great episode for IT Pro TV signing off,

519
00:25:56.750 --> 00:25:59.200
I've been your host Daniel Lourie.

520
00:25:59.200 --> 00:25:59.890
>> And I'm Don Pizet.

521
00:25:59.890 --> 00:26:01.835
>> And we'll see you next time.

522
00:26:01.835 --> 00:26:06.238
[SOUND]

WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.026 --> 00:00:10.388

2
00:00:10.388 --> 00:00:11.034

3
00:00:11.034 --> 00:00:14.585
Greetings everyone, and welcome to
another great episode of ITProTV,

4
00:00:14.585 --> 00:00:16.225
I'll be your host Daniel Lowry.

5
00:00:16.225 --> 00:00:20.235
And here with me today is none other than
the Linux guru himself, Mr. Don Pezet.

6
00:00:20.235 --> 00:00:20.839
>> How are you doing Don?

7
00:00:20.839 --> 00:00:21.956
I'm doing great, [LAUGH] Daniel.

8
00:00:21.956 --> 00:00:24.068
I don't know about the guru tag,
but we'll run with it.

9
00:00:24.068 --> 00:00:28.916
[LAUGH] So, I'm really looking
forward to today's episode,

10
00:00:28.916 --> 00:00:32.232
because it ties back to a memory I have.

11
00:00:32.232 --> 00:00:33.962
We'll walk down memory lane here, right?

12
00:00:33.962 --> 00:00:38.104
So the year is 1996, right, you are there.

13
00:00:38.104 --> 00:00:40.002
Actually, I guess it was 1994.

14
00:00:40.002 --> 00:00:42.042
Yeah, all right, the year is 1994!

15
00:00:42.042 --> 00:00:43.667
You are there.

16
00:00:43.667 --> 00:00:45.632
And I'm having a conversation
with my friend Nick.

17
00:00:45.632 --> 00:00:47.510
Now, at the time, I was running a,

18
00:00:47.510 --> 00:00:49.460
like a little bulletin board
system on my computer.

19
00:00:49.460 --> 00:00:51.950
And I was running it on top of Deskview,
Deskview X, or

20
00:00:51.950 --> 00:00:53.680
actually it was just
regular Deskview then.

21
00:00:53.680 --> 00:00:56.890
And I had another OS/2 system and so

22
00:00:56.890 --> 00:01:00.510
multitasking operating systems
were not unusual to me.

23
00:01:00.510 --> 00:01:03.640
I was used to systems that could
run more than one thing at a time.

24
00:01:03.640 --> 00:01:05.930
But they all work using time slicing,

25
00:01:05.930 --> 00:01:08.690
which is not the best
way to do multi-tasking.

26
00:01:08.690 --> 00:01:11.490
And my friend, Nick, tells me,
Don, you gotta check this out.

27
00:01:11.490 --> 00:01:12.540
There's this new operating system.

28
00:01:12.540 --> 00:01:18.530
It's called Linux, and
when you see the x window system and

29
00:01:18.530 --> 00:01:21.505
the multi-tasking on it it
will make you wet your pants.

30
00:01:21.505 --> 00:01:22.840
>> [LAUGH]
>> I remember to this day that's what he

31
00:01:22.840 --> 00:01:24.370
said, it will make you wet your pants.

32
00:01:24.370 --> 00:01:24.990
>> Quote unquote.

33
00:01:24.990 --> 00:01:26.200
[LAUGH]
>> And I said whatever,

34
00:01:26.200 --> 00:01:28.740
cuz I had OS/2,
I was really happy with OS/2.

35
00:01:28.740 --> 00:01:29.860
And I had Deskview.

36
00:01:29.860 --> 00:01:32.740
I was doing all sorts of multi tasking.

37
00:01:32.740 --> 00:01:36.540
And when I fired up Linux,
and Slackware Linux,

38
00:01:36.540 --> 00:01:37.680
it was the first distro that I used.

39
00:01:37.680 --> 00:01:41.100
I downloaded the floppy disks and
I installed it.

40
00:01:41.100 --> 00:01:43.264
I didn't wet my pants,
but I was impressed.

41
00:01:43.264 --> 00:01:44.819
>> [LAUGH]
>> I was really impressed.

42
00:01:44.819 --> 00:01:48.720
The multitasking nature inside
of Unix based operating systems

43
00:01:48.720 --> 00:01:50.270
is just inherent to the OS.

44
00:01:50.270 --> 00:01:54.610
It's not like the old Windows where
they added it on after the fact.

45
00:01:54.610 --> 00:01:57.580
This it was built in from the very
beginning to be able to multitask.

46
00:01:57.580 --> 00:01:58.950
It was really amazing.

47
00:01:59.990 --> 00:02:02.740
But, with great power comes
great responsibility.

48
00:02:02.740 --> 00:02:06.310
As we start running more and
more programs all at the same time,

49
00:02:06.310 --> 00:02:09.137
we run the risk of getting
our system too bogged down.

50
00:02:09.137 --> 00:02:13.220
And, even aside from that,
when we talk about multitasking,

51
00:02:13.220 --> 00:02:15.160
most people think about
Window operating systems.

52
00:02:15.160 --> 00:02:18.360
So they fire up these OSes and
they start opening up multiple windows.

53
00:02:18.360 --> 00:02:20.420
What if you just have the command line?

54
00:02:20.420 --> 00:02:23.249
Well, Linux can multitask
from the command-line,

55
00:02:23.249 --> 00:02:25.100
doing a great job of it, right.

56
00:02:25.100 --> 00:02:27.540
So that's what we're gonna take
a look at in this episode is

57
00:02:27.540 --> 00:02:30.720
how we can run more than one process
at the same time from the command-line,

58
00:02:30.720 --> 00:02:35.180
how we can manage those processes, and how
we can really get some great multitasking

59
00:02:35.180 --> 00:02:38.700
out of a system that doesn't even have
a GUI, and it's really powerful stuff.

60
00:02:38.700 --> 00:02:42.680
And it is what got me to
install Linux back in 1994 for

61
00:02:42.680 --> 00:02:45.140
the first time,
[COUGH] it was this functionality.

62
00:02:45.140 --> 00:02:46.290
>> Wow.
That's pretty cool.

63
00:02:46.290 --> 00:02:47.480
Let's dive into it.

64
00:02:47.480 --> 00:02:49.340
>> All right, so, it's time for
our walk down memory lane.

65
00:02:49.340 --> 00:02:51.990
So, first thing [COUGH] is we need
to understand what's going on in

66
00:02:51.990 --> 00:02:52.990
the background.

67
00:02:52.990 --> 00:02:56.730
When we log in to Linux, right, so
I've got my command prompt fired up here.

68
00:02:56.730 --> 00:02:57.940
I start to run commands.

69
00:02:57.940 --> 00:02:59.610
So, I do something like LS, right.

70
00:02:59.610 --> 00:03:01.170
Give me a directory listing.

71
00:03:01.170 --> 00:03:05.950
Well, that directory listing, I didn't
run that, my shell didn't even run that.

72
00:03:05.950 --> 00:03:09.570
It turned around and
told the Linux kernel to run it, and

73
00:03:09.570 --> 00:03:13.220
if you run newname-A you'll
see your Linux kernel.

74
00:03:13.220 --> 00:03:16.190
So this system is running
Linux kernel 3.13.

75
00:03:16.190 --> 00:03:19.050
It's running in the background, it says
that I'm running a 64 bit bluetooth but

76
00:03:19.050 --> 00:03:21.100
I think this is actually,
wait what is this?

77
00:03:21.100 --> 00:03:21.625
Is it a Bluetooth?

78
00:03:21.625 --> 00:03:22.680
This is mint.

79
00:03:22.680 --> 00:03:23.280
It's mint,

80
00:03:23.280 --> 00:03:27.645
which is based on a Bluetooth which is
based on a Devine, it's all inbred.

81
00:03:27.645 --> 00:03:29.410
[LAUGH] So anyhow,
the kernel in the background,

82
00:03:29.410 --> 00:03:31.650
that Linux kernel, that's what runs it.

83
00:03:31.650 --> 00:03:34.810
And it doesn't matter if you're
running Red Hat, CentOS, Ubuntu,

84
00:03:34.810 --> 00:03:37.070
Debian, Mint, whatever.

85
00:03:37.070 --> 00:03:41.350
All of them are different distros,
they have different choices they've made.

86
00:03:41.350 --> 00:03:43.790
But the kernel is that Linux kernel.

87
00:03:43.790 --> 00:03:45.870
And so in this case I'm running 3.13.

88
00:03:45.870 --> 00:03:48.600
And that's what actually ran
the software that I ran.

89
00:03:48.600 --> 00:03:51.450
When I ran LS, it's that kernel
that went and did the work.

90
00:03:51.450 --> 00:03:55.000
And that kernel is capable of doing
more than one thing at a time.

91
00:03:55.000 --> 00:03:56.040
All right.

92
00:03:56.040 --> 00:03:59.400
And even when I'm sitting here
at a shell prompt like this,

93
00:03:59.400 --> 00:04:01.960
it's likely doing more than
one thing at a time already.

94
00:04:01.960 --> 00:04:03.790
Cuz Daniel, you're logged into
the same machine, aren't you?

95
00:04:03.790 --> 00:04:04.740
>> I am.

96
00:04:04.740 --> 00:04:06.120
So Daniel's got a shell open to it.

97
00:04:06.120 --> 00:04:07.060
I've got a shell open to it.

98
00:04:07.060 --> 00:04:09.530
At a minimum it's presenting
two shells at once, but

99
00:04:09.530 --> 00:04:11.710
the reality is it's doing a lot more.

100
00:04:11.710 --> 00:04:14.410
If you ever want to see what your system
is doing we have a great command called

101
00:04:14.410 --> 00:04:16.370
PS, that's the process command.

102
00:04:16.370 --> 00:04:18.770
And PS has been around
since the UNIX days.

103
00:04:18.770 --> 00:04:21.820
It should be supported on every system,
even BSD systems.

104
00:04:21.820 --> 00:04:25.290
And it can display for
us everything that our display is doing.

105
00:04:25.290 --> 00:04:29.600
If I run PS-a, like that.

106
00:04:29.600 --> 00:04:33.060
It's going to give me a list of all the
processes that are running on the system.

107
00:04:33.060 --> 00:04:35.780
Now, if I'm an administrator
I'll see a lot.

108
00:04:35.780 --> 00:04:39.800
If I'm not an administrator this may
be limited to more of what I'm seeing

109
00:04:39.800 --> 00:04:41.320
just from my own session.

110
00:04:41.320 --> 00:04:44.550
So if you get a really short list back,
then you're probably not an admin and

111
00:04:44.550 --> 00:04:45.720
you're not seeing that.

112
00:04:45.720 --> 00:04:47.400
But you can see all this stuff.

113

00:26:35.990 --> 00:26:38.699
So we can do what's called a killall,

571
00:26:38.699 --> 00:26:42.863
which will allow us to kill more
than one process at a time.

572
00:26:42.863 --> 00:26:45.063
It's kind of important we
specify what that process is.

573
00:26:45.063 --> 00:26:48.120
Now I'm gonna do a swdo cuz I
think I ran some of these as root.

574
00:26:48.120 --> 00:26:50.810
So as just my regular user I
won't be able to terminate those.

575
00:26:50.810 --> 00:26:55.170
But I'm gonna do a killall -i stress, and

576
00:26:55.170 --> 00:26:58.770
this will look for
any process named stress and kill it.

577
00:26:58.770 --> 00:27:03.221
So here it just found on 8438, and there's
8439 and I said yes on both of those.

578
00:27:03.221 --> 00:27:07.995
There is actually, if we pull up the main
page there's an option where you

579
00:27:07.995 --> 00:27:10.239
can tell it to do it quietly, -q.

580
00:27:10.239 --> 00:27:14.070
If you do a -q then it's not
gonna prompt you for each one.

581
00:27:14.070 --> 00:27:21.050
And so we could say just pseudo
killall -q -i stress, right?

582
00:27:21.050 --> 00:27:22.140
Just quietly do it.

583
00:27:22.140 --> 00:27:25.020
Kill any process named stress, and
it's gonna knock them all out.

584
00:27:25.020 --> 00:27:29.050
And when that's done, you can look at your
processes and verify that it is gone.

585
00:27:29.050 --> 00:27:30.180
I don't have it anymore.

586
00:27:31.420 --> 00:27:34.770
Now if we want to filter that
a bit just to make sure,

587
00:27:34.770 --> 00:27:38.220
I can pipe that into grep, and
look for any process named stress.

588
00:27:38.220 --> 00:27:39.470
I don't get anything.

589
00:27:39.470 --> 00:27:41.870
And a lot of Linux distros actually
have a short cut for that.

590
00:27:41.870 --> 00:27:45.890
They'll have, let's see,
what is it, psgrep or pgrep?

591
00:27:45.890 --> 00:27:47.731
>> Yeah, pgrep, yeah.
>> It's pgrep.

592
00:27:47.731 --> 00:27:50.080
We're gonna say pgrep stress.

593
00:27:50.080 --> 00:27:55.310
And that'll basically run ps -a
piped into a grep command for you.

594
00:27:55.310 --> 00:27:58.780
So you can quickly see if you're
running any of those processes.

595
00:27:58.780 --> 00:28:04.160
So here I did a pgraph from my sld and
I am running a process id of 8089.

596
00:28:04.160 --> 00:28:07.644
And so then I can come in,
I can say kill 8089 and

597
00:28:07.644 --> 00:28:11.450
I can redo that with a sudo and
that'll kill that.

598
00:28:11.450 --> 00:28:12.824
And now I've stopped MySQL.

599
00:28:12.824 --> 00:28:15.941
So, couple of neat ways to manage
this stuff from the command line.

600
00:28:15.941 --> 00:28:19.199
The coolest part here is we're
multitasking from a command line

601
00:28:19.199 --> 00:28:20.420
environment.

602
00:28:20.420 --> 00:28:22.940
And a lot of people get this predisposed
notion that you can't do that.

603
00:28:22.940 --> 00:28:24.580
Oh, if I want to multitask,
I gotta have Windows.

604
00:28:25.750 --> 00:28:27.220
No, you don't need a Windows system.

605
00:28:27.220 --> 00:28:30.420
You don't need X-Windows, or
even Microsoft Windows, whatever for that.

606
00:28:30.420 --> 00:28:34.505
You go right here from the command line,
Linux is built to multi-task,

607
00:28:34.505 --> 00:28:37.635
it's built to run many,
many things at the same time.

608
00:28:37.635 --> 00:28:38.154
Take advantage of it.

609
00:28:38.154 --> 00:28:40.505
>> Yeah.
Now I would want to mention as well,

610
00:28:40.505 --> 00:28:44.775
with the kill command, you do have some
signals that you can send to that.

611
00:28:44.775 --> 00:28:47.319
And sometimes you get a process
that just doesn't want to die,

612
00:28:47.319 --> 00:28:48.615
no matter what you do.

613
00:28:48.615 --> 00:28:53.094
And if you send the signal of a 9,
which is the kill it no matter what,

614
00:28:53.094 --> 00:28:57.270
it's basically forcing it to die,
then it will, usually.

615
00:28:57.270 --> 00:28:59.740
I've never had a problem with Kill-9,

616
00:28:59.740 --> 00:29:02.110
making sure that something
goes out of there.

617
00:29:02.110 --> 00:29:06.095
>> Yeah, and the syntax, just like
Daniel mentioned there, it's Kill-9, and

618
00:29:06.095 --> 00:29:08.570
then the name of the process
that you want to kill.

619
00:29:08.570 --> 00:29:11.560
And it is terminating with
extreme prejudice, right?

620
00:29:11.560 --> 00:29:13.130
>> Yes.
>> That's when you want them gone.

621
00:29:13.130 --> 00:29:14.157
>> That's using the 50 cal.

622
00:29:14.157 --> 00:29:17.930
>> [CROSSTALK] [LAUGH]
>> On a squirrel.

623
00:29:17.930 --> 00:29:19.280
>> All right, well Daniel, I think,

624
00:29:19.280 --> 00:29:22.040
as far as basic process management,
that's about all we got for today.

625
00:29:22.040 --> 00:29:23.140
You got anything else you wanna throw in?

626
00:29:23.140 --> 00:29:25.120
>> No, I think that's about
all we have for today,

627
00:29:25.120 --> 00:29:28.340
wrapped up another great show for
ITProTV Studios.

628
00:29:28.340 --> 00:29:30.389
Signing off,
I've been your host Daniel Lowry.

629
00:29:30.389 --> 00:29:31.514
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

630
00:29:31.514 --> 00:29:32.590
>> And we'll see you next time.

631
00:29:32.590 --> 00:29:38.490
[MUSIC]

episodes.title: Configuring Hardware
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.578
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:10.578 --> 00:00:14.010
All right everyone, greetings and welcome
to another great episode of ITproTV.

3
00:00:14.010 --> 00:00:16.290
I'll be your host Daniel Lowrie.

4
00:00:16.290 --> 00:00:18.710
Here with me today is,
well it's Don Pezet.

5
00:00:18.710 --> 00:00:19.590
How you doing today Don?

6
00:00:19.590 --> 00:00:22.775
>> There was that moment of doubt,
where I was like, does he know who I am?

7
00:00:22.775 --> 00:00:24.480
[LAUGH] l am doing great today Daniel.

8
00:00:24.480 --> 00:00:28.530
We are jumping into a hardware based
episode, which is a little bit different

9
00:00:28.530 --> 00:00:30.810
than a lot of what we've been
talking about in this series.

10
00:00:30.810 --> 00:00:34.780
We've focused on the Linux operating
system and the software side of things.

11
00:00:34.780 --> 00:00:38.420
We do kinda lose sight sometimes that
Linux is running on top of our hardware

12
00:00:38.420 --> 00:00:41.270
and it's got to be able to recognize and
deal with the hardware.

13
00:00:41.270 --> 00:00:43.797
Now Daniel, I remember when
I first started with Linux,

14
00:00:43.797 --> 00:00:47.536
this was the biggest challenge, to get you
know you picked your distro based on which

15
00:00:47.536 --> 00:00:49.816
one recognized the most of your hardware,
right?

16
00:00:49.816 --> 00:00:50.761
>> That's exactly right.

17
00:00:50.761 --> 00:00:52.740
>> It didn't even come
down to your preference.

18
00:00:52.740 --> 00:00:56.960
It was, man, if I run Fedora,
it'll recognize my wireless card.

19
00:00:56.960 --> 00:01:00.680
But if I run Debian I get
this other software, and

20
00:01:00.680 --> 00:01:02.230
you had to kinda pick and choose.

21
00:01:02.230 --> 00:01:04.030
It's become a lot better since then,
right?

22
00:01:04.030 --> 00:01:04.590
>> Oh, yeah.

23
00:01:04.590 --> 00:01:06.260
It's just night and day.

24
00:01:06.260 --> 00:01:10.320
Back when we first started using it,
I remember trying to get a DVD burner to

25
00:01:10.320 --> 00:01:14.370
work in my Linux tile and
I was just like, this is impossible.

26
00:01:14.370 --> 00:01:18.210
This is the reason that no one goes to
Linux, and I'm thinking about giving up.

27
00:01:18.210 --> 00:01:21.046
And then I got it to work, and
I felt better about my life.

28
00:01:21.046 --> 00:01:22.440
[LAUGH]
>> You do get a sense of achievement,

29
00:01:22.440 --> 00:01:23.770
which is nice.

30
00:01:23.770 --> 00:01:27.580
Well, most users, if you're just
starting out with Linux today,

31
00:01:27.580 --> 00:01:29.500
well we're kind of pretty
far in this series, so

32
00:01:29.500 --> 00:01:31.780
maybe a few days ago when you
started watching the show,

33
00:01:31.780 --> 00:01:35.390
then you probably haven't had to deal with
much in the way of hardware troubles.

34
00:01:35.390 --> 00:01:39.950
Because the Linux distributors have gotten
so good about packaging drivers and

35
00:01:39.950 --> 00:01:42.680
open source support for
drivers have become a lot better,

36
00:01:42.680 --> 00:01:46.340
that today it's not uncommon to
install Linux on your hardware and

37
00:01:46.340 --> 00:01:47.700
everything just works
right out of the box.

38
00:01:47.700 --> 00:01:50.590
You don't have to tweak with anything and
it works great.

39
00:01:50.590 --> 00:01:52.560
But it doesn't always work great.

40
00:01:52.560 --> 00:01:55.290
So in this episode we're gonna talk
about how to recognize whether our

41
00:01:55.290 --> 00:01:58.220
hardware is being detected,
if we're having problems with hardware,

42
00:01:58.220 --> 00:02:01.170
some of the things we can do, and some of
the other interactions that we've got.

43
00:02:01.170 --> 00:02:03.390
So that's kind of what we've got lined up.

44
00:02:03.390 --> 00:02:06.730
And I want to start with something
that's not really Linux related.

45
00:02:06.730 --> 00:02:10.120
I wanna start with just
the BIOS of your system.

46
00:02:10.120 --> 00:02:14.350
Now, when you have a laptop or
a desktop and you press that power button,

47
00:02:14.350 --> 00:02:18.350
the first thing that comes up is not
Linux, it's the BIOS for your system,

48
00:02:18.350 --> 00:02:21.370
your Basic Input Output System
that kicks in.

49
00:02:21.370 --> 00:02:24.000
And one of the reasons why we have so

50
00:02:24.000 --> 00:02:28.270
much great compatibility today is that
the BIOS, which used to be fairly simple,

51
00:02:28.270 --> 00:02:32.190
has gotten more and more complex and
it does a lot more than it used to.

52
00:02:32.190 --> 00:02:36.790
So on a modern system, you're typically
gonna have an EFI or UEFI BIOS on it.

53
00:02:36.790 --> 00:02:40.850
And when your system boots up,
that BIOS is able to do a lot,

54
00:02:40.850 --> 00:02:43.930
including looking at the hard drives and
finding the operating systems and

55
00:02:43.930 --> 00:02:46.760
booting a particular OS
on a particular drive.

56
00:02:46.760 --> 00:02:48.240
Whereas BIOS in the past couldn't do that.

57
00:02:48.240 --> 00:02:52.620
It would just say, let me just throw
this at this drive and see what happens.

58
00:02:52.620 --> 00:02:55.690
Now UEFI actually has an understanding
what's on that drive.

59
00:02:55.690 --> 00:02:59.170
So that gives us a lot more
compatibility and flexibility, and

60
00:02:59.170 --> 00:03:02.060
as a result we don't normally
have to go to our BIOS.

61
00:03:02.060 --> 00:03:03.740
But on the exam,
they expect you to know that.

62
00:03:03.740 --> 00:03:06.926
So just in case you don't have it,
I wanna show you guys an example.

63
00:03:06.926 --> 00:03:10.910
Now, if you've never access the BIOS of
your system, it's a little different for

64
00:03:10.910 --> 00:03:11.930
different hardware.

65
00:03:11.930 --> 00:03:16.090
When you boot your system up, there's
normally a keyboard combination that you

66
00:03:16.090 --> 00:03:19.730
hit, and the most common ones are,
you'll see a little message on your screen

67
00:03:19.730 --> 00:03:24.030
that'll say, press F1 to access setup or
press F2 for BIOS configuration utility.

68
00:03:24.030 --> 00:03:27.960
Press F11, I've seen control F11,
that one's annoying.

69
00:03:27.960 --> 00:03:31.450
You know there's different ones you
have to hit keyboard combinations on

70
00:03:31.450 --> 00:03:33.110
to get it to the BIOS.

71
00:03:33.110 --> 00:03:38.240
There's other systems, like some of the
Toshiba Satellites or any Apple system,

72
00:03:38.240 --> 00:03:42.360
where they don't let you get to the BIOS,
it's locked away and you can't get to it.

73
00:03:42.360 --> 00:03:45.590
Sometimes you have that, sometimes it's
very obvious that you can't do it.

74
00:03:45.590 --> 00:03:48.540
If you can access the BIOS in your system,
there's

75
00:03:48.540 --> 00:03:51.700
really only a couple of settings we need
to worry about from a Linux perspective,

76
00:03:51.700 --> 00:03:54.340
so let me walk you through a few of those.

77
00:03:54.340 --> 00:04:00.570
Now I've got one of the Lenovo BIOS
emulators so this isn't my actual laptop.

78
00:04:00.570 --> 00:04:04.480
But what you can see is what you'd expect
when you get into the BIOS for a system.

79
00:04:04.480 --> 00:04:07.000
It's usually very basic,
text-based like this.

80
00:04:07.000 --> 00:04:08.680
It might have graphics, some of them do,

81
00:04:08.680 --> 00:04:11.480
but most of them look just
like this right here.

82
00:04:11.480 --> 00:04:14.200
And the first screen will probably give
you something that's like a summary

83
00:04:14.200 --> 00:04:17.690
of your hardware,
the amount of memory in your system,

84
00:04:17.690 --> 00:04:19.340
and other resources like that.

85
00:04:20.390 --> 00:04:23.340
When we go into configuration,
the most important things for

86
00:04:23.340 --> 00:04:26.940
us here are gonna be the date and
the hard drive configuration right?

87
00:04:26.940 --> 00:04:28.590
Those are usually the only
things that we care about,

88
00:04:28.590 --> 00:04:30.310
the rest of it we usually
leave at the default.

89
00:04:30.310 --> 00:04:32.290
But let's just walk through a few
of these to make sure that we're

90
00:04:32.290 --> 00:04:33.700
comfortable with it.

91
00:04:33.700 --> 00:04:36.960
Now you might ask yourself,
why is the date and time important?

92
00:04:36.960 --> 00:04:38.470
All right.

93
00:04:38.470 --> 00:04:41.510
Well your system has
a hardware clock in it.

94
00:04:41.510 --> 00:04:45.310
And by default Linux is gonna rely on that
hardware clock to know what time it is.

95
00:04:45.310 --> 00:04:49.080
And when you power your computer off,
Linux stops running.

96
00:04:49.080 --> 00:04:50.390
But your BIOS keeps running.

97
00:04:50.390 --> 00:04:53.130
It's got a battery, it keeps
running when your computer is off.

98
00:04:53.130 --> 00:04:56.190
And so when you turn your computer on
again, your computer knows exactly how

99
00:04:56.190 --> 00:04:59.870
much time has passed because of
the BIOS clock, the system clock.

100
00:04:59.870 --> 00:05:01.780
And so, Linux relies on that.

101
00:05:01.780 --> 00:05:04.590
Even if you're using an NTP server,
this is required for

102
00:05:04.590 --> 00:05:07.158
having accurate time at boot up.

103
00:05:07.158 --> 00:05:09.390
So we wanna make sure the time
is accurate in here and

104
00:05:09.390 --> 00:05:12.360
it may not be, it might have the wrong
date, it might have the wrong time.

105
00:05:12.360 --> 00:05:17.370
We'll need to adjust and change those
settings to reflect the current values.

106
00:05:17.370 --> 00:05:21.140
Then there's various hardware
you can turn on and off.

107
00:05:21.140 --> 00:05:23.840
If you've got a wireless adapter in
your system and you're not gonna use it,

108
00:05:23.840 --> 00:05:25.210
you might want to turn it off.

109
00:05:25.210 --> 00:05:26.600
Right?
Especially if it's like a server,

110
00:05:26.600 --> 00:05:28.230
you don't need wireless there.

111
00:05:28.230 --> 00:05:32.110
So certain things like sound cards and
USB you might want to disable, and

112
00:05:32.110 --> 00:05:33.530
you can disable those in BIOS.

113
00:05:33.530 --> 00:05:37.230
You might find that USB is not working in
Linux, and you're pulling your hair out

114
00:05:37.230 --> 00:05:40.810
trying to get it to work and it turns
out that it's just disabled in BIOS.

115
00:05:40.810 --> 00:05:44.170
So Linux never even had
the opportunity to make it work and

116
00:05:44.170 --> 00:05:46.760
we need to put the blame where it belongs,
right here in the BIOS.

117
00:05:48.440 --> 00:05:52.870
Other things, SATA Controller working
mode, you see this one a lot.

118
00:05:52.870 --> 00:05:54.900
This is your hard drive controller.

119
00:05:54.900 --> 00:05:58.910
A lot of motherboards have three
modes that they can run in for this.

120
00:05:58.910 --> 00:06:02.640
You'll see this one shows just two modes,
IDE and AHCI.

121
00:06:03.670 --> 00:06:07.320
IDE is the old method for
accessing disc storage.

122
00:06:07.320 --> 00:06:09.790
It's slower, but it's super compatible.

123
00:06:09.790 --> 00:06:13.080
It'll work with every Linux
distro that's out there.

124
00:06:13.080 --> 00:06:14.740
AHCI is the newer method.

125
00:06:14.740 --> 00:06:17.570
It attains higher speeds,
gives you more reliability,

126
00:06:17.570 --> 00:06:19.040
allows for larger hard drives.

127
00:06:19.040 --> 00:06:21.920
And so it allows a lot of stuff.

128
00:06:21.920 --> 00:06:24.590
But it may not be compatible
with every distro out there.

129
00:06:24.590 --> 00:06:27.030
Now, I'll tell you,
I think every distro these days is, so

130
00:06:27.030 --> 00:06:28.630
it's not such a big deal.

131
00:06:28.630 --> 00:06:33.120
But you might also have a third mode,
and that third mode might be RAID.

132
00:06:33.120 --> 00:06:36.220
Your motherboard might have an integrated
RAID controller in it, and there, I'll

133
00:06:36.220 --> 00:06:39.440
tell you it's a crapshoot whether Linux is
gonna support that RAID controller or not.

134
00:06:41.560 --> 00:06:43.434
I'd probably say I have
a 50% hit rate on that one.

135
00:06:43.434 --> 00:06:45.650
>> [LAUGH]
>> if you have an Intel RAID controller

136
00:06:45.650 --> 00:06:48.450
integrated into your motherboard,
Linux will probably support it.

137
00:06:48.450 --> 00:06:52.230
If it's any other vendor, it's really
really hit or miss, and you're not sure.

138
00:06:52.230 --> 00:06:55.430
And I've even seen some Intel ones that
didn't work quite right under Linux.

139
00:06:55.430 --> 00:06:57.765
So, even though you've got
an onboard RAID controller,

140
00:06:57.765 --> 00:07:02.565
you might wanna choose AHCI anyway and
disable that onboard RAID.

141
00:07:02.565 --> 00:07:05.505
And put in a separate RAID controller
that you know is supported.

142
00:07:05.505 --> 00:07:09.083
Or you might wanna do redundancy
inside of Linux in software.

143
00:07:09.083 --> 00:07:12.600
It's not as good for performance, but you
know those are options that are available.

144
00:07:12.600 --> 00:07:14.230
And those are thing that
we might want to tweak.

145
00:07:16.780 --> 00:07:18.350
Other things that we might
want to modify here,

146
00:07:18.350 --> 00:07:21.480
you've got security settings if you
want to set like a BIOS password.

147
00:07:21.480 --> 00:07:24.190
But the boot order, is the next one.

148
00:07:24.190 --> 00:07:27.850
And the boot order is gonna influence,
like if we wanna install Linux and

149
00:07:27.850 --> 00:07:29.610
I've got a bootable USB key or

150
00:07:29.610 --> 00:07:33.400
a bootable CD drive, I've gotta make
sure my boot order reflects that.

151
00:07:33.400 --> 00:07:35.020
That I can boot from the CD.

152
00:07:35.020 --> 00:07:39.640
Look at this one,
we've got USB floppy disk controller.

153
00:07:39.640 --> 00:07:43.480
If you've got a USB floppy,
which I think most of us don't,

154
00:07:43.480 --> 00:07:46.260
then you've got IDE hard drive,
Hitachi whatever.

155
00:07:46.260 --> 00:07:47.716
So it's gonna boot from this hard drive.

156
00:07:47.716 --> 00:07:49.986
If that hard drive doesn't
have a bootable OS,

157
00:07:49.986 --> 00:07:52.779
then it's gonna boot to
an optical disc drive, this DVD.

158
00:07:52.779 --> 00:07:55.403
Well, if I'm trying to
install Linux from a DVD And

159
00:07:55.403 --> 00:07:59.553
I've already got Windows on the hard
drive, it boots from the hard drive first,

00:29:51.570 --> 00:29:54.538
I'm just gonna break out of that, so.

610
00:29:54.538 --> 00:29:59.538
All right, there's one other thing
that might show up on the exam.

611
00:29:59.538 --> 00:30:03.550
If I wanna look at the modules that
are loaded, I use LS mod, right?

612
00:30:03.550 --> 00:30:05.400
It's super easy, it's there.

613
00:30:05.400 --> 00:30:07.990
But there is another
thing that you can do.

614
00:30:07.990 --> 00:30:11.148
The modules actually create
these process files, and

615
00:30:11.148 --> 00:30:14.312
the process files are stored
in the /proc directory.

616
00:30:14.312 --> 00:30:19.090
So another way I can kinda see
what modules are loaded is I

617
00:30:19.090 --> 00:30:22.764
can run cat /proc/modules, all right?

618
00:30:22.764 --> 00:30:26.140
And when you run that, it gives you
a list of the modules that are running.

619
00:30:26.140 --> 00:30:29.310
Now, that's not really any
different than LS mod,

620
00:30:29.310 --> 00:30:31.950
except that it does give you
a little additional information.

621
00:30:31.950 --> 00:30:35.350
With LS mod I saw the module, its size,

622
00:30:35.350 --> 00:30:39.610
a status ID number, which I forget
what all those are mapped to, and

623
00:30:39.610 --> 00:30:43.300
then just an alternate name for
the dependencies of the modules right?

624
00:30:43.300 --> 00:30:47.140
So I can see SCSI transport
has a dependency of NPTSPI,

625
00:30:47.140 --> 00:30:50.940
which is right up here in loaded,
so you can see those dependencies.

626
00:30:50.940 --> 00:30:54.879
When I look at the proc values here,
I see the module name, I see their size,

627
00:30:54.879 --> 00:30:56.867
their status, their dependencies.

628
00:30:56.867 --> 00:31:00.919
But I also see whether it's live or
not, which they should all be live and

629
00:31:00.919 --> 00:31:03.390
then I can see an address
that it's tied to.

630
00:31:03.390 --> 00:31:06.171
So you get a little bit more information
when you do it that way, but

631
00:31:06.171 --> 00:31:08.570
otherwise it's the same basic information.

632
00:31:08.570 --> 00:31:12.160
And that's just me pulling
up what's in /proc/modules.

633
00:31:12.160 --> 00:31:16.270
That file stores that data for
each of the modules that are loaded.

634
00:31:16.270 --> 00:31:18.760
LS mod is querying that, too,
it's just cleaning it up for us and

635
00:31:18.760 --> 00:31:19.690
making it look a little nicer.

636
00:31:21.160 --> 00:31:24.200
Let's see, who else do I have in here?

637
00:31:24.200 --> 00:31:29.362
Same thing goes for LSPCI and LSUSB, those
are really mapping up to directories also.

638
00:31:29.362 --> 00:31:35.351
If I were to really poke around
in here in the /sys folder.

639
00:31:35.351 --> 00:31:37.407
So we don't normally
mess with the sys folder.

640
00:31:37.407 --> 00:31:38.325
It's a system folder, right?

641
00:31:38.325 --> 00:31:39.728
We shouldn't have to mess with it.

642
00:31:39.728 --> 00:31:43.840
But if we dig in there and
we go into like the bus folder, so

643
00:31:43.840 --> 00:31:46.946
I'm in /sys/bus, these are my busses.

644
00:31:46.946 --> 00:31:50.263
And you'll see in here the pci bus,
the usb bus, right?

645
00:31:50.263 --> 00:31:53.640
These are all in here, and
you kinda see what's tied to them.

646
00:31:53.640 --> 00:31:56.450
If I wanna see what's tied to the usb bus,
I could dig into that, or

647
00:31:56.450 --> 00:31:59.720
if I go into the pci bus, for
example, we can go in there.

648
00:31:59.720 --> 00:32:01.990
And here's where your drivers get loaded.

649
00:32:01.990 --> 00:32:05.160
When you install a driver package,
they're getting copied here.

650
00:32:05.160 --> 00:32:07.890
So if I have some custom sound card, or

651
00:32:07.890 --> 00:32:11.980
I download those Nvidia drivers, they're
gonna end up in here with the folder for

652
00:32:11.980 --> 00:32:14.520
Nvidia, and
that's where the driver will be present.

653
00:32:14.520 --> 00:32:17.149
And modprobe and LS mod,
they know how to look for that, right,

654
00:32:17.149 --> 00:32:19.407
to be able to load the right modules for
that hardware.

655
00:32:21.960 --> 00:32:25.995
All right, so Daniel, I know we've been
talking about this for 30 minutes now, but

656
00:32:25.995 --> 00:32:29.221
I can kinda summarize it all into
just a couple of sentences, right?

657
00:32:29.221 --> 00:32:33.008
If we have hardware problems,
don't rule out BIOS, right?

658
00:32:33.008 --> 00:32:36.260
Cuz BIOS applies before Linux,
they can cause things not to show up.

659
00:32:36.260 --> 00:32:38.070
Number two, check your drivers.

660
00:32:38.070 --> 00:32:39.690
It's almost always a driver
problem these days.

661
00:32:39.690 --> 00:32:41.470
If you're Linux distro doesn't
support it out of the box,

662
00:32:41.470 --> 00:32:43.960
just go to the vendor's website,
download the drivers.

663
00:32:43.960 --> 00:32:48.660
That fixes the problem nine times out
of ten, and that's it, all right?

664
00:32:48.660 --> 00:32:53.282
If it's still not good, that's when
you can start delving into LS mod,

665
00:32:53.282 --> 00:32:56.690
LSPCI, LSUSB,
looking to see if the hardware's detected.

666
00:32:56.690 --> 00:32:59.130
You can use modprobe to assign modules and

667
00:32:59.130 --> 00:33:03.350
load those modules in there, to force them
and see if that detects the hardware.

668
00:33:03.350 --> 00:33:04.700
These are all little
things that we can do.

669
00:33:04.700 --> 00:33:07.677
But after that, it's really gonna be
a journey to the vendor's website to hit

670
00:33:07.677 --> 00:33:09.401
their troubleshooting documents, right?

671
00:33:09.401 --> 00:33:11.750
Cuz every hardware piece
is a little bit different.

672
00:33:11.750 --> 00:33:14.170
>> Yeah,
definitely gotta stay on top of that.

673
00:33:14.170 --> 00:33:17.780
This is definitely one of the most
difficult things, especially for newbies,

674
00:33:17.780 --> 00:33:19.060
that are new to Linux.

675
00:33:19.060 --> 00:33:22.340
Trying to get into that can be one of
the biggest stumbling blocks for them.

676
00:33:22.340 --> 00:33:24.980
Trying to get stuff to actually just work,
I want to plug it in and make it work.

677
00:33:24.980 --> 00:33:26.570
So, definitely learn this stuff,

678
00:33:26.570 --> 00:33:30.760
dive into those man pages, learn how
those commands work, down to in-depth.

679
00:33:30.760 --> 00:33:31.670
Not just for your exam,

680
00:33:31.670 --> 00:33:35.970
but just for yourself to be able to do
that on your own, for your own systems.

681
00:33:35.970 --> 00:33:39.200
Well, I guess that being said Don, we've
come to the end of another great episode.

682
00:33:39.200 --> 00:33:41.010
Hopefully everybody out
there has enjoyed it.

683
00:33:41.010 --> 00:33:42.070
We sure enjoyed making it.

684
00:33:42.070 --> 00:33:45.780
So signing off for ITProTV,
I've been your host Daniel Lowry.

685
00:33:45.780 --> 00:33:46.500
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

686
00:33:46.500 --> 00:33:47.837
>> And we'll see you next time.

687
00:33:47.837 --> 00:33:53.700
[NOISE]

>> I'm doing great Daniel, and

6
00:00:22.720 --> 00:00:24.190
We're actually gonna have some fun today.

7
00:00:24.190 --> 00:00:26.590

12

00:00:43.000 --> 00:00:46.680
a lot of Linux systems

But, in making this change we're going to

00:00:50.190 --> 00:00:53.995

stuff, and

00:00:58.445 --> 00:01:01.955
>> Yeah, a lot of times the examples of

19
00:01:01.955 --> 00:01:05.305
reading a book, or you're going through

20
00:01:05.305 --> 00:01:09.055
It's hard to show you practical stuff,

21
00:01:09.055 --> 00:01:12.185
So to have that practicality is
really going to hammer home,

22
00:01:12.185 --> 00:01:13.245
this is why we do this.

23
00:01:13.245 --> 00:01:16.430
This is where this becomes helpful.

24
00:01:16.430 --> 00:01:18.970
>> So, here's one thing that I've
dealt with a lot in the real world,

25
00:01:18.970 --> 00:01:22.920
which is if you've got
a headless Linux unit, right?

26
00:01:22.920 --> 00:01:25.850
So let's say you've got a one use server
that you've thrown Linux on there to

27
00:01:25.850 --> 00:01:29.030
provide some functionality, and
you don't have a monitor or

28
00:01:29.030 --> 00:01:32.110
a keyboard or
a mouse hooked up to it, right?

29
00:01:32.110 --> 00:01:34.050
Or maybe you got a monitor, keyboard and

30
00:01:34.050 --> 00:01:37.850
mouse but you've got 42 one user
servers stacked in a single rack and

31
00:01:37.850 --> 00:01:41.640
it's a pain to go and move those around or
to get an expensive KVM.

32
00:01:41.640 --> 00:01:43.190
What you might want to do,

33
00:01:43.190 --> 00:01:47.420
is redirect your video output
to the serial port, right?

34
00:01:47.420 --> 00:01:49.920
Instead of having the video
output go to a monitor and

35
00:01:49.920 --> 00:01:51.820
yeah when I want to connect
to that Linux server and

36
00:01:51.820 --> 00:01:54.430
work with it I got to hook a monitor up,
a keyboard and a mouse.

37
00:01:54.430 --> 00:01:58.570
Instead of all that, I could just have
it redirect output to the serial port.

38
00:01:58.570 --> 00:02:01.250
And, now, I can just take my
regular laptop and walk up and

39
00:02:01.250 --> 00:02:05.370
connect with the serial cable, and have
a prompt on that server, access the shell,

40
00:02:05.370 --> 00:02:06.710
and start to work with it.

41
00:02:06.710 --> 00:02:10.810
Or I can hook it up to a terminal server
that can provide terminal access to all of

42
00:02:10.810 --> 00:02:13.090
my servers via that serial port remotely.

43
00:02:13.090 --> 00:02:15.420
It's a lot less expensive than doing KVMs.

44
00:02:15.420 --> 00:02:18.160
And if you don't need a graphic user
interface, it works great if you're just

45
00:02:18.160 --> 00:02:21.010
doing stuff from the shell,
which on a server we normally would.

46
00:02:21.010 --> 00:02:25.940
So in these scenarios I disable the
graphics video adaptor, well, you don't

47
00:02:25.940 --> 00:02:30.010
truly disable it but you redirect
the primary video output to a serial port.

48
00:02:30.010 --> 00:02:32.420
And it does make things kinda neat.

49
00:02:32.420 --> 00:02:36.510
Large server farms, if you're doing a
Linux firewall you might wanna do this cuz

50
00:02:36.510 --> 00:02:38.980
it does give that console
access to the system.

51
00:02:38.980 --> 00:02:40.970
Now, on the exam they're not gonna say,

52
00:02:40.970 --> 00:02:42.730
how do you redirect video
output out the serial port?

53
00:02:43.770 --> 00:02:47.080
But, they do want you to know
the underlying systems that I've got

54
00:02:47.080 --> 00:02:48.160
to change to make this work.

55
00:02:48.160 --> 00:02:50.490
So this is just a real world example
of how you might go about this.

56
00:02:50.490 --> 00:02:52.460
So let's jump in.

57
00:02:52.460 --> 00:02:56.328
The first thing I need to do is I
need to get my Linux system ready so

58
00:02:56.328 --> 00:03:00.980
that it understands what I'm trying to do,
that I'm trying to basically make

59
00:03:00.980 --> 00:03:06.750
this boot differently than normal.

60
00:03:06.750 --> 00:03:12.250
Because that default functionality is
that it wants to display everything on

61
00:03:12.250 --> 00:03:13.290
the video adapter.

62
00:03:13.290 --> 00:03:15.440
That's kind of what it does by default.

63
00:03:15.440 --> 00:03:20.040
And I want to bump up my font size
here a little bit because it's

64
00:03:20.040 --> 00:03:21.560
got me in something small here.

65
00:03:21.560 --> 00:03:24.020
So we'll just bump that a little bigger so
everybody can see.

66
00:03:24.020 --> 00:03:25.088
there we go.

67
00:03:25.088 --> 00:03:28.610
All right, so
what I need to do is I need to modify my

68
00:03:28.610 --> 00:03:30.920
boot loader first to
tell it what I'm doing.

69
00:03:30.920 --> 00:03:35.810
So I'm going to jump in here and edit and
I've done an SU to assume the root

70
00:03:35.810 --> 00:03:38.888
user here because I didn't want to have
to run on every single command, but

71
00:03:38.888 --> 00:03:43.542
you do have to be an administrator
to do this So I'm going to edit

72
00:03:43.542 --> 00:03:48.450
/boot/grub/grub.conf.

73
00:03:48.450 --> 00:03:51.020
That's the configuration file for
my bootloader.

74
00:03:51.020 --> 00:03:53.440
When your system boots up, BIOS kicks in.

75
00:03:53.440 --> 00:03:55.370
BIOS looks to the hard drive
finds the boot loader,

76
00:03:55.370 --> 00:03:56.440
let's the boot loader kick in.

77
00:03:56.440 --> 00:03:59.280
And the boot loader follows these
instructions to find Linux and

78
00:03:59.280 --> 00:04:00.710
then let's Linux kick in.

79
00:04:00.710 --> 00:04:04.940
So I'm getting involved before Linux
is technically loaded, all right?

80
00:04:04.940 --> 00:04:06.840
Now if I'm doing away with a monitor and

81
00:04:06.840 --> 00:04:10.630
I'm going text only out the serial port,
I need to disable my splash image.

82
00:04:10.630 --> 00:04:12.810
So I'm gonna come in here and
throw a little pound symbol before that so

83
00:04:12.810 --> 00:04:14.090
the splash image is disabled.

84
00:04:15.480 --> 00:04:18.990
Then I need to modify my kernel so

85
00:04:18.990 --> 00:04:22.340
that it'll know that I'm
doing this redirection.

86
00:04:22.340 --> 00:04:25.720
So I'm gonna get in here and
add to the end of that kernel line.

87
00:04:25.720 --> 00:04:27.250
And the kernel line, it wraps.

88
00:04:27.250 --> 00:04:30.340
Like if I do a set number here
you'll see the line numbers.

89
00:04:30.340 --> 00:04:33.310
See how line 16 actually
wraps three times there.

90
00:04:33.310 --> 00:04:35.230
So I'm on my kernel line.

91
00:04:35.230 --> 00:04:38.910
And I'm gonna add to the end of it
a couple of little entries here.

92
00:04:38.910 --> 00:04:43.040
I'm gonna say Serial -- unit = 1.

93
00:04:43.040 --> 00:04:47.140
So I'm gonna be attaching
this to my first serial port.

94
00:04:47.140 --> 00:04:49.950
And then I'm gonna say, speed = 9600.

95
00:04:49.950 --> 00:04:56.620
Now, 9600 bod, or bits per second,
that's not screaming speed.

96
00:04:56.620 --> 00:04:59.430
But I'm just displaying text at
a console port, and that's plenty.

97
00:04:59.430 --> 00:05:01.950
This is what a lot of systems default to.

98
00:05:01.950 --> 00:05:07.330
Then I'm gonna add another entry here.

99
00:05:07.330 --> 00:05:08.530
Let's see, serial.

100
00:05:08.530 --> 00:05:13.020
Reset my, oh, wait,
I'm doing this in the wrong spot.

101
00:05:13.020 --> 00:05:14.560
Let me get rid of this.

102
00:05:14.560 --> 00:05:17.160
I need to add this as a menu item.

103
00:05:17.160 --> 00:05:18.390
I do need to add some kernel options,

104
00:05:18.390 --> 00:05:20.260
but I need to add this serial
option right here first.

105
00:05:20.260 --> 00:05:28.180
So I'm gonna say serial--
unit = 1- -speed = 9600.

106
00:05:28.180 --> 00:05:30.280
And then I need to follow up,
this is why I knew I made a mistake.

107
00:05:30.280 --> 00:05:36.040
I need to follow up my terminal entry and
so I'll say terminal- - timeout = 300.

108
00:05:36.040 --> 00:05:39.250
The timeout value says that if I
don't get key feedback on the port,

109
00:05:39.250 --> 00:05:41.230
I need to log that person out or
end that session and so

110
00:05:41.230 --> 00:05:43.660
I'm just setting a limit here
of 300 which is five minutes.

111
00:05:43.660 --> 00:05:46.450
You might want to set it
longer it's just up to you.

112
00:05:46.450 --> 00:05:48.870
And then I'll say console serial.

113
00:05:48.870 --> 00:05:50.340
That's the important line.

114
00:05:50.340 --> 00:05:54.570
I'm saying that the default console of my
Linux box needs to be the serial port.

115
00:05:54.570 --> 00:05:56.900
And the serial port is gonna
be that first serial port, and

116
00:05:56.900 --> 00:05:58.360
it's gonna be at a speed of 9600, right?

117
00:05:58.360 --> 00:06:00.730
This is all kind of tieing together.

118
00:06:00.730 --> 00:06:02.110
And then on my kernel line,

119
00:06:02.110 --> 00:06:06.330
this is where I need to get in and
add a little bit more here.

120
00:06:06.330 --> 00:06:09.590
I'm gonna say console = tty0.

121
00:06:10.590 --> 00:06:16.700
So it's gonna be my first teletype,
my virtual console, console = tty0,

122
00:06:16.700 --> 00:06:20.656
and then I'm gonna say console = ttyS1.

123
00:06:20.656 --> 00:06:24.970
Now S1, that's one that I'm making.

124
00:06:24.970 --> 00:06:25.930
I'm making it myself.

125
00:06:25.930 --> 00:06:27.250
S1 doesn't exist by default, right?

126
00:06:27.250 --> 00:06:30.930
They're normally tty followed
by one to three numbers.

127
00:06:30.930 --> 00:06:33.910
S1, that's me adding it so
I know that this is my serial one.

128
00:06:33.910 --> 00:06:37.720
Just so I can have that and it's a name
that I will be able to spot later.

129
00:06:37.720 --> 00:06:43.660
And it's gonna be 9600, and we'll do
no parity bits and eight, all right.

130
00:06:43.660 --> 00:06:48.660
So now, when the system boots up, it knows
to redirect that video output, right?

131
00:06:48.660 --> 00:06:53.030
So that's all kinda being done right here
in my boot configuration changing the way

132
00:06:53.030 --> 00:06:55.510
that Linus is gonna boot up,
so let me just Save that.

133
00:06:57.300 --> 00:07:02.670
Now, because I created a new TTY, the
system needs to be aware of that, right?

134
00:07:02.670 --> 00:07:03.680
It knows about all of it's TTYs,

135
00:07:03.680 --> 00:07:06.170
it doesn't know about this
new one that I just made.

136
00:07:06.170 --> 00:07:15.640
If I go into /etc/securetty, sorry,
it's not a directory, it's a file.

137
00:07:15.640 --> 00:07:22.850
If I edit that file, /etc/securetty, we
can see all these virtual consoles, right?

138
00:07:22.850 --> 00:07:24.810
These are the ones the system knows about.

139
00:07:24.810 --> 00:07:26.910
Some of them are just VCs,
other ones are TTYs.

140
00:07:26.910 --> 00:07:31.030
The TTYs are local, the VCs,
those are used for SSH sessions and stuff.

141
00:07:31.030 --> 00:07:34.090
So, I'm gonna come in here and
add another one to the end of this list.

142
00:07:34.090 --> 00:07:39.408
And I'll just say tty S1, that's the one
I made, so now it knows that that exists.

143
