00:19:03.810 --> 00:19:05.320
All right,
well that's all I've got Daniel.

371
00:19:05.320 --> 00:19:06.260
I hope everybody enjoyed that.

372
00:19:06.260 --> 00:19:08.770
It was kind of an aside from
the exam objectives there.

373
00:19:08.770 --> 00:19:09.770
But I think a useful thing.

374
00:19:09.770 --> 00:19:10.530
>> Yeah, yeah.

375
00:19:10.530 --> 00:19:11.170
I liked it a lot.

376
00:19:11.170 --> 00:19:12.700
I hope you guys did as well.

377
00:19:12.700 --> 00:19:14.810
But it is time to sign off for ITPROTV.

378
00:19:14.810 --> 00:19:17.060
I've been your host Daniel Lowery.

379
00:19:17.060 --> 00:19:17.650
>> And I'm Don Pazett.

380
00:19:17.650 --> 00:19:19.990
>> And we'll see you next time.

episodes.title: Configuring Hard Disks
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.065 --> 00:00:10.665
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:10.665 --> 00:00:14.790
All right, greetings everyone, and welcome
to another great episode of ITProTV.

3
00:00:14.790 --> 00:00:16.740
I'll be your host Daniel Lowry.

4
00:00:16.740 --> 00:00:20.240
And here with me today is none other
than the man, the myth, the well,

5
00:00:20.240 --> 00:00:20.788
I'll stop there.

6
00:00:20.788 --> 00:00:22.590
[LAUGH] Don Pezet.

7
00:00:22.590 --> 00:00:23.970
>> One in seven states.

8
00:00:23.970 --> 00:00:26.140
Thanks for
having me back on the show Daniel.

9
00:00:26.140 --> 00:00:30.800
I'm excited about today's show because
we're going to talking about partitioning,

10
00:00:30.800 --> 00:00:33.460
formatting, handling
hard drives in general.

11
00:00:33.460 --> 00:00:34.150
Right?

12
00:00:34.150 --> 00:00:37.100
When you install your Lennox distribution,
it asks you a bunch of

13
00:00:37.100 --> 00:00:40.770
questions about how you want to format and
arrange your hard disks, and

14
00:00:40.770 --> 00:00:43.190
usually people make those decisions and
that's kind of the end of it.

15
00:00:43.190 --> 00:00:46.400
But you can actually get involved
in that quite a bit more even

16
00:00:46.400 --> 00:00:47.670
after the install is done.

17
00:00:47.670 --> 00:00:50.980
At a minimum, if you're adding
new hard drives to your system,

18
00:00:50.980 --> 00:00:53.770
you're probably going to need to
get involved with formatting them,

19
00:00:53.770 --> 00:00:54.970
mounting them, getting them online.

20
00:00:54.970 --> 00:00:57.360
So that's what we're going to take
a look at here in this episode,

21
00:00:57.360 --> 00:00:59.560
how we get those drives ready for use.

22
00:00:59.560 --> 00:01:00.440
>> That's right.

23
00:01:00.440 --> 00:01:05.310
Now Don, my favorite way is just to start
my favorite graphical user interface,

24
00:01:05.310 --> 00:01:07.320
the old Jeep Hearted and go to town, and

25
00:01:07.320 --> 00:01:10.250
everything works great, but
that's not always an option is it?

26
00:01:10.250 --> 00:01:12.900
>> That's right.
If you're on a server with no Gui,

27
00:01:12.900 --> 00:01:15.730
then some of the graphics tools that we
use, all the graphics tools that we use,

28
00:01:15.730 --> 00:01:16.400
aren't going to work.

29
00:01:16.400 --> 00:01:18.950
Now, you might do like a remote x
window session, or something, and

30
00:01:18.950 --> 00:01:19.710
kind of get around that,

31
00:01:19.710 --> 00:01:22.980
but usually we're going to have to deal
with what we've got from the command line.

32
00:01:22.980 --> 00:01:25.860
So we're going to walk through a few
different ways to handle this.

33
00:01:25.860 --> 00:01:29.820
Now, before we dive into the tools, let's
talk about the principle a little bit.

34
00:01:29.820 --> 00:01:34.610
When you get a brand-new hard drive,
the odds are, well, it might be truly,

35
00:01:34.610 --> 00:01:36.010
completely blank.

36
00:01:36.010 --> 00:01:38.650
That used to happen, not so much any more.

37
00:01:38.650 --> 00:01:41.660
Now they usually put at least
a Windows partition on there.

38
00:01:41.660 --> 00:01:45.920
And if you do that, and throw it on
to a Linux system, it'll detect it,

39
00:01:45.920 --> 00:01:48.660
it can use it, but
it's not really optimal.

40
00:01:48.660 --> 00:01:53.260
Linux has its own file system
that it likes to use, the ExtFS,

41
00:01:53.260 --> 00:01:56.870
or, well there's a bunch of them,
ReiserFS and ZFS, all those good guys.

42
00:01:56.870 --> 00:02:01.110
But each of those are really optimized for
use with the Lennox journal and

43
00:02:01.110 --> 00:02:02.000
the Lennox operating system.

44
00:02:02.000 --> 00:02:05.108
You get various benefits usually
centering on performance from using them.

45
00:02:05.108 --> 00:02:07.620
So we don't want to use
the Windows partitions even

46
00:02:07.620 --> 00:02:09.270
if they're already created for us.

47
00:02:09.270 --> 00:02:12.090
So when we get a new drive,
we're going to want to wipe out

48
00:02:12.090 --> 00:02:14.710
the partitions that are on it and
create our own.

49
00:02:14.710 --> 00:02:15.300
Right?
And

50
00:02:15.300 --> 00:02:18.400
that way Lennox can format those and
prepare them to use them.

51
00:02:18.400 --> 00:02:22.530
When you get a drive, you might want
to create one big partition that spans

52
00:02:22.530 --> 00:02:25.950
the whole drive, or you might
want to divide it up into chunks.

53
00:02:25.950 --> 00:02:27.870
Now Daniel, what's my motivation,

54
00:02:27.870 --> 00:02:29.570
like why would I want to
divide a drive into chunks?

55
00:02:29.570 --> 00:02:30.780
>> Well, because you want to protect data.

56
00:02:30.780 --> 00:02:36.110
If I have system files on one partition,
and I've got program files on

57
00:02:36.110 --> 00:02:39.940
another partition, if one of my programs
goes crazy, it doesn't effect my system,

58
00:02:39.940 --> 00:02:45.220
or my system goes completely berserk,
my program files are still safe.

59
00:02:45.220 --> 00:02:49.330
All I have to do is reformat,
that partition on my system files on them,

60
00:02:49.330 --> 00:02:53.580
reinstall those files, and
I still have all my data, it's not gone.

61
00:02:53.580 --> 00:02:57.330
>> Yeah and a great example of this
might be, I'm installing Linux and

62
00:02:57.330 --> 00:02:57.960
I've got one hard drive.

63
00:02:57.960 --> 00:02:59.970
I've only got one hard drive.

64
00:02:59.970 --> 00:03:04.745
And I'm worried about my user files
growing and filling the hard drive.

65
00:03:04.745 --> 00:03:07.010
Because if I fill the hard drive up,

66
00:03:07.010 --> 00:03:08.785
operating system functions stop working,
right?

67
00:03:08.785 --> 00:03:10.450
Because as you run processes
they create files,

68
00:03:10.450 --> 00:03:12.900
they can't do that, processes can't run,
system can't run, right?

69
00:03:12.900 --> 00:03:15.340
It's kind of this whole
chain reaction that happens.

70
00:03:15.340 --> 00:03:20.140
What I might want to do is take that
slash-home folder at that directory, and

71
00:03:20.140 --> 00:03:21.820
put it in a separate partition.

72
00:03:21.820 --> 00:03:25.140
And that way, it's got boundaries on it,
so if it fills up, well great,

73
00:03:25.140 --> 00:03:29.005
the whole directory is filled up, but
my operating system still has room, right?

74
00:03:29.005 --> 00:03:31.205
So that's one reason we
might want to do it.

75
00:03:31.205 --> 00:03:35.325
We might want to encrypt one partition and
not encrypt another one.

76
00:03:35.325 --> 00:03:37.845
Usually it's just about
setting boundaries, right?

77
00:03:37.845 --> 00:03:39.291
It's not about redundancy.

78
00:03:39.291 --> 00:03:42.565
I wouldn't want to create a partition and
divide a hard drive in half, and

79
00:03:42.565 --> 00:03:44.395
back up data to the second partition.

80
00:03:44.395 --> 00:03:45.215
That doesn't make sense,

81
00:03:45.215 --> 00:03:48.465
because if the hard drives fails,
I lose both partitions, right?

82
00:03:48.465 --> 00:03:50.855
So that's not really a motivation for
partitioning.

83
00:03:50.855 --> 00:03:55.170
But for isolating your data, that's
really what partitions are all about.

84
00:03:55.170 --> 00:03:58.960
You may or may not need that, and
there's more than one way to go about it.

85
00:03:58.960 --> 00:04:02.450
In this episode, we're going to be talking
about the traditional methods of directly

86
00:04:02.450 --> 00:04:03.628
partitioning a single drive.

87
00:04:03.628 --> 00:04:04.915
In a follow-up episode,

88
00:04:04.915 --> 00:04:08.140
we're going to talk about
the logical volume manager, the LVM.

89
00:04:08.140 --> 00:04:11.630
And it let's you do crazy things like
have one partition span more than one

90
00:04:11.630 --> 00:04:12.490
physical drive.

91
00:04:12.490 --> 00:04:13.410
All sorts of magic there.

92
00:04:13.410 --> 00:04:14.630
It's really neat stuff.

93
00:04:14.630 --> 00:04:15.440
Let's start with the basics.

94
00:04:16.470 --> 00:04:19.540
So Daniel,
I've got a Linux box right here and

95
00:04:19.540 --> 00:04:22.310
I've got a couple of hard
drives on this system.

96
00:04:22.310 --> 00:04:25.714
And I know I've got a couple of hard
drives because if I look in like /etc.

97
00:04:25.714 --> 00:04:32.920
Inside of /etc oops, not etc,
if I look inside of /dev, there we go.

98
00:04:32.920 --> 00:04:37.150
I can see all the hardware that was picked
up and in here I can spot my hard drives.

99
00:04:37.150 --> 00:04:39.650
Now on most Linux distros,
the hard drives,

100
00:04:39.650 --> 00:04:44.530
if they're SATA drives, will show up
as sd followed by a letter, right?

101
00:04:44.530 --> 00:04:49.510
And that's just SATA disk,
sd, so sda is my first disk.

102
00:04:49.510 --> 00:04:52.580
And then I've got sdb as my second disk.

103
00:04:52.580 --> 00:04:54.230
Sdc, that's my third disk.

104
00:04:54.230 --> 00:04:55.486
And as I add more hard drives,

105
00:04:55.486 --> 00:04:58.159
it just keeps moving up the alphabet
with those drive letters.

106
00:04:58.159 --> 00:05:03.105
Right, if I've partitioned the disk,
I'll see a number after it.

107
00:05:03.105 --> 00:05:08.526
Sda1 is my first hard drive,
my first partition on it.

108
00:05:08.526 --> 00:05:12.800
Sda3 is my first hard drive,
the third partition on it.

109
00:05:12.800 --> 00:05:14.640
Sdb and sdc.

110
00:05:14.640 --> 00:05:16.230
Well, they don't have any numbers.

111
00:05:16.230 --> 00:05:17.910
That means I haven't partitioned them.

112
00:05:17.910 --> 00:05:19.500
Those drives are basically blank.

113
00:05:19.500 --> 00:05:20.140
They're sitting there.

114
00:05:20.140 --> 00:05:21.310
They're not in use.

115
00:05:21.310 --> 00:05:23.140
My system can't access them.

116
00:05:23.140 --> 00:05:26.660
So if I just added these hard drives,
I had to get them ready for use.

117
00:05:26.660 --> 00:05:30.350
And to do that, I need to put at
least one partition on there, and

118
00:05:30.350 --> 00:05:31.470
I need to format them.

119
00:05:31.470 --> 00:05:33.270
And once they're formatted,
you're in business.

120
00:05:33.270 --> 00:05:35.060
Now, that word format.

121
00:05:35.060 --> 00:05:37.220
Let me just add a little bit here.

122
00:05:37.220 --> 00:05:40.110
I know there's some of you guys out there
that are hard-core Linux users that

123
00:05:40.110 --> 00:05:42.991
are ready to turn off the video right now
>> [LAUGH]

124
00:05:42.991 --> 00:05:44.326
>> because I used the word format.

125
00:05:44.326 --> 00:05:46.270
The word format does come
from the Microsoft world.

126
00:05:46.270 --> 00:05:47.930
They call it formatting the disk.

127
00:05:47.930 --> 00:05:51.150
What you're actually doing
is laying out a file system.

128
00:05:51.150 --> 00:05:53.230
So you're applying a file
system to the disk.

129
00:05:53.230 --> 00:05:56.000
You're saying here's how
I'm going to store files.

130
00:05:56.000 --> 00:05:59.670
Here's the table where I'll store
the file names, and here's how I'll

131
00:05:59.670 --> 00:06:03.640
place that data on the drive itself so
that I can retrieve it quickly and safely.

132
00:06:03.640 --> 00:06:05.690
And maybe I've got advanced
features like journaling or

133
00:06:05.690 --> 00:06:07.410
whatever, whenever those are enabled,
right?

134
00:06:07.410 --> 00:06:09.120
It's all part of the file system.

135
00:06:09.120 --> 00:06:10.740
So when we say we're formatting a disc,

136
00:06:10.740 --> 00:06:15.080
what we're really saying is we're
applying a file system to it, right?

137
00:06:15.080 --> 00:06:16.620
But the term is formatting.

138
00:06:16.620 --> 00:06:19.280
Pretty much everyone uses it and
it's no big deal.

139
00:06:19.280 --> 00:06:22.335
But if you're one of the hardcore guys,
you're being nippy.

140
00:06:22.335 --> 00:06:23.100
[LAUGH] But

141
00:06:23.100 --> 00:06:27.550
anyhow, so that's one of the things
that we need to get the drive ready.

142
00:06:27.550 --> 00:06:32.210
Once it's ready, we still can't
access it until we mount it.

143
00:06:32.210 --> 00:06:35.690
Mounting it is the process
of taking a patrician and

144
00:06:35.690 --> 00:06:38.830
applying a path to it,
a folder path, right?

145
00:06:38.830 --> 00:06:41.690
When you browse your hard drive,
you're browsing through folders, and

146
00:06:41.690 --> 00:06:44.570
those folders can be mounted
to patricians, and so

147
00:06:44.570 --> 00:06:47.300
we have to do that to be able
to gain access to the drive.

148
00:06:47.300 --> 00:06:50.340
So there's really a three step
process to get a drive ready.

149
00:06:50.340 --> 00:06:51.840
You got to partition it.

150
00:06:51.840 --> 00:06:54.760
You got to apply a file system or
format it.

151
00:06:54.760 --> 00:06:55.920
And then you got to mount it.

152
00:06:55.920 --> 00:06:59.630
And once those three things are done,
you now got useable storage.

153
00:06:59.630 --> 00:07:01.430
So, let's run through that process.

154
00:07:01.430 --> 00:07:02.910
We'll start with formatting.

155
00:07:02.910 --> 00:07:06.470
Daniel I know you mentioned gparted,
which is a great utility,

156
00:07:06.470 --> 00:07:08.590
but I want to start with fdisk.

157
00:07:08.590 --> 00:07:09.880
>> Yeah, good old fdisk right?

158
00:07:09.880 --> 00:07:13.050
The tried and true, been around for
just about ever right?

159
00:07:13.050 --> 00:07:15.830
>> Yeah it's ancient,
it's been around a long long time.

160
00:07:15.830 --> 00:07:16.580
It's the one you can count on.

161
00:07:16.580 --> 00:07:18.990
You don't know if you'll have
the other tools on a server, but

162
00:07:18.990 --> 00:07:20.990
you know you'll have fdisk.

163
00:07:20.990 --> 00:07:22.080
And you can always check.

164
00:07:22.080 --> 00:07:25.060
You do a quick like fdisk, dash dash help.

165
00:07:25.060 --> 00:07:26.940
And you should get the help output for it.

166
00:07:26.940 --> 00:07:29.870
And this is just a simple command line
partition creator that we can use.

167
00:07:29.870 --> 00:07:33.790
And when you run fdisk,
you can do a couple of different things.

168
00:07:33.790 --> 00:07:36.610
You know, if you look at the various
options they've got here for

169
00:07:36.610 --> 00:07:40.200
displaying your table or
accessing a single disk or whatever.

170
00:07:40.200 --> 00:07:46.860
But the basic one is fdisk, followed by
a disk name to change the partition table.

171
00:07:46.860 --> 00:07:49.370
So maybe I'll do /dev/sdb.

172
00:07:49.370 --> 00:07:51.460
Sdb had no partitions.

173
00:07:51.460 --> 00:07:53.345
So when I go to access that, whoops.

174
00:07:53.345 --> 00:07:55.135
Kind of need to be an administrator
to mess with this one, so

175
00:07:55.135 --> 00:07:56.365
I'm going to sudo that.

176
00:07:56.365 --> 00:07:58.735
>> Don't want your regular users
partitioning for the fun of it [LAUGH].

177
00:07:58.735 --> 00:08:01.303
>> That's right,
that wouldn't be a good time.

178
00:08:01.303 --> 00:08:03.729
So now I can access it, and
I can start to create partitions.

179
00:08:03.729 --> 00:08:07.406
And I can see, I can press m for
help which is intuitive.

180
00:08:07.406 --> 00:08:09.710
And we can see all the different
commands that we can do.

181
00:08:09.710 --> 00:08:12.288
And you'll see things in here
like delete a partition, so

182
00:08:12.288 --> 00:08:16.310
if my hard drive shipped with those
Windows partitions, I can delete them.

183
00:08:16.310 --> 00:08:21.410
I can add partitions by using the create
option which is actually n for new.

184
00:08:21.410 --> 00:08:24.040
So I can throw in new partitions and
get those in place.

185
00:08:24.040 --> 00:08:24.890
And you can set it all, and

186
00:08:24.890 --> 00:08:29.120
when you're done you can write
the partition table to the hard drive.

187
00:08:29.120 --> 00:08:30.900
So all the changes that I'm about to make,

188
00:08:30.900 --> 00:08:33.300
don't actually take effect
until I say to write it.

189
00:08:33.300 --> 00:08:35.200
It's basically queueing
up all the changes.

190
00:08:35.200 --> 00:08:38.890
>> That's an important thing to know too,
because you can spend some time really

191
00:08:38.890 --> 00:08:41.700
tweaking the partitions the way
you want them, and then you hit q.

192
00:08:41.700 --> 00:08:44.030
You think you're done, and
it didn't write anything.

193
00:08:44.030 --> 00:08:46.130
You gotta go back and
do it all over again.

194
00:08:46.130 --> 00:08:49.190
>> Now,
the option I always go to first, is p.

195
00:08:49.190 --> 00:08:50.350
Print the partition table.

196
00:08:50.350 --> 00:08:54.720
I want to see what's on this drive right
now, so I'm gonna hit p, and here it is.

197
00:08:54.720 --> 00:08:56.433
I can see my drive, right?

198
00:08:56.433 --> 00:08:59.450
It's 68.7 gigabytes in size.

199
00:08:59.450 --> 00:09:01.800
Now we know, once we format and
stuff, it's much smaller, right?

200
00:09:01.800 --> 00:09:04.670
It's a whole difference of how
we measure bytes and all that.

201
00:09:04.670 --> 00:09:06.670
But I can see how many sectors, units.

202
00:09:06.670 --> 00:09:08.330
I can see all that information.

203
00:09:08.330 --> 00:09:11.860
I can also see if it's got a disk
label applied to it right now.

204
00:09:11.860 --> 00:09:13.930
Apparently mine does a DoS label.

205
00:09:13.930 --> 00:09:15.580
And then I can see the partitions.

206
00:09:15.580 --> 00:09:16.930
And I don't have any.

207
00:09:16.930 --> 00:09:18.430
So it's really just a blank drive.

208
00:09:18.430 --> 00:09:20.130
If I had some they'd be numbered.

209
00:09:20.130 --> 00:09:21.980
And I could hit D to delete, and

210
00:09:21.980 --> 00:09:24.650
then put the number of the partition I
wanted to remove and I could remove it.

211
00:09:24.650 --> 00:09:27.080
Great way to get rid of
those Windows partitions.

212
00:09:27.080 --> 00:09:31.060
Then I can hit N for new and
I'm going to create a partition.

213
00:09:31.060 --> 00:09:32.720
Now on a standard partition type,

214
00:09:32.720 --> 00:09:35.800
you have what's called a primary and
an extended partition.

215
00:09:35.800 --> 00:09:38.790
Your hard drive can have up
to four primary partitions.

216
00:09:38.790 --> 00:09:42.440
If you need more, well you probably
have a pretty specialized use case.

217
00:09:42.440 --> 00:09:44.700
Most people never need more,
but if you do,

218
00:09:44.700 --> 00:09:49.230
the fourth one can be
a extended partition.

219
00:09:49.230 --> 00:09:51.310
It can create basically this container,

220
00:09:51.310 --> 00:09:53.920
and you can start creating these
logical partitions inside of it.

221
00:09:53.920 --> 00:09:56.320

episodes.description: Errata: At the end of the episode, Don mentioned installing the LVM during an install allowed all partitions to participate in LVM. He specifically mentioned the "boot volume" when he should have said "root volume". For the system to boot, the EFI partition and /boot cannot be a part of LVM as the service is not loaded until after the kernel fires.

1

5
00:00:20.420 --> 00:00:23.100
>> I'm doing great and, Daniel,
are you ready to have some fun today?

6
00:00:23.100 --> 00:00:23.748

7
00:00:23.748 --> 00:00:27.047

we took a look at partitioning and getting
hard drives ready to use inside of Linux.

9
00:00:31.890 --> 00:00:33.540

10

right?

11
00:00:35.490 --> 00:00:37.930
We're gonna dive into the logical
volume manager, the LVM.

12
00:00:37.930 --> 00:00:40.760
And the LVM let's you do all sorts of

00:00:40.760 --> 00:00:44.120
crazy stuff that you couldn't do

14
00:00:45.670 --> 00:00:49.250
For example, with LVM,
we can take a partition and

15
00:00:49.250 --> 00:00:52.040
have it stretch across
more than one hard drive.

16
00:00:52.040 --> 00:00:56.190
So, like if I had two 4 terabyte drives,

00:00:56.190 --> 00:00:59.160

18
00:00:59.160 --> 00:01:00.460
Sometimes we want that.

19
00:01:00.460 --> 00:01:03.820
LVM also allows us to quickly and easily
resize partitions, make them bigger,

20
00:01:03.820 --> 00:01:04.940
make them smaller.

21
00:01:04.940 --> 00:01:08.910
You can do all sorts of
really cool stuff with LVM.

22
00:01:08.910 --> 00:01:09.950
And it's a neat technology.

25
00:01:17.540 --> 00:01:21.470
And so your system may already be set

26
00:01:21.470 --> 00:01:25.565
You may have a system like mine is right
now where I'm not using LVM at all, and

00:01:25.565 --> 00:01:28.530
I've just got regular partitions and
drives.

28
00:01:28.530 --> 00:01:29.350
So if that's the case,

00:01:29.350 --> 00:01:32.710
you might want to enable it to gain access

30
00:01:32.710 --> 00:01:33.874
And it is some really cool stuff.

31
00:01:33.874 --> 00:01:37.590
So let's take a look at LVM and kind

32
00:01:37.590 --> 00:01:41.416
>> Sorry, let's move from the witchcraft

00:01:41.416 --> 00:01:42.901
scientific method of LVM.

00:01:42.901 --> 00:01:45.635
[LAUGH]
>> All right, well one of the things that

35
00:01:45.635 --> 00:01:49.960
we have to remember about the LVM, right,
is that it's the logical volume manager.

36
00:01:49.960 --> 00:01:53.170
So it's gonna take our physical disks,
and our physical partitions, and

37
00:01:53.170 --> 00:01:54.830
it's gonna represent them logically.

38
00:01:54.830 --> 00:01:56.540
That's what lets it break the rules.

39
00:01:56.540 --> 00:01:59.730
But it also means it's gonna
create a lot of logical devices.

40
00:01:59.730 --> 00:02:04.570

41
00:02:04.570 --> 00:02:05.530
And I pull up a directory.

they're not gonna show up in here.

46
00:02:19.077 --> 00:02:22.365

folders that are gonna be created

47
00:02:22.365 --> 00:02:24.890
underneath it for

48
00:02:24.890 --> 00:02:27.410
When we start to create these drives,
we group them together so

49
00:02:27.410 --> 00:02:29.340
that we can span across them if we want.

50
00:02:29.340 --> 00:02:32.720
And then inside of them you have your
logical volumes that you actually make.

51
00:02:32.720 --> 00:02:36.480
So, if you're running LVM, you'll start to
see various sub folders and things that

52
00:02:36.480 --> 00:02:39.390
will show up in here to represent these
virtual drives that we're creating.

53

If I do just a quick fdisk -l, I can see
the drives that I've got, sda1, 2, and 3.

54
00:02:45.323 --> 00:02:48.218
And I can see that, well those are,
I'm sorry, those are sda1,

55
00:02:48.218 --> 00:02:50.110
2, 3, those are my partitions.

56
00:02:50.110 --> 00:02:53.820
I've also got sdb and
sdc which didn't show up.

57
00:02:53.820 --> 00:02:55.290

We can just stretch that volume out.

283
00:14:39.780 --> 00:14:41.330
I made it 20-gigs.

284
00:14:41.330 --> 00:14:43.630
Well I can stretch that out.

285
00:14:43.630 --> 00:14:46.760
So if I wanna bump that up,
I can use a resize command.

286
00:14:46.760 --> 00:14:50.233
And we can go in and we can pump that
up and make it that bigger size and

287
00:14:50.233 --> 00:14:51.640
get that in place.

288
00:14:51.640 --> 00:14:55.827
So we got a lvresize command and
lvresize is what let's you make

289
00:14:55.827 --> 00:15:00.010
those partitions bigger or
smaller based on your needs.

290
00:15:00.010 --> 00:15:04.052
Maybe I add a third hard drive to this
mix and now, I got more storage so

291
00:15:04.052 --> 00:15:06.517
I want to stretch out my logical volumes.

292
00:15:06.517 --> 00:15:13.290
So I'm just going to say lvresize and
then I am gonna give it a size.

293
00:15:13.290 --> 00:15:15.050
And I'm gonna tell it how
much bigger I wanna make it.

294
00:15:15.050 --> 00:15:17.200
Now, the marketing one I did 20-gigs.

295
00:15:17.200 --> 00:15:22.661
Let's say I wanna make it a nice even
36-gigs, so I'll add 16-gigs to it.

296
00:15:22.661 --> 00:15:26.393
So I'm gonna say lvresize
-L plus +16 gigs,

297
00:15:26.393 --> 00:15:30.410
now gigabytes and
then who it is that I'm resizing?

298
00:15:30.410 --> 00:15:35.001
So I'm gonna say /dev/vg1/Marketing.

299
00:15:35.001 --> 00:15:38.439
And I'm gonna add 16-gigs of storage
to it assuming it's available,

300
00:15:38.439 --> 00:15:40.800
if it's not available I get an error.

301
00:15:40.800 --> 00:15:42.230
So it just added it to it.

302
00:15:42.230 --> 00:15:44.269
Maybe I want to make the sales
department really big.

303
00:15:44.269 --> 00:15:47.467
I wanna add 50-gigs to
the sales department.

304
00:15:47.467 --> 00:15:51.835
So I'm gonna go in and just punch that
in and it's gonna make that one bigger.

305
00:15:51.835 --> 00:15:53.379
And there we go.

306
00:15:53.379 --> 00:16:00.400
And if I do a quick lvdisplay, I can
see where sales is now 70-gigs in size.

307
00:16:00.400 --> 00:16:03.067
My hard drives were only 64 gigs, right?

308
00:16:03.067 --> 00:16:07.230
This one drive is now bigger
than a single physical disk.

309
00:16:07.230 --> 00:16:09.580
And the other one is 36 gig, right?

310
00:16:09.580 --> 00:16:12.700
There's marketing, it's 36 gigs in size.

311
00:16:12.700 --> 00:16:14.550
So I've expanded these.

312
00:16:15.910 --> 00:16:21.060
But, while it's super easy to
expand the logical volume,

313
00:16:21.060 --> 00:16:23.390
your file system doesn't follow suit.

314
00:16:23.390 --> 00:16:30.390
So when I laid a file system on this,
I laid EXT4, EXT4, it didn't expand.

315
00:16:30.390 --> 00:16:35.450
So if I come and and take a look at like
DF-H and I start looking at my sizes,

316
00:16:35.450 --> 00:16:38.150
notice how marketing is still 20 gigs and
sales is still 20 gigs?

317
00:16:39.580 --> 00:16:42.650
To put it in terms of the physical hard
drive, the physical hard drive just got

318
00:16:42.650 --> 00:16:46.650
bigger, but the partition is
still the same size it was.

319
00:16:46.650 --> 00:16:49.480
So super easy to resize
the logical volume.

320
00:16:49.480 --> 00:16:53.360
But I've gotta follow that up by
resizing my file system too, so

321
00:16:53.360 --> 00:16:55.790
that it knows to be bigger,
to fill that space.

322
00:16:55.790 --> 00:16:59.050
Now that varies based on your file system,
so

323
00:16:59.050 --> 00:17:03.080
you may have to do different things
to get it to work for different ones.

324
00:17:03.080 --> 00:17:08.240
With EXT, we have the resize2fs command.

325
00:17:08.240 --> 00:17:10.210
And so I'm gonna do resize to fs, and

326
00:17:10.210 --> 00:17:16.130
I'm gonna point that at
/dev/vg1 /marketing, like that.

327
00:17:16.130 --> 00:17:18.660
And that's gonna resize it, and
if I don't give it any options,

328
00:17:18.660 --> 00:17:21.280
it's gonna resize it to the biggest
size that it can go to.

329
00:17:21.280 --> 00:17:25.370
So there it goes, it's resizing it,
and I'll do the same thing with sales.

330
00:17:25.370 --> 00:17:29.090
Just be aware, if you used a different
file system, that's not gonna work.

331
00:17:29.090 --> 00:17:32.708
So if you use ReiserFS, or ZFS,
they have their own commands for

332
00:17:32.708 --> 00:17:33.985
stretching that out.

333
00:17:33.985 --> 00:17:41.410
But now, when I do a df -h, I can see that
marketing is 36 gig and sales is 69 gigs.

334
00:17:41.410 --> 00:17:42.520
It's not quite the 70,

335
00:17:42.520 --> 00:17:45.670
file systems don't get the same
advantage as a physical hard drive.

336
00:17:45.670 --> 00:17:49.485
So, I can see that space,
now I've got tons of room on these drives.

337
00:17:49.485 --> 00:17:52.962
>> Now Don, we've talked about if we
have the space on the actual disks

338
00:17:52.962 --> 00:17:57.300
that we have installed in our computer at
that time, we can easily stretch that out.

339
00:17:57.300 --> 00:17:58.560
But what if we've run out of space,

340
00:17:58.560 --> 00:18:03.180
how difficult is it to add another
drive and extend that out to that?

341
00:18:03.180 --> 00:18:04.530
>> It's really not a big deal.

342
00:18:04.530 --> 00:18:09.230
So if my system supports hot plug,
which a lot of people don't realize this,

343
00:18:09.230 --> 00:18:12.410
even SATA, the default SATA
standard supports hot plug.

344
00:18:12.410 --> 00:18:15.880
The power connector doesn't so
much, but the SATA connector does.

345
00:18:15.880 --> 00:18:19.940
So you can probably add hard drives
to your system while it's online.

346
00:18:19.940 --> 00:18:21.780
Maybe not,
your hardware might not support that.

347
00:18:21.780 --> 00:18:22.810
If your hardware doesn't support it,

348
00:18:22.810 --> 00:18:26.750
you got to shut the server down,
add a hard drive, power it back on.

349
00:18:26.750 --> 00:18:29.890
But if it has hot plug,
if it's a 2U server whatever, and

350
00:18:29.890 --> 00:18:32.960
it's got bays right in front, you can
probably just slap a hard drive in there.

351
00:18:32.960 --> 00:18:37.088
And then you add that hard
drive to your volume group,

352
00:18:37.088 --> 00:18:40.493
so you use the pvcreate
to import that disk.

353
00:18:40.493 --> 00:18:46.540
So for me it it'd be /dev/sdd,
so I would do pvcreate /dev/sdd.

354
00:18:46.540 --> 00:18:48.870
That would add it to the LVM.

355
00:18:48.870 --> 00:18:52.830
Then my VG creator, we would need
to go into that volume group and

356
00:18:52.830 --> 00:18:54.760
add that drive to it.

357
00:18:54.760 --> 00:18:58.050
So we could go in and add it in,
put it in place and that expands out and

358
00:18:58.050 --> 00:18:59.600
gets that extra storage.

359
00:18:59.600 --> 00:19:01.430
Then you just go and
resize your logical volume.

360
00:19:01.430 --> 00:19:03.810
And you do it,
if you have hot plug drives,

361
00:19:03.810 --> 00:19:04.990
you can do it all while it's online.

362
00:19:04.990 --> 00:19:06.740
Your end users don't even notice.

363
00:19:06.740 --> 00:19:08.180
All of a sudden you have more storage,
right?

364
00:19:08.180 --> 00:19:12.020
That's really the advantage of using the
LVM is that you can do this stuff without

365
00:19:12.020 --> 00:19:14.070
affecting your users.

366
00:19:14.070 --> 00:19:15.250
>> Very cool.

367
00:19:15.250 --> 00:19:17.650
>> With the older systems,
you have to get people out of the system.

368
00:19:17.650 --> 00:19:20.610
You have to get them out of the drive or
go into single user mode to do stuff.

369
00:19:20.610 --> 00:19:21.910
And that was kind of a hassle.

370
00:19:21.910 --> 00:19:22.890
LVM, it's all live.

371
00:19:22.890 --> 00:19:25.050
It's really cool stuff,
so pretty cool to do.

372
00:19:27.270 --> 00:19:31.620
Another command that we want to be
aware of is, if we're adding drives to

373
00:19:31.620 --> 00:19:36.312
the volume group, you have vg extend.

374
00:19:36.312 --> 00:19:39.910
Vg extend is how we add
drives to the volume group.

375
00:19:39.910 --> 00:19:45.680
So, when we created our volume group
earlier, the command I used was vg create.

376
00:19:45.680 --> 00:19:47.580
And then I gave it a name,
so I said vg1 and

377
00:19:47.580 --> 00:19:50.800
then I pointed to the drives
I was brining in.

378
00:19:50.800 --> 00:19:57.450
So, I did /dev/sdb /dev/sdc, those guys.

379
00:19:57.450 --> 00:20:01.797
So, that created volume group one and
it added those two drives.

380
00:20:01.797 --> 00:20:06.471
Vgextend, the way it works,
is you say vgextend and

381
00:20:06.471 --> 00:20:10.520
then you come in and you provide the name.

382
00:20:10.520 --> 00:20:13.164
And that volume group already exists, vg1.

383
00:20:13.164 --> 00:20:16.231
And then we say /dev/sdd.

384
00:20:16.231 --> 00:20:17.915
That's not creating a new volume group,

385
00:20:17.915 --> 00:20:20.370
it's extending it to
encompass a new drive.

386
00:20:20.370 --> 00:20:26.400
So I would do the pv create /dev/sdd
first to import it into the system.

387
00:20:26.400 --> 00:20:31.063
And then vgextend vg1
/dev/sdd to add that to it.

388
00:20:31.063 --> 00:20:34.166
Now the volume group is bigger,
I can go to each of my logical volumes and

389
00:20:34.166 --> 00:20:35.056
stretch those out.

390
00:20:35.056 --> 00:20:39.331
So vg extend is the kind of
missing component there for

391
00:20:39.331 --> 00:20:41.333
adding those drives in.

392
00:20:41.333 --> 00:20:45.370
Straight forward if you
know the command [LAUGH].

393
00:20:45.370 --> 00:20:47.105
>> If you've learned those things,
that is.

394
00:20:47.105 --> 00:20:49.805
[LAUGH]
>> Now always verify the stuff when

395
00:20:49.805 --> 00:20:50.546
you create it.

396
00:20:50.546 --> 00:20:55.507
You saw I used DF-H, which is kind of
quick way that I verify stuff that's

397
00:20:55.507 --> 00:20:58.721
mounted and
what their storages is available.

398
00:20:58.721 --> 00:21:01.820
But if it's not mounted yet,
DF doesn't help you, right?

399
00:21:01.820 --> 00:21:07.050
So remember, your lvdisplay, and
your vgdisplay, and your pvdisplay.

400
00:21:07.050 --> 00:21:09.960
Those are the ways that you're gonna
see how the LVM is configured and

401
00:21:09.960 --> 00:21:11.490
what its got available to you.

402
00:21:11.490 --> 00:21:13.350
Trust the output from those commands.

403
00:21:13.350 --> 00:21:14.620
That's good stuff.

404
00:21:14.620 --> 00:21:19.418
But, the whole while,
this is all being mapped really easy.

405
00:21:19.418 --> 00:21:21.700
Your volume group shows up in here.

406
00:21:21.700 --> 00:21:24.640
Inside of the volume group,
you see the volumes that are a part of it.

407
00:21:24.640 --> 00:21:29.000
The mapper service is running,
and with the mapper, you can

408
00:21:29.000 --> 00:21:32.730
actually browse into that, and you'll
see these alias names that they use.

409
00:21:32.730 --> 00:21:35.550
And you can kind of see
the data that's in there.

410
00:21:35.550 --> 00:21:37.570
It's all right in /dev.

411
00:21:37.570 --> 00:21:42.480
It's adding an extra layer of complexity,
but the tradeoff is that with that extra

412
00:21:42.480 --> 00:21:46.440
complexity, you get a lot more power, the
ability to change this stuff dynamically.

413
00:21:46.440 --> 00:21:48.430
And there's ways to do it without the LVM.

414
00:21:48.430 --> 00:21:49.790
LVM didn't invent this stuff.

415
00:21:49.790 --> 00:21:53.470
There were ways to do it before, but
a lot of them require kicking users out.

416
00:21:53.470 --> 00:21:56.030
This can all be done seamlessly
while the system is online.

417
00:21:56.030 --> 00:22:00.150
>> Well, Don, it really seems like LVM is
just the way to fly if you have the means.

418
00:22:00.150 --> 00:22:02.290
It's so much easier,
it gives you a whole lot of control,

419
00:22:02.290 --> 00:22:05.080
a whole lot of ability on top of that.

420
00:22:05.080 --> 00:22:10.340
Is there any reason we would use the older
like, Fdisk and all of that over this?

421
00:22:10.340 --> 00:22:14.670
>> If you were trying to create the most
streamlined, optimized system possible,

422
00:22:14.670 --> 00:22:16.960
like reducing memory load, and so on.

423
00:22:16.960 --> 00:22:19.500
Then you might choose to leave LVM off

424
00:22:19.500 --> 00:22:22.950
if a normal hard drive
structure serves your needs.

425
00:22:22.950 --> 00:22:25.540
If you're not gonna use
the advanced functionality of LVM,

426
00:22:25.540 --> 00:22:28.340
then you don't necessarily
need to load it.

427
00:22:28.340 --> 00:22:32.000
But I'll tell you, boy is it a lot
easier if you start out with LVM in

428
00:22:32.000 --> 00:22:34.110
the beginning,
then it is to try and retrofit.

429
00:22:34.110 --> 00:22:37.848
And what I see is a lot of people end up
where their boot volume is traditional and

430
00:22:37.848 --> 00:22:39.558
then everything else is using LVM.

431
00:22:39.558 --> 00:22:42.827
Where as if you had started that way you
could have your boot volume as a part

432
00:22:42.827 --> 00:22:43.372
of LVM too.

433
00:22:43.372 --> 00:22:47.092
And now if you are ever running out of
hard drive space on your root drive you

434
00:22:47.092 --> 00:22:47.882
can expand it.

435
00:22:47.882 --> 00:22:52.201
And it's really hard to
retrofit that boot volume.

436
00:22:52.201 --> 00:22:54.920
So those are kind of
things to think about.

437
00:22:54.920 --> 00:22:57.845
I generally do choose to use
LVM if I have the option.

438
00:22:57.845 --> 00:23:01.457
Most hardware these days the footprint or
fingerprint, or whatever, for

439
00:23:01.457 --> 00:23:04.627
the memory consumption is so
small that we don't worry about it.

440
00:23:04.627 --> 00:23:06.773
>> Kind of a rather have it and
not need it, then need it and

441
00:23:06.773 --> 00:23:07.860
not have it kind of thing.

442
00:23:07.860 --> 00:23:09.280
>> That's exactly right, yeah.

443
00:23:09.280 --> 00:23:12.960
And, if you're running any kind of Red-Hat
based OS, the odds are you've got LVM

444
00:23:12.960 --> 00:23:16.670
at least installed if not
actually active on your system.

445
00:23:16.670 --> 00:23:20.831
If you're running Debian, Ubuntu, those
guys, you may not even have it installed,

446
00:23:20.831 --> 00:23:23.170
they have some of their
own systems they use too.

447
00:23:23.170 --> 00:23:24.510
But LVM it's a great option,

448
00:23:24.510 --> 00:23:27.720
it's out there, it's pretty
much supported on every system.

449
00:23:27.720 --> 00:23:28.750
>> Very awesome.

450
00:23:28.750 --> 00:23:32.540
All right Don, have we cracked this
nut at least the basics of it that is?

451
00:23:32.540 --> 00:23:35.623
>> The only thing we didn't
cover was making those mounted

452
00:23:35.623 --> 00:23:37.531
drives persistent past a reboot.

453
00:23:37.531 --> 00:23:40.370
And like I said, we'll tackle that
in the final system health episode.

454
00:23:40.370 --> 00:23:43.060
The final system health
episode is going to apply

455
00:23:43.060 --> 00:23:46.540
regardless of whether you're using LVM or
not, so it's a little more generic.

456
00:23:46.540 --> 00:23:49.160
And we'll talk about how to mount it and
keep that file system healthy and stuff,

457
00:23:49.160 --> 00:23:51.080
so definitely keep an eye out for
that one.

458
00:23:51.080 --> 00:23:52.804
>> Awesome, yes,
definitely check that show out.

459
00:23:52.804 --> 00:23:56.964
But for this show, looks like we've come
to the end, so signing off for ITProTV,

460
00:23:56.964 --> 00:23:59.160
I've been your host, Daniel Lowry.

461
00:23:59.160 --> 00:24:00.050
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

462
00:24:00.050 --> 00:24:01.124
>> We'll see you next time.

463
00:24:01.124 --> 00:24:07.350
[MUSIC]

episodes.title: Filesystem Health
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.384
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:10.384 --> 00:00:11.414
All right, greetings everyone.

3
00:00:11.414 --> 00:00:16.579
Welcome to another great episode of
ITProTV, I'm your host Daniel Lowrie,

4
00:00:16.579 --> 00:00:20.472
and here with me today is
the Linux guru himself my mentor,

5
00:00:20.472 --> 00:00:23.430
my Yoda as it were of Linux, Don Pezet.

6
00:00:23.430 --> 00:00:24.640
>> So now, I'm some kinda short green guy.

7
00:00:24.640 --> 00:00:25.279
>> I'm setting the bar.

8
00:00:25.279 --> 00:00:26.775
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] All right, ladies and

9
00:00:26.775 --> 00:00:29.855
gentlemen, welcome back to
another episode of Linux Plus.

10
00:00:29.855 --> 00:00:33.869
We are actually gonna be jumping into
another two part series, so be ready for

11
00:00:33.869 --> 00:00:38.220
a cliffhanger at the end of this one,
as we talk about file system help.

12
00:00:38.220 --> 00:00:41.650
In other episodes we talked about like
how devices are detected in Linux and

13
00:00:41.650 --> 00:00:43.870
how we can partition and
mount hard drive and

14
00:00:43.870 --> 00:00:48.180
stuff, and we need to take
a look at that process again,

15
00:00:48.180 --> 00:00:51.370
to understand not just how to create
a hard drive you definitely know that.

16
00:00:51.370 --> 00:00:54.654
But, how to keep that drive
healthy once it's attached.

17
00:00:54.654 --> 00:00:58.222
And there's some really interesting stuff,
some interesting settings that

18
00:00:58.222 --> 00:01:01.949
are available, that we need to look at to
make sure that our hard drives are storing

19
00:01:01.949 --> 00:01:05.028
our data, and that we're able to
retrieve the data when we need it,

20
00:01:05.028 --> 00:01:08.738
that it's available when we want it and
not disappeared or offline or whatever.

21
00:01:08.738 --> 00:01:11.390
So we're gonna take a look
at some neat stuff there,

22
00:01:11.390 --> 00:01:14.180
more than what we can fit in one episode.

23
00:01:14.180 --> 00:01:17.660
>> Now, Don, we've talked in previous
episodes about mounting partitions,

24
00:01:17.660 --> 00:01:20.050
we've built partitions,
we did all sorts of really cool stuff.

25
00:01:20.050 --> 00:01:21.183
The LVM stuff was awesome.

26
00:01:21.183 --> 00:01:23.100
If you guys haven't seen that show,
check that out.

27
00:01:23.100 --> 00:01:27.370
Some very, very cool, what you can do
with multiple partitions using that.

28
00:01:27.370 --> 00:01:29.460
But, we've talked about how
we needed to mount them so

29
00:01:29.460 --> 00:01:31.570
that we can actually use that device.

30
00:01:31.570 --> 00:01:33.270
But, the change wasn't permanent.

31
00:01:33.270 --> 00:01:35.460
>> That's right, so
the way we mounted them in that episode,

32
00:01:35.460 --> 00:01:38.490
if we had rebooted that computer,
all our drives would have disappeared.

33
00:01:38.490 --> 00:01:42.590
And what we really needed to do
was to make those persistent, so

34
00:01:42.590 --> 00:01:45.160
they'd survive after the reboot.

35
00:01:45.160 --> 00:01:48.860
But, we held off in that episode, because
it actually is a little bit involved,

36
00:01:48.860 --> 00:01:51.650
the process that we need to
add a hard drive in there.

37
00:01:51.650 --> 00:01:55.570
And it starts to tinker with how
the health of that drive is maintained,

38
00:01:55.570 --> 00:01:57.970
and we'll see that right here.

39
00:01:57.970 --> 00:02:02.230
When your computer boots up,
it goes through a series of processes.

40
00:02:02.230 --> 00:02:06.100
It runs its boots loader,
it initializes Linux, and gets fired up.

41
00:02:06.100 --> 00:02:11.530
And at boot time, it looks for

00:13:49.110 --> 00:13:51.985

and thing on them now, so

269
00:13:51.985 --> 00:13:54.690
we need to overwrite, we're actually
writing to the memory buffer, and then

270
00:13:54.690 --> 00:13:57.840
they write to the disk in the background,
and we don't necessarily see that.

271
00:13:57.840 --> 00:14:02.341
Well, your operating system gets to make
a choice If I issue a command like copy

272
00:14:02.341 --> 00:14:06.730
file1.txt to file2.txt and
I press Enter, all right?

273
00:14:06.730 --> 00:14:09.590
It's going to be copying a file and
writing a new one.

274
00:14:09.590 --> 00:14:12.800
That command can do one of two things.

275
00:14:12.800 --> 00:14:15.710
One, it can run and wait for

276
00:14:15.710 --> 00:14:20.740
the copy to actually finish before
coming back and saying it's done.

277
00:14:20.740 --> 00:14:21.920
Or it can run and

278
00:14:21.920 --> 00:14:25.410
say it's done even though the copy might
still be happening in the background.

279
00:14:26.920 --> 00:14:30.310
The difference here is whether
it's asynchronous or synchronous.

280
00:14:30.310 --> 00:14:33.620
If it's asynchronous, we type the command.

281
00:14:33.620 --> 00:14:34.460
We press Enter.

282
00:14:34.460 --> 00:14:38.540
It'll say it's done, even though it might
still be running in the background.

283
00:14:38.540 --> 00:14:41.390
All right,
that makes the system run faster for us.

284
00:14:41.390 --> 00:14:45.190
But it does put us at a little bit of a
risk because we think the command is done

285
00:14:45.190 --> 00:14:47.770
when in reality it's still kind
of working in the background.

286
00:14:47.770 --> 00:14:50.900
And if you were to like power off the
system or whatever, you could lose data.

287
00:14:50.900 --> 00:14:54.120
You could end up with what's called
a dirty read and a dirty write.

288
00:14:54.120 --> 00:14:56.370
With synchronous, that doesn't happen.

289
00:14:56.370 --> 00:14:57.380
You know, you wait for

290
00:14:57.380 --> 00:15:00.890
that write operation to finish
before you move onto the next thing.

291
00:15:00.890 --> 00:15:04.660
That results in slower performance but
more reliable data.

292
00:15:04.660 --> 00:15:06.520
You've gotta make a choice on that.

00:15:06.520 --> 00:15:10.770
The default for almost every system
these days is asynchronous, and

00:15:10.770 --> 00:15:11.770

00:15:11.770 --> 00:15:12.670

00:15:12.670 --> 00:15:17.270

00:15:19.780 --> 00:15:21.070

00:15:21.070 --> 00:15:23.780

00:25:30.160 --> 00:25:34.540
And you can see where right now everything
that's in my system's been done as UUIDs.

498
00:25:34.540 --> 00:25:35.730
So maybe I wanna continue that,

499
00:25:35.730 --> 00:25:38.330
I'll continue to use these
UUIDs on this system.

500
00:25:38.330 --> 00:25:42.620
And that means I need to come back
here and get those UUIDs for each one.

501
00:25:42.620 --> 00:25:47.349
So if I wanna mount accounting
to /mnt/accounting,

502
00:25:47.349 --> 00:25:51.680
I would copy that UUID and
I would paste it in here.

503
00:25:53.480 --> 00:25:57.030
So I'll just throw that one in and then I
will tell it where I wanna mount it to.

504
00:25:57.030 --> 00:25:58.860
All right,
I want to mount that to Accounting and

505
00:25:58.860 --> 00:26:00.550
then I would tell it the file system.

506
00:26:00.550 --> 00:26:04.160
And my file system, if you look
back here for Accounting, is ext4.

507
00:26:04.160 --> 00:26:07.430
Or I could I could roll the dice and
put auto.

508
00:26:07.430 --> 00:26:09.262
>> Mmhmm.
>> That's always fun.

509
00:26:09.262 --> 00:26:12.470
All right, and
I'll use default options, and

510
00:26:12.470 --> 00:26:16.140
then I can specify whether we
want checks and all that stuff.

511
00:26:16.140 --> 00:26:18.930
And then I can go through and
start to add each of the other ones.

512
00:26:18.930 --> 00:26:21.370
Doing the same basic thing, right?

513
00:26:21.370 --> 00:26:25.931
Each one just kind of sticking it in as
far as which one's we're gonna mount.

514
00:26:25.931 --> 00:26:29.484
You may go into do sales next,
I'll get that one's UUID.

515
00:26:29.484 --> 00:26:33.975
Whoops, and then we'll run from there and

516
00:26:33.975 --> 00:26:37.980
it's not such a big deal, right?

517
00:26:37.980 --> 00:26:40.390
What was that, sales?

518
00:26:40.390 --> 00:26:43.090
All right, so we'll make that guy ext.

519
00:26:43.090 --> 00:26:43.708
What was sales?

520
00:26:43.708 --> 00:26:47.110
That's ext, I know one of mine is EXT3 so
I gotta remember...

521
00:26:47.110 --> 00:26:47.850
You might mix and

522
00:26:47.850 --> 00:26:50.730
match your file systems, that's something
you have to keep an eye out for.

523
00:26:50.730 --> 00:26:54.070
If you get the file system wrong,
it's not going to work so well.

524
00:26:54.070 --> 00:26:54.640
Let me tell you.

525
00:26:56.060 --> 00:26:59.670
All right, and then my last one
which is good old Marketing.

526
00:26:59.670 --> 00:27:03.550
So, we'll grab that one's UUID and
we're almost done.

527
00:27:04.790 --> 00:27:11.960
And so we'll throw that one in And
this one is /mnt/Marketing.

528
00:27:11.960 --> 00:27:13.790
And those are just the folders
where I want it mounted.

529
00:27:13.790 --> 00:27:14.890
We could mount it to anywhere.

530
00:27:14.890 --> 00:27:22.000
And I'll set that one as ext3 and
good old default and there we go.

531
00:27:22.000 --> 00:27:24.840
All right, so now I'm pretty well set.

532
00:27:24.840 --> 00:27:27.360
I'm just gonna quick review that

533
00:27:27.360 --> 00:27:30.200
fstab file real quick to
make sure everything's good.

534
00:27:30.200 --> 00:27:31.680
I've formatted mine, nice and neat.

535
00:27:31.680 --> 00:27:33.820
You don't have to,
it just needs a space in between these.

536
00:27:33.820 --> 00:27:35.310
You don't have to tab it out all nice and
even, but

537
00:27:35.310 --> 00:27:37.620
it sure does make it easier to read.

538
00:27:37.620 --> 00:27:41.260
Now that said, if I reboot,
those drives will be present.

539
00:27:41.260 --> 00:27:43.440
And if I wanna force a file system check,

540
00:27:43.440 --> 00:27:46.370
I can just go and add a one,
oevr in that file system check or

541
00:27:46.370 --> 00:27:49.610
a two, and they'll know to go ahead and
do the check and let that happen.

542
00:27:49.610 --> 00:27:51.610
We'll see how to manually
run that check in part two.

543
00:27:51.610 --> 00:27:54.620
But I'm gonna go ahead and do a reboot.

544
00:27:54.620 --> 00:27:59.940
And when it reboots, assuming I didn't
screw up my UUIDs, right, it should

545
00:27:59.940 --> 00:28:04.280
find those drives, automatically mount
them and I should be back in business.

546
00:28:04.280 --> 00:28:07.530
>> Now Don, you did say that you can
mix and match for using label or

547
00:28:07.530 --> 00:28:13.770
using the device, using the UUID,
GUID, or the part of that as well.

548
00:28:13.770 --> 00:28:16.420
Is there any benefit to
using one over the other, or

549
00:28:16.420 --> 00:28:18.570
is it just basically pick your poison?

550
00:28:18.570 --> 00:28:20.200
>> Well, for
the most part it's pick your poison.

551
00:28:20.200 --> 00:28:24.050
If you do a device name or
a UUID those are the two best, right?

552
00:28:24.050 --> 00:28:26.240
Those are the ones that I usually use.

553
00:28:26.240 --> 00:28:29.130
The labels,
while the labels are easier, right?

554
00:28:29.130 --> 00:28:31.170
You're gonna say label equals sales.

555
00:28:31.170 --> 00:28:34.470
That's a heck of a lot easier
than let me go get the UUID or

556
00:28:34.470 --> 00:28:37.290
let me go get the device name,
label equals marketing, right?

557
00:28:37.290 --> 00:28:38.870
It's so much easier.

558
00:28:38.870 --> 00:28:42.670
But there is no duplicate
checking in labels.

559
00:28:42.670 --> 00:28:46.180
I could have five volumes all
with the same label name, right?

560
00:28:46.180 --> 00:28:50.240
So that opens you up for
the possibility of an error.

561
00:28:50.240 --> 00:28:52.480
Maybe you've got some removable
media like a USB drive,

562
00:28:52.480 --> 00:28:54.360
and you just happen to have
two with the same name.

563
00:28:54.360 --> 00:28:58.270
And if they're both connected at the same
time, which one's gonna get mounted?

564
00:28:58.270 --> 00:29:00.000
Whichever one comes first
is gonna get mounted,

565
00:29:00.000 --> 00:29:00.990
the other one's not gonna get mounted.

566
00:29:00.990 --> 00:29:02.960
So, you kind of open yourself up to doubt.

567
00:29:02.960 --> 00:29:06.550
So I don't like to use labels,
I don't normally even label my drives,

568
00:29:06.550 --> 00:29:08.840
to be honest with you.

569
00:29:08.840 --> 00:29:10.330
But using the device name,

570
00:29:10.330 --> 00:29:13.770
using the UUID, those are always safe,
those you don't have to sweat.

571
00:29:13.770 --> 00:29:17.020
>> Much more unique
identifier than to allow for

572
00:29:17.020 --> 00:29:18.160
none of those mistakes obviously.

573
00:29:18.160 --> 00:29:19.810
You're probably not gonna type those in,

574
00:29:19.810 --> 00:29:23.075
you're gonna be cutting and
pasting them into the document, itself.

575
00:29:23.075 --> 00:29:23.840
>> Hm-hm.
But

576
00:29:23.840 --> 00:29:26.440
gonna keep you away from having
any of those duplications.

577
00:29:26.440 --> 00:29:27.510
>> Yeah, absolutely.

578
00:29:27.510 --> 00:29:31.208
Yeah, UUIDs are neat, cuz they even
survive having the device name change.

579
00:29:31.208 --> 00:29:34.980
So, if UDIV, for whatever reason,
assigns you a new name or

580
00:29:34.980 --> 00:29:39.360
you move that drive to another physical
server, it actually preserves the UUID.

581
00:29:39.360 --> 00:29:41.760
It stays the same,
whereas the device name might change.

582
00:29:41.760 --> 00:29:45.850
So, that's why you see a lot of
systems use UUIDs by default now.

583
00:29:45.850 --> 00:29:49.194
But I'm just gonna double check,
so in my fstab,

584
00:29:49.194 --> 00:29:54.527
if I look I can see all of those guys are
still there, and if I run a mount command,

585
00:29:54.527 --> 00:29:59.386
and I'm just gonna grab for mnt, and
I can see marketing, accounting,

586
00:29:59.386 --> 00:30:03.158
and sales are all mounted,
and up and running, right?

587
00:30:03.158 --> 00:30:04.847
So they're all healthy, they're happy, and

588
00:30:04.847 --> 00:30:08.030
they're ready to rock right here at boot
time, cuz they were in that file today.

589
00:30:08.030 --> 00:30:09.220
>> That is awesome stuff, Don.

590
00:30:09.220 --> 00:30:12.610
This is the meat and
potatoes of Linux administration.

591
00:30:12.610 --> 00:30:14.710
This is stuff you're
actually going to be doing,

592
00:30:14.710 --> 00:30:18.800
probably quite a bit as you work with
Linux through your time with that.

593
00:30:18.800 --> 00:30:21.800
That being said, there is a whole lot
more and we do have a part 2 coming up.

594
00:30:21.800 --> 00:30:25.170
So check that out as soon
as it's available, as well.

595
00:30:25.170 --> 00:30:27.400
That being said,
it looks like we've wrapped up yet

596
00:30:27.400 --> 00:30:29.770
another episode here at ITProTV.

597
00:30:29.770 --> 00:30:31.000
So signing off.

598
00:30:31.000 --> 00:30:32.850
I guess I've been your host, Daniel Lowry.

599
00:30:32.850 --> 00:30:35.150
>> [LAUGH] And
I guess I've been Don Pezet.

600
00:30:35.150 --> 00:30:36.499
>> We'll see you next time.

601
00:30:36.499 --> 00:30:42.460

WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.414
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:10.414 --> 00:00:11.580
All right, greetings everyone.

3
00:00:11.580 --> 00:00:15.112
And welcome to another
fantastic episode of ITProTV.

4
00:00:15.112 --> 00:00:18.860
I'm your host, Daniel Lowry and here with
me today is none other than Don Pezet.

5
00:00:18.860 --> 00:00:20.060
How's it going, Don?

6
00:00:20.060 --> 00:00:23.130
>> I'm doing great, Daniel, and
I'm excited to jump back into another

7
00:00:23.130 --> 00:00:27.490
part two, right, another action-packed
adventure, conclusion, whatever.

8
00:00:27.490 --> 00:00:29.096
>> Thrills, chills and
bone-crunching spills.

9
00:00:29.096 --> 00:00:30.610
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] In part one,

10
00:00:30.610 --> 00:00:34.490
we started talking about file system help,
and we really focused more on

11
00:00:34.490 --> 00:00:37.830
just making sure our file system was
mounted when we booted up, right, and

12
00:00:37.830 --> 00:00:39.100
a couple of basic things.

13
00:00:39.100 --> 00:00:42.840
In this episode, we're gonna talk about
looking for errors on those drives,

14
00:00:42.840 --> 00:00:46.230
and keeping them clean and healthy, and
some of the different conversions and

15
00:00:46.230 --> 00:00:47.740
migrations that we can do.

16
00:00:47.740 --> 00:00:50.700
There's a couple of different tools
that are out there that can be

17
00:00:50.700 --> 00:00:53.350
really useful in maintaining your drives.

18
00:00:53.350 --> 00:00:53.850
>> Yeah.
That's one

19
00:00:53.850 --> 00:00:55.110
thing I really like about Linux.

20
00:00:55.110 --> 00:00:59.700
They give you such a variety of
applications and software and things that,

21
00:00:59.700 --> 00:01:04.490
basically those little tools that come
bundled into the Linux operating system

22
00:01:04.490 --> 00:01:09.140
itself that give you a vast
array of abilities to work with.

23
00:01:09.140 --> 00:01:10.230
Your file systems, your program,

24
00:01:10.230 --> 00:01:13.670
a bunch of stuff, whereas, normally you
have to get a bunch of third-party stuff.

25
00:01:13.670 --> 00:01:14.565
And you could still do that.

26
00:01:14.565 --> 00:01:17.410
>> Mm-hm.
>> But having that built into the OS

27
00:01:17.410 --> 00:01:18.930
out of the gate, that's a real help.

28
00:01:20.190 --> 00:01:21.760
>> Now one of the things
we have to watch for

29
00:01:21.760 --> 00:01:25.520
on our disks is how much disk
utilization we got, right?

30
00:01:25.520 --> 00:01:28.006
Running out of hard drive space is
something that happens [LAUGH] less and

31
00:01:28.006 --> 00:01:30.502
less frequently nowadays as the large
drives get really inexpensive.

32
00:01:30.502 --> 00:01:34.888
But when you start partitioning your drive
out and creating these smaller volumes,

33
00:01:34.888 --> 00:01:37.210
you can run out of hard drive space.

34
00:01:37.210 --> 00:01:40.545
So, knowing that's [LAUGH] happening
before it actually occurs is kind of

35
00:01:40.545 --> 00:01:41.200
a nice thing.

36
00:01:41.200 --> 00:01:44.860
And so we got a neat little command that,
which is the DF Command.

37
00:01:44.860 --> 00:01:47.440
So, I've got a Linux box
pulled up right here and

38
00:01:47.440 --> 00:01:49.820
if I just wanna see how
full my drives are or

39
00:01:49.820 --> 00:01:54.690
how empty my drives are, I can run df and
it will give me the information.

40
00:01:54.690 --> 00:01:58.250
Now, it lists it all by mount point,
right?

41
00:01:58.250 --> 00:02:02.560
So, you might have several volumes
all mounted inside of your hierarchy,

42
00:02:02.560 --> 00:02:04.020
you might just have a handful.

43
00:02:04.020 --> 00:02:08.400
But I can see like for me I got these
sales, marketing, accounting, drives.

44
00:02:08.400 --> 00:02:10.060
And they're all different sizes.

45
00:02:10.060 --> 00:02:14.000
If we look at the amount of blocks
in each one, how many are used and

46
00:02:14.000 --> 00:02:15.070
how many are available?

47
00:02:15.070 --> 00:02:17.810
Now, one problem I have
with the DF Command,

48
00:02:17.810 --> 00:02:20.210
is this isn't really very human readable.

49
00:02:20.210 --> 00:02:22.400
The only part that's human
readable is this Use column,

50
00:02:22.400 --> 00:02:26.555
where I can see that that
my root volume is 17% full.

51
00:02:26.555 --> 00:02:27.907
My boot volume is 14%.

52
00:02:27.907 --> 00:02:30.415
Everything else is next to empty, right?

53
00:02:30.415 --> 00:02:31.605
And that will update.

54
00:02:31.605 --> 00:02:35.192
But a way to make it a little
more useful is if you do DF-H.

55
00:02:35.192 --> 00:02:36.775
That makes it human readable.

56
00:02:36.775 --> 00:02:41.564
And when you do DF-H, see how now, instead
of blocks, I'm getting an actual size.

57
00:02:41.564 --> 00:02:44.830
My sda2 is 18 gigs in size.

58
00:02:44.830 --> 00:02:46.070
I've got 14 gigs available.

59
00:02:46.070 --> 00:02:48.310
That's pretty handy information to have.

60
00:02:48.310 --> 00:02:51.940
My Sales, Marketing and Accounting,
they're all 64 Gig drives, and

61
00:02:51.940 --> 00:02:54.860
they've all got at least 60
gigs available space on them.

62
00:02:54.860 --> 00:02:56.810
We've got plenty of room.

63
00:02:56.810 --> 00:02:58.580
And this updates in real time, right?

64
00:02:58.580 --> 00:03:02.681
If we were to try and like flood data
onto the drive to start filling it up for

65
00:03:02.681 --> 00:03:07.069
example, if I were to do like a d, let's
just see what I can get away with here.

66
00:03:07.069 --> 00:03:12.347
If I do a dd and
import something like /dev/zero,

67
00:03:12.347 --> 00:03:18.613
and I'll send that into
/mnt/Accounting/file.bin and

68
00:03:18.613 --> 00:03:26.260
we'll setup a large size of that
in a count of, let's do a 1000.

69
00:03:26.260 --> 00:03:30.020
I'm gonna throw in a quick
gig of data into that system.

70
00:03:30.020 --> 00:03:33.270
And so I'm gonna just chunk
that on over there and

71
00:03:33.270 --> 00:03:35.900
it's basically starting to fill
that drive up with some data.

72
00:03:35.900 --> 00:03:38.360
So I just do 1 gig of data in there.

73
00:03:38.360 --> 00:03:40.750
Well, it was 1% used a minute ago.

74
00:03:40.750 --> 00:03:45.700
Now, if I pull off my listing,
I can see I'm 2%, right?

75
00:03:45.700 --> 00:03:47.746
64 gig drive, I just used 1.2 gigs.

76
00:03:47.746 --> 00:03:50.410
This gives you a really good reflection.

77
00:03:50.410 --> 00:03:53.963
So if you've got a drive that's
in the danger zone, 80% or

78
00:03:53.963 --> 00:03:57.510
above, you know that that's a system
you need to take some attention to.

79
00:03:57.510 --> 00:04:00.451
>> Don, are you disk have full or
disk have empty kind of guy?

80
00:04:00.451 --> 00:04:02.780
[LAUGH]
>> The disk is always not big enough.

81
00:04:02.780 --> 00:04:04.413
>> There you go.
[LAUGH] >> That's the way I look at it.

82
00:04:04.413 --> 00:04:06.000
Doesn't matter how much
available space is on there.

83
00:04:06.000 --> 00:04:07.961
>> The IT Philosophizing of Don Pezet.

84
00:04:07.961 --> 00:04:09.933
[LAUGH]
>> Now, let's say you look at the disk and

85
00:04:09.933 --> 00:04:12.340
it is almost full, and you're like, man.

86
00:04:12.340 --> 00:04:14.760
Who is it that's using up my space?

87
00:04:14.760 --> 00:04:18.480
Sometimes we wanna have
an idea of how much space

88
00:04:18.480 --> 00:04:22.250
a folder is consuming on our drive,
not the whole drive like this.

89
00:04:22.250 --> 00:04:26.210
And so the sister command to
the DF utility is the DU command,

90
00:04:26.210 --> 00:04:28.130
which is the disk usage.

91
00:04:28.130 --> 00:04:32.410
And so you can say DU and
then you can specify a path.

92
00:04:32.410 --> 00:04:35.950
And so I can say like, my home directory,
I wonder how big that is?

93
00:04:35.950 --> 00:04:40.780
So, if I do du/home/dpezet,
I can run that and it's gonna

94
00:04:40.780 --> 00:04:45.160
give me a list of what's in there and
I can see that utilization, right?

95
00:04:45.160 --> 00:04:48.920
Now, running it like this just
gives me how much each file is.

96
00:04:48.920 --> 00:04:52.500
But then right here at the end,
I kind of get that bigger summary.

97
00:04:52.500 --> 00:04:56.760
Now it has a couple interesting options if
you look what's available inside of it.

98
00:04:56.760 --> 00:05:01.240
And so we get -a for write counts for
all, not just directories.

99
00:05:01.240 --> 00:05:02.600
We start to get the count information.

100
00:05:02.600 --> 00:05:05.320
And that's actually
the default on this system.

101
00:05:05.320 --> 00:05:09.420
But you can also tell it to show things
in bytes instead of kilobytes or

102
00:05:09.420 --> 00:05:10.610
blocks or whatever.

103
00:05:10.610 --> 00:05:14.780
You've got a few different variations
of that, -h to make it human readable.

104
00:05:14.780 --> 00:05:16.830
Again another kind of useful thing.

105
00:05:16.830 --> 00:05:19.880
And -c to give you a grand total.

106
00:05:19.880 --> 00:05:22.690
And that's one that I
absolutely like to use.

107
00:05:22.690 --> 00:05:27.007
So if I were to rerun that and
this time do like a -ch, right?

108
00:05:28.300 --> 00:05:30.830
And that way I get my total count and
it's human-readable.

109
00:05:30.830 --> 00:05:32.670
Now I can run it and I can see right here,

110
00:05:32.670 --> 00:05:36.890
the total,
my profile is 1.1 megs in size, right?

111
00:05:36.890 --> 00:05:41.210
So now I can start to spot where that
utilization is actually being eaten up.

112
00:05:41.210 --> 00:05:44.784
If I go into, like, /MNT,
and I take a look at it,

113
00:05:44.784 --> 00:05:47.787
in /MNT, I have about a gigabyte of data.

114
00:05:47.787 --> 00:05:52.290
And as I look at the folders underneath
it, I can see where that gig came from.

115
00:05:52.290 --> 00:05:54.420
It came from Accounting, right?

116
00:05:54.420 --> 00:05:57.790
Now we can start to find where our
disk is being consumed, right?

117
00:05:57.790 --> 00:05:58.940
Where we've got extra stuff.

118
00:05:58.940 --> 00:06:05.308
So, DF to look at the disk as a whole and
DU to look at folders inside of that disk.

119
00:06:05.308 --> 00:06:05.825
>> Awesome.
