it's going to do a check.

343
00:17:48.270 --> 00:17:50.310
Or, If I've only rebooted it once and

344
00:17:50.310 --> 00:17:54.590
six months goes by, the next time I
reboot it, it's going to do a check.

345
00:17:54.590 --> 00:17:58.270
This is how I can set the interval for
how often that occurs, and

346
00:17:58.270 --> 00:18:00.840
you can set something much,
much lower if you want.

347
00:18:00.840 --> 00:18:04.710
Maybe I want to check every
time I mount the thing, right,

348
00:18:04.710 --> 00:18:06.330
we can set that c to one.

349
00:18:06.330 --> 00:18:09.140
And now every time I reboot or
I mount this system,

350
00:18:09.140 --> 00:18:12.770
it's going to run an fsck check on it
automatically to make sure it's healthy.

351
00:18:12.770 --> 00:18:15.025
You might want that.

352
00:18:15.025 --> 00:18:19.495
You might not, on a desktop it would be
super annoying, on a server maybe you do.

353
00:18:19.495 --> 00:18:23.015
But on a desktop we might want something
bigger, we could specify that, so I might

354
00:18:23.015 --> 00:18:28.615
say every 30 reboot or every one month,
you're saying dash c is the count for

355
00:18:28.615 --> 00:18:32.435
amounts, and dash i is the interval for
time, that's what those two values are,

356
00:18:32.435 --> 00:18:34.965
and now I can tell it how often
I want those checks to occur.

357
00:18:36.130 --> 00:18:36.670
And there we go.

358
00:18:36.670 --> 00:18:39.520
I've set that maximum mount count,

359
00:18:39.520 --> 00:18:41.750
the maximum amount of mounts to
go without doing a check to 30m,

360
00:18:41.750 --> 00:18:45.781
and the interval between checks to,
you see it's done in seconds.

361
00:18:45.781 --> 00:18:48.190
I set it to one month, so
that's quite a few seconds.

362
00:18:48.190 --> 00:18:51.800
So, that's a cool way to kind of measure
when your systems are going to be checked.

363
00:18:53.780 --> 00:18:59.040
Another really powerful thing that tunefs
can do is it can enable journaling.

364
00:18:59.040 --> 00:18:59.960
All right?

365
00:18:59.960 --> 00:19:02.340
Now let's talk about journal
file systems for a second,

366
00:19:02.340 --> 00:19:04.270
because you might not know what those are.

367
00:19:04.270 --> 00:19:08.740
Almost all of your modern
file systems use journaling.

368
00:19:08.740 --> 00:19:13.600
Your EXT 4, XFS, JFS,
that's what we just created,

369
00:19:13.600 --> 00:19:19.190
Riser FS, even NTFS to an extent
has a weird kind of internal thing.

370
00:19:19.190 --> 00:19:23.450
If you have Apple HFS with Journaling,
it does journaling.

371
00:19:23.450 --> 00:19:24.680
It's kind of in the name.

372
00:19:24.680 --> 00:19:27.970
So, a lot of people do journaling,
but what is it?

373
00:19:27.970 --> 00:19:31.010
Well, one weakness our hard drive has is,

374
00:19:31.010 --> 00:19:35.540
what happens if you start writing data
to the hard drive and you lose power?

375
00:19:37.690 --> 00:19:39.080
You got a partial write.

376
00:19:39.080 --> 00:19:42.090
So when you reboot, you got half a file,
or third of a file,

377
00:19:42.090 --> 00:19:44.530
or two-thirds,
whenever the power went out, right?

378
00:19:44.530 --> 00:19:48.050
You got part of a file, and
what good is a part of a file?

379
00:19:48.050 --> 00:19:48.790
>> No good.

380
00:19:48.790 --> 00:19:50.350
>> No good at all, right.

381
00:19:50.350 --> 00:19:54.500
What if I had a file on the hard
drive that was a meg in size?

382
00:19:54.500 --> 00:19:55.490
I opened it.

383
00:19:55.490 --> 00:19:58.360
I edited one line, and
then I went to save it.

384
00:19:58.360 --> 00:19:59.440
It's going to rewrite that 1 meg file.

385
00:19:59.440 --> 00:20:03.560
It's going to start overwriting
part of the existing file.

386
00:20:03.560 --> 00:20:06.490
And then if I lose power,
I lose the whole thing.

387
00:20:06.490 --> 00:20:08.450
I just changed one line, but
it wrote the whole file.

388
00:20:08.450 --> 00:20:09.670
I just lost the whole thing.

389
00:20:09.670 --> 00:20:11.700
It's now corrupt,
it's damaged and that's it.

390
00:20:11.700 --> 00:20:17.430
Traditional hard drives are not very good
at surviving power outages or any kind of

391
00:20:17.430 --> 00:20:21.150
interruption to its write ability, right,
anything that causes that not to happen.

392
00:20:21.150 --> 00:20:24.680
So a journal works to save that, right?

393
00:20:24.680 --> 00:20:27.720
So if I have a 1 meg file and
it's stored right here, and

394
00:20:27.720 --> 00:20:32.420
I make a change to that one meg file, when
I go to save it, it says you know what?

395
00:20:32.420 --> 00:20:33.205
I'm going to save it over here.

396
00:20:33.205 --> 00:20:34.636
I'm going to just save
it in a different place.

397
00:20:34.636 --> 00:20:38.928
And it puts it over here and
when it writes 100% of this file,

398
00:20:38.928 --> 00:20:44.889
then it removes the other one, and you're
left with this good one that's 100% red,

399
00:20:44.889 --> 00:20:49.337
but if I've got my original file and
I start writing this new one and

400
00:20:49.337 --> 00:20:55.370
I lose power halfway through, when it
reboots, it just throws away the halfway.

401
00:20:55.370 --> 00:20:57.370
And now I'm back to the original file.

402
00:20:57.370 --> 00:20:58.520
Yeah, I lost my changes.

403
00:20:58.520 --> 00:20:59.910
That kind of sucks.

404
00:20:59.910 --> 00:21:01.280
But at least my file's intact.

405
00:21:01.280 --> 00:21:02.640
I didn't get corruption.

406
00:21:02.640 --> 00:21:04.650
That's what a journaling file system does.

407
00:21:04.650 --> 00:21:08.150
It sets aside a piece of disk space,

408
00:21:08.150 --> 00:21:10.930
and the percentage is various
based on how it's configured.

409
00:21:10.930 --> 00:21:13.420
But it sets aside a little
slice of the drive.

410
00:21:13.420 --> 00:21:14.880
And it says from now on, when I do writes,

411
00:21:14.880 --> 00:21:16.910
I'm going to do write
to this area instead.

412
00:21:16.910 --> 00:21:19.000
Or it might even do it inline
with just a regular drive.

413
00:21:19.000 --> 00:21:20.800
I've seen that too where
it just writes wherever.

414
00:21:20.800 --> 00:21:22.410
I'm going to write in this other space.

415
00:21:22.410 --> 00:21:24.470
I'm just not going to
overwrite the original file.

416
00:21:24.470 --> 00:21:28.640
Until I have a hundred 100% of that write
done, and then I'll remove the original.

417
00:21:28.640 --> 00:21:32.440
It gives you guaranteed write integrity,
if you write data,

418
00:21:32.440 --> 00:21:35.220
it's either going to write 100%,
or it's going to write 0%, you're

419
00:21:35.220 --> 00:21:38.590
never going to end up with something
in between on a journaling file system.

420
00:21:38.590 --> 00:21:40.210
Sounds like a good thing right?

421
00:21:40.210 --> 00:21:41.310
That's what we want.

422
00:21:41.310 --> 00:21:45.460
Well if you're running EXT 3 or higher,

423
00:21:45.460 --> 00:21:47.990
if you're running XFS,
you're already journaling.

424
00:21:47.990 --> 00:21:49.179
It's on, you don't have to mess with it.

425
00:21:50.180 --> 00:21:55.450
But if you inherit a server that's
running ext2, ext2 is not journaling.

426
00:21:55.450 --> 00:21:58.760
And the only difference between ext2 and
ext3 is journaling.

427
00:21:58.760 --> 00:22:01.940
That's the difference,
they turn on journaling, they become ext3.

428
00:22:01.940 --> 00:22:05.830
So, we may want to convert
from ext2 to ext3.

429
00:22:05.830 --> 00:22:07.590
We don't need to use FS transform for
that.

430
00:22:07.590 --> 00:22:09.360
We're not actually
converting file systems,

431
00:22:09.360 --> 00:22:13.630
we're just turning on journaling and
Tune 2 FS is what does it, all right?

432
00:22:13.630 --> 00:22:19.290
If I look at my drives here, you'll see
where I've got one drive on this turkey.

433
00:22:19.290 --> 00:22:20.250
Let's see, where is it?

434
00:22:20.250 --> 00:22:21.070
That one is EXT4.

435
00:22:21.070 --> 00:22:21.590
Got it.

436
00:22:21.590 --> 00:22:22.870
This guy, sales.

437
00:22:22.870 --> 00:22:27.880
My sales drive right here has
a file system type of ext2.

438
00:22:27.880 --> 00:22:31.760
So it's ext2, it is not journaling.

439
00:22:31.760 --> 00:22:35.510
If I want to make it journal,
I just need to turn it on, okay, and

440
00:22:35.510 --> 00:22:37.540
turning it on is kind
of a two-step process.

441
00:22:37.540 --> 00:22:44.630
Step one, I run tune2fs dash j,
I'm tuning the journaling on this drive,

442
00:22:44.630 --> 00:22:48.820
and then I specified a drive /dev/SDB1,
okay?

443
00:22:48.820 --> 00:22:50.670
So when I run that, there it runs and

444
00:22:50.670 --> 00:22:53.130
it tells me the system will
automatically check every 29 mounts,

445
00:22:53.130 --> 00:22:57.810
these are the default values that
I overrode earlier, or 180 days.

446
00:22:57.810 --> 00:23:01.490
And it's creating that journal inode,
and it's done.

447
00:23:01.490 --> 00:23:03.790
All right, I've now enabled journaling.

448
00:23:03.790 --> 00:23:06.340
That's awesome,
now my drive is super stable, right?

449
00:23:06.340 --> 00:23:08.990
Well, actually that drive's
really unstable right now,

450
00:23:08.990 --> 00:23:10.870
because the system still thinks it's EXT2.

451
00:23:10.870 --> 00:23:14.470
And if I reboot, it's going to try and
mount at EXT2 and there's this journal

452
00:23:14.470 --> 00:23:16.320
that's going to freak out and
the drive's not going to show up and

453
00:23:16.320 --> 00:23:19.090
I'm going to lose data and
it's not going to be a happy place.

454
00:23:19.090 --> 00:23:23.918
So, what I really need to do,
as I need to edit my fstab file.

455
00:23:23.918 --> 00:23:28.600
So /etc/fstab table.

456
00:23:28.600 --> 00:23:33.120
I need to go in and find my sales drive,
and I need to change it so

457
00:23:33.120 --> 00:23:35.720
then instead of ext2, it's now ext3.

458
00:23:35.720 --> 00:23:40.370
And when I change that, now it knows.

459
00:23:40.370 --> 00:23:42.680
Oh, well, this is the ext3.

460
00:23:42.680 --> 00:23:43.810
It has a journal.

461
00:23:43.810 --> 00:23:44.730
All right.

462
00:23:44.730 --> 00:23:47.130
If I can reboot the server,
that's the easiest way to reboot.

463
00:23:47.130 --> 00:23:49.300
If I can't,
if the server's in use right now,

464
00:23:49.300 --> 00:23:53.370
one of the things you can just do is
unmount it and remount it again, right?

465
00:23:53.370 --> 00:23:59.548
So, if I go in here and just say like
you mount slash mnt slash sales.

466
00:23:59.548 --> 00:24:02.650
I can un-mount it, right,
so now it's dismounted, and

467
00:24:02.650 --> 00:24:06.930
I can remount it again, and
it is, what is my sales drive,

468
00:24:06.930 --> 00:24:12.040
it's slash dev slash,
oh shoot now I forgot what it was.

469
00:24:12.040 --> 00:24:13.060
There, sdb1.

470
00:24:13.060 --> 00:24:16.370
So I'll steal it from my
toon command earlier.

471
00:24:16.370 --> 00:24:20.090
So I want to mount slash dev slash
sdb1 into slash mnt slash sales.

472
00:24:20.090 --> 00:24:23.580
Alright, so now I've remounted it.

473
00:24:23.580 --> 00:24:27.320
And once it's remounted,
it'll understand that it's ext3.

474
00:24:27.320 --> 00:24:30.800
And so if I find my Sales drive,
there it is.

475
00:24:30.800 --> 00:24:34.380
And then it understands that
it should have a journal.

476
00:24:34.380 --> 00:24:36.960
So at a minimum, edit fstab,
and then reboot.

477
00:24:38.100 --> 00:24:40.538
Or if you can't reboot,
still edit your f stab,

478
00:24:40.538 --> 00:24:44.000
that's important because
you will reboot eventually.

479
00:24:44.000 --> 00:24:46.620
And then make sure you unmount and
remount the drive.

480
00:24:46.620 --> 00:24:49.380
That way it'll now mount as ext3,
and it'll show up right.

481
00:24:49.380 --> 00:24:52.730
So really easy to turn that journaling
on and get that functionality.

482
00:24:52.730 --> 00:24:54.230
If you're ext4, you've already got it.

483
00:24:54.230 --> 00:24:55.520
It's a great function.

484
00:24:55.520 --> 00:24:58.190
It's definitely something you want.

485
00:24:58.190 --> 00:24:59.520
It really works out well.

486
00:24:59.520 --> 00:25:00.710
I say it's something you want.

487
00:25:00.710 --> 00:25:04.750
There's one little scenario with online
transaction processing databases where you

488
00:25:04.750 --> 00:25:08.910
might want to disable journaling, for
faster write performance, but for

489
00:25:08.910 --> 00:25:12.670
most people, like 99% of the time,
journaling is something you want.

490
00:25:12.670 --> 00:25:16.160
>> Yeah.
So many options, so many tools

491
00:25:16.160 --> 00:25:20.660
to help tune up our systems, make sure
they run as efficiently as possible.

492
00:25:20.660 --> 00:25:23.820
Journaling, obviously that is something
that we're definitely going to

493
00:25:23.820 --> 00:25:25.610
want to have enabled on our systems.

494
00:25:25.610 --> 00:25:28.035
I know when that came out I was like,
this is awesome, right?

495
00:25:28.035 --> 00:25:30.530
Because I fell prey to that as well.

496
00:25:30.530 --> 00:25:35.290
You lose power or something goes out,
lose those files and that's a big bummer.

497
00:25:35.290 --> 00:25:36.130
>> It's one of those things.

498
00:25:36.130 --> 00:25:39.820
I remember the first time I read about
it and I was thinking, man, this is so

499
00:25:39.820 --> 00:25:43.030
simple, why didn't anybody
think of this before?

500
00:25:43.030 --> 00:25:45.530
And how does, if you ever wonder,
like somebody

501
00:25:45.530 --> 00:25:48.240
who has a PhD in computer science,
they say what do you do with a PhD?

502
00:25:48.240 --> 00:25:49.530
You come up with junk like this.

503
00:25:49.530 --> 00:25:51.346
>> [LAUGH]
>> And it's so common sense,

504
00:25:51.346 --> 00:25:53.585
the way that it works,
it really is impressive.

505
00:25:53.585 --> 00:25:55.277
And you see that in computers a lot.

506
00:25:55.277 --> 00:25:57.070
That's the fascinating part.

507
00:25:57.070 --> 00:26:00.010
People come up with really
simple solutions to problems,

508
00:26:00.010 --> 00:26:03.410
and all of a sudden your disk integrity
goes through the roof, right?

509
00:26:03.410 --> 00:26:07.420
You don't have the failures you used to
just because you wrote to a different

510
00:26:07.420 --> 00:26:11.090
sector for a second while you removed it
in the other place, it really doesn't.

511
00:26:11.090 --> 00:26:14.240
>> The best app solutions are usually
the most simple, right Don?

512
00:26:14.240 --> 00:26:15.380
>> Yeah.
>> Well that being said,

513
00:26:15.380 --> 00:26:19.120
it does look like we've wrapped up
another episode here at IT Pro TV.

514
00:26:19.120 --> 00:26:22.250
So signing off,
I've been your host, Daniel Lowry.

515
00:26:22.250 --> 00:26:23.500
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

516
00:26:23.500 --> 00:26:25.870
>> And we'll see you next time.

episodes.title: File Management Commands
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:09.960
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:09.960 --> 00:00:14.193
All right, greetings everyone, and welcome
to another great episode of ITProTV.

3
00:00:14.193 --> 00:00:15.774
I'll be your host Daniel Lowrie,

4
00:00:15.774 --> 00:00:18.205
and here with me today is
none other than Don Pezet.

5
00:00:18.205 --> 00:00:19.315
What's going on, Don?

6
00:00:19.315 --> 00:00:22.055
>> Well, you know,
it's another exciting day of Linux Plus.

7
00:00:22.055 --> 00:00:24.845
And we're gonna be jumping
into file management commands.

8
00:00:24.845 --> 00:00:29.065
And these are commands that you're
gonna use every single day, right?

9
00:00:29.065 --> 00:00:30.255
Well, maybe not.

10
00:00:30.255 --> 00:00:31.665
Maybe you take a day off, right?

11
00:00:31.665 --> 00:00:32.935
But if you're at work,

12
00:00:32.935 --> 00:00:35.850
the odds are you're gonna use at least
one of these file management commands.

13
00:00:35.850 --> 00:00:38.120
And we've really been using them
all throughout the show anyway,

14
00:00:38.120 --> 00:00:43.120
because in the Linux operating system
everything is represented as a file,

15
00:00:43.120 --> 00:00:44.340
well almost everything.

16
00:00:44.340 --> 00:00:47.590
So all of our hardware that we've been
working with in our previous episodes,

17
00:00:47.590 --> 00:00:50.730
those were files as we've kind of
browsing our file system and so on.

18
00:00:50.730 --> 00:00:53.740
Well, we need to make sure that we've
got a good comfort level with that.

19
00:00:53.740 --> 00:00:56.380
And so today we're gonna tackle
some of the basic commands and

20
00:00:56.380 --> 00:00:58.990
some of the intermediate commands
you're gonna use as far as manipulating

21
00:00:58.990 --> 00:01:00.420
files on your hard drive.

22
00:01:00.420 --> 00:01:04.770
>> Yeah, unless you want to try to
actually memorize every path and filename,

23
00:01:04.770 --> 00:01:06.930
and that's probably never going to happen,

24
00:01:06.930 --> 00:01:09.850
we're gonna need these commands to get
us bopping around the command line.

25
00:01:09.850 --> 00:01:14.690
I use ls a lot, things like that, and even
if I know where I'm at and what I'm doing,

26
00:01:14.690 --> 00:01:18.480
I still tend to just out of habit
run these types of commands, so

27
00:01:18.480 --> 00:01:22.370
that I continually get a good visual
of where I'm at and what I'm doing.

28
00:01:22.370 --> 00:01:26.050
Keeps me going on the track I need
to go down, so yeah good stuff.

29
00:01:26.050 --> 00:01:30.460
>> All right, so, when you first log in to
a Linux shell, whether it be bash, or csh,

30
00:01:30.460 --> 00:01:35.550
tcsh, whatever shell it is that you use,
when you log in, you're given a prompt.

31
00:01:35.550 --> 00:01:38.970
And your prompt is just where
you type your commands and

32
00:01:38.970 --> 00:01:40.850
the system interprets it.

33
00:01:40.850 --> 00:01:44.330
It has a location that
you're at on the drive.

34
00:01:44.330 --> 00:01:46.960
What's called your present
working directory.

35
00:01:46.960 --> 00:01:48.540
And when you start issuing commands,

36
00:01:48.540 --> 00:01:51.490
it issues them from the perspective
of that present working directory.

37
00:01:51.490 --> 00:01:54.820
And in that directory there may or
may not be files.

38
00:01:54.820 --> 00:01:58.500
So one of the most important commands
that we can learn, really there's two.

39
00:01:58.500 --> 00:02:01.550
There's one command to figure
out what directory we're in and

40
00:02:01.550 --> 00:02:04.600
there's another command to see
what's in the directory, all right?

41
00:02:04.600 --> 00:02:08.990
The first one I want to show you is pwd,
which is present working directory.

42
00:02:08.990 --> 00:02:12.110
It's real easy to forget where you're
at on the hard drive because a lot of

43
00:02:12.110 --> 00:02:14.920
times your command prompt will
show you a part of your path, but

44
00:02:14.920 --> 00:02:17.610
not the whole thing, all right?

45
00:02:17.610 --> 00:02:20.890
Let me show you one thing that occurs,
or that kinda happens to me a lot.

46
00:02:20.890 --> 00:02:23.870
All right,
I'm logged in right now as dpezet.

47
00:02:23.870 --> 00:02:27.690
If I do a whoami,
I can see I'm dpezet, right?

48
00:02:27.690 --> 00:02:32.140
And If I want to change into my home
directory, well that's where I start.

49
00:02:32.140 --> 00:02:37.650
When I first log in, I'm in my home
directory, which is /home/dpezet.

50
00:02:37.650 --> 00:02:39.980
And see how it's got a little tilde there?

51

506
00:25:56.170 --> 00:25:58.660
So we'll do that.

507
00:25:58.660 --> 00:25:59.670
>> All right.
>> Well, I was gonna say,

508
00:25:59.670 --> 00:26:00.480
well that being said,

509
00:26:00.480 --> 00:26:03.365
it looks like we've wrapped up
another episode of Linux Plus here.

510
00:26:03.365 --> 00:26:05.235
Hope you guys have enjoyed it,
we sure did.

511
00:26:05.235 --> 00:26:08.505
Signing off for ITProvTV,
I've been your host, Daniel Lowrie.

512
00:26:08.505 --> 00:26:09.195
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

513

514

1

2
00:00:11.057 --> 00:00:15.338
All right, greetings everyone, and welcome
to another great episode of ITProTV.

3
00:00:15.338 --> 00:00:19.020
Be your host, Daniel Lowry, and here with
me today, is my good friend, Don Pezet.

4
00:00:19.020 --> 00:00:20.090
How are you doing today, Don?

5
00:00:20.090 --> 00:00:21.940
>> I am doing great, and
you know, we're back for

6
00:00:21.940 --> 00:00:25.530
the action packed conclusion to our two
part series on file management commands.

7
00:00:25.530 --> 00:00:27.050
>> That's right,
I'm on the edge of my seat.

8
00:00:27.050 --> 00:00:27.740
>> I know you guys,

9
00:00:27.740 --> 00:00:32.310
you've found some way to tolerate the
distance of time between the two episodes.

10
00:00:32.310 --> 00:00:35.310
In our last episode we covered a lot
of basic file management commands,

11
00:00:35.310 --> 00:00:37.440
copying files,
deleting files, moving files.

12
00:00:37.440 --> 00:00:39.990
You know, nothing too crazy,
but essential stuff.

13
00:00:39.990 --> 00:00:41.930
Things that we do all the time.

14
00:00:41.930 --> 00:00:45.310
In this episode we're going to
talk about file archive commands.

15
00:00:45.310 --> 00:00:49.570
There are times when we need to take
multiple files and bundle them together

16
00:00:49.570 --> 00:00:53.400
into one big fat file to be able to
use for for various reasons, right?

17
00:00:53.400 --> 00:00:55.480
For example,
maybe Daniel shoots me an email.

18
00:00:55.480 --> 00:00:57.880
And he says, hey Don,
I need these five files.

19
00:00:57.880 --> 00:00:59.150
Can you send them to me?

20
00:00:59.150 --> 00:01:03.150
Well, I might want to bundle
those five files together as one.

21
00:01:03.150 --> 00:01:05.160
So now I'm just sending Daniel one file.

22
00:01:05.160 --> 00:01:08.280
And I might even want to compress it with
a compression utility to make the file

23
00:01:08.280 --> 00:01:09.120
even smaller.

24
00:01:09.120 --> 00:01:10.920
Makes it easier to transmit, right?

25
00:01:10.920 --> 00:01:13.418
So that's one reason,
maybe I'm just taking backups.

26
00:01:13.418 --> 00:01:16.620
I want to backup my files, but
I don't want a ton of files laying around.

27
00:01:16.620 --> 00:01:19.640
So I want to compress those and
archive them into a single file.

28
00:01:19.640 --> 00:01:23.760
Well, there's several different utilities
available in Linux that'll let us do that,

29
00:01:23.760 --> 00:01:27.760
to let us just store everything together
and then retrieve it as needed.

30
00:01:27.760 --> 00:01:30.500
So we're going to look at a few
of those different methods today.

31
00:01:30.500 --> 00:01:32.250
>> Yeah if you come from
a Windows background,

32
00:01:32.250 --> 00:01:35.850
this really isn't a foreign concept,
it's just a different way of doing it.

33
00:01:35.850 --> 00:01:37.400
In Windows they use ZIP.

34
00:01:37.400 --> 00:01:40.950
You get those .ZIP files and you can
add some compression to those as well.

35
00:01:40.950 --> 00:01:44.140
But Linux has their own way of doing it,
and they're actually pretty handy.

36
00:01:44.140 --> 00:01:44.990
>> Yeah.

37
00:01:44.990 --> 00:01:47.150
Now, some of these are older than others,
so

38
00:01:47.150 --> 00:01:49.060
we're not necessarily going
to make use of all of them.

39
00:01:49.060 --> 00:01:52.760
Let's start off with probably the one
that's the most used, and that's TAR.

40
00:01:52.760 --> 00:01:54.330
The tar command in Linux,

41
00:01:54.330 --> 00:01:59.100
it stands for tape archive, and
it was used, back in the days of tapes.

42
00:01:59.100 --> 00:02:02.765
When you wanted to write files to a tape,
you know magnetic tapes,

43
00:02:02.765 --> 00:02:06.759
it didn't treat them as individual files,
it was just magnetic ones and

44
00:02:06.759 --> 00:02:10.314
zeros written in a serial line
right across this magnetic tape.

45
00:02:10.314 --> 00:02:14.628
And it needed some way to identify
where one file stopped and

46
00:02:14.628 --> 00:02:20.570
the next file started, otherwise it
would just think it was one big file.

47
00:02:20.570 --> 00:02:24.750
So, what TAR does,
is TAR gathers multiple files together,

48
00:02:24.750 --> 00:02:28.080
sticks them together to make one big file,
and

49
00:02:28.080 --> 00:02:32.110
keeps a little table to know where one
file stops and the other one starts.

50
00:02:32.110 --> 00:02:35.510
It actually has these little pointers
that it injects between each file and

51
00:02:35.510 --> 00:02:37.070
that's how we know it's there.

52
00:02:37.070 --> 00:02:40.270
Now most people don't store data
on tape anymore, so you might say,

53
00:02:40.270 --> 00:02:42.900
well why do we still use TAR?

54
00:02:42.900 --> 00:02:43.460
And the reason is,

55
00:02:43.460 --> 00:02:47.740
even if you're not saving to tape, it's
still a great way to stick files together.

56
00:02:47.740 --> 00:02:49.340
You could just use the cat command,

57
00:02:49.340 --> 00:02:52.890
concatenate, I could cat
five files together.

58
00:02:52.890 --> 00:02:56.550
But then when I want to split them apart,
how do I know where to split them?

59
00:02:56.550 --> 00:02:57.960
That's the real challenge.

60
00:02:57.960 --> 00:02:59.400
TAR takes care of that for us.

61
00:02:59.400 --> 00:03:02.320
It knows where to split them,
and it can do it.

62
00:03:02.320 --> 00:03:04.460
Now, most people don't
just do TAR anymore.

63
00:03:04.460 --> 00:03:09.170
They normally combine that with Gzip,
because what Gzip does,

64
00:03:09.170 --> 00:03:13.500
the GNU zip utility, It can compress
the contents of the files too.

65
00:03:13.500 --> 00:03:16.060
When you write to a tape,
it doesn't get compressed, but

66
00:03:16.060 --> 00:03:20.020
if we gzip it,
we can make those files even smaller.

67
00:03:20.020 --> 00:03:21.860
So we don't normally use TAR by itself,

68
00:03:21.860 --> 00:03:24.112
we normally combine it with
another utility, gzip.

69
00:03:24.112 --> 00:03:27.508
>> Yeah, that's really handy,
especially when you want to send,

70
00:03:27.508 --> 00:03:31.300
say I wanted to send Don that file that
has a bunch of files in it, email.

71
00:03:31.300 --> 00:03:36.840
Well, my online email provider might have
a limit on the size availability for

72
00:03:36.840 --> 00:03:41.580
attachments so if I have, I'm just
using an arbitrary number, 5 MB, right?

73
00:03:41.580 --> 00:03:43.301
They can't send anything over 5 MB.

74
00:03:43.301 --> 00:03:47.240
Well, I've got five 1.5 MB files each.

75
00:03:47.240 --> 00:03:48.510
I want to put those in.

76
00:03:48.510 --> 00:03:52.420
You use the TAR command with gzip,
compress that down, get it under that 5 MB

77
00:03:52.420 --> 00:03:55.690
limit, then I'm able to attach
that one file, Don can get in.

78
00:03:55.690 --> 00:03:58.890
He has all the information he needs
using that, it's very simple.

79
00:03:58.890 --> 00:03:59.710
>> Yeah.

80
00:03:59.710 --> 00:04:01.100
So, let's just do an example here.

81
00:04:01.100 --> 00:04:03.030
I've got a directory,
it's my sales directory and

82
00:04:03.030 --> 00:04:05.010
my sales department
stores their stuff there.

83
00:04:05.010 --> 00:04:06.700
And I've got couple of files in there.

84
00:04:06.700 --> 00:04:11.120
And if you look, I've got one file that's
actually pretty small, it's like 13 bytes.

85
00:04:11.120 --> 00:04:14.280
I've got one file that's 50 megs,
and another one that's 100 megs.

86
00:04:14.280 --> 00:04:19.175
If I were to just use TAR by itself, my
archive would be 150 megs in size, right?

87
00:04:19.175 --> 00:04:23.400
But if I combine it with gzip, it'll
compress it and hopefully end up smaller.

88
00:04:23.400 --> 00:04:24.950
Now, I say hopefully.

89
00:04:24.950 --> 00:04:30.130
There are some files that don't compress
well, files that are already compressed.

90
00:04:30.130 --> 00:04:34.365
If the file's already compressed, when we
lay gzip on top of it again, the file can

91
00:04:34.365 --> 00:04:38.499
actually get bigger, because now we have
to add gzip's headers and stuff to it.

92
00:04:38.499 --> 00:04:42.700
So if you try to gzip jpg files,
jpg files are already compressed, so

93
00:04:42.700 --> 00:04:46.190
often times they'll get bigger
when you compress them.

94
00:04:46.190 --> 00:04:48.330
So you have to be a little careful,
they don't get that much bigger,

95
00:04:48.330 --> 00:04:49.630
just a little bit.

96
00:04:49.630 --> 00:04:51.510
So we'll see how these files compress.

97
00:04:51.510 --> 00:04:53.389
I've got a straight up text file, and

98
00:04:53.389 --> 00:04:56.561
then I've got a couple of binary
files with binary data in them,

99
00:04:56.561 --> 00:05:00.117
and you'll find that your compression
on text files is usually great.

100
00:05:00.117 --> 00:05:04.805
And your compression on binary files
is somewhere in between decent and

101
00:05:04.805 --> 00:05:07.550
great, it's not necessarily the best.

102
00:05:07.550 --> 00:05:11.200
So If I want to zip up a file,
like I just want to zip up one file.

103
00:05:11.200 --> 00:05:13.920
That file.txt is 13 bytes right now.

104
00:05:13.920 --> 00:05:20.417
And if I want to zip that up,
I can just go through here and

105
00:05:20.417 --> 00:05:23.891
I can say, tar and then cvfz.

106
00:05:23.891 --> 00:05:26.170
There's a lot of different options.

107
00:05:26.170 --> 00:05:28.300
C, I'm creating a tar volume.

108
00:05:28.300 --> 00:05:30.530
V, I want that verbose output.

109
00:05:30.530 --> 00:05:33.320
F, I'm about to give it
a file name I'm gonna create.

110
00:05:33.320 --> 00:05:35.650
And Z, I want to use gzip.

111
00:05:35.650 --> 00:05:38.420
Right, these are all options
of that TAR command.

112
00:05:38.420 --> 00:05:43.988
So it's cvfz, and then I'm going to
tell it the file I'm going to create.

113
00:05:43.988 --> 00:05:48.820
I'm going to make a file right here in
this directory, so I'll just say ./, and

114
00:05:48.820 --> 00:05:54.222
I'll call it backup.bak, or
whatever you want to call it, right.

115
00:05:54.222 --> 00:05:57.820
TAR actually, it doesn't care about
that file name in the slightest.

116
00:05:57.820 --> 00:05:59.650
What most people normally do though,

117
00:05:59.650 --> 00:06:04.050
is they'll end it in .tar
if it's just a TAR file.

118
00:06:04.050 --> 00:06:10.190
But if you're combining it with gzip,
a lot of times they'll call it tgz, right?

119
00:06:10.190 --> 00:06:13.520
You've probably seen that extension before
if you manually downloaded the packages,

120
00:06:13.520 --> 00:06:16.970
and that means that the file
was created with TAR and gzip.

121
00:06:16.970 --> 00:06:20.040
But, the program doesn't actually care
about the extension, you can use whatever

122
00:06:20.040 --> 00:06:23.710
you want, this is for us as humans to
know what's been done to the file.

123
00:06:23.710 --> 00:06:25.320
>> Now Don,
I noticed that you're not using,

124
00:06:25.320 --> 00:06:30.670
with your arguments it doesn't say dash
cvf and z, you just put the letters on.

125
00:06:30.670 --> 00:06:33.230
I know in Linux,
a lot of times you do need that dash.

126
00:06:33.230 --> 00:06:35.810
Do you not need it here,
or what's up with that?

127
00:06:35.810 --> 00:06:38.930
>> Well, tar is a really,
really old command, and

128
00:06:38.930 --> 00:06:43.400
so, what you find with the old commands
is they have three different formats.

129
00:06:43.400 --> 00:06:46.440
They have the GNU format for arguments,
they have the Unix format for

130
00:06:46.440 --> 00:06:48.660
arguments, and
they have the BSD format for arguments.

131
00:06:48.660 --> 00:06:53.470
And so, you might not have a dash,
or you might have a single dash, or

132
00:06:53.470 --> 00:06:56.180
you might have a double dash
followed by words, right?

133
00:06:56.180 --> 00:06:58.020
Each one of those is from
these different elements, and

134
00:06:58.020 --> 00:07:03.320
you'll find a lot of times that it
supports all of them or multiple ones.

135
00:07:03.320 --> 00:07:07.170
So when I look at TAR's help file,
they got TAR followed by an option.

136
00:07:07.170 --> 00:07:08.410
As I start to look at the options here,

137
00:07:08.410 --> 00:07:11.000
like they're showing
with dashes right here.

138
00:07:11.000 --> 00:07:13.020
They're showing a double dash, right?

139
00:07:13.020 --> 00:07:15.408
So I could double dash format.

140
00:07:15.408 --> 00:07:17.450
That would be the GNU form, right?

141
00:07:17.450 --> 00:07:18.900
Or I could do -F.

142
00:07:18.900 --> 00:07:21.570
That might be the UNIX form.

143
00:07:21.570 --> 00:07:24.460
Or the dash, no dash just f,
and that would be the,

144
00:07:24.460 --> 00:07:27.440
shoot which form would that be,
I get them mixed up.

145
00:07:28.710 --> 00:07:31.810
>> The double dash, isn't it GNU?

146
00:07:31.810 --> 00:07:36.840
>> Well yeah, double dash is GNU, the no
dash whatsoever, I believe is the BSD?

147
00:07:36.840 --> 00:07:38.850
>> Yeah
>> Okay, so you'll see those and

148
00:07:38.850 --> 00:07:43.930
as I look here I've got -c versus
--create, they both do the same thing.

149
00:07:43.930 --> 00:07:47.380
It's just whether you're doing it in
the GNU format or the BSD format or

150
00:07:47.380 --> 00:07:48.600
the UNIX format.

151
00:07:48.600 --> 00:07:51.884
So you'll find that sometimes they
support one versus the other.

152
00:07:51.884 --> 00:07:54.623
And here, it's not actually
showing any without the dash,

153
00:07:54.623 --> 00:07:57.803
so we'll have to be careful and
make sure this works without the dash.

154
00:07:57.803 --> 00:07:58.647
I'm pretty sure it does.

155
00:07:58.647 --> 00:07:59.638
>> I think it does.
>> Okay.

156
00:07:59.638 --> 00:08:02.632
So, you'll find that it doesn't
really matter which one you use but

157
00:08:02.632 --> 00:08:06.208
there can be subtle variations, so you've
gotta make sure you get the right one.

158
00:08:06.208 --> 00:08:09.107
So I'm gonna say tar cvzf.

159
00:08:09.107 --> 00:08:12.373
I'm gonna create a file called backup.tgz,
so

160
00:08:12.373 --> 00:08:15.640
that I remember it was tarred and gzipped.

161
00:08:15.640 --> 00:08:18.080
And now, I need to tell it
the files that I wanna back up.

162
00:08:18.080 --> 00:08:20.770
And I'm just gonna back up, file.

163
00:08:20.770 --> 00:08:22.590
I'll just backup file1.txt.

164
00:08:22.590 --> 00:08:24.722
I'm just gonna do a single file for
this one, and

165
00:08:24.722 --> 00:08:27.600
then I'll back up all of
the files here in a minute.

166
00:08:27.600 --> 00:08:31.766
If I run that, it gives me an output
letting me know it added file1.txt.

167
00:08:31.766 --> 00:08:34.730
And then if I do an ls -la.

168
00:08:34.730 --> 00:08:37.089
I can see that backup file right there.

169
00:08:37.089 --> 00:08:42.240
Now notice file1.text, it was only 13
bytes in size, that was all it was.

170
00:08:43.790 --> 00:08:50.280
But backup that tgz is 139 bytes in size,
it actually got bigger.

171
00:08:51.320 --> 00:08:52.890
That's a problem that we have.

172
00:08:52.890 --> 00:08:56.690
If you're backing up small files, things
that don't contain a lot of data cuz we're

173
00:08:56.690 --> 00:09:00.420
having to add the archive header and the
gzip header and stuff like that to it and

174
00:09:00.420 --> 00:09:01.640
it actually grows.

175
00:09:01.640 --> 00:09:09.177
But if I put more text in there, so
if I took like, we'll take file one.

176
00:09:09.177 --> 00:09:12.872
And let's bulk up its text a bit.

177
00:09:12.872 --> 00:09:19.940
So i this is test,
that's all that I had inside of that file,

178
00:09:19.940 --> 00:09:25.300
I didn't have anything else but if I come
in here and let's just bulk that up a bit,

179
00:09:27.920 --> 00:09:30.550
I'm going to try and
mess this up as much as I can.

180
00:09:31.860 --> 00:09:33.850
My copy and paste is not working.

181
00:09:33.850 --> 00:09:34.470
That's awesome.

182
00:09:36.530 --> 00:09:38.750
Here we go.
We'll copy.

183
00:09:38.750 --> 00:09:39.372
>> Do it the GUI way.

184
00:09:39.372 --> 00:09:42.750
>> [LAUGH] Apparently it doesn't
wanna copy and paste for me.

185
00:09:42.750 --> 00:09:45.700
But I was just gonna
bulk in some data there.

186
00:09:45.700 --> 00:09:49.020
We can take one of our larger files, and
we'll be able to see it better there.

187
00:09:49.020 --> 00:09:51.870
I'm gonna just get out of this file.

188
00:09:51.870 --> 00:09:53.770
And we'll take one of the larger ones.

189
00:09:53.770 --> 00:09:57.889
So instead of backing up file1.txt
maybe I'll do like file2.bin.

190
00:09:57.889 --> 00:10:00.180
And now, file2.bin is 50 megs in size.

191
00:10:00.180 --> 00:10:02.950
It's bigger, and I'm gonna back that up.

192
00:10:02.950 --> 00:10:03.770
I'll call this one backup2.

193
00:10:04.820 --> 00:10:10.248
And now, we back it up and
we look at the sizes,

194
00:10:10.248 --> 00:10:14.295
well backup2 is 50 kilobytes.

195
00:10:14.295 --> 00:10:18.601
50 megs for file 2.bin, 50 kilobytes,
let me add lah on that so

196
00:10:18.601 --> 00:10:20.280
we can see the sizes.

197
00:10:20.280 --> 00:10:24.360
So we can see the back up two is 50 k,
that compressed a lot.

198
00:10:24.360 --> 00:10:26.290
It got a lot smaller.

199
00:10:26.290 --> 00:10:30.060
So don't assume that gzip is always
gonna make your data smaller,

200
00:10:30.060 --> 00:10:31.340
it's not a guarantee.

201
00:10:31.340 --> 00:10:32.940
But it usually does.

202
00:10:32.940 --> 00:10:34.200
And it can make it significantly smaller.

203
00:10:36.250 --> 00:10:39.240
All right, now I've just been
grabbing single files but

204
00:10:39.240 --> 00:10:40.820
I can grab more than one file.

205
00:10:40.820 --> 00:10:42.630
I can grab all the files if I want.

206
00:10:42.630 --> 00:10:47.199
If I wanna run that and grab everything,
I would just come in here and say,

207
00:10:47.199 --> 00:10:51.643
I'm gonna do tar cvzf and
then I'll create a file called backup.tgz.

208
00:10:51.643 --> 00:10:54.520
And I'm just gonna include
everything in the directory.

209
00:10:54.520 --> 00:10:56.223
So I'll just said ./*.

210
00:10:56.223 --> 00:10:57.890
So that's gonna back up everything.

211
00:10:57.890 --> 00:11:00.360
There goes file1, file2, file3.

212
00:11:00.360 --> 00:11:02.340
It tried to back up
those directory markers.

213
00:11:02.340 --> 00:11:03.250
Those don't work.

214
00:11:03.250 --> 00:11:07.951
But it got my files, that's what I wanted.

215
00:11:07.951 --> 00:11:14.570
And when I look at that, I had 150 megs

00:23:27.365 --> 00:23:28.160
many hours.

440
00:23:28.160 --> 00:23:30.145
[LAUGH]
>> Or if you do need to do it during

441
00:23:30.145 --> 00:23:33.360
production hours, you wanna make
sure that the image you're creating

442
00:23:33.360 --> 00:23:35.410
>> Is on a separate physical hard drive

443
00:23:35.410 --> 00:23:36.670
from the source that you're copying.

444
00:23:36.670 --> 00:23:41.330
In my case, both of these drives
actually exist on the one SSDMI laptop.

445
00:23:41.330 --> 00:23:45.820
So I'm reading from and
writing to my hard drive at the same time.

446
00:23:45.820 --> 00:23:47.640
And that creates a bigger performance hit.

447
00:23:47.640 --> 00:23:51.490
>> If I was reading from one drive and
writing to another one it's a different

448
00:23:51.490 --> 00:23:56.320
story, but reading across all that empty
space creates a huge amount of IO,

449
00:23:56.320 --> 00:24:00.750
and that can be, well it will shorten the
lifetime of an SSD like mine, but it also

450
00:24:00.750 --> 00:24:03.200
creates a performance issue, that's
the one we're really concerned about.

451
00:24:03.200 --> 00:24:05.210
Lifetimes, you know this stuff is
under warranty, what do I care.

452
00:24:05.210 --> 00:24:08.100
>> Yea you'd hate to see your
database crawl, crawling,

453
00:24:08.100 --> 00:24:09.930
would you please let me go.

454
00:24:09.930 --> 00:24:13.260
>> Cuz that's gonna be
a lot of IO on that disk,

455
00:24:13.260 --> 00:24:15.460
and they really need that stuff for that.

456
00:24:15.460 --> 00:24:16.330
>> Yep.
>> All right, Don.

457
00:24:16.330 --> 00:24:20.300
Have we fathomed the depths of
these three lovely processes?

458
00:24:20.300 --> 00:24:22.580
>> Yeah, those are the ones
we need to know for the exam.

459
00:24:22.580 --> 00:24:25.810
In real life land,
you might prefer 7-zip or RAR or

460
00:24:25.810 --> 00:24:27.250
the other formats that are out there.

461
00:24:27.250 --> 00:24:29.230
And there's Linux equivalents for
all those.

462
00:24:29.230 --> 00:24:33.080
But the exam focuses on the ones you can
pretty much count on being every distro.

463
00:24:33.080 --> 00:24:34.690
Every distro has gzip.

464
00:24:34.690 --> 00:24:35.710
Every distro has tar.

465
00:24:35.710 --> 00:24:37.100
Every distro has cpio.

466
00:24:37.100 --> 00:24:38.350
So, they're available.

467
00:24:38.350 --> 00:24:38.940
Use them.

468
00:24:38.940 --> 00:24:40.090
They've been around a long time.

469
00:24:40.090 --> 00:24:41.570
Those are the ones that you can count on.

470
00:24:41.570 --> 00:24:42.900
>> Awesome!
Excellent stuff.

471
00:24:42.900 --> 00:24:45.540
Well, it looks like we've actually
come to the end of another great

472
00:24:45.540 --> 00:24:48.850
episode here at ITProTV, so
>> Signing off,

473
00:24:48.850 --> 00:24:53.890
I have been your host, Daniel Lowry.

474
00:24:53.890 --> 00:24:54.560
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

475
00:24:54.560 --> 00:24:56.600
>> And we'll see you next time.

episodes.title: Ownership and Permissions
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.013 --> 00:00:11.858
All right, everyone.

3
00:00:11.858 --> 00:00:15.757
Greetings and welcome to another
great episode of ITProTV.

4
00:00:15.757 --> 00:00:17.565
I'll be your host Daniel Lowery and

5
00:00:17.565 --> 00:00:19.989
here with me today is none
other than Don Pezet.

6
00:00:19.989 --> 00:00:21.018
What's going on today Don?

7
00:00:21.018 --> 00:00:22.138
>> I am doing great Daniel.

8
00:00:22.138 --> 00:00:26.463
And today we're gonna be jumping into
ownership and permission of files.

9
00:00:26.463 --> 00:00:28.811
Which is a pretty
important topic to hit on,

10
00:00:28.811 --> 00:00:31.095
because a lot of times
we see these values,

11
00:00:31.095 --> 00:00:35.790
especially when we're doing directory
listings and we don't know what they mean.

12
00:00:35.790 --> 00:00:37.590
And each one actually does
have a particular purpose.

13
00:00:37.590 --> 00:00:39.840
So we're gonna talk about
that a good bit today.

14
00:00:39.840 --> 00:00:43.563
So, I wanna start off just by showing
you guys a directory listing.

15
00:00:43.563 --> 00:00:47.743
Let me use my terminal here and I'll pull
up a directory listing and you're gonna

16
00:00:47.743 --> 00:00:51.506
see all sorts of little columns and
values and stuff that are spread out.

17
00:00:51.506 --> 00:00:53.890
And, we always look for file name.

18
00:00:53.890 --> 00:00:55.620
We always look for file size.

19
00:00:55.620 --> 00:00:57.500
Those are kind of our critical things,

20
00:00:57.500 --> 00:01:01.720
but what's all the other stuff
that shows up on that screen?

21
00:01:01.720 --> 00:01:06.740
So when I run an ls-lah,
I sure I get file name.

22
00:01:06.740 --> 00:01:09.010
Sure I get file size and modified date.

23
00:01:09.010 --> 00:01:10.410
Those are things that we know.

24
00:01:10.410 --> 00:01:11.810
Those are easy to understand.

25
00:01:11.810 --> 00:01:15.390
But what about all this
stuff over here to the left?

26
00:01:15.390 --> 00:01:19.480
Well, all of that relates to
permissions and ownership.

27
00:01:20.670 --> 00:01:24.160
So I've got kind of an example
here of what we might see and

28
00:01:24.160 --> 00:01:26.230
what each of these columns represent.

29
00:01:26.230 --> 00:01:29.940
So file name, we know that one,
it's the name of the file.

30
00:01:29.940 --> 00:01:30.890
Modified.

31
00:01:30.890 --> 00:01:33.939
When was it modified or when was it
created if it hasn't been modified.

32
00:01:33.939 --> 00:01:35.100
What size is it?

33
00:01:35.100 --> 00:01:38.750
Which might be in bytes or
kilobytes, megabytes, whatever.

34
00:01:38.750 --> 00:01:40.490
Each one listed there.

35
00:01:40.490 --> 00:01:43.440
And then these other
guys here on the left.

36
00:01:43.440 --> 00:01:48.555
The permissions on the file,
the amount of links to this file.

37
00:01:48.555 --> 00:01:52.160
Cuz if we've created hard links to a file,
then that number will show up here.

38
00:01:52.160 --> 00:01:53.170
I can see there's two links.

39
00:01:53.170 --> 00:01:55.690
A directory will almost
always have two links.

40
00:01:55.690 --> 00:01:56.720
There's itself.

41
00:01:56.720 --> 00:01:57.430
That counts as a link.

42
00:01:57.430 --> 00:01:59.020
That's why they all have one.

43
00:01:59.020 --> 00:02:03.520
And then inside of a directory,
you've got the dot and dot, dot.

44
00:02:03.520 --> 00:02:04.990
Well, dot refers to this directory.

45
00:02:04.990 --> 00:02:06.360
It's a hard link to this directory.

46
00:02:06.360 --> 00:02:10.100
So that's why directories
are almost always two if not more.

47
00:02:10.100 --> 00:02:13.810
If we put more subdirectories under there,
each one of them has a dot,

48
00:02:13.810 --> 00:02:17.180
dot that points to the parent, and so the
parent keeps getting bigger and bigger and

49
00:02:17.180 --> 00:02:18.830
bigger as we create those links.

50
00:02:18.830 --> 00:02:22.190
So we don't normally care about links,
we kind of ignored it, but

51
00:02:22.190 --> 00:02:24.580
then we've got user and group.

52
00:02:24.580 --> 00:02:28.760
Well, the user is the person
who owns the file.

53
00:02:28.760 --> 00:02:30.920
It's usually the person who created it.

54
00:02:30.920 --> 00:02:33.167
So if I create a file,
the owner's gonna be dpezet.

55
00:02:33.167 --> 00:02:34.348
That's me.

56
00:02:34.348 --> 00:02:36.688
I created it, and I'll be the owner.

57
00:02:36.688 --> 00:02:42.400
The group, well, usually by default
it's also the user has their own group.

58
00:02:42.400 --> 00:02:45.460
So you might see a file that's dpezet,
dpezet.

59
00:02:45.460 --> 00:02:46.390
I made it.

60
00:02:46.390 --> 00:02:49.710
I'm the owner and
I'm the group that's in control of it.

61
00:02:49.710 --> 00:02:52.876
But if we're using Unix to it's fullest
we may have created other groups.

62
00:02:52.876 --> 00:02:56.068
And I might have a sales group and
a marketing group, and so

63
00:02:56.068 --> 00:02:57.574
I might have a user dpezet.

64
00:02:57.574 --> 00:03:00.830
Yeah, that's the person who made it,
but the group might be sales.

65
00:03:00.830 --> 00:03:03.553
And then if I put ten
people in that sales group,

66
00:03:03.553 --> 00:03:08.040
then they'll be able to access this
file and do whatever they need to do.

67
00:03:08.040 --> 00:03:10.420
And we have another episode
on creating users and groups.

68
00:03:10.420 --> 00:03:12.230
So you guys will see all that later.

69
00:03:12.230 --> 00:03:15.190
But this is important for permissions.

70
00:03:15.190 --> 00:03:19.470
Because the file permissions are all
represented over here on the left.

71
00:03:19.470 --> 00:03:21.789
And they're represented as nine values.

72
00:03:23.130 --> 00:03:26.040
Each value has a particular purpose.

73
00:03:26.040 --> 00:03:29.210
Let me just kind of run
through each one of these.

74
00:03:29.210 --> 00:03:33.340
The first one identifies whether
this is a file or a directory.

75
00:03:33.340 --> 00:03:35.780
If it is a file you'll have a dash.

76
00:03:35.780 --> 00:03:38.120
If it's a directory you'll have a d.

77
00:03:38.120 --> 00:03:40.770
So, if you look at my list
I've got one with a d.

78
00:03:40.770 --> 00:03:41.820
That's a directory.

79
00:03:41.820 --> 00:03:44.088
That's this files folder.

80
00:03:44.088 --> 00:03:46.520
I know it's a folder because
it's got a d over here,

81
00:03:46.520 --> 00:03:49.370
all the other ones I know were
files cuz they have dashes.

82
00:03:49.370 --> 00:03:51.930
So that first one is just
indicating whether or a file or

83
00:03:51.930 --> 00:03:53.290
a folder and that's it.

84
00:03:54.639 --> 00:03:59.640
After that then we get into
our next set of values,

85
00:03:59.640 --> 00:04:05.190
the next three pertain to
the users permissions.

86
00:04:05.190 --> 00:04:07.260
What permission does the user get?

87
00:04:07.260 --> 00:04:09.680
This person here, in the user column.

88
00:04:09.680 --> 00:04:13.280
The next three are what
permissions the group gets.

89
00:04:13.280 --> 00:04:16.290
The group is right here,
so what do they get?

90
00:04:16.290 --> 00:04:20.360
And then the third set,
this is what's called the other.

91
00:04:20.360 --> 00:04:21.260
What others get.

92
00:04:21.260 --> 00:04:23.310
In other words, if you're not the user and

93
00:04:23.310 --> 00:04:26.280
you're not in the group,
what does everybody else get?

94
00:04:27.570 --> 00:04:31.050
And that's what makes up
these last nine values,

95
00:04:31.050 --> 00:04:34.520
the user, the group, and the other.

96
00:04:34.520 --> 00:04:38.822
So, user, apparently,
I don't know how to use my caps lock user,

97
00:04:38.822 --> 00:04:43.070
[LAUGH] like apparently 50% of
the people on the internet.

98
00:04:43.070 --> 00:04:44.760
And user, group, and other.

99
00:04:44.760 --> 00:04:45.669
Those are those three values.

100
00:04:47.170 --> 00:04:49.540
The cool part here is,
I can control permissions.

101
00:04:49.540 --> 00:04:53.900
What permissions does the owner
have of that file, this user.

102
00:04:53.900 --> 00:04:54.960
The user is the owner.

103
00:04:54.960 --> 00:04:56.560
What do they get?

104
00:04:56.560 --> 00:04:58.740
And then,
what permissions does the group get?

105
00:04:58.740 --> 00:05:00.350
It might be different.

106
00:05:00.350 --> 00:05:03.290
The owner might have ways
super mega access, and

107
00:05:03.290 --> 00:05:05.600
the group might have something
a little more limited.

108
00:05:05.600 --> 00:05:08.540
And then the others,
everybody else, what do they get?

109
00:05:08.540 --> 00:05:09.640
And that might be really limited.

110
00:05:09.640 --> 00:05:11.560
They might not have any access at all.

111
00:05:12.690 --> 00:05:16.190
Well, these permissions, it's actually
pretty easy to understand them

112
00:05:16.190 --> 00:05:20.130
cuz there's only three,
read, write, and execute.

113
00:05:20.130 --> 00:05:24.323
When we look at those values,

114
00:05:24.323 --> 00:05:31.216
you're gonna see it's r for
read, W for write.

115
00:05:31.216 --> 00:05:31.970
[LAUGH] There we go.

116
00:05:31.970 --> 00:05:33.090
>> If you can write.

117
00:05:33.090 --> 00:05:34.770
>> Apparently, it's beyond me.

118
00:05:34.770 --> 00:05:37.330
And then X for execute.

119
00:05:37.330 --> 00:05:39.279
Those are the ones that
we're gonna see and

120
00:05:39.279 --> 00:05:41.510
each one pertains to
a certain type of activity.

121
00:05:41.510 --> 00:05:45.660
If I just wanna read the file and
look inside of it I need an r.

122
00:05:45.660 --> 00:05:48.560
If I wanna write to it, though,
if I wanna change that file,

123
00:05:48.560 --> 00:05:51.660
or I even wanna delete the file,
I need a W.

124
00:05:51.660 --> 00:05:54.260
And then if it's a program,
if it's a binary or a script, and

125
00:05:54.260 --> 00:05:56.450
I wanna run it, I need an X.

126
00:05:56.450 --> 00:05:59.130
That's gonna give me
the execute permission.

127
00:05:59.130 --> 00:06:02.120
And so, as you look at some of
the files that I've got listed here,

128
00:06:02.120 --> 00:06:04.100
like this directory.

129
00:06:04.100 --> 00:06:07.820
This directory,
we know it's a directory cuz its got a d.

130
00:06:07.820 --> 00:06:11.960
The owner dpezet, I can read, write,
and execute to the directory.

131
00:06:11.960 --> 00:06:15.080
Now, in a directory that means
that I can write, in other words,

132
00:06:15.080 --> 00:06:17.110
I can create files inside of it.

133
00:06:17.110 --> 00:06:19.630
A little bit different
than writing to a file.

134
00:06:19.630 --> 00:06:23.260
I can see that my group can also read,
write, and execute.

135
00:06:23.260 --> 00:06:25.953
So anybody in my group,
which is just dpezet, but

136
00:06:25.953 --> 00:06:30.379
if we changed that to like sales, anybody
in the sales group would be able to read,

137
00:06:30.379 --> 00:06:33.797
write, and actually they'd be
able to create files in there.

138
00:06:33.797 --> 00:06:36.343
And then everybody else
can read the directory,

139
00:06:36.343 --> 00:06:39.137
they can browse into the directory and
see the files,

140
00:06:39.137 --> 00:06:42.690
they can execute programs if
there's programs in there.

141
00:06:42.690 --> 00:06:47.850
But they can't change files or
create new files or delete files.

142
00:06:47.850 --> 00:06:49.720
They don't have the write permission.

143
00:06:49.720 --> 00:06:53.320
Now you'll almost always have execute
on a directory cuz the act of

144
00:06:53.320 --> 00:06:55.780
browsing into a directory
is like executing it.

145
00:06:55.780 --> 00:06:56.690
So you'll usually see, and

146
00:06:56.690 --> 00:06:59.340
I know it's odd, you're like,
well, it's not a program.

147
00:06:59.340 --> 00:07:00.360
Well, it's a directory.

148
00:07:00.360 --> 00:07:02.826
You sort of execute it when you
browse to it, so expect to see that.

149
00:07:04.770 --> 00:07:07.970
Other files, like, listing1.1.txt.

150
00:07:07.970 --> 00:07:11.784
Notice my user has read and
write but not execute.

151
00:07:11.784 --> 00:07:13.508
I can't execute this.

152
00:07:13.508 --> 00:07:14.660
Well, it's funny, it's a text file.

153
00:07:14.660 --> 00:07:16.422
I'm not gonna execute a text file.

154
00:07:16.422 --> 00:07:20.860
I'm gonna use another program like vim or
nano or whatever to open this.

155
00:07:20.860 --> 00:07:22.130
That's the executable.

156
00:07:22.130 --> 00:07:25.030
So I don't need execute on it,
I've just got read and write.

157
00:07:25.030 --> 00:07:29.180
So as my group and
everyone else just has read.

158
00:07:29.180 --> 00:07:31.360
Maybe I don't want everybody
else to read this file.

159
00:07:31.360 --> 00:07:34.228
I can take that away,
and now we apparently,

160
00:07:34.228 --> 00:07:40.640
auto-correct in some crazy dash, well,
that's gonna annoy the hell out of me.

161
00:07:40.640 --> 00:07:44.440
Well, so anyhow you would see three
dashes here that would represent that

162
00:07:45.690 --> 00:07:49.710
that not having any permission,
you're denied access to that point.

163
00:07:49.710 --> 00:07:51.890
Three dashes is a deny.

164
00:07:52.940 --> 00:07:55.605
Those are kind of the permissions and
how they're set.

165
00:07:55.605 --> 00:07:59.094
Well, how they're set
in the system already.

166
00:07:59.094 --> 00:08:01.331
What if we wanna change them, though?

167
00:08:01.331 --> 00:08:05.210
That's where the commands we're
gonna cover in this episode come in.

168
00:08:05.210 --> 00:08:09.340
We've got two main commands that
we really need to be aware of.

169
00:08:09.340 --> 00:08:14.130
There's chown, which is change owner.

170
00:08:14.130 --> 00:08:21.140
So, if I do man chown, I can see
that change file owner and group.

171
00:08:21.140 --> 00:08:24.840
Here's how I can set, who it is that owns
it and who's the group on it, right?

172
00:08:24.840 --> 00:08:27.130
I can modify that right here.

173
00:08:27.130 --> 00:08:30.670
And then, the other command is chmod,
all right?

174
00:08:32.620 --> 00:08:37.683
That is what lets me change the file mode
bits, which are the permissions, right?

175
00:08:37.683 --> 00:08:40.590
Here's where I can modify
those permissions on the file.

176
00:08:40.590 --> 00:08:46.310
Chmod is a very old command, and it has
an old syntax that's kinda hard to use.

177
00:08:46.310 --> 00:08:49.820
And it's got a new syntax that's
actually a lot easier to use.

178
00:08:49.820 --> 00:08:52.570
I'm gonna show you both though,
cuz they both show up on the exam.

179
00:08:54.090 --> 00:08:57.065
Let's start with kinda the easy way,
all right?

180
00:08:57.065 --> 00:09:00.040
I wanna start with the c-h-o-w-n,
change ownership.

181
00:09:01.050 --> 00:09:07.300
If I look in my directory, I can see
these files, like I've got dontest.txt.

182
00:09:07.300 --> 00:09:11.032
And right now it's owned by me,
owned by dpezet, right?

183
00:09:11.032 --> 00:09:14.250
So I've got that one right there,
very exciting, right?

184
00:09:14.250 --> 00:09:19.049
Well, if I have a new user that I create,
and I wanna make them the owner,

185
00:09:19.049 --> 00:09:21.195
I can set that or I can change it.

186
00:09:21.195 --> 00:09:26.250
And this happens a lot because maybe the
root user is setting something up, right?

187
00:09:26.250 --> 00:09:30.080
So if I'm adding a new hard drive as root,
it's not uncommon for

188
00:09:30.080 --> 00:09:31.200
that hard drive to be tied to me.

189
00:09:31.200 --> 00:09:33.940
I created it, I put it in there,
so it's tied to me.

190
00:09:33.940 --> 00:09:37.230
But if it's tied to root,
no other user can use it.

191
00:09:37.230 --> 00:09:41.228
I have to make it where they can, so
I might wanna change who that user is or

192
00:09:41.228 --> 00:09:44.519
who that group is and
get that kind of set up and put in place.

193
00:09:44.519 --> 00:09:46.653
So we can use chown for that.

194
00:09:46.653 --> 00:09:50.417
So for example let's say that
I am running as root, right?

195
00:09:50.417 --> 00:09:52.833

419
00:21:58.960 --> 00:22:02.380
>> Now Don, 0 is technically
a root only access, right?

420
00:22:02.380 --> 00:22:04.570
And everyone else gets no access.

421
00:22:04.570 --> 00:22:07.730
>> Yeah, if you're the owner you can
never truly lock yourself out of a file.

422
00:22:07.730 --> 00:22:10.060
So even if you take away
your owner permissions,

423
00:22:10.060 --> 00:22:12.650
you still have the permission
to change permissions.

424
00:22:12.650 --> 00:22:15.614
So you can never truly lock yourself out,
even if you do all 0s.

425
00:22:17.330 --> 00:22:20.200
But if I want to take that dir.sh and

426
00:22:20.200 --> 00:22:23.490
I don't want anybody else to run
it other than me and my group.

427
00:22:23.490 --> 00:22:24.950
Or maybe I don't even
want my group to run it.

428
00:22:24.950 --> 00:22:27.430
I just want me to be able to run it.

429
00:22:27.430 --> 00:22:31.235
Well, I could use the other
notation of like g- x and

430
00:22:31.235 --> 00:22:34.620
o- x to take away their
execute permissions.

431
00:22:35.790 --> 00:22:38.450
Or if I know what I want them to have,
and I know the bit values,

432
00:22:38.450 --> 00:22:39.890
I can provide it that way.

433
00:22:39.890 --> 00:22:43.350
If I want me to have full access,
read, write and execute,

434
00:22:43.350 --> 00:22:45.506
and everybody else to have nothing.

435
00:22:45.506 --> 00:22:52.689
Then what I would do is I
would say chmod 700 dir.sh.

436
00:22:52.689 --> 00:22:55.120
700, three numbers.

437
00:22:55.120 --> 00:22:57.320
The first number applies to the user.

438
00:22:57.320 --> 00:22:59.410
The second number applies to the group.

439
00:22:59.410 --> 00:23:02.370
The third number applies to everyone else.

440
00:23:02.370 --> 00:23:06.329
7 for me means I get read,
write and execute, I'm the user.

441
00:23:06.329 --> 00:23:09.400
0 for my group means they get nothing.

442
00:23:09.400 --> 00:23:12.810
And then 0 for the others means
everybody else gets nothing.

443
00:23:12.810 --> 00:23:17.960
And when I run that,
now I can take a look at that file and

444
00:23:17.960 --> 00:23:22.140
sure enough, I have read, write, execute,
everybody else has nothing, all right?

445
00:23:22.140 --> 00:23:23.590
But you see how difficult this is.

446
00:23:23.590 --> 00:23:25.760
I had to remember what
the numbers correspond to.

447
00:23:25.760 --> 00:23:29.590
If I wanna let my group read and execute,
but not write, if I remember, hey,

448
00:23:29.590 --> 00:23:36.170
that's a 5, then I can come in and
I can say chmod 750.

449
00:23:36.170 --> 00:23:38.930
And I know 7 gives me everything,
5 gives them read and

450
00:23:38.930 --> 00:23:42.390
execute, 0 gives everybody else nothing.

451
00:23:42.390 --> 00:23:46.620
And now, when I look at that file I
can see that's exactly what I got.

452
00:23:46.620 --> 00:23:50.120
Read, write, execute for me,
read and execute for my group.

453
00:23:50.120 --> 00:23:52.540
And nothing for everybody else, right?

454
00:23:52.540 --> 00:23:54.172
Not the easiest way to do things, but

455
00:23:54.172 --> 00:23:57.445
that's the way it was all through
the 80s and really through the 90s.

456
00:23:57.445 --> 00:23:59.960
This notation of u + whatever.

457
00:23:59.960 --> 00:24:01.638
That's really somewhat new.

458
00:24:01.638 --> 00:24:03.740
Came out, you know,
around the turn of the century.

459
00:24:03.740 --> 00:24:05.950
That's obviously a very
important thing to know.

460
00:24:05.950 --> 00:24:10.064
[LAUGH] Now like Don said, this does get a
little difficult when you're working with

461
00:24:10.064 --> 00:24:13.017
those bids and
having to memorize these different things.

462
00:24:13.017 --> 00:24:15.809
I'm not a 100% but
when I took the Linux Plus test,

463
00:24:15.809 --> 00:24:18.192
they wanted you to know that down pat.

464
00:24:18.192 --> 00:24:20.700
And there's charts that you can
look up and things like that.

465
00:24:20.700 --> 00:24:23.770
Maybe we'll make one up and
slap it on the show notes or something.

466
00:24:23.770 --> 00:24:24.940
It's not that difficult.

467
00:24:24.940 --> 00:24:27.036
Well, as you start to memorize it.

468
00:24:27.036 --> 00:24:29.840
Definitely get it memorized so
that when you do it and you hit that exam,

469
00:24:29.840 --> 00:24:33.170
and they hit you with the mode bits,
you're not completely lost.

470
00:24:33.170 --> 00:24:36.836
Only if you've memorized 7 and 5 and
0 they might throw a 6 or a 4 at you,

471
00:24:36.836 --> 00:24:39.120
and expect you to know
what that means as well.

472
00:24:39.120 --> 00:24:41.030
So, definitely memorize that table.

473
00:24:41.030 --> 00:24:43.150
>> Now, if you're watching this on our
website, you got the show notes there,

474
00:24:43.150 --> 00:24:43.830
the bits are in there.

475
00:24:43.830 --> 00:24:46.100
But for those of you that are watching
like on a Roku or something,

476
00:24:46.100 --> 00:24:47.226
you might not have those notes.

477
00:24:47.226 --> 00:24:49.410
So just to run through
the list real quick.

478
00:24:49.410 --> 00:24:50.670
0 is no access.

479
00:24:50.670 --> 00:24:52.180
Nobody gets anything.

480
00:24:52.180 --> 00:24:54.800
1 is just execute.

481
00:24:54.800 --> 00:24:58.670
That's not terribly useful, cuz if you
don't have the read permission also,

482
00:24:58.670 --> 00:25:00.220
you can't really execute it.

483
00:25:00.220 --> 00:25:02.810
So, 1 isn't used very often.

484
00:25:02.810 --> 00:25:04.730
2 is just write.

485
00:25:04.730 --> 00:25:09.605
Again, writing to a file without having
read permissions is kind of challenging.

486
00:25:09.605 --> 00:25:12.264
But if you want that, if you want that
Dropbox type functionality, people can

487
00:25:12.264 --> 00:25:14.905
drop off files, but not read them,
that's where that permission comes in.

488
00:25:14.905 --> 00:25:16.495
So, 2 is just write.

489
00:25:16.495 --> 00:25:19.050
3 is write and execute.

490
00:25:19.050 --> 00:25:20.170
That's really dangerous.

491
00:25:20.170 --> 00:25:23.030
You can't read the file, but
you can write to it and then execute it.

492
00:25:23.030 --> 00:25:26.875
So, again, not a terribly useful, and
that's why we don't see 3 that much.

493
00:25:26.875 --> 00:25:31.955
4 is just read, they can read,
but they can't write or execute.

494
00:25:31.955 --> 00:25:33.400
5 is read and execute.

495
00:25:33.400 --> 00:25:34.560
That one's really common.

496
00:25:34.560 --> 00:25:36.840
I want people to read it, and execute it.

497
00:25:36.840 --> 00:25:39.095
I don't want them to be able to modify it.

498
00:25:39.095 --> 00:25:40.660
6 is read and write.

499
00:25:40.660 --> 00:25:44.101
I want them to be able to read, and
write to the file but not execute it.

500
00:25:44.101 --> 00:25:46.460
I think I might have said that
was 4 earlier, so it is 6.

501
00:25:46.460 --> 00:25:48.900
And then 7 is everything,
read, write, and execute.

502
00:25:48.900 --> 00:25:50.960
Those are the values that fall in there.

503
00:25:50.960 --> 00:25:52.780
And you just have to memorize it.

504
00:25:52.780 --> 00:25:54.350
That's what each of those corresponds to.

505
00:25:54.350 --> 00:25:56.630
But they'll be in the show notes.

506
00:25:56.630 --> 00:25:59.430
All right, now, a couple other
things we might want to look at.

507
00:25:59.430 --> 00:26:03.680
When I create a new file, it's gonna
have some default permissions on it.

508
00:26:03.680 --> 00:26:08.780
So if I come in here and
I say like touch file 1.txt,

509
00:26:08.780 --> 00:26:11.950
that file ended up with
certain permissions.

510
00:26:11.950 --> 00:26:13.760
Where do those permissions come from?

511
00:26:13.760 --> 00:26:16.840
Well, we have what's called a Umask and

512
00:26:16.840 --> 00:26:21.100
the Umask is what defines the default
permissions on your system.

513
00:26:21.100 --> 00:26:22.222
We don't normally mess with it.

514
00:26:22.222 --> 00:26:26.055
Each distro usually stays about the same
but some of them have little variations

515
00:26:26.055 --> 00:26:28.940
and we learn to live with that and
we change them as needed.

516
00:26:28.940 --> 00:26:33.460
But, if you wanna override the way
the default permissions are set, you can.

517
00:26:33.460 --> 00:26:37.500
It's actually stored in your
own user configuration.

518
00:26:37.500 --> 00:26:39.480
If I get into my home directory,

519
00:26:39.480 --> 00:26:42.860
there's a file in your home
directory called BashRC, right?

520
00:26:42.860 --> 00:26:45.060
And that's what's got
your shell configuration.

521
00:26:45.060 --> 00:26:48.710
And if I take a look at that,
I'm just going to it up in vie here, and

522
00:26:48.710 --> 00:26:49.920
look inside of it.

523
00:26:49.920 --> 00:26:52.840
You'll see some information and
you may have a Umask

524
00:26:52.840 --> 00:26:56.900
defined in here that defines how those
default permissions will be set.

525
00:26:56.900 --> 00:26:58.113
I don't have one.

526
00:26:58.113 --> 00:26:59.238
Now, I don't have one.

527
00:26:59.238 --> 00:26:59.860
What does that mean?

528
00:26:59.860 --> 00:27:03.470
Well, that means I rely on the default
one that's set up on my system.

529
00:27:03.470 --> 00:27:07.490
If I wanted, I could override it here and
put in what I wanted those values to be.

530
00:27:07.490 --> 00:27:09.190
If you don't have it defined in here,

531
00:27:09.190 --> 00:27:14.850
then it's gonna be in the default which
is in /etc/profile, and oh, it's a file.

532
00:27:14.850 --> 00:27:20.810
But, if I open up that file, that's
the default profile for my users and

533
00:27:20.810 --> 00:27:24.570
we can look in here and see if the Umask
is defined, and I'm sure it will be.

534
00:27:24.570 --> 00:27:26.330
Let's see if we can find it.

535
00:27:26.330 --> 00:27:28.240
And we have some path stuff.

536
00:27:28.240 --> 00:27:29.980
Oh, there is Umask.

537
00:27:29.980 --> 00:27:34.460
So here we go, where it's basically
coming through and doing a check to see

538
00:27:34.460 --> 00:27:38.780
what we're dealing with, as far as user
IDs and how these permissions can be set.

539
00:27:38.780 --> 00:27:41.610
Basically, the root user will get slightly
different permissions than a regular

540
00:27:41.610 --> 00:27:42.900
user when it's defined.

541
00:27:42.900 --> 00:27:44.950
But see how it's got these
Umasks that are defining it.

542
00:27:44.950 --> 00:27:48.870
And the Umask syntax is
a little bit different than

543
00:27:48.870 --> 00:27:53.120
what we see with our bits for
normal files.

544
00:27:53.120 --> 00:27:57.762
So, you'll wanna look up that man file for
Umask to find out the proper bits there.

545
00:27:57.762 --> 00:28:02.840
Like 002 in our normal one would
mean that everybody gets rights and

546
00:28:02.840 --> 00:28:05.510
the owner and the group get nothing,
and that's not how it actually applies.

547
00:28:05.510 --> 00:28:07.470
These bits mean different things for
Umask.

548
00:28:07.470 --> 00:28:09.890
But that's where these default
permissions are coming from.

549
00:28:09.890 --> 00:28:13.657
And you can manipulate that
to change it how you want.

550
00:28:13.657 --> 00:28:18.392
All right, you know Daniel, I also
wanted to talk about a few other things.

551
00:28:18.392 --> 00:28:21.550
But we don't really have the time for
it, do we?

552
00:28:21.550 --> 00:28:24.044
One thing to mention real quick.

553
00:28:24.044 --> 00:28:29.150
Chown, change owner, that's great for
changing the owner, and the group, right?

554
00:28:29.150 --> 00:28:31.450
You can put the owner,
a colon and the group.

555
00:28:31.450 --> 00:28:34.800
If you just want to change the group,
you can still use change owner for that,

556
00:28:34.800 --> 00:28:40.350
you just put the same owner in, or you
can use chgrp, the change group command.

557
00:28:40.350 --> 00:28:44.057
Chgrp is useful because it will
just change, well, the group,

558
00:28:44.057 --> 00:28:46.260
that's why they call it that.

559
00:28:46.260 --> 00:28:48.720
So, we can change that
group ownership of a file,

560
00:28:48.720 --> 00:28:50.868
if you just want to modify that one,
that one's out there too.

561
00:28:50.868 --> 00:28:55.100
So we saw chmod for changing permissions,

562
00:28:55.100 --> 00:28:59.780
we saw chown for changing the owner and
the group if we want, and

563
00:28:59.780 --> 00:29:04.750
then chgrp for just changing the group,
couple of unique commands there for those.

564
00:29:04.750 --> 00:29:05.870
>> Yeah, good stuff.

565
00:29:05.870 --> 00:29:07.780
Definitely gets you into
that file security.

566
00:29:07.780 --> 00:29:12.160
This is basically the beginnings of
securing your Linux systems, right?

567
00:29:12.160 --> 00:29:14.560
Making sure that the right people
have the right access, and

568
00:29:14.560 --> 00:29:17.100
that the people that don't need access,
well, they get denied.

569
00:29:17.100 --> 00:29:19.430
You don't want them grabbing
stuff like in our Apache server.

570
00:29:19.430 --> 00:29:22.810
That'd probably be a bad place for
people to just be dropping files in,

571
00:29:22.810 --> 00:29:28.440
naming things like index.html of their
own design, might not be a good thing.

572
00:29:28.440 --> 00:29:31.234
So having this file
permission's very good stuff.

573
00:29:31.234 --> 00:29:36.470
>> Now on the LX0-103 exam, they want
you to know how these permissions work.

574
00:29:36.470 --> 00:29:39.227
But they don't necessarily want you to
know how to create users and groups.

575
00:29:39.227 --> 00:29:41.931
On the 104, on the second part of
the exam, that's where the users and

576
00:29:41.931 --> 00:29:42.970
groups come in.

577
00:29:42.970 --> 00:29:47.550
I encourage you, before you take the 103
exam, jump ahead to the 104 show, and

578
00:29:47.550 --> 00:29:49.830
watch the part on users and groups.

579
00:29:49.830 --> 00:29:52.770
These permissions aren't really useful
unless you have user accounts and

580
00:29:52.770 --> 00:29:54.870
groups to be able to
tie all this stuff to.

581
00:29:54.870 --> 00:29:56.030
So be aware of that.

582
00:29:56.030 --> 00:29:57.950
But, we've covered everything
that's gonna be on the exam,

583
00:29:57.950 --> 00:29:59.990
so it's a pretty good spot for
us to wrap this one up.

584
00:29:59.990 --> 00:30:02.330
>> Yep, looks like we've come to
the end of another great episode.

585
00:30:02.330 --> 00:30:04.760
Hopefully you guys enjoyed it,
we sure enjoyed making it.

586
00:30:04.760 --> 00:30:05.560
That being said,

587
00:30:05.560 --> 00:30:09.280
it is time to sign off from ITProTV,
I've been your host, Daniel Lawry.

588
00:30:09.280 --> 00:30:10.211
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

589
00:30:10.211 --> 00:30:11.369
>> And we'll see you next time.

590
00:30:11.369 --> 00:30:17.190
[MUSIC]

episodes.title: Disk Quotas
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.374
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:10.374 --> 00:00:14.508
All right, everyone, greetings and welcome
to another great episode of ITProTV.

3
00:00:14.508 --> 00:00:18.671
I'm your host Daniel Lowrie and here with
my today is none other than Don Pezet.

4
00:00:18.671 --> 00:00:19.910
How's it going today, Don?

5
00:00:19.910 --> 00:00:20.960
>> It is going great, Daniel.

6
00:00:20.960 --> 00:00:22.060
I'm excited to be on the show today.

7
00:00:22.060 --> 00:00:24.630
We're gonna be talking about disk quotas.

8
00:00:24.630 --> 00:00:27.770
And disk quotas are one of those
things that in the 1980s and

9
00:00:27.770 --> 00:00:30.940
even the 1990s we really lived and
died by.

10
00:00:30.940 --> 00:00:35.330
What a quota is is simply a limit to
the amount of storage that somebody or

11
00:00:35.330 --> 00:00:37.520
a group of people are allowed
to use on a drive.

12
00:00:37.520 --> 00:00:43.300
And in the days of 60 MB drives or 100 MB
drives, you had to limit people's usage.

13
00:00:43.300 --> 00:00:45.270
You didn't want people going crazy.

14
00:00:45.270 --> 00:00:49.260
And you might say to yourself, well,
Don today, 6 TB drives, 8 TB drives,

15
00:00:49.260 --> 00:00:50.473
they're super cheap.

16
00:00:50.473 --> 00:00:53.017
And I can let my users eat all
the space they want and if I run out,

17
00:00:53.017 --> 00:00:54.565
I'll just add some more hard drives.

18
00:00:54.565 --> 00:00:56.180
They don't cost a lot of money.

19
00:00:56.180 --> 00:00:57.890
And you'd be right, you can do that.

20
00:00:57.890 --> 00:01:00.760
So you'd think quotas
are kind of obsolete.

21
00:01:00.760 --> 00:01:02.440
But I'll tell you,
I really like quotas and

22
00:01:02.440 --> 00:01:06.030
the main reason is, they are still
incredibly useful even today.

23
00:01:07.060 --> 00:01:08.570
And let me mention
something that Daniel and

24
00:01:08.570 --> 00:01:11.660
I were talking about before the show
that I think is important to mention.

25
00:01:11.660 --> 00:01:13.556
A lot of people think about
how cheap that storage is.

26
00:01:13.556 --> 00:01:16.510
Yeah, we can just let our
storage grow as much as we want.

27
00:01:16.510 --> 00:01:21.255
But what you forget is
the larger your dataset is,

28
00:01:21.255 --> 00:01:23.565
the longer your backups are going to take.

29
00:01:23.565 --> 00:01:26.735
So if you're trying to do your backups at
night, while your company is closed, but

30
00:01:26.735 --> 00:01:30.155
your data keeps growing and growing and
growing, your backups take longer and

31
00:01:30.155 --> 00:01:33.535
longer and longer, and all of a sudden
you can't do your backup at night.

32
00:01:33.535 --> 00:01:37.365
And now the backup's overlapping with work
hours and it's affecting performance.

33
00:01:37.365 --> 00:01:42.480
Not only that, the longer your backup
takes, the longer your restore takes.

34
00:01:42.480 --> 00:01:46.430
So now, a disaster's hit, everything's
critical, you're trying to restore data as

35
00:01:46.430 --> 00:01:51.330
fast as possible, and instead of restoring
payroll, you're sitting there waiting

36
00:01:51.330 --> 00:01:54.385
while it's restoring Johnny in
Accounting's MP3 collection.

37
00:01:54.385 --> 00:01:58.620
And you're watching that little blue bar
scroll across the screen as Freebird is

38
00:01:58.620 --> 00:02:02.840
restored and you're thinking, this is not
furthering my company getting back online.

39
00:02:02.840 --> 00:02:06.720
So this is an area where
we can use quotas.

40
00:02:06.720 --> 00:02:09.910
We can enforce quotas if we just
don't have a lot of disk space, or

41
00:02:09.910 --> 00:02:12.650
we can enforce quotas if we're
trying to keep our dataset

42
00:02:12.650 --> 00:02:17.180
within a reasonable boundary to
facilitate backups and restores.

43
00:02:17.180 --> 00:02:22.830
>> Yeah, Don, we've talked about how
large the email servers can get.

44
00:02:22.830 --> 00:02:24.760
Having disk quotas can
definitely help a lot with that.

45
00:02:24.760 --> 00:02:27.980
I've seen people with huge mailboxes that

46
00:02:27.980 --> 00:02:30.780
we had to put a quota on because
it was just getting too large.

47
00:02:30.780 --> 00:02:32.720
Backups were a real problem at that point.

48
00:02:32.720 --> 00:02:33.410
>> Absolutely.

49
00:02:33.410 --> 00:02:34.550
And with Linux,

50
00:02:34.550 --> 00:02:38.570
we have native quota support right in
the file system that we can turn on.

51
00:02:38.570 --> 00:02:39.730
It's been around a long time,

52
00:02:39.730 --> 00:02:42.230
and it's really not that big
of a deal to get it turned on.

53
00:02:42.230 --> 00:02:44.330
There are a few steps that
we have to go through and

54
00:02:44.330 --> 00:02:46.100
they have to be done
in a particular order.

55
00:02:46.100 --> 00:02:50.340

00:12:43.370 --> 00:12:46.710
Well, when you write

some have a minimum size of four

00:12:55.830 --> 00:12:58.660
And so
if I have a four kilobyte inode size and

00:12:58.660 --> 00:13:03.290

00:13:03.290 --> 00:13:05.680

00:13:17.600 --> 00:13:21.210

00:25:34.050 --> 00:25:39.380
That being said, I am your host,
Daniel Lowrie signing off with Don Pezet.

506
00:25:39.380 --> 00:25:39.989
I totally messed that up.

507
00:25:39.989 --> 00:25:41.709
But we'll see you next time,
have a good one.

508
00:25:41.709 --> 00:25:48.450
>> [LAUGH]
