episodes.title: Locating Files
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.127 --> 00:00:11.121
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.121 --> 00:00:12.627
All right.
Greetings everyone and

3
00:00:12.627 --> 00:00:14.900
welcome to another great
episode of ITProTV.

4
00:00:14.900 --> 00:00:16.820
I'll be your host Daniel Lowry and

5
00:00:16.820 --> 00:00:18.930
here with me today is none
other than Don Pezet.

6
00:00:18.930 --> 00:00:20.550
How's it going today Don?

7
00:00:20.550 --> 00:00:21.800
>> It is going great Daniel.

8
00:00:21.800 --> 00:00:24.719
Excited about another Linux+ episode and
this episode.

9
00:00:25.760 --> 00:00:27.900
As you watch this episode,
you're gonna think gee,

10
00:00:27.900 --> 00:00:31.170
I wish they would have filmed this one
way back in the beginning of this series.

11
00:00:31.170 --> 00:00:34.810
We're gonna talk about locating
files on a Linux hard drive, and

12
00:00:34.810 --> 00:00:37.030
just the Linux file structure in general.

13
00:00:37.030 --> 00:00:38.390
And if you've watched our episodes so

14
00:00:38.390 --> 00:00:41.120
far, you know you've seen more than
once where I've gone to run a command.

15
00:00:41.120 --> 00:00:42.980
I've was like, oh shoot,
where is that command.

16
00:00:42.980 --> 00:00:45.200
And I check two or three directories,
and then I find it.

17
00:00:45.200 --> 00:00:48.190
Or where that's library, and I check
two or three directories and I find it.

18
00:00:48.190 --> 00:00:50.810
Well, I'm doing that by hand.

19
00:00:50.810 --> 00:00:52.810
There's actually ways that we
can automate that process,

20
00:00:52.810 --> 00:00:55.610
and the reality is there's a whole
little table we can memorize

21
00:00:55.610 --> 00:00:57.720
that would tell us exactly
where these files are.

22
00:00:57.720 --> 00:01:01.300
So locating files on the hard drive in
Linux doesn't have to be voodoo magic or

23
00:01:01.300 --> 00:01:02.510
crazy memorization.

24
00:01:02.510 --> 00:01:04.570
There actually is a system to it.

25
00:01:04.570 --> 00:01:07.350
And we just have to have the basic
understanding of how that system works.

26
00:01:07.350 --> 00:01:07.850
>> Yeah.
Well,

27
00:01:07.850 --> 00:01:10.230
before I figured out how
to use some of these tools,

28
00:01:10.230 --> 00:01:14.980
and how the system is actually kinda
set up in some sort of logical order

29
00:01:14.980 --> 00:01:18.400
to help you remember
where things should be.

30
00:01:18.400 --> 00:01:20.530
And until I got that understanding,
I was completely lost.

31
00:01:20.530 --> 00:01:22.820
I was like, this file system's insane.

32
00:01:22.820 --> 00:01:24.040
There's files everywhere.

33
00:01:24.040 --> 00:01:27.470
I've got sbin, I've got bin,
I've got user, I've got- what is going on.

34
00:01:27.470 --> 00:01:28.640
I have no idea.

35
00:01:28.640 --> 00:01:30.300
Help me out here please, Linux.

36
00:01:30.300 --> 00:01:33.820
And then you read the man find command and
you're just, okay,

37
00:01:33.820 --> 00:01:34.945
I'm even further confused.

38
00:01:34.945 --> 00:01:38.140
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah so, one of the big things we

39
00:01:38.140 --> 00:01:42.390
hear about from our viewers is how that
they're coming from a Windows world.

40
00:01:42.390 --> 00:01:43.080
And in Windows,

41
00:01:43.080 --> 00:01:47.580
if you install Windows on your hard drive,
your drive gets a letter, right, C:.

42
00:01:47.580 --> 00:01:50.070
And in Linux you don't have a drive
letters you have mount points,

43
00:01:50.070 --> 00:01:51.440
it's different right?

44
00:01:51.440 --> 00:01:54.640
And then when you do install Windows,
you have C:\WIndows that's where your

45
00:01:54.640 --> 00:01:59.370
operating system is, and C:\ProgramFiles,
that's where you program files go.

46
00:01:59.370 --> 00:02:02.710
And then that's it, there's really any
other folder is optional at that point.

47
00:02:02.710 --> 00:02:07.340
Well the reason Windows only has a couple
of folders like that, is because there's

48
00:02:07.340 --> 00:02:10.500
a lot of stuff that's just outright hidden
in Windows the end users don't see,

49
00:02:10.500 --> 00:02:12.830
cuz it's designed for end users.

50
00:02:12.830 --> 00:02:15.030
Linux on the other hand
is built off of Unix.

51
00:02:15.030 --> 00:02:18.960
And in the Unix world, almost
everything is represented as a file.

52
00:02:18.960 --> 00:02:23.570
So files are very important,
and nothing is hidden from us.

53
00:02:23.570 --> 00:02:26.510
So when you do a basic install
of Linux you're going to

54
00:02:26.510 --> 00:02:28.180
have a number of folders in there.

55
00:02:28.180 --> 00:02:32.900
And the majority of them are going to have
three letter abbreviated names that follow

56
00:02:32.900 --> 00:02:35.720
the old Unix standard, so
they're not necessarily intuitive.

57
00:02:35.720 --> 00:02:36.480
All right?

58
00:02:36.480 --> 00:02:38.790
But once you get used to them,
once you've worked with them a bit,

59
00:02:38.790 --> 00:02:39.610
it becomes second nature.

60
00:02:39.610 --> 00:02:40.980
It's not a big deal.

61
00:02:40.980 --> 00:02:44.510
But it is confusing for
people coming from the Windows world.

62
00:02:44.510 --> 00:02:48.830
If this is your first system,
you've never used Windows before,

63
00:02:48.830 --> 00:02:52.770
it's actually pretty easy to kinda snap
into it and figure out what each piece is,

64
00:02:52.770 --> 00:02:54.480
what it does and what it's important for.

65
00:02:54.480 --> 00:02:57.430
So let's take a look at what we've got.

66
00:02:57.430 --> 00:02:59.300
I've got a CentOS 7 machine here.

67
00:02:59.300 --> 00:03:03.860
I did a base install CentOS 7,
I haven't messed with it very much at all.

68
00:03:03.860 --> 00:03:06.360
I think I did some updates
on it at some point.

69
00:03:06.360 --> 00:03:09.550
when you drop to a terminal
you default to being in

70
00:03:09.550 --> 00:03:11.730
what's called your home directory.

71
00:03:11.730 --> 00:03:14.620
And your home directory you can always
view the directory with a PWD command,

72
00:03:14.620 --> 00:03:18.340
but your home directory is
slash home slash d pizet.

73
00:03:18.340 --> 00:03:22.090
Let's talk about what that means,
right, that very first slash.

74
00:03:22.090 --> 00:03:27.860
That means my root, so my root drive or
wherever my root mount point is.

75
00:03:27.860 --> 00:03:30.940
Inside of there there's
a folder called home.

76
00:03:30.940 --> 00:03:35.760
And inside of that folder, this slash
tells me that there's another folder, and

77
00:03:35.760 --> 00:03:38.150
inside of it there's
a folder called dpezet.

78
00:03:38.150 --> 00:03:41.230
And so that's where I am right now.

79
00:03:41.230 --> 00:03:44.150
If I were to change to my Root directory.

80
00:03:44.150 --> 00:03:45.840
So I'm just going to do a cd slash.

81
00:03:45.840 --> 00:03:48.760
and if I do my present work
directory I'm right there in slash.

82
00:03:48.760 --> 00:03:51.990
And I pull up a listing of
the folders that are in there,

83
00:03:51.990 --> 00:03:54.830
there's that folder called home.

84
00:03:54.830 --> 00:03:57.880
And if I go into my home folder and

85
00:03:57.880 --> 00:04:01.144
I pull up that listing,
there's that folder called dpezet.

86
00:04:01.144 --> 00:04:05.880
And if I change into that, if I can spell
my own name, then you'll see the files and

87
00:04:05.880 --> 00:04:06.840
folders that I have in there.

88
00:04:06.840 --> 00:04:08.840
So that's our basic file hierarchy.

89
00:04:08.840 --> 00:04:11.380
Not really different than
any other operating system.

90
00:04:11.380 --> 00:04:14.330
Linux, Unix, Mac OS,

91
00:04:14.330 --> 00:04:18.790
BSD, all of those guys use forward
slashes to represent folders.

92
00:04:18.790 --> 00:04:21.620
If you're coming from the Windows
world for whatever reason,

93
00:04:21.620 --> 00:04:23.260
Microsoft uses back slashes right?

94
00:04:23.260 --> 00:04:27.090
So just take your mind and flip it
the other way, so instead of a back slash,

95
00:04:27.090 --> 00:04:27.800
do a forward slash.

96
00:04:27.800 --> 00:04:30.140
That's how it's represented in Unix and
Linux.

97
00:04:30.140 --> 00:04:33.610
Now, we don't have drive letters,
we don't have C: or F: or

98
00:04:33.610 --> 00:04:36.330
whatever, we just have
straight up mount points.

99
00:04:36.330 --> 00:04:39.560
And you can always see your
mounts with the mount command.

100
00:04:39.560 --> 00:04:43.060
But on modern OS's you're gonna
get a ton of security mounts, and

101
00:04:43.060 --> 00:04:44.770
other things that are kind of temporary.

102
00:04:44.770 --> 00:04:48.960
So, I find one of the better ways
is to simply look at the slash etc

103
00:04:48.960 --> 00:04:50.100
slash fs tab folder.

104
00:04:50.100 --> 00:04:53.430
And when you look in there you can
see each of your different drives and

105
00:04:53.430 --> 00:04:54.040
where they're mounted.

106
00:04:54.040 --> 00:04:57.840
So, see how I've got this slash
that's being my root drive,

107
00:04:57.840 --> 00:05:01.420
and then I've got slash boot and
slash mounts, slash accounting and

108
00:05:01.420 --> 00:05:03.600
some other things that
we did in another show.

109
00:05:03.600 --> 00:05:05.640
So I can see each of those mount points.

110
00:05:05.640 --> 00:05:08.540
Now, you may see something very simple,
like mine.

111
00:05:08.540 --> 00:05:09.570
I added these three.

112
00:05:09.570 --> 00:05:11.450
But let's assume that I
didn't add those three.

113
00:05:11.450 --> 00:05:13.550
I would just see these first three.

114
00:05:13.550 --> 00:05:18.400
Slash, which is my root, slash,
boot, which is a special folder for

115
00:05:18.400 --> 00:05:19.150
my boot loaders.

116
00:05:19.150 --> 00:05:21.360
If you watched the boot loader episode,
you saw that.

117
00:05:21.360 --> 00:05:24.140
And then swap,
where my memory swapping is.

118
00:05:25.190 --> 00:05:26.970
If you install other Linux distros,

119
00:05:26.970 --> 00:05:31.550
they may create 5, 10,
15 mount points for different things.

120
00:05:31.550 --> 00:05:35.410
A lot of the folders we have in Linux may
be broken out into their own mount point,

121
00:05:35.410 --> 00:05:37.540
their own volume or
partition on your hard drive.

122
00:05:37.540 --> 00:05:39.880
Now, why would I do that?

123
00:05:39.880 --> 00:05:41.690
There's usually two main reasons,
all right?

124
00:05:41.690 --> 00:05:43.010
One reason is security.

125
00:05:43.010 --> 00:05:46.120
We're isolating those files out
from the rest of our system.

126
00:05:46.120 --> 00:05:48.370
The other reason is stability.

127
00:05:48.370 --> 00:05:52.330
When you fill up a folder with junk,
what happens to your system?

128
00:05:52.330 --> 00:05:54.560
Well, other parts of the system may break.

129
00:05:54.560 --> 00:05:57.010
Services may not be able to run,
they don't have the file storage.

130
00:05:57.010 --> 00:05:58.810
So by pushing things off
to their own folders,

131
00:05:58.810 --> 00:06:02.310
you start to set boundaries, limits for
the amount of space that they can consume.

132
00:06:02.310 --> 00:06:05.060
So those are reasons for moving off,
you can see I didn't do that.

133
00:06:05.060 --> 00:06:10.460
When I did a default install of CentOS,
it installed everything except for

134
00:06:10.460 --> 00:06:15.430
the boot folder in /boot,
everything else it just put in /.

135
00:06:15.430 --> 00:06:18.940
But that's not always the case,
other distros may do different things.

136
00:06:18.940 --> 00:06:22.840
But at the end of the day,
inside of your root directory,

137
00:06:22.840 --> 00:06:26.480
you're going to have a set of folders.

138
00:06:26.480 --> 00:06:30.520
And those folders are, for the most part,
consistent from distro to distro.

139
00:06:30.520 --> 00:06:35.740
If I go to Debian and install,
Ubuntu and install, Red Hat, CentOS,

140
00:06:35.740 --> 00:06:40.660
Slackware, I can expect to see
the majority of these folders right here.

141
00:06:42.230 --> 00:06:44.850
So let's run down these folders and
kinda see what they are.

142
00:06:44.850 --> 00:06:47.730
Now, if you're missing a few of them,
don't freak out.

143
00:06:47.730 --> 00:06:52.160
Sometimes they're not required by the OS
and some vendors choose different things.

144
00:06:52.160 --> 00:06:57.000
But in Linux we have what's called
the FHS, or File Hierarchy Standard.

145
00:06:57.000 --> 00:07:01.510
And Red Hat is really the one who
made the big push for the FHS.

146
00:07:01.510 --> 00:07:04.265
Each distro was doing different things,
storing files in different places.

147
00:07:04.265 --> 00:07:06.965
It was reeking havoc for software vendors.

148
00:07:06.965 --> 00:07:08.135
If you wrote a program and

149
00:07:08.135 --> 00:07:11.615
you wanted it to run on Linux, you didn't
know where to put your config files.

150
00:07:11.615 --> 00:07:12.895
Where should I put them?

151
00:07:12.895 --> 00:07:14.074
This distro does one thing.

152
00:07:14.074 --> 00:07:15.135
This distro does another.

153
00:07:15.135 --> 00:07:19.395
Red hat made a big push and said, look the
freedom to do what you want is awesome.

154
00:07:19.395 --> 00:07:23.585
We appreciate that, but if everybody
followed the same folder structure,

155
00:07:23.585 --> 00:07:25.825
is that going to limit your
ability to do cool stuff?

156
00:07:25.825 --> 00:07:28.630
No, and it's gonna make it easier for
developers.

157
00:07:28.630 --> 00:07:31.480
So they don't have to follow it, but

158
00:07:31.480 --> 00:07:35.160
most distros follow the Red Hat
file hierarchy system.

159
00:07:35.160 --> 00:07:39.010
And I've got red hat's page pulled up back
here this is the Red Hat customer portal.

160
00:07:39.010 --> 00:07:43.470
And they basically lay out
the folders that they recommend.

161
00:07:43.470 --> 00:07:46.338
They recommend that you
have a /boot folder, and

162
00:07:46.338 --> 00:07:49.144
that that's where your
boot loader stuff goes.

163
00:07:49.144 --> 00:07:52.958
And, because of the nature of the boot
loader, that needs to be available before

164
00:07:52.958 --> 00:07:56.380
the kernel starts, they recommend
that being on a separate partition,

165
00:07:56.380 --> 00:07:58.814
a separate volume, or
even a separate hard drive.

166
00:07:58.814 --> 00:08:00.683
You know, it might be on flash or
whatever.

167
00:08:00.683 --> 00:08:03.411
So they recommend that being separate.

168
00:08:03.411 --> 00:08:07.910
Everything else could be combined or
separate if we wanted to.

169
00:08:07.910 --> 00:08:12.680
So, things like /dev,
that's where our devices are, right?

170
00:08:12.680 --> 00:08:17.275
So if I have a mouse,
a keyboard, my hard drives,

171
00:08:17.275 --> 00:08:22.365
my CD-ROM drive, udev assigns them
a name inside the /dev folder.

172
00:08:22.365 --> 00:08:26.645
And it's laid out exactly how that should
be structured and example names and stuff.

173
00:08:26.645 --> 00:08:31.185
And their FHS goes through and
lays out each of those directories and

174
00:08:31.185 --> 00:08:33.340
what their purpose is, okay?

175
00:08:33.340 --> 00:08:36.920
Now, I made a quick little table
that I'll post in the show notes.

176
00:08:36.920 --> 00:08:39.750
Well, I say I made a quick little table,
what did I do with that thing?

177
00:08:39.750 --> 00:08:40.560
Here we go.

178
00:08:40.560 --> 00:08:44.950
I'll post in the show notes, it kind
of breaks down what those folders are.

179
00:08:44.950 --> 00:08:49.400
But let's just run through them right
here in my actual system, okay?

180
00:08:49.400 --> 00:08:52.710
So, we'll start with some of
the really important ones.

181
00:08:52.710 --> 00:08:59.010
If I do a, let me just do a ls -la,
there we go, bin, right?

182
00:08:59.010 --> 00:09:00.800
bin is short for binary.

183
00:09:00.800 --> 00:09:05.110
And these are gonna be binaries, or
executables, programs that we can run.

184
00:09:05.110 --> 00:09:09.200
Generally, the files that are in
/bin are files that were put there

185
00:09:09.200 --> 00:09:11.480
by who made your distribution, okay?

186
00:09:11.480 --> 00:09:14.590
And these are binaries that
end users are expected to run.

187
00:09:14.590 --> 00:09:19.960
So, if I log into the computer or
another user in my company logs in,

188
00:09:19.960 --> 00:09:24.131
the executables that are part of the OS
that they need to run would be in /bin,

189
00:09:24.131 --> 00:09:25.420
all right?

190
00:09:25.420 --> 00:09:28.010
Now, there's another folder called sbin.

191
00:09:29.130 --> 00:09:32.560
And sbin, these are system binaries.

192
00:09:32.560 --> 00:09:36.504
These are ones that are intended to be run
by the operating system, not by us, but

193
00:09:36.504 --> 00:09:38.420
by the operating system.

194
00:09:38.420 --> 00:09:41.202
And in both cases, /bin and

195
00:09:41.202 --> 00:09:45.700
/sbin, these are binaries that
are a part of the distro.

196
00:09:45.700 --> 00:09:48.569
We will rarely modify what's
in those two folders.

197
00:09:50.310 --> 00:09:54.150
Then you'll notice another folder usr,
all right?

198
00:09:54.150 --> 00:09:57.230
usr, that's for user programs.

199
00:09:57.230 --> 00:10:01.750
When we start to install software,
it's gonna go into /usr, and

200
00:10:01.750 --> 00:10:08.151
inside of /usr you'll see I have
another bin and another sbin.

201
00:10:09.330 --> 00:10:13.180
So if I'm installing software, and the
software's gonna install a program for me,

202
00:10:13.180 --> 00:10:16.720
it would go into /usr/bin.

203
00:10:16.720 --> 00:10:19.780
But if it's installing software
that's gonna be used by the system,

204
00:10:19.780 --> 00:10:22.940
like maybe some NTFS drivers for
reading a hard drive,

205
00:10:22.940 --> 00:10:27.880
then it's going to go into /usr/sbin,
system binaries, right?

206
00:10:27.880 --> 00:10:33.782
So those four folders, /bin,
/sbin, /usr/sbin, and /usr/bin,

207
00:10:33.782 --> 00:10:39.330
those four are the locations for
all of our executable binaries.

208
00:10:40.330 --> 00:10:42.590
Now, it gets confusing fast, doesn't it?

209
00:10:42.590 --> 00:10:46.946
Well, notice what RedHat
did here on my system,

210
00:10:46.946 --> 00:10:52.684
that if I pull that directory back up,
see how /bin is symlinked

211
00:10:52.684 --> 00:10:57.940
to /usr/bin, and
/sbin is symlinked to /usr/sbin.

212
00:10:57.940 --> 00:11:00.445
RedHat just said you know what, forget it,
we're not gonna maintain two separate

213
00:11:00.445 --> 00:11:04.420
repositories for distro stuff and user
stuff, we'll just combine them together.

214
00:11:04.420 --> 00:11:08.230
But they still support the old
names to maintain compatibility.

215
00:11:08.230 --> 00:11:10.380
That's that file hierarchy structure.

216
00:11:10.380 --> 00:11:13.502
We don't want developers to have to
worry about where the files are.

217
00:11:13.502 --> 00:11:16.835
The distro manufacturers,
they can move stuff around all they want,

218
00:11:16.835 --> 00:11:20.577
as long as they support the old structure,
the software works great, right?

219
00:11:20.577 --> 00:11:22.550
So you see that pretty commonly.

220
00:11:22.550 --> 00:11:25.470
All right, some of the other folders
that we need to be aware of.

221
00:11:25.470 --> 00:11:26.720
/etc.

222
00:11:26.720 --> 00:11:28.720
If you've watched any of our episodes so
far,

223
00:11:28.720 --> 00:11:30.960
we've gone into that at

the locate command.

449
00:23:27.050 --> 00:23:30.490
I'll tell you, I like the locate command,
but I don't use it very often, and

450
00:23:30.490 --> 00:23:35.790
the main reason is, locate doesn't
do a file search across the drives.

451
00:23:35.790 --> 00:23:38.020
Locate actually maintains
a little database,

452
00:23:38.020 --> 00:23:40.380
a database of all
the files on your system.

453
00:23:40.380 --> 00:23:42.940
And the database is updated.

454
00:23:42.940 --> 00:23:47.220
Well, it depends on how often your admin
sets it up, or you, if you're the admin.

455
00:23:47.220 --> 00:23:49.640
If you haven't set it up,
then it doesn't update.

456
00:23:49.640 --> 00:23:53.378
The way to update that database is
by running the updatedb command.

457
00:23:53.378 --> 00:23:57.395
And When you run that, it's gonna
generate the database that locate uses.

458
00:23:57.395 --> 00:23:58.601
And I'm not an admin.

459
00:23:58.601 --> 00:24:01.951
Let me switch back to an admin account and
I'll run updatedb.

460
00:24:01.951 --> 00:24:06.241
And it's gonna run and now it's updating
the catalog of all my files and

461
00:24:06.241 --> 00:24:08.300
when I do a search now.

462
00:24:08.300 --> 00:24:11.209
I'll get a good quick response
right out of that database and

463
00:24:11.209 --> 00:24:13.843
if you want that to run routinely
you set up a chron job.

464
00:24:13.843 --> 00:24:16.303
And just say run update
db every 24 hours but

465
00:24:16.303 --> 00:24:20.463
that means the locate command is not
always returning timely information.

466
00:24:20.463 --> 00:24:24.270
Things might be different and as a result,
I don't normally use the locate command.

467
00:24:25.380 --> 00:24:28.090
Now, we saw using find,
find searches the hard drive,

468
00:24:28.090 --> 00:24:31.230
you definitely get timely information
there, it's just not fast.

469
00:24:31.230 --> 00:24:34.410
The more files your system has,
the longer the find command takes.

470
00:24:35.570 --> 00:24:37.310
A few other alternatives.

471
00:24:37.310 --> 00:24:40.160
There's things like whereis, right?

472
00:24:40.160 --> 00:24:41.780
Now, I do use this one a lot.

473
00:24:41.780 --> 00:24:46.010
If I say whereis LS,
what it's gonna do is it's gonna look up

474
00:24:46.010 --> 00:24:50.130
through the package manager and
say okay, we installed a package for LS.

475
00:24:50.130 --> 00:24:51.552
Where'd you install it to?

476
00:24:51.552 --> 00:24:57.680
All right, now this is a good
in-between of doing find and locate.

477
00:24:57.680 --> 00:25:03.920
Find gives me real time information but
might be processor or disk IO intensive.

478
00:25:03.920 --> 00:25:07.690
Locate is not intensive but
it might be out of date.

479
00:25:07.690 --> 00:25:12.060
This one shows me where the package
was installed and that's usually very,

480
00:25:12.060 --> 00:25:14.930
very accurate unless somebody's
messed with the package.

481
00:25:14.930 --> 00:25:17.500
If somebody went and
moved the files after it was installed,

482
00:25:17.500 --> 00:25:19.170
the package manager won't know that.

483
00:25:19.170 --> 00:25:21.277
So this is pretty accurate and

484
00:25:21.277 --> 00:25:25.167
pretty fast where it is is
typically the one that I use.

485
00:25:25.167 --> 00:25:26.260
All right couple other ones.

486
00:25:28.020 --> 00:25:31.430
Sometimes we run a command and
we think we're running a command and

487
00:25:31.430 --> 00:25:34.300
we're actually running an alias
of something else right?

488
00:25:34.300 --> 00:25:38.530
So for example when I run LS I think
I'm just running the list command.

489
00:25:38.530 --> 00:25:41.200
But I'm actually running it with several
different options enabled that I

490
00:25:41.200 --> 00:25:42.560
just don't see.

491
00:25:42.560 --> 00:25:45.370
Or, maybe you have an alias for
something like DIR, right?

492
00:25:45.370 --> 00:25:47.860
So I just run DIR and
I get my directory listing.

493
00:25:47.860 --> 00:25:50.380
Well, where's the DIR command?

494
00:25:50.380 --> 00:25:56.431
So if I do like a where is DIR, I can
find that it's showing /user/bin/dir.

495
00:25:56.431 --> 00:26:00.921
I don't realize that that's truly just
a soft link that's pointing to the LS

496
00:26:00.921 --> 00:26:02.020
command.

497
00:26:02.020 --> 00:26:02.650
All right.

498
00:26:02.650 --> 00:26:07.630
So, sometimes the information that we get
back is not necessarily exactly accurate.

499
00:26:07.630 --> 00:26:10.594
But good enough for our purposes
to find what we're looking for.

500
00:26:10.594 --> 00:26:11.540
All right.

501
00:26:11.540 --> 00:26:13.050
If we wanna see a little bit
more about the commands,

502
00:26:13.050 --> 00:26:14.800
we can use the which command.

503
00:26:14.800 --> 00:26:20.750
If I say which LS, now it tells me that
LS, I'm actually running an alias.

504
00:26:20.750 --> 00:26:24.157
When I run LS,
I'm not truly running the LS command,

505
00:26:24.157 --> 00:26:27.582
instead I'm running LS dash
dash color equals auto.

506
00:26:27.582 --> 00:26:28.660
That's why I get those nice,
colorful prompts.

507
00:26:28.660 --> 00:26:33.320
And then the other thing which does,
is it tells me where LS is, right?

508
00:26:33.320 --> 00:26:34.980
So I get the valuable
information right there.

509
00:26:34.980 --> 00:26:39.340
I get where the program is and
the options that I'm applying to it.

510
00:26:39.340 --> 00:26:44.140
If I do which DIR, well it shows me here
that I don't actually have an alias for

511
00:26:44.140 --> 00:26:45.920
DIR, I'm pointing that file.

512
00:26:45.920 --> 00:26:49.460
And I think I want to look to see what
that file is actually assembling, but

513
00:26:49.460 --> 00:26:52.380
which is a nice one you know you
could run this for any command.

514
00:26:52.380 --> 00:26:56.536
If I want to know where vie is installed,
I can do which vie,

515
00:26:56.536 --> 00:27:00.289
which really would be the same
output as where is vie.

516
00:27:00.289 --> 00:27:04.541
Except where is vie also shows
the packages that it came from, right, so

517
00:27:04.541 --> 00:27:08.317
I can kind of see that and
where those packages and man files are.

518
00:27:08.317 --> 00:27:10.370
That information is all right there.

519
00:27:10.370 --> 00:27:15.430
So any command that you use or whatever
you come in here and use which to find it.

520
00:27:15.430 --> 00:27:17.500
All right so, find?

521
00:27:17.500 --> 00:27:20.965
That's a great utility that can search
inside of files and it can search for

522
00:27:20.965 --> 00:27:23.786
file names, you can search by
what user owns them with find.

523
00:27:23.786 --> 00:27:27.295
It's very powerful, right, I encourage
you to take a look at that one.

524
00:27:27.295 --> 00:27:30.377
You know, if you do like a dash,
dash help on it,

525
00:27:30.377 --> 00:27:35.060
you'll see where you can search by
things like what user owns it and so on.

526
00:27:35.060 --> 00:27:39.650
Those are all options that we
can search buy, we did where is,

527
00:27:39.650 --> 00:27:42.350
we did locate, locate, I didn't like so
much, because of that database.

528
00:27:42.350 --> 00:27:46.720
In the exam remember, update db,
that's how you update that database.

529
00:27:46.720 --> 00:27:49.360
And then the which command,
which is incredibly useful,

530
00:27:49.360 --> 00:27:54.030
shows us the aliases if we've got one and
where the program actually resides.

531
00:27:54.030 --> 00:27:57.410
All great ways to find the files if you
don't have the hierarchy memorized.

532
00:27:58.500 --> 00:28:00.864
But for the exam, you need to know both.

533
00:28:00.864 --> 00:28:03.880
You need to know the commands
to quickly find this stuff.

534
00:28:03.880 --> 00:28:06.540
And you need to know the file hierarchy.

535
00:28:06.540 --> 00:28:09.790
Expect to see that, at least one or
two questions on the exam.

536
00:28:09.790 --> 00:28:13.220
>> Yeah, it seems like it's a lot to
swallow, and it very well may be.

537
00:28:13.220 --> 00:28:16.860
But as you continually use Linux and
you're working with it more and

538
00:28:16.860 --> 00:28:19.650
more on a daily basis and
you're studying for the exam.

539
00:28:19.650 --> 00:28:22.640
This stuff really starts to become
second nature pretty quickly,

540
00:28:22.640 --> 00:28:25.790
so don't fret too much [LAUGH]
about it being overwhelming.

541
00:28:25.790 --> 00:28:28.300
Just dig you heels in and
keep plowing through it,

542
00:28:28.300 --> 00:28:30.720
and eventually you're gonna be like,
oh, yeah, I know where that stuff is.

543
00:28:30.720 --> 00:28:33.450
And if I don't, well, I've got that
find command down, I've got locate down,

544
00:28:33.450 --> 00:28:38.090
I've got whereis, or which, and
plenty of other tools as well.

545
00:28:38.090 --> 00:28:40.420
These are the ones that they'll
want you to know for the exam.

546
00:28:40.420 --> 00:28:43.360
Great stuff, it's must-know information,

547
00:28:43.360 --> 00:28:46.090
even if you're just going to be using
Linux and not even taking the exam.

548
00:28:47.250 --> 00:28:49.510
>> Daniel, I just skimmed over
the exam objectives real quick, and

549
00:28:49.510 --> 00:28:51.650
there's one more command
we need to mention.

550
00:28:51.650 --> 00:28:56.320
The type command, and
I knew the type command output file data.

551
00:28:56.320 --> 00:28:59.500
But the type command is just type,
T-Y-P-E,

552
00:28:59.500 --> 00:29:01.350
it can show you a little
bit of information also.

553
00:29:01.350 --> 00:29:04.530
And it might turn up on the exam, so
let me just show you an example of that.

554
00:29:04.530 --> 00:29:08.410
The type command, if you just run
type it doesn't do much right?

555
00:29:08.410 --> 00:29:13.630
But if you run type followed by a command
like LS, see how it shows me the alias?

556
00:29:13.630 --> 00:29:15.360
It doesn't show me where the file resides.

557
00:29:15.360 --> 00:29:18.100
But it shows me the alias and what it's
doing here is it's not specifically

558
00:29:18.100 --> 00:29:21.380
showing me the alias,
it's saying if you run this command.

559
00:29:21.380 --> 00:29:24.420
Here is how the system will interpret it,
this is what the system will see.

560
00:29:24.420 --> 00:29:28.310
All right, and if there's an alias,
the system will see the alias.

561
00:29:28.310 --> 00:29:32.800
If there's not an alias,
it will show the binary, right?

562
00:29:32.800 --> 00:29:34.500
Here it's saying DIR is hash.

563
00:29:34.500 --> 00:29:36.251
That means it's indexed and it's got it.

564
00:29:36.251 --> 00:29:39.540
And it's going to run /user/bin/dir.

565
00:29:39.540 --> 00:29:41.560
Right, or if I do vie,

566
00:29:41.560 --> 00:29:46.250
right, vie is not hashed, this one
is hashed because it is assembling.

567
00:29:46.250 --> 00:29:49.800
But here we got slash USR
slash bin slash vie so

568
00:29:49.800 --> 00:29:52.020
the type command is another way to see.

569
00:29:52.020 --> 00:29:56.520
What's actually gonna be sent to the
operating system when you run that command

570
00:29:56.520 --> 00:29:58.410
so you can type the type command.

571
00:29:58.410 --> 00:30:03.377
Followed by, really,
any kinda string like nano file.txt, and

572
00:30:03.377 --> 00:30:06.580
it's gonna try and interpret that for me.

573
00:30:06.580 --> 00:30:09.090
So Nano, it lays that out,
and then see how here,

574
00:30:09.090 --> 00:30:11.159
it tried to actually interpret file.txt?

575
00:30:11.159 --> 00:30:12.704
Well, I can't just run,

576
00:30:12.704 --> 00:30:17.491
file.text, I get that command, and
that's what it output right there for me.

577
00:30:17.491 --> 00:30:19.937
As it were separate commands so,
you can feed those in,

578
00:30:19.937 --> 00:30:22.910
it'll give you the output and
let you know what system it sees.

579
00:30:22.910 --> 00:30:25.290
>> Yeah, that's really helpful when it
comes to scripting and stuff like that,

580
00:30:25.290 --> 00:30:27.336
because that's what you're
gonna be working with.

581
00:30:27.336 --> 00:30:28.320
>> Yeah.
>> Good stuff, Don.

582
00:30:28.320 --> 00:30:29.690
Good stuff.
Thank you very much for

583
00:30:29.690 --> 00:30:33.550
that very well-rehearsed and
put together demonstration,

584
00:30:33.550 --> 00:30:37.260
because this is the soup and
the nuts of working in Linux.

585
00:30:37.260 --> 00:30:40.150
You're gonna be doing a lot of finding,
a lot of searching.

586
00:30:40.150 --> 00:30:44.480
How is this command being interpreted
by the actual command line itself?

587
00:30:44.480 --> 00:30:47.450
That's gonna be very helpful,
especially when it comes to that exam.

588
00:30:47.450 --> 00:30:49.510
But looks like we have done it again.

589
00:30:49.510 --> 00:30:52.650
We've got, plowed through
another episode of Linux Plus.

590
00:30:52.650 --> 00:30:54.010
Hopefully you guys have enjoyed it.

591
00:30:54.010 --> 00:30:55.472
We sure enjoyed making it for you.

592
00:30:55.472 --> 00:30:59.960
That being said, it's time to sign off for
ITProTV I've been your host Daniel Lowrie.

593
00:30:59.960 --> 00:31:00.680
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

594
00:31:00.680 --> 00:31:02.095
>> And we'll see you next time.

595
00:31:02.095 --> 00:31:08.250

episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.763
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:10.763 --> 00:00:11.943
All right everyone.

3
00:00:11.943 --> 00:00:15.163
Greetings and welcome to another
great episode of ITProTV.

4
00:00:15.163 --> 00:00:18.887
We are host Daniel Lowrie and here with
me today is none other than Don Pezet.

5
00:00:18.887 --> 00:00:20.000
How's it going, Don?

6
00:00:20.000 --> 00:00:22.730
>> I'm doing great Daniel,
excited about another episode.

7
00:00:22.730 --> 00:00:24.980
We're gonna be jumping right
back into Linux Plus today.

8
00:00:24.980 --> 00:00:28.630
And we're taking a look the boot
process inside of Linux,

9
00:00:28.630 --> 00:00:30.500
which is largely controlled
by our boot loader.

10
00:00:30.500 --> 00:00:32.900
So we've got some really
interesting things to look at.

11
00:00:32.900 --> 00:00:36.401
These are things that a lot of people
ignore, you push the power button and

12
00:00:36.401 --> 00:00:38.844
you wait until you get into X Windows and
off you go.

13
00:00:38.844 --> 00:00:41.878
But there's a lot of neat stuff that goes
on behind the scenes that we need to

14
00:00:41.878 --> 00:00:42.420
be aware of.

15
00:00:42.420 --> 00:00:45.480
>> Yeah, it's kind of important that
your computer actually boots up and

16
00:00:45.480 --> 00:00:46.370
does a lot of stuff.

17
00:00:46.370 --> 00:00:49.694
Things like initializing different
services that you may need.

18
00:00:49.694 --> 00:00:50.510
Well I don't know.

19
00:00:50.510 --> 00:00:52.885
The good old X systems got
to get that up and running.

20
00:00:52.885 --> 00:00:55.820
And then there's the partitions on your
hard drive, it's gotta read from them.

21
00:00:55.820 --> 00:00:59.800
Try to find out what actually do you want
to read from a mount, all that goodness.

22
00:00:59.800 --> 00:01:04.080
A lot of stuff that goes into actually
getting your system booted before you're

23
00:01:04.080 --> 00:01:08.190
live at five, you're sitting behind the
wheel there, taking it for a drive, so.

24
00:01:08.190 --> 00:01:09.510
Don that's what we're gonna
talk about today, right?

25
00:01:09.510 --> 00:01:12.317
You know it's funny Daniel that you
mention it, most people ignore it.

26
00:01:12.317 --> 00:01:15.432
And I know I say that too, you ignore it
because you push the power button and

27
00:01:15.432 --> 00:01:17.874
it just works,
up until the point where it doesn't work.

28
00:01:17.874 --> 00:01:20.665
And when it doesn't work that's when
we really need to know what the heck

29
00:01:20.665 --> 00:01:21.180
is going on.

30
00:01:21.180 --> 00:01:24.980
And kind of what that process is,
so it's actually pretty neat.

31
00:01:24.980 --> 00:01:27.590
Unfortunately, what we're going
to see in this episode and

32
00:01:27.590 --> 00:01:30.960
really our next couple episodes,
is this is an area where things

33
00:01:30.960 --> 00:01:35.220
really start to get different
in-between Linux distributions.

34
00:01:35.220 --> 00:01:40.250
There is a common criticism out there
that Linux would be a lot more successful

35
00:01:40.250 --> 00:01:44.070
if a lot of the distros would just settle
on a consistent way of doing things.

36
00:01:44.070 --> 00:01:48.105
And for a lot of things,
like the Linux kernel and the GNU tools.

37
00:01:48.105 --> 00:01:50.065
Those things, they are consistent on,

38
00:01:50.065 --> 00:01:52.885
there's thing you can count
on between the Linux distros.

39
00:01:52.885 --> 00:01:55.435
But then there's other things
like the boot process that can

40
00:01:55.435 --> 00:01:57.085
vary from distro to distro.

41
00:01:57.085 --> 00:01:59.045
On the exam,
we need to know some of the main ones, but

42
00:01:59.045 --> 00:02:00.875
in real life you might even
encounter some others.

43
00:02:00.875 --> 00:02:03.195
>> Yeah, Don, you just kind of
threw some jet fuel on that fire.

44
00:02:03.195 --> 00:02:05.905
I know the Linux users out there,
it's hotly debated,

45
00:02:05.905 --> 00:02:08.995
like should we go to some
sort of standardization, or

46
00:02:08.995 --> 00:02:14.210
is Linux meant to be that's whatever
you prefer kind of operating system.

47
00:02:14.210 --> 00:02:18.640
And that does seem to be the prevailing
argument, but it would be.

48
00:02:18.640 --> 00:02:23.330
I would say that would be a whole lot
more well received if they did that.

49
00:02:23.330 --> 00:02:25.610
>> Well, let's try to keep things
general here in the beginning.

50
00:02:25.610 --> 00:02:28.950
We'll talk about some stuff that applies
pretty much to every Linux distro.

51
00:02:28.950 --> 00:02:30.740
When you push the power
button on your computer,

52
00:02:30.740 --> 00:02:33.080
you're starting the boot process right?

53
00:02:33.080 --> 00:02:35.780
And what your power
button is doing is it's

54
00:02:35.780 --> 00:02:39.160
basically applying power to
the motherboard and initializing the BIOS.

55
00:02:39.160 --> 00:02:43.280
Now BIOS use to do all the work,
but in today's computers,

56
00:02:43.280 --> 00:02:46.620
most of the time BIOS has
been replaced by EFI right?

57
00:02:46.620 --> 00:02:49.969
EFI is what Extensible Firmware Interface?

58
00:02:51.150 --> 00:02:52.060
Give me a look there.

59
00:02:52.060 --> 00:02:54.170
[LAUGH] Well, either way, EFI.

60
00:02:54.170 --> 00:02:56.230
So EFI was designed to replace BIOS.

61
00:02:56.230 --> 00:02:59.760
Remember that BIOS is very old,
developed I don't even know when,

62
00:02:59.760 --> 00:03:03.030
probably earlier than the 70s,
that Basic Input Output System.

63
00:03:03.030 --> 00:03:06.900
When you power on the computer, it's
what says, oh, look you have a keyboard,

64
00:03:06.900 --> 00:03:07.570
let's turn that on.

65
00:03:07.570 --> 00:03:09.950
Oh, look you have have a mouse,
let's turn that on.

66
00:03:09.950 --> 00:03:12.590
Oh look the CPU should probably
be doing some work now.

67
00:03:12.590 --> 00:03:15.380
Or a video card,
maybe you want to see some things.

68
00:03:15.380 --> 00:03:17.380
Your BIOS is what's kicking all that on.

69
00:03:17.380 --> 00:03:22.680
Well, when BIOS was originally developed,
having 640k of memory was unheard of.

70
00:03:22.680 --> 00:03:24.300
That was a ton of memory.

71
00:03:24.300 --> 00:03:27.600
So BIOS was designed to be very,
very compact.

72
00:03:27.600 --> 00:03:29.850
Very small, very efficient.

73
00:03:29.850 --> 00:03:33.910
And it served us well 30 years or
however long.

74
00:03:33.910 --> 00:03:35.940
But, as computers became more advanced.

75
00:03:35.940 --> 00:03:37.330
As hard drives became bigger.

76
00:03:37.330 --> 00:03:39.250
As large quantities of memory happened.

77
00:03:39.250 --> 00:03:42.930
As people wanted to do fancy things,
like instead of the old text based BIOS,

78
00:03:42.930 --> 00:03:44.720
maybe I want to have a graphic one,

79
00:03:44.720 --> 00:03:47.460
with a mouse where I can click
on buttons in the BIOS screens.

80
00:03:47.460 --> 00:03:48.100
You couldn't do that.

81
00:03:48.100 --> 00:03:49.840
There just wasn't enough room and

82
00:03:49.840 --> 00:03:52.600
power inside a traditional BIOS,
so EFI replaced it.

83
00:03:54.520 --> 00:03:57.090
If your computer is doing
what's called legacy boot.

84
00:03:57.090 --> 00:03:59.540
Now, traditional BIOS booting
is called legacy boot.

85
00:03:59.540 --> 00:04:02.550
If you're doing legacy boot,
you push the power button.

86
00:04:02.550 --> 00:04:06.100
Your BIOS starts to initialize
all the different hardware.

87
00:04:06.100 --> 00:04:09.650

time to find an operating system.

88
00:04:09.650 --> 00:04:11.780
And what it does is it looks
in its BIOS configuration for

89
00:04:11.780 --> 00:04:14.450
your hard drives, or
it actually looks for your boot order.

90
00:04:14.450 --> 00:04:18.600
Right, because you can define a boot order
in your BIOS, you say I want the CD ROM to

91
00:04:18.600 --> 00:04:22.010
boot first, I want the USB to boot second,
I want hard drives to boot third.

92
00:04:22.010 --> 00:04:24.880
Or if I have five hard drives,
I want this hard drive to boot third,

93
00:04:24.880 --> 00:04:26.390
I want this other hard
drive to boot fourth.

94
00:04:26.390 --> 00:04:28.050
Right, you specify that order.

95
00:04:28.050 --> 00:04:29.280
So the BIOS looks at its order,

96
00:04:29.280 --> 00:04:33.000
and it just goes one by one down
that order looking at those drives.

97
00:04:33.000 --> 00:04:35.980
And it looks for a Master Boot Record.

98
00:04:35.980 --> 00:04:41.120
And in that Master Boot Record, There's
typically going to be a bootloader.

99
00:04:42.180 --> 00:04:46.660
Now what happens from that bootloader then

100
00:04:46.660 --> 00:04:48.670
There's a couple of different things
that's gonna happen once that

101
00:04:48.670 --> 00:04:49.910

102
00:04:49.910 --> 00:04:53.270
But that's the basic steps that
we go through when a BIOS,

103
00:04:53.270 --> 00:04:55.400
a legacy boot system happens.

104
00:04:55.400 --> 00:04:59.280
With EFI it's a little bit different,
with EFI.

105
00:04:59.280 --> 00:05:01.620
EFI isn't entirely stored in a BIOS,

106
00:05:01.620 --> 00:05:05.290
like BIOS is entirely stored

107
00:05:05.290 --> 00:05:07.020
But EFI isn't.

108
00:05:07.020 --> 00:05:10.200
The loader for EFI is stored in
the chip on the motherboard, but

109
00:05:10.200 --> 00:05:14.920
the actual EFI BIOS itself is stored
on your hard drive somewhere, right?

110
00:05:14.920 --> 00:05:15.910
Because it can be big,

111
00:05:15.910 --> 00:05:18.360
it can be way bigger then what
your typical BIOS chips are.

112
00:05:18.360 --> 00:05:20.640
So the EFI loader kicks
in from the motherboard,

113
00:05:20.640 --> 00:05:24.720
and then it looks to the hard drive
to try to find the EFI boot loader.

114
00:05:24.720 --> 00:05:29.160
And once it finds the EFI boot loader,
that's where it knows what drives or

115
00:05:29.160 --> 00:05:30.870
CDs to boot from and
all of that other stuff.

116
00:05:30.870 --> 00:05:33.730
It's a little bit of a different process,
right?

117
00:05:33.730 --> 00:05:35.350
And that's not dependent on Linux.

118
00:05:35.350 --> 00:05:38.530
This would apply to Windows,

119
00:05:38.530 --> 00:05:41.530
But it is a function of your hardware.

120
00:05:41.530 --> 00:05:43.140
Your laptop, your desktop, your server.

121
00:05:43.140 --> 00:05:45.780
They are the ones that make that decision.

122
00:05:45.780 --> 00:05:46.800
Now.

123
00:05:46.800 --> 00:05:50.180
EFI gives us two big
improvements over buyouts.

124
00:05:50.180 --> 00:05:53.010
The biggest improvement is
it's graphically bigger.

125
00:05:53.010 --> 00:05:56.630
We can have graphical screens,
we can have mouse-driven menus and

126
00:05:56.630 --> 00:05:58.490
things without the headaches

127
00:05:58.490 --> 00:06:01.380
The other thing is it gives
us a lot more flexibility.

128
00:06:01.380 --> 00:06:04.680
We can easily add in many,
many operating systems,

129
00:06:04.680 --> 00:06:08.610
many different partitions to boot from,

130
00:06:08.610 --> 00:06:11.120
But the other thing it
gives us is security.

131
00:06:11.120 --> 00:06:12.580
EFI supports Secure Boot.

132
00:06:12.580 --> 00:06:14.850
And what Secure Boot says is,

133
00:06:14.850 --> 00:06:18.750
I will only load bootloaders
that are digitally signed.

134
00:06:20.260 --> 00:06:22.260
And this has created some controversy.

135
00:06:22.260 --> 00:06:25.540

to EFI because of this move.

136
00:06:25.540 --> 00:06:28.870
Because the way the Secure Boot
works is it says

137
00:06:28.870 --> 00:06:31.860
If you're going to load a bootloader,
it has to be digitally signed.

138
00:06:31.860 --> 00:06:34.590
And if somebody modifies the bootloader,
the digital signature doesn't match,

139
00:06:34.590 --> 00:06:35.550

140
00:06:35.550 --> 00:06:40.010

boot record infection, virus protection.

141
00:06:40.010 --> 00:06:42.860
So it really does solve a lot of problems

00:06:43.870 --> 00:06:48.000

the digital signature for

That installation used to be

00:25:43.070 --> 00:25:46.550
But at this stage, if I reboot,
GRUB is now updated.

532
00:25:46.550 --> 00:25:48.790
And so I'm gonna see that
boot loader here in a second.

533
00:25:48.790 --> 00:25:51.270
When you see the VMware screen pop
up in my screen, that'll be BIOS.

534
00:25:51.270 --> 00:25:55.120
And then, once the BIOS screen is gone,
now, here's GRUB.

535
00:25:55.120 --> 00:25:56.010
And I did hiddenmenu.

536
00:25:56.010 --> 00:25:58.800
So that's why I had to press
Enter to see this menu.

537
00:25:58.800 --> 00:26:01.560
But if I hadn't done hidden menu it
would have gone straight to this.

538
00:26:01.560 --> 00:26:03.200
And now I can pick who I want to boot.

539
00:26:04.300 --> 00:26:06.680
And I've got five seconds,
if I don't touch anything,

540
00:26:06.680 --> 00:26:09.150
I've got five seconds before
it just boots CentOS.

541
00:26:09.150 --> 00:26:11.955
But now, because I'm in the menu,
I can take all the time time in the world.

542
00:26:11.955 --> 00:26:13.795
And I can go through here and
I can pick which one I want to boot,

543
00:26:13.795 --> 00:26:14.635
and I can boot to it.

544
00:26:15.855 --> 00:26:19.607
And a lot of modern GRUB versions actually
have where you can modify things.

545
00:26:19.607 --> 00:26:22.165
So see, I can choose Windows 7 and
I can e to edit it.

546
00:26:22.165 --> 00:26:24.575
Or I can choose CentOS and
I can e to edit it.

547
00:26:24.575 --> 00:26:28.045
And now I can go in and
I can modify what drive that distro is on.

548
00:26:28.045 --> 00:26:29.745
Maybe I moved it to another drive.

549
00:26:29.745 --> 00:26:30.805
What kernel it's booting.

550
00:26:30.805 --> 00:26:34.120
Maybe I just didn't update and
GRUB is pointing to the wrong kernel.

551
00:26:34.120 --> 00:26:36.410
You can do things like that,
or I just did an update, and

552
00:26:36.410 --> 00:26:38.860
now I want to point at the old kernel
because something's not working right.

553
00:26:38.860 --> 00:26:40.790
We can go in and we kinda manipulate that.

554
00:26:40.790 --> 00:26:42.920
So you got a few neat
little options there.

555
00:26:42.920 --> 00:26:45.110
But then you choose your OS, and it boots.

556
00:26:46.945 --> 00:26:50.385
The only other thing I wanna mention for
GRUB version 1 is,

557
00:26:50.385 --> 00:26:55.195
if we're running EFI, the command to
install it's a little bit different.

558
00:26:55.195 --> 00:26:55.785
And that's because,

559
00:26:55.785 --> 00:27:00.705
remember that EFI isn't storing everything
in the BIOS chip on the motherboard.

560
00:27:00.705 --> 00:27:03.280
EFI stores part of its
information on the hard drive.

561
00:27:03.280 --> 00:27:05.700
And so, when we go and
enter in this GRUB boot loader, and

562
00:27:05.700 --> 00:27:07.650
we tell what hard drive to boot from and
all that stuff,

563
00:27:07.650 --> 00:27:11.310
we actually have to tell it a little
bit more because it's an EFI system.

564
00:27:11.310 --> 00:27:13.940
And we don't have to wait for
this machine to boot.

565
00:27:13.940 --> 00:27:15.340
Well, it boots pretty fast.

566
00:27:15.340 --> 00:27:18.380
So, when it runs,
we're gonna run a different command.

567
00:27:18.380 --> 00:27:21.240
Before, I ran the grub -install command,
but

568
00:27:21.240 --> 00:27:26.390
with EFI we're gonna use the efi -, or
just efi, boot manager command, and

569
00:27:26.390 --> 00:27:28.960
that let's you change the stuff
if you've got an EFI system.

570
00:27:28.960 --> 00:27:34.860
So if I needed to reinstall GRUB on an EFI
system, the config files are the same.

571
00:27:34.860 --> 00:27:39.205
That doesn't change, but
the command to reinstall GRUB does.

572
00:27:39.205 --> 00:27:43.499
So what I would run is efibootmgr.

573
00:27:43.499 --> 00:27:45.903
And this is what's gonna
let me modify that.

574
00:27:45.903 --> 00:27:50.130
And then I tell it that I'm
gonna be doing a reinstall.

575
00:27:50.130 --> 00:27:51.380
I'm doing a -c -l.

576
00:27:51.380 --> 00:27:53.365
And then here's where it
gets it's a little weird.

577
00:27:53.365 --> 00:27:56.011
Now I've got to point to
where that EFI store is.

578
00:27:56.011 --> 00:28:01.240
And the way EFI does things,
I have to do back slashes and

579
00:28:01.240 --> 00:28:04.243
I've gotten to escape them, so

580
00:28:04.243 --> 00:28:09.475
it's \\EFI\\redhat\\grub.efi -L grub, and

581
00:28:09.475 --> 00:28:16.600
actually I think that one has to be
all caps, let me fix that, there.

582
00:28:16.600 --> 00:28:21.100
So, what I'm doing here is I'm
reaching into that grub.efi file and

583
00:28:21.100 --> 00:28:23.950
reinstalling GRUB there and
putting its information in.

584
00:28:23.950 --> 00:28:26.170
So, it's a little bit
different of a process,

585
00:28:26.170 --> 00:28:29.530
because EFI is storing it's
information in a different place.

586
00:28:29.530 --> 00:28:33.170
And apparently I'm not booted EFI, so
that's why it's not running for me.

587
00:28:33.170 --> 00:28:36.140
But if you go into /boot,
you probably saw this earlier.

588
00:28:36.140 --> 00:28:37.650
I have this EFI directory.

589
00:28:37.650 --> 00:28:42.080
And if we go into EFI,
you'll see there's that capital EFI,

590
00:28:42.080 --> 00:28:45.090
that's what I'm actually
referring to right here.

591
00:28:45.090 --> 00:28:49.210
And then inside of that, I've got redhat,
that's that next folder here.

592
00:28:49.210 --> 00:28:52.778
And inside redhat,
that's where grub.efi is.

593
00:28:52.778 --> 00:28:56.140
And that's a binary file, so if I try and

594
00:28:56.140 --> 00:29:00.540
open that thing up, see how it says it's
a binary file, do I wanna see it anyway?

595
00:29:00.540 --> 00:29:03.550
And if I look at it,
it doesn't help me at all, right?

596
00:29:03.550 --> 00:29:07.630
So a little bit different than when
we're just writing it to a boot record.

597
00:29:07.630 --> 00:29:09.591
We do have to be aware of that.

598
00:29:09.591 --> 00:29:13.703
All right, so that command again,
let me just bring it back up, it was

599
00:29:13.703 --> 00:29:18.373
efibootmgr -c -l, and we point to where
the EFI file is going, and then -L and

600
00:29:18.373 --> 00:29:23.400
the name of the bootloader we're throwing
in there, which is GRUB in this case.

601
00:29:23.400 --> 00:29:25.430
That'll reinstall it on an EFI system.

602
00:29:27.090 --> 00:29:29.830
All right, well, that's GRUB version 1.

603
00:29:29.830 --> 00:29:33.230
I want to take a look at GRUB version 2,
but I kind of talked too long,

604
00:29:33.230 --> 00:29:34.380
didn't I, Daniel?

605
00:29:34.380 --> 00:29:35.250
>> Just a little bit.

606
00:29:35.250 --> 00:29:36.480
But this is a lot of information.

607
00:29:36.480 --> 00:29:39.280
It's not like this is something
we can just gloss over.

608
00:29:39.280 --> 00:29:41.510
We need to give you those kind of details.

609
00:29:41.510 --> 00:29:44.095
It does make for a great part two,
though don't they Don?

610
00:29:44.095 --> 00:29:45.205
>> Yeah, absolutely.

611
00:29:45.205 --> 00:29:46.035
So let's do that.

612
00:29:46.035 --> 00:29:46.945
We'll stop right here.

613
00:29:46.945 --> 00:29:48.215
But we're gonna do a part two.

614
00:29:48.215 --> 00:29:48.915
And in part two,

615
00:29:48.915 --> 00:29:52.205
I wanna take a look at GRUB version 2,
cuz it is very common on distros, right.

616
00:29:52.205 --> 00:29:53.745
We saw it on that Debian 7 system.

617
00:29:53.745 --> 00:29:55.682
We saw it on my CentOS 7 system.

618
00:29:55.682 --> 00:29:57.532
So you wanna know about GRUB version 2.

619
00:29:57.532 --> 00:29:58.492
We'll take a look at it, and

620
00:29:58.492 --> 00:30:02.312
it's config files, and get a chance
to kind of see how it works also.

621
00:30:02.312 --> 00:30:03.442
So stay tuned for that.

622
00:30:03.442 --> 00:30:04.842
>> Yeah.
>> And I think that's about all we got.

623
00:30:04.842 --> 00:30:06.030
>> Yeah, that's about all we have for

624
00:30:06.030 --> 00:30:08.986
GRUB version 1,
hopefully you guys enjoyed that.

625
00:30:08.986 --> 00:30:10.776
When we'll see you on GRUB version two.

626
00:30:10.776 --> 00:30:14.166
Signing off for ITProTV,
I've been your host Daniel Lowery.

627
00:30:14.166 --> 00:30:15.126
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

00:00:21.595 --> 00:00:24.251

11

talked about the boot process in Linux and

12
00:00:34.070 --> 00:00:37.280
And we didn't get to GRUB version 2 and

13
00:00:37.280 --> 00:00:38.981
here we are back again for part two.

14
00:00:38.981 --> 00:00:40.409
>> Well, it's good stuff.

15
00:00:40.409 --> 00:00:42.652
The part one had a lot of
interesting things, and

16
00:00:42.652 --> 00:00:45.236
you still may run into GRUB
version 1 from time to time.

17
00:00:45.236 --> 00:00:47.689
They definitely want you to know it for

18
00:00:47.689 --> 00:00:50.650
there's a good reason to
[LAUGH] watch part one of this.

19
00:00:50.650 --> 00:00:52.226
Part two is probably gonna
be the more practical one.

20
00:00:52.226 --> 00:00:54.403
This is the stuff you're
most likely gonna see,

21
00:00:54.403 --> 00:00:56.602
the GRUB version that
you're gonna encounter.

22
00:00:56.602 --> 00:01:00.649
>> Yep, all right, so I know we did talk
a little bit about GRUB's configuration

23
00:01:00.649 --> 00:01:03.070
files, but let's rehash real quick.

24
00:01:03.070 --> 00:01:08.245
So GRUB, the grand unified bootloader is
a bootloader that is built into Linux.

25
00:01:08.245 --> 00:01:11.728
So, when you push your Power button,
your BIOS, your EFI process kicks in, and

26
00:01:11.728 --> 00:01:13.879
once those fire up,
they locate your hard drive,

27
00:01:13.879 --> 00:01:17.443
they locate where you're gonna boot from,
or your master boot record normally.

28
00:01:17.443 --> 00:01:22.407
And then from there,
they hand over control to your bootloader.

29
00:01:22.407 --> 00:01:24.367
Our bootloader in this case
is gonna be GRUB version 2.

30
00:01:24.367 --> 00:01:28.877
And GRUB version 2 is gonna present
you with a menu of different operating

31
00:01:28.877 --> 00:01:31.581
systems that are available for
you to boot.

32
00:01:31.581 --> 00:01:36.267
>> And in GRUB version 1, those are stored
in just a simple little file, menu.list,

33
00:01:36.267 --> 00:01:38.915
but in GRUB version 2,
it's a lot different.

34
00:01:38.915 --> 00:01:42.622
They moved the configuration files around,
they've changed things.

35
00:01:42.622 --> 00:01:46.852
They've simplified it, but
even when you simplify things,

36
00:01:46.852 --> 00:01:48.532
if you change the commands,
it makes it more challenging.

37
00:01:48.532 --> 00:01:51.952
So, for a lot of people, we had to relearn
GRUB 2, and kind of get used to it.

38
00:01:51.952 --> 00:01:55.530
And that's what I wanna show
you here in this episode.

39
00:01:55.530 --> 00:01:58.960
The first thing, the biggest
difference between GRUB version 2 and

40
00:01:58.960 --> 00:02:02.790
version 1 is the configuration
files are moved.

41
00:02:02.790 --> 00:02:04.900
Let me show you what I mean.

42
00:02:04.900 --> 00:02:07.170
So, here I am on a CentOS 7 machine.

43
00:02:07.170 --> 00:02:13.010
And if I I go into /boot, see how
I've got a grub and a grub2 folder.

44
00:02:13.010 --> 00:02:16.660
Well, GRUB version 2,
it just depends on the distro.

45
00:02:16.660 --> 00:02:20.880
Some distros, like CentOS,
puts it in the grub2 folder.

46
00:02:20.880 --> 00:02:24.250
Other distros, like Debian,
which I've got parked back here,

47
00:02:24.250 --> 00:02:29.300
will put it in the /grub folder,
/boot/grub.

48
00:02:29.300 --> 00:02:31.877
It may or not be in /boot/grub or

49
00:02:31.877 --> 00:02:35.240
/boot/grub2, you just have
to kinda look for it.

50
00:02:35.240 --> 00:02:37.460
It kinda sucks, but that's how it is.

51
00:02:37.460 --> 00:02:40.050
And the way you can tell the difference
between GRUB version 1 and

52
00:02:40.050 --> 00:02:41.750
GRUB version 2 is the config file.

53
00:02:41.750 --> 00:02:46.015
The config file for
GRUB version 2 is grub.cfg.

54
00:02:46.015 --> 00:02:48.800
Remember in version 1,
it's just grub.conf.

55
00:02:48.800 --> 00:02:51.510
So, that's our big difference there,
grub.cfg.

56
00:02:51.510 --> 00:02:55.180
And here on my Red Hat system,
or CentOS system here,

57
00:02:55.180 --> 00:03:00.550
if I get into the grub2 folder,
I'll see grub.cfg right there.

58
00:03:00.550 --> 00:03:06.310
And if I look inside of grub.cfg,
I'm gonna see the second big difference.

59
00:03:06.310 --> 00:03:08.262
It's this line right here.

60
00:03:08.262 --> 00:03:10.781
Do not edit this file.

61
00:03:10.781 --> 00:03:15.266
Remember, if you already watched
our first episode of this, in GRUB,

62
00:03:15.266 --> 00:03:17.528
I just went and edited grub.conf.

63
00:03:17.528 --> 00:03:20.340
Went in, edit it, threw in a new OS,
things worked great.

64
00:03:20.340 --> 00:03:23.560
But here, I get this really big warning,
DO NOT EDIT THIS FILE.

65
00:03:23.560 --> 00:03:24.560
What, are you crazy?

66
00:03:24.560 --> 00:03:26.000
Don't touch this thing!

67
00:03:26.000 --> 00:03:30.040
Well, what they tried [LAUGH] to
do is to make life easier for you.

68
00:03:30.040 --> 00:03:34.890
And GRUB has its own little editor now
that you can use to go in and add OSes and

69
00:03:34.890 --> 00:03:38.860
things like that without having
to go here and edit these files.

70
00:03:38.860 --> 00:03:42.070
And the reason they did that
is because the config file for

71
00:03:42.070 --> 00:03:44.050
GRUB version 2 is much more complex.

72
00:03:45.420 --> 00:03:47.480
When you start to look at this file,

73
00:03:47.480 --> 00:03:51.530
it can be made up of tons
of scriptable options.

74
00:03:52.660 --> 00:03:55.900
And so this is a pretty big file,
mine's at the default.

75
00:03:55.900 --> 00:03:59.550
I haven't touched this one bit
from doing this CentOS 7 install.

76
00:03:59.550 --> 00:04:01.400
There's a lot in here.

77
00:04:01.400 --> 00:04:04.140
And if you make a mistake then
your system's not gonna boot, so

78
00:04:04.140 --> 00:04:06.110
that's kind of important.

79
00:04:06.110 --> 00:04:10.337
So, instead of loading everything from
here, what's happening is this file is

80
00:04:10.337 --> 00:04:14.328
being assembled for us, and that's what
this very next line is telling us.

81
00:04:14.328 --> 00:04:16.907
It's saying, DON'T EDIT THIS FILE.

82
00:04:16.907 --> 00:04:21.675
That's a no, no.
Instead, you want to edit any file

83
00:04:21.675 --> 00:04:25.242
inside of /etc/grub.d.

84
00:04:25.242 --> 00:04:30.582
And anything that's in this
particular file, /etc/default.grub.

85
00:04:30.582 --> 00:04:34.326
This file is one file, /etc/default/grub,

86
00:04:34.326 --> 00:04:39.130
that's the default grub configuration for
a system.

87
00:04:39.130 --> 00:04:44.000
So, that's what it bases,
grub.cfg on, is this file right here.

88
00:04:44.000 --> 00:04:49.840
And then it takes any file you've
defined inside of /etc/grub.d and

89
00:04:49.840 --> 00:04:54.480
it adds that onto it, and
it builds the grub.cfg file for us, and

90
00:04:54.480 --> 00:04:57.680
it does a lot of error checking and
validation before it does it.

91
00:04:57.680 --> 00:05:02.610
And it helps save you a situation where
you've created a grub file that won't

92
00:05:02.610 --> 00:05:05.690
boot, but you don't notice it
until you reboot next time.

93
00:05:05.690 --> 00:05:09.800
Here we'll know right away, because we
modify these files, and when we're done

94
00:05:09.800 --> 00:05:14.720
we execute a command to build grub.cfg.

95
00:05:14.720 --> 00:05:16.550
Now, watch out for this one.

96
00:05:16.550 --> 00:05:17.850
Here's another one where
you think all right,

97
00:05:17.850 --> 00:05:21.300
well I've got one command that builds it,
well you don't.

98
00:05:21.300 --> 00:05:26.379
Here on this CentOS 7 box,
I've got grub2-mkconfig.

99
00:05:26.379 --> 00:05:31.372
On other distros,
they might just call it grub-mkconfig.

100
00:05:31.372 --> 00:05:36.355
Remember just like the folder, where
it might be in grub2, it might not be.

101
00:05:36.355 --> 00:05:40.015
This is another example, although,
with this grub-mkconfig.

102
00:05:40.015 --> 00:05:45.064
So, if I jump over to my Debian
system here, and I run grub-mkconfig,

103
00:05:45.064 --> 00:05:49.152
or if I run grub2 like that,
command not found.

104
00:05:49.152 --> 00:05:55.177
But I if take out that 2, right, and maybe
I do like a --help, command not found.

105
00:05:55.177 --> 00:05:57.452
Uh-oh, now we're in real trouble, right?

106
00:05:57.452 --> 00:05:59.022
I don't have either
version of this command.

107
00:05:59.022 --> 00:06:02.147
Well, why stop at one command,
when you can have a third one.

108
00:06:02.147 --> 00:06:06.380
So, there is actually yet
another version of this command,

109
00:06:06.380 --> 00:06:09.543
which is update-grub, and if you run that.

110
00:06:09.543 --> 00:06:12.433
[LAUGH] Oh, crap,
I didn't get it there either.

111
00:06:12.433 --> 00:06:14.750
There is a fourth one we can
try which is update-grub2.

112
00:06:15.990 --> 00:06:18.230
I must not have installed them, all right.

113
00:06:18.230 --> 00:06:21.650
Well, those are the four, I'm out of
other commands, there is a bunch.

114
00:06:21.650 --> 00:06:24.436
So, you do have to do a little bit of
trial and error to find out which one,

115
00:06:24.436 --> 00:06:26.846
exactly, it is that's gonna be
needed to build your system.

116
00:06:26.846 --> 00:06:31.746
And so, it might be grub-mkconfig,
it might be grub2-mkconfig,

117
00:06:31.746 --> 00:06:35.907
it might be update-grub, or
it might be update-grub2.

118
00:06:35.907 --> 00:06:39.019
And it's really unfortunate that
the different distros have chosen

119
00:06:39.019 --> 00:06:41.610
different names for this,
but that's how it is.

120
00:06:41.610 --> 00:06:44.320
And that's why a lot of
them do what Red Hat did,

121

which is to put it right

451
00:23:48.090 --> 00:23:51.908
And if I look inside of my init,
I don't have a dedicated http and

452
00:23:51.908 --> 00:23:56.749
that's because it's just adding it to
the default configuration for upstart.

453
00:23:56.749 --> 00:23:59.315
I don't have to write the scripts anymore.

454
00:23:59.315 --> 00:24:03.140
And there's another neat command,
I really like this one,

455
00:24:03.140 --> 00:24:06.270
which is chkconfig--list, all right.

456
00:24:06.270 --> 00:24:07.570
And if I pull up my list,

457
00:24:07.570 --> 00:24:10.340
here's all the services that
are set to start on my computer.

458
00:24:10.340 --> 00:24:13.840
Most of these don't have scripts and
I can see their run level status.

459
00:24:14.980 --> 00:24:20.020
So if I can find httpd in this list, here
it is, and I can see each run level and

460
00:24:20.020 --> 00:24:24.850
see how it's set to run on 2, 3, 4 and 5.

461
00:24:24.850 --> 00:24:26.520
Now, I did 2, 3, 5.

462
00:24:26.520 --> 00:24:31.177
The reason here is I ran
the chkconfig httpd on command, and

463
00:24:31.177 --> 00:24:34.880
the default is 2, 3, 4 and 5.

464
00:24:34.880 --> 00:24:38.550
And then I followed it up with
chkconfig -- level 2, 3, 5.

465
00:24:38.550 --> 00:24:42.210
Well, what that did, is it just added 2,
3, 5, it didn't take it away 4, so

466
00:24:42.210 --> 00:24:42.910
that's why I've got that one.

467
00:24:42.910 --> 00:24:44.770
So I need to remove 4
if I didn't want that.

468
00:24:44.770 --> 00:24:48.700
But I can see the run levels that it's set
to fire up on, and it's all right here.

469
00:24:48.700 --> 00:24:51.305
I don't have to go digging through
those config scripts and so on.

470
00:24:51.305 --> 00:24:52.905
It's just a lot easier to work with.

471
00:24:52.905 --> 00:24:54.465
That's what upstart was all about.

472
00:24:54.465 --> 00:24:57.935
If you make things easier,
mistakes become less likely, right?

473
00:24:57.935 --> 00:25:02.485
I'm not gonna have a typo in some script
cuz I just ran a command to do it.

474
00:25:02.485 --> 00:25:05.325
>> Now Don, if I wanted to turn off
one of those services would I just use

475
00:25:05.325 --> 00:25:10.210
the chkconfig off or and then give the run
levels as well or whatever that is?

476
00:25:10.210 --> 00:25:12.610
>> Yeah, if you wanted to turn it off for
a particular run level.

477
00:25:12.610 --> 00:25:16.105
So I want to get rid of that 4, so

478
00:25:16.105 --> 00:25:21.161
I would say chkconfig
-- level 4 httpd off.

479
00:25:21.161 --> 00:25:23.995
If I just say chkconfig httpd off,
it turns it off for

480
00:25:23.995 --> 00:25:28.390
all run levels, but if I do level 4 off,
now it's just gonna be off for level 4.

481
00:25:28.390 --> 00:25:32.310
And if I pull that list up, and

482
00:25:32.310 --> 00:25:35.400
I go in here, see how it's off for
4 but it's still on for 2, 3 and 5.

483
00:25:35.400 --> 00:25:39.010
So really easy to manipulate those levels,
no scripting involved, right.

484
00:25:39.010 --> 00:25:44.960
Now when I reboot, or when I change run
levels, init will run and see this.

485
00:25:44.960 --> 00:25:46.680
But that service is not running right now.

486
00:25:46.680 --> 00:25:50.420
I'm not running a web server until I
start it myself or I change run levels.

487
00:25:50.420 --> 00:25:55.320
So I could do a service httpd start and
it will start that one up.

488
00:25:55.320 --> 00:25:56.330
So there it goes.

489
00:25:56.330 --> 00:25:58.550
Going to boot it up and
now the service is running.

490
00:25:58.550 --> 00:26:01.530
Or if I change run levels it
would have fired up, okay?

491
00:26:01.530 --> 00:26:04.370
But yeah,
that's the thing about System V Init and

492
00:26:04.370 --> 00:26:08.290
even Upstart, it really only does
it work when you change run levels.

493
00:26:08.290 --> 00:26:11.390
If you're not changing run levels it
just sits there and it doesn't recognize

494
00:26:11.390 --> 00:26:15.240
things, like the fact that I turned
that service on, that doesn't happen.

495
00:26:15.240 --> 00:26:17.839
That's one of its bigger limitations.

496
00:26:17.839 --> 00:26:21.278
All right, let's see, is there anything
else I want to mention on this guy?

497
00:26:21.278 --> 00:26:26.850
One other thing that you
might see are rc.d files.

498
00:26:26.850 --> 00:26:32.771
When I went into /etc,
there was a folder in here,

499
00:26:32.771 --> 00:26:36.370
this guy, rc.d, all right?

500
00:26:36.370 --> 00:26:40.100
That's for that initialization,
and we went into rc.

501
00:26:40.100 --> 00:26:43.280
You may have other folders for
each run level.

502
00:26:43.280 --> 00:26:45.490
See how I've got rc0 through rc6.d?

503
00:26:45.490 --> 00:26:47.870
Well, see how all mine are light blue?

504
00:26:47.870 --> 00:26:50.180
They're all symlinked, right?

505
00:26:50.180 --> 00:26:57.030
If I do a ls-la rc?.d, there we go.

506
00:26:57.030 --> 00:27:01.190
See how they're all symlinked and they're
all just kind of pointing to rc.d right?

507
00:27:01.190 --> 00:27:03.810
And then a single thing underneath there.

508
00:27:03.810 --> 00:27:06.318
So they may be symlinked,
the reason those symlinks are there is for

509
00:27:06.318 --> 00:27:08.608
backwards compatibility
with the old Sys V Init.

510
00:27:08.608 --> 00:27:11.920
Sys V Init, if you wanted to have
those separate scripts you could, and

511
00:27:11.920 --> 00:27:14.210
here it's just symlinking to
put them all in one place.

512
00:27:14.210 --> 00:27:16.180
Upstart was all about tidying house,
right?

513
00:27:16.180 --> 00:27:18.880
Cleaning up, doing a little spring
cleaning, getting it organized and

514
00:27:18.880 --> 00:27:20.585
minimizing the mistakes that we make.

515
00:27:20.585 --> 00:27:23.280
So there's very little resistance to
Upstart, you see it out there a lot.

516
00:27:23.280 --> 00:27:27.570
It's not much different than the System V
Init cuz you have full compatibility, but

517
00:27:27.570 --> 00:27:30.300
the configuration is more simple,
the commands make it easier.

518
00:27:30.300 --> 00:27:32.970
It is a really nice one and
you just see it very commonly.

519
00:27:32.970 --> 00:27:37.230
Here, I'm on CentOS 6.5, and it was the
default all the way up through CentOS 6.6.

520
00:27:37.230 --> 00:27:40.212
>> Yeah, that's awesome for
users like me, right?

521
00:27:40.212 --> 00:27:40.724
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

522
00:27:40.724 --> 00:27:42.490
>> Where I'm not great about the scripting

523
00:27:42.490 --> 00:27:44.920
language and everything like that,
I just need to be able to get in there and

524
00:27:44.920 --> 00:27:45.940
make my changes.

525
00:27:45.940 --> 00:27:49.380
Upstart, if I am running
a Debian type of system, or

526
00:27:49.380 --> 00:27:52.480
something that's running Upstart,
it's gonna do a lot of help for

527
00:27:52.480 --> 00:27:55.310
me being able to say, well,
these are the services I wanna start and

528
00:27:55.310 --> 00:27:58.910
I don't wanna get dirty doing it,
I just want it to work.

529
00:27:58.910 --> 00:28:00.420
And that's a lot helpful.

530
00:28:00.420 --> 00:28:01.260
>> Yeah, absolutely.

531
00:28:01.260 --> 00:28:04.110
All right.
>> Well Don, have we done this thing?

532
00:28:04.110 --> 00:28:05.250
With this system five?

533
00:28:05.250 --> 00:28:10.610
I mean it's a lot of information out
there, and definitely, it's a hot topic.

534
00:28:10.610 --> 00:28:12.645
But that's not the only game in town.

535
00:28:12.645 --> 00:28:13.400
>> Yeah, stay tuned for

536
00:28:13.400 --> 00:28:15.690
part two of this episode because
we're gonna dive into system D and

537
00:28:15.690 --> 00:28:17.370
that's where the controversy begins.

538
00:28:17.370 --> 00:28:18.270
So check that one out.

539
00:28:18.270 --> 00:28:19.670
It's definitely important to be aware of.

540
00:28:19.670 --> 00:28:21.910
Even if you hate system D,
you gotta know if for the exams.

541
00:28:21.910 --> 00:28:23.810
So definitely, definitely watch that.

542
00:28:23.810 --> 00:28:24.380
>> That's right.
So

543
00:28:24.380 --> 00:28:27.210
guys gets your best
flames ready at ITProTV.

544
00:28:27.210 --> 00:28:30.910
But it is time to sign off, so
I've been your host Daniel Lowrie.

545
00:28:30.910 --> 00:28:31.850
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

546
00:28:31.850 --> 00:28:33.174
>> And we'll see you next time.

547
00:28:33.174 --> 00:28:38.970
