episodes.title: systemd Initialization Process
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.724
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:10.724 --> 00:00:11.820
All right everyone.

3
00:00:11.820 --> 00:00:15.050
Greetings and welcome to another
great episode of ITProTV.

4
00:00:15.050 --> 00:00:17.030
I'll be your host, Daniel Lawrey and

5
00:00:17.030 --> 00:00:20.160
with me today is the Linux man himself,
Mr. Don Pezet.

6
00:00:20.160 --> 00:00:21.230
How's it going, Don?

7
00:00:21.230 --> 00:00:22.730
>> It is going great.

8
00:00:22.730 --> 00:00:25.930
Normally this is the part where I say I'm
excited about our great Linux Plus Show

9
00:00:25.930 --> 00:00:29.680
lineup, but this is kind of a show
that I've been dreading because of

10
00:00:29.680 --> 00:00:34.610
the amount of controversy that
centers around this topic.

11
00:00:34.610 --> 00:00:37.820
>> Should we have worn our fire retardant
clothes with all the flames that

12
00:00:37.820 --> 00:00:38.945
might come our way.

13
00:00:38.945 --> 00:00:40.660
[LAUGH]
>> So today we're gonna be talking about

14
00:00:40.660 --> 00:00:45.220
System D, and
System D is one of those things that on

15
00:00:46.370 --> 00:00:49.380
the Internet, people have very,
very extreme opinions on it.

16
00:00:49.380 --> 00:00:52.230
Some people love it,
think it's the greatest thing ever.

17
00:00:52.230 --> 00:00:56.429
Some people hate it and wish it would
die and go away and not be used.

18
00:00:58.370 --> 00:01:01.678
This is a big topic and
it's something we need to be aware of.

19
00:01:01.678 --> 00:01:06.700
I'm not gonna get judgemental or anything
on that and talk about it like that.

20
00:01:06.700 --> 00:01:09.130
Let's just focus on the facts,
because it's on the exam.

21
00:01:09.130 --> 00:01:12.220
So whether you like it or not,
it's on the exam, you gotta know it.

22
00:01:12.220 --> 00:01:16.890
So System D is an alternative
initialization process.

23
00:01:16.890 --> 00:01:20.130
It's designed to replace
the System V init.

24
00:01:20.130 --> 00:01:24.840
So, if you remember, when you push power
on your computer, your BIOS kicks in, or

25
00:01:24.840 --> 00:01:26.570
EFI kicks in, right?

26
00:01:26.570 --> 00:01:29.660
And then they locate the part of your
drive that has your boot loader, and

27
00:01:29.660 --> 00:01:31.030
your boot loader kicks in.

28
00:01:31.030 --> 00:01:33.210
And the boot loader then finds
your operating system and

29
00:01:33.210 --> 00:01:36.140
it finds your Linux kernel,
and it turns that on.

30
00:01:36.140 --> 00:01:40.100
And your kernel then
creates an init RAM disk.

31
00:01:40.100 --> 00:01:42.180
And that RAM disk,
it loads some tools in there and

32
00:01:42.180 --> 00:01:44.480
it starts to initialize the system.

33
00:01:44.480 --> 00:01:50.102
Now for years, most people used
the old Unix System V init, all right?

34
00:01:50.102 --> 00:01:52.249
Which was found in /sbin/init.

35
00:01:52.249 --> 00:01:54.302
That's been around forever.

36
00:01:54.302 --> 00:02:00.210
In the last decade, we saw a new
initialization come out called Upstart.

37
00:02:00.210 --> 00:02:03.937
And Upstart was 100% compatible
with System V init and

38
00:02:03.937 --> 00:02:07.280
it made some improvements upon it, right?

39
00:02:07.280 --> 00:02:10.893
But deep down inside,
it really is still just System V init.

40
00:02:10.893 --> 00:02:13.940
It's just improved upon and
added a lot of new functionality.

41
00:02:13.940 --> 00:02:18.955
System D is really the first time
where in the mainstream people said,

42
00:02:18.955 --> 00:02:24.830
let's ditch System V init and
replace it with something else entirely.

43
00:02:24.830 --> 00:02:27.240
And people love their systems,

44
00:02:27.240 --> 00:02:31.370
they love them to work the way they
expected them to for over 30 years.

45
00:02:31.370 --> 00:02:33.750
And to have change like that,
yeah, it's gonna be controversial.

46
00:02:33.750 --> 00:02:34.425
>> It's heresy, Don.

47
00:02:34.425 --> 00:02:36.180
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah, so some people are really,

48
00:02:36.180 --> 00:02:37.290
really opposed to it.

49
00:02:37.290 --> 00:02:39.505
But, let's focus on the good things,
right?

50
00:02:39.505 --> 00:02:41.303
If you don't have anything good to say
you, shouldn't say anything at all.

51
00:02:41.303 --> 00:02:43.209
So let's say some good things, right?

52
00:02:43.209 --> 00:02:44.565
Well, we'll say some bad things.

53
00:02:44.565 --> 00:02:45.285
We'll do that too, right?

54
00:02:45.285 --> 00:02:47.769
What's wrong with System D?

55
00:02:47.769 --> 00:02:49.743
It's different than System V init, right?

56
00:02:49.743 --> 00:02:50.346
>> How dare you?

57
00:02:50.346 --> 00:02:51.036
[LAUGH]
>> I know.

58
00:02:51.036 --> 00:02:53.857
So, what that means though is
that if you've written scripts,

59
00:02:53.857 --> 00:02:56.993
if you've written things that depend
on the old System V init process,

60
00:02:56.993 --> 00:02:59.040
they don't work under System D.

61
00:02:59.040 --> 00:03:01.210
If you rely on things like run levels,

62
00:03:01.210 --> 00:03:03.590
well you don't have run
levels under System D.

63
00:03:03.590 --> 00:03:08.010
So that kind of functionality is gone,
and you gotta find a new way to do it.

64
00:03:08.010 --> 00:03:10.480
And, that takes work.

65
00:03:10.480 --> 00:03:13.380
And that's what a lot of people don't
like is they don't like to change stuff

66
00:03:13.380 --> 00:03:17.790
that worked fine before to a new
system just for that, right?

67
00:03:17.790 --> 00:03:19.270
So, what are the good things?

68
00:03:19.270 --> 00:03:21.780
What would motivate me to
want to go with System D?

69
00:03:21.780 --> 00:03:24.760
Well, there's some neat
stuff that it does.

70
00:03:24.760 --> 00:03:28.615
First off, it breaks up the configuration
for how these things are done.

71
00:03:28.615 --> 00:03:31.330
Remember that System V init,
all of its configuration,

72
00:03:31.330 --> 00:03:35.080
all the scripting that it did,
was in one big fat file.

73
00:03:35.080 --> 00:03:37.990
And some distros broke that out,
like what Upstart does,

74
00:03:37.990 --> 00:03:41.010
broke it out into individual files,
that made it a little easier to manage.

75
00:03:41.010 --> 00:03:45.610
But System D breaks it apart even more,
and makes it super clean,

76
00:03:45.610 --> 00:03:48.180
super tidy, really easy to work with.

77
00:03:48.180 --> 00:03:49.960
So, it's much neater.

78
00:03:49.960 --> 00:03:51.540
That's nice, right?

79
00:03:51.540 --> 00:03:56.050
The other thing is System V init at
the end of the day is really a script.

80
00:03:56.050 --> 00:03:57.050
It's a script.

81
00:03:57.050 --> 00:04:00.180
And when you run a script,
how does a script work?

82
00:04:00.180 --> 00:04:04.301
It runs each command one after the other,
right?

83
00:04:04.301 --> 00:04:07.020
System V init is a linear boot process.

84
00:04:07.020 --> 00:04:11.310
You go in a straight line, one after
another, and that means it's slow.

85
00:04:11.310 --> 00:04:14.630
Even if you love System V init,
it is slow.

86
00:04:14.630 --> 00:04:17.310
And, we've probably all bumped into
this as some point or another.

87
00:04:17.310 --> 00:04:21.120
If you do a Linux install and
whatever chucklehead made that distro,

88
00:04:21.120 --> 00:04:25.260
turned on send mail by default and
has it doing reverse DNS lookups, and

89
00:04:25.260 --> 00:04:27.020
you're not plugged into a network.

90
00:04:27.020 --> 00:04:29.200
And all the sudden your boot sits
there and it stops for a minute and

91
00:04:29.200 --> 00:04:31.670
a half while it does 3 30 second retries.

92
00:04:31.670 --> 00:04:32.820
Pull my hair out when that happens.

93
00:04:32.820 --> 00:04:35.330
What idiot configured this thing.

94
00:04:35.330 --> 00:04:37.185
It's the idiots who make the distros.

95
00:04:37.185 --> 00:04:38.570
>> [LAUGH]
>> So that happens, and

96
00:04:38.570 --> 00:04:39.310
it's really annoying.

97
00:04:39.310 --> 00:04:41.900
And while that's happening,
your system is idle.

98
00:04:41.900 --> 00:04:43.390
Nothing else is happening.

99
00:04:43.390 --> 00:04:47.190
Your DNS lookup is happening, and
Sendmail is holding up that boot.

100
00:04:48.330 --> 00:04:51.130
With System D, it's not a script.

101
00:04:51.130 --> 00:04:51.790
It's a binary.

102
00:04:51.790 --> 00:04:52.870
It's a program.

103
00:04:52.870 --> 00:04:54.420
System D is a program.

104
00:04:54.420 --> 00:04:58.550
And when it runs, it sees all
the things that it needs to launch, and

105
00:04:58.550 --> 00:05:00.440
it can do more than one at once.

106
00:05:00.440 --> 00:05:04.335
And so, if you're running a web server,
and a mail server, and

107
00:05:04.335 --> 00:05:07.958
a database server,
it can start all three at the same time.

108
00:05:07.958 --> 00:05:11.091
And if one gets hung up, big deal,
it moves on at starting the other one.

109
00:05:11.091 --> 00:05:14.354
So now when Sendmail is hung up because
some chucklehead configured it to

110
00:05:14.354 --> 00:05:17.140
expect a network connection by default,
that's fine.

111
00:05:17.140 --> 00:05:18.980
Your other services continue to start.

112
00:05:18.980 --> 00:05:20.870
You get to a command prompt and
now you can kill it and

113
00:05:20.870 --> 00:05:22.840
then go and update that configuration.

114
00:05:22.840 --> 00:05:24.970
So, it's a lot faster, right?

115
00:05:26.390 --> 00:05:31.060
Whether you love it or hate it, System D
is absolutely faster than System V init.

116
00:05:31.060 --> 00:05:33.330
Unless your system is tuned
to exact perfection and

117
00:05:33.330 --> 00:05:37.520
you're only running a couple of things,
System D will almost always be faster.

118
00:05:37.520 --> 00:05:38.560
And that was its goal.

119
00:05:38.560 --> 00:05:43.490
They wanted it to be easier to use,
wanted it to be tidier, cleaner and

120
00:05:43.490 --> 00:05:47.500
simpler, and
they want it to be faster, all right?

121
00:05:47.500 --> 00:05:48.470
The other thing is,

122
00:05:48.470 --> 00:05:52.840
System D was updated to fix a big
problem that we have in System V init.

123
00:05:52.840 --> 00:05:55.310
System V init, it's a script.

124
00:05:55.310 --> 00:05:58.670
A script that only runs
when you change run levels.

125
00:05:58.670 --> 00:06:02.270
Well, there's things that happen
on our system where we need init,

126
00:06:02.270 --> 00:06:04.350
even when we're not changing run levels.

127
00:06:04.350 --> 00:06:08.150
So System D said, forget it,
let's just ditch these run levels, and

128
00:06:08.150 --> 00:06:10.600
let's just monitor
the system all the time.

129
00:06:10.600 --> 00:06:13.236
And so System D's running all the time,
and that is great for

130
00:06:13.236 --> 00:06:16.340
situations where you have
things like hot plug hardware.

131
00:06:16.340 --> 00:06:19.450
System V init in its original form
didn't support hot plug hardware.

132
00:06:19.450 --> 00:06:23.502

plug hard drive, it wouldn't detect it.

133
00:06:23.502 --> 00:06:26.330

a run level change for

134
00:06:26.330 --> 00:06:28.248
it to run in script to detect
the hardware then add it.

135
00:06:28.248 --> 00:06:32.140
And so, OSs added that support,
like Upstart added it or

136
00:06:32.140 --> 00:06:34.690
Debian added their work around to
be able to detect the hardware.

137
00:06:34.690 --> 00:06:36.350
Well System D is always running.

138
00:06:36.350 --> 00:06:38.580
So when you add that new hardware,
it says Oh, new hardware.

139
00:06:38.580 --> 00:06:39.940
What should I do about that?

140
00:06:39.940 --> 00:06:42.480
And then it takes an action based
on it and it has the hardware and

141
00:06:42.480 --> 00:06:43.500
makes it available.

142
00:06:43.500 --> 00:06:46.249
So, System D is running all the time.

143
00:06:46.249 --> 00:06:47.271
Some people don't like that.

144
00:06:47.271 --> 00:06:50.661
They're like, hey, I like that
System V runs and then goes away, and

145
00:06:50.661 --> 00:06:51.879
just runs when I need it.

146
00:06:51.879 --> 00:06:54.308
But the problem is sometimes it
doesn't run when you need it,

147
00:06:54.308 --> 00:06:56.987
whereas System D is always running,
so it is there when you need it.

148
00:06:56.987 --> 00:07:01.562
If you've got low resources, if you're
still running a 286 with 4 megs of RAM,

149
00:07:01.562 --> 00:07:03.117
that's terrible, right?

150
00:07:04.300 --> 00:07:07.310
But on modern hardware it's
a negligible amount of overhead.

151
00:07:07.310 --> 00:07:10.230
So the people that complain about that
are normally people that are running on

152
00:07:10.230 --> 00:07:12.660
embedded systems where
that still is important.

153
00:07:12.660 --> 00:07:16.160
And in that scenario, System V init
might be the better choice for you.

154
00:07:16.160 --> 00:07:20.280
So, the people that don't like System D,
don't just discount them out of hand.

155
00:07:20.280 --> 00:07:22.240
Some of them have a legitimate concern and

00:07:22.240 --> 00:07:24.410
a reason why System D is not good for
them.

157
00:07:24.410 --> 00:07:27.350
But for the majority of users,
System D is really good.

And so, you have Red Hat,

00:07:33.800 --> 00:07:35.240

Well, that means it's pretty good, right?

00:07:46.568 --> 00:07:49.320
So it is a good system,

00:07:49.320 --> 00:07:51.019
it is a lot simpler to work with.

00:07:51.019 --> 00:07:55.244

It's definitely easier for

00:08:08.590 --> 00:08:11.710

00:08:11.710 --> 00:08:14.420

00:08:15.550 --> 00:08:18.300

00:08:18.300 --> 00:08:22.310
First off the name, it's called systemd
because they followed the Demon naming

00:08:22.310 --> 00:08:23.870
system or the service naming system for

179
00:08:23.870 --> 00:08:27.700
Linux which is you have an all lowercase
name followed by the letter d.

180
00:08:27.700 --> 00:08:30.010
And so systemd,
that's where the name came from.

181
00:08:30.010 --> 00:08:33.570
And normally when our boot loader
fires up and our kernel fires up,

182
00:08:33.570 --> 00:08:37.090
the next thing it runs is /bin /init.

00:08:37.090 --> 00:08:41.550
Well that's a function of the kernel, not

00:08:41.550 --> 00:08:44.440
So systemd actually hooks on to that.

00:08:44.440 --> 00:08:47.089
You can recognize if you've got

00:08:47.089 --> 00:08:48.250

00:08:48.250 --> 00:08:52.592

00:08:59.920 --> 00:09:04.144

00:09:12.230 --> 00:09:17.879

00:09:17.879 --> 00:09:21.207

00:09:24.140 --> 00:09:27.170
So it's pretty easy to

00:09:27.170 --> 00:09:29.640

00:09:29.640 --> 00:09:33.900

00:09:33.900 --> 00:09:39.060

00:09:39.060 --> 00:09:41.334

00:09:41.334 --> 00:09:44.380

00:09:44.380 --> 00:09:46.490

203
00:09:46.490 --> 00:09:48.592
Let's talk about two terms really quick.

204
00:09:48.592 --> 00:09:51.640
When systemd fires up,
it's looking for two things.

205
00:09:51.640 --> 00:09:55.366
It's looking for units and targets.

206
00:09:55.366 --> 00:09:59.028
In system V init you just have scripts and
executables and that's it.

207
00:09:59.028 --> 00:10:02.970
But in systemd you have units

208
00:10:02.970 --> 00:10:07.130
which are various things that can happen
on your system at any given time.

209
00:10:07.130 --> 00:10:10.017
And then you have targets which
are just groups of units.

210
00:10:10.017 --> 00:10:12.690
There's some units you need
to happen at the same time,

211
00:10:12.690 --> 00:10:15.890
and if you need that you group
them together into a target.

212
00:10:15.890 --> 00:10:20.210
And when you call that target, all
the units inside of it fire up at the same

213
00:10:20.210 --> 00:10:22.460
time or they're dependent on each other.

214
00:10:22.460 --> 00:10:24.950
We got to do a dependency
check on all this stuff.

215
00:10:24.950 --> 00:10:27.770
Because one program might
depend on another and

216
00:10:27.770 --> 00:10:29.510
they've got to be started in that order.

217
00:10:29.510 --> 00:10:32.340
We used to be able to handle that
because you wrote the script and so

218
00:10:32.340 --> 00:10:34.680
you put things in order in the script.

219
00:10:34.680 --> 00:10:36.910
Well in systemd you
don't have that script.

220
00:10:36.910 --> 00:10:42.640
So instead when you define each unit you
define the other units that it depends on.

221
00:10:42.640 --> 00:10:45.960
And then systemd figures out
the best order to run it in.

222
00:10:45.960 --> 00:10:52.500
And it'll say all right, this SSHD depends
on something else like agetty or whatever.

223
00:10:52.500 --> 00:10:57.335
And it'll say let's run the TTY
service first and then we'll run SSHD.

224
00:10:57.335 --> 00:10:59.160
It'll put it in order.

225
00:10:59.160 --> 00:11:01.570
So it figures all that out for us.

226
00:11:01.570 --> 00:11:08.770
And it does that through its configuration
which is mostly in /lib/systemd.

227
00:11:08.770 --> 00:11:14.240
If you browse to /lib/systemd and take a
look in there you'll see a bunch of stuff.

228
00:11:14.240 --> 00:11:16.110
And most of these are executables.

229
00:11:16.110 --> 00:11:20.410
And so when you look in here the systemd
executable, that's the main one.

230
00:11:20.410 --> 00:11:26.130
But then there's all of this other stuff
like systemd activate or bootchart, fsck.

231
00:11:27.140 --> 00:11:30.610
Systemd can do a lot
more than run scripts.

232
00:11:30.610 --> 00:11:33.180
Systemd can check your hard drive for
errors.

233
00:11:33.180 --> 00:11:37.670
Systemd can initialize
the journaling on your file system.

234
00:11:37.670 --> 00:11:39.800
It's really powerful.

235
00:11:39.800 --> 00:11:41.920
And this there's a good thing and
a bad thing.

236
00:11:41.920 --> 00:11:44.780
It's good in that system gets
a lot of stuff in it and

237
00:11:44.780 --> 00:11:46.140
make sure that the OS
doesn't have to do it.

238
00:11:46.140 --> 00:11:50.310
And my complaint about all these distros
doing things different ways, goes away.

00:11:50.310 --> 00:11:52.810
If it's a systemd system,
I know how it does it.

00:11:52.810 --> 00:11:58.020
But the other side of that argument is

00:11:58.020 --> 00:11:59.870
giving it to a servers

00:12:00.950 --> 00:12:04.660
And I don't think that's

00:12:04.660 --> 00:12:07.090
because you can still do the same things,

00:12:07.090 --> 00:12:08.070
Here's my quota check.

I do it differently here than I

00:12:11.860 --> 00:12:16.090
So different kind of variations

00:12:16.090 --> 00:12:17.640
Inside of this folder,

00:12:17.640 --> 00:12:22.310
inside of /lib/systemd,

00:12:22.310 --> 00:12:27.210
And I get inside of that folder so

00:12:27.210 --> 00:12:28.950

00:12:33.670 --> 00:12:38.430
Now, there are a number of

00:12:38.430 --> 00:12:40.240

00:12:41.590 --> 00:12:46.419
When I configure something like if I wanna

00:12:46.419 --> 00:12:48.770
server service, httpd.service.

00:12:48.770 --> 00:12:53.051
Let's see, I don't know if I am one oh I

so I'm a web server.

But services aren't the only type of unit.

00:12:59.630 --> 00:13:01.077
Here, I've got mount.

00:13:01.077 --> 00:13:05.320
When I mount a hard drive to a folder or

00:13:05.320 --> 00:13:08.490
I mount a volume to a path on the system.

00:13:08.490 --> 00:13:10.650
Well that's a mount target.

00:13:10.650 --> 00:13:14.100

00:13:14.100 --> 00:13:16.858
You'll see,

00:13:16.858 --> 00:13:21.360
So in system V we have udev.

00:13:21.360 --> 00:13:24.097
And udev would run in assign

00:13:26.684 --> 00:13:30.610

00:13:53.970 --> 00:13:56.270

00:13:56.270 --> 00:13:58.600

00:14:33.380 --> 00:14:35.680
So you'll see a lot of

00:14:35.680 --> 00:14:39.030
But at the end of the day,

00:14:39.030 --> 00:14:42.930

00:14:46.680 --> 00:14:52.010

00:15:13.630 --> 00:15:16.880

Well the network target includes

00:15:26.760 --> 00:15:29.660

If I'm mounting remote file

00:15:32.830 --> 00:15:35.280

00:15:35.280 --> 00:15:37.380

00:15:46.210 --> 00:15:48.384
So wait for

00:15:48.384 --> 00:15:51.264
Wait for nss lookups to kick in.

00:15:51.264 --> 00:15:54.618
Wait for those and then start httpd.

00:15:54.618 --> 00:15:57.939
And then we can see information

00:15:57.939 --> 00:15:59.274
We do a type notify.

Let us know rather it works or

00:16:01.625 --> 00:16:04.360

00:16:04.360 --> 00:16:06.780
Including how we execute it.

00:16:13.689 --> 00:16:14.760

00:16:25.020 --> 00:16:27.820

That program has its own config files and

00:16:30.740 --> 00:16:34.510

00:16:34.510 --> 00:16:37.830
And then, if I want to do those things, if

00:16:37.830 --> 00:16:42.400

00:16:48.910 --> 00:16:52.550

00:16:52.550 --> 00:16:54.820

00:16:54.820 --> 00:16:58.280

00:16:58.280 --> 00:17:04.240

00:17:13.460 --> 00:17:15.000

00:17:15.000 --> 00:17:17.410

00:17:17.410 --> 00:17:18.700

00:17:18.700 --> 00:17:21.840

00:17:21.840 --> 00:17:24.530

00:17:39.720 --> 00:17:42.330

And I refer to it as httpd here but

it'll find it.

00:18:03.560 --> 00:18:09.720
But, in theory,

00:18:09.720 --> 00:18:12.580
and I could have a mount unit

00:18:12.580 --> 00:18:15.680
Maybe I have a path that
I've called httpd, and

00:18:15.680 --> 00:18:17.900
I've got a service called httpd,
and in that case,

00:18:17.900 --> 00:18:21.900
I would need to make sure that I specified
what type of unit it was, all right?

366
00:18:21.900 --> 00:18:26.010
So that makes it fairly easy to work
with and at the end of the day,

00:18:26.010 --> 00:18:33.630
I install my services, they get added
right there in my /lib/systemd/system and

00:18:33.630 --> 00:18:36.410
it says what they depend on, it says
how to start them, how to stop them.

00:18:36.410 --> 00:18:38.230
I don't have to go modify scripts.

370
00:18:38.230 --> 00:18:41.740
And as far as run levels are concerned,
I don't really need those anymore.

371
00:18:41.740 --> 00:18:44.140
When it fires up,
it's defining what to go into.

372
00:18:44.140 --> 00:18:46.740
If I don't want a GUI, I go in and

373
00:18:46.740 --> 00:18:52.390
I modify the graphical unit,
which is usually the default one.

374
00:18:52.390 --> 00:18:53.960
There is a default unit,

375
00:18:53.960 --> 00:18:57.720
I'm glad I kinda mentioned that offhand,
that you'll spot in here.

376
00:18:57.720 --> 00:18:59.210
Let's see if I can find it.

377
00:18:59.210 --> 00:19:01.578
Here, you've got this default.target.

378
00:19:01.578 --> 00:19:04.090
Okay?
And default.that target,

00:19:04.090 --> 00:19:08.870
right here, says when I boot up,
what's my default grouping of units?

00:19:08.870 --> 00:19:10.810
What units do I wanna start?

00:19:10.810 --> 00:19:15.290
And if I want a different run levels,

00:19:15.290 --> 00:19:16.300
different groupings.

00:19:16.300 --> 00:19:20.270
One grouping might include the GUI,

Here on CentOS the default of that target

00:19:24.690 --> 00:19:26.220
Let me show you what I mean.

00:19:26.220 --> 00:19:29.305
If I do default.target.

00:19:29.305 --> 00:19:30.870
There we go.

00:19:30.870 --> 00:19:34.160
See how default.target is
symlinked to graphical.target?

00:19:34.160 --> 00:19:36.420
That would be like run level
five under system 5, right?

390
00:19:36.420 --> 00:19:39.710
With multi user width and
graphical user interface.

391
00:19:39.710 --> 00:19:43.040
But if you look in here
there's another one which

392
00:19:43.040 --> 00:19:44.990
I've forgotten what it's name is.

393
00:19:44.990 --> 00:19:46.980
Let me see if I can find it.

394
00:19:46.980 --> 00:19:50.549
I think it's console.target.

395
00:19:50.549 --> 00:19:53.470
I can't remember the name of it but
there is another target

00:19:53.470 --> 00:19:56.600
that is one that just boots to
a command line instead of GUI.

397
00:19:56.600 --> 00:20:00.730
So I would just sim link the default
target to be that other one and

00:20:00.730 --> 00:20:03.650
point it and now it's gonna load up and
I won't have a GUI.

399
00:20:03.650 --> 00:20:04.570
So you can find those

400
00:20:04.570 --> 00:20:07.040
in your different systems defined
them a little bit differently.

401
00:20:07.040 --> 00:20:11.880
But you can spot on them and kinda pick
the one that you need for your system.

402
00:20:11.880 --> 00:20:15.800
So, is it easier than System 5?

403
00:20:15.800 --> 00:20:16.970
I think so.

404
00:20:16.970 --> 00:20:18.730
It's a lot easier to work with.

405
00:20:18.730 --> 00:20:19.720
Is it faster?

406
00:20:19.720 --> 00:20:20.610
Absolutely.

407
00:20:20.610 --> 00:20:23.410
Because it's not running synchronously,
it's running asynchronously.

408
00:20:23.410 --> 00:20:26.910
It can start all these targets and
units along the dependencies.

409
00:20:26.910 --> 00:20:30.040
But it can do more than
one at the same time.

410
00:20:30.040 --> 00:20:34.570
So it can move forward in an order
that's different than System 5 init.

411
00:20:34.570 --> 00:20:35.720
That makes it faster.

412
00:20:35.720 --> 00:20:37.310
Is it a lot more powerful?

413
00:20:37.310 --> 00:20:38.600
Absolutely.

414
00:20:38.600 --> 00:20:39.570
Is is a lot more different?

415
00:20:40.720 --> 00:20:42.100
Super absolutely, right?

416
00:20:42.100 --> 00:20:43.790
And that's where a lot of
this resistance comes from.

417
00:20:45.890 --> 00:20:46.670
All right.
I feel like I'm

418
00:20:46.670 --> 00:20:48.760
forgetting something important
that I wanna to talk about.

419
00:20:48.760 --> 00:20:49.260
Shoot.

420
00:20:51.000 --> 00:20:52.190
I guess maybe that's it.

421
00:20:52.190 --> 00:20:55.330
Yeah.
One of the term that you might see batted

422
00:20:55.330 --> 00:20:59.646
about on the exam is that System D
is considered to be monolithic.

423
00:20:59.646 --> 00:21:00.665
All right?

424
00:21:00.665 --> 00:21:02.910
System 5, when it ran,

425
00:21:02.910 --> 00:21:06.670
it was one big script then they
could call smaller scripts.

426
00:21:06.670 --> 00:21:09.070
So it was made up of multiple pieces.

427
00:21:09.070 --> 00:21:11.150
System D, is a program.

428
00:21:11.150 --> 00:21:14.319
So at the end of the day,
all boils down to one executable,

429
00:21:14.319 --> 00:21:16.175
the System D executable.

430
00:21:16.175 --> 00:21:18.815
And so it's considered monolithic,
one piece.

431
00:21:18.815 --> 00:21:22.555
If systemd were to crash,
your system would stop working, right?

432
00:21:22.555 --> 00:21:24.785
It's that critical to the system.

433
00:21:24.785 --> 00:21:27.945
Whereas init, the old SystemVinit,
it can't crash.

434
00:21:27.945 --> 00:21:28.585
It's just a script.

435
00:21:28.585 --> 00:21:30.335
The script stops running, and runs again.

436
00:21:30.335 --> 00:21:30.925
Fine, whatever.

437
00:21:30.925 --> 00:21:33.570
The kernel doesn't depend
on it like System D does.

438
00:21:33.570 --> 00:21:37.720
So it does become a more
essential part of your system and

439
00:21:37.720 --> 00:21:38.640
some people don't like that.

440
00:21:38.640 --> 00:21:41.510
And this is another area where
some of that controversy comes in.

441
00:21:41.510 --> 00:21:44.410
>> Yeah, it's a reluctant to change
out there which is interesting

442
00:21:44.410 --> 00:21:48.330
to me coming from the Linux community
because their all about being different.

443
00:21:48.330 --> 00:21:51.160
Their all about pushing the envelope,
doing different things.

444
00:21:51.160 --> 00:21:55.210
So it is interesting to see that, hey
this is the way we've always done it so

445
00:21:55.210 --> 00:21:56.580
don't move away from that.

446
00:21:56.580 --> 00:21:58.040
But as you can see,

447
00:21:58.040 --> 00:22:02.390
it's a really good idea to do that, this
is gonna be beneficial down the road, and

448
00:22:02.390 --> 00:22:06.390
the more people that jump on board
to that way of thinking for Linux,

449
00:22:06.390 --> 00:22:10.950
it's gonna help Linux keep growing in
the market share and things like that, and

450
00:22:10.950 --> 00:22:16.656
being used more by regular end users,
not so much just in the server club.

451
00:22:16.656 --> 00:22:17.710
>> Yeah.

452
00:22:17.710 --> 00:22:18.900
We had a question in the forum.

453
00:22:18.900 --> 00:22:22.030
I sort of answered this earlier, but
let me go a little more in depth.

454
00:22:22.030 --> 00:22:23.770
About the wants option, right?

455
00:22:23.770 --> 00:22:27.230
When we take a look at a unit,
I'll pull up sshd.

456
00:22:29.060 --> 00:22:30.830
So like ssh, right?

00:22:30.830 --> 00:22:34.030
When the ssh demon starts,
I can find it right here.

458
00:22:34.030 --> 00:22:35.470
Right?
It's got a unit defined for it,

459
00:22:35.470 --> 00:22:37.310
there's the open ssh server.

460
00:22:37.310 --> 00:22:41.970
And it's got this wants
the sshd.keygen.service.

461
00:22:41.970 --> 00:22:44.690
Wants is different than after, okay?

462
00:22:44.690 --> 00:22:49.490
After means these other guys,
they've gotta be started before me, right?

463
00:22:49.490 --> 00:22:51.630
I've gotta have these
things started before me.

464
00:22:51.630 --> 00:22:54.227
So it's gonna start network.target, and

465
00:22:54.227 --> 00:22:57.325
it's gonna start sshd-keygen.service,
okay?

466
00:22:57.325 --> 00:23:02.070
But then I've got wants also, and
I've got that same key gen service.

467
00:23:02.070 --> 00:23:03.310
What does that mean?

468
00:23:03.310 --> 00:23:07.250
Well, what it means is once sshd is up and

469
00:23:07.250 --> 00:23:12.880
running, you could actually stop the key
gen service and sshd would keep running.

470
00:23:12.880 --> 00:23:13.770
It'll keep running.

471
00:23:13.770 --> 00:23:17.380
It actually it wants that other
service to be running but

472
00:23:17.380 --> 00:23:19.850
it doesn't truly depend on it.

473
00:23:19.850 --> 00:23:23.580
And so by adding this once
in like this It says hey,

474
00:23:23.580 --> 00:23:28.880
if the sshd key gen service stops,
stop this one too, stop sshd.

475
00:23:28.880 --> 00:23:32.970
Because even though it will technically
still run, it won't actually work.

476
00:23:32.970 --> 00:23:35.880
If your key gen service is not running
when somebody connects you can't generate

477
00:23:35.880 --> 00:23:38.180
a session key, you're not gonna connect.

478
00:23:38.180 --> 00:23:39.620
So take this one down too.

479
00:23:39.620 --> 00:23:46.230
So it's kind of a a more true dependency,
something we absolutely have to have.

480
00:23:46.230 --> 00:23:47.910
Versus like the network target.

481
00:23:47.910 --> 00:23:52.500
If the network target were to stop, and
network were to go off-line, I can still

482
00:23:52.500 --> 00:23:57.500
use ssh from the local console to my own
system, you can still do it other ways.

483
00:23:57.500 --> 00:24:01.090
And so that one doesn't necessarily
get thrown in as a want.

484
00:24:01.090 --> 00:24:02.380
But you'll see that.

485
00:24:02.380 --> 00:24:04.890
And then there's this WantedBy down here.

486
00:24:04.890 --> 00:24:07.930
If we've got the multi-user target,
for example,

487
00:24:07.930 --> 00:24:12.620
that that one will initialize sshd,
at least that one's in here.

488
00:24:12.620 --> 00:24:13.470
Some of these wanted bys,

489
00:24:13.470 --> 00:24:16.010
you can actually leave them out by
accident and it still works just fine.

490
00:24:16.010 --> 00:24:18.040
It's just kinda one of those things.

491
00:24:18.040 --> 00:24:21.520
But, by having it properly defined
you get a proper hierarchy.

492
00:24:21.520 --> 00:24:24.930
And services know when to start and
stop based on their dependencies, so.

493
00:24:24.930 --> 00:24:26.030
>> Very cool, Don.

494
00:24:26.030 --> 00:24:29.570
Well, obviously, System D is,
like you said, it's very powerful.

495
00:24:29.570 --> 00:24:35.250
It's very easier to use,
comparing it to that old System 5 in it.

496
00:24:35.250 --> 00:24:38.360
Now if you're entrenched in System
5 in it, you love System 5,

497
00:24:38.360 --> 00:24:40.460
that's fine there's
nothing wrong with that.

498
00:24:40.460 --> 00:24:43.010
But System D is probably
the wave of the future.

499
00:24:43.010 --> 00:24:47.610
So for us as new Linux users, if you're
just getting into Linux, this is gonna be

500
00:24:47.610 --> 00:24:51.320
what you're gonna get your teeth on and
not the other way around.

501
00:24:51.320 --> 00:24:53.490
>> Well I mean,
let's say you're a big Red Hat shop.

00:24:53.490 --> 00:24:54.900
And you got all red hat servers.

00:24:54.900 --> 00:24:57.430
If you're running red
hat enterprise Lenox 6.

00:24:57.430 --> 00:25:02.340
Whatever then you're on upstart,
the variation of System 5 init.

00:25:02.340 --> 00:25:06.300
But when you upgrade to scint OS 7 or
Red Hat 7, it's System D.

00:25:06.300 --> 00:25:10.490
And they don't give you an easy way

00:25:10.490 --> 00:25:13.010
You get some basic compatibility but

00:25:13.010 --> 00:25:14.610
so you now have a choice.

00:25:14.610 --> 00:25:18.400
Do I just stay with six for the rest
of the duration of the server's life or

00:25:18.400 --> 00:25:19.650
do I go to seven and embrace System D?

00:25:19.650 --> 00:25:21.450
They kind of force that choice on you.

512
00:25:21.450 --> 00:25:24.240
And you're gonna see a lot of
distros do that over time,

00:25:24.240 --> 00:25:27.090
unless the community rebels, which is

00:25:27.090 --> 00:25:28.870
why Debian is still in System 5 init, so.

515
00:25:28.870 --> 00:25:29.860
>> That's right.

00:01:18.180 --> 00:01:22.520

00:01:22.520 --> 00:01:23.380

00:01:24.532 --> 00:01:26.010

00:01:26.010 --> 00:01:30.110

00:01:30.110 --> 00:01:32.736

00:01:32.736 --> 00:01:36.770

00:01:36.770 --> 00:01:39.300

00:01:39.300 --> 00:01:41.383

00:01:41.383 --> 00:01:44.887

00:01:44.887 --> 00:01:47.740

00:23:00.310 --> 00:23:01.400
>> Very cool.

447
00:23:01.400 --> 00:23:03.850
Now this is a very convenient thing.

448
00:23:03.850 --> 00:23:08.431
I mean I'll be honest here, I did not
know we could do this with Linux.

449
00:23:08.431 --> 00:23:11.460
>> [LAUGH]
>> This is one of the coolest features

450
00:23:11.460 --> 00:23:14.160
I'm probably gonna be
switching back to Linux.

451
00:23:14.160 --> 00:23:15.460
[LAUGH]
>> People are always excited

452
00:23:15.460 --> 00:23:18.380
about this you know, and maybe it's not
a matter of switching back to Linux,

453
00:23:18.380 --> 00:23:21.530
maybe sometimes you need Linux but
most of the time you need Mac OS or

454
00:23:21.530 --> 00:23:23.110
most of the time you need Windows.

455
00:23:23.110 --> 00:23:26.890
well you could have your native
applications running in a Linux VM,

456
00:23:26.890 --> 00:23:31.060
and you could launch them in a native
window in your main desktop OS.

457
00:23:31.060 --> 00:23:34.030
You could have Windows or
Mac OS running those Linux apps.

458
00:23:34.030 --> 00:23:37.970
So you could certainly do that, and
now you're not switching between VMs,

459
00:23:37.970 --> 00:23:40.120
there just windows sitting
right there in one desktop,

460
00:23:40.120 --> 00:23:41.670
so that's kind of the power of it.

461
00:23:41.670 --> 00:23:42.750
>> I like it.
I like it a lot.

462
00:23:42.750 --> 00:23:44.720
Hopefully you guys out
there are enjoying this.

463
00:23:44.720 --> 00:23:48.260
This is one of the coolest features
I've ever seen on just about

464
00:23:48.260 --> 00:23:49.930
any operating system.

465
00:23:49.930 --> 00:23:51.780
Just super cool.

466
00:23:51.780 --> 00:23:52.355
I'm flabbergasted.

467
00:23:52.355 --> 00:23:53.569
[LAUGH]
>> You know,

468
00:23:53.569 --> 00:23:56.655
another good question there in
the chatroom was I launched a web browser,

469
00:23:56.655 --> 00:23:57.915
I launched Firefox, right?

470
00:23:57.915 --> 00:24:00.571
And the question in the chatroom was well,
what about DNS hookups,

471
00:24:00.571 --> 00:24:01.698
where are those happening?

472
00:24:01.698 --> 00:24:06.960
Well, it's Firefox doing the DNS hookup
and Firefox is running from that server.

473
00:24:06.960 --> 00:24:08.790
So that's where it's all happening.

474
00:24:08.790 --> 00:24:10.250
I don't even have to
have a default gateway or

475
00:24:10.250 --> 00:24:14.110
DNS servers defined on my client because
everything's happening from the server.

476
00:24:14.110 --> 00:24:17.660
So you might have a web filtering software
package installed on that server and

477
00:24:17.660 --> 00:24:20.430
that's all gonna take effect cuz
it's all happening over there.

478
00:24:20.430 --> 00:24:23.090
All I'm seeing,
think of this as like a television set.

479
00:24:23.090 --> 00:24:26.490
I'm just watching stuff that's happening
on a different server somewhere else.

480
00:24:26.490 --> 00:24:28.810
100% of it is happening
on that other server.

481
00:24:28.810 --> 00:24:32.440
>> Yeah, and that's a very important thing
to understand, is what's going on here is

482
00:24:32.440 --> 00:24:35.520
that, like Don said, everything
is happening on the other server.

483
00:24:35.520 --> 00:24:39.840
So let's say you fired up that Wireshark
and you want use it to sniff network,

484
00:24:39.840 --> 00:24:43.910
you're gonna be using that server's
Ethernet interfaces to sniff on.

485
00:24:43.910 --> 00:24:47.400
Its not gonna be your local machine,
your not gonna be looking at local files.

486
00:24:47.400 --> 00:24:52.051
Just think of it as a normal SSH
connection really like SSHed into this

487
00:24:52.051 --> 00:24:54.950
just normal shell prompt and I didn't LS.

488
00:24:54.950 --> 00:24:56.372
Its not gonna show me my files,

489
00:24:56.372 --> 00:24:59.530
its gonna show me its files
because I'm remotely connected.

490
00:24:59.530 --> 00:25:03.820
Same concept, we're just looking at
graphics instead of a shell prompt.

491
00:25:03.820 --> 00:25:05.580
And that's pretty cool.

492
00:25:05.580 --> 00:25:08.850
>> And then at the end of the day when
you're done you close your windows down.

493
00:25:08.850 --> 00:25:11.230
So I close these applications,
get them out there.

494
00:25:11.230 --> 00:25:13.950
And then we just terminate the shell.

495
00:25:13.950 --> 00:25:17.050
So here my shell actually got some
little information coming back.

496
00:25:17.050 --> 00:25:19.140
Oh, this must be tied to that
Firefox error that I saw.

497
00:25:19.140 --> 00:25:20.980
I'll ignore that error then.

498
00:25:20.980 --> 00:25:22.900
[LAUGH] We can ignore old Firefox.

499
00:25:22.900 --> 00:25:25.634
But when you're done at the end of
the day, you close your Windows and

500
00:25:25.634 --> 00:25:26.740
then you get out of SSH.

501
00:25:26.740 --> 00:25:31.200
Now, normally when I get out of SSH,
I just type exit and it knocks right out.

502
00:25:31.200 --> 00:25:34.440
This time when I run,
see how it's taking a little while?

503
00:25:34.440 --> 00:25:36.970
It's gotta close down all
those X tunnels that it made.

504
00:25:36.970 --> 00:25:38.920
And so it's closing each one of those,

505
00:25:38.920 --> 00:25:42.290
and it'll take a little longer to
close that SSH session than normal.

506
00:25:42.290 --> 00:25:43.120
And that's gonna close down.

507
00:25:43.120 --> 00:25:45.187
If I'd done this while
the Windows were open,

508
00:25:45.187 --> 00:25:48.536
the windows would be disappearing right
now, I closed mine ahead of mine.

509
00:25:48.536 --> 00:25:49.970
Just kind of use that.

510
00:25:49.970 --> 00:25:52.640
But bam, that's it,
it goes away, problem's gone, and

511
00:25:52.640 --> 00:25:55.530
now you're back to just running stuff
right here from your own machine.

512
00:25:55.530 --> 00:25:57.780
>> Very cool stuff, Tom, very cool stuff.

513
00:25:57.780 --> 00:25:58.490
That being said,

514
00:25:58.490 --> 00:26:03.210
have we hopefully you guys have learned
something here today that is going to

515
00:26:03.210 --> 00:26:07.365
help you do a lot of neat stuff and
maybe even impress your friends, right?

516
00:26:07.365 --> 00:26:10.462
[LAUGH] I know it impressed me,
that's the good stuff.

517
00:26:10.462 --> 00:26:13.110
All right Don,
the end of this show, though huh?

518
00:26:13.110 --> 00:26:14.490
We've finally wrapped it up?

519
00:26:14.490 --> 00:26:15.770
>> Yep, let's wrap this one up.

520
00:26:15.770 --> 00:26:19.100
And then make sure to stay tuned, we got
a little bit more on X Windows to go into,

521
00:26:19.100 --> 00:26:21.550
we're gonna tackle accessibility
features that are there, right?

522
00:26:21.550 --> 00:26:23.330
We need to make sure we know that for
the exam.

523
00:26:23.330 --> 00:26:27.350
And then we'll switch back to the nice
comfort of the command line interface as

524
00:26:27.350 --> 00:26:29.300
we move through the rest
of the exam objectives.

525
00:26:29.300 --> 00:26:30.020
>> Awesome stuff.

526
00:26:30.020 --> 00:26:33.180
All right everybody out there,
I hope you've enjoyed this episode.

527
00:26:33.180 --> 00:26:34.640
We really had a good time making it.

528
00:26:34.640 --> 00:26:37.110
That being said,
it is time to sign off for ITProTV.

529
00:26:37.110 --> 00:26:39.850
I've been your host Daniel Lowry,
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

530
00:26:39.850 --> 00:26:41.240
>> And we'll see you next time.

531
00:26:41.240 --> 00:26:47.150

episodes.title: X Accessibility
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.305
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:10.305 --> 00:00:15.280
All right, greetings everyone and welcome
to another great episode of ITProTv.

3
00:00:15.280 --> 00:00:19.025
I'll be your host Daniel Lowry and
here with me today is the man, the myth,

4
00:00:19.025 --> 00:00:21.766
the legend that is Don Pezet
how's it going today Don?

5
00:00:21.766 --> 00:00:23.571
>> You know when you set up
these expectations Daniel,

6
00:00:23.571 --> 00:00:24.604
it's hard to live up to them.

7
00:00:24.604 --> 00:00:29.573
>> I like to watch you crumble [LAUGH]
>> Here's my failure captured on video.

8
00:00:29.573 --> 00:00:34.206
Well, I'm excited to be here we're jumping
back into another episode of Linux Plus,

9
00:00:34.206 --> 00:00:38.330
and today we're gonna be taking a look
at the accessibility features found in

10
00:00:38.330 --> 00:00:41.610
the X Windows graphical user interface for
Linux.

11
00:00:41.610 --> 00:00:44.961
Now accessibility is kind of
a generic umbrella term for

12
00:00:44.961 --> 00:00:49.178
any kind of assistive technology
that helps somebody use a computer.

13
00:00:49.178 --> 00:00:52.970
You know when people design software,
and Linux is no exception to this,

14
00:00:52.970 --> 00:00:55.734
they design it for
the most common use case scenario.

15
00:00:55.734 --> 00:01:00.615
So you expect somebody to have
full use of motor skills, visual,

16
00:01:00.615 --> 00:01:05.587
auditory skills, have ten fingers,
just normal typical usage,

17
00:01:05.587 --> 00:01:10.300
but not everybody fits that
standard use case scenario.

18
00:01:10.300 --> 00:01:14.230
There are many people out there,
an unfortunate large amount of people,

19
00:01:14.230 --> 00:01:17.440
that aren't able to use
computers the normal method.

20
00:01:17.440 --> 00:01:19.720
For example,
you might be visually impaired, and

21
00:01:19.720 --> 00:01:23.520
so does it matter that you've got
a nice screen arrangement of icons,

22
00:01:23.520 --> 00:01:27.890
if you can't see them right, or
you might have auditory issues, and

23
00:01:27.890 --> 00:01:31.440
that sound, the warning bell that
let's you know you just got an email.

24
00:01:31.440 --> 00:01:34.308
That's not very effective anymore,
because you can't hear that.

25
00:01:34.308 --> 00:01:37.593
If you have Parkinson's Disease,
which is really,

26
00:01:37.593 --> 00:01:40.526
its unfortunate how
common that's becoming.

27
00:01:40.526 --> 00:01:44.659
Parkinson's disease can make it very
difficult to type on a keyboard, and so

28
00:01:44.659 --> 00:01:48.931
for people like that, you don't want them
just not to be able to use a computer.

29
00:01:48.931 --> 00:01:53.036
You just need them to be able to use the
computer a little bit differently, and so

30
00:01:53.036 --> 00:01:57.204
the X Windows user and interface has a
number of different add-ons that make that

31
00:01:57.204 --> 00:02:00.635
possible, that kind of facilitate
being able to use the system for

32
00:02:00.635 --> 00:02:02.437
nonstandard use case scenarios.

33
00:02:02.437 --> 00:02:07.761
Now, as an administrator, you may not
need these technologies yourself right,

34
00:02:07.761 --> 00:02:09.857
but you need to be aware of them.

35
00:02:09.857 --> 00:02:13.073
So that as you work with other employees,
and people in your company,

36
00:02:13.073 --> 00:02:16.359
that you're able to help them get
the full benefit out of the computer.

37
00:02:16.359 --> 00:02:20.663
And let me tell you guys out of all the
work that I've done, there is nothing more

38
00:02:20.663 --> 00:02:24.003
rewarding than helping somebody
to be able to use a computer,

39
00:02:24.003 --> 00:02:28.177
to be able to reach out there and connect
to services that we take for granted,

40
00:02:28.177 --> 00:02:30.320
that they have to work a lot harder for.

41
00:02:30.320 --> 00:02:32.780
And so anything that we can
do to make that easier, or

42
00:02:32.780 --> 00:02:36.150
just to facilitate that in general it's
something we really should do, right.

43
00:02:36.150 --> 00:02:39.860
So it's a great thing and it is something
that even if you don't care about it,

44
00:02:39.860 --> 00:02:43.424
you still have to know for the exams,
so you wanna learn one way or another.

45
00:02:43.424 --> 00:02:47.614
But, as a good administrator, you should
always be sensitive of everybody's needs,

46
00:02:47.614 --> 00:02:51.027
and know that not everybody uses
the computer the same way, all right.

47
00:02:51.027 --> 00:02:55.693
Now, regardless of whether you're running
the Gnome graphical user interface, or

48
00:02:55.693 --> 00:03:00.290
KDE, or Enlightenment, or any of
the number of UIs that are out there.

49
00:03:00.290 --> 00:03:03.970
They almost all have accessibilities
features built in, and

50
00:03:03.970 --> 00:03:06.660
sometimes they're really obvious,
sometimes they're kind of hidden away.

51
00:03:06.660 --> 00:03:11.940
Let me show you as an example here if
I take, let me take a CentOS 6 system.

52
00:03:11.940 --> 00:03:15.140
So here I've got a CentOS 6 system,
and if I log out.

53
00:03:15.140 --> 00:03:16.240
Let me just log out of this.

54
00:03:17.850 --> 00:03:21.830
When I'm at the log in screen for
CentOS 6, so here's my log in screen, and

55
00:03:21.830 --> 00:03:25.076
I can see my name and
other users I can pick from and so on.

56
00:03:25.076 --> 00:03:31.040
Down here in my little taskbar,
see that little person?

57
00:03:31.040 --> 00:03:33.490
It's a white stick
figure in a blue circle.

58
00:03:33.490 --> 00:03:35.915
That's the accessibility button, and

59
00:03:35.915 --> 00:03:40.703
if I click on that I get this nice little
popup of universal access preferences.

60
00:03:40.703 --> 00:03:44.589
These are tools that I can use to
facilitate the use of the computer if I

61
00:03:44.589 --> 00:03:45.320
need this.

62
00:03:45.320 --> 00:03:49.860
Now if someone is, say visually impaired,
and they're going to use this system,

63
00:03:49.860 --> 00:03:51.420
are they gonna see that button?

64
00:03:51.420 --> 00:03:51.950
No.

65
00:03:51.950 --> 00:03:55.080
Are they gonna see these
entries here on screen?

66
00:03:55.080 --> 00:03:57.180
No, and that's where as an administrator,

67
00:03:57.180 --> 00:04:00.270
it's up to us to make sure that
computer is prepared for them.

68
00:04:00.270 --> 00:04:04.180
So they say hey, I need a computer and I
need it to support a screen reader, right.

69
00:04:04.180 --> 00:04:06.940
I need it to read out loud,
what's on the screen so

70
00:04:06.940 --> 00:04:08.990
I can hear it, instead of seeing it.

71
00:04:08.990 --> 00:04:11.490
Well, we just need to turn that on and
you'll see the option right here,

72
00:04:11.490 --> 00:04:12.770
view screen reader.

73
00:04:12.770 --> 00:04:16.927
And if we turn that on now, when something
appears on the screen it's not just,

74
00:04:16.927 --> 00:04:19.795
something that we can't see and
that's the end of it.

75
00:04:19.795 --> 00:04:23.461
It's actually gonna read it out loud and
let us know, and mine's thinking.

76
00:04:23.461 --> 00:04:27.185
Sometimes it has to download some voices
to get ready, and enable other systems, so

77
00:04:27.185 --> 00:04:28.760
it's gonna kind of pause.

78
00:04:28.760 --> 00:04:33.680
But you'll see each of these provides
some different kind of functionality, and

79
00:04:33.680 --> 00:04:36.580
that's going to be
enabling that to happen.

80
00:04:36.580 --> 00:04:39.100
I might have my speakers set wrong
cuz I'm not actually hearing it.

81
00:04:39.100 --> 00:04:42.070
Normally once the screenreader's on,
you actually start to hear it.

82
00:04:42.070 --> 00:04:44.830
You'll see things like,
use the on screen keyboard.

83
00:04:44.830 --> 00:04:47.420
Okay, why would I want
an on screen keyboard,

84
00:04:47.420 --> 00:04:49.420
if I've got a keyboard right here?

85
00:04:49.420 --> 00:04:52.640
Well, the keyboard that's right in front
of you is expecting you to be able to

86
00:04:52.640 --> 00:04:54.030
press multiple keys.

87
00:04:54.030 --> 00:04:56.810
It's expecting a ten fingered typer.

88
00:04:56.810 --> 00:05:01.740
Well, if you are a quadriplegic and
you're using a mouth pointer to type,

89
00:05:01.740 --> 00:05:04.410
a traditional keyboard is not
really set up very well for that.

90
00:05:04.410 --> 00:05:07.300
So an on screen keyboard
might be easier to use,

91
00:05:07.300 --> 00:05:09.940
or maybe you've got just mouse control and

92
00:05:09.940 --> 00:05:13.240
not keyboard control and you can use
a mouse to type on a non-screen keyboard.

93
00:05:13.240 --> 00:05:14.811
You can't use a mouse to
type on a physical keyboard.

94
00:05:14.811 --> 00:05:19.151
It's a little awkward to press the keys,
so you've got that functionality,

95
00:05:19.151 --> 00:05:23.619
we can turn that on, and now I'll get
the on-screen keyboard to be able to type,

96
00:05:23.619 --> 00:05:27.394
right, and that functionality
there is pretty handy, all right.

97
00:05:27.394 --> 00:05:30.039
Now, let me close this one, or here,

98
00:05:30.039 --> 00:05:34.430
we'll just move it out of the way for
me here, all right.

99
00:05:34.430 --> 00:05:36.780
So, with each of these
accessibility options,

100
00:05:36.780 --> 00:05:40.080
they're all addressing
different use case scenarios.

101
00:05:40.080 --> 00:05:42.850
For the exam you need to familiarize
yourself with each one, right.

102
00:05:42.850 --> 00:05:45.530
An on screen keyboard can help
with somebody whose having to do

103
00:05:45.530 --> 00:05:47.180
point typing, right.

104
00:05:47.180 --> 00:05:50.320
Screen reader can help for
somebody whose visually impaired.

105
00:05:50.320 --> 00:05:51.880
The screen magnifier.

106
00:05:51.880 --> 00:05:53.750
Now, when we talk about
visual impairments,

107
00:05:53.750 --> 00:05:56.120
we could be talking about
full clinical blindness.

108
00:05:56.120 --> 00:05:57.880
They cannot see the screen.

109
00:05:57.880 --> 00:06:01.030
We need auditory cues from that,
but it could be that

110
00:06:01.030 --> 00:06:04.190
it's not that they're clinically blind,
but that they just have an impairment.

111
00:06:04.190 --> 00:06:07.860
They have reduced vision, tunnel vision,
things of that nature, and so we could use

112
00:06:07.860 --> 00:06:13.470
a screen magnifier to make portions of the
screen bigger, to highlight those areas

113
00:06:13.470 --> 00:06:16.970
and make it easier to read for someone who
might not have the clearness of vision.

114
00:06:18.110 --> 00:06:22.380
You can turn on contrasting colors,
that makes things stand out a lot more.

115
00:06:22.380 --> 00:06:26.720
There's an unfortunate design, not ethic.

116
00:06:26.720 --> 00:06:27.729
What is it design,

117
00:06:27.729 --> 00:06:31.715
I don't know, something that people are
following, thanks to the fine people at

118
00:06:31.715 --> 00:06:36.640
Apple who think it's beautiful to have
light gray text on a white background.

119
00:06:36.640 --> 00:06:38.770
I hate it.
It's the dumbest thing on the planet.

120
00:06:38.770 --> 00:06:40.630
It looks nice, but
you can't read anything.

121
00:06:40.630 --> 00:06:43.450
So when you choose
enhanced contrast colors,

122
00:06:43.450 --> 00:06:46.420
see how it's starting to make
things a little more stark?

123
00:06:46.420 --> 00:06:48.670
The text is being set
out a lot more clearly,

124
00:06:48.670 --> 00:06:53.290
I've got nice black text on this brownish
background now versus what I said,

125
00:06:53.290 --> 00:06:55.750
which was white text on
a light blue background.

126
00:06:55.750 --> 00:06:57.880
That's not exactly easy to read.

127
00:06:57.880 --> 00:06:59.990
So that's another quick change.

128
00:06:59.990 --> 00:07:02.200
We can make text larger.

129
00:07:02.200 --> 00:07:06.721
This is kinda like the magnifier, except
now it's making all of my text larger.

130
00:07:06.721 --> 00:07:10.805
You can do keyboard shortcuts
one key at a time, all right.

131
00:07:10.805 --> 00:07:14.200
Now I wanna put you in a scenario, right.

132
00:07:14.200 --> 00:07:18.663
Imagine you are in terminal, and
you wanna open up a new tab, and

133
00:07:18.663 --> 00:07:22.974
you've gotta do Ctrl+Shift+T
to open up a new tab, right.

134
00:07:22.974 --> 00:07:26.656
So, we hit Ctrl+Shift+T and
it opens up a new tab and terminal.

135
00:07:26.656 --> 00:07:30.436
Well, if you've got full use of both
hands, that works out great, but

136
00:07:30.436 --> 00:07:34.594
if you've got one hand it's kinda hard
to hit Ctrl+Shift+T if you contort,

137
00:07:34.594 --> 00:07:36.927

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don explore localization in Linux operating systems. They begin by explaining the concept of localization, which is the regional settings for your system; including language, numbering, and symbol characters. Then they show you how to see what your system's localization is set to and the file encoding being employed. Finally they show you how to make changes to your system's localization settings from the terminal.

00:07:59.379 --> 00:08:02.296

00:08:02.296 --> 00:08:03.212

00:08:03.212 --> 00:08:05.661

00:08:05.661 --> 00:08:10.660

146
00:08:10.660 --> 00:08:14.740

147
00:08:14.740 --> 00:08:17.590

files from one computer to another.

148
00:08:17.590 --> 00:08:19.951
And so they started standardizing
on things like ASCII,

149
00:08:19.951 --> 00:08:21.758
the ASCII character set.

150
00:08:21.758 --> 00:08:25.790
But the ASCII character set did a really
bad job with international characters.

151
00:08:25.790 --> 00:08:28.312
And so if you had just a through z,
lowercase and

152
00:08:28.312 --> 00:08:30.457
uppercase, 0 through 9 for numbers,

153
00:08:30.457 --> 00:08:34.890
exclamation point, the at symbol, the
things you normally see on your keyboard.

154
00:08:34.890 --> 00:08:37.150
If you just had that stuff,
ASCII worked fine.

155
00:08:37.150 --> 00:08:41.130
But when you started getting into things
like accented characters, an e with

156
00:08:41.130 --> 00:08:45.910
an accent veriu or an accent aigu above
it or whatever it is that you had,

157
00:08:45.910 --> 00:08:51.270
all of those started to cause problems, or
umlauts, a u with the two dots above it.

158
00:08:51.270 --> 00:08:53.520
ASCII, it could handle it, but

159
00:08:53.520 --> 00:08:56.550
it didn't handle it consistently
across all languages.

160
00:08:56.550 --> 00:09:00.160
And so there was a big movement a few
years back to get everybody to move to

161
00:09:00.160 --> 00:09:04.590

everybody could use that handled all

162
00:09:04.590 --> 00:09:06.000

00:09:06.000 --> 00:09:10.320
Another big driving force for this was

00:09:10.320 --> 00:09:13.455

00:09:13.455 --> 00:09:15.783
Well, the ASCII standard had
been around a long time.

00:09:15.783 --> 00:09:17.405
To go and
update that standard would be a problem.

167
00:09:17.405 --> 00:09:19.345
So they made it where it was
a little more extensible, so

168
00:09:19.345 --> 00:09:21.485
when we add new currency symbols
they can get thrown in there.

169
00:09:21.485 --> 00:09:23.810
So there's a big push
these days to go to UTF-8,

00:09:23.810 --> 00:09:27.475

00:09:28.595 --> 00:09:29.574

then pool.net.org and it synced right up.

687
00:35:51.240 --> 00:35:54.050
And I got that step time server,
it reached out, found the time,

688
00:35:54.050 --> 00:35:54.790
and synchronized it.

689
00:35:54.790 --> 00:35:55.938
So, that's how we'd get that.

690
00:35:55.938 --> 00:35:59.186
Yeah, time is really important, especially
if you doing things like kerberos

691
00:35:59.186 --> 00:36:02.440
authentication, cuz if your time stamp
is off, stuff really starts to break.

692
00:36:02.440 --> 00:36:03.468
>> Awesome stuff.

693
00:36:03.468 --> 00:36:06.680
Well, Don, we've covered a lot of ground
today when it comes to localization.

694
00:36:06.680 --> 00:36:09.370
A lot of stuff that you probably
aren't thinking about as important,

695
00:36:09.370 --> 00:36:12.840
but in certain situations
it surely can be.

696
00:36:12.840 --> 00:36:14.160
So this is important stuff for
you to learn.

697
00:36:14.160 --> 00:36:16.560
Is there anything else that we need
to go over for this episode, Don?

698
00:36:16.560 --> 00:36:17.810
Or have we covered it all?

699
00:36:17.810 --> 00:36:18.740
>> I think that's about it.

700
00:36:18.740 --> 00:36:20.140
I need to set my localization back.

701
00:36:20.140 --> 00:36:20.980
>> [LAUGH] Yeah.
>> I'm gonna have a hard time

702
00:36:20.980 --> 00:36:21.860
the rest of the day.

703
00:36:21.860 --> 00:36:25.200
But to set it back, you just do
the same process we did going forward.

704
00:36:25.200 --> 00:36:27.640
So you can change it again,
it's pretty straightforward.

705
00:36:27.640 --> 00:36:29.790
Just be aware, things might be a little
bit different in different distros.

706
00:36:29.790 --> 00:36:33.010
It's often easier to change this from
the GUI than the command line, but

707
00:36:33.010 --> 00:36:34.760
on the exam, they want you to
know the command line, and so

708
00:36:34.760 --> 00:36:35.660
that's what we're seeing.

709
00:36:35.660 --> 00:36:36.330
>> That's right.

710
00:36:36.330 --> 00:36:38.050
Well, Don, thank you so
much for joining us today and

711
00:36:38.050 --> 00:36:39.450
explaining localization to us.

712
00:36:39.450 --> 00:36:42.582
It can be a little cryptic, but
as you can see, it's not too bad.

713
00:36:42.582 --> 00:36:44.700
And then, once in a while you
may actually have to do it,

714
00:36:44.700 --> 00:36:46.360
especially if you're
trying to take that exam.

715
00:36:46.360 --> 00:36:48.220
That being said,
we've wrapped another great show.

716
00:36:48.220 --> 00:36:49.040
Hopefully, you've enjoyed it.

717
00:36:49.040 --> 00:36:50.570
Thank you so much for watching.

718
00:36:50.570 --> 00:36:53.260
Signing off for ITProTV,
I've been your host Daniel Lowrie.

719
00:36:53.260 --> 00:36:53.890
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

720
00:36:53.890 --> 00:36:54.941
>> And we'll see you next time.

721
00:36:54.941 --> 00:37:01.338

episodes.title: Managing Users and Groups
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.133 --> 00:00:10.793
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:10.793 --> 00:00:14.020
All right everyone, welcome to
another great episode of ITProTV.

3
00:00:14.020 --> 00:00:18.050
I'm your host Daniel Lowrie and here with
me today is none other than Don Pezet.

4
00:00:18.050 --> 00:00:19.140
How's it going today, Don?

5
00:00:19.140 --> 00:00:20.160
>> It is going well.

6
00:00:20.160 --> 00:00:23.450
I'm all pumped up and
ready to go on another LINUX Plus episode.

7
00:00:23.450 --> 00:00:25.430
Today we're gonna take a look
at an important topic,

8
00:00:25.430 --> 00:00:28.200
which is managing users and groups.

9
00:00:28.200 --> 00:00:30.690
All throughout the show I've kind of
been logging in with this one account,

10
00:00:30.690 --> 00:00:34.180
and that's fine if you've got
a machine that's dedicated to you.

11
00:00:34.180 --> 00:00:38.100
But if we have any kind of shared system,
like a laptop that more than one person

12
00:00:38.100 --> 00:00:42.790
uses, or a server where you've got more
than one admin, then you need to have

13
00:00:42.790 --> 00:00:46.540
accounts for those people so they can get
in there and work Individually, right?

14
00:00:46.540 --> 00:00:49.490
Now why is it important that
we have separate accounts?

15
00:00:49.490 --> 00:00:54.710
Well Linux, Unix, all the different
distros, they do logging.

16
00:00:54.710 --> 00:00:55.960
They log who did what.

17
00:00:55.960 --> 00:00:57.550
And if everybody's logging
with the same account,

18
00:00:57.550 --> 00:00:59.140
you really don't know who did what.

19
00:00:59.140 --> 00:01:00.580
And if we wanna keep files separate,

20
00:01:00.580 --> 00:01:04.050
I want my files separate from Daniel,
then we need two separate user accounts.

21
00:01:04.050 --> 00:01:05.850
And we need to control permissions.

22
00:01:05.850 --> 00:01:09.450
I might want Daniel to be an admin on
a system and me to be just a regular user.

23
00:01:09.450 --> 00:01:12.480
So I can't restart a service,
but Daniel can, all right?

24
00:01:12.480 --> 00:01:15.490
That's the kind of functionality
that we get when we create

25
00:01:15.490 --> 00:01:17.200
individual user accounts.

26
00:01:17.200 --> 00:01:20.180
So let's take a look at the way
that Linux handles this.

27
00:01:20.180 --> 00:01:25.010
Now, Linux handles users pretty much
the same way that Unix did, and

28
00:01:25.010 --> 00:01:27.310
so it's a pretty straightforward process.

29
00:01:27.310 --> 00:01:28.900
Everything is represented as a file,
and so

30
00:01:28.900 --> 00:01:33.540
we find where user accounts
are really just an entry in a file.

31
00:01:33.540 --> 00:01:35.540
Let me show you what I mean.

32
00:01:35.540 --> 00:01:37.818
So I've got a Cent OS box pulled up here.

33
00:01:37.818 --> 00:01:41.040
But you'll find almost every
Linux distro does this.

34
00:01:41.040 --> 00:01:44.260
Your user accounts are all
listed in single file.

35
00:01:44.260 --> 00:01:49.763
That file is /etc/passwd, all right?

36
00:01:49.763 --> 00:01:54.800
Now you don't have to be a super user or
root or whatever to access this file.

37
00:01:54.800 --> 00:01:57.050
Anybody can look inside
of the password file.

38
00:01:57.050 --> 00:01:59.670
Now you might say, wait a minute,
it's the password file!

39
00:01:59.670 --> 00:02:03.820
Well, UNIX used to store the user names
and passwords right here in this file, and

40
00:02:03.820 --> 00:02:07.140
the passwords were in plain text,
and yeah, that'd be a big deal.

41
00:02:07.140 --> 00:02:08.360
But things have changed since then.

42
00:02:08.360 --> 00:02:09.000
And so now,

43
00:02:09.000 --> 00:02:13.120
when we look inside of the password file,
notice that I wasn't a root user.

44
00:02:13.120 --> 00:02:15.540
I just had a dollar sign for my prompt.

45
00:02:15.540 --> 00:02:18.290
And I can see a list of all the accounts,
all right.

46
00:02:18.290 --> 00:02:21.320
Here's all the user accounts
that are on my system.

47
00:02:21.320 --> 00:02:23.350
And the circle of that list, I see root.

48
00:02:23.350 --> 00:02:25.300
Right, there's that root user.

49
00:02:25.300 --> 00:02:28.570
And then we see other ones like sync and
shutdown, operator, games,

50
00:02:28.570 --> 00:02:30.800
gopher, I didn't create those.

51
00:02:30.800 --> 00:02:32.430
Well, my Lennox distro did.

52
00:02:32.430 --> 00:02:34.020
It created those when I installed it.

53
00:02:34.020 --> 00:02:35.220
All of those were made.

54
00:02:35.220 --> 00:02:39.210
But if we get all the way down to the end,
we'll start to see the ones that we made.

55
00:02:39.210 --> 00:02:40.150
And there as deep as that.

56
00:02:40.150 --> 00:02:41.120
There's my account.

57
00:02:41.120 --> 00:02:42.870
Right there.

58
00:02:42.870 --> 00:02:43.450
Okay.
The other

59
00:02:43.450 --> 00:02:46.480
information that's stored in this file
is information about the account.

60
00:02:46.480 --> 00:02:47.400
That next field.

61
00:02:47.400 --> 00:02:49.220
See how we've got these colons?

62
00:02:49.220 --> 00:02:52.290
Each colon indicates we're moving
from one field to another.

63
00:02:52.290 --> 00:02:53.890
So that first field, that's my user name.

64
00:02:53.890 --> 00:02:56.530
When I logged in, I logged in as dpezet.

65
00:02:56.530 --> 00:02:58.270
But I provided a password.

66
00:02:58.270 --> 00:03:00.760
And that's what the next field is, that x.

67
00:03:00.760 --> 00:03:03.370
Now, it used to be that the password
was there in plaintext.

68
00:03:03.370 --> 00:03:05.690
And then they started
hashing the passwords and so

69
00:03:05.690 --> 00:03:07.200
the password hash was there.

70
00:03:07.200 --> 00:03:09.243
But then they finally said,
you know what, forget it,

71
00:03:09.243 --> 00:03:10.900
we'll just move that
out to a separate file.

72
00:03:10.900 --> 00:03:12.470
So we have what's called a shadow file,

73
00:03:12.470 --> 00:03:15.880
and the shadow file is where
the passwords are stored now.

74
00:03:15.880 --> 00:03:17.900
Well, they are hashed,
they're not in plaintext,

75
00:03:17.900 --> 00:03:21.560
they are secured, but this little x is
just kind of a note to the system to say,

76
00:03:21.560 --> 00:03:24.190
hey, passwords aren't here,
they're over in a shadow file.

77
00:03:25.670 --> 00:03:29.410
Then, we have the user ID and group ID.

78
00:03:29.410 --> 00:03:30.560
All right?

79
00:03:30.560 --> 00:03:32.060
Every user has a user ID.

80
00:03:32.060 --> 00:03:33.060
You'll see mine is 500.

81
00:03:33.060 --> 00:03:33.560
Okay.

82
00:03:34.860 --> 00:03:38.870
Most Linux distros start numbering
the accounts that you create at 500.

83
00:03:38.870 --> 00:03:42.090
Some of them start at 1,000,
but most of them start at 500.

84
00:03:42.090 --> 00:03:43.860
So if I add a user, the first one is 500.

85
00:03:43.860 --> 00:03:47.070
If I add another user it'll be 501 and

86
00:03:47.070 --> 00:03:49.190
another user it will be 502,
503, and so on.

87
00:03:49.190 --> 00:03:50.980
Those are user IDs.

88
00:03:50.980 --> 00:03:53.110
Linux cares about the user ID.

89
00:03:53.110 --> 00:03:54.940
It doesn't care about the name.

90
00:03:54.940 --> 00:03:56.130
That doesn't mean anything to it.

91
00:03:56.130 --> 00:03:58.000
Right, deep as that,
that's what we see as humans.

92
00:03:58.000 --> 00:03:59.700
I could change the name on the account.

93
00:03:59.700 --> 00:04:03.530
And as long as my user ID stayed 500,
I'd still have the same permissions and

94
00:04:03.530 --> 00:04:04.840
access as normal, right?

95
00:04:04.840 --> 00:04:06.540
So the ID is what matters.

96
00:04:06.540 --> 00:04:10.340
Now notice that my group ID
is the same as my user ID.

97
00:04:10.340 --> 00:04:14.500
That means that my account
is both a user and a group.

98
00:04:14.500 --> 00:04:15.520
And that's pretty common.

99
00:04:15.520 --> 00:04:17.530
I mean look at all these other guys,
they're the same way.

100
00:04:17.530 --> 00:04:19.380
It doesn't have to be that way.

101
00:04:19.380 --> 00:04:24.030
I can be in a sales group and the sales
group might have an ID of 501, so

102
00:04:24.030 --> 00:04:28.000
my user ID might be 500 and
then my group might be 501.

103
00:04:28.000 --> 00:04:29.869
Right, depending on the groups
that I'm assigned in,

104
00:04:29.869 --> 00:04:33.020
but normally we'll see the number
twice there for user and group.

105
00:04:33.020 --> 00:04:35.026
Then I've got my full name, Don Pezet,

106
00:04:35.026 --> 00:04:39.910
right, the nice human readable format,
followed by my home directory.

107
00:04:39.910 --> 00:04:42.630
Where do my personal files go, right?

108
00:04:42.630 --> 00:04:45.190
Slash home slash dpezet is my default.

109
00:04:45.190 --> 00:04:47.610
And then lastly, what's my shell,right?

110
00:04:47.610 --> 00:04:50.900
My shell is slash bin slash bash.

111
00:04:50.900 --> 00:04:53.860
So when I log in, I'm gonna get bash.

112
00:04:53.860 --> 00:04:56.720
But if I go up here and
check out like root for example.

113
00:04:56.720 --> 00:04:58.600
Oh well I thought it was different,
but apparently it's not,

114
00:04:58.600 --> 00:05:00.500
it's slash bin slash bash also.

115
00:05:00.500 --> 00:05:05.210
But maybe you change yours to tcsh or
zsh or something like that.

116
00:05:05.210 --> 00:05:07.110
You'll see that alternate
shell right there.

117
00:05:08.180 --> 00:05:10.570
Notice the shell on most
of these other accounts.

118
00:05:10.570 --> 00:05:11.990
Slash s bin slash no login.

119
00:05:13.080 --> 00:05:17.950
That means that these can run as services,
but they can't get an interactive log in.

120
00:05:17.950 --> 00:05:19.900
They can't actually log in to get a shell.

121
00:05:19.900 --> 00:05:21.580
So, if you're setting
up a service account,

122
00:05:21.580 --> 00:05:23.460
that's a great way to
ensure security on it.

123
00:05:23.460 --> 00:05:25.334
That nobody can actually
figure out that password and

124
00:05:25.334 --> 00:05:28.430
actually log in as that user,
it just runs as a service, right.

125
00:05:28.430 --> 00:05:30.580
So you'll see some of
those mapped to that.

126
00:05:30.580 --> 00:05:33.030
You can actually map the shell to
anything, you can map it to a command.

127
00:05:33.030 --> 00:05:37.310
And, when somebody logs in, that command
would run, and then it would log them out.

128
00:05:37.310 --> 00:05:42.110
So like if you wanted to,
I don't know, cause anacron to run,

129
00:05:42.110 --> 00:05:45.830
you could put it in here as /bin/anacron,
and when you logged in,

130
00:05:45.830 --> 00:05:47.720
it would run that and
then kick you right back out again.

131
00:05:47.720 --> 00:05:49.890
So, not a whole lot of need for
that, but you can do it.

132
00:05:51.770 --> 00:05:54.980
All right, now, in the really old days,
if you wanted to add a user,

133
00:05:54.980 --> 00:05:58.360
you would edit this slash
etc slash past wd file.

134
00:05:58.360 --> 00:06:02.000
And you would add the user's entry and
you just created a user account.

135
00:06:02.000 --> 00:06:05.250
But thanks to the GNU tools, we actually
have a whole set of commands that

136
00:06:05.250 --> 00:06:07.870
we can use that make it really
easy to create user accounts and

137
00:06:07.870 --> 00:06:09.990
modify this data without editing it.

138
00:06:11.030 --> 00:06:13.450
So we'll get a chance to see
those here in just a second.

139
00:06:13.450 --> 00:06:15.601
But I want to double back on something
I mentioned just a moment ago,

140
00:06:15.601 --> 00:06:17.300
which was that shadow file.

141
00:06:17.300 --> 00:06:22.820
The shadow file, well, this was
slash ETC slash password or passwd.

142
00:06:22.820 --> 00:06:27.260
If I do slash ETC slash shadow,
that's my shadow file.

143
00:06:27.260 --> 00:06:30.080
And remember how I said even
though I wasn't a real real user,

144
00:06:30.080 --> 00:06:34.160
I could get to passwd, still I can't get
to shadow, this one's special, right.

145
00:06:34.160 --> 00:06:35.810
It's actually got passwords in it.

146
00:06:35.810 --> 00:06:40.965
And so, I need to elevate my privileges
real quick, and once I do that,

147
00:06:40.965 --> 00:06:45.710
[LAUGH]
if I know my password, there we go.

148
00:06:45.710 --> 00:06:50.502
Now I can go in and take a look at
that shadow file, and there it is.

149
00:06:50.502 --> 00:06:51.750
All right.

150
00:06:51.750 --> 00:06:56.940
Now the shadow file is made up of
almost the same as the past WD file.

151
00:06:56.940 --> 00:07:01.370
You'll see the user's name
followed by their password.

152
00:07:01.370 --> 00:07:03.290
And see how it's showing
an asterisk there.

153
00:07:03.290 --> 00:07:05.740
Well that's the system
protecting me from myself.

154
00:07:05.740 --> 00:07:10.710
In the file the actual password hash
is there, but when you output it on

155
00:07:10.710 --> 00:07:15.755
your screen the Linux kernel is stepping
in and rendering that as as a asterisk.

156
00:07:15.755 --> 00:07:17.400
Notice this root user up here.

157
00:07:17.400 --> 00:07:20.020
See how we've got the password
hash right there.

158
00:07:20.020 --> 00:07:21.220
That's the password hash.

159
00:07:21.220 --> 00:07:22.240
Right?
But these others,

160
00:07:22.240 --> 00:07:25.410
these service accounts that they create,
they're obscured.

161
00:07:25.410 --> 00:07:29.470
And what you'll find is that some of these
cases, they don't even have a password.

162
00:07:29.470 --> 00:07:31.420
Like where we've got
the double exclamation points

163
00:07:31.420 --> 00:07:32.900
where there's no password
assigned to them.

164
00:07:32.900 --> 00:07:35.480
They don't worry about it because
it's just a service that runs.

165
00:07:35.480 --> 00:07:39.080
And, you can't log in as the user anyway,
so you may see that kind of syntax too.

166
00:07:39.080 --> 00:07:42.130
But, if I scroll all the way down,
here's dpezet and

167
00:07:42.130 --> 00:07:46.105
there's my hash password
right inside there.

168
00:07:46.105 --> 00:07:49.140
Okay.
Now, the values that follow that.

169
00:07:49.140 --> 00:07:50.390
That's my password policy.

170
00:07:52.030 --> 00:07:54.350
When's the next time I need
to change my password?

171
00:07:54.350 --> 00:07:56.210
When was it that I changed this password?

172
00:07:56.210 --> 00:08:01.210
How many times can I get an incorrect
password before I'm locked out?

173
00:08:01.210 --> 00:08:01.750
Right?

174
00:08:01.750 --> 00:08:04.960
That's my password policy and it's kind
of stored here in these various values.

175
00:08:04.960 --> 00:08:06.130
We'll see those at the end of the episode.

176
00:08:06.130 --> 00:08:10.790
I'll show you how to modify those, but
that's all stored in that shadow file.

177
00:08:10.790 --> 00:08:13.260
So two files make up our passwords, right?

178
00:08:13.260 --> 00:08:18.350
There was /etc/passwd and /etc/shadow.

179
00:08:18.350 --> 00:08:21.280
Two really important files to remember.

180
00:08:21.280 --> 00:08:22.677
>> Now that shadow file is
really the mother lode for

181
00:08:22.677 --> 00:08:24.688
anybody trying to get at passwords and
they use a really good encrypt or

182
00:08:24.688 --> 00:08:25.381
it's not encryption.

183
00:08:25.381 --> 00:08:28.101
It's a hashing algorithm
to make sure that's and

184
00:08:28.101 --> 00:08:30.051
it's a non reversible algorithm.

185
00:08:30.051 --> 00:08:31.320
Isn't that right, Don?

186
00:08:33.660 --> 00:08:36.153
>> Yeah, hash is a general non reversible.

187
00:08:36.153 --> 00:08:39.080
So they didn't have to do basically
a brute force attack against it, and

188
00:08:39.080 --> 00:08:40.710
there are rainbow tables and
things out there but

189
00:08:40.710 --> 00:08:43.410
this is a really strong
bit strength on these.

190
00:08:43.410 --> 00:08:46.820
Different distros use different hashes
though so just be aware of that.

191
00:08:46.820 --> 00:08:50.400
If you're running an outdated distro
you might be using a weaker hash on

192
00:08:50.400 --> 00:08:51.370
your shadow file.

193
00:08:51.370 --> 00:08:54.250
Fortunately the shadow file's restricted
so that only the root user can get to it.

194
00:08:54.250 --> 00:08:57.440
So if they've already got root access,
you got bigger problems than

195
00:08:57.440 --> 00:08:59.880
them getting at the shadow file cuz
they could just reset your passwords.

196
00:08:59.880 --> 00:09:00.520
Right?

00:32:15.700 --> 00:32:17.106
We're signing off for ITProTV.

643
00:32:17.106 --> 00:32:18.441
I've been your host, Daniel Lowrie.

644
00:32:18.441 --> 00:32:19.544
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

645
00:32:19.544 --> 00:32:20.786
>> And we'll see you next time.

646
00:32:20.786 --> 00:32:26.990
