episodes.title: System Logging
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.805
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:10.805 --> 00:00:15.380
All right, greetings everyone and welcome
to another great episode of ITProTV.

3
00:00:15.380 --> 00:00:19.566
I'm your host Daniel Lowrie and here with
me is none other than the man himself,

4
00:00:19.566 --> 00:00:20.198
Don Pezet.

5
00:00:20.198 --> 00:00:21.162
How you doing today, Don?

6
00:00:21.162 --> 00:00:21.917
>> I am doing great Daniel.

7
00:00:21.917 --> 00:00:24.824
>> [LAUGH]
>> Today we're gonna talk about something

8
00:00:24.824 --> 00:00:27.361
really important,
which is logging under Linux.

9
00:00:29.040 --> 00:00:30.840
Every Linux system
maintains some kind of log,

10
00:00:30.840 --> 00:00:33.400
a record of the activities that
are going on in the background.

11
00:00:33.400 --> 00:00:35.230
And we use them for
troubleshooting, right?

12
00:00:35.230 --> 00:00:39.368
But one key thing that we really [LAUGH]
need to remember is that logs aren't

13
00:00:39.368 --> 00:00:41.716
really important, until you need them.

14
00:00:41.716 --> 00:00:44.275
And we need them,
boy will you be glad that you have them.

15
00:00:44.275 --> 00:00:47.548
But if they weren't configured properly,
when you get to that point where you

16
00:00:47.548 --> 00:00:50.919
need them, there's no way to go back and
re-create this things if they weren't

17
00:00:50.919 --> 00:00:53.018
maintained originally
from the very beginning.

18
00:00:53.018 --> 00:00:57.423
So when I set up a new Linux server,
one of the first things I do is go in and

19
00:00:57.423 --> 00:00:58.682
tweak the logging.

20
00:00:58.682 --> 00:01:03.095
And there's kind of two different
ways to do logging these days.

21
00:01:03.095 --> 00:01:05.750
Most systems still use
the traditional Unix method,

22
00:01:05.750 --> 00:01:08.052
which is a service called syslog,
all right?

23
00:01:08.052 --> 00:01:12.021
Syslog is just short for system log,
right, nothing special there.

24
00:01:12.021 --> 00:01:15.279
And basically as your system boots up,
as your system runs programs and

25
00:01:15.279 --> 00:01:17.990
other software,
it's generating log messages.

26
00:01:17.990 --> 00:01:20.570
And those are being put in the system log.

27
00:01:20.570 --> 00:01:22.870
So that syslog functionality,
and it's basic,

28
00:01:22.870 --> 00:01:24.850
really doesn't sound like much, right?

29
00:01:24.850 --> 00:01:27.750
We generate log events, they go into
a text file, they're there for us to view.

30
00:01:27.750 --> 00:01:29.217
Great, whoop-dee-do.

31
00:01:29.217 --> 00:01:32.147
Well, there are some advanced
functionalities we can take advantage of

32
00:01:32.147 --> 00:01:34.740
with syslog, and it's an important
one to be familiar with, so

33
00:01:34.740 --> 00:01:36.180
I want to talk about that.

34
00:01:36.180 --> 00:01:38.800
And then at the end of the episode,
I wanna talk about a new type

35
00:01:38.800 --> 00:01:41.740
of logging called journaling,
that's available in systemd.

36
00:01:41.740 --> 00:01:45.221
So we'll get a chance to see that too
if you're on a systemd enabled distro.

37
00:01:45.221 --> 00:01:47.748
But let's just start with syslog cuz
that's the one you can count on for

38
00:01:47.748 --> 00:01:49.573
pretty much every Linux
distro that's out there.

39
00:01:49.573 --> 00:01:55.340
As well as BSD, Unix, even Mac OS,
right, they all use Syslog.

40
00:01:55.340 --> 00:01:59.077
All right, first thing, syslog is
a service, so it runs in the background.

41
00:01:59.077 --> 00:02:02.728
It's a default service,
it's installed as part of your distro.

42
00:02:02.728 --> 00:02:06.315
So there's the syslog daemon,
syslogd, that runs in the background.

43
00:02:06.315 --> 00:02:08.160
It's what's responsible for
doing the logging.

44
00:02:08.160 --> 00:02:10.410
It runs automatically,
it logs automatically.

45
00:02:10.410 --> 00:02:13.250
We can tell it's working by
looking at the log files.

46
00:02:13.250 --> 00:02:18.912
It puts the logs in /var/log, all right?

47
00:02:18.912 --> 00:02:20.785
So you'll have a folder /var/log,

48
00:02:20.785 --> 00:02:24.990
and if you look in there you'll see
all sorts of different log files.

49
00:02:24.990 --> 00:02:28.086
There's two that we normally
care about the most, right.

50
00:02:28.086 --> 00:02:32.990
The most important one is the messages
file, this guy right here.

51
00:02:32.990 --> 00:02:34.160
That's your syslog.

52
00:02:34.160 --> 00:02:35.340
All the system events and

53
00:02:35.340 --> 00:02:38.260
other activities are being logged
right to that messages file.

54
00:02:38.260 --> 00:02:41.060
There's another one on here that we
talked about in our hardware episode,

55
00:02:41.060 --> 00:02:42.502
which is dmesg.

56
00:02:42.502 --> 00:02:43.990
And dmesg,

57
00:02:43.990 --> 00:02:47.370
that's for hardware detection, stuff
that's happening when our system boots.

58
00:02:47.370 --> 00:02:54.304
So if we were to take a look at these,
if I pull up more /var/log/dmesg.

59
00:02:54.304 --> 00:02:57.067
Here's the hardware detection that
happened as my system booted up.

60
00:02:57.067 --> 00:03:00.242
It picked up my CPU,
it started identifying hardware,

61
00:03:00.242 --> 00:03:03.223
as I scroll down we'll see
more fun stuff down here.

62
00:03:03.223 --> 00:03:06.578
As it picks up hard drives, and
network adapters and all of that,

63
00:03:06.578 --> 00:03:08.840
and starts provisioning them out, right?

64
00:03:08.840 --> 00:03:14.490
So here it's looking for CMOS color VGA
console, you gotta have the best, right?

65
00:03:14.490 --> 00:03:16.580
So [LAUGH] all that stuff
that gets detected.

66
00:03:16.580 --> 00:03:19.830
If we're troubleshooting hardware,
that's where we go, right?

67
00:03:19.830 --> 00:03:22.920
But hardware isn't something
we troubleshoot very often,

68
00:03:22.920 --> 00:03:25.920
because once it's configured
you're kinda done.

69
00:03:25.920 --> 00:03:28.080
Software on the other hand,
it's a different story.

70
00:03:28.080 --> 00:03:32.030
I know it's all ones and zeroes on
the back end, but it's like when it runs

71
00:03:32.030 --> 00:03:35.306
there's this in-between value
where things sort of work.

72
00:03:35.306 --> 00:03:38.765
[LAUGH] And so we end up troubleshooting,

73
00:03:38.765 --> 00:03:43.460
and that's where we end
up in /var/log/messages.

74
00:03:43.460 --> 00:03:45.070
And when we look inside of that messages,

75
00:03:45.070 --> 00:03:47.010
that's when we're gonna
see our software logs.

76
00:03:47.010 --> 00:03:50.710
And I'm not a super user so
I don't have the ability to view it, so

77
00:03:50.710 --> 00:03:53.590
I'm just gonna escalate,
or elevate my privileges.

78
00:03:53.590 --> 00:03:55.465
I'm gonna escalate the situation!

79
00:03:55.465 --> 00:03:58.557
And I'll take a look in
/var/log/messages and

80
00:03:58.557 --> 00:04:02.080
we'll start to see some information,
all right.

81
00:04:02.080 --> 00:04:05.420
Now, I don't have a lot in mine,
I just have one entry.

82
00:04:05.420 --> 00:04:08.580
And my one entry is stating
that syslogd is starting.

83
00:04:08.580 --> 00:04:11.430
And then after that I'm just there,
that's it.

84
00:04:11.430 --> 00:04:14.500
Well, as services start to
do things on my system,

85
00:04:14.500 --> 00:04:18.190
as activities happen,
we'll start to see log messages.

86
00:04:18.190 --> 00:04:22.835
So, for example, if I do something
like installing a web server, right,

87
00:04:22.835 --> 00:04:25.216
which apparently I've already got.

88
00:04:25.216 --> 00:04:30.806
And if I do a service httpd stop and I
stop that service, or I start it again, or

89
00:04:30.806 --> 00:04:37.267
if the service crashes, or whatever, these
are things that can generate log messages.

90
00:04:37.267 --> 00:04:41.110
And they may or may not log,
it kinda depends on the software.

91
00:04:41.110 --> 00:04:44.700
Each software, you have configuration
options inside of it that determine

92
00:04:44.700 --> 00:04:47.760
when something is severe
enough to go ahead and log.

93
00:04:47.760 --> 00:04:51.006
So those may or may not have actually
made it into my log, let's see.

94
00:04:51.006 --> 00:04:54.134
Yeah, they weren't exciting enough,
apparently.

95
00:04:54.134 --> 00:04:57.259
But you start to see entries pop
in there as our systems goes and

96
00:04:57.259 --> 00:05:00.160
as we start encountering errors and
other things.

97
00:05:00.160 --> 00:05:02.422
They'll populate that file, all right?

98
00:05:02.422 --> 00:05:06.390
Now the file can get pretty big, so
I'm using the more command, right?

99
00:05:06.390 --> 00:05:09.170
And more just shows me the whole
thing with pagination.

100
00:05:09.170 --> 00:05:10.810
But a lot of times we'll use grep,

101
00:05:10.810 --> 00:05:13.520
to search to find certain
things inside of it.

102
00:05:13.520 --> 00:05:17.730
Or instead you might use the tail
command to see the most recent stuff.

103
00:05:17.730 --> 00:05:26.085
One thing I like to do is
tail -f /var/log/messages.

104
00:05:26.085 --> 00:05:29.384
What this one does is it says,
show me the last ten lines, and

105
00:05:29.384 --> 00:05:32.210
if the file gets updated, you update too.

106
00:05:32.210 --> 00:05:34.110
Show me what's going on, okay?

107
00:05:34.110 --> 00:05:36.060
So I'll do that, I'm gonna say tail -f.

108
00:05:36.060 --> 00:05:39.040
It's showing me the last ten lines,
and see how it's staying open?

109
00:05:40.160 --> 00:05:44.003
As messages get generated,
it's gonna update, all right?

110
00:05:44.003 --> 00:05:45.642
Well, I could wait.

111
00:05:45.642 --> 00:05:47.789
This could be the longest episode ever and
we could just wait for

112
00:05:47.789 --> 00:05:50.236
some error to happen on my system or
other information to be generated.

113
00:05:50.236 --> 00:05:52.998
Or I could cause something to happen.

114
00:05:52.998 --> 00:05:54.997
We can raise our own error messages.

115
00:05:54.997 --> 00:05:58.680
And that's really useful if you're
gonna be doing things from a script.

116
00:05:58.680 --> 00:06:01.460
You might have a script that runs and
you wanna generate log messages so

117
00:06:01.460 --> 00:06:03.965
you can see if the script ran or
different stages of it happened.

118
00:06:03.965 --> 00:06:07.430
And I say error, a lot of us think
of errors as a bad thing, but

119
00:06:07.430 --> 00:06:09.308
error messages can be a good thing, right?

120
00:06:09.308 --> 00:06:12.850
Technically, when your software returns,
hey everything went fine,

121
00:06:12.850 --> 00:06:15.620
it's returning an error code
that means everything went fine.

122
00:06:15.620 --> 00:06:17.890
So error isn't always bad.

123
00:06:17.890 --> 00:06:20.714
So I'm gonna open up a new tab.

124
00:06:20.714 --> 00:06:25.920
And in this other tab, I'm gonna
raise an error message on my own.

125
00:06:25.920 --> 00:06:28.648
You have this command,
it's called the logger command.

126
00:06:28.648 --> 00:06:32.922
And logger can generate, oh,
apparently it doesn't have a- -help.

127
00:06:32.922 --> 00:06:37.695
But logger can generate log messages,
if I can pull its help file.

128
00:06:37.695 --> 00:06:41.906
And so you can come in and generate
a log message that'll show up in syslog.

129
00:06:41.906 --> 00:06:45.116
But it's not as easy as just saying
logger and then your message.

130
00:06:45.116 --> 00:06:48.730
Syslog entries actually have
a lot of data tied to them.

131
00:06:48.730 --> 00:06:50.780
If you look at the one
message that I've got here,

132
00:06:50.780 --> 00:06:54.610
this line is actually made up on
a number of different pieces, all right?

133
00:06:54.610 --> 00:06:56.040
Let's talk about the pieces.

134
00:06:56.040 --> 00:06:59.170
The first one is pretty easy,
the date and time.

135
00:06:59.170 --> 00:07:01.318
Here's the date and
time that this message occurred.

136
00:07:01.318 --> 00:07:04.010
That's important cuz if
I'm trying to correlate

137
00:07:04.010 --> 00:07:06.240
messages across more than one
server I need to have that time.

138
00:07:06.240 --> 00:07:08.590
And time synchronization
is really important,

139
00:07:08.590 --> 00:07:10.880
we'll have an episode on
time synchronization later.

140
00:07:10.880 --> 00:07:14.717
Make sure you check that out because you
wanna make sure the clocks are the same on

141
00:07:14.717 --> 00:07:17.416
your systems, or
you won't be able to correlate logs.

142
00:07:17.416 --> 00:07:20.910
All right,
the next part is what server generated it.

143
00:07:20.910 --> 00:07:23.430
Well, I'm on the server,
why do I need that?

144
00:07:23.430 --> 00:07:27.591
Well you can actually ship your syslogs
to another system if you want, all right?

145
00:07:27.591 --> 00:07:31.930
That's really handy because, what's gonna
happen if a hacker gets into your server?

146
00:07:31.930 --> 00:07:35.150
A good hacker,
target number one is your log files.

147
00:07:35.150 --> 00:07:36.960
They need to be able
to cover their tracks.

148
00:07:36.960 --> 00:07:40.100
So they're gonna try and clear your
logs to hide what they're doing, and

149
00:07:40.100 --> 00:07:42.260
then they do the real damage.

150
00:07:42.260 --> 00:07:43.770
Your logs are a big target.

151
00:07:43.770 --> 00:07:45.958
By using a network syslog server,

152
00:07:45.958 --> 00:07:49.961
[COUGH] we can send those log
messages off to a different system.

153
00:07:49.961 --> 00:07:52.283
And now if the hacker clears
our logs here, big deal,

154
00:07:52.283 --> 00:07:54.407
I've still got the log somewhere else,
right?

155
00:07:54.407 --> 00:07:57.237
So that's why it has
the host name right here,

156
00:07:57.237 --> 00:08:00.511
followed by what service
generated the log message.

157
00:08:00.511 --> 00:08:04.991
In my case this is from rsyslogd
That's what generated this message.

158
00:08:04.991 --> 00:08:08.250
And then after that we
have the actual message.

159
00:08:08.250 --> 00:08:10.890
So here's the message that
was generated by this system

160
00:08:10.890 --> 00:08:13.890
letting me know that the system fired up.

161
00:08:13.890 --> 00:08:17.715
There's a few other things that you
might see attached to a message, for

162
00:08:17.715 --> 00:08:20.335
example a facility, all right.

163
00:08:20.335 --> 00:08:23.344
And a facility and an error code.

164
00:08:23.344 --> 00:08:24.458
And I made some little tables.

165
00:08:24.458 --> 00:08:26.525
I'll put these with the show notes.

166
00:08:26.525 --> 00:08:33.280
But the facility is identifying
what generated the message.

167
00:08:33.280 --> 00:08:36.510
And not just the service,
but what type of service.

168
00:08:36.510 --> 00:08:40.680
And so you'll see this in default
facilities like kernel, user, mail.

169
00:08:40.680 --> 00:08:43.630
And so, if it's the Linux kernel
that's generating this message,

170
00:08:43.630 --> 00:08:46.800
it'll have a facility of 0 and
that'll identify that.

171
00:08:46.800 --> 00:08:50.350
Or if it's your clock that's generating,
it'll have a facility of 9.

172
00:08:50.350 --> 00:08:54.150
But, most of the time, we're gonna
see these facilities down here,

173
00:08:54.150 --> 00:08:55.870
local0 through local7.

174
00:08:55.870 --> 00:08:57.454
These are ones that you can use for
whatever you want.

175
00:08:57.454 --> 00:08:59.055
So when you write your software,

176
00:08:59.055 --> 00:09:03.880
you might say, my software is always
gonna generate messages that are local5.

177
00:09:03.880 --> 00:09:07.460
I'm gonna do local5, so
that when I go to view the log files,

178
00:09:07.460 --> 00:09:10.460
I can just look at local5, and
find them right there, and that's that.

179
00:09:10.460 --> 00:09:12.247
Right?
Make it real easy to filter out

180
00:09:12.247 --> 00:09:13.082
my log messages.

181
00:09:13.082 --> 00:09:15.483
That's really what these
facilities are all about,

182
00:09:15.483 --> 00:09:17.670
is making it easy to filter messages.

183
00:09:17.670 --> 00:09:18.770
All right.

184
00:09:18.770 --> 00:09:22.410
And then each message has
a severity level, right?

185
00:09:22.410 --> 00:09:24.570
How bad is this message?

186
00:09:24.570 --> 00:09:25.290
Maybe it's not bad at all.

187
00:09:25.290 --> 00:09:27.270
Maybe it's just information, right?

188
00:09:27.270 --> 00:09:30.590
That'll be an information,
a security level of 6.

189
00:09:30.590 --> 00:09:32.700
Or maybe it's really bad.

190
00:09:32.700 --> 00:09:33.770
System Unusable.

191
00:09:33.770 --> 00:09:35.880
Right?
That would be a message of 0.

192
00:09:35.880 --> 00:09:37.150
That's emergency.

193
00:09:37.150 --> 00:09:39.720
So you'll see a severity type to it also,
and

194
00:09:39.720 --> 00:09:41.920
that's important for filtering purposes.

195
00:09:41.920 --> 00:09:45.760
I might say just show me errors and above.

196
00:09:45.760 --> 00:09:47.050
That's all I wanna see.

197
00:09:47.050 --> 00:09:50.940
I don't wanna see warnings, notices,
info, that stuff, that's just whatever,

198
00:09:50.940 --> 00:09:51.920
I ignore most of that.

199
00:09:51.920 --> 00:09:53.660
Just show me the bad stuff, right?

200
00:09:53.660 --> 00:09:56.950
So these are all designed
to help us kinda filter.

201
00:09:56.950 --> 00:10:00.340
So when we use the logger
command to come in and

202
00:10:00.340 --> 00:10:04.810
create a log message, those are some
of the things that we need to provide

203
00:10:04.810 --> 00:10:07.300
in order to generate the log message.

204
00:10:07.300 --> 00:10:11.492
So for example,
I might say, logger -p, and

205
00:10:11.492 --> 00:10:16.690
then I'm gonna say local0 for
this one, right, that's my facility.

206
00:10:16.690 --> 00:10:19.550
And then, I say, .crit.

207
00:10:19.550 --> 00:10:22.320
This is gonna be a critical message,
right.

208
00:10:22.320 --> 00:10:27.020
So there's my facility, and my severity,
right, I'm providing that information.

209
00:10:27.020 --> 00:10:29.640
Then I give it what my
message is gonna be.

210
00:10:29.640 --> 00:10:33.860
I'm gonna say, Major issue detected.

211
00:10:33.860 --> 00:10:36.640
Stop drop and roll.

212
00:10:36.640 --> 00:10:38.460
Right, and there we go.

213
00:10:38.460 --> 00:10:39.695
I just generated a log message.

214
00:10:39.695 --> 00:10:41.752
All right now, where did it go?

215
00:10:41.752 --> 00:10:45.292
Well, hopefully it went
into /var/log/messages.

216
00:10:45.292 --> 00:10:48.621
And back here I was running tail-f and so,

217
00:10:48.621 --> 00:10:53.378
as the new messages came in I see
it right there on the screen.

218
00:10:53.378 --> 00:10:54.930
So tail-f is really handy for

219
00:10:54.930 --> 00:10:58.090
seeing stuff in real time as
the messages get generated.

220
00:10:58.090 --> 00:11:02.050
I can see that message right
here from local host dpzet and

221
00:11:02.050 --> 00:11:05.190
then it's listing it out right there,
right.

222
00:11:05.190 --> 00:11:07.870
That's the way these syslogs work.

223
00:11:07.870 --> 00:11:12.160
Just logging it, storing the data,
and leaving it here available for us.

224
00:11:14.322 --> 00:11:16.935
All right, couple other things

451
00:23:07.300 --> 00:23:10.010
And if you don't have the directory,
journal d might be running but

452
00:23:10.010 --> 00:23:12.410
it's not actually saving anything
until you print that directory.

453
00:23:13.450 --> 00:23:14.616
Now you an manipulate
where that directory is.

454
00:23:14.616 --> 00:23:18.529
It doesn't have to be there,
that's just the default, /var/log/journal.

455
00:23:18.529 --> 00:23:25.715
If you want to manipulate it, this is all
controlled inside of /etc/log/journal.

456
00:23:25.715 --> 00:23:28.490
And actually, there's files inside
of that, so let me get into that.

457
00:23:28.490 --> 00:23:33.296
So that's etc/log/journal.

458
00:23:33.296 --> 00:23:38.187
And, oh, I don't even have that folder,
oh, [LAUGH] I'm going to the wrong place.

459
00:23:38.187 --> 00:23:43.047
/etc/systemd, there we go, it's inside
of the System D configuration and

460
00:23:43.047 --> 00:23:46.223
you'll see journald.comf
that guy right there.

461
00:23:46.223 --> 00:23:48.615
I'm gonna get to that other
folder here in just a second.

462
00:23:48.615 --> 00:23:53.506
journald.comf, if I take a look at
that file, that's where its got,

463
00:23:53.506 --> 00:23:55.638
where the storage is, right?

464
00:23:55.638 --> 00:23:57.270
You can move that somewhere else.

465
00:23:57.270 --> 00:24:00.682
You remove this hash mark to uncomment the
line and you specify an alternate path.

466
00:24:00.682 --> 00:24:04.880
But the default is to go
to /var/log/journal and

467
00:24:04.880 --> 00:24:08.791
In fact, if I go in here,
let me edit this file.

468
00:24:08.791 --> 00:24:11.672
If I go in here and change it and
just leave it at auto,

469
00:24:11.672 --> 00:24:14.910
it's going to go ahead and
put it in that location.

470
00:24:14.910 --> 00:24:17.162
You can turn on compression,
you can set other values,

471
00:24:17.162 --> 00:24:19.680
all right, all sorts of other stuff that
we can configure in here, and I'm just

472
00:24:19.680 --> 00:24:23.510
gonna leave them all at their defaults to
get the new journaling system turned on.

473
00:24:23.510 --> 00:24:27.150
Now the folder I was trying to go
to a moment ago, /var/log/journal,

474
00:24:27.150 --> 00:24:32.080
that was where the logs get stored and
then /etc/log/journal, that one doesn't

475
00:24:32.080 --> 00:24:36.800
actually exist, so
that's why I wasn't getting to it.

476
00:24:38.170 --> 00:24:42.110
All right so at this point I've
got journald configured, but

477
00:24:42.110 --> 00:24:43.890
it's not actually running.

478
00:24:43.890 --> 00:24:46.800
It is fired up by systemd when it starts,
and you do have to reboot for

479
00:24:46.800 --> 00:24:47.680
this one to take effect.

480
00:24:47.680 --> 00:24:49.048
So I'm gonna go ahead and issue a reboot.

481
00:24:49.048 --> 00:24:53.026
And when it reboots,
I've got /var/log/journal, so

482
00:24:53.026 --> 00:24:54.878
it has a place to store it.

483
00:24:54.878 --> 00:25:01.460
And in /etc/systemD/journal.cnof,
it knows to use that.

484
00:25:01.460 --> 00:25:06.270
And so now, I'm still sys logging,
but I'm journaling also.

485
00:25:06.270 --> 00:25:09.140
And if I'm happy with the journaling,
I can go and disable sys log and

486
00:25:09.140 --> 00:25:10.700
I wouldn't have it anymore.

487
00:25:10.700 --> 00:25:12.690
But very few distros
are doing that right now.

488
00:25:12.690 --> 00:25:17.510
Most of the distros are supporting syslog,
so expect to see that.

489
00:25:17.510 --> 00:25:18.600
But we do need to be aware of this and

490
00:25:18.600 --> 00:25:21.390
I just kind of want to show you those
logs, once they come up and get generated.

491
00:25:22.860 --> 00:25:25.850
Now for viewing the logs, I can go and
poke around the files themselves, but

492
00:25:25.850 --> 00:25:28.420
we actually have a system D
utility we can use for it too.

493
00:25:29.960 --> 00:25:37.020
So that I've rebooted,
the command is journalctl, right?

494
00:25:37.020 --> 00:25:39.590
Remember in system D you have
like systemctl for starting and

495
00:25:39.590 --> 00:25:40.730
stopping services?

496
00:25:40.730 --> 00:25:43.590
You got journalctl for
looking at the journal.

497
00:25:43.590 --> 00:25:45.710
And there's my log messages, right?

498
00:25:45.710 --> 00:25:49.680
Journalctl, I can see the logs,
and now I've got those entries and

499
00:25:49.680 --> 00:25:53.090
you can see my domain name,
the service that generated it,

500
00:25:53.090 --> 00:25:56.220
the process ID of the service,
the message that was generated.

501
00:25:56.220 --> 00:25:59.280
It's all right here in Journal CTL.

502
00:25:59.280 --> 00:26:05.800
And if I go into /var/log/journal,
I can see that file right there.

503
00:26:05.800 --> 00:26:09.720
It's generated my first one, and it's
gonna start drawing from there, all right?

504
00:26:09.720 --> 00:26:14.330
So, it's an alternative to syslog, it's
very new, it's not widely accepted yet,

505
00:26:14.330 --> 00:26:17.150
but it is kind of on the horizon,
just something you're gonna see.

506
00:26:17.150 --> 00:26:18.320
>> It was very neat and clean though.

507
00:26:18.320 --> 00:26:20.750
A whole lot easier,
at least to work with and

508
00:26:20.750 --> 00:26:25.550
deal with as far as the output,
and especially with that one.

509
00:26:25.550 --> 00:26:28.510
>> You know one of the big
advantages of the,

510
00:26:28.510 --> 00:26:32.610
of journaling is it's tied the system
ds is tied to the inet process.

511
00:26:32.610 --> 00:26:36.270
Versus syslog, where for a lot of distros,
syslog is just it's own service.

512
00:26:36.270 --> 00:26:39.980
So it's possible this service could crash
and now you're not getting logs anymore.

513
00:26:39.980 --> 00:26:41.080
That'd be bad.

514
00:26:41.080 --> 00:26:45.340
Well with journaling in system D if
it crashes, if system D crashes,

515
00:26:45.340 --> 00:26:46.560
your whole system crashes, right, so

516
00:26:46.560 --> 00:26:50.460
you're kinda guaranteed to get those
log messages, so it's more reliable.

517
00:26:50.460 --> 00:26:52.220
That makes it nice.

518
00:26:52.220 --> 00:26:56.460
A lot of people though have software and
systems that depend on syslog.

519
00:26:56.460 --> 00:26:58.260
So I don't know that we'll
ever get away from that,

520
00:26:58.260 --> 00:27:02.210
but you probably see a lot of people run
both, like I'm running both now here.

521
00:27:02.210 --> 00:27:06.330
I haven't disabled syslog, so
I've got both systems in place and

522
00:27:06.330 --> 00:27:07.200
it works just fine.

523
00:27:07.200 --> 00:27:10.650
>> Yeah I guess it won't be until
those older systems start really

524
00:27:10.650 --> 00:27:14.110
going the way of the dodo that the new
systems will completely take over and

525
00:27:14.110 --> 00:27:16.870
we won't have to worry about the old
way anymore, we'll have nice new way.

526
00:27:16.870 --> 00:27:19.190
And maybe they'll have an even
newer way at that point, who knows.

527
00:27:19.190 --> 00:27:21.120
>> Yeah, it probably would have
happened already if there wasn't so

528
00:27:21.120 --> 00:27:24.975
much like controversy over system D but,
you know that's just how it is.

529
00:27:24.975 --> 00:27:25.950
[LAUGH]
>> Well Don, this was

530
00:27:25.950 --> 00:27:30.280
excellent information, the system logs,
being able to look at the logs,

531
00:27:30.280 --> 00:27:33.360
what happened, events that have occurred
>> That's really

532
00:27:33.360 --> 00:27:34.830
something that we need to know how to do.

533
00:27:34.830 --> 00:27:38.710
Because a lot of times, like Don was
saying before, those error messages,

534
00:27:38.710 --> 00:27:41.610
they're there to actually tell
us this is what's happened,

535
00:27:41.610 --> 00:27:44.780
this is the information you need to
know to get to the root of the problem.

536
00:27:44.780 --> 00:27:47.390
Find out where the error occurred,
why it happened.

537
00:27:47.390 --> 00:27:50.230
So being able to parse through our logs,
find out what's going on, or

538
00:27:50.230 --> 00:27:53.430
maybe if you've had some sort
of malfeasance going on,

539
00:27:53.430 --> 00:27:56.410
maybe somebody's trying to break in,
do things they shouldn't do,

540
00:27:56.410 --> 00:27:58.530
this is definitely gonna
help out with that as well.

541
00:27:58.530 --> 00:28:00.980
Don have we basically covered this?

542
00:28:00.980 --> 00:28:03.230
This is the good and a foundation right?

543
00:28:03.230 --> 00:28:04.460
>> Yep, there's a ton more in there.

544
00:28:04.460 --> 00:28:06.140
You know, poke around through
the configuration files,

545
00:28:06.140 --> 00:28:08.000
you'll see all the options,
they're well documented.

546
00:28:08.000 --> 00:28:09.220
It's a great system.

547
00:28:09.220 --> 00:28:14.290
And having a centralized syslog
server is so nice for tracking down

548
00:28:14.290 --> 00:28:18.410
security alerts and other things,
kind of correlating errors across servers.

549
00:28:18.410 --> 00:28:19.410
Really valuable stuff.

550
00:28:19.410 --> 00:28:20.190
>> Awesome, awesome.

551
00:28:20.190 --> 00:28:22.410
Well it looks like we've
wrapped up this show.

552
00:28:22.410 --> 00:28:24.800
Hopefully you guys out there
learned a lot from this one.

553
00:28:24.800 --> 00:28:27.990
Definitely take that to the bank, this
is gonna be good stuff in your career.

554
00:28:27.990 --> 00:28:32.260
That being said, it's time to sign off for
ITProTV I've been your host Daniel Lowry.

555
00:28:32.260 --> 00:28:33.100
>> And I'm Don Bissette.

556
00:28:33.100 --> 00:28:34.212
>> And we'll see you next time.

557

episodes.title: System Time
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.958
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:10.958 --> 00:00:15.457
All right, greetings everyone, and welcome
to another great episode of ITProTV.

3
00:00:15.457 --> 00:00:18.961
I'm your host Daniel Lowry and
here with me today is Don Pezet.

4
00:00:18.961 --> 00:00:20.240
How's it going today, Don?

5
00:00:20.240 --> 00:00:21.450
>> I'm doing great Daniel.

6
00:00:21.450 --> 00:00:25.120
Today we're gonna be talking
about one of the unsung

7
00:00:25.120 --> 00:00:28.090
heroes of the Linux server world,
which is time.

8
00:00:28.090 --> 00:00:32.430
Just setting our clock, and for those of
you that watch this live, before the show

9
00:00:32.430 --> 00:00:35.690
Daniel and I had a funny conversation
about, why do we care about this?

10
00:00:35.690 --> 00:00:36.992
We're just setting the time, right?

11
00:00:36.992 --> 00:00:40.290
We're gonna do a whole episode on setting
the clock on our stupid computer,

12
00:00:40.290 --> 00:00:42.600
and you might think to yourself
yeah it's no big deal,

13
00:00:42.600 --> 00:00:45.200
but on a work station it really
isn't a big deal, right?

14
00:00:45.200 --> 00:00:49.540
You set your clock during the install and
you're pretty much done, but on a server,

15
00:00:49.540 --> 00:00:54.000
having a properly synchronized clock
is really important all right, and

16
00:00:54.000 --> 00:00:55.710
let me just give you an example.

17
00:00:55.710 --> 00:01:00.690
So, let's say that a hacker manages
to penetrate one of your servers.

18
00:01:00.690 --> 00:01:01.418
You know what happened.

19
00:01:01.418 --> 00:01:05.690
You saw some warning signs or whatever, so
you have an idea that somebody broke into

20
00:01:05.690 --> 00:01:09.750
your system, and now you need to
figure out what systems were effected.

21
00:01:09.750 --> 00:01:12.070
All right well, you look at the log
messages on your server and

22
00:01:12.070 --> 00:01:13.770
it shows the attack happened at 3:53 pm.

23
00:01:15.068 --> 00:01:17.970
Then you go to your other servers,
you start looking at 3:53 PM to see what

24
00:01:17.970 --> 00:01:20.240
happens and
none of them really show anything.

25
00:01:20.240 --> 00:01:24.730
But, you've got one server
that's logging in UTC.

26
00:01:24.730 --> 00:01:28.240
You've got other servers that
are logging in their local time zone.

27
00:01:28.240 --> 00:01:31.480
You got other servers that are obeying
daylight savings time, and yet

28
00:01:31.480 --> 00:01:34.050
again other servers that just
have a wrong clock all together.

29
00:01:34.050 --> 00:01:36.910
Now when you look at the logs,
how do you know it happened at 3:53?

30
00:01:36.910 --> 00:01:39.980
It becomes very challenging and
really, really difficult, and

31
00:01:39.980 --> 00:01:42.180
if you're trying to coordinate
that against firewalls and

32
00:01:42.180 --> 00:01:46.680
intrusion detection devices, and other
things like that, it's just a nightmare.

33
00:01:46.680 --> 00:01:50.620
If you had a unified clock, if all of
your systems had a synchronized clock,

34
00:01:50.620 --> 00:01:54.150
that wouldn't be a problem, you'd know
exactly what time it was, and so,

35
00:01:54.150 --> 00:01:56.010
that's what we're gonna take
a look at in this episode.

36
00:01:56.010 --> 00:01:59.360
How do we ensure that we have the most
accurate time possible on our system for

37
00:01:59.360 --> 00:02:00.430
consistent network behavior?

38
00:02:00.430 --> 00:02:03.710
All right, well let's just
start with the simple stuff.

39
00:02:03.710 --> 00:02:06.640
Setting the clock right
here on our own system.

40
00:02:06.640 --> 00:02:10.370
I'm on a CentOS 7 box here, and
if I just type the date command,

41
00:02:10.370 --> 00:02:12.500
it'll tell me what time my
system thinks that it is,

42
00:02:12.500 --> 00:02:16.280
and you'll see my system thinks
it's June 23rd, which it is.

43
00:02:16.280 --> 00:02:17.420
That's good.

44
00:02:17.420 --> 00:02:21.040
It thinks it's 11:01
AM Eastern Daylight Time 2015.

45
00:02:21.040 --> 00:02:23.240
That's right.

46
00:02:23.240 --> 00:02:24.210
My clocks right.

47
00:02:24.210 --> 00:02:25.230
That's good.

48
00:02:25.230 --> 00:02:28.900
If you just installed your system though,
it may be wrong, or if your system has

49
00:02:28.900 --> 00:02:31.050
been powered off for a while and
you power it on it might be wrong.

50
00:02:31.050 --> 00:02:33.632
There's different thinks
that can make it be wrong.

51
00:02:33.632 --> 00:02:38.620
All right, so one of the number one things
that makes it be wrong is the time zone.

52
00:02:38.620 --> 00:02:40.585
When somebody installs a Linux distro,

53
00:02:40.585 --> 00:02:43.800
during the install it asks
them to pick a time zone.

54
00:02:43.800 --> 00:02:46.656
Well what if you're company has
offices in more than one state, or

55
00:02:46.656 --> 00:02:49.257
your in one of those states that
has more than one time zone and

56
00:02:49.257 --> 00:02:52.628
you ship a computer from one time zone
to another, now the time zone's wrong.

57
00:02:52.628 --> 00:02:56.579
And what I get, I get this all the time,
where you'll have a machine that's set for

58
00:02:56.579 --> 00:02:59.967
the Pacific Time zone, and somebody
brings it over to the East coast and

59
00:02:59.967 --> 00:03:01.287
it's three hours behind.

60
00:03:01.287 --> 00:03:03.133
And so what do they do,
they edit their clock and

61
00:03:03.133 --> 00:03:05.500
they move their clock ahead three hours.

62
00:03:05.500 --> 00:03:09.680
Well, if you move your clock
instead of changing the time zone,

63
00:03:09.680 --> 00:03:13.760
your clock is now off by three hours, and
that's gonna break all sorts of things.

64
00:03:13.760 --> 00:03:16.940
You'll have things like IP SEC
encryption to stop working because that.

65
00:03:16.940 --> 00:03:21.180
So, instead you should have corrected
the timezone, not the clock, but

66
00:03:21.180 --> 00:03:24.200
changing the timezone is
unfortunately difficult

67
00:03:24.200 --> 00:03:27.220
because different distros handle
time zones different ways.

68
00:03:27.220 --> 00:03:30.680
So let me show you guys a couple of the
variations that you're gonna bump into.

69
00:03:30.680 --> 00:03:37.611
One of the easiest methods is when
a system uses the /etc/timezone file.

70
00:03:37.611 --> 00:03:41.157
So it's one of the first things
that I look for, is /etc/timezone,

71
00:03:41.157 --> 00:03:44.200
but if you look on my system
I don't have /etc/timezone.

72
00:03:44.200 --> 00:03:47.208
If you do, it's just a text file,
you edit it,

73
00:03:47.208 --> 00:03:50.761
you change the time zone in there,
you reboot, right.

74
00:03:50.761 --> 00:03:53.793
You do kinda have to reboot, which stinks,
but it's the clock so you gotta do it.

75
00:03:53.793 --> 00:03:55.270
So there we go.

76
00:03:55.270 --> 00:03:58.000
That's one way to do it,
but I don't have it.

77
00:03:58.000 --> 00:04:02.410
Another one is /etc/localtime, and

78
00:04:02.410 --> 00:04:06.970
if I look at my files in here,
I do have /etc/localtime.

79
00:04:06.970 --> 00:04:08.001
Well, sort of.

80
00:04:08.001 --> 00:04:09.156
It's a sim link, right.

81
00:04:09.156 --> 00:04:15.141
So if I do a little ls-la for
localtime, I can see it's sim linked to

82
00:04:15.141 --> 00:04:20.950
/usr/share/zoneinfo/America/Kentucky/Mont-
icello.

83
00:04:20.950 --> 00:04:23.930
What's that all about?

84
00:04:23.930 --> 00:04:29.022
Well, the local time file is sim
linked to a time zone file, and

85
00:04:29.022 --> 00:04:34.330
in CentOS, and Red Hat they store all the
time zone files in /usr/share/zoneinfo.

86
00:04:34.330 --> 00:04:39.070
And all the zones are defined in there,
and you can just sim link to that, and

87
00:04:39.070 --> 00:04:40.040
now you'll be in the right time zone.

88
00:04:40.040 --> 00:04:43.020
So I can change from this Kentucky,
Monticello,

89
00:04:43.020 --> 00:04:45.720
which I have no idea where that city is,
I mean its obviously in Kentucky, but

90
00:04:45.720 --> 00:04:47.300
that's the extent of my knowledge.

91
00:04:47.300 --> 00:04:49.310
I could pick a different city.

92
00:04:49.310 --> 00:04:51.360
So maybe I wanted to
send link it to New York.

93
00:04:51.360 --> 00:04:56.804
Right so,
if I went to /usr/shares/zoneinfo.

94
00:04:56.804 --> 00:05:02.370
I'll see countries and
I can go into America, and

95
00:05:02.370 --> 00:05:08.220
inside of America I start to see various
states and other countries that are here.

96
00:05:08.220 --> 00:05:13.868
So maybe I can find New York in the list
and sure enough, there is New York,

97
00:05:13.868 --> 00:05:17.600
and oh, well apparently New York doesn't
have cities underneath it and so

98
00:05:17.600 --> 00:05:19.150
it's just a straight up file New York.

99
00:05:19.150 --> 00:05:21.180
So I could link right to New York and
I'd be set.

100
00:05:21.180 --> 00:05:24.350
You'll see there's also
other abbreviations in here,

101
00:05:24.350 --> 00:05:28.270
like inside of zone info I've got est and
est5edt.

102
00:05:29.440 --> 00:05:32.155
We could be daylight time versus
not observing daylight time,

103
00:05:32.155 --> 00:05:35.180
cuz some people are in the Eastern time
zone but don't observe daylight time.

104
00:05:35.180 --> 00:05:40.098
So I can pick between those to choose
the right one for me, all right.

105
00:05:40.098 --> 00:05:43.760
Your distro may not have the exact
same entries that I do though.

106
00:05:43.760 --> 00:05:45.276
So you might have to
browse around to try and

107
00:05:45.276 --> 00:05:47.272
find the one that matches up
best with what you've got.

108
00:05:47.272 --> 00:05:48.970
All right, just be aware of that.

109
00:05:48.970 --> 00:05:51.690
>> Now Don, are we stuck with
what they give us in our distro?

110
00:05:51.690 --> 00:05:55.110
Or can we add different,
like if I don't see the the correct

111
00:05:55.110 --> 00:05:57.510
time zone that I would like for
myself, can I add that in?

112
00:05:57.510 --> 00:05:58.330

out and synchronize against that.

341
00:17:29.300 --> 00:17:31.860
Notice how it's telling me
the NTP socket is in use?

342
00:17:31.860 --> 00:17:34.230
That's cuz the NTP service is using it.

343
00:17:34.230 --> 00:17:38.920
So if I want to use ntpdate I'm gonna
have to stop my NTP service, so

344
00:17:38.920 --> 00:17:45.330
I'll stop it, and then I can use
ntpdate to go and do that update.

345
00:17:45.330 --> 00:17:47.990
So it's reaching out to that server,
trying to set my date.

346
00:17:47.990 --> 00:17:51.180
And then once that's done I can
start the NTP service again.

347
00:17:51.180 --> 00:17:51.990
And so it will be up and running.

348
00:17:51.990 --> 00:17:53.130
There we go.

349
00:17:53.130 --> 00:17:56.530
And now I'll just start that
back again and we're set.

350
00:17:56.530 --> 00:18:00.295
Now look at the output that I got on that,
it got a date and

351
00:18:00.295 --> 00:18:04.960
it's saying adjust time server
offset 0.028978 seconds.

352
00:18:06.670 --> 00:18:10.780
I'm doing an offset of .02 seconds,
but why am I doing that?

353
00:18:10.780 --> 00:18:12.500
That's correcting for the time it took for

354
00:18:12.500 --> 00:18:15.720
my connection to get to that
other server and back again.

355
00:18:15.720 --> 00:18:19.185
If I picked a server that was closer,
that offset might be smaller, right?

356
00:18:19.185 --> 00:18:22.609
So, if I stop the service and

357
00:18:22.609 --> 00:18:27.048
pick like, let me just do us.pool.

358
00:18:27.048 --> 00:18:30.785
This should hit servers that are
geographically closer to me, and when it

359
00:18:30.785 --> 00:18:35.270
does I should see a smaller offset,
unless I just pick a really bad server.

360
00:18:35.270 --> 00:18:36.400
There we go.

361
00:18:36.400 --> 00:18:41.720
So see how the offset here was .02 and
this one is .001.

362
00:18:41.720 --> 00:18:44.800
I actually ended up with a negative
offset for some reason, that's odd.

363
00:18:44.800 --> 00:18:47.810
My clock must have been ahead,
so it's having to move me back.

364
00:18:47.810 --> 00:18:49.520
But I can kinda see what that offset is.

365
00:18:49.520 --> 00:18:52.200
So, just be aware that it
is kinda correcting for

366
00:18:52.200 --> 00:18:53.340
the time it takes to get to those servers.

367
00:18:54.610 --> 00:18:59.120
But, assuming you're using NTP and
you've pointed it to a common

368
00:18:59.120 --> 00:19:02.780
server that it's gonna be all your
systems are synchronizing off of,

369
00:19:02.780 --> 00:19:06.740
all your systems should have very accurate
clocks that are very much in line.

370
00:19:06.740 --> 00:19:09.558
And that's really important for
proper management of your system.

371
00:19:09.558 --> 00:19:10.340
All right.

372
00:19:10.340 --> 00:19:14.357
The only other thing
worth mentioning I guess,

373
00:19:14.357 --> 00:19:18.073
we could have updated, I used ntpdate, and

374
00:19:18.073 --> 00:19:23.530
the problem there was I had to
stop the NTP service to do it.

375
00:19:23.530 --> 00:19:29.490
You can also use the ntpq,
that query utility,

376
00:19:29.490 --> 00:19:35.940
if you follow it with -gq,
like that, ntpq -gq.

377
00:19:35.940 --> 00:19:38.393
Oh nope, maybe not.

378
00:19:38.393 --> 00:19:40.669
Is it qg?

379
00:19:40.669 --> 00:19:41.772
Do I have it backwards?

380
00:19:41.772 --> 00:19:42.810
>> I think it is gq.

381
00:19:42.810 --> 00:19:43.770
>> Huh.

382
00:19:43.770 --> 00:19:46.700
Why is it not working for me?

383
00:19:46.700 --> 00:19:49.187
Oh, because I'm typing the wrong command.
It's ntpd -gq.

384
00:19:49.187 --> 00:19:51.080
There we go.

385
00:19:51.080 --> 00:19:54.060
That is gonna reach out and
synchronize your time also.

386
00:19:54.060 --> 00:19:58.760
And the advantage of it over the other
ones is if I'm running my NTP service,

387
00:19:58.760 --> 00:20:02.390
see how I can update my time even
though the service is running, right?

388
00:20:02.390 --> 00:20:03.090
That's kind of nice.

389
00:20:03.090 --> 00:20:05.875
Now I don't get any output because what
it's actually doing is just telling

390
00:20:05.875 --> 00:20:08.325
the service to do the update instead
of it doing the update itself.

391
00:20:08.325 --> 00:20:12.517
So just be aware of that
little difference, ntpd -gq.

392
00:20:12.517 --> 00:20:13.945
That tells us to go out and get that time.

393
00:20:15.850 --> 00:20:21.430
All right, well,
I think that's about it as far as time.

394
00:20:21.430 --> 00:20:23.810
We did wanna do a special episode
on it because it is important,

395
00:20:23.810 --> 00:20:27.410
it is something you wanna have set,
having that common server is important.

396
00:20:27.410 --> 00:20:30.610
If you're gonna be the server, we saw
where we could turn that function on,

397
00:20:30.610 --> 00:20:33.350
you set your allow list to say
who's allowed to sync off of it.

398
00:20:33.350 --> 00:20:35.160
Make sure you open up
your firewall portal or

399
00:20:35.160 --> 00:20:38.260
people won't be able to connect there,
and you can get up and going.

400
00:20:38.260 --> 00:20:41.390
It's a neat system,
there's really no reason not to use it.

401
00:20:41.390 --> 00:20:44.110
You wanna have your clocks in sync.

402
00:20:44.110 --> 00:20:47.160
>> Now Don, do you have to worry
about things like reflective or

403
00:20:47.160 --> 00:20:51.280
amplified denial service attacks
with these NTP service running?

404
00:20:51.280 --> 00:20:51.910
>> It could, yeah.

405
00:20:51.910 --> 00:20:54.330
If you have an external time server and

406
00:20:54.330 --> 00:20:58.810
somebody attacks the external time server,
it could cause an offset in your clocks.

407
00:20:58.810 --> 00:20:59.430
Now for

408
00:20:59.430 --> 00:21:02.240
most people that's not gonna be a problem
cuz all your systems are syncing the same.

409
00:21:02.240 --> 00:21:04.070
So they all end up with the offset.

410
00:21:04.070 --> 00:21:08.860
But it's possible an attacker can
manipulate that clock to then

411
00:21:08.860 --> 00:21:13.570
use it to do replay attacks
on IP sect tunnels and stuff.

412
00:21:13.570 --> 00:21:14.210
It is possible.

413
00:21:14.210 --> 00:21:16.390
It is a very complex attack,
but it is possible.

414
00:21:16.390 --> 00:21:20.820
So the solution there is to have
your own internal time server

415
00:21:20.820 --> 00:21:22.540
as opposed to relying on an external one.

416
00:21:22.540 --> 00:21:24.660
The internal one can still be attacked,
but

417
00:21:24.660 --> 00:21:27.020
it's far less likely than one that's out
there on the internet that's public.

418
00:21:27.020 --> 00:21:29.560
You have your own private one,
you manually set the time,

419
00:21:29.560 --> 00:21:31.270
you set the hardware
clock on that one server.

420
00:21:31.270 --> 00:21:34.950
It then services time for your network,
and everybody syncs off of it.

421
00:21:34.950 --> 00:21:37.100
That kind of alleviates that a little bit.

422
00:21:37.100 --> 00:21:39.230
You can still have an internal attack,
and that's always a risk.

423
00:21:41.960 --> 00:21:45.495
Time is but an illusion, right?

424
00:21:45.495 --> 00:21:47.851
[CROSSTALK]
>> Now Rick in our chatroom had a really

425
00:21:47.851 --> 00:21:51.750
good question, how many NTP servers
do you think is a good one to have?

426
00:21:51.750 --> 00:21:53.390
A good number of NTP?

427
00:21:53.390 --> 00:21:54.020
>> One.

428
00:21:54.020 --> 00:21:54.600
>> One?

429
00:21:54.600 --> 00:21:55.690
>> I know a lot of people think,

430
00:21:55.690 --> 00:21:57.680
well this is important I want
redundancy and all that stuff.

431
00:21:57.680 --> 00:22:00.120
But at the end of the day if
your time-server fails and

432
00:22:00.120 --> 00:22:04.320
goes offline, it's gonna take awhile for
your clocks to get offset, right?

433
00:22:04.320 --> 00:22:08.280
Most computer clocks only lose
a fraction of a second a month.

434
00:22:08.280 --> 00:22:12.610
So, you could run for years and
not have a time offset that's measurable.

435
00:22:12.610 --> 00:22:14.320
Measurable by humans, at least.

436
00:22:14.320 --> 00:22:17.500
So, I usually don't worry about
redundancy with time servers.

437
00:22:17.500 --> 00:22:18.775
If my time server fails,

438
00:22:18.775 --> 00:22:22.292
it's kind of trivial to just spin up a new
machine and use it as a time server.

439
00:22:22.292 --> 00:22:25.980
Or oftentimes, I'll use a router or a
firewall in my system as the time server.

440
00:22:25.980 --> 00:22:28.955
Cuz if that fails network's down anyway,
so you got bigger problems.

441
00:22:28.955 --> 00:22:29.730
>> [LAUGH]
>> But

442
00:22:29.730 --> 00:22:32.490
I don't normally bother with
redundant time servers.

443
00:22:33.550 --> 00:22:36.730
I know a lot of people
in Microsoft Worlds will

444
00:22:36.730 --> 00:22:39.110
use things like Microsoft domain
control versus their time servers.

445
00:22:39.110 --> 00:22:40.810
You're gonna have more than
one domain controller, so

446
00:22:40.810 --> 00:22:42.490
now you have more than one time server.

447
00:22:42.490 --> 00:22:44.470
But I don't normally worry about it.

448
00:22:44.470 --> 00:22:45.930
In the time server world,

449
00:22:45.930 --> 00:22:48.680
they actually have this whole hierarchy
you can use that are called stratums.

450
00:22:48.680 --> 00:22:52.250
And you can have stratum one servers and
stratum two servers and stratum three.

451
00:22:52.250 --> 00:22:54.010
So you can set up tiers, it's hierarchy.

452
00:22:54.010 --> 00:22:57.890
So you have a core time server, and then
it syncs down to two sub-time servers, and

453
00:22:57.890 --> 00:22:59.330
then they sync out to clients.

454
00:22:59.330 --> 00:23:01.870
You can do crazy stuff
like that if you want.

455
00:23:01.870 --> 00:23:05.470
Even if I had a network of 100,000 servers

456
00:23:05.470 --> 00:23:07.820
I'd probably still do just one time
server, unless it got overwhelmed.

457
00:23:07.820 --> 00:23:09.020
Right?
If it's just too much work for

458
00:23:09.020 --> 00:23:11.450
that one time server to handle,
then I might have more than one.

459
00:23:11.450 --> 00:23:14.250
But for redundancy purposes,
I wouldn't bother.

460
00:23:14.250 --> 00:23:18.200
>> And do we get maybe like the crazy
kind of log in problems that you have?

461
00:23:18.200 --> 00:23:20.480
Like in a Windows Active Directory Domain,

462
00:23:20.480 --> 00:23:26.300
if your time is off on your local machine
then what is on the Active Directory,

463
00:23:26.300 --> 00:23:28.770
the AD, the domain controller,
it won't let you log in.

464
00:23:28.770 --> 00:23:30.780
Do we get that kind of weirdness as well?

465
00:23:30.780 --> 00:23:32.720
>> Yeah.
So that problem you're describing,

466
00:23:32.720 --> 00:23:35.590
you described it as a Windows problem,
it's not actually a Windows problem.

467
00:23:35.590 --> 00:23:37.620
It's a Kerberos problem.

468
00:23:37.620 --> 00:23:40.150
And Kerberos authentication
came from Unix.

469
00:23:40.150 --> 00:23:42.240
It's right here in our own systems.

470
00:23:42.240 --> 00:23:45.470
With Kerberos you don't send your
password across the network,

471
00:23:45.470 --> 00:23:48.020
you send a hashed version
of your password.

472
00:23:48.020 --> 00:23:52.010
And part of the hash calculation
is using your clock to set it.

473
00:23:52.010 --> 00:23:55.660
Well if your clock is off
by more than a few minutes,

474
00:23:55.660 --> 00:23:57.880
it causes that hash not
to calculate right and

475
00:23:57.880 --> 00:24:00.550
it causes Kerberos to fail
the authentication, and you can't log in.

476
00:24:00.550 --> 00:24:04.180
So that would happen on a Windows Box,
a Mac, a Linux box.

477
00:24:04.180 --> 00:24:05.398
Anybody that's using Kerberos,

478
00:24:05.398 --> 00:24:07.970
it's time sensitive you've
got to be within two minutes.

479
00:24:07.970 --> 00:24:10.540
Remember at the beginning of the show
I mentioned, hey I just went from

480
00:24:10.540 --> 00:24:14.040
the Pacific Time zone to the Eastern,
I'll change my clock ahead three hours.

481
00:24:14.040 --> 00:24:16.210
I'm not changing my timezone,
I'm changing my clock.

482
00:24:16.210 --> 00:24:18.760
Now all of my packets are three
hours in the future, or

483
00:24:18.760 --> 00:24:21.170
three hours in the past,
stuff like Kerberos will fail.

484
00:24:21.170 --> 00:24:22.900
You won't be able to login to that domain,
or

485
00:24:22.900 --> 00:24:26.500
you won't be able to use IPsec to connect
to another session on another machine.

486
00:24:26.500 --> 00:24:27.570
That's the kind of problem you have,

487
00:24:27.570 --> 00:24:30.770
cuz it sees a packet that's three
hours in the future and it says,

488
00:24:30.770 --> 00:24:33.440
oh somebody modified this data,
it's not valid, I'll throw it out.

489
00:24:33.440 --> 00:24:37.230
Or they see it three hours in the past and
they say, oh this is a replay attack,

490
00:24:37.230 --> 00:24:38.380
I'm gonna throw that away.

491
00:24:38.380 --> 00:24:41.390
So we gotta have that synchronized
time for that to work properly.

492
00:24:41.390 --> 00:24:41.900
>> Awesome.

493
00:24:41.900 --> 00:24:42.680
Good stuff, Don.

494
00:24:42.680 --> 00:24:45.560
This is actually a little more
interesting than we probably

495
00:24:45.560 --> 00:24:46.840
thought it was going to be.

496
00:24:46.840 --> 00:24:48.150
You think, it's nothing to it.

497
00:24:48.150 --> 00:24:49.350
It's just a little clock.

498
00:24:49.350 --> 00:24:52.070
What can possibly be the big
hairy deal about this?

499
00:24:52.070 --> 00:24:56.310
Well obviously we're seeing it does have
a lot to do with how these systems run,

500
00:24:56.310 --> 00:24:58.340
how they maintain,
how they work correctly.

501
00:24:58.340 --> 00:25:02.590
And we gotta keep that time right if we
do want them to actually work correctly.

502
00:25:02.590 --> 00:25:03.220
So.
>> Yeah.

503
00:25:03.220 --> 00:25:04.630
>> It's been a good episode Don.

504
00:25:04.630 --> 00:25:07.400
>> And you know we had a question
in the chat room about

505
00:25:07.400 --> 00:25:10.100
what happens if the time server goes
crazy and hands out some insane date?

506
00:25:10.100 --> 00:25:12.193
You know,
it hands out like that we're in 1901.

507
00:25:12.193 --> 00:25:13.530
>> [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] For the year.

508
00:25:13.530 --> 00:25:15.890
Cuz the year is passed with this stuff.

509
00:25:15.890 --> 00:25:18.930
Well, that now all your machines will
sync that and you'll all be in 1901.

510
00:25:18.930 --> 00:25:20.760
And that, that sucks, right?

511
00:25:20.760 --> 00:25:21.640
That's a problem.

512
00:25:21.640 --> 00:25:26.230
But [LAUGH] at the end of the day all
your machines have the same time, and

513
00:25:26.230 --> 00:25:30.650
so, at least they still function and
they work and you can fix the time.

514
00:25:30.650 --> 00:25:32.590
David and
Rick added some comments in there, and

515
00:25:32.590 --> 00:25:36.620
they're absolutely right that if you have
four time servers or ten time servers

516
00:25:36.620 --> 00:25:40.220
it can actually sync across more than
one and detect when one is going crazy.

517
00:25:40.220 --> 00:25:43.280
But that's a lot of infrastructure for
most organizations.

518
00:25:43.280 --> 00:25:44.310
We don't normally worry about it.

519
00:25:44.310 --> 00:25:46.020
If the time goes crazy you
just go to that system and

520
00:25:46.020 --> 00:25:48.240
fix it, it's not normally
gonna be server standing.

521
00:25:48.240 --> 00:25:51.400
But if time is super critical
in your environment you might

522
00:25:51.400 --> 00:25:52.580
need more than one time server.

523
00:25:52.580 --> 00:25:56.134
And that's usually where it's better to
just rely on an external time server and

524
00:25:56.134 --> 00:25:58.930
then that way they deal with all
that extra infrastructure and

525
00:25:58.930 --> 00:26:00.230
you just hang on it.

526
00:26:00.230 --> 00:26:02.126
And that's how this system was
configured by default, right?

527
00:26:02.126 --> 00:26:04.330
The CentOS pools are what
I was reaching out to, and

528
00:26:04.330 --> 00:26:07.080
I was reaching out to four servers.

529
00:26:07.080 --> 00:26:09.465
>> Well it looks like time
is actually relative.

530
00:26:09.465 --> 00:26:10.480
[LAUGH] That being said,

531
00:26:10.480 --> 00:26:13.277
it looks like we've wrapped up
another episode here at ITProTV.

532
00:26:13.277 --> 00:26:16.423
We'll go ahead and sign off,
I've been your host Daniel Lowrie.

533
00:26:16.423 --> 00:26:17.340
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

534
00:26:17.340 --> 00:26:18.628
>> And we'll see you next time.

535
00:26:18.628 --> 00:26:25.270
[SOUND]

episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.897
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:10.897 --> 00:00:14.815
All right greetings everyone and welcome
to another great Great episode of ITProTV.

3
00:00:14.815 --> 00:00:18.135
I'll be your host Daniel Lowrie and
here with me today is well,

4
00:00:18.135 --> 00:00:19.065
my good friend, Don Pezet.

5
00:00:19.065 --> 00:00:20.375
How's it going today Don?

6
00:00:20.375 --> 00:00:21.615
>> I'm doing great Daniel.

7
00:00:21.615 --> 00:00:25.965
In this episode we're gonna be taking
a look at scheduling jobs inside of Linux.

8
00:00:25.965 --> 00:00:28.947
In other words, making stuff happen
when you're not there to make it happen.

9
00:00:28.947 --> 00:00:30.874
>> [LAUGH] Well,
we're gonna be forward looking.

10
00:00:30.874 --> 00:00:31.548
>> Forward looking.

11
00:00:31.548 --> 00:00:35.574
[LAUGH] So this is one of my, it's kind
of one of my favorite things to do but

12
00:00:35.574 --> 00:00:39.336
it's a lot of times there's stuff
we want to happen on our server but

13
00:00:39.336 --> 00:00:43.075
we want it to happen at a time
that's not really convenient for us.

14
00:00:43.075 --> 00:00:45.010
Right?
I wanna install an update but

15
00:00:45.010 --> 00:00:48.020
I want it to happen at one AM or
I wanna reboot the server but

16
00:00:48.020 --> 00:00:48.780
I want it to happen at three AM.

17
00:00:48.780 --> 00:00:53.110
The only problem is I don't wanna be awake
at one AM or three AM, I wanna be in bed.

18
00:00:54.130 --> 00:00:56.900
So fortunately we got a couple
of different systems inside of

19
00:00:56.900 --> 00:00:58.350
Linux that will let us do that.

20
00:00:59.440 --> 00:01:03.540
We can give it certain commands and
tell it to do them later on in the day.

21
00:01:03.540 --> 00:01:05.000
At some other point.

22
00:01:05.000 --> 00:01:09.040
There are a few different ways to do it
though and I wanna show you each one.

23
00:01:09.040 --> 00:01:11.610
And I think I'm gonna go a slightly
different order than my notes here but

24
00:01:11.610 --> 00:01:13.970
they each have a different purpose.

25
00:01:13.970 --> 00:01:18.050
One of the easiest way is if
I want to reboot my computer

26
00:01:18.050 --> 00:01:18.920
I wanna reboot it at 1 AM.

27
00:01:18.920 --> 00:01:20.670
All right?

28
00:01:20.670 --> 00:01:21.940
It's just a one time thing.

29
00:01:21.940 --> 00:01:24.810
Just in the morning,
tonight at 1 AM, I want it to reboot.

30
00:01:24.810 --> 00:01:26.220
I don't want to do it again,
just one time.

31
00:01:26.220 --> 00:01:30.600
One of the easiest ways to do it,
is to use the at command.

32
00:01:30.600 --> 00:01:31.890
At.
A-T.

33
00:01:31.890 --> 00:01:34.810
That means, I want you do do
something at a certain time.

the faster you're gonna get at it,
and it's gonna be really easy for you.

488
00:24:02.088 --> 00:24:05.639
>> Yep, another good question in
the chat room was about time zones and

489
00:24:05.639 --> 00:24:07.370
how that's all handled.

490
00:24:07.370 --> 00:24:10.580
Well, these times that I'm providing,
it is all local time.

491
00:24:10.580 --> 00:24:14.240
So if daylight savings time kicks in, it
honors that, 3 AM during daylight savings

492
00:24:14.240 --> 00:24:16.930
time it'll be different than 3
AM not in daylight savings time.

493
00:24:16.930 --> 00:24:18.900
It recognizes that and it handles it.

494
00:24:18.900 --> 00:24:19.990
If you want it to happen at UTC,

495
00:24:19.990 --> 00:24:23.770
you need to change the timezone
of your server to UTC.

496
00:24:23.770 --> 00:24:25.270
That's just kind of part of cron.

497
00:24:25.270 --> 00:24:26.920
I'm not aware of a way to override that.

498
00:24:26.920 --> 00:24:27.456
Do you know one Daniel?

499
00:24:27.456 --> 00:24:28.652
>> Not that I'm aware of, no.

500
00:24:28.652 --> 00:24:32.107
>> So, you'll see a lot of people where
they just set their servers to UTC and

501
00:24:32.107 --> 00:24:32.850
that's that.

502
00:24:32.850 --> 00:24:35.240
You can still have your desktop
set to the right time zone, but

503
00:24:35.240 --> 00:24:36.460
you'll leave your servers at UTC.

504
00:24:36.460 --> 00:24:39.340
Now your cron jobs observe that and
now they ignore daylight savings time.

505
00:24:39.340 --> 00:24:40.820
Cuz it's just that universal time.

506
00:24:40.820 --> 00:24:42.160
So, yep.

507
00:24:42.160 --> 00:24:42.880
>> Awesome stuff.

508
00:24:42.880 --> 00:24:46.680
Hopefully you guys are picking up
a lot of cool Linux utilities all,

509
00:24:46.680 --> 00:24:47.650
you know, getting that,

510
00:24:47.650 --> 00:24:52.230
getting that Linux bug dug right into you
and permeating through out your systems.

511
00:24:52.230 --> 00:24:53.068
>> Permeating.
>> That's right,

512
00:24:53.068 --> 00:24:54.112
I like to use big words from time to time.

513
00:24:54.112 --> 00:24:57.159
[LAUGH] All right Don, have we,
have we covered cron, the basics of cron,

514
00:24:57.159 --> 00:24:58.600
what we need to know for this exam.

515

>> Yeah, pretty much wraps up and
don't forget the @command,

516
00:25:00.630 --> 00:25:04.170
still useful if you just want to do
a single instance of an occurrence.

517
00:25:04.170 --> 00:25:04.805
>> Very good stuff.

518
00:25:04.805 --> 00:25:06.940
All right,
looks like we've come to the end of yet

519
00:25:06.940 --> 00:25:08.770
another great episode here at ITProTV.

520
00:25:08.770 --> 00:25:10.560
Hopefully you guys loved it.

521
00:25:10.560 --> 00:25:12.030
We sure enjoyed making it.

522

Signing off,
I've been your host Daniel Lowery

>> And I'm Don Pezet.

All right.

3
00:00:11.560 --> 00:00:14.760
Greetings everyone, and welcome to
another great episode of ITProTV.

4
00:00:14.760 --> 00:00:16.920
I'll be your host, Daniel Lowery, and

5
00:00:16.920 --> 00:00:19.842
here with me today is none
other than Don TCP/IP Pezet.

6
00:00:19.842 --> 00:00:22.160
>> [LAUGH]
>> How's it going today Don?

7
00:00:22.160 --> 00:00:24.240
>> I am doing great
>> Yeah,

8
00:00:24.240 --> 00:00:27.210
I wish my name was a part
of that abbreviation.

9
00:00:27.210 --> 00:00:30.920
In this episode we're going to start
talking about TCP/IP, which is honestly

10
00:00:30.920 --> 00:00:35.810
the single most important protocol
stack that we use in networking today.

11
00:00:35.810 --> 00:00:37.260
So, it's a great episode.

12
00:00:37.260 --> 00:00:39.810
We're going to talk about some neat
foundational knowledge that we

13
00:00:39.810 --> 00:00:40.480
really need to know for

14
00:00:40.480 --> 00:00:44.930
the exam if we're going to be setting
up networks for a Linux based system.

15
00:00:44.930 --> 00:00:49.340
Now everything that we cover in this
episode is really foundational knowledge.

16
00:00:49.340 --> 00:00:51.320
It's general knowledge
that you need to have.

17
00:00:51.320 --> 00:00:53.560
If you're already Network Plus certified,

18
00:00:53.560 --> 00:00:56.860
well we're not going to break any
new boundaries in this episode.

19
00:00:56.860 --> 00:00:59.040
And you won't hurt my
feelings if you skip past it.

20
00:00:59.040 --> 00:01:02.584
But if you're not Network Plus certified,
if you haven't worked with networks,

21
00:01:02.584 --> 00:01:05.821
what we're going to cover today,
are the basic things that we need to know,

22
00:01:05.821 --> 00:01:08.453
before we go and assign IP
addresses inside of a Linux system,

23
00:01:08.453 --> 00:01:10.660
before we set up a basic network and
get that going.

24
00:01:10.660 --> 00:01:14.760
So it's not really Linux specific today,
it's TCP/IP specific.

25
00:01:14.760 --> 00:01:15.360
All right.

26
00:01:15.360 --> 00:01:18.720
Now, we're gonna focus on
the second part of that acronym.

27
00:01:18.720 --> 00:01:24.210
The full acronym is transmission control
protocol slash internet protocol.

28
00:01:24.210 --> 00:01:26.575
Notice how there's two protocols.

29
00:01:26.575 --> 00:01:28.650
TCP/IP is not one protocol.

30
00:01:28.650 --> 00:01:30.710
It's what's called a protocol stack,

31
00:01:30.710 --> 00:01:35.400
more than one protocol working together
to create full network connectivity.

32
00:01:35.400 --> 00:01:38.890
Individually neither piece can allow
you to talk to another computer.

33
00:01:38.890 --> 00:01:41.010
You have to use them all together,
all right.

34
00:01:41.010 --> 00:01:44.190
But in this episode we're going
to focus just on the IP piece,

35
00:01:44.190 --> 00:01:46.120
the internet protocol.

36
00:01:46.120 --> 00:01:48.920
IP is really, really important.

37
00:01:48.920 --> 00:01:51.720
It provides one primary function.

38
00:01:51.720 --> 00:01:56.630
And that is to help you find
another computer on the network.

39
00:01:56.630 --> 00:01:59.520
It doesn't help you talk to that computer,
it doesn't help you actually

40
00:01:59.520 --> 00:02:02.650
send data to that computer,
it just helps you find somebody.

41
00:02:02.650 --> 00:02:04.120
All right, where the heck are they?

42
00:02:04.120 --> 00:02:04.960
How do I get to them?

43
00:02:04.960 --> 00:02:08.110
All right, that's what IP is all about.

44
00:02:08.110 --> 00:02:11.020
The most common version of IP that's
out there is IP version four,

45
00:02:11.020 --> 00:02:12.440
internet protocol version four.

46
00:02:12.440 --> 00:02:14.210
It's what's used across the internet,

47
00:02:14.210 --> 00:02:18.020
almost every computer system
today supports IP version four.

48
00:02:18.020 --> 00:02:21.200
There is a newer version of it,
though, called IP version six.

49
00:02:21.200 --> 00:02:23.180
And it's important that
we know about that.

50
00:02:23.180 --> 00:02:25.590
The exam doesn't hit on
IPv6 very hard at all,

51
00:02:25.590 --> 00:02:27.960
but It is something that's
coming down the line.

52
00:02:27.960 --> 00:02:29.230
We're seeing more and more of it so

53
00:02:29.230 --> 00:02:32.710
we'll talk a little bit about it towards
the end of the episode, all right.

54
00:02:32.710 --> 00:02:33.570
Let's talk about IPv4.

55
00:02:34.790 --> 00:02:39.200
If you have a Linux box, and you wanna get
it so that it can browse to the Internet.

56
00:02:39.200 --> 00:02:42.720
If you wanna get it where it can talk to
other computers on the network, one of

57
00:02:42.720 --> 00:02:47.330
the first steps you're gonna have to do is
setting up an IP address on your system..

58
00:02:47.330 --> 00:02:49.910
The IP address,
your address, it's a number.

59
00:02:49.910 --> 00:02:51.640
A number that identifies your computer and

60
00:02:51.640 --> 00:02:55.010
the other computers on
the network have a number also.

61
00:02:55.010 --> 00:02:57.490
And if we know our number and
we know their number,

62
00:02:57.490 --> 00:02:59.360
then in theory we can find them.

63
00:02:59.360 --> 00:03:01.630
I equate it to like a street address.

64
00:03:01.630 --> 00:03:04.876
The building I'm in right now
is 6933 Northwest 4th Boulevard.

65
00:03:04.876 --> 00:03:06.201
All right.

66
00:03:06.201 --> 00:03:09.260
What does that mean?

67
00:03:09.260 --> 00:03:12.430
Well, Northwest 4th Boulevard,
that's the street that we're on.

68
00:03:12.430 --> 00:03:15.310
That's the road outside the building here.

69
00:03:15.310 --> 00:03:18.430
And then 6933,
that's this building that I'm standing in.

70
00:03:18.430 --> 00:03:22.710
So if you know the building address
is 6933 Northwest 4th Boulevard,

71
00:03:22.710 --> 00:03:24.430
you can find this building, right?

72
00:03:24.430 --> 00:03:26.730
Throw it on Google Maps or
whatever and you'll find it.

73
00:03:26.730 --> 00:03:29.170
Well, that's how IP addresses work.

74
00:03:29.170 --> 00:03:32.290
Part of the IP address
represents your network and

75
00:03:32.290 --> 00:03:34.850
the other part of the address
represents your host.

76
00:03:34.850 --> 00:03:35.980
Let me show you guys a sample here.

77
00:03:35.980 --> 00:03:39.720
So, I've got on my machine
a sample IP address here,

78
00:03:39.720 --> 00:03:42.730
a pretty common one, 192.168.0.1.

79
00:03:42.730 --> 00:03:43.760
Right.

80
00:03:43.760 --> 00:03:48.310
Part of that represents a network,
and part of it represents a host.

81
00:03:48.310 --> 00:03:52.902
So it's actually made up of these
two pieces, a NetworkID and

82
00:03:52.902 --> 00:03:54.591
a HostID, all right.

83
00:03:54.591 --> 00:03:58.020
The NetworkID, or I should probably just
put a plus in there instead, there we go.

84
00:03:58.020 --> 00:03:59.440
The NetworkID is my network.

85
00:03:59.440 --> 00:04:01.590
And that would be like my street, right?

86
00:04:01.590 --> 00:04:04.550
So it would be like NW 4th Blvd, right?

87
00:04:05.860 --> 00:04:09.140
There are many buildings
here on NW 4th Blvd.

88
00:04:09.140 --> 00:04:10.090
We're not the only ones.

89
00:04:10.090 --> 00:04:11.521
Right.
There's several other buildings and

90
00:04:11.521 --> 00:04:13.780
shopping centers, things like that,
they're all along the trail.

91
00:04:13.780 --> 00:04:17.460
We share that road with other people,
all right?

92
00:04:17.460 --> 00:04:21.970
But we are the only 6933 on this road,
right.

93
00:04:23.160 --> 00:04:26.780
There's no other 6933 on NW 4th Blvd,
it's just us.

94
00:04:26.780 --> 00:04:28.441
There's a 6931, there a 6935.

95
00:04:28.441 --> 00:04:32.810
There's probably a 6934, although I
think it's an empty field over there.

96
00:04:32.810 --> 00:04:37.030
So there are other numbers that are on
our road, but we're the only 6933.

97
00:04:37.030 --> 00:04:37.676
All right.

98
00:04:37.676 --> 00:04:39.845
Network addresses are the same way.

99
00:04:39.845 --> 00:04:48.113
This address up here,
well 192.168.0 that's the NetworkID,

100
00:04:48.113 --> 00:04:52.670
and 1, that's the HostID, right?

101
00:04:52.670 --> 00:04:57.997
So my network is 192.168.0 and
1 is my host.

102
00:04:57.997 --> 00:05:02.722
So 192 at168.0 there might be many
computers on that network, but

103
00:05:02.722 --> 00:05:04.301
there's only one .1.

104
00:05:04.301 --> 00:05:10.395
So there might be a 192.168.0.99 or
a 192.168.0.200.

105
00:05:10.395 --> 00:05:12.910
They're on the same network.

106
00:05:12.910 --> 00:05:17.040
But they have different HostIDs, so
they're unique in that perspective.

107
00:05:17.040 --> 00:05:18.180
All right.

108
00:05:18.180 --> 00:05:19.990
Now, why is that important to us?

109
00:05:19.990 --> 00:05:23.978
Well, if two computers wanna talk to each
other, and they're on the same network,

110
00:05:23.978 --> 00:05:29.150
they can just talk directly to each other.

111
00:05:29.150 --> 00:05:30.970
Daniel's laptop is on
the 10.1.230 network.

112
00:05:30.970 --> 00:05:31.590
I'm on the 10.1.230 network.

113
00:05:31.590 --> 00:05:33.250
Our laptops can talk to
each other just fine.

114
00:05:34.960 --> 00:05:36.340
But what about you?

115
00:05:36.340 --> 00:05:37.770
You're watching this episode.

116
00:05:37.770 --> 00:05:40.600
You're, maybe you're watching this live,
if you're watching this live then you're

117
00:05:40.600 --> 00:05:44.924
out there somewhere in the world on
a network that's not 10.1.230 right,

118
00:05:44.924 --> 00:05:47.140
on some completely other
network that's out there.

119
00:05:47.140 --> 00:05:50.140
And you're coming to access our
systems here, to watch the video.

120
00:05:50.140 --> 00:05:52.940
Well, how do you do that?

121
00:05:52.940 --> 00:05:54.270
You go through routers, right?

122
00:05:54.270 --> 00:05:57.200
There's many routers that are out there
on the internet that we pass through when

123
00:05:57.200 --> 00:06:00.280
we go out to some kind of source,
to some destination.

124
00:06:00.280 --> 00:06:04.530
Let me,
we'll use ITProTV as an example, right.

125
00:06:04.530 --> 00:06:07.460
So let me fire up
a terminal here real quick.

126
00:06:07.460 --> 00:06:12.563
If I were to jump out to ITProTV I could
do something like ping itpro.tv and

127
00:06:12.563 --> 00:06:14.050
I'm pinging it.

128
00:06:14.050 --> 00:06:16.262
I know I can get to itpro.tv.

129
00:06:16.262 --> 00:06:19.560
All right, well how did I get there?

130
00:06:19.560 --> 00:06:25.410
I can use the utility like trace
route to see how I got out there.

131
00:06:25.410 --> 00:06:30.330
And it starts to lay out the route that
I followed on my way out to that system.

132
00:06:30.330 --> 00:06:32.990
And if you look,
here's our firewall, right?

133
00:06:32.990 --> 00:06:34.890
That's the equipment that we control.

134
00:06:34.890 --> 00:06:37.710
And then after that,
we start bouncing through GRU,

135
00:06:37.710 --> 00:06:39.650
which is our internet service provider.

136
00:06:39.650 --> 00:06:42.430
And from there,
they bounce us over to some other network.

137
00:06:42.430 --> 00:06:44.950
And then looks like after we
hit level three communications,

138
00:06:44.950 --> 00:06:46.480
we hit some kind of firewall there.

139
00:06:46.480 --> 00:06:51.300
And it's not returning names anymore,
but we can see all these different

140
00:06:51.300 --> 00:06:55.470
routers we're passing through on our
way out to that destination, all right.

141
00:06:55.470 --> 00:06:58.200
Those routers are all on
different networks, and

142
00:06:58.200 --> 00:07:02.010
it's a router's job to know how
to get to those destinations.

143
00:07:02.010 --> 00:07:05.530
But your computer has to
know when to use the router.

144
00:07:05.530 --> 00:07:08.130
And it's your address
that keys it in on that.

145
00:07:08.130 --> 00:07:10.100
When your address starts
with 192.168.0 and

146
00:07:10.100 --> 00:07:14.530
you're talking to somebody whose address
starts with something different,

147
00:07:14.530 --> 00:07:17.610
you say well I don't know how to get
there, let me go through my router.

148
00:07:17.610 --> 00:07:20.260
And your router will guide you
on the way to that destination.

149
00:07:21.396 --> 00:07:25.774
All right.
Now, I said my network was 192.168.0.

150
00:07:25.774 --> 00:07:26.680
How did I know that?

151
00:07:27.820 --> 00:07:31.400
Well, to understand how we know where
the NetworkID and where the HostID is,

152
00:07:31.400 --> 00:07:34.060
we kind of have to understand
how these addresses are made up.

153
00:07:34.060 --> 00:07:36.110
When we see an IPv4 address,

154
00:07:36.110 --> 00:07:40.400
we see it written as four numbers
separated by periods, okay.

155
00:07:40.400 --> 00:07:43.620
This is called the dotted
decimal notation.

156
00:07:43.620 --> 00:07:47.450
In computers there's really three
different types of numbers that you see.

157
00:07:47.450 --> 00:07:50.150
There's decimal,

158
00:07:51.210 --> 00:07:56.400
there is binary and
there's hexadecimal, right.

159
00:07:56.400 --> 00:07:58.168
Those are the three types
of numbers that we see.

160
00:07:58.168 --> 00:08:02.167
Decimal we recognize really easy, right?

161
00:08:02.167 --> 00:08:06.044
Each digit, each placeholder Is
a value between zero and nine.

162
00:08:06.044 --> 00:08:08.367
Right?
So I have zero, one, two, three, four,

163
00:08:08.367 --> 00:08:10.870
five, six, seven, eight,
nine, and then I go to ten.

164
00:08:10.870 --> 00:08:12.560
I went to two digits.

165
00:08:12.560 --> 00:08:14.310
Right?
And I go all the way to 99 and

166
00:08:14.310 --> 00:08:15.470
then I go to three digits.

167
00:08:15.470 --> 00:08:17.480
And I go to 999 and I go to four digits.

168
00:08:17.480 --> 00:08:18.730
Right?
That's decimal mathematics.

169
00:08:18.730 --> 00:08:20.890
It's what most of us
learned in grade school.

170
00:08:20.890 --> 00:08:24.090
It's pretty common, I should say.

171
00:08:24.090 --> 00:08:25.540
Binary, on the other hand,
is what computers use.

172
00:08:25.540 --> 00:08:29.690
And with binary,
each digit is just a zero or a one.

173
00:08:29.690 --> 00:08:32.700
And that's it, zeroes and ones,
that's what your computer sees.

174
00:08:32.700 --> 00:08:34.319
It does everything in terms of zeroes and
ones.

175
00:08:36.210 --> 00:08:43.290
Then there's hexadecimal, and
hexadecimal does things in zero through F.

176
00:08:43.290 --> 00:08:45.760
Now, what do I mean by zero through F?

177
00:08:45.760 --> 00:08:50.420
Well, I mean zero, one, two, three,
four, five, six, seven, eight, nine.

178
00:08:50.420 --> 00:08:50.960
Whoops.

179
00:08:50.960 --> 00:08:55.800
And then instead of ten,
it goes to A, B, C, D, E, and F.

180
00:08:57.050 --> 00:08:59.580
It's actually got 16 different values.

181
00:08:59.580 --> 00:09:05.390
So, when we say 16 different values,
these are Base 10 mathematics,

182
00:09:05.390 --> 00:09:10.720
Base 2 mathematics, and
Base 16 mathematics.

183
00:09:11.790 --> 00:09:14.540
I've got 16 different values for
each digit.

184
00:09:14.540 --> 00:09:17.880
So, different ways of
representing those numbers.

185
00:09:17.880 --> 00:09:22.120
Well, when we see an IP address,
an IPv4 address,

186
00:09:22.120 --> 00:09:26.140
is written like this which
is four decimal numbers.

187
00:09:26.140 --> 00:09:28.340
In the background, your computer
takes that decimal number and

188
00:09:28.340 --> 00:09:29.980
it converts it to binary.

189
00:09:29.980 --> 00:09:36.129
So it would take something like
192.168.01 and convert that to binary.

190
00:09:36.129 --> 00:09:41.561
So you'd see something like this
one the computer that number

191
00:09:41.561 --> 00:09:46.575
would actually be,
let's see if I can do this in my head,

192
00:09:46.575 --> 00:09:50.347
11000000.10101000.

193
00:09:53.660 --> 00:09:54.451
There.

194
00:09:54.451 --> 00:09:59.571
All right,
that is 192.168.0.1 written in binary.

195
00:09:59.571 --> 00:10:01.940
Now I've put these

episodes.description: TCP/IP Networking Part 2 is the updated episode to the original Understanding TCP/IP Part 2. In this episode, Daniel and Don continue looking at TCP/IP networking in Linux. They begin by explaining the Transmission Control Protocol and how it is used to deliver data over the network. Then they show you how to use some of the built-in systems, like netstat, to see these connections. Finally they talk about the concepts and uses of TCP/UDP ports; giving you a list of common ports that you'll need to know for the exam.

21

22
00:01:05.420 --> 00:01:10.344
>> Yeah, now we're talking TCP here, so

24

Give me some of the foundational
understanding so that,

as we move through this particular
