26
00:01:19.400 --> 00:01:22.880
>> All right, so
TCP is the Transmission Control Protocol.

27
00:01:22.880 --> 00:01:27.950
When you reach out to a web server, or
an FTP server or something like that,

28
00:01:27.950 --> 00:01:31.110
your computer is talking to
a server somewhere in the world.

29
00:01:31.110 --> 00:01:34.400
And the IP address,
what we talked about in the last episode,

30
00:01:34.400 --> 00:01:37.650
it is really important because that's
how we find the server, right.

31
00:01:37.650 --> 00:01:41.970
So I want to go to www.google.com.

32
00:01:41.970 --> 00:01:43.030
I need to find the server.

33
00:01:43.030 --> 00:01:46.560
I do a DNS lookup first, right,
I get the name converted it to an IP.

34
00:01:46.560 --> 00:01:48.250
Now I've got an IP address.

35
00:01:48.250 --> 00:01:49.890
How do I get to the IP?

36
00:01:49.890 --> 00:01:52.130
Well, that's where the IP
addressing side of things comes in.

37
00:01:52.130 --> 00:01:53.130
We have routes, and all that.

38
00:01:53.130 --> 00:01:54.600
We find a way to the server.

39
00:01:54.600 --> 00:01:58.780
Now when we find the server,
how do we talk to it, right?

40
00:01:58.780 --> 00:02:01.300
We have to have some way to
communicate between us and

41
00:02:01.300 --> 00:02:02.860
the machine on the other end.

42
00:02:02.860 --> 00:02:06.290
And there's various levels of
complexity we can go for here.

43
00:02:06.290 --> 00:02:10.770
So for example, there's a protocol
called UDP, User Datagram Protocol.

44
00:02:10.770 --> 00:02:14.440
And with UDP,
I just start chucking data at that server.

45
00:02:14.440 --> 00:02:16.670
I say, here you go,
I'm throwing data right at you, okay.

46
00:02:16.670 --> 00:02:20.290
And that works,
it works well in a lot of scenarios.

47
00:02:20.290 --> 00:02:23.152
But what happens if some of that
data gets lost along the way?

48
00:02:23.152 --> 00:02:26.190
The Internet's a crazy place,
sometimes packets get lost,

49
00:02:26.190 --> 00:02:28.020
it's a very common thing.

50
00:02:28.020 --> 00:02:30.510
With UDP you're just rifling
that data out there, so

51
00:02:30.510 --> 00:02:34.050
if data gets lost, it gets lost, it's
not a big deal you just move on, right.

52
00:02:34.050 --> 00:02:38.100
I know what you're thinking,
when is it okay for data to get lost?

53
00:02:38.100 --> 00:02:41.355
If I fire off ten emails and
one of them gets lost is that no big deal?

54
00:02:41.355 --> 00:02:43.610
Nine out of ten, that's not bad.

55
00:02:43.610 --> 00:02:45.620
Well, it usually is bad.

56
00:02:45.620 --> 00:02:48.770
So we need some kind of control
mechanism in there to help us to make

57
00:02:48.770 --> 00:02:49.560
sure we don't lose data.

58
00:02:49.560 --> 00:02:51.330
And that's not always necessary, right.

59
00:02:51.330 --> 00:02:52.550
Let's say it's streaming video.

60
00:02:52.550 --> 00:02:54.970
You're watching this episode right now,
okay.

61
00:02:54.970 --> 00:02:59.490
We're sending 30 frames per second
across the network to your computer.

62
00:02:59.490 --> 00:03:01.800
What happens if one of
those frames disappears?

63
00:03:01.800 --> 00:03:04.350
If one of those frames disappears
when I'm moving my hand,

64
00:03:04.350 --> 00:03:08.080
you might see it disappear and
then reappear a few centimeters over.

65
00:03:08.080 --> 00:03:09.480
That's no big deal, right.

66
00:03:09.480 --> 00:03:12.910
With streaming video,
with streaming audio, things like that,

67
00:03:12.910 --> 00:03:17.270
a voice over IP calls, if you miss
a frame, you miss a little chunk of data,

68
00:03:17.270 --> 00:03:19.160
you just skip right past it.

69
00:03:19.160 --> 00:03:20.830
Cuz otherwise you start
getting a bigger and

70
00:03:20.830 --> 00:03:22.710
bigger delay in the data
that you're sending.

71
00:03:22.710 --> 00:03:24.250
You definitely don't want that, right.

72
00:03:24.250 --> 00:03:29.730
So we keep kind of churning right through
and moving on, and that's what UDP is for.

73
00:03:29.730 --> 00:03:32.960
But for everything else, for
email, browsing the web,

74
00:03:32.960 --> 00:03:36.920
transferring files, we don't even want
to lose even one single packet of data.

75
00:03:36.920 --> 00:03:38.950
We want everything to make it.

76
00:03:38.950 --> 00:03:40.140
And we need something to help with that.

77
00:03:40.140 --> 00:03:44.630
And what helps is TCP,
the Transmission Control Protocol.

78
00:03:44.630 --> 00:03:48.270
When you connect to a server
TCP reaches out and says,

79
00:03:48.270 --> 00:03:52.580
hey I want to have a good healthy
communication with you so

80
00:03:52.580 --> 00:03:55.830
that we can start to exchange data and
that's really important.

81
00:03:55.830 --> 00:03:58.120
And I've got a little diagram here,
let me show you guys.

82
00:03:58.120 --> 00:04:01.380
So with UDP,
we just start rifling that data out.

83
00:04:01.380 --> 00:04:04.650
So your client just starts rifling
packet after packet after packet across

84
00:04:04.650 --> 00:04:05.880
the network to the other end.

85
00:04:05.880 --> 00:04:10.100
And if a packet doesn't make it, big deal,
you just right on past it, right.

86
00:04:10.100 --> 00:04:15.070
But TCP on the other hand, with TCP
when you start to talk to that server,

87
00:04:15.070 --> 00:04:17.340
you do what's called a handshake.

88
00:04:17.340 --> 00:04:21.760
And a handshake works like this, the very
first thing you send to the server

89

544
00:26:52.340 --> 00:26:54.330
It's right here on my screen.

545
00:26:54.330 --> 00:26:58.860
It's normally 143, but when you encrypt
it it's 993, and POP is normally 110, but

546
00:26:58.860 --> 00:27:01.690
when you encrypt it it's 995.

547
00:27:01.690 --> 00:27:04.200
So that's about 15 protocols right there.

548
00:27:04.200 --> 00:27:07.900
These are all ones that can and
likely will show up on the exam so

549
00:27:07.900 --> 00:27:09.400
you definitely want to
have those memorized.

550
00:27:09.400 --> 00:27:10.700
It's just one of those things.

551
00:27:10.700 --> 00:27:12.950
I'll put them all in the show notes so
that you'll have them.

552
00:27:12.950 --> 00:27:17.320
Make sure you memorize the protocol name,
the port number, and

553
00:27:17.320 --> 00:27:22.970
whether it uses TCP or UDP, and be careful
cuz some of them can use both like DNS,

554
00:27:22.970 --> 00:27:25.780
some of them only use UDP,
some of them only use TCP.

555
00:27:25.780 --> 00:27:28.260
So make sure you know those, and
know the differences between them,

556
00:27:28.260 --> 00:27:30.840
but you definitely wanna have that
memorized because it'll be easy questions

557
00:27:30.840 --> 00:27:31.880
on the exam if you do.

558
00:27:31.880 --> 00:27:34.280
>> Yeah Don,
this is great flash card material for

559
00:27:34.280 --> 00:27:37.460
you out there that are studying for
this exam specifically.

560
00:27:37.460 --> 00:27:38.500
Just go ahead and create them.

561
00:27:38.500 --> 00:27:42.940
I know it's a bear, it's drudgery,

562
00:27:42.940 --> 00:27:45.930
but you bury that stuff into your
brain when it comes time for

563
00:27:45.930 --> 00:27:50.750
that exam you are prepared for any
question that references port numbers and

564
00:27:50.750 --> 00:27:54.370
protocols, and whether or
not what's using what, so be prepared for

565
00:27:54.370 --> 00:27:57.570
this, cuz like Don said they
are gonna hit you with that stuff.

566
00:27:57.570 --> 00:27:59.440
Don, that being said is there anything
else that we need to cover for

567
00:27:59.440 --> 00:28:01.000
this episode when it comes to networking.

568
00:28:01.000 --> 00:28:04.100
>> Well, I want everybody to remember
that we are going to see this again.

569
00:28:04.100 --> 00:28:07.170
When you're troubleshooting network
connectivity you see those port numbers.

570
00:28:07.170 --> 00:28:08.920
Like when I ran NetStat I
saw the port numbers,

571
00:28:08.920 --> 00:28:11.800
and I knew it was web traffic because
I knew the port 80 was web traffic.

572
00:28:11.800 --> 00:28:15.190
So if we know this stuff it definitely
helps the troubleshooting, and

573
00:28:15.190 --> 00:28:17.940
we're gonna see it when we talk about
security cuz if you're configuring

574
00:28:17.940 --> 00:28:21.940
a firewall like IP tables you've gotta
authorize what ports are open and

575
00:28:21.940 --> 00:28:24.790
what ports are closed to allow
traffic in and out of your machine.

576
00:28:24.790 --> 00:28:28.250
You need to know the port numbers for that
too, so this is something that will come

577
00:28:28.250 --> 00:28:32.160
up over and over again not just in Linux
but in other operating systems as well.

578
00:28:32.160 --> 00:28:34.370
So this is good foundational
knowledge to have.

579
00:28:34.370 --> 00:28:36.180
I know it stinks to have
to memorize something, but

580
00:28:36.180 --> 00:28:38.220
in this case it's definitely
something you wanna do.

581
00:28:38.220 --> 00:28:39.945
>> Yep.
Well, great words for Don.

582
00:28:39.945 --> 00:28:41.810
>> [LAUGH]
>> He's totally right.

583
00:28:41.810 --> 00:28:43.000
Definitely just memorize this.

584
00:28:43.000 --> 00:28:44.750
We can't hammer them away enough.

585
00:28:44.750 --> 00:28:47.470
Like he says we're gonna see it again
anyway, so it's gonna help you with

586
00:28:47.470 --> 00:28:51.770
the retention and give you a little
context to help retain that as well.

587
00:28:51.770 --> 00:28:55.320
Don, thank you so much for explaining
this to us cuz it can be a little bit

588
00:28:55.320 --> 00:28:59.100
overwhelming if this is something you're
new to, but really great explanations.

589
00:28:59.100 --> 00:29:00.560
We appreciate you showing up.

590
00:29:00.560 --> 00:29:02.560
That being said we thank you for watching.

591
00:29:02.560 --> 00:29:04.150
We're gonna go ahead and
sign off for IT Pro TV.

592
00:29:04.150 --> 00:29:06.140
I've been your host Daniel Lowrie.

593
00:29:06.140 --> 00:29:06.990
>> And I'm Don Pazette.

episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.124 --> 00:00:10.804
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:10.804 --> 00:00:14.770
All right, everyone welcome to
another great episode of ITProTV.

3
00:00:14.770 --> 00:00:16.030
I'll be your host, Daniel Lowrie.

4
00:00:16.030 --> 00:00:19.120
And here with me today is feeling it,
Don Pezet.

5
00:00:19.120 --> 00:00:19.690
How's it going, Don?
[LAUGH]

6
00:00:19.690 --> 00:00:21.270
>> That's right, I feel it, feel it,

7
00:00:21.270 --> 00:00:23.005
just like Marky Mark and the funky bunch.

8
00:00:23.005 --> 00:00:29.810
[LAUGH] Welcome back to another episode of
Linux+, not the 90s pop flashback episode.

9
00:00:29.810 --> 00:00:32.450
So we're gonna be taking a look at
configuring our network adapters,

10
00:00:32.450 --> 00:00:33.190
inside of Linux.

11
00:00:33.190 --> 00:00:35.280
This is something that
it is really important,

12
00:00:35.280 --> 00:00:38.210
and I know some of you are thinking right
now, configuring a network adapter?

13
00:00:38.210 --> 00:00:40.340
It works out of the box!

14
00:00:40.340 --> 00:00:41.180
And your right.

15
00:00:41.180 --> 00:00:42.820
If you install a distro with a GUI,

16
00:00:42.820 --> 00:00:47.190
you know with a graphical user interface,
almost all of the distro's,

17
00:00:47.190 --> 00:00:51.010
automatically detect network adapters and
automatically set them up.

18
00:00:51.010 --> 00:00:56.270
However, if you're deploying a server,
its rare that you put a GUI on a server,

19
00:00:56.270 --> 00:00:57.530
or it should be, right [LAUGH]?

20
00:00:57.530 --> 00:00:59.330
You shouldn't have a GUI on your server.

21
00:00:59.330 --> 00:01:01.120
So you gotta do it from the command line.

22
00:01:01.120 --> 00:01:02.800
And when you do a minimal install for

23
00:01:02.800 --> 00:01:06.760
a server, all that automatic network
stuff, that's kinda out the window.

24
00:01:06.760 --> 00:01:08.210
That, really doesn't apply.

25
00:01:08.210 --> 00:01:11.890
So we need to have an understanding
of where these settings actually go,

26
00:01:11.890 --> 00:01:13.650
what it is they do.

27
00:01:13.650 --> 00:01:16.979
And then start to take a look at
how we configure that adapter,

28
00:01:16.979 --> 00:01:19.100
how we get the IPs assigned, and so on.

29
00:01:19.100 --> 00:01:21.974
And remember, there's really just a few
pieces of information we need to set.

30
00:01:21.974 --> 00:01:29.070
IP address, subnet mask, default gateway,
DNS servers, and host name.

31
00:01:29.070 --> 00:01:32.520
Those five pieces of information, those
are kind of the key components we need to

32
00:01:32.520 --> 00:01:34.690
have and, host name,
you could leave that one off I guess,

33
00:01:34.690 --> 00:01:38.680
but the other four you really gotta have,
if you want basic network communications.

34
00:01:38.680 --> 00:01:41.040
So we're gonna take a look at
the configuration files, and

35
00:01:41.040 --> 00:01:43.275
all that define our network adapters.

36
00:01:44.310 --> 00:01:47.930
Let's start with just the basic
adapter itself, right.

37
00:01:47.930 --> 00:01:51.930
Maybe I just need quick and dirty,
get an adapter fired up, and I'm not so

38
00:01:51.930 --> 00:01:54.430
worried about config files and
all that stuff, right?

39
00:01:54.430 --> 00:01:58.020
Well, from the command prompt, one of
the most important commands we have is one

40
00:01:58.020 --> 00:02:02.570
called ifconfig, the interface
configuration command, right.

41
00:02:02.570 --> 00:02:08.030
And I use ifconfig all the time, I run it
cause it tells me what my interfaces are,

42
00:02:08.030 --> 00:02:10.730
well, configured for,
kinda where it got it's name.

43
00:02:10.730 --> 00:02:14.630
So I can see I've got like,
F zero there, for my Ethernet zero,

44
00:02:14.630 --> 00:02:16.380
my first network adapter.

45
00:02:16.380 --> 00:02:20.610
And I've got lo, for my loopback adapter,
right, so I can see those two adapters,

46
00:02:20.610 --> 00:02:23.560
and if they've got an IP address,
I'll see it in here.

47
00:02:23.560 --> 00:02:26.770
I can see my eth0 has a ipv6 address, but

48
00:02:26.770 --> 00:02:30.275
I don't have an ipv4 address for
some reason.

49
00:02:30.275 --> 00:02:31.125
That's odd.

50
00:02:31.125 --> 00:02:32.725
Well, it's not too odd.

51
00:02:32.725 --> 00:02:36.105
When you do a new server and install, and
you do a minimal install it, it's not

52
00:02:36.105 --> 00:02:39.485
gonna configure the adapter, or some of
the distros, I think Debian actually does

53
00:02:39.485 --> 00:02:42.875
ask for an IP during the setup, and so
you can have a basic config put on there.

54
00:02:42.875 --> 00:02:45.495
But you may or may not have that, alright.

55
00:02:45.495 --> 00:02:49.823
So, I can use ifconfig,
to actually configure this adapter and

56
00:02:49.823 --> 00:02:51.720
bring it on if I want.

57
00:02:51.720 --> 00:02:55.970
So I could do something like this, I could
say, well I'm gonna start by elevating my

58
00:02:55.970 --> 00:02:59.670
privileges, because you do need to
have admin privileges to do this.

59
00:02:59.670 --> 00:03:01.090
So you can use sudo if you want.

60
00:03:01.090 --> 00:03:03.067
I'm just gonna SU into root.

61
00:03:03.067 --> 00:03:09.522
And then I'm gonna say ifconfig,
followed by my adapter, right, f0 for me.

62
00:03:09.522 --> 00:03:12.563
Up, cuz I wanna turn it on.

63
00:03:12.563 --> 00:03:14.305
And then I'm gonna give it an IP.

64
00:03:14.305 --> 00:03:17.860
So I'm gonna give it 10.1.230.245.

65
00:03:17.860 --> 00:03:24.725
I'll give it a net mask of,
255 255 255 0, like that.

66
00:03:24.725 --> 00:03:28.795
And it's gonna apply that IP address to
the interface, and it's gonna bring it up,

67
00:03:28.795 --> 00:03:29.630
all right?

68
00:03:29.630 --> 00:03:30.840
That interface just came up.

69
00:03:30.840 --> 00:03:32.990
Well the interface was already up, right?

70
00:03:32.990 --> 00:03:35.010
I could see where I was receiving packets,
but I,

71
00:03:35.010 --> 00:03:37.270
you know,
wasn't really doing anything with them.

72
00:03:37.270 --> 00:03:40.420
Now, I should be able to send and receive.

73
00:03:40.420 --> 00:03:44.270
And I can see right here that I've
got that IP address assigned, and

74
00:03:44.270 --> 00:03:48.230
I should be able to ping out to
host on that network in there.

75
00:03:48.230 --> 00:03:49.925
I can see I can communicate.

76
00:03:49.925 --> 00:03:54.175
I've got an IP.
The only problem here is,

77
00:03:54.175 --> 00:03:55.715
what if I reboot?

78
00:03:55.715 --> 00:03:58.215
If I reboot,
what I just did is not persistent.

79
00:03:58.215 --> 00:03:59.425
That was just a one time thing.

80
00:03:59.425 --> 00:04:00.295
I used ifconfig.

81
00:04:00.295 --> 00:04:01.105
I assigned it.

82
00:04:01.105 --> 00:04:03.035
If I reboot, I lose those settings.

83
00:04:03.035 --> 00:04:07.730
So, if I just need to temporarily get on
the network, that's a great way to do it.

84
00:04:07.730 --> 00:04:12.220
There's other temporary commands
like that like, ifup and ifdown.

85
00:04:12.220 --> 00:04:16.670
If I want to temporarily take that
interface down, I could say ifdown.

86
00:04:16.670 --> 00:04:19.130
F zero, and that's gonna shut it down.

87
00:04:19.130 --> 00:04:23.340
And when you do ifconfig here you'll see
that, actually it's still showing as up.

88
00:04:23.340 --> 00:04:26.700
If I give it a second, it'll actually
disappear from this list, and

89
00:04:26.700 --> 00:04:31.140
it'll be off and if I try and
ping out, let's see.

90
00:04:31.140 --> 00:04:32.920
Well, that's actually not going down.

91
00:04:32.920 --> 00:04:36.140
Oh, did I forget to do
something a little important?

92
00:04:36.140 --> 00:04:36.810
Nope, I did it, eth0.

93
00:04:36.810 --> 00:04:40.720
You have to say ifdown followed by the
interface, and then it'll take it down.

94
00:04:40.720 --> 00:04:45.830
And then you can bring it back up with
ifup eth0, and that'll bring it back up.

95
00:04:45.830 --> 00:04:49.070
Now mine's gonna get a little angry
at me here, cuz it's already up.

96
00:04:49.070 --> 00:04:52.990
So, quick little commands you can issue
to bring it up, or bring it down.

97
00:04:52.990 --> 00:04:55.290
I could also use ifconfig to do that.

98
00:04:55.290 --> 00:04:57.640
You know it's gonna kind of hang there for
a second.

99
00:04:57.640 --> 00:05:02.132
So I can use ifconfig, f0, and

100
00:05:02.132 --> 00:05:06.823
up, which is what I did a minute ago or
down to take it down.

101
00:05:06.823 --> 00:05:07.487
So those are kind of different ways.

102
00:05:07.487 --> 00:05:10.380
But all these commands,
are just temporary, right.

103
00:05:10.380 --> 00:05:13.240
They're not persistent if I reboot,
I lose them.

104
00:05:13.240 --> 00:05:16.692
So if we really wanna get our
network card configured properly,

105
00:05:16.692 --> 00:05:18.407
we've gotta modify some config files,
alright.

106
00:05:19.700 --> 00:05:24.420
Now, unfortunately, different distro's
store the configs, in different places.

107
00:05:24.420 --> 00:05:27.000
But fortunately, there's two real
leaders that are out there right now,

108
00:05:27.000 --> 00:05:28.810
RedHat and Debian.

109
00:05:28.810 --> 00:05:31.830
And so, most of the distros that we run,
are based off of one of those two.

110
00:05:31.830 --> 00:05:34.650
If you're on Ubuntu or Mint,
they're based off of Debian.

111
00:05:34.650 --> 00:05:37.720
If you run CentOS,
it's built off of RedHat.

112
00:05:37.720 --> 00:05:40.650
So, it's usually gonna
be in one of two places.

113
00:05:40.650 --> 00:05:45.541
On a RedHat based system,
the configs are stored in

114
00:05:45.541 --> 00:05:49.654
/etc/sysconfig/network-scripts.

115
00:05:49.654 --> 00:05:52.860
Whoops, if I spell scripts right.

116
00:05:52.860 --> 00:05:54.415
There we go, that path right there.

117
00:05:54.415 --> 00:05:58.130
/etc/sysconfig/network-scripts.

118
00:05:58.130 --> 00:06:01.490
If you're on a Debian system,
it's actually a little bit different.

119
00:06:01.490 --> 00:06:06.280
It's in /etc/network/interfaces, right.

120
00:06:06.280 --> 00:06:09.490
/etc/network/interfaces.

121
00:06:09.490 --> 00:06:13.340
But inside of either of those directories,
what you'll find are a bunch

122
00:06:13.340 --> 00:06:17.360
of scripts that run when your system boots
up when it turns on the network service.

123
00:06:17.360 --> 00:06:21.130
And you'll have a script for
each network adapter in your system.

124
00:06:21.130 --> 00:06:25.160
I can see ifconfig-eth0 right,
there for me.

125
00:06:25.160 --> 00:06:30.335
And if I take a look at that file,
you'll see some settings in there,

126
00:06:30.335 --> 00:06:32.845
that are defining how this adapter works,
alright.

127
00:06:32.845 --> 00:06:35.405
Mine says, device equals f0, alright.

128
00:06:35.405 --> 00:06:37.935
So that's it's name, Ethernet zero.

129
00:06:37.935 --> 00:06:39.975
BOOTPROTO equals DHCP.

130
00:06:39.975 --> 00:06:43.575
You're normally gonna see one
of two values here, DHCP,

131
00:06:43.575 --> 00:06:45.685
for dynamic host configuration protocol,

132
00:06:45.685 --> 00:06:48.260
that means automatically get
an address from the network.

133
00:06:48.260 --> 00:06:51.645
It'll ask the network, say hey,
can somebody get me an IP?

134
00:06:51.645 --> 00:06:53.745
And hopefully there's a DHCP server
out there, that will reply and

135
00:06:53.745 --> 00:06:54.279
give us an address.

136
00:06:55.600 --> 00:06:57.520
You might see BOOTPROTO equals static,

137
00:06:57.520 --> 00:07:00.790
and that means we're gonna
manually assign an IP ourselves.

138
00:07:00.790 --> 00:07:03.440
We'll always have the same address and
that's what you normally do on a server.

139
00:07:04.680 --> 00:07:09.390
Then we see HWADDR,
that's the hardware address, right.

140
00:07:09.390 --> 00:07:12.390
That's the MAC address, or
Media Access Control address,

141
00:07:12.390 --> 00:07:14.400
that's tied to your network adapter.

142
00:07:14.400 --> 00:07:15.370
I see IPV6INIT.

143
00:07:15.370 --> 00:07:18.570
Alright, I'm enabling IPV6 for
this adapter.

144
00:07:19.570 --> 00:07:21.470
I see NM_CONTROLLED="yes".

145
00:07:21.470 --> 00:07:23.760
Now this one is gonna cause us a problem.

146
00:07:24.930 --> 00:07:26.732
NM is short for network manager.

147
00:07:26.732 --> 00:07:30.020
In RedHat systems, we have a software
service called network manager.

148
00:07:30.020 --> 00:07:31.750
That's the name here.

149
00:07:31.750 --> 00:07:34.300
And it's what automatically
configures our adapters.

150
00:07:34.300 --> 00:07:36.460
That's why I have these settings
in here in the first place.

151
00:07:36.460 --> 00:07:38.110
The network manager put it there.

152
00:07:38.110 --> 00:07:39.790
If we're gonna take over
this configuration,

153
00:07:39.790 --> 00:07:41.050
we're gonna have to turn that off.

154
00:07:41.050 --> 00:07:44.250
I'm gonna have to tell the network
manager to leave this adapter alone.

155
00:07:44.250 --> 00:07:45.570
If you use a RedHat base system,

156
00:07:45.570 --> 00:07:47.850
your network manager it's just
this little icon up here.

157
00:07:47.850 --> 00:07:49.505
And see how I can see
my different adapters?

158
00:07:49.505 --> 00:07:54.003
And I can see system eth0, and I can
disconnect it, or I can reconnect it and

159
00:07:54.003 --> 00:07:55.490
start to manipulate it.

160
00:07:55.490 --> 00:07:57.557
That's what's taking care of that.

161
00:07:57.557 --> 00:07:59.909
And that's probably why my ifdown
command didn't work earlier,

162
00:07:59.909 --> 00:08:01.740
is the network manager was keeping it up.

163
00:08:01.740 --> 00:08:03.190
We'll disable that in just a moment.

164
00:08:05.080 --> 00:08:05.890
All right.

165
00:08:05.890 --> 00:08:08.190
The other one I've got
is onboot equals yes.

166
00:08:08.190 --> 00:08:09.675
This one's really important.

167
00:08:09.675 --> 00:08:12.565
When you do a minimal install for
a server, onboot is almost

168
00:08:12.565 --> 00:08:15.935
always set to no and that means when
it boots up don't bother connecting it.

169
00:08:15.935 --> 00:08:18.935
If it says onboot equals yes when you
reboot it will actually connect it

170
00:08:18.935 --> 00:08:20.755
to the network and start the function.

171
00:08:20.755 --> 00:08:23.870
That's normally what we want.

172
00:08:23.870 --> 00:08:26.415
Type equals ethernet hopefully
that's what you see.

173
00:08:26.415 --> 00:08:28.675
You could see type equals
tokenring I hope not.

174
00:08:28.675 --> 00:08:30.935
[LAUGH] There are still some
tokenring networks out there.

175
00:08:30.935 --> 00:08:32.197
>> Old network if you're doing that.

176
00:08:32.197 --> 00:08:33.570
[LAUGH]

I can see here that I've got 10.1.230.238.

411
00:19:47.318 --> 00:19:51.449
That's my IP and if I try and ping out
to the Internet, I'm getting there so

412
00:19:51.449 --> 00:19:54.340
I'm going through my default gateway.

413
00:19:54.340 --> 00:19:57.075
And if I try to do an NS look up for

414
00:19:57.075 --> 00:20:01.430
google.com, there we go
it's working all right?

415
00:20:01.430 --> 00:20:05.790
Now I've got network connectivity,
and more importantly, it's persistent.

416
00:20:05.790 --> 00:20:11.260
If I reboot this system, my network should
be functioning exactly as it is now.

417
00:20:11.260 --> 00:20:13.500
We should be in good shape.

418
00:20:13.500 --> 00:20:17.000
Now my host name, did it take effect?

419
00:20:17.000 --> 00:20:20.250
It looks like it didn't, but
the problem here is actually my shell.

420
00:20:20.250 --> 00:20:23.870
The shell generated this prompt
when I first launched into it and

421
00:20:23.870 --> 00:20:24.930
I haven't restarted my shell.

422
00:20:24.930 --> 00:20:27.210
But if I just run the hostname command.

423
00:20:28.530 --> 00:20:30.020
Actually it hasn't taken effect, has it?

424
00:20:30.020 --> 00:20:33.120
The hostname command is returning
still localhost.localdomain.

425
00:20:33.120 --> 00:20:35.100
And that's an indicator of two things.

426
00:20:35.100 --> 00:20:38.190
Either one, I do need to restart for
the hostname to take effect.

427
00:20:38.190 --> 00:20:42.170
Or two, this distro is storing
the hostname somewhere else.

428
00:20:42.170 --> 00:20:44.450
Remember, I put it in resolve.com.

429
00:20:44.450 --> 00:20:47.870
I might have another place
where I need to put that.

430
00:20:47.870 --> 00:20:48.980
Wait, I didn't put it there.

431
00:20:48.980 --> 00:20:55.840
I put it in slash ETC slash
system PEG slash network.

432
00:20:55.840 --> 00:21:01.850
Let's verify now I'm
getting myself confused

433
00:21:01.850 --> 00:21:05.600
and I take a look at that network file.

434
00:21:05.600 --> 00:21:07.701
That's where I defined it, right there.

435
00:21:07.701 --> 00:21:11.101
Hostname, dplaptop.lab.itpro.tv.

436
00:21:11.101 --> 00:21:13.020
So, I'm not seeing
the hostname take effect yet.

437
00:21:13.020 --> 00:21:16.490
Now, I've either picked the wrong file,
or i just need to do a reboot.

438
00:21:16.490 --> 00:21:18.770
Reboot is the path of least resistance,
so I'm gonna give a quick reboot,

439
00:21:18.770 --> 00:21:20.490
and we'll see if that takes care of it.

440
00:21:20.490 --> 00:21:22.620
If not, I'm gonna look for
a different file.

441
00:21:22.620 --> 00:21:26.810
Now, the other file that I would
expect to see is /etc/hostname.

442
00:21:26.810 --> 00:21:30.020
Now I looked for that file and
it didn't exist.

443
00:21:30.020 --> 00:21:35.270
So what's up with that, well that made me
think I didn't need it, but maybe I do.

444
00:21:35.270 --> 00:21:38.920
So just because it doesn't exist
doesn't mean I can't use it, right,

445
00:21:38.920 --> 00:21:40.430
I'll just go and create it.

446
00:21:40.430 --> 00:21:44.105
So if my hostname doesn't take effect
still, I'll go and create that file

447
00:21:44.105 --> 00:21:49.070
/etc/hostname and I'll just define my host
name right in there and that's about that.

448
00:21:49.070 --> 00:21:51.480
So we'll give that a chance and
see what happens there.

449
00:21:51.480 --> 00:21:55.140
So, there's one other file
that we need to be aware of.

450
00:21:55.140 --> 00:21:57.685
While this is rebooting
I'll talk about it.

451
00:21:57.685 --> 00:22:03.680
/etc/hosts you might wanna override
DNS lookups for certain things.

452
00:22:03.680 --> 00:22:06.120
You can edit that hosts file to do that.

453
00:22:06.120 --> 00:22:09.840
And so, you can put things like an IP
address to a particular name and

454
00:22:09.840 --> 00:22:12.260
it's great for testing and other services.

455
00:22:12.260 --> 00:22:13.950
So, that's pretty useful.

456
00:22:13.950 --> 00:22:16.110
Oh, here, my system's rebooting and

457
00:22:16.110 --> 00:22:20.000
I can see right on my login screen,
dplaptop.lab.itpro.tv.

458
00:22:20.000 --> 00:22:22.000
So, that's a good sign, right?

459
00:22:22.000 --> 00:22:24.780
That means that my host name likely
took effect and I don't have to go and

460
00:22:24.780 --> 00:22:25.740
create that other file.

461
00:22:25.740 --> 00:22:31.600
So, if I go back into my terminal,
there we go.

462
00:22:31.600 --> 00:22:35.490
There, I see my host name,
dpezet@dplaptop right?

463
00:22:35.490 --> 00:22:40.200
I've got my new host name and
it's dplaptop.lab.itpro.tv.

464
00:22:40.200 --> 00:22:41.620
So that worked out just fine.

465
00:22:41.620 --> 00:22:43.140
I didn't have to create that other file.

466
00:22:43.140 --> 00:22:46.040
Just be aware there are little
variations between distros and

467
00:22:46.040 --> 00:22:46.810
you might have to do that.

468
00:22:46.810 --> 00:22:50.470
Now, let's take a look
at that etc hosts file.

469
00:22:50.470 --> 00:22:55.350
So if I want to edit /etc/hosts
I can go in here and

470
00:22:55.350 --> 00:23:00.370
I can, whoops,
I can come in as a super user instead.

471
00:23:02.509 --> 00:23:04.885
All right, so I'm gonna go and
edit that file.

472
00:23:06.702 --> 00:23:11.322
And I can add in things,
like 1.1.1.1 is mapped to www.google.com.

473
00:23:11.322 --> 00:23:17.650
All right, now I know Google's not there,
but maybe I'm doing testing.

474
00:23:17.650 --> 00:23:20.910
I've got a production website, a staging
website, and I want to connect to staging.

475
00:23:20.910 --> 00:23:25.955
I can override those DNS lookups right
here and now when I do an nslookup, for

476
00:23:25.955 --> 00:23:33.050
www.google.com, well, I get this full list
because I'm querying the name server.

477
00:23:33.050 --> 00:23:38.317
But if I use something like
ping to www.google.com,

478
00:23:38.317 --> 00:23:42.674
I use my own lookup and I see 1.1.1.1.

479
00:23:42.674 --> 00:23:46.000
I've overridden what the DNS
servers would respond with.

480
00:23:46.000 --> 00:23:48.940
So, that's useful for testing or
for pulling pranks on people.

481
00:23:48.940 --> 00:23:52.030
I've had some fun with that.

482
00:23:52.030 --> 00:23:53.174
I'll go off on a tangent here.

483
00:23:53.174 --> 00:23:57.575
I pulled a prank on our help desk at the
bank I used to work for where I redirected

484
00:23:57.575 --> 00:24:01.396
all of Google to Bing and
I told them that Microsoft bought Google.

485
00:24:01.396 --> 00:24:02.603
[LAUGH]
>> And I walked in that morning,

486
00:24:02.603 --> 00:24:03.299
I was like, did you guys here?

487
00:24:03.299 --> 00:24:04.483
Microsoft bought Google.

488
00:24:04.483 --> 00:24:06.971
And, I had them going for about an hour,
it was pretty entertaining.

489
00:24:06.971 --> 00:24:08.202
It was just sad the help
desk didn't catch that one.

490
00:24:08.202 --> 00:24:09.055
>> That's a good one.

491
00:24:09.055 --> 00:24:10.291
>> But yeah,
you can have some fun with it.

492
00:24:10.291 --> 00:24:14.095
But using it for testing and staging,
that's where it's really handy.

493
00:24:14.095 --> 00:24:16.025
So, interesting stuff you can do there.

494
00:24:16.025 --> 00:24:20.215
That's really about it for
basic networking, am I missing anything?

495
00:24:20.215 --> 00:24:24.397
Let's see, oh,
I do wanna mention one other,

496
00:24:24.397 --> 00:24:30.075
this is not very common, but if you have
Solaris servers in your environment,

497
00:24:30.075 --> 00:24:34.265
then you might have what's
called a NIS+ domain, N-I-S+.

498
00:24:34.265 --> 00:24:36.520
And NIS+ is another type of name lookup.

499
00:24:36.520 --> 00:24:40.190
So it's not DNS, it's NIS+,
it's different, you might have that.

500
00:24:40.190 --> 00:24:43.391
And so
if you are in that kind of environment,

501
00:24:43.391 --> 00:24:48.213
there's another file in here,
/etc/nsswitch.conf, right?

502
00:24:48.213 --> 00:24:51.000
And that's where you'd
configure those name lookups.

503
00:24:51.000 --> 00:24:52.840
These are getting to be less and
less common.

504
00:24:52.840 --> 00:24:54.760
They used to be really
common back in the day.

505
00:24:54.760 --> 00:24:58.070
But these days, if you've got NIS+ or
whatever, you can define it here.

506
00:24:58.070 --> 00:25:02.430
The reason I bring it up is that you
can define DNS servers here too.

507
00:25:02.430 --> 00:25:05.210
And, so,
you could have a situation where a server

508
00:25:05.210 --> 00:25:08.420
has no DNS entries on its interface, and

509
00:25:08.420 --> 00:25:12.640
no DNS entries on /etc/resolve.conf,
but it's still doing name lookups.

510
00:25:12.640 --> 00:25:13.296
I'm like, how is this working?

511
00:25:13.296 --> 00:25:14.570
It's like magic.

512
00:25:14.570 --> 00:25:17.970
Well, it's not magic,
it may just be in this nsswitch file.

513
00:25:17.970 --> 00:25:21.300
Not very common at all, but I did want
to bring that up cuz that is possible.

514
00:25:21.300 --> 00:25:24.260
And if you scroll down, there's a ton of
settings in here that have absolutely

515
00:25:24.260 --> 00:25:26.810
nothing to do with name lookups but
with authentication.

516
00:25:26.810 --> 00:25:30.220
But you might have DNS entries
in here that define that, or

517
00:25:30.220 --> 00:25:32.210
it might even be disabling DNS lookups.

518
00:25:32.210 --> 00:25:34.370
Cuz see how you've got here your hosts?

519
00:25:34.370 --> 00:25:36.780
And it's got an order for
doing the lookups.

520
00:25:36.780 --> 00:25:40.490
It's saying look at files first,
\etc\hosts, and

521
00:25:40.490 --> 00:25:44.290
then look at dns second,
it's setting that priority.

522
00:25:44.290 --> 00:25:46.344
And they coulc remove DNS from that list,

523
00:25:46.344 --> 00:25:49.990
and now you won't do a lookup against
DNS even if you got servers defined.

524
00:25:49.990 --> 00:25:54.760
So just be aware that nsswitch.conf file
seems like it's outdated and useless, but

525
00:25:54.760 --> 00:25:59.530
it does actually have some power here in
defining the order in which we do lookups.

526
00:25:59.530 --> 00:26:03.820
If you need nisplus, you'd come in and
add nisplus to the search order.

527
00:26:03.820 --> 00:26:05.930
And you could either override or

528
00:26:05.930 --> 00:26:10.020
make it secondary to DNS, depending
on the order of this line right here.

529
00:26:10.020 --> 00:26:11.880
So kind of an important file to have.

530
00:26:11.880 --> 00:26:13.190
>> Awesome stuff, Don.

531
00:26:13.190 --> 00:26:16.678
Now I did notice something, I remembered
something and one of our viewers here in

532
00:26:16.678 --> 00:26:20.235
our chat room reminded me of that when we
were talking about the ifconfig command.

533
00:26:20.235 --> 00:26:23.983
Not always is it bundled with the actual
operating system that you may have

534
00:26:23.983 --> 00:26:24.716
downloaded.

535
00:26:24.716 --> 00:26:28.980
So CentOS happens to be one
of those operating systems.

536
00:26:28.980 --> 00:26:32.641
I know that first thing I did was try to
do an ifconfig when I installed CentOS and

537
00:26:32.641 --> 00:26:34.208
it was like, command not found.

538
00:26:34.208 --> 00:26:35.572
I said, okay.

539
00:26:35.572 --> 00:26:38.990
So just make sure if that does happen,
you just have to download the net tools.

540
00:26:38.990 --> 00:26:42.860
So if you're running a Red Hat version
it would just be yum install net tools.

541
00:26:42.860 --> 00:26:48.050
So if it's a Debian fork then it's
just app get install net tools.

542
00:26:48.050 --> 00:26:51.740
And then you should get right back into
order, that should help out with that.

543
00:26:51.740 --> 00:26:52.860
So in case you just run that command,

544
00:26:52.860 --> 00:26:56.080
you get a command not found,
easily fixed, not a big deal.

545
00:26:56.080 --> 00:26:58.310
>> Yeah, and you usually see that
when you do like a minimal install.

546
00:26:58.310 --> 00:27:00.300
What we do on a server,
you choose minimal install.

547
00:27:00.300 --> 00:27:03.140
They're gonna give you just what
you absolutely have to have.

548
00:27:03.140 --> 00:27:05.600
Well, do I need ifconfig?

549
00:27:05.600 --> 00:27:09.160
You actually don't, cuz you can just go
and edit your configuration files and

550
00:27:09.160 --> 00:27:10.150
restart the network service.

551
00:27:10.150 --> 00:27:13.350
You don't actually need ifconfig for
that so they leave it out.

552
00:27:13.350 --> 00:27:15.660
It's going a little too
literal in my opinion,

553
00:27:15.660 --> 00:27:19.260
it is nice to have a tool to be
able to see what the heck is up.

554
00:27:19.260 --> 00:27:22.230
But there are some other commands that are
out there that you can use to troubleshoot

555
00:27:22.230 --> 00:27:24.620
and find information, but
yeah, that's basically it.

556
00:27:24.620 --> 00:27:25.280
>> All right, guys.

557
00:27:25.280 --> 00:27:28.720
Well hopefully you have definitely
seen how we can do this.

558
00:27:28.720 --> 00:27:31.760
Not that difficult, you just gotta
know where these things go, and

559
00:27:31.760 --> 00:27:32.760
that's all it takes.

560
00:27:32.760 --> 00:27:35.280
And then all the settings,
you go right in, you should know that.

561
00:27:35.280 --> 00:27:37.380
That being said, we've come to
the end of another great episode.

562
00:27:37.380 --> 00:27:40.449
Signing off for ITProTV,
I've been your host, Daniel Lowrie.

563
00:27:40.449 --> 00:27:41.351
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

564
00:27:41.351 --> 00:27:42.500
>> And we'll see you next time.

565
00:27:42.500 --> 00:27:48.470
[SOUND]

episodes.title: Diagnosing Networking
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.606 --> 00:00:12.362
Greetings everyone!

3
00:00:12.362 --> 00:00:16.500
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'll be your host today, Daniel Lowrie.

4
00:00:16.500 --> 00:00:20.610
Here with me is a man who mostly does
all his Linux work at night, mostly.

5
00:00:20.610 --> 00:00:21.490
That's Don Pezet.

6
00:00:21.490 --> 00:00:22.560
How's it going today, Don?

7
00:00:22.560 --> 00:00:24.205
>> I'm doing great, Daniel.

8
00:00:24.205 --> 00:00:27.862
We're going to continue our networking
trifecta here for this episode, and

9
00:00:27.862 --> 00:00:31.349
we're going to jump right back into
the world of Linux plus networking but

10
00:00:31.349 --> 00:00:34.385
this time we're not going to focus
on how to set things up right,

11
00:00:34.385 --> 00:00:37.900
we're going to focus on how to figure
things out when they're not right.

12
00:00:37.900 --> 00:00:39.310
When things are going wrong.

13
00:00:39.310 --> 00:00:42.420
We've got a ton of diagnostic
utilities built into Linux and

14
00:00:42.420 --> 00:00:44.740
we need to be familiar with them
to use them for trouble shooting.

15
00:00:44.740 --> 00:00:46.960
I've got a laundry list of tools
that we're going to talk about here.

16
00:00:46.960 --> 00:00:50.100
It'll be a great chance for
us to see those and see how they work.

17
00:00:50.100 --> 00:00:50.880
>> Yeah, good stuff Don.

18
00:00:50.880 --> 00:00:52.110
This is really the meat and

19
00:00:52.110 --> 00:00:56.950
potatoes of being a network
administrators portion of Linux plus.

20
00:00:56.950 --> 00:00:58.780
And when things do go a little haywire,

21
00:00:58.780 --> 00:01:01.960
maybe a little left turn on you, well
you're not completely out in the dark.

22
00:01:01.960 --> 00:01:05.300
You've got some things at your fingertips,
you just gotta pull them up,

23
00:01:05.300 --> 00:01:07.530
start employing them, and
then you'll figure out what's wrong,

24
00:01:07.530 --> 00:01:09.930
hopefully get things fixed
back to a working order.

25
00:01:09.930 --> 00:01:11.580
So Don, where do we start?

26
00:01:11.580 --> 00:01:15.320
>> All right, well the first tool I wanna
start with is one we've already seen,

27
00:01:15.320 --> 00:01:17.130
which is ifconfig.

28
00:01:17.130 --> 00:01:20.480
Ifconfig is a great way to see what
network adaptors you have, whether they

29
00:01:20.480 --> 00:01:23.180
have IP addresses, and whether
they're sending and receiving traffic.

30
00:01:23.180 --> 00:01:26.380
So, let me just take my system here and

31
00:01:26.380 --> 00:01:30.240
I'm gonna run ifconfig, and let me stretch
my window out a little bit here so

32
00:01:30.240 --> 00:01:33.740
I don't get any kind of word
wrap on this guy, there we go.

33
00:01:33.740 --> 00:01:36.410
And you can see on my system
I've got two network adaptors.

34
00:01:36.410 --> 00:01:39.160
Now you'll usually have at least two.

35
00:01:39.160 --> 00:01:40.870
You might have three or four or even more.

36
00:01:40.870 --> 00:01:44.700
If you got a laptop that has wireless and
wired connections you'll see those laid

37
00:01:44.700 --> 00:01:50.470
out and you'll see usually one virtual
interface called LO for your loopback.

38
00:01:50.470 --> 00:01:53.010
Now your physical interface,
like the name implies,

39
00:01:53.010 --> 00:01:55.810
is tied to a physical
adaptor on your system.

40
00:01:55.810 --> 00:01:59.720
If it's up, you should see
an IP address like I see here.

41
00:01:59.720 --> 00:02:02.780
You might have an IPv6 address,
which you might see.

42
00:02:02.780 --> 00:02:06.070
I can see that mine is indeed up and
not down, right.

43
00:02:06.070 --> 00:02:08.820
That's some of the output
that it's giving me here.

44
00:02:08.820 --> 00:02:12.180
There's other information on here that's
not too terribly useful, like whether or

45
00:02:12.180 --> 00:02:15.400
not we support broadcast,
whether we support multicast,

46
00:02:15.400 --> 00:02:18.720
what our maximum transmission unit,
or MTU, size is.

47
00:02:18.720 --> 00:02:23.190
These are all pretty standard, so
we don't normally see variations on these.

48
00:02:23.190 --> 00:02:26.690
But the next couple of
lines are really important.

49
00:02:26.690 --> 00:02:30.310
These are kind of like
your status messages here.

50
00:02:30.310 --> 00:02:32.425
Telling us about
the health of the adapter.

51
00:02:32.425 --> 00:02:37.054
You can see how many packets you've
received and how many packets you've sent,

52
00:02:37.054 --> 00:02:37.746
all right?

53
00:02:37.746 --> 00:02:42.644
I can see I 've received 5,012,
I've sent 138.

54
00:02:42.644 --> 00:02:44.830
Now, if you see one of those as zero.

55
00:02:44.830 --> 00:02:46.470
I haven't received anything.

56
00:02:46.470 --> 00:02:49.430
Well, I may not be plugged
into the network properly.

57
00:02:49.430 --> 00:02:51.000
Or if I see that I've received but

58
00:02:51.000 --> 00:02:54.210
I haven't sent anything,
I might be missing my IP address.

59
00:02:54.210 --> 00:02:56.300
I'm not gonna send anything if
I don't have an IP address.

60
00:02:56.300 --> 00:02:58.490
So you can use these
numbers to gauge whether or

61
00:02:58.490 --> 00:03:01.420
not traffic is even flowing
over your adapter at all.

62
00:03:02.480 --> 00:03:04.540
You can also see any
errors you’ve received.

63
00:03:04.540 --> 00:03:07.510
Those would be packets that came in or
went out that were malformed.

64
00:03:07.510 --> 00:03:10.220
Any that were dropped or overruns.

65
00:03:10.220 --> 00:03:12.850
Overruns are ones that
are bigger than your MTU.

66
00:03:12.850 --> 00:03:16.450
Dropped ones, those are typically ones
that come in and you’ve run out of memory.

67
00:03:16.450 --> 00:03:19.530
Every network adapter has a certain amount
of memory that it uses to store packets

68
00:03:19.530 --> 00:03:24.270
while it processes them and if that memory
fills up you start dropping packets.

00:03:24.270 --> 00:03:27.540

00:03:27.540 --> 00:03:29.940

00:03:29.940 --> 00:03:34.300

to be zero unless there's a problem.

72
00:03:34.300 --> 00:03:36.150
Other things you can see, collisions.

73
00:03:38.200 --> 00:03:41.620
Most, not most, all, ethernet networks,

74
00:03:41.620 --> 00:03:45.437
use a multi broadcast
multi access type network.

75
00:03:45.437 --> 00:03:48.940
So, you can have more than one
computer talking at the same time And

76
00:03:48.940 --> 00:03:51.410
if that happens, they collide.

77
00:03:51.410 --> 00:03:54.090
So they do thing called CSMACD.

78
00:03:54.090 --> 00:03:55.850
We don't care about this too much,

79
00:03:55.850 --> 00:03:59.840
but it's Carrier Sense Multiple
Access Collision Detection.

80
00:03:59.840 --> 00:04:02.740
Your system is listening for
when a collision happens.

81
00:04:02.740 --> 00:04:05.870
Cuz if two electrical signals hit each
other, they just gets scrambled, and

82
00:04:05.870 --> 00:04:06.910
you lose your data.

83
00:04:06.910 --> 00:04:09.020
So you have to listen for that,
and if there's a collision,

84
00:04:09.020 --> 00:04:10.490
you have to re-transmit.

85
00:04:10.490 --> 00:04:13.210
Well, if you're plugged
into a switch network,

86
00:04:13.210 --> 00:04:14.880
you don't normally have collisions.

87
00:04:14.880 --> 00:04:16.530
Unless there's a real problem.

88
00:04:16.530 --> 00:04:19.340
If you're on a hub network,
collisions are actually pretty common.

89
00:04:19.340 --> 00:04:21.390
So on a hub network,
we kinda ignore that value.

90
00:04:21.390 --> 00:04:23.210
But on a switch network,
you can watch this.

91
00:04:23.210 --> 00:04:26.140
And if you see your collisions going up,
it normally indicates some

92
00:04:26.140 --> 00:04:29.280

you're having network issues.

93
00:04:29.280 --> 00:04:31.630

though,

00:04:31.630 --> 00:04:33.180

00:08:20.170 --> 00:08:21.550

00:08:21.550 --> 00:08:22.640

00:08:22.640 --> 00:08:25.390

00:08:25.390 --> 00:08:27.620

00:08:27.620 --> 00:08:29.700

00:08:29.700 --> 00:08:31.980

00:08:33.300 --> 00:08:37.211
Now, if I ping 127.0.0.1,

00:08:37.211 --> 00:08:41.170

00:08:41.170 --> 00:08:44.210

test your TCPIP stack.

00:08:44.210 --> 00:08:47.831
Just using software by pinging 127.001.

194
00:08:47.831 --> 00:08:54.170
But if I ping my actual IP, if I ping
that IP, now it's using my hardware.

195
00:08:54.170 --> 00:08:56.528
The ping actually goes to the network
adapter and comes back again.

196
00:08:56.528 --> 00:08:59.487
So this is a great way to test
your network adapter driver.

00:08:59.487 --> 00:09:01.200

what software is generating them.

00:25:39.610 --> 00:25:43.542
Right?
So that was nets@-atp.

531
00:25:43.542 --> 00:25:47.900
All right, you can modify that,
if you drop the a, a stands for active.

532
00:25:47.900 --> 00:25:50.690
I'm showing all of the active connections.

533
00:25:50.690 --> 00:25:53.560
I'm sorry,
let me get this correct the A means all.

534
00:25:53.560 --> 00:25:55.250
We're seeing all the connections.

535
00:25:55.250 --> 00:25:59.900
If I leave the A off,
it's gonna show me only the active ones.

536
00:25:59.900 --> 00:26:02.760
Because some of these are in
like time-wait, right?

537
00:26:02.760 --> 00:26:04.440
So they're not actually doing
anything anymore, right?

538
00:26:04.440 --> 00:26:08.095
They're kinda sitting there stalled,
but other ones are sleeping.

539
00:26:08.095 --> 00:26:09.915
In other words, they're about to close.

540
00:26:09.915 --> 00:26:12.755
And so when you leave the A off,
the ones that are sleeping,

541
00:26:12.755 --> 00:26:14.895
which I guess didn't have
any that were sleeping, and

542
00:26:14.895 --> 00:26:16.755
the ones that are all about to close,
it leaves them off.

543
00:26:16.755 --> 00:26:19.625
And you just see what's truly
active on your system right then.

544
00:26:19.625 --> 00:26:23.705
So that was netstat -tp, like that.

545
00:26:23.705 --> 00:26:25.105
What else do we want?

546
00:26:25.105 --> 00:26:26.535
Netstat is actually really powerful.

547
00:26:26.535 --> 00:26:28.750
You can do things like netstat -- route.

548
00:26:28.750 --> 00:26:32.100
And it'll show your routing table.

549
00:26:32.100 --> 00:26:33.800
Not any different than route- n, right?

550
00:26:33.800 --> 00:26:40.580
But you can get it in one command if you
want, netstat-- program is another one.

551
00:26:40.580 --> 00:26:42.440
We already saw the program output, but

552
00:26:42.440 --> 00:26:45.930
netstat-- program goes a little bit
beyond because it'll start to give you

553
00:26:45.930 --> 00:26:49.490
some additional information about the
software that's accessing the resources.

554
00:26:49.490 --> 00:26:52.130
So you can see some kind of neat
information there about what it is that's

555
00:26:52.130 --> 00:26:54.880
truly generating those connections,
where they're coming from, but

556
00:26:54.880 --> 00:26:58.200
sometimes you'll see things like,
the users temp files and

557
00:26:58.200 --> 00:27:02.610
stuff that are involved, which helps you
isolate who's doing what on the system.

558
00:27:02.610 --> 00:27:04.400
So, few different variations in that set.

559
00:27:06.360 --> 00:27:10.200
All right, the last command
that I want to talk about,

560
00:27:10.200 --> 00:27:12.160
is probably the most technical.

561
00:27:12.160 --> 00:27:13.140
All these things we've run so

562
00:27:13.140 --> 00:27:15.890
far, the output you can pretty
much interpret on your own.

563
00:27:15.890 --> 00:27:20.310
But there are times where you
just need to see the raw network

564
00:27:20.310 --> 00:27:22.240
data moving through your system.

565
00:27:22.240 --> 00:27:25.390
And for that we have the tcp dump command.

566
00:27:25.390 --> 00:27:27.660
Now if you use tcp dump,
the command itself is pretty simple,

567
00:27:27.660 --> 00:27:33.030
you can just say tcp dump-I,
followed by an interface.

568
00:27:33.030 --> 00:27:37.300
So if I want to monitor eth0,
I can run that.

569
00:27:37.300 --> 00:27:40.570
All the network data sent out is being
rendered on my screen right here.

570
00:27:40.570 --> 00:27:43.880
I can see every single packet
moving in and out of my system.

571
00:27:43.880 --> 00:27:45.770
But, as you can see, it.

572
00:27:45.770 --> 00:27:48.105
>> I don't think you can see it, Don.

573
00:27:48.105 --> 00:27:48.750
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah,

574
00:27:48.750 --> 00:27:53.410
so what we normally do is you run tcpdump
and you pipe that into like a file.

575
00:27:53.410 --> 00:27:58.780
So, I might create a netdata.txt file and
so I start dumping into that.

576
00:27:58.780 --> 00:28:01.960
So it's running and it's dumping
that data right into that file.

577
00:28:01.960 --> 00:28:05.816
And I can switch to another tab.

578
00:28:05.816 --> 00:28:06.872
Leave that one be.

579
00:28:08.115 --> 00:28:12.960
And, let me see if I can figure out
where I just put that netdata file.

580
00:28:12.960 --> 00:28:16.930
There it is and you can stop the dump and
then edit that file or

581
00:28:16.930 --> 00:28:20.150
I can do like a tail -f of netdata.

582
00:28:20.150 --> 00:28:23.410
And now it's just gonna show
me the ten most recent ones.

583
00:28:23.410 --> 00:28:26.470
And so I can kinda spot that and see how
it's updating to show me the most recent

584
00:28:26.470 --> 00:28:30.180
ten or maybe I don't even want that,
maybe I just want to tail it and

585
00:28:30.180 --> 00:28:35.060
get what it's generated so far and there
I can see kinda like last little bits.

586
00:28:35.060 --> 00:28:36.960
This is good for trouble shooting, too.

587
00:28:36.960 --> 00:28:39.670
Am I seeing traffic actually
reach my machine at all?

588
00:28:39.670 --> 00:28:41.610
Somebody says,
hey I can't ping your machine.

589
00:28:41.610 --> 00:28:45.410
Well I might fire up TCP dump and say,
am I even seeing their pings hit me?

590
00:28:45.410 --> 00:28:48.800
And that will tell you, if you see them
hit and they're not getting a response,

591
00:28:48.800 --> 00:28:49.930
maybe you're blocking it with IP tables.

592
00:28:49.930 --> 00:28:51.860
You're blocking it with your firewall, or

593
00:28:51.860 --> 00:28:55.350
if you don't even see them get here,
it's not your fault.

594
00:28:55.350 --> 00:28:57.260
Sorry buddy, you're getting
blocked somewhere in between,

595
00:28:57.260 --> 00:29:01.002
it's not my computer that's the problem,
I don't even see your pings here.

596
00:29:01.002 --> 00:29:05.140
So tcpdump is pretty handy for
that, and it's really powerful

597
00:29:05.140 --> 00:29:09.660
If you pull up the man page for tcbdump,
you can actually write filters, and

598
00:29:09.660 --> 00:29:13.730
you can say only capture traffic
coming from this source IP or

599
00:29:13.730 --> 00:29:17.050
going to this destination port,
like just capture my Telnet traffic.

600
00:29:17.050 --> 00:29:20.490
You can say things like that in this
command line, it's pretty powerful.

601
00:29:20.490 --> 00:29:24.180
They give some examples in
the man page somewhere in here.

602
00:29:24.180 --> 00:29:25.920
I think I just scrolled one.

603
00:29:25.920 --> 00:29:31.240
Yeah, here, so they're doing tcpdump for
just TCP port 80 and

604
00:29:31.240 --> 00:29:36.670
when the IP address falls in some kind of
range, doing with just gateway traffic.

605
00:29:36.670 --> 00:29:40.470
You can filter by all sorts of
cool stuff to minimize the,

606
00:29:40.470 --> 00:29:43.140
just data overload that you get out of it.

607
00:29:43.140 --> 00:29:44.890
So, very powerful command.

608
00:29:44.890 --> 00:29:47.030
I think it's there by default
on most of the distros.

609
00:29:47.030 --> 00:29:49.610
I've never encountered a machine
that didn't have tcpdump.

610
00:29:49.610 --> 00:29:50.980
It just always seems to be there.

611
00:29:50.980 --> 00:29:52.770
>> Yeah.
It's a wonderful tool and, of course,

612
00:29:52.770 --> 00:29:54.250
there's always Wireshark, but

613
00:29:54.250 --> 00:29:57.720
Wireshark usually doesn't come
pre-installed on your system.

614
00:29:57.720 --> 00:30:01.720
tcpdump, like Don said, is normally
pre-installed on your system, so

615
00:30:01.720 --> 00:30:04.550
it's good to get familiar with it because
you never know when you're just gonna

616
00:30:04.550 --> 00:30:08.170
sit behind a terminal and you need to
troubleshoot, and you can use these tools.

617
00:30:08.170 --> 00:30:11.760
All of these tools are typically
found on any Linux distro.

618
00:30:11.760 --> 00:30:13.270
That should might be working with.

619
00:30:13.270 --> 00:30:14.320
>> Yeah, and they're all CLI, right?

620
00:30:14.320 --> 00:30:18.020
Remember Wireshark, if you're on a server
and no GUI, good luck using Wireshark.

621
00:30:18.020 --> 00:30:22.410
It's great software, but, you know,
great software on your laptop.

622
00:30:22.410 --> 00:30:25.090
So on a server you don't
have those resources.

623
00:30:25.090 --> 00:30:27.470
TCP dump is nice, you can just fire
it up real quick, gather your data.

624
00:30:27.470 --> 00:30:30.080
I've used it tuns of times,
very, very valuable.

625
00:30:30.080 --> 00:30:33.160
>> Well Don looks like we've wrapped
up yet another Linux plus episode.

626
00:30:33.160 --> 00:30:35.998
Hopefully all you guys out there watching,
you've learned a lot from this.

627
00:30:35.998 --> 00:30:39.270
This is gonna help you a lot when it
comes to that network trouble shooting,

628
00:30:39.270 --> 00:30:41.440
all those great tools that
we've shown you for today.

629
00:30:41.440 --> 00:30:44.303
That being said it is time to sign off.

630
00:30:44.303 --> 00:30:45.787
I've been your host, Daniel Lowrie.

631
00:30:45.787 --> 00:30:46.809
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

632
00:30:46.809 --> 00:30:48.051
>> And we'll see you next time.

633
00:30:48.051 --> 00:30:53.950
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don round out network troubleshooting for Linux+, starting with a quick review of some common troubleshooting tools like ifconfig and ip. Then they take a look at some of the newer versions of older standard tools which includes ping6, traceroute6, and tracepath6; to prepare you for IPv6 networks. Also covered is the netcat tool, as well as network configuration files that are helpful when troubleshooting.
episodes.title: Diagnosing Networking Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.306 --> 00:00:17.341
All right, greetings, everyone and welcome
to another exciting episode of ITPro TV.

3
00:00:17.341 --> 00:00:20.430
I'm your host, Daniel Lowry,
and in today's episode, well,

4
00:00:20.430 --> 00:00:24.191
we're continuing on with our Linux Plus
series Joining me in the studio today is

5
00:00:24.191 --> 00:00:27.250
our good friend, our colleague,
our mentor, Mr. Don Pezet.

6
00:00:27.250 --> 00:00:28.820
Don, welcome back to the show, sir.

7
00:00:28.820 --> 00:00:32.450
>> Thanks for having me back, Daniel, and
back to jump into the world of Linux Plus,

8
00:00:32.450 --> 00:00:35.920
we're gonna continue on with our
network troubleshooting series that we

9
00:00:35.920 --> 00:00:37.170
started in the last episode.

10
00:00:37.170 --> 00:00:41.020
We had to really see some good things that
were there, as far as trying to identify

11
00:00:41.020 --> 00:00:43.890
the source of a problem, some of
the different places we might have issues.

12
00:00:43.890 --> 00:00:45.900
We saw a lot of tools that we could use.

13
00:00:45.900 --> 00:00:49.530
But there were a few things we didn't get
to, like we really didn't mention IPv6 or

14
00:00:49.530 --> 00:00:51.025
a few other configuration files.

15
00:00:51.025 --> 00:00:54.314
So we're gonna take a look at those today
in this episode and kind of shore that up

16
00:00:54.314 --> 00:00:57.780
and make sure that we have everything
that we need to be prepared for the exam.

17
00:00:57.780 --> 00:01:01.350
>> That's right, we want to wrap it up in
a nice little bow in a pretty pink package

18
00:01:01.350 --> 00:01:04.750
so that you guys are ready for
that test when you sit in that seat.

19
00:01:04.750 --> 00:01:07.070
That being said, Don,
there are some good basics and

20
00:01:07.070 --> 00:01:10.540
maybe that's a good place to begin,
just to refresh things in our mind.

21
00:01:10.540 --> 00:01:12.970
What are some of those
tools that we're gonna use

22
00:01:12.970 --> 00:01:15.060
to troubleshoot network
connectivity issues?

23
00:01:15.060 --> 00:01:17.710
>> All right, one of the tools I
wanna talk is ifconfig, right.

24
00:01:17.710 --> 00:01:19.830
Ifconfig is the interface
configuration utility.

25
00:01:19.830 --> 00:01:21.990
It's been around in Linux for a long time.

26
00:01:21.990 --> 00:01:25.390
And I know we used it in the last
episode to check our interfaces.

27
00:01:25.390 --> 00:01:29.190
And I got some feedback from viewers out
there in the field that were saying, hey,

28
00:01:29.190 --> 00:01:32.329
Don, I've seen some distros that
didn't come with ifconfig, and

29
00:01:32.329 --> 00:01:33.618
that's absolutely true.

30
00:01:33.618 --> 00:01:36.980
Some of the newer distros are not
packaging it with them anymore.

31
00:01:36.980 --> 00:01:40.581
And they've replaced it with
a new utility that's just,

32
00:01:40.581 --> 00:01:42.793
the old IP routing utilities or IP.

33
00:01:42.793 --> 00:01:45.819
Well, you might even find some
distros that don't have that one,

34
00:01:45.819 --> 00:01:49.210
that really just don't have any
troubleshooting utilities at all.

35
00:01:49.210 --> 00:01:50.780
And I'm on a great example here.

36
00:01:50.780 --> 00:01:55.917
I've got a, this is a centOS 7 install,
right, so if I look at my little Red Hat

37
00:01:55.917 --> 00:02:01.990
release file here, I'm running centOS 7.2,
and this is a minimal install, right.

38
00:02:01.990 --> 00:02:04.660
When you do a minimal install, this is
like what you would do on a server.

39
00:02:04.660 --> 00:02:06.170
And so if I'm bringing up a new server,

40
00:02:06.170 --> 00:02:08.360
I don't wanna install a bunch
of extra utilities or anything.

41
00:02:08.360 --> 00:02:10.490
I just want the minimum
stuff to get it working.

42
00:02:10.490 --> 00:02:13.670
Well, it doesn't have ifconfig.

43
00:02:13.670 --> 00:02:14.887
It doesn't have IP.

44
00:02:14.887 --> 00:02:16.880
Heck, I don't think it even
has traceroute, does it?

45
00:02:16.880 --> 00:02:18.050
Yeah, it doesn't even have traceroute.

46
00:02:18.050 --> 00:02:20.752
So a lot of the tools we talked
about in the last episode you,

47
00:02:20.752 --> 00:02:22.221
you may not have in your distro.

48
00:02:22.221 --> 00:02:24.980
And so you may need to install
them to be able to use them.

49
00:02:24.980 --> 00:02:28.040
All right, well, if you know
the package names that's really easy.

50
00:02:28.040 --> 00:02:29.590
Sometimes we need a little more though.

51
00:02:29.590 --> 00:02:31.391
So, for example, this is a centOS box.

52
00:02:31.391 --> 00:02:36.920
So I can do yum install on a Debian Box or
Ubuntu, you do app get.

53
00:02:36.920 --> 00:02:40.350
If I try and do an install for
traceroute, right?

54
00:02:40.350 --> 00:02:41.140
Well, that's no big deal.

55
00:02:41.140 --> 00:02:41.960
It's gonna install it.

56
00:02:41.960 --> 00:02:43.630
There we go and now I've got traceroute.

57
00:02:43.630 --> 00:02:47.000
But what if I try that for ifconfig?

58
00:02:48.160 --> 00:02:50.280
Nothing to do, there's no package, right?

59
00:02:50.280 --> 00:02:54.690
Because these commands, they've been
ingrained in the system so long, they

60
00:02:54.690 --> 00:02:58.240
don't actually have a dedicated package
to themselves or part of another package.

61
00:02:58.240 --> 00:03:04.720
So, in a Red Hat based system, you can do
yum provides and then look for a command.

62
00:03:04.720 --> 00:03:07.970
And so, if you do that, you can look and
find out which command or

63
00:03:07.970 --> 00:03:09.460
which packages that contains that.

64
00:03:09.460 --> 00:03:12.250
So, when I do yum provides ifconfig,
it's gonna look and

65
00:03:12.250 --> 00:03:14.395
it will show that it's part
of the net tools package.

66
00:03:14.395 --> 00:03:19.418
And so if I know that, now I know I
need to install the net tools package.

67
00:03:19.418 --> 00:03:22.478
And same thing for the IP command,
it's part of the IP route package and

68
00:03:22.478 --> 00:03:24.170
so you can find those and install them.

69
00:03:24.170 --> 00:03:25.635
So I'm gonna do that real quick.

70
00:03:25.635 --> 00:03:29.665
I'll install the net tools package and
the IP route package.

71
00:03:29.665 --> 00:03:33.245
That's gonna get me the older
ifconfig command and

72
00:03:33.245 --> 00:03:36.105
the newer IP command that I can use for
troubleshooting.

73
00:03:36.105 --> 00:03:40.185
So now if I want to run ifconfig,
I can, and there's my interfaces and

74
00:03:40.185 --> 00:03:41.035
I can get the information.

75
00:03:41.035 --> 00:03:43.915
So in the last episode we just
kind of treated it like ifconfig

76
00:03:43.915 --> 00:03:45.210
was always gonna be there.

77
00:03:45.210 --> 00:03:47.480
But in case it isn't,
this is how we get past it and

78
00:03:47.480 --> 00:03:48.710
now we've got it up and running.

79
00:03:48.710 --> 00:03:53.550
We can see our interfaces,
our IP addresses, we can see our netmask.

80
00:03:53.550 --> 00:03:56.675
Right here we can see our IPv6 address,
and so on,

81
00:03:56.675 --> 00:03:59.738
just like we saw on the other episode,
all right.

82
00:03:59.738 --> 00:04:02.813
However, a lot of distros
are moving away from ifconfig and

83
00:04:02.813 --> 00:04:06.256
moving to the IP command, so
I wanna show you that one real quick and

84
00:04:06.256 --> 00:04:08.182
how we can get the same information.

85
00:04:08.182 --> 00:04:09.668
>> It's blasphemy, Don, blasphemy!

86
00:04:09.668 --> 00:04:10.411
>> [LAUGH] I know.

87
00:04:10.411 --> 00:04:11.904
>> [LAUGH]
>> It's hard to change.

88
00:04:11.904 --> 00:04:14.992
And in the Unix world, believe me,
people are resistant to change, but

89
00:04:14.992 --> 00:04:17.129
it does happen and
some of the commands are nicer.

90
00:04:17.129 --> 00:04:18.970
When we look at this we
get a lot of information.

91
00:04:18.970 --> 00:04:22.650
We get our layer three addresses
right here, so our IP addressing.

92
00:04:22.650 --> 00:04:25.630
Then we get our layer two address in here,
our Mac address.

93
00:04:25.630 --> 00:04:28.530
And then we get our statistics
all lumped into one output.

94
00:04:28.530 --> 00:04:31.270
And if you have a lot of adapters
this can be a lot of data.

95
00:04:31.270 --> 00:04:33.660
Well, what the IP command
does is it breaks it up.

96
00:04:33.660 --> 00:04:37.330
If I do IP Addr, right?

97
00:04:37.330 --> 00:04:39.940
That's gonna show me my layer three data.

98
00:04:39.940 --> 00:04:43.028
So now I see my interfaces and
their layer three information, and

99
00:04:43.028 --> 00:04:46.780
it's more detailed than what I would
get with the old ifconfig command.

100
00:04:46.780 --> 00:04:51.150
So, not only do I see my IPv4 addresses or
whatever, right?

101
00:04:51.150 --> 00:04:52.510
So here's an IPv4 address.

102
00:04:52.510 --> 00:04:55.110
But I also see the subnet mask and

103
00:04:55.110 --> 00:04:57.600
the other additional information
applied to it, right?

104
00:04:57.600 --> 00:04:59.470
And I can get my link status right here.

105
00:04:59.470 --> 00:05:02.110
I can see, for example,
that this one is up and running.

106
00:05:02.110 --> 00:05:06.160
It's all right there laid out for
me with ip addr.

107
00:05:06.160 --> 00:05:08.510
You can also run ip link.

108
00:05:08.510 --> 00:05:10.680
And if you're on ip link,
you just see the link status.

109
00:05:10.680 --> 00:05:12.757
And so you get that information
kind of popping up right there.

110
00:05:12.757 --> 00:05:17.170
And it's just a little bit pared down,
so it's a little less to overwhelm you.

111
00:05:17.170 --> 00:05:18.720
And you can get the statistics.

112
00:05:18.720 --> 00:05:20.147
And neither of those had statistics,
right?

113
00:05:20.147 --> 00:05:22.900
So I can say ip -s link.

114
00:05:22.900 --> 00:05:27.270
Show me the statistics for my links and
now I get those when I need them, right.

115
00:05:27.270 --> 00:05:29.806
So a few different commands to replace
what used to be one command but

116
00:05:29.806 --> 00:05:32.263
it does give you a little more

the configuring/networking episode.

00:27:37.880 --> 00:27:39.200
Definitely check that one out.

562
00:27:39.200 --> 00:27:44.430
There's also
the /etc/sysconfig/network file.

563
00:27:44.430 --> 00:27:45.870
And if I take a look at that one,

564
00:27:45.870 --> 00:27:48.850
that one's kind of important because
you can set a default gateway.

565
00:27:48.850 --> 00:27:51.940
And you can set DNS name servers in there
too, although most people don't do that.

566
00:27:51.940 --> 00:27:53.590
So your gateway might be set in this file.

567
00:27:53.590 --> 00:27:56.340
Mine's empty cuz everything's
set somewhere else.

568
00:27:56.340 --> 00:28:00.560
And then if you're on a Debian or
Ubuntu system, I'm on CentOS so

569
00:28:00.560 --> 00:28:01.850
I'm not gonna have it.

570
00:28:01.850 --> 00:28:08.080
But for them, it's usually /etc/network
and then in there, you'll have a file or

571
00:28:08.080 --> 00:28:10.940
a folder called interfaces, depending
on the system, usually it's a file.

572
00:28:10.940 --> 00:28:13.980
And you'll see your interface
configuration there.

573
00:28:13.980 --> 00:28:17.270
Be familiar with those configuration
files because if there's a mistake in

574
00:28:17.270 --> 00:28:20.150
one of them, then that's gonna
lead to your network not working.

575
00:28:20.150 --> 00:28:23.160
So check out our network configuration
episode and we covered those files,

576
00:28:23.160 --> 00:28:24.680
I just wanted to repeat
them real quick here.

577
00:28:24.680 --> 00:28:26.040
>> Awesome stuff Don, well thank you so

578
00:28:26.040 --> 00:28:29.810
much for joining us today and showing
us how we can start to troubleshoot

579
00:28:29.810 --> 00:28:34.460
some of the issues that we might
walk into as Linux users and admins.

580
00:28:34.460 --> 00:28:37.160
That being said, looks like we've wrapped
up another great show, thank you again for

581
00:28:37.160 --> 00:28:39.190
joining us, thank you guys for watching.

582
00:28:39.190 --> 00:28:41.174
We're going to sign off for ITProTV.

583
00:28:41.174 --> 00:28:42.417
I've been you host, Daniel Lowrie.

584
00:28:42.417 --> 00:28:43.276
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

585
00:28:43.276 --> 00:28:44.900
>> And we'll see you next time.

586
00:28:44.900 --> 00:28:52.190
