episodes.title: Managing the Shell
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.865
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:10.865 --> 00:00:15.270
All right everyone, greetings and welcome
to another great episode of ITProTV.

3
00:00:15.270 --> 00:00:17.170
I'm your host Daniel Laury.

4
00:00:17.170 --> 00:00:21.520
Here with me today is the president of the
Jim Varney fan club, that is, Don Pezet.

5
00:00:21.520 --> 00:00:22.530
How's it going today, Don?

6
00:00:22.530 --> 00:00:23.920
>> It's going great, Daniel.

7
00:00:23.920 --> 00:00:26.660
In this episode we're gonna be
jumping back into Linux Plus.

8
00:00:26.660 --> 00:00:28.290
And we're gonna take a look about,

9
00:00:28.290 --> 00:00:32.160
at kind of customizing the shell
interface of our system.

10
00:00:32.160 --> 00:00:36.440
When you log into a server with no GUI or
you log into a system with a GUI and

11
00:00:36.440 --> 00:00:38.230
you launch the terminal,
you're given a shell.

12
00:00:38.230 --> 00:00:40.800
And there's kind of this
default layout that you get and

13
00:00:40.800 --> 00:00:42.890
default information that we get used to.

14
00:00:42.890 --> 00:00:45.540
You can operate in that environment and
that's perfectly fine.

15
00:00:45.540 --> 00:00:48.260
In fact, it's kind of nice because
whenever you go to a different server,

16
00:00:48.260 --> 00:00:49.750
that's what you can expect.

17
00:00:49.750 --> 00:00:53.910
But what a lot of people don't realize is
you can customize that shell a good bit

18
00:00:53.910 --> 00:00:55.250
to make it work for you.

19
00:00:55.250 --> 00:00:58.130
You can make that shell do more than
what it does out of the box, and

20
00:00:58.130 --> 00:00:59.790
it can really streamline
the way you do work.

21
00:00:59.790 --> 00:01:02.950
You can add some neat functions,
neat features, it's really cool stuff.

22
00:01:02.950 --> 00:01:06.310
So that's what we're gonna look at
today is things we can do to customize

23
00:01:06.310 --> 00:01:07.069
that shell environment.

24
00:01:08.288 --> 00:01:12.210
Now, I wanna start off with talking about
where our shell environment comes from.

25
00:01:12.210 --> 00:01:14.710
So, here on my machine, I've logged in.

26
00:01:14.710 --> 00:01:19.480
I do have a GUI, so fired up my terminal
app and I was given this right here.

27
00:01:19.480 --> 00:01:21.220
In fact,
if I just kind of start over again.

28
00:01:21.220 --> 00:01:25.480
Let me get out of that and
we will go straight into it from scratch.

29
00:01:25.480 --> 00:01:28.640
So if I go into my terminal, I end up
with a shell that looks like this.

30
00:01:28.640 --> 00:01:31.440
Now where did this come from?

31
00:01:31.440 --> 00:01:32.580
How did it know to give me this?

32
00:01:32.580 --> 00:01:35.160
Well there were certain
defaults that were said.

33
00:01:35.160 --> 00:01:38.550
It said when I launched a shell here's
the shell that I used, I used Bash.

34
00:01:38.550 --> 00:01:39.540
Maybe I used TCSH.

35
00:01:39.540 --> 00:01:42.850
What we saw in the users and
groups episode,

36
00:01:42.850 --> 00:01:45.420
how when you create a user You
defined their default shell.

37
00:01:45.420 --> 00:01:47.050
That's tied to the user account.

38
00:01:47.050 --> 00:01:51.140
But then when bash fires up, it decides,
hey, I'm gonna give you a prompt.

39
00:01:51.140 --> 00:01:54.880
And in that prompt, I'm gonna put your
name, followed by the hostname of this

40
00:01:54.880 --> 00:01:57.530
system, followed by the current
path that you're in.

41
00:01:57.530 --> 00:01:59.790
And I'm gonna surround that in brackets.

42
00:01:59.790 --> 00:02:01.730
How did it decide to do that?

43
00:02:01.730 --> 00:02:05.080
Well, Bash has its own configuration
files that it uses and

44
00:02:05.080 --> 00:02:07.800
that's how it's determining
what to render for me.

45
00:02:07.800 --> 00:02:11.940
Now that configuration file can come
from a few different places, all right?

46
00:02:11.940 --> 00:02:13.025
First of, it might not exist.

47
00:02:13.025 --> 00:02:14.790
[LAUGH] That's always possible.

48
00:02:14.790 --> 00:02:19.540
If it doesn't exist, there's one
default kind of configuration for

49
00:02:19.540 --> 00:02:20.900
it that sits on your system.

50
00:02:20.900 --> 00:02:25.325
And you can spot it,
it is in /etc/profile, right?

51
00:02:25.325 --> 00:02:31.450
/ect/profile is a file,
that goes without saying,

52
00:02:31.450 --> 00:02:35.710
and it defines what a user's profile is
going to be like unless they overwrite it.

53
00:02:35.710 --> 00:02:39.410
So these are kind of like defaults for
a user, what they would expect to see.

54
00:02:39.410 --> 00:02:43.360
And there's a lot of stuff in here,
a lot of stuff that we don't really

55
00:02:43.360 --> 00:02:47.030
normally want to manipulate, things like,
you know, what the host name is or

56
00:02:47.030 --> 00:02:50.890
what the default permissions are gonna
be like when we create new file.

57
00:02:50.890 --> 00:02:54.030
That's the stuff that's
tucked away in here, right.

58
00:02:54.030 --> 00:02:57.510
So, that /etc/profile is
kind of important, right.

59
00:02:58.670 --> 00:03:00.400
But it is commonly override.

60
00:03:01.550 --> 00:03:07.742
In each user's home directory,
they maintain a file called .bashrc,

61
00:03:07.742 --> 00:03:13.710
and .bashrc, and
that's the configuration for your shell.

62
00:03:13.710 --> 00:03:17.330
If you're running a different shell
like TCSH, it might use bashrc or

63
00:03:17.330 --> 00:03:19.650
it might have its own configuration file.

64
00:03:19.650 --> 00:03:21.590
So look for your appropriate shell.

65
00:03:21.590 --> 00:03:23.900
Bash is the most common,
that's the one we use here.

66
00:03:23.900 --> 00:03:26.256
So I've got .bashrc,
I've also got .bash.profile.

67
00:03:26.256 --> 00:03:29.180
I've got bash logout and bash history.

68
00:03:29.180 --> 00:03:32.212
These are all files that
are dictating what Bash is gonna see.

69
00:03:32.212 --> 00:03:33.150
Bash history,

70
00:03:33.150 --> 00:03:35.277
that's the history of my commands
that's where they're being stored.

71
00:03:35.277 --> 00:03:39.315
Bash logout, those are scripts that
run when I logout of the system.

72
00:03:39.315 --> 00:03:43.993
Bash profile, well those
are the overrides for /etc/profile.

73
00:03:43.993 --> 00:03:47.680
And then bashrc,
that's the configuration for Bash and

74
00:03:47.680 --> 00:03:50.570
that's normally what I'm gonna
modify to customize my shell.

75
00:03:50.570 --> 00:03:53.430
Now where do these files come from?

76
00:03:53.430 --> 00:03:55.540
Well, when you create a new user account,

77
00:03:55.540 --> 00:04:01.220
their home directory is
built from /etc/skel.

78
00:04:01.220 --> 00:04:06.630
Skel is skeleton, and that directory,
let me do a -la on that.

79
00:04:06.630 --> 00:04:11.150
There we go, that directory contains
the default files for a user.

80
00:04:11.150 --> 00:04:15.280
So if I want to customize my shell I can
modify bashrc right in my home directory.

81
00:04:15.280 --> 00:04:19.110
But if I wanna modify the shell for
every new user I create,

82
00:04:19.110 --> 00:04:23.300
I should modify it here in /etc/skeleton
and then when I create new users

83
00:04:23.300 --> 00:04:25.780
they'll get my customizations too,
right, and they'll have it, so

84
00:04:25.780 --> 00:04:29.210
I can create this consistent
environment for all of my users.

85
00:04:29.210 --> 00:04:32.100
But only applies to new users, so if you
hae existing users, you'd have to and

86
00:04:32.100 --> 00:04:36.599
modify their bashrc's also, so
it can get a little bit messy.

87
00:04:38.010 --> 00:04:41.120
All right, so those are some of
the files that we need to look for.

88
00:04:41.120 --> 00:04:42.810
You might also have one more.

89
00:04:42.810 --> 00:04:44.178
Let's see if I have this one.

90
00:04:44.178 --> 00:04:48.780
Inside of /etc,
you might have oh, I sure do,

91
00:04:48.780 --> 00:04:53.090
a bashrc file right there, /etc/bashrc.

92
00:04:53.090 --> 00:04:57.840
All right, and that, just like
/etc/profile, is kind of that default and

93
00:04:57.840 --> 00:05:00.310
so if I look in there.

94
00:05:00.310 --> 00:05:02.230
I can see a file that's laying out.

95
00:05:02.230 --> 00:05:05.400
A lot of the same stuff that
we saw inside of profile,

96
00:05:05.400 --> 00:05:07.630
but things that are focused
a little more on the user.

97
00:05:07.630 --> 00:05:09.450
So, like what my prompt is gonna be.

98
00:05:09.450 --> 00:05:11.610
Remember how I said that my
prompt was going to formatted?

99
00:05:11.610 --> 00:05:15.420
Well you can spot that if I stop
scrolling like a madman here.

100
00:05:15.420 --> 00:05:18.110
Where we can see where it
gets laid out right here.

101
00:05:18.110 --> 00:05:21.320
So my prompt is being defined as, and

102
00:05:21.320 --> 00:05:25.290
I know these don't really mean a whole lot
to us, these little variable letters and

103
00:05:25.290 --> 00:05:29.030
stuff, but
those are corresponding to the host name,

104
00:05:29.030 --> 00:05:33.800
user name at host name and path all
kind of being laid out there in pieces.

105
00:05:33.800 --> 00:05:37.850
So it's mentioning that, and then notice
right down here that we can modify our

106
00:05:37.850 --> 00:05:42.750
shell scripts in /etc/profile.d,
there's that profile coming back.

107
00:05:42.750 --> 00:05:47.990
So, your profile and your bashrc combine
to kinda create this environment.

108
00:05:47.990 --> 00:05:50.490
That's where all of our
settings are coming from.

109
00:05:50.490 --> 00:05:52.491
And the defaults we're
normally happy with, right.

110
00:05:52.491 --> 00:05:55.790
Those work for us, they do basic
things that let us function and

111
00:05:55.790 --> 00:05:58.240
do whatever we need and that's that.

112
00:05:58.240 --> 00:05:59.520
But you might need to come in and

113
00:05:59.520 --> 00:06:04.480
customize these to create the greatest
working environment ever, right?

114
00:06:04.480 --> 00:06:06.440
Well, what do I mean by
the greatest working environment?

115
00:06:06.440 --> 00:06:09.230
Well, let's see some of
the stuff that we can do here.

116
00:06:09.230 --> 00:06:10.890
One thing we might want is,

117
00:06:10.890 --> 00:06:15.540
we might wanna have like variables
that are available to us.

118
00:06:15.540 --> 00:06:20.200
One thing that I always
hate is that if you

119
00:06:20.200 --> 00:06:24.890
log into a system it can be very hard
to figure out what distro it is, right?

120
00:06:24.890 --> 00:06:26.785
So you've got like the uname command,

121
00:06:26.785 --> 00:06:29.690
uname-a and that will tell you
what Linux kernel you're running.

122
00:06:29.690 --> 00:06:30.970
Great, now I know.

123
00:06:30.970 --> 00:06:33.380
Am I running Debian or
am I running Redhat?

124
00:06:33.380 --> 00:06:34.210
I don't know, it doesn't say that.

125
00:06:34.210 --> 00:06:36.630
And there is no real command to do that.

126
00:06:36.630 --> 00:06:39.580
So, I might wanna create
a session variable

127
00:06:39.580 --> 00:06:41.010
that stores what distro I'm running.

128
00:06:41.010 --> 00:06:42.190
And then that way, I can call it.

129
00:06:42.190 --> 00:06:44.320
If I log into five different servers
I can call this variable, and

130
00:06:44.320 --> 00:06:46.110
it'll tell me what distro it is, right?

131
00:06:46.110 --> 00:06:47.380
So I might wanna create that.

132
00:06:47.380 --> 00:06:49.630
Now creating a variable is
not a hard thing to do,

133
00:06:49.630 --> 00:06:52.640
you can create it from the command line,
but it's not persistent.

134
00:06:52.640 --> 00:06:55.825
So I might wanna put that in my profile,
or in my bashrc, so

135
00:06:55.825 --> 00:06:59.866
that every time I log into a shell that
variable is created for me, right?

136
00:06:59.866 --> 00:07:02.800
So we can do that, we can define it and
have it available.

137
00:07:02.800 --> 00:07:06.980
So that kind of stuff is not
too terribly hard to do.

138
00:07:06.980 --> 00:07:09.390
It would go into my bashrc.

139
00:07:09.390 --> 00:07:11.290
Another thing I might want
to do is an alias, right?

140
00:07:11.290 --> 00:07:15.910
You guys have probably noticed in the show
that I rarely just run LS by itself.

141
00:07:15.910 --> 00:07:19.450
When I run LS, it's running and
it gives me my output, but

142
00:07:19.450 --> 00:07:25.070
I really like the long output better and
I like to show my hidden files too.

143
00:07:25.070 --> 00:07:28.670
I always like to do ls -la,
so you've probably seen that,

144
00:07:28.670 --> 00:07:31.190
I almost always do that so
I get that output.

145
00:07:31.190 --> 00:07:35.780
Well, maybe I want to default to ls -la,
I can do that.

146
00:07:35.780 --> 00:07:37.020
We can do that with aliases, right?

147
00:07:37.020 --> 00:07:39.610
Command aliases are one of
the customizations that I am most

148
00:07:39.610 --> 00:07:40.600
likely to do.

149
00:07:40.600 --> 00:07:44.000
In fact you probably already have
some command aliases in place.

150
00:07:44.000 --> 00:07:49.460
So for example, if I do, what was
the command that which, yeah, which,

151
00:07:49.460 --> 00:07:55.380
if I do which LS it shows me that the LS
command I'm running is actually an alias.

152
00:07:55.380 --> 00:07:58.817
It's an alias saying,
instead of just running ls,

153
00:07:58.817 --> 00:08:04.340
run ls--color=auto, right, so
that's what I'm running right now.

154
00:08:04.340 --> 00:08:07.570
But maybe,
I want it to run not just --color auto,

155
00:08:07.570 --> 00:08:13.140
but I also want it to run -la, so I get
my long output and always show the files.

156
00:08:13.140 --> 00:08:17.590
So let's do that,
let's modify my -rc to contain that.

157
00:08:17.590 --> 00:08:21.693
I'm gonna get into my home directory,
and I'm gonna edit that

158
00:08:21.693 --> 00:08:26.470
-bashrc file, and when you go in,
yours might be empty.

159
00:08:26.470 --> 00:08:30.870
Yours might not have anything in there
at all, but all mine is saying is,

160
00:08:30.870 --> 00:08:34.680
if there is no /etc/bashrc,

161
00:08:34.680 --> 00:08:40.620
then use the bashrc here,
to basically define my global definitions.

162
00:08:40.620 --> 00:08:43.710
And then after that,
I can define my own stuff.

163
00:08:43.710 --> 00:08:46.640
So that's why it says,
user specific aliases right here.

164
00:08:46.640 --> 00:08:48.970
This is where everything else would go,
all right?

165
00:08:48.970 --> 00:08:50.380
So in here I can start to define things.

166
00:08:50.380 --> 00:08:56.842
I can say alias ls= and then I can I
can say what I want that alias to be.

167
00:08:56.842 --> 00:09:00.991
I want to be ls --color=auto,

168
00:09:00.991 --> 00:09:07.074
followed by -la,
I'm gonna add to it, right?

169
00:09:07.074 --> 00:09:09.071
I want it to always do that,
that's the alias.

170
00:09:09.071 --> 00:09:11.540
Now I could have defined this
alias from the command prompt, but

171
00:09:11.540 --> 00:09:13.560
that wouldn't have been persistent, right?

172
00:09:13.560 --> 00:09:15.800
If I logout and log back in,
the alias is gone.

173
00:09:15.800 --> 00:09:20.940
By putting it here, every time I log in,
that customization takes effect.

174
00:09:20.940 --> 00:09:24.940
And now, I get my kind of,
I gotta use the right back tick there.

175
00:09:24.940 --> 00:09:25.670
There we go.

176
00:09:25.670 --> 00:09:27.560
And now it'll get over written.

177
00:09:27.560 --> 00:09:28.090
Okay.

178
00:09:28.090 --> 00:09:32.240
So I'm gonna put that in here, and
if I really wanna be on the safe side,

179
00:09:32.240 --> 00:09:36.060
I might want to issue
an un alias ls first.

180
00:09:36.060 --> 00:09:38.240
Just to get rid of the alias they put in.

181
00:09:38.240 --> 00:09:40.510
And then put mine in, but
this'll over write it so,

182
00:09:40.510 --> 00:09:42.130
I'm not too terribly worried about that.

183
00:09:42.130 --> 00:09:43.420
So I'm gonna leave that out.

184
00:09:44.440 --> 00:09:46.140
I'll only put that in if I have to.

185
00:09:46.140 --> 00:09:48.140
All right, so
I'm gonna go ahead and save that.

186
00:09:48.140 --> 00:09:49.840
So I've got it in place, I'm good, right?

187
00:09:49.840 --> 00:09:52.925
I can run ls, and it doesn't take affect.

188
00:09:52.925 --> 00:09:57.810
bashrc only takes affect, when you log
in or when you launch a new shell.

189
00:09:57.810 --> 00:09:59.310
So this shell I already had.

190
00:09:59.310 --> 00:10:02.540
I'm gonna get rid of it, and
I'm gonna open up a new one.

191
00:10:03.740 --> 00:10:06.190
And now when I open up this nice,
shiny, new shell.

192
00:10:07.780 --> 00:10:11.190
If I come in here and
I run an ls, there we go,

193
00:10:11.190 --> 00:10:15.220
it defaulted to the long format and
it displayed all the files.

194
00:10:15.220 --> 00:10:22.260
And if I do a which ls, I can see that it
is an alias and it's --color auto and -la.

195
00:10:22.260 --> 00:10:24.880
Right, I put that in my bashrc.

196
00:10:24.880 --> 00:10:28.120
So any customizations you wanna make,
any aliases.

197
00:10:28.120 --> 00:10:31.100
Any variables you wanna define,
any of that stuff?

198
00:10:31.100 --> 00:10:34.180
You can put right there in your bashrc and
you'll have it available, right.

199
00:10:34.180 --> 00:10:34.960
It's really powerful stuff.

200
00:10:34.960 --> 00:10:37.070
Let me show you a bigger example.

201
00:10:37.070 --> 00:10:40.740
And we're gonna film
an episode on shell scripting.

202
00:10:40.740 --> 00:10:44.190
With shell scripts,
you can do a ton of cool stuff.

203
00:10:44.190 --> 00:10:45.960
But you can actually take
those shell scripts, and

204
00:10:45.960 --> 00:10:47.030
you can put them in your bashrc.

205
00:10:47.030 --> 00:10:48.980
I'll show you a neat one that I use.

206
00:10:48.980 --> 00:10:51.450
This is one I actually
use in real life land.

207
00:10:51.450 --> 00:10:52.680
I've got it written right here.

208
00:10:52.680 --> 00:10:55.420
So I've got this function,
that I like to define,

209
00:10:55.420 --> 00:10:59.650
and if you look at the function,
see how I'm running more than one thing?

210
00:10:59.650 --> 00:11:01.860
I'm running several commands.

211
00:11:01.860 --> 00:11:06.530
What a function is like, is like an alias,
that runs more than one thing.

212
00:11:06.530 --> 00:11:09.420
Right, normally an alias
just runs one command, but

213
00:11:09.420 --> 00:11:11.690
with a function I can run a lot of stuff.

214
00:11:11.690 --> 00:11:14.876
And so,
I'm going to edit my .bashrc file, and

215
00:11:14.876 --> 00:11:19.542
I'm gonna come in here in my user
specified aliases and functions, and

216
00:11:19.542 --> 00:11:24.210
I just did an alias,
I'm gonna add that function afterwards.

217
00:11:24.210 --> 00:11:25.780
So I'm gonna paste that guy in cuz,

218
00:11:25.780 --> 00:11:27.237
I really don't feel like typing all this,
right.

219
00:11:28.270 --> 00:11:33.350
And so here's the function that I just
brought in from my little notepad.

220
00:11:33.350 --> 00:11:35.650
And this function, all it's doing.

221
00:11:35.650 --> 00:11:40.465
Well, what it should be doing here,
if I can get rid of my tabs.

222
00:11:40.465 --> 00:11:43.040
[LAUGH] I got a bit of a mess on this one.

223
00:11:43.040 --> 00:11:45.630
All right, there we go.

224
00:11:45.630 --> 00:11:48.760
So what this function is doing,
I'm just trying to make it neat and

225
00:11:48.760 --> 00:11:52.150
I don't have to, so
I'm just being a little OCD on this one.

226
00:11:52.150 --> 00:11:57.380
But what it's doing, now let me
explain each line, function sysinf.

227
00:11:57.380 --> 00:11:59.980
That means I'm creating
a function called sysinfo and

228
00:11:59.980 --> 00:12:02.170
sysinfo is basically gonna be an alias.

229
00:12:02.170 --> 00:12:04.030
Right.
I'll have a command called sysinfo.

230
00:12:04.030 --> 00:12:06.710
Now, that command doesn't
normally exist on a system.

231
00:12:06.710 --> 00:12:09.300
I'm making that command up, so
I can call it whatever I want.

232
00:12:09.300 --> 00:12:12.490
It could be function bob,
doesn't matter, alright.

233
00:12:12.490 --> 00:12:15.620
And then, in parenthesis is
where I provide any input,

234
00:12:15.620 --> 00:12:16.510
that I wanted to give it.

235
00:12:16.510 --> 00:12:19.600
If I wanted to provide
command line arguments to it,

236
00:12:19.600 --> 00:12:22.040
they'd be kinda tucked away in
variables in that parentheses.

237
00:12:22.040 --> 00:12:24.160
But I don't have any, so
I'm just closing it off.

238
00:12:24.160 --> 00:12:28.900
And then inside of that function,
I'm defining what I want it to do.

239
00:12:28.900 --> 00:12:31.270
So I want it to run five commands.

00:12:31.270 --> 00:12:35.851
It's gonna echo, and the first one's

00:12:52.540 --> 00:12:54.910

246
00:12:54.910 --> 00:12:59.620
I'm gonna exit my shell and
come back in, and when I get back in,

00:12:59.620 --> 00:13:05.350
now I should have this nice new command

248
00:13:05.350 --> 00:13:09.960
sysinfo is not a normal command, but
now when I run it, I get this nice

249
00:13:09.960 --> 00:13:14.550
big layout and in the layout I can
see right here, kernel information.

250
00:13:14.550 --> 00:13:15.920
That's the kernel I'm running.

251
00:13:15.920 --> 00:13:17.590
I see OS version.

252
00:13:17.590 --> 00:13:21.180
There's the operating system I'm running,
CentOS release 6.5 (final).

253
00:13:21.180 --> 00:13:23.950
I've got system Uptime,
how long I've been up.

254
00:13:23.950 --> 00:13:27.450
My Memory Utilization, right there,
how much RAM am I consuming?

255
00:13:27.450 --> 00:13:29.360
And then my filesystem information.

256
00:13:29.360 --> 00:13:31.370
All laid out In one big set.

257
00:13:31.370 --> 00:13:33.280
Now, I know all five of those commands.

258
00:13:33.280 --> 00:13:35.140
I could run each of them individually.

259
00:13:35.140 --> 00:13:36.800
But now I've rolled them all up into one.

260
00:13:36.800 --> 00:13:37.690
All right?

261
00:13:37.690 --> 00:13:38.940
It's called a function.

262
00:13:38.940 --> 00:13:40.030
You can put it in your profile.

263
00:13:40.030 --> 00:13:43.490
If I put that in the skeleton file for
bashrc, it'll cover everybody.

00:13:43.490 --> 00:13:46.570
Or if I put it in /etc/bashrc,

265
00:13:46.570 --> 00:13:50.220

existing users, not just new ones.

266
00:13:50.220 --> 00:13:52.350
So a couple of different
places I can put that.

267
00:13:52.350 --> 00:13:57.100
I've effectively created a super command

00:13:57.100 --> 00:13:59.360

Or if my end users are having a problem,

00:14:07.440 --> 00:14:10.108

information gathering things I need.

273
00:14:10.108 --> 00:14:13.410
You know, ifconfig and all that other

00:14:13.410 --> 00:14:16.140
You know, run this command, and you
could even make it in the command where

00:14:16.140 --> 00:14:19.710

276
00:14:19.710 --> 00:14:21.670
You can put whatever you
want inside of a function,

277
00:14:21.670 --> 00:14:24.890
it's a series of commands that
can do all sorts of crazy stuff.

278
00:14:24.890 --> 00:14:26.410
Really powerful, right.

279
00:14:26.410 --> 00:14:28.700
These are ways that we can
extend the functionality.

280
00:14:29.770 --> 00:14:35.140
One word of caution, right, the more you
customize it, the harder it'll become for

281
00:14:35.140 --> 00:14:37.870

that hasn't been customized.

282
00:14:37.870 --> 00:14:39.956
So, if I have to support
a thousand servers and

283
00:14:39.956 --> 00:14:43.432
I customize one with everything I want,

00:14:43.432 --> 00:14:45.000
now I'm missing those commands.

285

I'm like, all right,
I'm gonna run sysinfo and it doesn't work.

00:14:47.610 --> 00:14:50.620
And you're like, aw shoot now I gotta

287
00:14:50.620 --> 00:14:52.455
So it's a doubled edged sword, right?

288
00:14:52.455 --> 00:14:56.002
If you start customizing this a lot,
you can end up in that environment where

289
00:14:56.002 --> 00:14:58.600
you kind of get rusty

00:14:58.600 --> 00:15:01.770
It doesn't mean don't use it,
it just means, you know be aware,

291
00:15:01.770 --> 00:15:03.270
be sensitive of that.

292
00:15:03.270 --> 00:15:03.975
Be sensitive.

293

>> [LAUGH]
>> That's what we're going to teach you in

those are some key things

username followed by the name of your

00:16:17.558 --> 00:16:21.650
my working directory,

00:16:21.650 --> 00:16:26.590
And then it's got the square parentheses

00:16:26.590 --> 00:16:30.870
slash is just an escape character there,

00:16:30.870 --> 00:16:32.638

00:16:32.638 --> 00:16:34.251
I might wanna customize that,

00:16:42.740 --> 00:16:45.170

00:16:46.910 --> 00:16:51.160

00:16:51.160 --> 00:16:55.740

00:16:55.740 --> 00:16:59.899

see if they have a user ID.

454
00:24:07.250 --> 00:24:08.590
That was one way to do it.

455
00:24:08.590 --> 00:24:10.830
But you can use the test command and
do things also.

456
00:24:10.830 --> 00:24:13.820
Test is really useful for
checking to see if something exists.

457
00:24:13.820 --> 00:24:16.830
So, maybe I wanna see if
a user has a home directory.

458
00:24:16.830 --> 00:24:23.340
So I can do something like
test -d/home/ dpezet, right?

459
00:24:23.340 --> 00:24:27.620
That's going to test and let me know
whether or not that directory exists.

460
00:24:27.620 --> 00:24:29.620
But it doesn't really give me any output.

461
00:24:29.620 --> 00:24:32.670
You're supposed to follow that up
with what to do if it's true, and

462
00:24:32.670 --> 00:24:34.500
what to do if it's false.

463
00:24:34.500 --> 00:24:39.512
And so,, I could say,
ampersand, ampersand, echo,

464
00:24:39.512 --> 00:24:43.150
directory exists.

465
00:24:43.150 --> 00:24:45.570
So that's what we do if it's true, and

466
00:24:45.570 --> 00:24:50.310
then I could follow that up by two
pipes and what to do if it's false.

467
00:24:50.310 --> 00:24:53.583
Now my head's gonna cover this up,
but I'm just gonna echo that

468
00:24:53.583 --> 00:24:58.830
the directory does not exist.

469
00:24:58.830 --> 00:24:59.940
There we go.

470
00:24:59.940 --> 00:25:02.660
And so, if it exists,
echo that out on the screen.

471
00:25:02.660 --> 00:25:04.780
If it doesn't exist,
echo that out on the screen.

472
00:25:04.780 --> 00:25:07.150
And that's gonna be our
test to let us know.

473
00:25:07.150 --> 00:25:10.990
And when I run it,
see how I get that directory exists?

474
00:25:10.990 --> 00:25:14.800
You could easily have it
echo out a zero or a one.

475
00:25:14.800 --> 00:25:17.420
Then you could say if the variable
equals zero, do this.

476
00:25:17.420 --> 00:25:19.240
If the variable equals one, do this.

477
00:25:19.240 --> 00:25:21.050
And you could set up all sorts
of actions based on that.

478
00:25:21.050 --> 00:25:24.480
So the test command is really,
really helpful.

479
00:25:24.480 --> 00:25:26.100
And it's got a lot of operators on it.

480
00:25:26.100 --> 00:25:28.420
I use the -d to check the directory.

481
00:25:28.420 --> 00:25:31.340
Or you'll see I can also
just string comparisons, so

482
00:25:31.340 --> 00:25:37.060
you can test how those are, -b for
if a file exists, -c for characters.

483
00:25:37.060 --> 00:25:39.370
You've got all sorts of other
different ones you can use for

484
00:25:39.370 --> 00:25:42.450
testing different things in
characteristics of files and folders.

485
00:25:42.450 --> 00:25:44.440
So really useful one to do there.

486
00:25:44.440 --> 00:25:47.060
Now, notice how the test command is
all centered around files and folders.

487
00:25:47.060 --> 00:25:51.410
It's a little hard to use that to test
to see if a user account exists, and

488
00:25:51.410 --> 00:25:55.420
that's why in my user account example
I went after the user id instead.

489
00:25:55.420 --> 00:25:59.350
Because no matter how you make a user,
at a minimum they're gonna have a user id.

490
00:25:59.350 --> 00:26:01.814
That's like the one guaranteed
thing you know they're gonna have.

491
00:26:01.814 --> 00:26:03.375
They might not have a password.

492
00:26:03.375 --> 00:26:05.050
They might not have a home directory.

493
00:26:05.050 --> 00:26:08.070
They might not have a default shell,
but they're going to have a user ID.

494
00:26:08.070 --> 00:26:10.080
So you have to think like
that when you write a script.

495
00:26:10.080 --> 00:26:14.700
What do I know for a fact is going to be
there, because you don't want to rely on

496
00:26:14.700 --> 00:26:17.160
something that might go away and
now your script is broken.

497
00:26:17.160 --> 00:26:20.430
So that's kind of a key
principle of Shell scripting.

498
00:26:20.430 --> 00:26:24.470
>> And having the command UD, or
the where it actually looks for that,

499
00:26:24.470 --> 00:26:26.490
I can't remember the name?

500
00:26:26.490 --> 00:26:26.990
>> The id.
>> The ID.

501
00:26:26.990 --> 00:26:27.900
>> The ID, I'm sorry, yes.

502
00:26:27.900 --> 00:26:28.630
The ID command,

503
00:26:28.630 --> 00:26:30.110
having that built into the system,

504
00:26:30.110 --> 00:26:34.570
well it allows you to build these types of
scripts to do what Don is talking about.

505
00:26:34.570 --> 00:26:38.710
That it can call that numerical value
makes it a little bit easier to work with

506
00:26:38.710 --> 00:26:41.930
in a scripting language, because you
can have an equal to, a greater than,

507
00:26:41.930 --> 00:26:42.490
a less than.

508
00:26:42.490 --> 00:26:45.063
It's kinda hard to have less than dpizet,
right?

509
00:26:45.063 --> 00:26:46.310
That doesn't make a lot of sense.

510
00:26:46.310 --> 00:26:51.110
But if he pulls out his user,
that UID, then gets that and

511
00:26:51.110 --> 00:26:53.480
it's a numerical,
he can say it's less than this or

512
00:26:53.480 --> 00:26:57.680
greater than that, makes it easy for
him to make those scripts.

513
00:26:57.680 --> 00:26:59.195
And then those ampersand,
ampersand, and the pipe,

514
00:26:59.195 --> 00:27:01.440
pipe, they can also use
those by themselves as well.

515
00:27:01.440 --> 00:27:04.350
You don't have to actually use
them within the test space.

516
00:27:04.350 --> 00:27:07.990
It's just basically saying, if I have
ampersand, ampersand, it's like this and

517
00:27:07.990 --> 00:27:12.640
this must be true for a true variable,
or whatever to come out for

518
00:27:12.640 --> 00:27:14.070
it to give me true results.

519
00:27:14.070 --> 00:27:18.190
And then you have the pipe pipe which
says this or this can be true, so

520
00:27:18.190 --> 00:27:21.280
you can use those in your scripts wherever
you need them as well, very handy stuff.

521
00:27:21.280 --> 00:27:22.130
>> Absolutely.

522
00:27:22.130 --> 00:27:24.340
Now obviously,
there's a 30 minute episode,

523
00:27:24.340 --> 00:27:28.720
we've only really scratched
the surface of Shell scripting.

524
00:27:28.720 --> 00:27:30.250
It's extremely powerful.

525
00:27:30.250 --> 00:27:32.640
For the exam, they just want you
to have that basic familiarity.

526
00:27:32.640 --> 00:27:34.540
Some of the simple things you can do, and

527
00:27:34.540 --> 00:27:37.320
how you can automate things to
save yourself a lot of time.

528
00:27:37.320 --> 00:27:40.310
But if you wanna learn more about it
there's tons of resources out there on

529
00:27:40.310 --> 00:27:42.110
the Internet you can check out.

530
00:27:42.110 --> 00:27:44.985
I know the Arch Linux website
has a ton of documentation,

531
00:27:44.985 --> 00:27:46.840
the CentOS website does too.

532
00:27:46.840 --> 00:27:48.890
There's just tons of
great examples out there.

533
00:27:48.890 --> 00:27:52.460
Stack Overflow is a website I go to
constantly to find examples of how other

534
00:27:52.460 --> 00:27:53.900
people are achieving things.

535
00:27:53.900 --> 00:27:56.060
It's really impressive
what people come up with.

536
00:27:56.060 --> 00:27:58.270
>> Yeah, don't forget the Linux
documentation project.

537
00:27:58.270 --> 00:27:59.120
>> Oh, yeah.

538
00:27:59.120 --> 00:28:03.620
>> That joker's got tons of information on
just about everything to do with Linux.

539
00:28:03.620 --> 00:28:05.320
Its very comprehensive.

540
00:28:05.320 --> 00:28:06.072
>> Absolutely.

541
00:28:06.072 --> 00:28:10.430
>> All right, Don, have we wrapped
this up in a pretty little package?

542
00:28:10.430 --> 00:28:13.390
>> Yeah, let's close it here, otherwise
we'll do the longest episode on record.

543
00:28:13.390 --> 00:28:15.610
So we'll wrap it here but stay tuned.

544
00:28:15.610 --> 00:28:16.580
We got more stuff coming up soon.

545
00:28:16.580 --> 00:28:19.280
You're gonna see a little bit of scripting
through some of the different episodes

546
00:28:19.280 --> 00:28:22.340
that we go through, but this is kind of
the bare minimum of what you need for

547
00:28:22.340 --> 00:28:23.242
the exam.

548
00:28:23.242 --> 00:28:24.520
>> All right Don,
well that was good stuff,

549
00:28:24.520 --> 00:28:26.480
hope you guys learned a lot from that.

550
00:28:26.480 --> 00:28:29.820
Start writing some scripts,
get your hands dirty on the keyboard and

551
00:28:29.820 --> 00:28:30.980
get some scripts happening.

552
00:28:30.980 --> 00:28:33.400
That being said,
it is time to sign off for ITProTV.

553
00:28:33.400 --> 00:28:35.380
I've been your host, Daniel Lawry.

554
00:28:35.380 --> 00:28:36.050
>> And I'm Don Pizet.

555
00:28:36.050 --> 00:28:37.765
>> And we'll see ya next time.

556
00:28:37.765 --> 00:28:38.265

episodes.title: Managing Email
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.033 --> 00:00:10.370
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:10.370 --> 00:00:15.730
All right, greetings everyone, and welcome
to another great episode of ITProTV.

3
00:00:15.730 --> 00:00:17.100
I'll be your host Daniel Lowery,

4
00:00:17.100 --> 00:00:20.160
and here with me today is none
other than the Linux man himself.

5
00:00:20.160 --> 00:00:22.490
The guy's going to teach us everything
we need to know, right, Don?

6
00:00:22.490 --> 00:00:23.580
Don Pezet.

7
00:00:23.580 --> 00:00:25.832
>> Well let's just not set those
expectations too high, right?

8
00:00:25.832 --> 00:00:26.612
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

9
00:00:26.612 --> 00:00:27.588
>> All right, well ladies and

10
00:00:27.588 --> 00:00:29.760
gentlemen, we're back for
another episode of Linux Plus.

11
00:00:29.760 --> 00:00:32.870
In this episode,
we're gonna take a look at email.

12
00:00:32.870 --> 00:00:34.334
Right, everybody uses email, right Daniel?

13
00:00:34.334 --> 00:00:34.915
>> What's email?

14
00:00:34.915 --> 00:00:38.385
>> [LAUGH]
>> Email, it's like better than Dmail, but

15
00:00:38.385 --> 00:00:39.950
not as good as like Fmail.

16
00:00:39.950 --> 00:00:40.850
So email.

17
00:00:42.220 --> 00:00:44.940
Every Linux server,
every Linux desktop for that matter,

18
00:00:44.940 --> 00:00:48.490
is capable of being an email server,
and in fact, most of them are.

19
00:00:48.490 --> 00:00:52.600
Most distros, when you install them, even
if you choose to do the desktop install,

20
00:00:52.600 --> 00:00:55.500
still have basic email
services built into them.

21
00:00:55.500 --> 00:00:57.700
And there's a few different reasons for
that.

22
00:00:57.700 --> 00:01:01.670
Maybe you want to be a mail server,
in which case, great, you need that.

23
00:01:01.670 --> 00:01:03.560
But at a minimum,

24
00:01:03.560 --> 00:01:07.890
there's several services inside of
LINUX that are capable of emailing you.

25
00:01:07.890 --> 00:01:10.040
We already saw one in a past episode.

26
00:01:10.040 --> 00:01:15.680
If you watched the episode on scheduling
jobs, we talked about the Chron command.

27
00:01:15.680 --> 00:01:17.810
And in the Chron config
file in that episode,

28
00:01:17.810 --> 00:01:22.160
I showed you where we can have Chron email
us the status of Chron jobs, let us know,

29
00:01:22.160 --> 00:01:23.980
hey, did this job succeed or fail?

30
00:01:23.980 --> 00:01:28.730
Well, how is it supposed to email us if
it doesn't have email software, right?

31
00:01:28.730 --> 00:01:31.060
It's a command line service
that's running in the background.

32
00:01:31.060 --> 00:01:33.979
It can't fire up Thunderbird or
Microsoft Outlook or whatever and

33
00:01:33.979 --> 00:01:34.873
shoot you an email.

34
00:01:34.873 --> 00:01:36.100
It can't do that.

35
00:01:36.100 --> 00:01:40.880
So we need to have basic email services
just to enable that functionality.

36
00:01:40.880 --> 00:01:44.750
Now when I say your Linux Box already has
an email server on it, I don't mean it's

37
00:01:44.750 --> 00:01:47.030
got like a public one that people
on the Internet can connect to.

38
00:01:47.030 --> 00:01:48.700
It's not like that, it's really used for

39
00:01:48.700 --> 00:01:53.610
just email on the local system, but
it's very powerful software, and you

40
00:01:53.610 --> 00:01:58.730
can use it to be a full blown email server
out there on the Internet if you want to.

41
00:01:58.730 --> 00:02:01.590
So let's talk about that email
service a little bit, and

42
00:02:01.590 --> 00:02:03.460
get kind of an understanding
of what it is.

43
00:02:03.460 --> 00:02:06.140
Now inside of Linux you're
typically gonna have

44
00:02:06.140 --> 00:02:09.040
two different types of email software.

45
00:02:09.040 --> 00:02:12.660
There's MTA's and MUA's, right.

46
00:02:12.660 --> 00:02:15.410
An MTA is a message transfer agent.

47
00:02:15.410 --> 00:02:17.900
It's software that's sole purpose is

48
00:02:17.900 --> 00:02:19.661
moving email from one point to another,
all right.

49
00:02:20.730 --> 00:02:26.130
The most common example of an MTA
is any kind of SMTP software,

50
00:02:26.130 --> 00:02:28.200
simple message transport protocol.

51
00:02:28.200 --> 00:02:32.420
SMTP is what servers use to
move email between each other.

52
00:02:32.420 --> 00:02:34.730
And its what we use when we send an email.

53
00:02:34.730 --> 00:02:38.140
If you're sending an email, you use
SMTP to transfer it to a server, and

54
00:02:38.140 --> 00:02:41.710
then the server uses it to SMTP to move
it to the destination server, and then

55
00:02:41.710 --> 00:02:46.370
the destination server uses something else
to let the client access the email, right?

56
00:02:46.370 --> 00:02:50.720
But as far as sending the email,
we use MTAs, Message Transfer Agents.

57
00:02:50.720 --> 00:02:54.700
And almost every Linux box out there,
even if you choose a minimal install in

58
00:02:54.700 --> 00:02:58.240
a lot of cases, is still going
to be an MTA so that it can move

59
00:02:58.240 --> 00:03:02.090
internal messages on the server for
things like Chron jop reporting, right?

60
00:03:02.090 --> 00:03:03.520
That's why it's there.

61
00:03:03.520 --> 00:03:06.861
>> So Don, is that why I'm seeing
root has mail when I log in?

62
00:03:06.861 --> 00:03:09.250
[LAUGH]
>> You know, that's really common.

63
00:03:09.250 --> 00:03:10.309
You do a minimal install, right.

64
00:03:10.309 --> 00:03:13.084
Like I'm gonna install just the bare
minimum, and you log into that shell

65
00:03:13.084 --> 00:03:16.870
the first time and you get that message
right above your prompt, root has mail.

66
00:03:16.870 --> 00:03:18.670
Well, you're running an MTA.

67
00:03:18.670 --> 00:03:21.520
You actually have a mailbox and
if you check that email,

68
00:03:21.520 --> 00:03:24.010
a lot of distros will give you
a welcome email that'll say hey,

69
00:03:24.010 --> 00:03:27.730
welcome to Debian and here's some steps
you should take to harden your system for

70
00:03:27.730 --> 00:03:30.710
security purposes and here's some
links to getting started guides.

71
00:03:30.710 --> 00:03:31.760
They'll put that in there, right?

72
00:03:31.760 --> 00:03:33.340
It's pretty nice.

73
00:03:33.340 --> 00:03:36.417
But most people look at it and like,
how the heck do I even get to the email?

74
00:03:36.417 --> 00:03:37.541
>> [LAUGH]
>> I haven't even

75
00:03:37.541 --> 00:03:38.880
installed Thunderbird yet.

76
00:03:38.880 --> 00:03:40.210
>> How does it even know I exist?

77
00:03:40.210 --> 00:03:41.070
>> That's right.

78
00:03:41.070 --> 00:03:44.440
And it's because of that default mail
functionality that's built in, all right.

79
00:03:45.490 --> 00:03:47.290
That's an MTA.

80
00:03:47.290 --> 00:03:51.490
There's also the MUA which is a message or
mail user agent,

81
00:03:51.490 --> 00:03:56.450
and the mail user agent that's how we
access our email as a human being, right?

82
00:03:56.450 --> 00:04:01.980
So SMTP, the MTAs, that's server talk or
software talk in the background.

83
00:04:01.980 --> 00:04:04.650
But when we want humans to
get involved we need a MUA.

84
00:04:04.650 --> 00:04:10.570
An MUA's usually gonna take the form
of a POP3 client, or an IMAP4 client.

85
00:04:10.570 --> 00:04:12.450
POP3 is the Post Office Protocol.

86
00:04:12.450 --> 00:04:17.215
It's a very old email protocol
that's been around a long time.

87
00:04:17.215 --> 00:04:18.535
Lets you check your mail.

88
00:04:18.535 --> 00:04:19.425
It reaches out to a server.

89
00:04:19.425 --> 00:04:23.206
It downloads the emails to your system and
now you've got access and

90
00:04:23.206 --> 00:04:25.474
you can read them and have at it, right?

91
00:04:25.474 --> 00:04:29.307
But POP3 isn't really good when it comes
to things like having subfolders and

92
00:04:29.307 --> 00:04:32.271
leaving messages on the server
as opposed to downloading and

93
00:04:32.271 --> 00:04:33.854
deleting them from the server.

94
00:04:33.854 --> 00:04:35.770
Pop3 is not the greatest for that.

95
00:04:35.770 --> 00:04:36.880
So if you have more than one computer,

96
00:04:36.880 --> 00:04:39.480
Pop3 can get really
frustrating really fast.

97
00:04:39.480 --> 00:04:44.591
IMap4 on the other hand, that's
the Internet Message Access Protocol.

98
00:04:44.591 --> 00:04:46.460
There we go I'm gonna get it this time.

99
00:04:46.460 --> 00:04:49.340
IMAP 4, it lets you have subfolders,

100
00:04:49.340 --> 00:04:52.450
it leaves the emails on the server by
default and you can mark them as read.

101
00:04:52.450 --> 00:04:54.029
And that way if you have
more than one email client,

102
00:04:54.029 --> 00:04:55.610
they're all kind of synchronized.

103
00:04:55.610 --> 00:04:57.500
It's a lot more robust, right.

104
00:04:57.500 --> 00:05:00.010
Now more robust means that it
takes more resources to run, but

105
00:05:00.010 --> 00:05:02.010
it's a lot more powerful so
people like it.

106
00:05:02.010 --> 00:05:05.081
IMAP is far more common today than POP3,
right.

107
00:05:05.081 --> 00:05:08.410
But both of those are MUAs,
mail user agents, and so

108
00:05:08.410 --> 00:05:12.193
you might be using Thunderbird,
or Microsoft Outlook, or

109
00:05:12.193 --> 00:05:15.824
some other email client,
whatever it happens to be, but

110
00:05:15.824 --> 00:05:21.410
at the end of the day it's a POP3 or an
IMAP4 client that's talking to the server.

111
00:05:21.410 --> 00:05:23.370
And that's how you get your messages and
you read them.

112
00:05:23.370 --> 00:05:27.458
Then when you go to send your message,
you use SMTP, and you send it with

113
00:05:27.458 --> 00:05:31.630
that to the server, it then uses SMTP
to move it to a destination server.

114
00:05:31.630 --> 00:05:36.365
And at that destination some user
uses POP3 or IMAP to open it up and

115
00:05:36.365 --> 00:05:38.323
read their email, right?

116
00:05:38.323 --> 00:05:42.350
That's been the model for a long time,
it's not really gonna change anytime soon.

117
00:05:42.350 --> 00:05:47.290
The only big difference is we've started
seeing webmail kind of take the place of

118
00:05:47.290 --> 00:05:52.275
the mail user agent, MUAs,
that instead of having POP3 or

119
00:05:52.275 --> 00:05:56.130
IMAP4 you browse to some web page and
you see your mailbox and all of that.

120
00:05:56.130 --> 00:06:00.072
Those are usually IMAP under the hood to,
but they can be other things.

121
00:06:00.072 --> 00:06:02.090
But webmail is getting to be really,
really common.

122
00:06:03.662 --> 00:06:06.860
All right so, let's talk about
some of the common MTAs and

123
00:06:06.860 --> 00:06:08.970
then we'll talk about some of
the common MUAs, all right?

124
00:06:08.970 --> 00:06:13.970
On the MTA side,
well almost every Linux box has one and

source products into a great job because,

577
00:28:09.047 --> 00:28:10.188
who created email?

578
00:28:10.188 --> 00:28:14.858
Well, email began in the Unix world and
the Linux world.

579
00:28:14.858 --> 00:28:16.675
That's really where the stuff started.

580
00:28:16.675 --> 00:28:20.165
And so the other guys, they have great
email products that are out there,

581
00:28:20.165 --> 00:28:23.365
like Microsoft Exchange and stuff,
but you don't have to use those.

582
00:28:23.365 --> 00:28:25.185
These solutions are really world class.

583
00:28:25.185 --> 00:28:26.285
They're good stuff.

584
00:28:26.285 --> 00:28:28.910
>> Bunch of johnny-come-latelies
in my opinion, right?

585
00:28:28.910 --> 00:28:29.995
>> [LAUGH]
>> Stick with the Unix,

586
00:28:29.995 --> 00:28:30.665
that's the way to go.

587
00:28:30.665 --> 00:28:31.995
No, I'm just kidding.

588
00:28:31.995 --> 00:28:33.005
Go with whatever you like.

589
00:28:33.005 --> 00:28:35.555
But if you are into Linux or
Unix, it's got it there.

590
00:28:35.555 --> 00:28:36.395
It's ready to go.

591
00:28:36.395 --> 00:28:40.180
That being said Don, I think we've wrapped
up another pretty good episode here for

592
00:28:40.180 --> 00:28:41.100
our viewers.

593
00:28:41.100 --> 00:28:44.950
Hopefully they enjoyed it, I know I sure
did listening to all this good stuff.

594
00:28:44.950 --> 00:28:47.290
That being said, it is time to sign off.

595
00:28:47.290 --> 00:28:50.470
For IT Pro TV,
I've been your host Daniel Lowry.

596
00:28:50.470 --> 00:28:51.170
>> And I'm Don Pizet.

episodes.title: Managing Data with SQL
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.039 --> 00:00:11.741
All right.

3
00:00:11.741 --> 00:00:15.810
Greetings everyone and welcome to
another great episode of ITProTV.

4
00:00:15.810 --> 00:00:19.060
I'll be your host Daniel Lowrie, and
here with me today is a man that actually

5
00:00:19.060 --> 00:00:22.010
owns a full size copy
of Vigo the Carpathian.

6
00:00:22.010 --> 00:00:23.050
That is Don Pezet.

7
00:00:23.050 --> 00:00:24.000
How's it going today Don?

8
00:00:24.000 --> 00:00:25.460
>> It is going great.

9
00:00:25.460 --> 00:00:28.930
We're back for another Linux plus episode
and this one's kinda a neat one cuz we're

10
00:00:28.930 --> 00:00:32.040
gonna be talking about
managing data with SQL.

11
00:00:32.040 --> 00:00:34.300
Now what the heck is SQL?

12
00:00:34.300 --> 00:00:36.240
Well it's a database query language.

13
00:00:36.240 --> 00:00:39.800
And it's getting to be very common
that companies have databases.

14
00:00:39.800 --> 00:00:43.110
You stick all your data in there, maybe
your authenticating users against it,

15
00:00:43.110 --> 00:00:44.320
maybe your web pages are stored there,

16
00:00:44.320 --> 00:00:47.190
there's all sorts of different
things you could put in a database.

17
00:00:47.190 --> 00:00:50.490
So as a systems administrator,
you may find yourself at one

18
00:00:50.490 --> 00:00:53.330
point in a position where you
need to create a database server.

19
00:00:53.330 --> 00:00:55.571
Now, the exam, they don't expect
you to be a DBA, right, or

20
00:00:55.571 --> 00:00:56.883
database administrator, right.

21
00:00:56.883 --> 00:00:59.630
They don't expect you to know how to
do all the crazy queries and stuff, but

22
00:00:59.630 --> 00:01:02.070
they want you to have some
basic familiarity with it.

23
00:01:02.070 --> 00:01:06.350
So I'm gonna show you how to create
a SQL Server, get a database created,

24
00:01:06.350 --> 00:01:11.140
get some tables created, throw some
data in there and retrieve it again, and

25
00:01:11.140 --> 00:01:12.580
just kind of see how that works.

26
00:01:12.580 --> 00:01:13.730
It's actually not so bad.

27
00:01:13.730 --> 00:01:16.910
It seems kind of intimidating, but
it's really not that bad to get it up and

28
00:01:16.910 --> 00:01:18.190
going on the system.

29
00:01:18.190 --> 00:01:22.310
>> Yeah, Don, it's really interesting how
many other systems that you might install

30
00:01:22.310 --> 00:01:26.010
into your Linux operating system that
actually need a database server.

31
00:01:26.010 --> 00:01:30.810
They, all the time it's like, dependency
needed, this SQL Server, or this this type

32
00:01:30.810 --> 00:01:36.200
of database is needed, usually SQL
is the one that they're calling for.

33
00:01:36.200 --> 00:01:38.680
So it's gonna be interesting to see,
why does it need this, and

34
00:01:38.680 --> 00:01:41.370
how we can actually
implement it ourselves.

35
00:01:41.370 --> 00:01:43.730
Especially if you just wanna put a little
bit of the database together, right?

36
00:01:43.730 --> 00:01:44.360
>> Yep.

37
00:01:44.360 --> 00:01:47.560
Now, up until about a year ago,

38
00:01:47.560 --> 00:01:52.450
the most common SQL Server
on top of Linux was MySQL.

39
00:01:52.450 --> 00:01:57.520
MySQL is an open source product that,
it just worked really well, provided

40
00:01:57.520 --> 00:02:00.530
you with a relational database that you
could spin up in a matter of minutes.

41
00:02:00.530 --> 00:02:03.330
Didn't require a like of maintenance,
you could scale pretty large, so

42
00:02:03.330 --> 00:02:03.860
very, very popular.

43
00:02:03.860 --> 00:02:06.170
But then something happened.

44
00:02:06.170 --> 00:02:08.680
Oracle bought the MySQL foundation.

45
00:02:08.680 --> 00:02:12.370
And I don't understand how it works
exactly when a commercial entity buys

46
00:02:12.370 --> 00:02:17.700
a none profit or whatever, but at the end
of the day the open source community felt

47
00:02:17.700 --> 00:02:20.240
that Oracle wasn't
providing the support or

48
00:02:20.240 --> 00:02:24.470
allowing the changes needed to properly
support an open source database like that.

49
00:02:24.470 --> 00:02:28.670
And so while MySQL was the de facto
standard up until about a year or

50
00:02:28.670 --> 00:02:32.570
two ago now, we're seeing a lot
of people switch over to MariaDB.

51
00:02:33.860 --> 00:02:37.390
MariaDB or
the Maria database server is just MySQL.

52
00:02:37.390 --> 00:02:38.680
It's the same thing.

53
00:02:38.680 --> 00:02:42.640
But they fort the codebase and
now instead of having a push code

54
00:02:42.640 --> 00:02:46.830
changes through Oracle, they use push
code changes through themselves.

55
00:02:46.830 --> 00:02:50.026
So when you fire up
a brand new Linux distro.

56
00:02:50.026 --> 00:02:55.200
it depends, your distro may or
may not have switched over to MySQL.

57
00:02:55.200 --> 00:03:00.222
So for example if you're on cento S6, it's
still MySQL, but if you're on cento S7,

58
00:03:00.222 --> 00:03:04.730
it's MariaDB, so one of the first things
we need to do if we're going to go and

59
00:03:04.730 --> 00:03:08.050
install a database server is
figure out which one is supported.

60
00:03:08.050 --> 00:03:12.200
Now once they're installed they
both function exactly the same, so

61
00:03:12.200 --> 00:03:15.520
your end users they don't need to
know whether it's MariaDB or MySQL.

62
00:03:15.520 --> 00:03:17.030
They don't care about that.

63
00:03:17.030 --> 00:03:19.570
But for you to install it,
you need to know the package names and so

64
00:03:19.570 --> 00:03:21.620
you do need to know the difference.

65
00:03:21.620 --> 00:03:24.760
So one of the first things that I
usually do when I need to do an install

66
00:03:24.760 --> 00:03:26.150
is search for the packages.

67
00:03:26.150 --> 00:03:28.440
So let me do that and
I'm gonna use the yum command,

68
00:03:28.440 --> 00:03:30.110
because I'm on a RedHat based system.

69
00:03:30.110 --> 00:03:34.830
But if you're on the BN you'd use app get,
to go and try and find these packages.

70
00:03:34.830 --> 00:03:37.930
So I'm just gonna do a yum list mysql*.

71
00:03:37.930 --> 00:03:40.832
Show me every package
that starts with MySQL.

72
00:03:40.832 --> 00:03:45.780
All right, and I'm gonna run it and
I only see three packages,

73
00:03:45.780 --> 00:03:49.840
none of which are mysql-server which
is kinda the important one, right.

74
00:03:49.840 --> 00:03:53.326
So that's a pretty good indicator that
this system is already switched over

75
00:03:53.326 --> 00:03:53.929
to MariaDB.

76
00:03:53.929 --> 00:03:59.630
So instead I'll do a yum list, mariadb*,
and see what I get back there.

77
00:03:59.630 --> 00:04:03.000
And here we go the two
packages I'm looking for

78
00:04:03.000 --> 00:04:06.910
are mariadb-server,
that's the server itself.

79
00:04:06.910 --> 00:04:10.630
And mariadb by itself,
that's the client, all right?

80
00:04:10.630 --> 00:04:14.510
If you want to connect to an SQL
database you need the client.

81
00:04:14.510 --> 00:04:17.850
If you want to be the server,
you needed a minimum the server.

82
00:04:17.850 --> 00:04:20.240
But to configure it,
you need the client also.

83
00:04:20.240 --> 00:04:22.350
So we normally install the server and
the client together.

84
00:04:23.420 --> 00:04:26.100
Now, if these were MySQL,
it'd be the same thing.

85
00:04:26.100 --> 00:04:29.600
There'd be one called MySQL and
there'd be one called mySQL dash server.

86
00:04:29.600 --> 00:04:32.140
So I just need to install
the appropriate package.

87
00:04:32.140 --> 00:04:34.300
Once they are installed,
the two are identical and

88
00:04:34.300 --> 00:04:38.010
you'll actually see the commands
are MySQL after I install MariaDB.

89
00:04:38.010 --> 00:04:41.160
It is just a fork of the same code base.

90
00:04:41.160 --> 00:04:44.108
I'm gonna do a quick yum install.

91
00:04:44.108 --> 00:04:47.063
Actually hang on a second let
me do a little super user,

92
00:04:47.063 --> 00:04:49.530
I need to elevate my privileges here.

93
00:04:49.530 --> 00:04:56.870
And I'll do a yum install and, if it was
mysql I would do mysql and mysql-server.

94
00:04:56.870 --> 00:05:03.570
But since it's MariaDB I'm gonna install
mariadb and mariadb-server, all right.

95
00:05:03.570 --> 00:05:06.800
So it's gonna install those two packages
and their associated dependencies.

96
00:05:06.800 --> 00:05:10.230
See how I needed pearl also so
it's grabbing those pearl components and

97
00:05:10.230 --> 00:05:15.890
it's gonna load it in there and now I'll
have that database and the client alright.

98
00:05:15.890 --> 00:05:17.750
So we'll give it just
a second while it installs.

99
00:05:17.750 --> 00:05:19.570
Now while it's installing,

100
00:05:19.570 --> 00:05:24.000
something we really have to worry
about databases store data and

101
00:05:24.000 --> 00:05:28.940
hackers love data so this is something
that people are gonna target for attacks.

102
00:05:28.940 --> 00:05:32.140
SQL injection attacks are one of the most
common types of attacks that are out

103
00:05:32.140 --> 00:05:33.260
there on the Internet.

104
00:05:33.260 --> 00:05:36.070
And so, we need to make sure
that our database is secured.

105
00:05:36.070 --> 00:05:38.850
When it installs, it is not secure.

106
00:05:38.850 --> 00:05:41.610
So you do not want to run
it with a default install.

107
00:05:41.610 --> 00:05:45.120
For example,
the root user has no password, by default.

108
00:05:45.120 --> 00:05:47.240
So for somebody to get in,
there's no password set.

109
00:05:47.240 --> 00:05:49.060
They can get in and
have full access to the database.

110
00:05:49.060 --> 00:05:50.670
That would be bad, right?

111
00:05:50.670 --> 00:05:54.810
So we need to take a couple extra steps
to get in and make sure this is secure.

112
00:05:54.810 --> 00:05:57.870
All right, so
my server just finished installing and

113
00:05:57.870 --> 00:06:02.160
I'm gonna go in and start the service,
even though it's not secure.

114
00:06:02.160 --> 00:06:05.110
And then go in and apply a configuration
to it to make it secure.

115
00:06:05.110 --> 00:06:09.520
During this time the way I normally do
this is if I have an IP tables firewall

116
00:06:09.520 --> 00:06:11.050
I don't open up MySQL ports yet.

117
00:06:11.050 --> 00:06:14.200
I leave them closed while I
get the server secured and

118
00:06:14.200 --> 00:06:16.180
then I open up the firewall ports.

119
00:06:16.180 --> 00:06:16.740
All right?

120
00:06:16.740 --> 00:06:19.990
So, just be aware that this is kinda
vulnerable in its default install.

121
00:06:21.010 --> 00:06:25.320
Now, I just installed MariaDB, so
it's in there, it's up and it's going.

122
00:06:25.320 --> 00:06:29.780
I need to make sure it's set to run,
and to set to startup.

123
00:06:29.780 --> 00:06:37.428
If it was MySQL,
I would be using the MySQL D service.

124
00:06:37.428 --> 00:06:40.600
If it's MariaDB,
it'll be the MariaDB d service, and so

125
00:06:40.600 --> 00:06:45.200
I need to make sure that I specify
the right service when I tell it to start.

126
00:06:45.200 --> 00:06:50.920
On a system five or upstart system we
would use the service start command.

127
00:06:50.920 --> 00:06:56.030
On a system D system we'll use the system
CTL command and I'm on a system D system.

128
00:06:56.030 --> 00:07:00.641
So I'm gonna say systemctl start mariadb,
so

129
00:07:00.641 --> 00:07:04.600
I'm gonna start that service up.

130
00:07:04.600 --> 00:07:07.300
Now, it's gonna take a second and
then it'll start,

131
00:07:07.300 --> 00:07:13.000
I'm not running a non secure SQL Server,
so I'm at risk right now.

132
00:07:13.000 --> 00:07:18.380
I'm gonna follow that with a,
actually let me do a system CTL

133
00:07:18.380 --> 00:07:23.350
enable mariadb so it'll make sure that
it starts up with my system, and so

134
00:07:23.350 --> 00:07:26.900
it's checking it out here,
and just creating a link.

135
00:07:26.900 --> 00:07:30.370
So now when my system boots up,
MariaDB will automatically start,

136
00:07:30.370 --> 00:07:31.500
so I'm good there.

137
00:07:31.500 --> 00:07:34.460
On an upstart system,
you'd use chkconfig to do the same thing.

138
00:07:35.570 --> 00:07:36.140
All right.

139
00:07:36.140 --> 00:07:38.310
Now I need to get this guy secure.

140
00:07:38.310 --> 00:07:41.610
Well, fortunately,
they put a nice little script in here.

141
00:07:41.610 --> 00:07:44.930
And from this point on,
everything that we do is the same.

142
00:07:44.930 --> 00:07:47.410
From MySQL or MariaDB,
there's no more differences.

143
00:07:47.410 --> 00:07:50.454
So that's really the differences
right there right up to that point,

144
00:07:50.454 --> 00:07:52.836
but at this stage now
everything's gonna be the same.

145
00:07:52.836 --> 00:07:57.448
So to secure it they actually created

146
00:07:57.448 --> 00:08:02.355
a little script for us that will do it and

147
00:08:02.355 --> 00:08:08.917
its /usr/bin/ mysql_secure_installation.

148
00:08:08.917 --> 00:08:12.230
Now I installed mariadb, but
see how the script is called mysql?

149
00:08:12.230 --> 00:08:14.130
Even the commands are mysql
from this point on.

150
00:08:14.130 --> 00:08:16.170
Everything is basically the same.

151
00:08:16.170 --> 00:08:19.040
So when I run that it's a simple
script to help secure the system.

152
00:08:19.040 --> 00:08:21.050
Here it's asking for my root password.

153
00:08:21.050 --> 00:08:23.410
It's none by default so
I just press Enter.

154
00:08:23.410 --> 00:08:24.910
There was no password.

155
00:08:24.910 --> 00:08:25.980
Here's a chance for me to set it.

156
00:08:25.980 --> 00:08:27.780
I'm gonna go and set that password, and

157
00:08:27.780 --> 00:08:32.400
I'll pick a super secure password,
like the word password.

158
00:08:32.400 --> 00:08:35.080
Then do I want to remove anonymous users?

159
00:08:35.080 --> 00:08:37.130
Anonymous users actually
have access by default.

160
00:08:37.130 --> 00:08:39.000
That's not a necessarily a great thing.

161
00:08:39.000 --> 00:08:40.970
So I'm gonna say yeah, go ahead and
remove those anonymous users.

162
00:08:40.970 --> 00:08:42.470
Get them out of there.

163
00:08:42.470 --> 00:08:44.950
And then here's probably
the most important option,

164
00:08:44.950 --> 00:08:47.550
disallow root login remotely.

165
00:08:47.550 --> 00:08:48.780
In other words,

166
00:08:48.780 --> 00:08:53.410
only allow root to login if they're
actually on the console of this machine.

167
00:08:53.410 --> 00:08:56.440
Don't allow them to SSH in and
do it or run it from a remote client.

168
00:08:56.440 --> 00:08:59.540
Don't allow that,
they've gotta be on this console.

169
00:08:59.540 --> 00:09:00.390
That's an absolute.

170
00:09:00.390 --> 00:09:01.560
You want to do that.

171
00:09:01.560 --> 00:09:05.010
We want them to be logged into this system
directly, not running a remote client.

172
00:09:05.010 --> 00:09:07.100
Cuz that remote client could be a hacker.

173
00:09:07.100 --> 00:09:09.800
So this is gonna stop them from
being able to use that root account.

174
00:09:09.800 --> 00:09:11.010
So I'll say yes to disallow that.

175
00:09:12.440 --> 00:09:17.230
There's a test database created by
default and it's offering to remove that.

176
00:09:17.230 --> 00:09:18.910
I'm gonna leave it here on the show.

177
00:09:18.910 --> 00:09:19.640
In real life land,

178
00:09:19.640 --> 00:09:24.130
I always remove it because attackers
know about that test database.

179
00:09:24.130 --> 00:09:26.740
So they know the name of at least
one database on your system and

180
00:09:26.740 --> 00:09:27.790
they can target that.

181
00:09:27.790 --> 00:09:32.110
It's a good idea to remove it, but
I'll leave it here just for the show.

182
00:09:32.110 --> 00:09:34.080
And then anytime we change permissions,

183
00:09:34.080 --> 00:09:37.320
like allowing that root user
not to log in remotely, well,

184
00:09:37.320 --> 00:09:40.200
we need to refresh our permissions table,
so it's offering to do that right here.

185
00:09:40.200 --> 00:09:43.031
I'll say yes, and it's gonna refresh that.

186
00:09:43.031 --> 00:09:45.678
Now my database is more secure.

187
00:09:45.678 --> 00:09:49.076
Now I can open up those firewall ports or
whatever and start to go in and

188
00:09:49.076 --> 00:09:50.080
configure things.

189
00:09:51.130 --> 00:09:55.587
Running that secure install
script is really important.

190
00:09:55.587 --> 00:09:58.390
All right, so I've got it.

191
00:09:58.390 --> 00:10:00.720
Now I should be able to
connect to my system.

192
00:10:00.720 --> 00:10:03.120
To connect to the system
I can use the client.

193
00:10:03.120 --> 00:10:07.110
Now the client, I know when I installed
it the package was called MariaDB, but

194
00:10:07.110 --> 00:10:09.845
the command that it installs is mysql.

195
00:10:09.845 --> 00:10:12.920
Cuz everything's the same
past the install.

196
00:10:12.920 --> 00:10:16.260
So I'm gonna say mysql,
and then I can specify.

197
00:10:16.260 --> 00:10:20.320
Well, if I just run it like this,
it's going to use my current user name and

198
00:10:20.320 --> 00:10:21.970
then it's going to prompt me for
a password.

199
00:10:21.970 --> 00:10:25.210
So if I'm logged in as dpezet,
it's going to try to access it as dpezet.

200
00:10:25.210 --> 00:10:28.810
If I want to log in as a different user
though I can say -u and specify that user.

201
00:10:28.810 --> 00:10:30.276
I'm gonna log in as root.

202
00:10:30.276 --> 00:10:35.330
And then -p, which is telling it, hey,
you need to prompt me for the password.

203
00:10:35.330 --> 00:10:36.980
And when I press Enter it asks for
my password.

204
00:10:36.980 --> 00:10:43.000
I punch that in, and
now I'm in a MariaDB shell.

205
00:10:43.000 --> 00:10:47.860
I'm in the SQL command line interface and
I can start to issue SQL commands.

equals a certain number.

440
00:21:48.630 --> 00:21:52.810
And that filters the results, makes the
query run better, return less data, and

441
00:21:52.810 --> 00:21:54.320
gives the user the data they want.

442
00:21:54.320 --> 00:21:55.900
That's the power of a database.

443
00:21:55.900 --> 00:21:59.540
So the select statement I ran,
that's not terribly efficient, right?

444
00:21:59.540 --> 00:22:02.150
But if I just want people
in department two,

445
00:22:02.150 --> 00:22:04.372
I can take that query and I can add to it.

446
00:22:04.372 --> 00:22:09.550
SELECT *, give me everything
FROM employees WHERE and

447
00:22:09.550 --> 00:22:10.830
then I can start to limit this down.

448
00:22:10.830 --> 00:22:18.016
And I can say something like,
department is LIKE 1.

449
00:22:18.016 --> 00:22:18.632
All right?

450
00:22:18.632 --> 00:22:21.860
So if the department equals one, right?

451
00:22:21.860 --> 00:22:25.208
And not the LIKE command is kind of
a funny one, because when you say LIKE it

452
00:22:25.208 --> 00:22:29.120
can actually equal other things,
I'll show you another example in a second.

453
00:22:29.120 --> 00:22:31.914
But when I run that, so
WHERE the department is LIKE 1,

454
00:22:31.914 --> 00:22:34.120
it's giving me Bob Smith and Alan Johnson.

455
00:22:34.120 --> 00:22:37.470
It's leaving off John Doe and
Alice Smith cuz they're in department two.

456
00:22:37.470 --> 00:22:39.140
I'm getting that filtered data back.

457
00:22:40.390 --> 00:22:44.260
Now LIKE, you can actually use it to
kinda tailor things a bit differently.

458
00:22:44.260 --> 00:22:49.905
Maybe I want people where their last
name starts with the letter S, right?

459
00:22:49.905 --> 00:22:55.757
So I might say, WHERE lastname is LIKE %S.

460
00:22:55.757 --> 00:22:56.314
All right?

461
00:22:56.314 --> 00:23:01.168
That percent I'm basically saying that the
name, oh wait I got it backwards, shoot.

462
00:23:01.168 --> 00:23:02.863
I'm doing it the Linux way.

463
00:23:02.863 --> 00:23:04.965
There, the SQL way, S*.

464
00:23:04.965 --> 00:23:08.023
So I'm saying where the name
starts with the letter S and

465
00:23:08.023 --> 00:23:11.224
is followed by anything else,
that % is like a wildcard.

466
00:23:11.224 --> 00:23:11.850
Okay?

467
00:23:11.850 --> 00:23:14.745
So just give me the people with
the last name starts with S and,

468
00:23:14.745 --> 00:23:16.480
oh did I have it right the first time?

469
00:23:16.480 --> 00:23:17.680
Let's see.

470
00:23:17.680 --> 00:23:21.045
Last name, LIKE oh,
I forgot something important.

471
00:23:21.045 --> 00:23:24.500
SQL is very finicky about the syntax and

472
00:23:24.500 --> 00:23:28.790
when I do this S% like isn't expecting
that percent sign to be there.

473
00:23:28.790 --> 00:23:33.620
So I actually need to put that inside
of some single quotes there, right?

474
00:23:33.620 --> 00:23:35.880
To make it happy and there we go.

475
00:23:35.880 --> 00:23:37.580
Now it's gonna run and
it's gonna handle that.

476
00:23:37.580 --> 00:23:39.680
It was interpreting the percent
sign was the problem there.

477
00:23:39.680 --> 00:23:42.170
So putting it in those single
quotes stops that from happening.

478
00:23:42.170 --> 00:23:44.160
And now I get Bob Smith and

479
00:23:44.160 --> 00:23:49.170
Alice Smith, just the two people whose
last name started with S, right?

480
00:23:49.170 --> 00:23:52.429
So pretty nice way to filter that,
get just the data we want and

481
00:23:52.429 --> 00:23:53.752
start to do work with it.

482
00:23:53.752 --> 00:23:57.828
Now each time I've done this,
I've done select star, right?

483
00:23:57.828 --> 00:23:59.414
I've selected everything.

484
00:23:59.414 --> 00:24:03.981
Maybe I wanna filter that down, maybe I
just want the firstname and lastname.

485
00:24:03.981 --> 00:24:09.353
So, I can get rid of that * and
I can say firstname, lastname.

486
00:24:09.353 --> 00:24:12.318
Right, so
now I'm just getting the first name and

487
00:24:12.318 --> 00:24:17.500
last name from the employee's table
where the last name starts with that S.

488
00:24:17.500 --> 00:24:18.110
Right?

489
00:24:18.110 --> 00:24:21.508
And there we go, no I don't get those
other columns so you can filter that, too.

490
00:24:21.508 --> 00:24:26.537
And you can even filter on
a column that you don't return, so

00:24:26.537 --> 00:24:33.460
maybe I'm gonna change this and I'll say

00:24:33.460 --> 00:24:37.380
Now when I run that, so my heads not

493
00:24:37.380 --> 00:24:39.740
Well I'm saying where that

00:24:39.740 --> 00:24:43.910
now I'm not selecting the department but

495
00:24:43.910 --> 00:24:46.320
I can still query against it and
it returns something else.

496
00:24:46.320 --> 00:24:49.060
So I get Bob and Alan,
who are in department one, but

497
00:24:49.060 --> 00:24:50.310
i don't have that column.

498
00:24:50.310 --> 00:24:53.190
That column's not useful to me,
cuz I did where they were like one,

499
00:24:53.190 --> 00:24:56.130
I already know that it's gonna be one,
what do I need to see a column for?

500
00:24:56.130 --> 00:24:56.680
Right?

501
00:24:56.680 --> 00:24:59.618
So again, customizing that data
that we get back from the system.

502
00:25:01.149 --> 00:25:02.150
All right.

503
00:25:02.150 --> 00:25:04.700
So those are some examples
of how we can do this.

504
00:25:04.700 --> 00:25:08.350
Now you can get really, really fancy and

00:25:08.350 --> 00:25:13.710
Some other examples like, here let me,

00:25:13.710 --> 00:25:19.260
a departments table, and let me just jump

507
00:25:20.390 --> 00:25:21.080
There we go.

508
00:25:21.080 --> 00:25:25.538
So I just created another table called
departments and if I do a select star from

00:25:25.538 --> 00:25:30.325
departments, whoops, forgot my semicolon.

00:25:30.325 --> 00:25:31.445
I just created marketing and sales.

00:25:31.445 --> 00:25:34.225
I'm giving a name to the departments,

00:25:34.225 --> 00:25:37.175
I said somebody was in department one,

00:25:37.175 --> 00:25:38.085
what are those.

Well this table has the mapping.

00:25:40.155 --> 00:25:42.895
It maps one to marketing and two to sales.

00:25:44.115 --> 00:25:47.715
I can then take data

And that's called doing a join.

519
00:25:53.120 --> 00:25:54.210
And so.

00:25:54.210 --> 00:25:56.260
Do I not actually have a?

00:25:56.260 --> 00:25:57.890
I thought I wrote a?

522
00:25:57.890 --> 00:25:58.955
Oh, this is my join, here.

00:25:58.955 --> 00:26:01.890
[LAUGH] I thought I'd written

524
00:26:01.890 --> 00:26:04.090
So here, I'm going to paste this one in.

525
00:26:04.090 --> 00:26:06.174
And let me show you what it's doing.

526
00:26:06.174 --> 00:26:13.410
I'm selecting employees.firstname,
employees.lastname, and departments.name.

527
00:26:13.410 --> 00:26:17.130
Notice the dots there,
I'm specifying a table in the column.

528
00:26:17.130 --> 00:26:20.070
So I'm getting first name and
last name from employees, and

529
00:26:20.070 --> 00:26:23.090
I'm getting the name from departments.

530
00:26:23.090 --> 00:26:27.580
And then I'm saying pull that from
employees and join it to departments on.

531
00:26:27.580 --> 00:26:30.200
And I'm saying that in
the employees table,

532
00:26:30.200 --> 00:26:35.350
the department column equals the ID
column in the departments table.

533
00:26:35.350 --> 00:26:40.430
So it's combining that data and
I end up with a table like this.

534
00:26:40.430 --> 00:26:45.000
So now I can see Bob Smith isn't just in
department one, Bob Smith is in Marketing.

535
00:26:45.000 --> 00:26:46.730
And John Doe is in Sales.

536
00:26:46.730 --> 00:26:50.950
We're combining that data in a join
to create a table that doesn't exist.

537
00:26:50.950 --> 00:26:54.330
To create a table that's more meaningful
to us in this particular scenario.

538
00:26:54.330 --> 00:26:58.870
That's how customizable this information
is and that's why SQL is so powerful.

539
00:26:58.870 --> 00:27:02.090
>> Well, Don, it seems like, basically,
what we're doing here with this database

540
00:27:02.090 --> 00:27:05.680
business is saying, I got a bunch of
data and I just need to organize it.

541
00:27:05.680 --> 00:27:10.650
And if you can learn the SQL language,
the syntax that it uses,

542
00:27:10.650 --> 00:27:14.590
you can do that pretty effectively, and
then call that data as you need it.

543
00:27:14.590 --> 00:27:15.160
Very helpful.

544
00:27:15.160 --> 00:27:17.650
I think I already know what I'm going
to do with my first SQL database.

545
00:27:17.650 --> 00:27:22.330
I'm going to arrange all of my movies into
[LAUGH] by name, and genre, and all that,

00:27:22.330 --> 00:27:24.210
and that could be a very handy thing for

547
00:27:24.210 --> 00:27:25.310
>> Absolutely.

548
00:27:25.310 --> 00:27:28.820
Let me show you guys one more thing and
then we'll wrap up our SQL lesson here.

549
00:27:28.820 --> 00:27:32.340
I created those records,
what if I need to change one?

550
00:27:32.340 --> 00:27:32.950
Okay?

551
00:27:32.950 --> 00:27:37.389
So, for example, if I do select star

552
00:27:37.389 --> 00:27:41.845
from Employees where ID equals one.

553
00:27:41.845 --> 00:27:43.315
Okay, or here, we'll do ID number four.

554
00:27:43.315 --> 00:27:45.655
We'll do the last one that I made.

555
00:27:45.655 --> 00:27:47.725
I didn't use the like command here,
I used equals and

556
00:27:47.725 --> 00:27:50.245
equals is actually a more efficient query,
so when you're searching for

557
00:27:50.245 --> 00:27:52.245
something in particular
equals works a little better.

558
00:27:52.245 --> 00:27:56.095
So, select star from employees where
id equals four, I can see Alice Smith.

559
00:27:56.095 --> 00:27:59.105
And see how Alice is in department two?

560
00:27:59.105 --> 00:28:01.850
Maybe I want to change
her to department 1,

561
00:28:01.850 --> 00:28:04.570
all right, I wanna move her
over to the other department.

562
00:28:04.570 --> 00:28:08.970
Well what I can do is I can
do an update statement.

563
00:28:08.970 --> 00:28:12.950
And what I'm doing here is I'm saying
update the employees table and

564
00:28:12.950 --> 00:28:15.784
I wanna set department equals one.

565
00:28:15.784 --> 00:28:18.998
And if I were to stop right there it
would set everybody to department one.

566
00:28:18.998 --> 00:28:22.411
And so
then I say where the ID equals four.

567
00:28:22.411 --> 00:28:23.501
Now who is ID four?

568
00:28:23.501 --> 00:28:25.200
Alice Smith.

569
00:28:25.200 --> 00:28:31.150
So I'm just updating Alice's record to
change her department from two to one.

570
00:28:31.150 --> 00:28:35.870
And if I rerun my query, I can see
that Alice is now in department one.

571
00:28:35.870 --> 00:28:38.480
And if I rerun my big
join from a minute ago.

572
00:28:38.480 --> 00:28:39.710
And I rerun that.

573
00:28:39.710 --> 00:28:42.630
I can see I now have three
people in marketing.

574
00:28:42.630 --> 00:28:46.100
So that update command is
pretty straight forward.

575
00:28:46.100 --> 00:28:48.070
And it can update more than one row.

576
00:28:48.070 --> 00:28:53.160
You could say where, instead of ID,
you could say where last name,

577
00:28:53.160 --> 00:28:57.900
like S%, and it would do everybody
whose last name started with S, right?

578
00:28:57.900 --> 00:29:02.490
So you can update tens of thousands
of rows all in a single command,

579
00:29:02.490 --> 00:29:04.070
all very, very quickly.

580
00:29:04.070 --> 00:29:07.450
And if you're somebody like Amazon,
that's pretty important, right?

581
00:29:07.450 --> 00:29:10.510
If they have something that's on sale,
and they then wanna take it off sale,

582
00:29:10.510 --> 00:29:13.070
right, maybe they have a big
Black Friday sale, right?

583
00:29:13.070 --> 00:29:16.770
And a ton of stuff is 30 percent off and
the next day the sale is over.

584
00:29:16.770 --> 00:29:19.400
They need to update all this
stuff to show the sale's over.

585
00:29:19.400 --> 00:29:22.040
If they have thousands and
thousands of products,

586
00:29:22.040 --> 00:29:23.840
that could take forever doing it by hand.

587
00:29:23.840 --> 00:29:28.130
A quick SQL query runs through,
updates them, sale is over, right?

588
00:29:28.130 --> 00:29:30.370
That's the kind of power that we
have with databases like this.

589
00:29:31.912 --> 00:29:34.450
All right, well, I think that's enough for
our initial primer.

590
00:29:34.450 --> 00:29:37.730
Keep in mind that COMPTIA, they don't

591
00:29:37.730 --> 00:29:40.360
They just want you to know
how to install SQL server,

592
00:29:40.360 --> 00:29:43.060
how to get it up, and how that functions.

593
00:29:43.060 --> 00:29:46.160
How the database works, how the table
works, and how you can quickly and

594
00:29:46.160 --> 00:29:47.380
easily put data in there.

595
00:29:47.380 --> 00:29:48.400
and get it out, right?

596
00:29:48.400 --> 00:29:50.700
So, I think we've got
a pretty good primer here.

597
00:29:50.700 --> 00:29:53.550
If you want to learn more about
the data bases I encourage you to check

598
00:29:53.550 --> 00:29:57.790
out Oracle's website and the Maria DB
website at, I think its tied to the,

00:29:57.790 --> 00:30:00.250
oh no they've got their own site.

Its not part of the Apache umbrella.

00:30:01.948 --> 00:30:06.071
But you can jump over and check them

602
00:30:06.071 --> 00:30:07.550
a lot of efficiencies.

603
00:30:07.550 --> 00:30:11.000
You can learn a lot more about
primary keys, foreign keys, indexes,

604
00:30:11.000 --> 00:30:13.940
all the stuff that's really important

00:30:13.940 --> 00:30:17.540
But just to get a basic understanding in
place, we've kind of seen what we need.

00:30:17.540 --> 00:30:19.680
>> Yeah, really great stuff and
a lot of cool information,

00:30:19.680 --> 00:30:21.310
especially if you're new to this.

00:30:21.310 --> 00:30:24.650
Not a huge database guy but

play with some, then it never hurts to

00:30:29.310 --> 00:30:33.080
So hopefully you guys will work on that

up and maybe even become a database
