WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.877
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:10.877 --> 00:00:14.064
All right, good morning,
good afternoon, and good evening,

3
00:00:14.064 --> 00:00:16.483
and welcome back to another
episode of ITProTV,

4
00:00:16.483 --> 00:00:20.390
I'm your host Don Pezet back again
with another episode of Linux plus.

5
00:00:20.390 --> 00:00:23.450
Daniel's out sick today so
I'm taking over the show, solo style.

6
00:00:23.450 --> 00:00:26.630
And that's pretty cool because today
we're gonna be taking a look at

7
00:00:26.630 --> 00:00:30.610
printing inside the Linux world which
is a pretty neat little system.

8
00:00:30.610 --> 00:00:33.660
Something you are gonna encounter
sooner or later, believe it or not.

9
00:00:33.660 --> 00:00:35.425
No matter how green and

10
00:00:35.425 --> 00:00:40.790
e-document kind of our systems have
gotten, people still expect to print.

11
00:00:40.790 --> 00:00:43.640
I mean, even look at people like me
where sure at home, everything I do

12
00:00:43.640 --> 00:00:46.900
is digital but when we do a show,
I've got my notes on paper right here.

13
00:00:46.900 --> 00:00:50.780
So plenty of people still have a need
to get what's in their computer out

14
00:00:50.780 --> 00:00:52.340
on a piece of dead tree from time to time,

15
00:00:52.340 --> 00:00:55.630
and that's what I'm gonna show you guys
today, we're gonna kill some trees.

16
00:00:55.630 --> 00:01:00.690
So inside the Linux world, if you had the
opportunity to work with Linux printing,

17
00:01:00.690 --> 00:01:04.200
say eight or more years ago,
it was a nightmare.

18
00:01:04.200 --> 00:01:05.640
It was really challenging.

19
00:01:05.640 --> 00:01:09.870
That for a printer to be supported
under Linux was kind of a rarity, and

20
00:01:09.870 --> 00:01:13.560
to have printer manufacturers actually
create hardware and create drivers and

21
00:01:13.560 --> 00:01:16.730
all of that, that worked in the Linux
world, it was really, really, rough.

22
00:01:16.730 --> 00:01:18.580
And then something happened.

23
00:01:18.580 --> 00:01:24.660
That something was that Apple decided
to switch to using a BSD core for

24
00:01:24.660 --> 00:01:25.735
their operating system.

25
00:01:25.735 --> 00:01:28.480
So, Mac OS in Mac OS 9 and

26
00:01:28.480 --> 00:01:32.130
earlier, can get kinda ran
Apple's own proprietary stuff.

27
00:01:32.130 --> 00:01:35.473
And then starting with OS X,
they ran BSD under the hood.

28
00:01:35.473 --> 00:01:40.107
BSD is built on top of Unix,
Linux which is build on top of Unix.

29
00:01:40.107 --> 00:01:44.086
And so because Linux and
Mac OS share that kind of common heritage,

30
00:01:44.086 --> 00:01:47.711
when something's developed for
one, sometimes it can make

31
00:01:47.711 --> 00:01:52.100
it's way over to the other and
printing is a great example of that.

32
00:01:52.100 --> 00:01:53.900
When Apple started creating Mac OS X,

33
00:01:53.900 --> 00:01:59.170
they said man, printing is just a mess
under Unix, let's create our own system.

34
00:01:59.170 --> 00:02:02.535
And so they did.
They created a system called CUPS,

35
00:02:02.535 --> 00:02:03.150
C-U-P-S.

36
00:02:03.150 --> 00:02:06.960
And it stands for
the Common Unix Printing System.

37
00:02:06.960 --> 00:02:08.940
And Apple dumped a ton of money into it,
and

38
00:02:08.940 --> 00:02:12.350
a ton of power because
they're a fairly big name.

39
00:02:12.350 --> 00:02:17.160
They got printer manufactures to get on
board and they created this common driver

40
00:02:17.160 --> 00:02:22.310
format that can be used across any
Unix-based system and they released

41
00:02:22.310 --> 00:02:27.630
it as open source, and so every major
Linux distro has picked this up.

42
00:02:27.630 --> 00:02:32.530
And as a result, printing today under
Linux is really no big deal at all.

43
00:02:32.530 --> 00:02:35.790
It's pretty much a given that your
hardware manufacturers are going to have

44
00:02:35.790 --> 00:02:39.180
Linux drivers because they're
making them from Mac OS also.

45
00:02:39.180 --> 00:02:41.050
And it's the same driver.

46
00:02:41.050 --> 00:02:44.630
Even though they usually package them in
separate files because of the installer,

47
00:02:44.630 --> 00:02:47.000
the driver at the end
of the day is the same.

48
00:02:47.000 --> 00:02:51.320
So that CUPS printing system is
really what makes this easy,

49
00:02:51.320 --> 00:02:53.760
what makes this work,

And when I print to it, it's going to use

270
00:14:17.650 --> 00:14:22.950
the configuration defined in this PPD
file to know how to talk to that printer.

271
00:14:22.950 --> 00:14:27.590
Those are the three pieces of information
we need to get that set up and

272
00:14:27.590 --> 00:14:29.680
make it where we can print to the printer.

273
00:14:29.680 --> 00:14:32.690
So now we've got the printer defined,
let's use it, right?

274
00:14:32.690 --> 00:14:36.430
We've got the lp command, which lets you
print to a printer from the command line.

275
00:14:36.430 --> 00:14:39.480
I just need a file, so let me,
I'll whip up like a quick file here.

276
00:14:41.020 --> 00:14:43.100
Maybe we'll just call one file.txt.

277
00:14:43.100 --> 00:14:46.600
And I'll insert some text,
this is a test document.

278
00:14:47.760 --> 00:14:49.330
All right, there we go.

279
00:14:49.330 --> 00:14:51.520
Oops!
[LAUGH] Stayed in insert mode there.

280
00:14:51.520 --> 00:14:52.740
There we go, all right.

281
00:14:52.740 --> 00:14:54.400
So I got a little document.

282
00:14:54.400 --> 00:14:57.990
I wanna print this document,
so I can just say, lp and

283
00:14:57.990 --> 00:14:59.330
I need to give it a destination.

284
00:14:59.330 --> 00:15:01.272
Who am I gonna print to?

285
00:15:01.272 --> 00:15:04.690
So -d and I'll specify that
I'm printing to Canon7065.

286
00:15:04.690 --> 00:15:09.460
That was the name that I gave to my
printer, the easy name to remember, right?

287
00:15:09.460 --> 00:15:11.030
So lp -d Canon7065.

288
00:15:11.030 --> 00:15:14.220
And then I just need to
tell it what I'm printing.

289
00:15:14.220 --> 00:15:17.300
I'm gonna print file.txt, right?

290
00:15:17.300 --> 00:15:19.000
It's gonna take that file.

291
00:15:19.000 --> 00:15:22.280
It's gonna look at the PPD for
Canon7065, and say all right,

292
00:15:22.280 --> 00:15:25.360
what do I need to do this file to
get the printer to recognize it?

293
00:15:25.360 --> 00:15:26.870
Not much, in this case.

294
00:15:26.870 --> 00:15:30.080
And then it's gonna send it
to the printer, all right?

295
00:15:30.080 --> 00:15:33.650
Now, when I say, what do we have to
do to it, some printers use PCL,

296
00:15:33.650 --> 00:15:36.650
the printer control language,
some use PostScript,

297
00:15:36.650 --> 00:15:39.560
which is another way of defining fonts and
arrangement on a page.

298
00:15:39.560 --> 00:15:43.010
Others expect it to be a raw
image that's sent to the printer.

299
00:15:43.010 --> 00:15:44.458
The PPD is what defines that, and

300
00:15:44.458 --> 00:15:48.000
tells your system how to manipulate
the document before sending it, all right?

301
00:15:48.000 --> 00:15:50.960
So it's gonna know that, and
it's gonna send it to the printer.

302
00:15:50.960 --> 00:15:54.774
Now I'm stalling here, and the reason is
Once I run this, this is a small document,

303
00:15:54.774 --> 00:15:56.140
It's gonna print very fast.

304
00:15:56.140 --> 00:15:58.610
How do I know if it actually printed?

305
00:15:58.610 --> 00:16:03.440
Well, there's a second command
we can run called lpstat, and

306
00:16:03.440 --> 00:16:07.300
lpstat shows us the status of a print job,
so you can see if it's printing, or

307
00:16:07.300 --> 00:16:08.840
if it's stuck in your queue.

308
00:16:08.840 --> 00:16:10.850
Maybe I can't contact that printer, and

309
00:16:10.850 --> 00:16:13.800
the document will say stuck in
my queue and waiting, right.

310
00:16:13.800 --> 00:16:16.240
So I'm gonna print this, and
then as soon as it's done,

311
00:16:16.240 --> 00:16:19.070
I'm gonna pull up an lpstat for
that printer.

312
00:16:19.070 --> 00:16:21.310
Now when I run lpstat,
there's two ways I can run it.

313
00:16:21.310 --> 00:16:24.240
If I'm in a hurry, I can do lpstat-a,

314
00:16:24.240 --> 00:16:27.690
and that'll show me the status
of all of my printers.

315
00:16:27.690 --> 00:16:31.471
But if I have a lot of
printers I'm gonna wanna run

316
00:16:31.471 --> 00:16:36.820
lpstat-p followed by the name of
the printer, so I get just that one skew.

317
00:16:36.820 --> 00:16:38.900
I've got several printers here so
I want to do a dash p and

318
00:16:38.900 --> 00:16:42.140
I just want to type it fast,
so that's what I'm gonna do.

319
00:16:42.140 --> 00:16:45.050
All right, so I'm gonna run this and

320
00:16:45.050 --> 00:16:50.730
then I'll do an lp stat dash p Canon7065
and shoot, I wasn't fast enough.

321
00:16:50.730 --> 00:16:53.540
When you print a small document
it goes really fast and so

322
00:16:53.540 --> 00:16:59.680
I can see the Canon 7065 is idle, it's not
doing anything, and it's ready to print.

323
00:16:59.680 --> 00:17:03.190
Well, I sent it a job but
that document was so

324
00:17:03.190 --> 00:17:06.690
small that it whipped through that
queue really fast and it's over there.

325
00:17:06.690 --> 00:17:10.470
But if I had made a mistake, maybe I put
the wrong IP address in for the printer.

326
00:17:10.470 --> 00:17:15.700
Then that job might get stuck here in
the queue and then it's just gonna wait.

327
00:17:15.700 --> 00:17:18.230
So, for example, if I went back and
redefined that printer,

328
00:17:18.230 --> 00:17:24.470
I'm gonna create another Canon7065,
I'll call it the same thing dash two.

329
00:17:24.470 --> 00:17:28.790
And maybe I'll put it at an IP
that wouldn't respond, right?

330
00:17:28.790 --> 00:17:30.115
So here I'll point it to a firewall.

331
00:17:30.115 --> 00:17:37.450
[LAUGH] So, it's gonna point it to
an invalid IP and kind of define that one.

332
00:17:37.450 --> 00:17:40.200
And you can have more than one printer
defined on the same PPD file right?

333
00:17:40.200 --> 00:17:43.130
You can reuse that same driver over and
over again.

334
00:17:43.130 --> 00:17:46.680
So now if I were to print to that printer.

335
00:17:48.420 --> 00:17:52.670
All right, so there it goes to print,
and then I do an lpstat for

336
00:17:52.670 --> 00:17:57.480
that other one what I should see is,
right there, connecting to printer.

337
00:17:57.480 --> 00:17:59.960
It's sitting there, it's ready to print.

338
00:17:59.960 --> 00:18:03.440
See it says, Canon printer, now printing.

339
00:18:03.440 --> 00:18:06.900
So it's ready to print, but
it's stuck connecting to the printer.

340
00:18:06.900 --> 00:18:09.810
I can see that status, so
if you're wondering like where's my job,

341
00:18:09.810 --> 00:18:10.830
why isn't it going out?

342
00:18:10.830 --> 00:18:14.956
Well you can see it right here, lpstat.

343
00:18:14.956 --> 00:18:18.271
All right, now, when I printed,
I used the LP command, and

344
00:18:18.271 --> 00:18:22.190
I had to do dash p to tell it which
printer I wanted to print to.

345
00:18:22.190 --> 00:18:26.685
Well, you can set a default printer,
all you have to do is set a variable.

346
00:18:26.685 --> 00:18:28.975
There is a session
variable you can define.

347
00:18:28.975 --> 00:18:33.655
It's called the LPDEST, or
line printer destination, and

348
00:18:33.655 --> 00:18:36.125
you can set that to who you want
your default printer to be.

349
00:18:36.125 --> 00:18:40.895
So for example, LPDEST equals and
then what your printer is, so

350
00:18:40.895 --> 00:18:42.075
I might say Canon7065.

351
00:18:43.520 --> 00:18:46.788
All right, if I do that,

352
00:18:46.788 --> 00:18:52.310
now, LP dest, oop dollar signs.

353
00:18:52.310 --> 00:18:56.560
There we go, you can see my
variable is storing that Canon 65.

354
00:18:56.560 --> 00:18:57.670
Now when I print,

355
00:18:57.670 --> 00:19:01.670
if I leave out that dash p I'll just
automatically print to that one.

356
00:19:01.670 --> 00:19:03.800
So you can put that in
your bashrc file and

357
00:19:03.800 --> 00:19:08.100
that way every time you boot up you'll
have that default printer already defined.

358
00:19:08.100 --> 00:19:10.940
If you've got a graphical user interface,
a lot of this stuff is taken care of

359
00:19:10.940 --> 00:19:14.220
from there, but on the exam they
want you to know the CLI sign right?

360
00:19:14.220 --> 00:19:16.450
Doing it from the command line,
so we know it's always there,

361
00:19:16.450 --> 00:19:18.790
even if we don't have a graphical
user interface installed.

362
00:19:21.040 --> 00:19:24.540
All right,
the other thing to remember is, well,

363
00:19:24.540 --> 00:19:27.300
I've got a print job that's
kinda just sitting there.

364
00:19:27.300 --> 00:19:29.160
Well, you can cancel print jobs too.

365
00:19:29.160 --> 00:19:33.330
We had lp to create a print job,
lpstat to view the status, and

366
00:19:33.330 --> 00:19:36.730
you have cancel to kill a print job,
right?

367
00:19:36.730 --> 00:19:40.150
So if we take a look at the cancel
command, you'll see where you

368
00:19:40.150 --> 00:19:44.520
can cancel jobs and you can specify
that print job to kill off and stop it.

369
00:19:45.810 --> 00:19:50.100
The commands that I've been showing you,
those are really just the Linux

370
00:19:50.100 --> 00:19:54.760
commands which are based off of Unix
system 5, the SysV commands, right?

371
00:19:54.760 --> 00:19:57.430
But because Apple created
a lot of this stuff and

372
00:19:57.430 --> 00:20:00.870
they were basing it on BSD,
they used BSD commands.

373
00:20:00.870 --> 00:20:06.020
And so most Linux distros will
actually take both the Unix version,

374
00:20:06.020 --> 00:20:09.520
the SysV command and the BSD commands.

375
00:20:09.520 --> 00:20:12.910
So, I don't know if it'll show up on
the exam, but I just wanna mention it for

376
00:20:12.910 --> 00:20:15.940
your own benefit here,
these alternate version.

377
00:20:15.940 --> 00:20:19.634
So for example, lp is what I use to print,
that's the sysv command.

378
00:20:19.634 --> 00:20:22.045
In BSD, it's lpr.

379
00:20:22.045 --> 00:20:27.600
All right, LPR is what prints and
if I do like a man lp,

380
00:20:27.600 --> 00:20:32.580
right and I see it prints files in
man LPR, it prints files, right?

381
00:20:32.580 --> 00:20:37.100
So it's actually kind of
doing the same thing, right?

382
00:20:37.100 --> 00:20:40.980
So the command is defined lpr but

383
00:20:40.980 --> 00:20:46.320
it's working just like lp, so they kind
of put in both sets of commands for us.

384
00:20:46.320 --> 00:20:49.620
So the BSD equivalent of lp is LPR.

385
00:20:49.620 --> 00:20:55.190
The bsd equivalent of lpstat, for
viewing your print jobs, is lpq, right?

386
00:20:55.190 --> 00:21:00.060
Which is the line printer queue,
versus the line printer status, and

387
00:21:00.060 --> 00:21:03.600
it will do that same thing,
as far as showing us what's sitting there.

388
00:21:03.600 --> 00:21:07.090
As you can see, I've got that one job
that's stuck, kinda sitting there,

389
00:21:07.090 --> 00:21:11.840
job number 5, and so I can cancel out
job number 5, if I wanted and delete it.

390
00:21:11.840 --> 00:21:16.200
And the cancel command, the BSD
equivalent of the cancel command is lprm,

391
00:21:17.820 --> 00:21:20.750
remove the job from the line printer,
right?

392
00:21:20.750 --> 00:21:25.730
Lprm will do that, and so
we can come in and knockout job five and

393
00:21:25.730 --> 00:21:28.640
now when I look at my queue,
it's gone and empty.

394
00:21:28.640 --> 00:21:31.610
So you can define these things
pretty easily to get in there and

395
00:21:31.610 --> 00:21:34.450
manipulate the job to kind of seem them,
work with them, and so on.

396
00:21:34.450 --> 00:21:36.370
There's just two sets of commands right?

397
00:21:36.370 --> 00:21:38.190
And I'll put these in the show notes so
you'll have them.

398
00:21:38.190 --> 00:21:41.400
I don't know if the BSD equivalents
will show up on the exam but they might.

399
00:21:41.400 --> 00:21:43.990
They are there but the sysV equivalent, or

400
00:21:43.990 --> 00:21:46.320
the sysV commands are the ones
we really need to know.

401
00:21:47.420 --> 00:21:49.920
All right, well I think that
sums it up pretty nicely there.

402
00:21:49.920 --> 00:21:52.651
We got a chance to see
setting up a printer, right?

403
00:21:52.651 --> 00:21:55.630
Loading a PPD, getting it published,
getting the CUPS service up and

404
00:21:55.630 --> 00:21:58.030
running, and
then sending some print jobs at it.

405
00:21:58.030 --> 00:22:00.580
It's really not a big deal to
get printing up and going.

406
00:22:00.580 --> 00:22:03.050
It's so
much easier now than it used to be.

407
00:22:03.050 --> 00:22:05.030
It used to be a nightmare to
set this up under Linux, so

408
00:22:05.030 --> 00:22:09.820
the CUPS system really did make
that a lot more convenient for us.

409
00:22:09.820 --> 00:22:10.740
So be appreciative,

410
00:22:10.740 --> 00:22:14.750
and even if you hate Apple, here's at
least one thing you can thank them for.

411
00:22:14.750 --> 00:22:18.302
CUPS really did revolutionized
printing on the Unix and Linux.

412
00:22:18.302 --> 00:22:19.620
All right,
well I hope you guys enjoyed the show.

413
00:22:19.620 --> 00:22:23.327
Stay tuned,
we've got more Linux content coming up.

414
00:22:23.327 --> 00:22:29.430
[MUSIC]

episodes.title: Security Administration
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.012 --> 00:00:13.391
>> All right, good morning,
good afternoon, and good evening.

3
00:00:13.391 --> 00:00:15.670
Welcome back to another
episode of ITProTV.

4
00:00:15.670 --> 00:00:21.170
I'm your host Don Pezet, back with
another episode of Comptia LINUX+.

5
00:00:21.170 --> 00:00:25.200
Now in this episode, we're gonna be
diving into security administration.

6
00:00:25.200 --> 00:00:28.830
And let me tell you guys,
when you bring up a new LINUX server and

7
00:00:28.830 --> 00:00:30.300
you chuck it onto the internet,

8
00:00:30.300 --> 00:00:33.490
expose it to the public,
there's a lot of risk that's there.

9
00:00:33.490 --> 00:00:36.370
But even if it's not exposed to
the public, even if it's an internal only

10
00:00:36.370 --> 00:00:40.310
server, there's a lot of risk just
amongst your own internal employees.

11
00:00:40.310 --> 00:00:44.570
So there's certain steps that we should go
through to harden and protect our servers,

12
00:00:44.570 --> 00:00:47.250
and that's what we're
gonna see in this episode.

13
00:00:47.250 --> 00:00:49.080
Every distro is a little bit different.

14
00:00:49.080 --> 00:00:51.010
Some of them come with
different security sub-layers,

15
00:00:51.010 --> 00:00:52.710
some of them come with
different firewalls.

16
00:00:52.710 --> 00:00:56.230
So definitely take advantage of what
each individual distro offers, right?

17
00:00:56.230 --> 00:00:58.030
That's why they offer that stuff,

18
00:00:58.030 --> 00:01:02.930
but there's a common set of things
that we can do on any Linux system,

19
00:01:02.930 --> 00:01:05.750
and you really need to be
familiar with those for the exam.

20
00:01:05.750 --> 00:01:08.640
And that's what we're gonna be looking
at right here some of those basic things

21
00:01:08.640 --> 00:01:09.430
that we need to tackle.

22
00:01:09.430 --> 00:01:13.500
Now I've got my notes here I know what I
wanna cover, I'm pretty sure I can't do

23
00:01:13.500 --> 00:01:18.260
it in 30 minutes so don't be surprised if
we go into a multi-part series on this.

24
00:01:18.260 --> 00:01:20.350
It's that important,
I don't wanna skip out on anything.

25
00:01:20.350 --> 00:01:23.920
I don't wanna cover anything too briefly
cuz this is really kinda critical stuff.

26
00:01:23.920 --> 00:01:27.300
So we're gonna take our time and we're
gonna go through each of these options and

27
00:01:27.300 --> 00:01:31.790
really get a chance to see stuff that you
should be doing on every system, desktops

28
00:01:31.790 --> 00:01:35.040
too, but definitely on your servers to
make sure that they're protected and

29
00:01:35.040 --> 00:01:37.150
that you're not leaving yourself
open to vulnerabilities.

30
00:01:38.430 --> 00:01:40.930
All right, now the very first
thing that I want to talk about

31
00:01:40.930 --> 00:01:44.280
is a really misunderstood file permission.

32
00:01:44.280 --> 00:01:48.400
There is a file permission,
well what do I mean file permissions?

33
00:01:48.400 --> 00:01:52.560
Well, in Linux, when we look at files,
everything in Linux is a file.

34
00:01:52.560 --> 00:01:54.480
Let's take a look at my laptop here.

35
00:01:54.480 --> 00:01:57.480
So everything in Linux
is treated as a file.

36
00:01:57.480 --> 00:02:00.610
Like if we go into /dev,
And poke around in there.

37
00:02:00.610 --> 00:02:01.840
There's all my hardware.

38
00:02:01.840 --> 00:02:06.050
My CPU, my hard drive, my terminal
interfaces, all defined as a file.

39
00:02:06.050 --> 00:02:10.200
And then we browse around our file, you've
got things like your home directory,

40
00:02:10.200 --> 00:02:11.965
where you've got all your
various files there too.

41
00:02:11.965 --> 00:02:15.910
They're files and they have permissions
and we covered permissions in another

42
00:02:15.910 --> 00:02:18.550
episode, you guys have probably
watched it already and so

43
00:02:18.550 --> 00:02:23.870
your used to seeing these kind of letters
and stuff over her to the left side.

44
00:02:23.870 --> 00:02:27.050
The first of which represents
whether it's a directory or not and

45
00:02:27.050 --> 00:02:31.990
then you've got read, write, and
execute permissions for the owner.

46
00:02:31.990 --> 00:02:35.690
You've got read, write, and
execute permissions for the group.

47
00:02:35.690 --> 00:02:40.210
And then you've got read, write, and
execute permissions for everybody else.

48
00:02:40.210 --> 00:02:42.900
So if I'm the owner of the file,
I might get one set of permissions.

49
00:02:42.900 --> 00:02:46.570
If I'm the group attached to the file, I
might get a different set of permissions,

50
00:02:46.570 --> 00:02:50.460
and if I'm anybody else,
then I get a third set of permissions.

51
00:02:50.460 --> 00:02:53.650
And you can see the owner and
the group right here.

52
00:02:54.860 --> 00:02:58.710
So normally we expect to see rwx rwx rwx.

53
00:02:58.710 --> 00:03:01.520
That's what I expect to see.

54
00:03:01.520 --> 00:03:06.240
But sometimes, we can see something
a little bit different, right?

55
00:03:07.320 --> 00:03:09.350
Like with the Pass WD command.

56
00:03:09.350 --> 00:03:13.560
Now Pass WD, if you remember that
from the user account episode,

57
00:03:13.560 --> 00:03:15.840
that's the command we use
to set people's passwords.

58
00:03:15.840 --> 00:03:18.010
If I want to reset a user's password.

59
00:03:18.010 --> 00:03:21.650
And it's located in /USR/Bin.

60
00:03:21.650 --> 00:03:26.830
And if I take a look at
the permissions for it,

61
00:03:26.830 --> 00:03:30.920
look at the permissions, rwsr-xr-x.

62
00:03:30.920 --> 00:03:34.700
What the heck is that s right there?

63
00:03:34.700 --> 00:03:40.640
There's a special permission
that's called set UID or set GID.

64
00:03:42.240 --> 00:03:47.930
When you run a program, when you run
any program, you run it as yourself.

65
00:03:47.930 --> 00:03:51.440
And you run it as whatever
your default group is.

66
00:03:51.440 --> 00:03:57.770
So when I run something, my user account
is dpezet, and my default group is dpezet.

67
00:03:57.770 --> 00:04:01.650
So when I run a program, that's the user
and group that I run it as, and

68
00:04:01.650 --> 00:04:03.950
it runs with whatever permissions
are associated with that.

69
00:04:05.100 --> 00:04:08.730
But what if you have a program

70
00:04:08.730 --> 00:04:13.910
that you want other people to run
as if they were somebody else?

71
00:04:13.910 --> 00:04:16.280
If you want them to
impersonate somebody else.

72
00:04:16.280 --> 00:04:19.170
Well we've got a command like

00:16:23.100 --> 00:16:26.610
But again, we need to be sure
of what our system is open and

296
00:16:26.610 --> 00:16:28.840
doing and kinda get an eye on that.

297
00:16:28.840 --> 00:16:33.750
Now, when I did netstat -tp,
it didn't show ssh on my list.

298
00:16:33.750 --> 00:16:37.180
So I'm gonna rerun that as netstat -atp.

299
00:16:37.180 --> 00:16:38.250
There we go.

300
00:16:38.250 --> 00:16:42.440
So -tp is showing me
my active connections.

301
00:16:43.470 --> 00:16:46.390
I'm listening on ssh, but it's not
active so it didn't make the list.

302
00:16:46.390 --> 00:16:49.340
So when I do -atp,
now I'll see those other things.

303
00:16:49.340 --> 00:16:51.085
And so I can see ssh, right there.

304
00:16:51.085 --> 00:16:53.570
I'm listening on ssh.

305
00:16:53.570 --> 00:16:57.131
So if I see that I've got port 1028 open,
for whatever reason,

306
00:16:57.131 --> 00:16:58.641
it would be here in the list.

307
00:16:58.641 --> 00:17:01.150
And now I'd be able to see
the program name that was tied to it.

308
00:17:01.150 --> 00:17:02.649
So another great way to track that down.

309
00:17:02.649 --> 00:17:06.680
So that was just netstat -atp
to get even the idle ones.

310
00:17:08.280 --> 00:17:12.710
All right, so
that's kind of a good example.

311
00:17:12.710 --> 00:17:18.623
The nmap command that I ran, when I ran
that, I just ran like nmap.10.1.10.4 here.

312
00:17:18.623 --> 00:17:21.000
And it scanned it, and
it kinda listed that out.

313
00:17:21.000 --> 00:17:24.420
There's a number of different
subcommands you can issue to nmap.

314
00:17:24.420 --> 00:17:27.500
If you ever read a command file,
it's got a ton of information in there.

315
00:17:27.500 --> 00:17:30.930
You can scan entire networks,
you can do deep scans.

316
00:17:30.930 --> 00:17:33.550
Usually I don't do too much
in the way of variation.

317
00:17:33.550 --> 00:17:35.123
I might do like a -v.

318
00:17:35.123 --> 00:17:38.332
A -v tells it really just to hit
some of the well known ports, and

319
00:17:38.332 --> 00:17:40.243
that makes it run a little bit faster.

320
00:17:40.243 --> 00:17:43.657
But you'll see on my system it ran
in basically the same time, right?

321
00:17:43.657 --> 00:17:48.480
I had 0.26 seconds on that one,
versus when I ran it a moment ago.

322
00:17:48.480 --> 00:17:50.780
Actually, it ran faster last time.

323
00:17:50.780 --> 00:17:52.920
So that really didn't seem to help,
did it?

324
00:17:52.920 --> 00:17:56.510
Yeah, well anyhow,
sometimes that'll give you a faster scan.

325
00:17:56.510 --> 00:18:00.070
In my case, it actually made things worse.

326
00:18:00.070 --> 00:18:01.570
So you can do that.

327
00:18:01.570 --> 00:18:05.480
Various changes you can make to nmap,
but just use it as a quick scanner.

328
00:18:05.480 --> 00:18:06.960
Again, run it from your laptop or

329
00:18:06.960 --> 00:18:09.170
desktop, it'll give you an idea
of your server's listening on.

330
00:18:11.080 --> 00:18:13.200
All right,
few other things that we can do.

331
00:18:13.200 --> 00:18:18.510
Let's say that we've got a user,
or we just notice on our system

332
00:18:18.510 --> 00:18:22.370
that resource utilization is way
higher than it should be, right.

333
00:18:22.370 --> 00:18:25.120
Somebody calls in and says, hey Don,
this server is running slow, and

334
00:18:25.120 --> 00:18:26.390
I don't know why.

335
00:18:26.390 --> 00:18:28.150
And you go and you look,
and you start diagnosing.

336
00:18:28.150 --> 00:18:29.160
You do troubleshooting, right.

337
00:18:29.160 --> 00:18:31.860
You connect into your server,
and you run a command like top.

338
00:18:31.860 --> 00:18:33.740
Right, let me run the top command.

339
00:18:33.740 --> 00:18:36.427
So if I run top,
it's gonna show me my processes.

340
00:18:36.427 --> 00:18:39.907
And I can start to see who is
consuming resources on my system, and

341
00:18:39.907 --> 00:18:40.867
I can look at CPU.

342
00:18:40.867 --> 00:18:42.710
And let's say we look at it in there,
dpezet.

343
00:18:42.710 --> 00:18:45.470
See how dpezet just jumped
up that gnome-terminal?

344
00:18:45.470 --> 00:18:47.458
And sure, it's only 1% of the CPU,
big deal.

345
00:18:47.458 --> 00:18:50.840
But let's say it was 99% or 100%.

346
00:18:50.840 --> 00:18:52.910
I'm pegging out the CPU.

347
00:18:52.910 --> 00:18:55.170
And other users are calling in and
complaining, like, hey,

348
00:18:55.170 --> 00:18:57.340
somebody's driving this system nuts.

349
00:18:57.340 --> 00:19:00.110
Well, it might be good, it might be bad.

350
00:19:00.110 --> 00:19:01.480
We don't necessarily know at this point,
or

351
00:19:01.480 --> 00:19:03.290
you might,
you might be aware of it, right?

352
00:19:03.290 --> 00:19:04.705
If you're aware of it,
you might choose to ignore it.

353
00:19:04.705 --> 00:19:06.122
But if you're not aware of it,

354
00:19:06.122 --> 00:19:09.948
you might want to throttle that user while
you figure out what's going on, right?

355
00:19:09.948 --> 00:19:12.230
Why are they pegging out 100% of the CPU?

356
00:19:12.230 --> 00:19:13.570
Should they be doing that?

357
00:19:13.570 --> 00:19:16.060
We might want to impose limits.

358
00:19:16.060 --> 00:19:21.030
Now, limits, we didn't really use those,
or we don't really use those today.

359
00:19:21.030 --> 00:19:23.230
Back in the day, we used limits a lot.

360
00:19:23.230 --> 00:19:25.522
You might remember if you've
been in computers a while,

361
00:19:25.522 --> 00:19:28.387
if you've been using the Internet a while,
back in the dial-up days,

362
00:19:28.387 --> 00:19:30.365
you'd sign up for
a dial-up Internet account.

363
00:19:30.365 --> 00:19:35.530
And they'd say, you get 100 minutes
of Internet access per month.

364
00:19:35.530 --> 00:19:37.010
Well how did they track that?

365
00:19:37.010 --> 00:19:39.422
Well they use radius accounting and
limits.

366
00:19:39.422 --> 00:19:42.230
And when you'd connect into a shared
system to get that Internet access,

367
00:19:42.230 --> 00:19:44.670
you'd share that system
with 1,000 other users.

368
00:19:44.670 --> 00:19:47.078
How do they make sure that one
person didn't monopolize the system?

369
00:19:47.078 --> 00:19:48.900
They used limits.

370
00:19:48.900 --> 00:19:53.970
We can define limits, how much CPU, how
much memory a user is allowed to consume.

371
00:19:53.970 --> 00:19:57.450
And that stops one person
from hogging the system.

372
00:19:57.450 --> 00:19:59.050
And there's two ways we can do it.

373
00:19:59.050 --> 00:20:01.300
We can do it as a on-the-spot thing,
right?

374
00:20:01.300 --> 00:20:02.520
I see a user consuming too much.

375
00:20:02.520 --> 00:20:06.490
I can throttle that user,
right, just a one time thing.

376
00:20:06.490 --> 00:20:10.910
Or we can actually build the limits into
our system so that they're always there.

377
00:20:10.910 --> 00:20:14.170
So that those users aren't able to
consume more resources than necessary.

378
00:20:14.170 --> 00:20:17.910
So when we're starting to evaluate
our system, it's running slow, why?

379
00:20:17.910 --> 00:20:18.598
Here's this user,

380
00:20:18.598 --> 00:20:20.868
I don't want to stop what they're
doing because it might be good.

381
00:20:20.868 --> 00:20:24.260
I just want to limit them so
I can work within the system, right?

382
00:20:24.260 --> 00:20:25.931
That's where these limits come in.

383
00:20:25.931 --> 00:20:30.747
So for that in the Linux kernel,
we actually have this tie in that we

384
00:20:30.747 --> 00:20:35.403
can use called ulimit that let's
us go in and apply user limits.

385
00:20:35.403 --> 00:20:37.920
Let me show you how that works.

386
00:20:37.920 --> 00:20:42.228
ulimit is the command, an oop,
it doesn't have a normal help.

387
00:20:42.228 --> 00:20:45.268
Well anyhow, so
if you take a look at ulimit,

388
00:20:45.268 --> 00:20:47.757
it has a ton of different functions.

389
00:20:47.757 --> 00:20:50.333
And when I run the ulimit and
I pull its man page,

390
00:20:50.333 --> 00:20:52.539
see how I'm getting the BASH BUILTINS.

391
00:20:52.539 --> 00:20:55.693
ulimit is actually a part
of the BASH shell.

392
00:20:55.693 --> 00:20:58.853
And when these users are coming in and
launching their shells,

393
00:20:58.853 --> 00:21:01.666
its BASH is actually applying
those limitations to it.

394
00:21:01.666 --> 00:21:05.702
And so it's got a ton of
functionality buried in here if I dug

395
00:21:05.702 --> 00:21:08.064
through this help file to find it.

396
00:21:08.064 --> 00:21:11.268
There we go, ulimit, and here's all
the different options that we can specify.

397
00:21:11.268 --> 00:21:16.218
Maximum socket buffer, maximum size of
core files, maximum size of a process

398
00:21:16.218 --> 00:21:21.250
data segment, and it goes on and on and
on where we can limit so much stuff.

399
00:21:21.250 --> 00:21:25.410
Limit the amount of threads they run,
limit the amount of cpu time in seconds.

400
00:21:25.410 --> 00:21:27.620
You could really go crazy with this stuff.

401
00:21:27.620 --> 00:21:31.120
And stop users from monopolizing
the system, all right.

402
00:21:31.120 --> 00:21:37.870
Now if we do ulimit and do like
a ulimit -a, you'll see right here.

403
00:21:37.870 --> 00:21:39.870
All current limits are reported.

404
00:21:39.870 --> 00:21:42.370
That's gonna show us
the limits that we have,

405
00:21:42.370 --> 00:21:45.020
and normally we don't really have limits.

406
00:21:45.020 --> 00:21:49.916
And so notice what I've got here as I look
at core, data, scheduling, files by size,

407
00:21:49.916 --> 00:21:51.676
open file, cpu time, right?

408
00:21:51.676 --> 00:21:55.223
cpu time is normally the one we
care about, and if you look at it,

409
00:21:55.223 --> 00:21:57.480
it's set to unlimited.

410
00:21:57.480 --> 00:22:01.290
So you could do a ulimit -t and
specify a limit,

411
00:22:01.290 --> 00:22:06.900
and now you'd tie down the amount of CPU
utilization that each user can generate.

412
00:22:06.900 --> 00:22:08.030
And you can specify other things too,

413
00:22:08.030 --> 00:22:11.870
like virtual memory, the maximum amount of
memory each user is allowed to consume.

414
00:22:11.870 --> 00:22:14.190
And that kind of creates that ceiling,
right?

415
00:22:14.190 --> 00:22:15.830
You just have to be
careful with it though,

416
00:22:15.830 --> 00:22:17.480
because sometimes it's legitimate use.

417
00:22:17.480 --> 00:22:20.930
You want your users to be able to
have the resources when they need it.

418
00:22:20.930 --> 00:22:22.754
And most of the time, users spike, right.

419
00:22:22.754 --> 00:22:25.484
They spike and consume the resources for
a moment, and then it drops down.

420
00:22:25.484 --> 00:22:27.970
So we don't need like a long-term limit.

421
00:22:27.970 --> 00:22:31.950
We can just apply it temporarily or
something.

422
00:22:31.950 --> 00:22:35.200
Or we can ignore it and just,
the users spike, and then it's done.

423
00:22:35.200 --> 00:22:37.320
And we just move on, right.

424
00:22:37.320 --> 00:22:39.980
Be careful of the ulimit command
though because it's not persistent.

425
00:22:39.980 --> 00:22:43.840
If we start defining limits here,
ulimit -t, whatever and

426
00:22:43.840 --> 00:22:45.810
we reboot, we lose those limits.

427
00:22:45.810 --> 00:22:47.699
So if you want the limits
to be persistent,

428
00:22:47.699 --> 00:22:49.539
you need to store them in your etc folder.

429
00:22:49.539 --> 00:22:50.700
And let me show you.

430
00:22:50.700 --> 00:22:53.200
I don't know if I actually
have a limit file on here.

431
00:22:53.200 --> 00:22:57.500
But if you go into /etc/security,

432
00:22:57.500 --> 00:23:01.090
you'll have a file in here
called limits.conf, there it is.

433
00:23:01.090 --> 00:23:02.650
So I have the configuration file.

434
00:23:02.650 --> 00:23:05.400
It might not be there for you,
if it's not there, you just create it.

435
00:23:05.400 --> 00:23:06.998
And then you can start to
put your limits in there.

436
00:23:06.998 --> 00:23:11.725
So it's /etc/security/limits.conf.

437
00:23:11.725 --> 00:23:16.523
And if I edit that file and
take a look in here, you'll see it's

438
00:23:16.523 --> 00:23:21.791
pretty well documented, and
you can specify the limits right here.

439
00:23:21.791 --> 00:23:24.778
And the nice part about this
is it'll be persistent.

440
00:23:24.778 --> 00:23:27.630
It'll stay past a reboot, all right.

441
00:23:27.630 --> 00:23:30.440
Now, when you define these,
notice how they're defined.

442
00:23:30.440 --> 00:23:34.580
You can do a * or a username, okay.

443
00:23:34.580 --> 00:23:36.630
If you do a username, or a group name,

444
00:23:36.630 --> 00:23:39.140
for that matter, then it's going
to apply just to that person.

445
00:23:39.140 --> 00:23:41.290
Notice how some of these
start with an @ symbol?

446
00:23:41.290 --> 00:23:43.640
And some start without an @ symbol,
all right.

447
00:23:43.640 --> 00:23:48.350
This one says ftp,
it's applying to a user named ftp.

448
00:23:48.350 --> 00:23:50.000
This one says @student.

449
00:23:50.000 --> 00:23:53.460
That's applying to a group
called students, all right.

450
00:23:53.460 --> 00:23:54.890
And then you can see the limit.

451
00:23:54.890 --> 00:23:59.430
They've got a hard limit for students,
for the number of processes at 20.

452
00:23:59.430 --> 00:24:03.570
A student can only run 20 simultaneous
processes, and it's a hard limit.

453
00:24:03.570 --> 00:24:06.030
So if they try and
run a 21st one, it'll stop it.

454
00:24:06.030 --> 00:24:08.210
They're limited at 20 processes.

455
00:24:08.210 --> 00:24:11.460
Versus their faculty
has a soft limit of 20.

456
00:24:11.460 --> 00:24:14.280
If they run 21, it lets them run it.

457
00:24:14.280 --> 00:24:15.730
But it sets off a little alert.

458
00:24:15.730 --> 00:24:18.430
We see an alert get triggered,
a SYSLOG message.

459
00:24:18.430 --> 00:24:21.220
So we're aware that that
staff user generates more.

460
00:24:21.220 --> 00:24:23.970
And then they've got a hard
limit defined of 50.

461
00:24:23.970 --> 00:24:27.170
When they get to that 51st process,
it won't run.

462
00:24:27.170 --> 00:24:29.010
So we can define that as *.

463
00:24:29.010 --> 00:24:30.620
It applies to everybody.

464
00:24:30.620 --> 00:24:34.160
Or we can do it as @student or
@ whatever when it applies to group.

465
00:24:34.160 --> 00:24:36.290
Or just a name, and it applies to a user.

466
00:24:36.290 --> 00:24:40.142
And it can be a hard or a soft limit,
much like our disk quotas for storage,

467
00:24:40.142 --> 00:24:40.772
all right?

468
00:24:40.772 --> 00:24:43.750
But you put those things in here,
and now when those users connect,

469
00:24:43.750 --> 00:24:45.276
they'll always have that limit.

470
00:24:45.276 --> 00:24:48.307
And if our server reboots,
it'll be preserved, all right?

471
00:24:48.307 --> 00:24:52.410
Now, you might ask yourself,
why is this in the security section?

472
00:24:52.410 --> 00:24:54.890
Well, think about denial
of service attacks.

473
00:24:54.890 --> 00:24:57.714
Most people think of denial of service
attacks as coming from the network.

474
00:24:57.714 --> 00:25:01.228
But just as easily a user
could be on the system and

475
00:25:01.228 --> 00:25:05.707
start monopolizing CPU and
generating a denial service act.

476
00:25:05.707 --> 00:25:09.249
Other users can't work cuz
they're consuming CPU.

477
00:25:09.249 --> 00:25:11.596
So putting these limits in place
is a great way to limit that.

478
00:25:11.596 --> 00:25:13.657
Now, if you don't have
end users in your system,

479
00:25:13.657 --> 00:25:17.145
if it's a true server and they're just
accessing the various processes remotely,

480
00:25:17.145 --> 00:25:18.635
then you don't need these limits.

481
00:25:18.635 --> 00:25:20.940
And that's why a lot of
people don't use them.

482
00:25:20.940 --> 00:25:25.410
But if this is a terminal, if users are
connecting, these limits are a great way

483
00:25:25.410 --> 00:25:29.230
to make sure that they play nice
with the other users, all right?

484
00:25:29.230 --> 00:25:33.894
So those are the limits,
/etc/security/limits.conf.

485
00:25:33.894 --> 00:25:34.730
Remember that file location.

486
00:25:36.570 --> 00:25:40.380
All right, I've got a lot of other
things that I want to talk about,

487
00:25:40.380 --> 00:25:42.440
but I'm kind of out of
time on this segment.

488
00:25:42.440 --> 00:25:45.060
So, this is a good spot for
us to wrap it up.

489
00:25:45.060 --> 00:25:47.650
Stay tuned, I'm gonna do a part two,
maybe even a part three.

490
00:25:47.650 --> 00:25:49.380
I don't know,
I kind of rambled on a long time.

491
00:25:49.380 --> 00:25:52.510
But we're definitely doing a part two,
cuz I need to talk about the sudo command,

492
00:25:52.510 --> 00:25:55.520
which is probably the most important
command I can teach you guys for

493
00:25:55.520 --> 00:25:56.100
this exam.

494
00:25:56.100 --> 00:25:59.690
We definitely wanna be aware of that
one so I wanna take my time with it.

495
00:25:59.690 --> 00:26:03.100
Stay tuned for that, but for
this episode we'll wrap it up here.

496
00:26:03.100 --> 00:26:04.752
And I'll see you next time.

497
00:26:04.752 --> 00:26:10.670
[SOUND]

WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.142 --> 00:00:13.546
All right, good morning,
good afternoon, and good evening.

3
00:00:13.546 --> 00:00:16.227
And welcome back to another
episode of ITProTV.

4
00:00:16.227 --> 00:00:20.800
I'm your host, Don Pezet, back again
with another episode of Linux plus.

5
00:00:20.800 --> 00:00:25.371
In this episode we're gonna be
continuing with our system security or

6
00:00:25.371 --> 00:00:28.476
administering security
on our system series.

7
00:00:28.476 --> 00:00:32.844
We did one episode already and I talked
too much, we didn't get through it all, so

8
00:00:32.844 --> 00:00:34.198
here we are for part two.

9
00:00:34.198 --> 00:00:37.950
I got a couple of important commands
that we need to cover to be aware of on

10
00:00:37.950 --> 00:00:40.530
the exam, but
also to be aware of in real life.

11
00:00:40.530 --> 00:00:44.000
And the one I'm gonna start of
with today is the sudo command and

12
00:00:44.000 --> 00:00:46.780
it is really, really important.

13
00:00:46.780 --> 00:00:49.440
It's probably the most important command
that we learn out of this whole series for

14
00:00:49.440 --> 00:00:50.260
the exam, and

15
00:00:50.260 --> 00:00:54.000
it's one you'll use most every single
day if you're an administrator.

16
00:00:54.000 --> 00:00:56.820
Well, let's talk a little bit
about what we're worried about,

17
00:00:56.820 --> 00:00:59.483
what our problem is and
how sudo solves it for us.

18
00:00:59.483 --> 00:01:01.190
So we have a little bit of a problem.

19
00:01:01.190 --> 00:01:05.382
When we log into a Linux box, if we
created a user account for ourselves,

20
00:01:05.382 --> 00:01:08.490
it's probably just a regular user account.

21
00:01:08.490 --> 00:01:12.090
And there's things that
a regular user can't do.

22
00:01:12.090 --> 00:01:15.840
So for example, a regular user
can't modify configuration files.

23
00:01:15.840 --> 00:01:17.940
And that can be a real problem.

24
00:01:17.940 --> 00:01:22.010
So if I'm logged in, let's take my machine
here, so I'm logged in as my user.

25
00:01:22.010 --> 00:01:24.615
And if I do a whoami,
I'm logged in as dpezet.

26
00:01:26.140 --> 00:01:28.810
And let's say that I want to go in and

27
00:01:28.810 --> 00:01:33.580
perform something like ifdown eth0,
I want to shut down an interface.

28
00:01:34.800 --> 00:01:37.613
And I get Users cannot
control this device.

29
00:01:37.613 --> 00:01:38.620
I don't have permission.

30
00:01:38.620 --> 00:01:41.755
I'm just a regular old user.

31
00:01:41.755 --> 00:01:44.135
So what can I do?

32
00:01:44.135 --> 00:01:45.899
Well, I can log in as root.

33
00:01:45.899 --> 00:01:49.010
If I log in as the root user,
I can shut that interface down.

34
00:01:49.010 --> 00:01:51.299
And so that's what a lot of people do,
is they open up another window and

35
00:01:51.299 --> 00:01:52.610
they log in as root.

36
00:01:52.610 --> 00:01:58.450
But the problem is if you log in as root,
everything you do runs as root.

37
00:01:58.450 --> 00:02:00.920
So if you're running the X Windows
interface, like I am,

38
00:02:00.920 --> 00:02:04.360
the graphical user interface,
that whole GUI is now running as root, and

39
00:02:04.360 --> 00:02:06.820
every program you run
is now running as root.

40
00:02:06.820 --> 00:02:09.010
And they can all do really bad things.

41
00:02:09.010 --> 00:02:12.469
You fire up Firefox and start browsing
the Internet, you're running as root,

42
00:02:12.469 --> 00:02:14.586
plugins start doing all
sorts of crazy things and

43
00:02:14.586 --> 00:02:17.285
you end up with a system whose
security has been compromised.

44
00:02:17.285 --> 00:02:20.779
So you should never log in as root, ever.

45
00:02:20.779 --> 00:02:24.767
There's never a time where you
should log into a system as root.

46
00:02:24.767 --> 00:02:27.028
Except the very first
time you do an install,

47
00:02:27.028 --> 00:02:29.500
you've got to create your own account.

48
00:02:29.500 --> 00:02:32.080
Now most distros will actually
do that during the installation,

49
00:02:32.080 --> 00:02:33.930
so if you've already got
your own user account,

50
00:02:33.930 --> 00:02:36.330
you literally never should
log in as root on a system.

51
00:02:37.840 --> 00:02:42.780
Instead, there's a few other ways
we can perform these actions

52
00:02:42.780 --> 00:02:44.130
with elevated privileges.

53
00:02:45.240 --> 00:02:48.580
One of the original ways was to
use the super user command su.

54
00:02:49.930 --> 00:02:53.280
su allows you to assume
the identity of another user,

55
00:02:53.280 --> 00:02:56.800
and we most commonly use it with
assuming the identity of the root user.

56
00:02:56.800 --> 00:03:00.770
So here I'm logged in as dpezet.

57
00:03:00.770 --> 00:03:04.350
But if I run su and then leave it blank or

58
00:03:04.350 --> 00:03:09.480
su root, either one,
it's gonna switch me to root.

59
00:03:09.480 --> 00:03:13.250
So if I do that su it's now asking me for
the root user's password and

60
00:03:13.250 --> 00:03:16.370
I can provide that, and
now I'm logged in as root.

61
00:03:16.370 --> 00:03:22.270
See how my prompt changed from
dpezet@dplaptop to root@dplaptop?

62
00:03:22.270 --> 00:03:25.630
And if I do a whoami, I'm now root.

63
00:03:25.630 --> 00:03:31.710
I can now run things like ifdown eth0 and
that interface just went down.

64
00:03:31.710 --> 00:03:36.550
And then I can run ifup and
I'll bring it back up.

65
00:03:36.550 --> 00:03:38.490
Oh, apparently it wasn't down yet.

66
00:03:38.490 --> 00:03:40.150
Oh, no, it came back up, yep.

67
00:03:40.150 --> 00:03:42.530
Verifying the IP address is not in use and
then it's back up.

68
00:03:42.530 --> 00:03:44.950
So now I can perform those actions.

69
00:03:44.950 --> 00:03:48.530
I'm logged in as dpezet,
my graphical user interface is dpezet,

70
00:03:48.530 --> 00:03:50.080
all the other programs I'm running.

71
00:03:50.080 --> 00:03:53.060
But this one shell is now root.

72
00:03:53.060 --> 00:03:55.837
And so I can run that and
I can start to do things.

73
00:03:55.837 --> 00:03:58.148
Now that kind of solves our problem.

74
00:03:58.148 --> 00:03:59.382
And as a root user,

75
00:03:59.382 --> 00:04:04.960
you might want to impersonate another user
to test something, so I could say su jdoe.

76
00:04:04.960 --> 00:04:07.330
I'm gonna assume the identity of John Doe.

77
00:04:07.330 --> 00:04:10.000
And now there I am, I'm John Doe.

78
00:04:10.000 --> 00:04:12.150
As a root user, I'm allowed to do that.

79
00:04:12.150 --> 00:04:13.440
It didn't even ask me for a password.

80
00:04:14.810 --> 00:04:17.510
If I type exit,
I get out of that su instance and

81
00:04:17.510 --> 00:04:20.572
you can see I'm all the way
back to being dpezet now.

82
00:04:20.572 --> 00:04:26.880
And as dpezet if I run su jdoe, I have to
have his password to assume his identity.

83
00:04:26.880 --> 00:04:28.150
A root user doesn't.

84
00:04:28.150 --> 00:04:30.900
But now I can assume Joe's identity and

85
00:04:30.900 --> 00:04:33.930
now I'm running programs as Joe
because I had his password.

86
00:04:35.030 --> 00:04:37.150
So the su command is a pretty
neat way to do that.

87
00:04:37.150 --> 00:04:40.490
The problem is it's easy
to forget you've done it.

88
00:04:40.490 --> 00:04:44.080
When you run su and you get logged in,
you're now in the shell,

89
00:04:44.080 --> 00:04:45.120
you start working.

90
00:04:45.120 --> 00:04:46.390
Maybe you move on and do other things and

91
00:04:46.390 --> 00:04:49.240
you come back here and
you forget that you're logged in as root.

92
00:04:50.280 --> 00:04:52.020
su is kind of a permanent thing.

93
00:04:52.020 --> 00:04:55.900
You stay as the root user
until you exit out of it,

94
00:04:55.900 --> 00:04:57.820
until you actually type the exit
command to get out of it.

95
00:04:59.130 --> 00:05:02.490
Well, most of the times we don't
need to stay as the root user.

96
00:05:02.490 --> 00:05:04.740
We just need to run one
command as the root user.

97
00:05:04.740 --> 00:05:07.050
We just need to temporarily run something.

98
00:05:07.050 --> 00:05:10.620
And that's what the sudo command does.

99
00:05:10.620 --> 00:05:13.480
That means super user do.

100
00:05:13.480 --> 00:05:15.690
Do something as the super user.

101
00:05:15.690 --> 00:05:20.880
I can say sudo followed
by a command like ls, and

102
00:05:20.880 --> 00:05:22.960
it's gonna run just that
command as super user and

103
00:05:22.960 --> 00:05:26.460
then put me right back to who I am,
to my regular user.

104
00:05:27.950 --> 00:05:31.500
The only problem here is, by default,

105
00:05:31.500 --> 00:05:35.460
you probably don't have permission
to run the sudo command.

106
00:05:35.460 --> 00:05:39.700
So for example, if I run sudo ls,
it's gonna ask me for my password,

107
00:05:39.700 --> 00:05:45.245
and I'm gonna provide it, and
I get dpezet is not in the sudoers file.

108
00:05:45.245 --> 00:05:46.910
The incident will be reported.

109
00:05:46.910 --> 00:05:49.010
So it's showing that I tried
to use the sudo command, and

110
00:05:49.010 --> 00:05:49.980
I didn't have permissions.

111
00:05:49.980 --> 00:05:51.166
I put the right password in.

112
00:05:51.166 --> 00:05:52.525
I just don't have permissions.

113
00:05:52.525 --> 00:05:54.297
So if we wanna make use of this,

114
00:05:54.297 --> 00:05:59.090
we need to specifically authorize users or
groups to be able to do the sudo command.

115
00:06:00.090 --> 00:06:01.900
Let me show you how that's done.

116
00:06:01.900 --> 00:06:05.050
It's actually all maintained
in a configuration file.

117
00:06:05.050 --> 00:06:07.060
And so you can go and
edit that configuration file.

118
00:06:07.060 --> 00:06:10.910
You do have to be a root user
to modify that file, though, so

119
00:06:10.910 --> 00:06:13.900
I am gonna have to use the su
command here to take care of that.

120
00:06:13.900 --> 00:06:18.430
So I'll just say su and
switch over to the root user.

121
00:06:18.430 --> 00:06:22.350
Now in some distros you can just go
straight over to where the config file

122
00:06:22.350 --> 00:06:23.350
is and edit it.

123
00:06:23.350 --> 00:06:27.920
In other systems, they actually
have a command called visudo which

124
00:06:27.920 --> 00:06:32.540
pulls up the configuration file in the vi
editor for you and takes you right to it.

125
00:06:32.540 --> 00:06:35.620
You usually want to use this
because some distros protect

126
00:06:35.620 --> 00:06:37.390
the configuration file for sudo.

127
00:06:37.390 --> 00:06:41.020
Obviously it's pretty dangerous and so
they don't want you directly editing it.

128
00:06:41.020 --> 00:06:43.290
So I'm gonna use the visudo command.

129
00:06:43.290 --> 00:06:45.480
And it's just gonna launch vi and
it's modifying the file.

130
00:06:45.480 --> 00:06:49.630
Now notice it's got /etc/sudoers.

131
00:06:49.630 --> 00:06:55.230
That's the file that I would normally go
to, But right now I'm in /etc/sudoers.tmp,

132
00:06:55.230 --> 00:06:56.910
so I'm modifying a temporary
version of that file.

133
00:06:58.200 --> 00:07:01.190
Now the way the file is
structured is pretty simple.

134
00:07:01.190 --> 00:07:02.740
You've got a series of lines.

135
00:07:02.740 --> 00:07:05.900
Well, if you take all these comments
out it's actually almost empty.

136
00:07:05.900 --> 00:07:09.300
And you basically put in here an alias for

137
00:07:09.300 --> 00:07:11.960
who it is that you want
to give permissions to.

138
00:07:11.960 --> 00:07:14.870
And you can be giving permissions
to a user or a group.

139
00:07:16.150 --> 00:07:20.400
So it's up to you how you wanna do this,
specific users or entire groups.

140
00:07:20.400 --> 00:07:25.246
Then you specify what computers they're
allowed to use the sudo command

141
00:07:25.246 --> 00:07:26.923
from when they connect.

142
00:07:26.923 --> 00:07:30.460
Are they only allowed to use sudo when
they're sitting here at this machine?

143
00:07:30.460 --> 00:07:34.130
Or are they allowed to use sudo when
they're remotely connecting via SSH

144
00:07:34.130 --> 00:07:35.130
from another work station?

145
00:07:35.130 --> 00:07:38.030
And if they are,
what work stations do we wanna allow?

146
00:07:38.030 --> 00:07:41.150
So you can get really specific about
how they're allowed to connect

147
00:07:41.150 --> 00:07:41.920
to be able to run sudo.

148
00:07:44.190 --> 00:07:47.034
And then you specify, they don't
show it here in this example but

149
00:07:47.034 --> 00:07:48.545
if we go down a little bit further.

150
00:07:48.545 --> 00:07:52.549
You can specify what commands
they're allowed to run.

151
00:07:52.549 --> 00:07:53.962
You can get really specific.

152
00:07:53.962 --> 00:07:57.459
They're allowed to use sudo but
only for running fdisk.

153
00:07:57.459 --> 00:08:00.374
Or only for running mount or
partprobe, or something like that,

154
00:08:00.374 --> 00:08:04.400
being really specific about what
commands they wanna be able to run.

155
00:08:04.400 --> 00:08:08.600
And then you can specify whether or
not we ask for a password,

156
00:08:08.600 --> 00:08:11.500
which they don't really have
an example in the comment, do they?

157
00:08:11.500 --> 00:08:12.890
Well, I'll add my own.

158
00:08:12.890 --> 00:08:14.360
So you can kind of specify that too.

159
00:08:14.360 --> 00:08:17.040
You can really get detailed
with these sudo commands.

160
00:08:17.040 --> 00:08:21.766
Most people don't dig through the configs
very much because there's a standard

161
00:08:21.766 --> 00:08:25.740
example, which is this example right here,
that most people use.

162
00:08:25.740 --> 00:08:31.505
And what this is saying is we're
gonna give the wheel group,

163
00:08:31.505 --> 00:08:39.079
so anybody in the wheel group, we're gonna
let them log in from any computer and

164
00:08:39.079 --> 00:08:44.980
be able to run all commands as
long as they provide a password.

165
00:08:44.980 --> 00:08:48.396
The sudo command actually came from
the BSD world, and in the BSD world,

166
00:08:48.396 --> 00:08:51.670
they use the wheel group to
define basically administrators.

167
00:08:51.670 --> 00:08:54.760
In the Linux world, we have the wheel
group just for compatibility with BSD,

168
00:08:54.760 --> 00:08:57.680
but we don't actually use it,
so wheel is normally empty.

169
00:08:57.680 --> 00:09:01.540
You can choose to use the wheel group if
you want, kinda keep it BSD-compatible.

170
00:09:01.540 --> 00:09:05.560
Or you can make your own group that you
want to treat as your administrators.

171
00:09:05.560 --> 00:09:07.970
So maybe I create a group called admins,
and

172
00:09:07.970 --> 00:09:11.800
then in here I can define admins as
having the ability to run sudo, and

173
00:09:11.800 --> 00:09:14.380
then that kinda makes them actual admins,
right?

174
00:09:14.380 --> 00:09:17.020
So you can define that however you want.

175
00:09:17.020 --> 00:09:20.600
Now, they've got this NOPASSWD: ALL.

176
00:09:20.600 --> 00:09:25.355
That means that for this group if I turn
this on, they can run every command, and

177
00:09:25.355 --> 00:09:28.240
sudo is not gonna ask them for
their password.

178
00:09:28.240 --> 00:09:31.200
Well, it's usually a good idea to ask for
the password, cuz if

179
00:09:31.200 --> 00:09:34.680
they stay logged in on a machine and they
walk away, and somebody else runs and sits

180
00:09:34.680 --> 00:09:39.080
down on their machine, and runs a sudo,
it's gonna prompt for the password again.

181
00:09:39.080 --> 00:09:42.060
So you kind of effectively stop
that mistake from happening.

182
00:09:42.060 --> 00:09:46.020
Versus if you say NOPASSWD, if somebody
gets up and walks away from the computer,

183
00:09:46.020 --> 00:09:48.970
somebody could run up and start sudoing
commands and it doesn't ask for

184
00:09:48.970 --> 00:09:51.790
their password again, and so
now you're somewhat vulnerable.

185
00:09:52.800 --> 00:09:56.370
So, we can add in specific users,
we can add in particular groups,

186
00:09:56.370 --> 00:09:58.950
you can do all sorts of cool stuff
in here, it's really not a big deal.

187
00:09:58.950 --> 00:10:02.210
Here's the only uncommented
line that I got,

188
00:10:02.210 --> 00:10:06.360
which is the root user is allowed
to connect from any workstation and

189
00:10:06.360 --> 00:10:09.640
run any command, and
it'll just prompt for their password.

190
00:10:09.640 --> 00:10:13.239
So I may wanna come in here and
add to that, dpezet, and

191
00:10:13.239 --> 00:10:17.233
I might wanna allow myself to
log in from any workstation, or

192
00:10:17.233 --> 00:10:20.311
I might even wanna put
in just like local host.

193
00:10:20.311 --> 00:10:22.430
I can only log in from this host.

194
00:10:22.430 --> 00:10:23.650
And I'm gonna allow myself to run ALL.

195
00:10:24.650 --> 00:10:28.210
Or if I create a group,
I might do like a group called admins, and

196
00:10:28.210 --> 00:10:31.200
so I would say %admins.

197
00:10:31.200 --> 00:10:35.470
I'll let them log in from anywhere and
execute all commands.

198
00:10:35.470 --> 00:10:39.140
That's gonna let them
use the sudo command.

199
00:10:39.140 --> 00:10:40.720
And then I just need to save this file.

200
00:10:40.720 --> 00:10:45.770
So it's vi, so I'll hit Escape
:wq to exit and write that.

201
00:10:47.540 --> 00:10:51.220
Now I'm gonna type exit to
get out of my su shell.

202
00:10:51.220 --> 00:10:54.250
So you can see here, I'm just dpezet and

203
00:10:54.250 --> 00:11:00.060
if I do whoami, it says dpezet,
it ran it as me.

204
00:11:00.060 --> 00:11:06.390
If I do sudo whoami, that means run the
whoami command but run it as a superuser.

205
00:11:06.390 --> 00:11:09.840
And it's gonna ask for my password,
and I'm gonna provide that, and

206
00:11:09.840 --> 00:11:11.840
notice who it returned, root.

207
00:11:12.850 --> 00:11:16.360
Now, it asked for my password, and it's
gonna cache that for a brief moment, so

208
00:11:16.360 --> 00:11:19.030
if I run the command again,
see how it didn't ask for it?

209
00:11:19.030 --> 00:11:21.630
But it's got a timer, I don't
remember what it's actually set to,

210
00:11:21.630 --> 00:11:23.610
I think five minutes, where for
the next five minutes,

211
00:11:23.610 --> 00:11:26.958
I can continue to run more commands and
it's not gonna ask for that password.

212
00:11:26.958 --> 00:11:29.610
But once five minutes passes,
then it's gonna start asking for

213
00:11:29.610 --> 00:11:30.540
that password again.

214
00:11:30.540 --> 00:11:33.680
So it's not super-annoying about it,
but it wants to make sure that if you

215
00:11:33.680 --> 00:11:36.570
walk away from your computer that
you're not putting yourself at risk.

216
00:11:36.570 --> 00:11:39.150
Now I can just quickly run one command.

217
00:11:39.150 --> 00:11:42.720
I'm logged in as dpezet, but
I wanna turn that interface off.

218
00:11:42.720 --> 00:11:48.350
So I can say sudo ifdown eth0.

219
00:11:48.350 --> 00:11:53.030
That one command ran as root, and
now I'm back to just being me, and

220
00:11:53.030 --> 00:11:56.300
I don't have to worry about leaving
myself in a root shell or whatever.

221
00:11:56.300 --> 00:11:59.840
When I have a command that needs admin
access, I can run it that way, but

222
00:11:59.840 --> 00:12:02.710
then everything else I'm just
running as my regular user.

223
00:12:02.710 --> 00:12:07.400
Sudo protects you from accidentally
messing up stuff by staying in as root.

224
00:12:07.400 --> 00:12:08.560
It's really, really handy.

225
00:12:09.760 --> 00:12:12.480
So you can use it that way,
and then if I try and

226
00:12:12.480 --> 00:12:18.190
do something like ifup eth0, well,
a regular user can't do that.

227
00:12:18.190 --> 00:12:22.404
I can just add sudo right before it,
and now there it goes coming up, and

228
00:12:22.404 --> 00:12:23.960
the interface is back up.

229
00:12:23.960 --> 00:12:26.880
So that's the sudo command,
really, really handy.

230
00:12:26.880 --> 00:12:31.220
For the exam, remember that you should
be using sudo, definitely want that one.

231
00:12:31.220 --> 00:12:37.000
You also need to remember that we had
to add ourselves to /etc/sudoers,

232
00:12:37.000 --> 00:12:43.710
to that file, S-U-D-O-E-R-S, sudoers, and
we have to add ourselves to that file.

233
00:12:43.710 --> 00:12:46.160
On some distros you can just go and
edit it directly.

234
00:12:46.160 --> 00:12:51.320
On others like this one, you need to
use visudo, V-I-S-U-D-O, to actually go

235
00:12:51.320 --> 00:12:54.740
in there and edit that file, and it's kind
of a security mechanism that it's got.

236
00:12:54.740 --> 00:12:59.540
So, Sudo, it's installed on every
distro that I've touched in the last

237
00:12:59.540 --> 00:13:01.830
probably eight years, so
it's not a new thing.

238
00:13:01.830 --> 00:13:03.060
It's been around a while.

239
00:13:03.060 --> 00:13:05.506
Definitely take advantage of that one.

240
00:13:05.506 --> 00:13:10.302
All right, a couple other things that we
need to be aware of as we harden security

241
00:13:10.302 --> 00:13:11.240
on our system.

242
00:13:12.490 --> 00:13:15.630
Many Linux systems have
the GNU tools installed.

243
00:13:15.630 --> 00:13:18.370
And that's what gives us a lot
of the commands that we use.

244
00:13:18.370 --> 00:13:22.180
In addition to that, you might have
some standard network services,

245
00:13:22.180 --> 00:13:25.930
things like telnet, finger, Archie.

246
00:13:25.930 --> 00:13:28.520
These are protocols that you
might not have ever heard of.

247
00:13:28.520 --> 00:13:32.600
If you're new to computers, if you've
only been in IT for a handful of years,

248
00:13:32.600 --> 00:13:36.790
you've probably never heard of Archie or
Gopher or protocols like that.

249
00:13:36.790 --> 00:13:40.650
But back in the day, back in late 80s,
early 90s, these were very,

250
00:13:40.650 --> 00:13:45.390
very common Internet protocols,
and UNIX had them built in.

251
00:13:45.390 --> 00:13:47.920
Linux is based on UNIX, and as a result,

252
00:13:47.920 --> 00:13:50.730
some distros still have
these services built in.

253
00:13:50.730 --> 00:13:56.290
Now most of them have been moved off to
a special service process called xinetd,

254
00:13:56.290 --> 00:13:59.750
which I think is the extended Internet

00:13:59.750 --> 00:14:00.730
if I remember right.

00:14:00.730 --> 00:14:02.380
But it's xinetd, and

00:14:02.380 --> 00:14:06.010
it adds these services that

258
00:14:06.010 --> 00:14:09.630
And so if you're setting up a new system,
if you're working in a new distro that

259
00:14:09.630 --> 00:14:15.650

to check and see if you're got xinetd.

00:14:15.650 --> 00:14:19.886

00:14:19.886 --> 00:14:22.880

00:14:22.880 --> 00:14:24.100

00:14:24.100 --> 00:14:27.435
But if run CentOS 5 or
Red Hat Enterprise Linux 5 or

264
00:14:27.435 --> 00:14:31.840

265
00:14:31.840 --> 00:14:34.640
So you may have some non-secure
protocols in place, and

00:14:34.640 --> 00:14:35.980

00:14:35.980 --> 00:14:38.800
And that really goes for any service,

00:14:41.080 --> 00:14:43.910

00:14:43.910 --> 00:14:46.455

00:14:46.455 --> 00:14:48.450

00:14:48.450 --> 00:14:52.480
Turn it off, you don't need it,

00:14:52.480 --> 00:14:57.190

00:14:57.190 --> 00:15:02.470

Anything like that.

That guy is the one that

00:15:48.262 --> 00:15:51.860

00:15:53.527 --> 00:15:56.507
The other thing though is,

00:16:02.437 --> 00:16:05.630
So, you install that xinetd,

00:16:08.700 --> 00:16:12.760

00:16:12.760 --> 00:16:17.995
So for example, here I'm gonna,

00:16:17.995 --> 00:16:22.946

All right, so that's gonna install it and

00:16:27.630 --> 00:16:29.880
So I've got that and now I can go and

00:16:29.880 --> 00:16:32.320

00:16:51.470 --> 00:16:57.300

So if I.

Now we can start to take a look

00:17:18.840 --> 00:17:20.790
whether they're turned on or not, right?

00:17:20.790 --> 00:17:22.650
And so as you start to look through here,

00:17:22.650 --> 00:17:25.950
you'll see this one is actually just

00:17:25.950 --> 00:17:28.410
So this one actually is not gonna

00:17:29.730 --> 00:17:32.960
But here we've got the enabled equals and

00:17:32.960 --> 00:17:36.330
And here's where we can specify which

00:17:36.330 --> 00:17:38.770
and which of the services

00:17:38.770 --> 00:17:43.170
And so if you actually need xinetd,

00:17:43.170 --> 00:17:47.070

00:17:47.070 --> 00:17:49.500

00:17:49.500 --> 00:17:51.350
this goes for

00:17:51.350 --> 00:17:54.040
If you add a service to your system,

00:17:54.040 --> 00:17:57.350

00:17:57.350 --> 00:18:00.220

00:18:00.220 --> 00:18:03.442
Giving a hacker less stuff that

00:18:03.442 --> 00:18:05.481
that's a pretty important thing to do.

All right now, if I need to

You hunt down those config files and

00:18:21.730 --> 00:18:26.879

00:18:26.879 --> 00:18:32.151

slash let's see it's slash

00:18:32.151 --> 00:18:39.050
etc slash a command.allow, or

00:18:39.050 --> 00:18:40.650
So look here at my system.

00:18:40.650 --> 00:18:45.460
I've got /etc/hosts.allow, all right?

That's people allowed to use the hosts

00:18:50.914 --> 00:18:55.300
people who are denied the ability

00:18:55.300 --> 00:18:59.230
People denied the ability to use cron or
host, so

00:18:59.230 --> 00:19:03.220
I've got these files that are specifying
who's allowed or denied the ability to use

00:19:03.220 --> 00:19:06.650
a particular command, or a service,
it's really tied to a service.

350
00:19:06.650 --> 00:19:10.580
So that the at and cron,
those run jobs at a scheduled interval, so

351
00:19:10.580 --> 00:19:12.350
that's a service that
runs in the background.

00:19:12.350 --> 00:19:14.960
Host is a service for

353
00:19:14.960 --> 00:19:17.852
So we can restrict
people's access to that.

354
00:19:17.852 --> 00:19:20.670
All right,
now that is kind of an interesting thing,

355
00:19:20.670 --> 00:19:23.360
because it's not a function
of the service itself.

356
00:19:23.360 --> 00:19:28.986
Many services inside of Linux
leverage what are TCP wrappers.

357
00:19:28.986 --> 00:19:30.951
These are TCP wrappers.

358
00:19:30.951 --> 00:19:36.320
When a TCP port is open on your system,
which is what a network service will use.

359
00:19:36.320 --> 00:19:38.730
We can define who's allowed
to use that TCP port.

360
00:19:38.730 --> 00:19:42.270
In other words, who's allowed
to even talk to that service?

361
00:19:42.270 --> 00:19:45.780
And we can leverage these allow and
deny files to define that.

362
00:19:45.780 --> 00:19:48.000
Well, which services support that?

363
00:19:48.000 --> 00:19:49.670
Sometimes it's kinda hard to tell.

364
00:19:49.670 --> 00:19:53.220
When somebody writes a service
all they have to do is include

365
00:19:53.220 --> 00:19:57.050
the TCP wrapper library in that
service and now it supports wrappers.

366
00:19:57.050 --> 00:20:01.100
So technically any developer,
any developer of any software on Linux can

367
00:20:02.530 --> 00:20:05.650
incorporate TCP wrappers just
by simply including the library.

368
00:20:05.650 --> 00:20:09.160
That's all they have to do,
but not every developer does.

369
00:20:09.160 --> 00:20:11.720
They might have their own system for
controlling access.

370
00:20:11.720 --> 00:20:13.135
So like MySQL.

371
00:20:13.135 --> 00:20:15.770
MySQL has it's own way of
setting permissions for

372
00:20:15.770 --> 00:20:18.010
what systems are allowed to connect
to it and which ones aren't.

373
00:20:18.010 --> 00:20:23.200
So it doesn't need TCP wrappers so they
don't include it, but other services do.

374
00:20:23.200 --> 00:20:25.150
If you want to take advantage of these,

375
00:20:25.150 --> 00:20:27.260
you'd be surprised how many
services do support it.

00:20:27.260 --> 00:20:30.070
If you want to find out,

00:20:30.070 --> 00:20:33.310

00:20:33.310 --> 00:20:35.550

00:20:35.550 --> 00:20:40.730
LDD lists your dynamic libraries that
are attached to any particular file.

00:20:40.730 --> 00:20:43.680
So I can take a look at any
service on my system and

00:20:43.680 --> 00:20:47.370
see if it's linking
the TCP wrapper library.

382
00:20:47.370 --> 00:20:47.980
All right?

00:20:47.980 --> 00:20:54.260
The way I normally do it is just
something like LDD /user/sbin/sshd.

00:20:54.260 --> 00:20:57.890
So I wanna pull up a list

00:20:57.890 --> 00:21:02.250
Now I don't see any SSH allow or

00:21:02.250 --> 00:21:06.220
So I don't know if SSH can use it or

00:21:06.220 --> 00:21:08.920
they're gonna be a lot of libraries,
so I'm gonna filter that out a bit.

00:21:08.920 --> 00:21:11.380
I'm just gonna, rep that, there we go.

389
00:21:11.380 --> 00:21:14.520
And I'm gonna look for
the word wrap, right.

390
00:21:14.520 --> 00:21:18.290
And so when it lists the libraries,
sure enough I can see that

391
00:21:18.290 --> 00:21:23.440
the SSH demon that service,
is linking to libwrap, right.

392
00:21:23.440 --> 00:21:26.760
That's the TCP library, libwrap.

393
00:21:26.760 --> 00:21:30.770
Any service that links to that
library you can use these allow and

00:21:30.770 --> 00:21:35.180
deny files to restrict access so
if I wanna restrict access to SSH

00:21:35.180 --> 00:21:38.950
all I need to do is come in and
create an SSHD dot allow or

00:21:38.950 --> 00:21:43.160
SSH dot deny and
that's gonna restrict that access.

00:21:44.860 --> 00:21:49.270
So, for example I might want to
do an allow file, and I go in and

00:21:49.270 --> 00:21:50.790
I start to specify those.

00:21:50.790 --> 00:21:54.650
And you would just basically mirror the

All I have to do is go in here and

00:22:14.020 --> 00:22:20.030

00:22:20.030 --> 00:22:20.790
All right.

00:22:20.790 --> 00:22:24.820
If we want to allow everybody,

00:22:24.820 --> 00:22:28.320
we use the deny file and we just put

00:22:28.320 --> 00:22:31.190
If we want to deny everybody, and

00:22:31.190 --> 00:22:34.220

we use the allow file instead.

00:22:34.220 --> 00:22:35.210
All right.

00:22:35.210 --> 00:22:38.860
And you go in, and then you put it in
there, and then you create a At dot allow,

00:22:38.860 --> 00:22:40.892
and you put just a few people in there.

00:22:40.892 --> 00:22:45.870
All right, be careful though, because

notice my hosts, I've got hosts.allow and

00:23:02.140 --> 00:23:06.020
So, I should probably get rid of one of

00:23:06.020 --> 00:23:07.670

But, that is something to remember is that

00:23:20.670 --> 00:23:25.030

00:23:25.030 --> 00:23:26.690
So use that LDD command.

Use the LDD command,

Maybe I've got HTTPD right,

So, we need to apply that on our own,

00:24:00.840 --> 00:24:02.940

We've got more of that,
definitely stay tuned for it.

472
00:25:35.420 --> 00:25:38.720
But for
this episode we're going to wrap it up.

473
00:25:38.720 --> 00:25:44.813
For ITProTV, I'm Don Pezet,
and I'll see you next time.

1
