2
00:00:10.541 --> 00:00:15.257
All right, greetings everyone, and welcome
to another great episode of ITProTV.

3
00:00:15.257 --> 00:00:19.149
I'm your host Daniel Lowry and here with
me today is the dance master himself Mr.

4
00:00:19.149 --> 00:00:19.740
Don Pezet.

5
00:00:19.740 --> 00:00:20.660
How's it going today, Don?

6
00:00:20.660 --> 00:00:21.590
>> Lord of the dance.

7
00:00:21.590 --> 00:00:23.400
>> That's right.
>> Is my official title.

8
00:00:23.400 --> 00:00:24.200
Welcome back everybody.

9
00:00:24.200 --> 00:00:27.864
Just excited today because we're jumping
back into Linux + which is always

10
00:00:27.864 --> 00:00:28.503
a good time.

11
00:00:28.503 --> 00:00:33.063
In this episode we're going to be
taking a look at GPG, encrypting and

12
00:00:33.063 --> 00:00:35.722
sending and decrypting data using GPG.

13
00:00:35.722 --> 00:00:37.950
Now hat the heck is GPG,.

14
00:00:37.950 --> 00:00:43.400
Well a long time ago in a galaxy far far
away there was a gentleman who said boy,

15
00:00:43.400 --> 00:00:46.100
wouldn't it be nice if I could send
emails and not have people read them

16
00:00:46.100 --> 00:00:49.530
except the people I intend it to be,
I can send private email.

17
00:00:49.530 --> 00:00:52.750
And so
they came up with a utility called PGP,

18
00:00:52.750 --> 00:00:55.670
and PGP stood for pretty good privacy.

19
00:00:55.670 --> 00:00:58.000
And what the program will let you do
is you can put data in there, and

20
00:00:58.000 --> 00:00:59.968
it would encrypt it, and
you could send it to somebody.

21
00:00:59.968 --> 00:01:03.116
And then, lo and behold,
they could receive it, and decrypt it and

22
00:01:03.116 --> 00:01:04.340
actually read the stuff.

23
00:01:04.340 --> 00:01:05.690
It was great right.

24
00:01:05.690 --> 00:01:08.924
But PGP was never really freely available.

25
00:01:08.924 --> 00:01:10.699
The software was always private and

26
00:01:10.699 --> 00:01:14.603
it ended up getting bought by Semantic,
which If you watch enough of my shows,

27
00:01:14.603 --> 00:01:17.643
you know that I think Semantic
is where software goes to die.

28
00:01:17.643 --> 00:01:19.710
And that's exactly what's happened to PGP.

29
00:01:19.710 --> 00:01:25.695
So, instead, we now have GPG,
which is an open-source equivalent to PGP.

30
00:01:25.695 --> 00:01:32.028
GPG stands for GNU Privacy Guard and
it's just an open source version of PGP.

31
00:01:32.028 --> 00:01:36.020
It's software that lets us encrypt data,
send it securely, and

32
00:01:36.020 --> 00:01:37.330
someone on the other end
can decrypt the data.

33
00:01:37.330 --> 00:01:41.580
Now, you might be saying, well why not
just use SSH or something like that?

34
00:01:41.580 --> 00:01:44.746
The nice thing about GPG is you can
encrypt something now while the other

35
00:01:44.746 --> 00:01:46.320
user's not even online.

36
00:01:46.320 --> 00:01:49.320
And you can send it via email and
it can just wait until they go and

37
00:01:49.320 --> 00:01:50.660
check their email and
receive it and then open it.

38
00:01:50.660 --> 00:01:54.310
And so it's a, what'd that be,
like an asynchronous type model.

39
00:01:54.310 --> 00:01:56.610
You don't have to have the two
users connected at the same time.

40
00:01:56.610 --> 00:01:59.075
So that's the nice part about GPG.

41
00:01:59.075 --> 00:02:00.765
And it can encrypt anything.

42
00:02:00.765 --> 00:02:03.365
Any file, text stream, you even copy and

43
00:02:03.365 --> 00:02:05.455
paste right from the clipboard,
you can do all sorts of stuff.

44
00:02:05.455 --> 00:02:08.911
Encrypt the data, and then you know
it's secure and it's protected,

45
00:02:08.911 --> 00:02:11.915
even if you stick it somewhere
like Dropbox or cloud storage.

46
00:02:11.915 --> 00:02:14.235
You know it's safe cuz you encrypted
it before it left your machine.

47
00:02:15.305 --> 00:02:20.380
All right now using GPG is not terribly
difficult, but it does require some setup.

48
00:02:20.380 --> 00:02:22.470
Because there's keys involved.

49
00:02:22.470 --> 00:02:25.220
You have to have a private and
a public key pair.

50
00:02:26.300 --> 00:02:30.550
The private key is capable of
encrypting and decrypting data, but

51
00:02:30.550 --> 00:02:34.430
the public key is only
capable of encrypting data.

52
00:02:34.430 --> 00:02:38.990
So somebody can take data and encrypt it
with a public key, send it to you, and

53
00:02:38.990 --> 00:02:41.310
if you have the private key,
you can decrypt it.

54
00:02:41.310 --> 00:02:45.584
So if Daniel wants to send something
to me secure and encrypted,

55
00:02:45.584 --> 00:02:48.846
I have to generate a private key and
a public key.

56
00:02:48.846 --> 00:02:51.893
I have to send him my public key, and

57
00:02:51.893 --> 00:02:57.390
then he can use my public key to
encrypt the data and send it to me.

58
00:02:57.390 --> 00:02:59.553
Now he can't decrypt data
with that public key.

59
00:02:59.553 --> 00:03:01.616
He can just encrypt it and send it to me.

60
00:03:01.616 --> 00:03:04.360
But when I get it,
I've got the private key.

61
00:03:04.360 --> 00:03:06.449
I can decrypt it and read it.

62
00:03:06.449 --> 00:03:10.420
Now the advantage of this is that my
private key never travels the network.

63
00:03:10.420 --> 00:03:11.547
I've got it, it's just me,

64
00:03:11.547 --> 00:03:13.766
somebody would have to break
into my computer to get at it.

65
00:03:13.766 --> 00:03:16.424
And if they've done that then I've
got bigger problems than whether my

66
00:03:16.424 --> 00:03:17.230
data's encrypted.

67
00:03:18.460 --> 00:03:20.710
So that's kind of where that
private key comes into play.

68
00:03:20.710 --> 00:03:23.560
And the public key,
I can send that out to anybody.

69
00:03:23.560 --> 00:03:26.735
I could put it in my email signature so
that everybody gets my public key.

70
00:03:26.735 --> 00:03:29.108
And I can say if you ever wanna
send something encrypted to me,

71
00:03:29.108 --> 00:03:31.540
here's my public key, just use it,
encrypt it, and send it.

72
00:03:31.540 --> 00:03:32.924
There's plenty of people that do that.

73
00:03:32.924 --> 00:03:37.652
You'll see it in their email signature or
they'll have like a, what are they, VCB,

74
00:03:37.652 --> 00:03:39.634
VCF, the virtual business cards.

75
00:03:39.634 --> 00:03:44.029
They'll have those attached to their email
that has a private, a public key in there.

76
00:03:44.029 --> 00:03:45.635
>> [CROSSTALK] Don't send the private key.

77
00:03:45.635 --> 00:03:48.355
>> Yeah don't bother
sending that person data.

78
00:03:48.355 --> 00:03:50.105
Send them right to the recycle bin.

79
00:03:50.105 --> 00:03:53.775
But so that makes it where people
can securely send data to you.

80
00:03:53.775 --> 00:03:56.880
Now, if Daniel and
I want to send data securely back and

81
00:03:56.880 --> 00:04:01.360
forth between each other, he would need my
public key, I would need his public key.

82
00:04:01.360 --> 00:04:03.160
And that's really the only
challenging part about GPG,

83
00:04:03.160 --> 00:04:05.430
is you have to have that key exchange,
right?

84
00:04:05.430 --> 00:04:08.250
And that's why people put their public
keys in their email signatures so

85
00:04:08.250 --> 00:04:12.330
that everybody out there gets a copy
of it, but it hasn't really caught on.

86
00:04:12.330 --> 00:04:16.238
So a lot of users don't even know
about GPG or PGP or any of it.

87
00:04:16.238 --> 00:04:19.070
So, you gotta kinda educate the users,
do the key exchange.

88
00:04:19.070 --> 00:04:21.140
And once that's done,
it's really powerful.

89
00:04:21.140 --> 00:04:22.307
>> And that's a real shame, right Don?

90
00:04:22.307 --> 00:04:25.290
Because this is some
pretty good encryption.

91
00:04:25.290 --> 00:04:27.490
It is basically them being facetious.

92
00:04:27.490 --> 00:04:28.701
This is good encryption.

93
00:04:28.701 --> 00:04:31.464
This is military,
government grade encryption, right.

94
00:04:31.464 --> 00:04:32.130
>> Yeah.

95
00:04:32.130 --> 00:04:35.709
It's good stuff and it fixes everything
that's wrong with e-mail right.

96
00:04:35.709 --> 00:04:39.018
E-mail, just SMPT in general,
sends things in plain text.

97
00:04:39.018 --> 00:04:43.130
Maybe it's base-64 encoded,
which takes two seconds to decode.

98
00:04:43.130 --> 00:04:46.910
It's just not really secure.

99
00:04:46.910 --> 00:04:49.480
If you encrypt your email now,
it's secure.

100
00:04:49.480 --> 00:04:51.470
And it's not just email,
any kind of file transfer.

101
00:04:51.470 --> 00:04:54.180
You can use regular old ftp,
which is plain text.

102
00:04:54.180 --> 00:04:56.569
But if you've already encrypted
your files, it's safe, right.

103
00:04:56.569 --> 00:04:58.420
So that's kind of a nice thing.

104
00:04:58.420 --> 00:05:00.040
All right, let's see how GPG works.

105
00:05:00.040 --> 00:05:02.090
Step one, we need to install it.

106
00:05:02.090 --> 00:05:04.615
Some distros have it installed already,
some don't right.

107
00:05:04.615 --> 00:05:06.740
If you don't know,
it's easy to just go in and install it.

108
00:05:06.740 --> 00:05:10.060
So here I'll take my system,
this is a CentOS box and

109
00:05:10.060 --> 00:05:14.980
I'm just gonna run gpg and
sure enough it's already installed right.

110
00:05:14.980 --> 00:05:19.420
And when I ran gpg by itself it
actually started its startup wizard.

111
00:05:19.420 --> 00:05:22.700
The startup wizard for
GPG is what's getting it ready for use.

112
00:05:22.700 --> 00:05:23.940
It knows that if you're gonna use it.

113
00:05:23.940 --> 00:05:25.870
It's got to generate a private key and
a public key and

114
00:05:25.870 --> 00:05:27.630
it's starting to kind of do that.

115
00:05:27.630 --> 00:05:32.752
If GPG wasn't installed I could
just do a yum install gpg right?

116
00:05:32.752 --> 00:05:36.070
Or @-get install gpg and
it would install it.

117
00:05:36.070 --> 00:05:38.310
But a lot of distros already have it.

118
00:05:38.310 --> 00:05:41.480
By running gpg,
it's gonna kick off and start running.

119
00:05:41.480 --> 00:05:44.415
Now I do have a slight problem here,
is that I kinda ran it as root.

120
00:05:44.415 --> 00:05:45.957
>> [LAUGH]
>> So I'm gonna cancel that.

121
00:05:45.957 --> 00:05:48.060
I'm a super user in this prompt.

122
00:05:48.060 --> 00:05:49.620
So let me just switch to
like a regular user here.

123
00:05:49.620 --> 00:05:50.250
I'll do John Doe.

124
00:05:50.250 --> 00:05:52.880
So this is my user, John Doe.

125
00:05:52.880 --> 00:05:58.300
And John, he needs to generate a private
and public key and get the system ready.

126
00:05:58.300 --> 00:06:01.800
So you can just run gpg and
that'll start that start up wizard.

127
00:06:01.800 --> 00:06:05.579
If you've already got a key and
you want a new one, right,

128
00:06:05.579 --> 00:06:10.690
maybe you just don't trust the one
you've got, you can do gpg-- gen-key.

129
00:06:10.690 --> 00:06:11.950
And that'll do it too, right.

130
00:06:11.950 --> 00:06:13.530
That kinda kicks it off again.

131
00:06:13.530 --> 00:06:16.130
And see here it's gonna start and
generate that key.

132
00:06:16.130 --> 00:06:19.120
But notice these little messages here,
directory created,

133
00:06:19.120 --> 00:06:21.500
new configuration file created, and so on.

134
00:06:21.500 --> 00:06:24.860
It's basically looking for those files
that they're missing and creating them.

135
00:06:24.860 --> 00:06:28.310
So I've kind of gotten in the habit
of running this right here instead of

136
00:06:28.310 --> 00:06:33.140
just running gpg, and that way if there's
already a key, I don't know who made that.

137
00:06:33.140 --> 00:06:34.880
I don't trust that, I wanna make my own,

138
00:06:34.880 --> 00:06:38.390
this is gonna do it and it will run
the startup wizard too if it's necessary.

139
00:06:38.390 --> 00:06:40.931
So here it's kinda getting
things started up.

140
00:06:40.931 --> 00:06:46.027
So gpg-- gen-key creates that key.

141
00:06:46.027 --> 00:06:48.695
Here it's asking me what
kind of key I want.

142
00:06:48.695 --> 00:06:49.565
And you can pick.

143
00:06:49.565 --> 00:06:54.285
The default is to use RSA keys for the
private and the public, for the key pair.

144
00:06:54.285 --> 00:07:00.225
You can choose to use, in here it's the
cipher as well as the hashing algorithm,

145
00:07:00.225 --> 00:07:01.885
so it's using RSA for both.

146
00:07:01.885 --> 00:07:03.721
You can use DSA and Elgamal.

147
00:07:03.721 --> 00:07:07.245
You can use DSA and RSA just for
signing and not encrypting.

148
00:07:08.315 --> 00:07:12.520
Maybe you wanna send data that's signed,
so that you know if it's been modified.

149
00:07:12.520 --> 00:07:14.300
But you don't care if somebody reads it,
right.

150
00:07:14.300 --> 00:07:16.000
Then why bother encrypting it?

151
00:07:16.000 --> 00:07:19.860
Now people will be able to read
your email, even if they don't have

152
00:07:19.860 --> 00:07:22.580
the private key associated with it,
cuz it's not encrypted.

153
00:07:22.580 --> 00:07:24.730
But they can verify whether
it's been tampered with, so

154
00:07:24.730 --> 00:07:26.520
that's why we're gonna do sign only.

155
00:07:26.520 --> 00:07:29.030
All right, but
the default is to do RSA for both, and

156
00:07:29.030 --> 00:07:30.860
I'll go ahead and choose that.

157
00:07:30.860 --> 00:07:34.866
Now when I ran gpg in the other window
as root, it didn't generate a new key,

158
00:07:34.866 --> 00:07:37.071
it didn't ask for questions like these.

159
00:07:37.071 --> 00:07:40.505
It just generated the default one, so
this is nice that I get that option.

160
00:07:40.505 --> 00:07:41.936
I can pick my key strength right.

161
00:07:41.936 --> 00:07:45.502
Do I want it to be 1,024 bits or
all the way up to 4,096,

162
00:07:45.502 --> 00:07:48.288
default's 2,048, I'll stick with that.

163
00:07:48.288 --> 00:07:52.285
>> Now Don, is there any,
say you picked 4,096, right.

164
00:07:52.285 --> 00:07:55.347
Is there anything on my end as I
receive it that I would have to do, or

165
00:07:55.347 --> 00:07:58.935
am I just going to be able to decrypt that
no problemo because I've got your key

166
00:07:58.935 --> 00:08:00.925
>> Yeah, it's not a big deal.

167
00:08:00.925 --> 00:08:03.865
So once you have the key you know
the bit strength and that's it.

168
00:08:03.865 --> 00:08:04.941
Picking a stronger key,

169
00:08:04.941 --> 00:08:08.075
the main thing is that it just takes
longer to generate that key, right?

170
00:08:08.075 --> 00:08:09.750
So it is a harder key to generate.

171
00:08:09.750 --> 00:08:13.430
That also means it's a harder key to
guess so it's more secure, right?

172
00:08:13.430 --> 00:08:15.130
And on the client,
whoever's sending you data,

173
00:08:15.130 --> 00:08:17.580
they don't really have to do anything
different, it's not a big deal, awesome.

174
00:08:18.730 --> 00:08:21.020
All right, so
I'll just think with that default of 2048.

175
00:08:21.020 --> 00:08:24.220
And then how long is
the key gonna be valid for?

176
00:08:24.220 --> 00:08:25.840
Now the default is
the key is good forever.

177
00:08:25.840 --> 00:08:29.420
But the problem here is you might
not want it to be good forever.

178
00:08:29.420 --> 00:08:33.380
You might wanna do a new key every year,
so you generate a new key and you move on.

179
00:08:33.380 --> 00:08:36.300
That means if somebody is trying
to read your emails in the past,

180
00:08:36.300 --> 00:08:38.360
they would have to have the private
key that you used in the past,

181
00:08:38.360 --> 00:08:40.650
because your private key changes.

182
00:08:40.650 --> 00:08:44.540
Most people don't do an expiration date
on their GPG keys, but you certainly can.

183
00:08:44.540 --> 00:08:46.560
I'm gonna specify here but
the default is zero.

184
00:08:46.560 --> 00:08:47.530
It's not going to expire.

185
00:08:48.900 --> 00:08:51.560
And then it's just asking me to
make sure that I really want that.

186
00:08:51.560 --> 00:08:52.960
I'll say yes.

187
00:08:52.960 --> 00:08:55.500
And now it's building up my identity.

188
00:08:55.500 --> 00:08:56.860
I need to give it my real name.

189
00:08:56.860 --> 00:08:58.360
So this is a user called John Doe.

190
00:08:58.360 --> 00:09:00.420
So I'm gonna give it his name.

191
00:09:00.420 --> 00:09:03.900
And his email address, so
this is jdoe@localhost.

192
00:09:03.900 --> 00:09:05.570
I haven't actually
assigned a machine name.

193
00:09:05.570 --> 00:09:06.950
Actually I think I did, didn't I?

194
00:09:06.950 --> 00:09:11.470
This is like a dplaptop.lab.itpro.tv
I think is what it's called.

195
00:09:12.550 --> 00:09:15.430
All right, I can do a comment,
well whatever you want here.

196
00:09:15.430 --> 00:09:21.198
I'll say John Doe is super awesome,
just so we can remember.

197
00:09:21.198 --> 00:09:22.295
>> Yeah.
[LAUGH]

198
00:09:22.295 --> 00:09:23.360
>> [LAUGH] But oh and

199
00:09:23.360 --> 00:09:25.620
I spelled John Does is super awesome, so

200
00:09:25.620 --> 00:09:29.500
apparently I'm a moron, but
here we'll just blank the comment out.

201
00:09:29.500 --> 00:09:30.268
All right.
So there we go, so

202
00:09:30.268 --> 00:09:31.260
we got good old John Doe.

203
00:09:31.260 --> 00:09:34.780
I'm okay with all of that, so we'll go
ahead and just say that we are okay.

204
00:09:34.780 --> 00:09:36.910
And now it's gonna go and generate it.

205
00:09:36.910 --> 00:09:39.540
Now, it's going to generate that key, and

206
00:09:39.540 --> 00:09:42.310
you'll see it's like doing a- this
is a pine entry here for email.

207
00:09:42.310 --> 00:09:44.280
This is sent to us being annoying.

208
00:09:44.280 --> 00:09:47.660
So I just need to get my pass-phrase,
which I'll punch in there.

209
00:09:47.660 --> 00:09:50.635
And I just used the word password.

210
00:09:50.635 --> 00:09:53.103
I'm not happy about that, but
I'm going to use it anyway.

211
00:09:53.103 --> 00:09:53.948
[LAUGH] So I'm gonna punch that in there.

212
00:09:53.948 --> 00:09:56.930
And there we go.

213
00:09:56.930 --> 00:10:00.460
Now it's going to
generate my private keys.

214
00:10:00.460 --> 00:10:04.630
Okay, now it's telling me right here we
need to generate a lot of random bytes.

215
00:10:04.630 --> 00:10:06.720
It's a good idea to perform
some other actions.

216
00:10:07.850 --> 00:10:09.270
This is where things get a little tricky.

217
00:10:09.270 --> 00:10:09.840
All right.

218
00:10:09.840 --> 00:10:15.040
When it generates a private key it needs
to make sure that it's randomly generated.

219
00:10:15.040 --> 00:10:18.330
If it's not randomly generated somebody
could guess the key that I've made.

220
00:10:18.330 --> 00:10:20.280
Right?
Guess based on the version of operating

221
00:10:20.280 --> 00:10:22.520
system I'm running and
the seed values used by it.

00:31:01.560 --> 00:31:06.100

604
00:31:06.100 --> 00:31:10.260
So, I'm gonna remove my known host file,

605
00:31:10.260 --> 00:31:13.430
And then,

00:31:13.430 --> 00:31:19.270

607
00:31:19.270 --> 00:31:20.690
And, by doing that.

00:31:22.700 --> 00:31:24.320
It's going to make sure
I don't get any typos.

00:31:24.320 --> 00:31:26.100
Let's take the human element out of it.

610
00:31:26.100 --> 00:31:27.740
I'm just gonna dump it right into there.

00:31:27.740 --> 00:31:30.090
And now we should be

00:31:30.090 --> 00:31:32.205

00:31:41.020 --> 00:31:44.300

618
00:31:44.300 --> 00:31:51.040
But now I can get in here, I can log in,
and now I'm on that laptop and

619
00:31:51.040 --> 00:31:55.010
I'm secure and I did it with my own keys,
keys I know I trust.

620
00:31:55.010 --> 00:31:56.600
>> Don that is super awesome.

621
00:31:56.600 --> 00:32:02.040
Being able to demystify the SSH and

622
00:32:02.040 --> 00:32:06.570
It can be really daunting to a new user

623
00:32:06.570 --> 00:32:09.610
That is the avenue in which

00:32:09.610 --> 00:32:12.720
And it gets a little scary when we start
kicking our feet around somewhere we're

00:32:12.720 --> 00:32:13.750
not really sure about.

00:32:13.750 --> 00:32:14.760
But it's really not that hard,

00:32:14.760 --> 00:32:18.140
we really showed that this

00:32:18.140 --> 00:32:19.910
And even when you have
a little bit of trouble,

00:32:19.910 --> 00:32:21.950
you quickly troubleshoot that as well.

00:32:21.950 --> 00:32:25.230
Not really that difficult,

00:32:25.230 --> 00:32:28.380
If you were doing this,

00:32:28.380 --> 00:32:31.470

00:32:31.470 --> 00:32:32.520
Not that difficult.

634
00:32:32.520 --> 00:32:36.100
>> And a good question in the chat room
about how do you set what ciphers it uses.

635
00:32:36.100 --> 00:32:40.560
And you got a couple of choices

00:32:40.560 --> 00:32:41.060
Right?

00:32:41.060 --> 00:32:45.250
You need to go and modify that

00:32:45.250 --> 00:32:49.440
You go in that config file, and

00:32:49.440 --> 00:32:50.900
do you wanna support version one?

00:32:50.900 --> 00:32:51.680
Or version two?

641
00:32:51.680 --> 00:32:53.100
What ciphers do you wanna support?

642
00:32:53.100 --> 00:32:54.720
So you dictate that on the server.

643
00:32:54.720 --> 00:32:58.120
When you generate your certificates,
that command that we used,

644
00:32:58.120 --> 00:33:02.170
that RSA keygen command,
we generated those keys.

645
00:33:02.170 --> 00:33:03.820
I'm sorry, the SSH keygen command.

00:33:03.820 --> 00:33:07.400
When we generated those keys, there's

00:33:07.400 --> 00:33:12.130

648
00:33:12.130 --> 00:33:15.280
When you generate those keys but you gotta

649
00:33:15.280 --> 00:33:18.330
You don't wanna generate keys that are
harder than what your SSH daemon will even

650
00:33:18.330 --> 00:33:19.120
support, right?

651
00:33:19.120 --> 00:33:20.920
So you gotta make sure those match.

652
00:33:20.920 --> 00:33:22.860
And then on the client

00:33:22.860 --> 00:33:25.930
there's a lot of command line options

I just ran the SSH command with its

7
00:00:21.810 --> 00:00:26.070
We're back again for another Linux+
episode, part two of our SSH

8
00:00:26.070 --> 00:00:27.916
episode that we kinda started and-

9
00:00:27.916 --> 00:00:30.140
[LAUGH]

00:00:33.139 --> 00:00:34.148
it's pretty important.

12
00:00:34.148 --> 00:00:36.510
It's SSH tunneling.

13
00:00:36.510 --> 00:00:39.580
And let me tell you, boy,
SSH tunneling is some fun stuff cuz

14
00:00:39.580 --> 00:00:42.420
there's really no limit to
what you can do with it.

15
00:00:42.420 --> 00:00:44.470
What SSH tunneling is,
it's kinda like a VPN.

16
00:00:44.470 --> 00:00:45.882
A lot of you guys out there in TV land,

17
00:00:45.882 --> 00:00:47.854
you've probably used
virtual private networks.

18
00:00:47.854 --> 00:00:53.734
And you used, PPTP or L2TP,
maybe you used SSL VPNs, IPsec, right,

19
00:00:53.734 --> 00:00:59.231
to build an encrypted tunnel between

20
00:00:59.231 --> 00:01:01.000
And it worked well enough, right?

21
00:01:01.000 --> 00:01:04.180
But when you did that,
you had to set things up on both ends,

22
00:01:04.180 --> 00:01:06.140
you had to build the tunnel up.

23
00:01:06.140 --> 00:01:08.130
And you had to have identities and

24
00:01:08.130 --> 00:01:11.070
kind of things configured there, and
it can be a little bit challenging.

25
00:01:11.070 --> 00:01:14.410
Well, what a lot of people don't
realize is, if you just need something

26
00:01:14.410 --> 00:01:17.860
temporarily, you don't have to go
through the trouble of setting up a VPN.

27
00:01:17.860 --> 00:01:19.060
You can just use SSH.

28
00:01:19.060 --> 00:01:22.730
Now normally, when we hear SSH,
we think of the secure shell.

29
00:01:22.730 --> 00:01:26.160
I'm getting a shell session and
it's encrypted and there we go.

30
00:01:26.160 --> 00:01:31.010
But, you can actually send whatever
the heck you want over that session.

31
00:01:31.010 --> 00:01:34.890
The default, when you connect via SSH,
the default is for

32
00:01:34.890 --> 00:01:39.390
it to run a shell on the other end for
you, but you don't have to do that.

33
00:01:39.390 --> 00:01:42.060
You can tell it, hey,
don't run anything on the other end.

34
00:01:42.060 --> 00:01:45.910
Let me start running programs over this
and let me run whatever the heck I want.

35
00:01:45.910 --> 00:01:48.000
And it'll do that just fine.

36
00:01:48.000 --> 00:01:52.610
SSH isn't actually a shell protocol,
its an encryption protocol, right?

37
00:01:52.610 --> 00:01:54.170
It creates a tunnel,

38
00:01:54.170 --> 00:01:58.620
SSH is a tunneling in protocol that
just happens to run a shell by default.

39
00:01:58.620 --> 00:02:02.153
But if we tell it not to run the shell,
you can run anything.

40
00:02:02.153 --> 00:02:03.106
I sound kind of creepy-
>> [LAUGH]

41
00:02:03.106 --> 00:02:04.216
>> When I say it that way,

42
00:02:04.216 --> 00:02:05.275
let me back off that.

43
00:02:05.275 --> 00:02:08.085
You can run things like
X-Window applications.

44
00:02:08.085 --> 00:02:11.375
You can run GUI apps that are actually
running on a server on the other end but

45
00:02:11.375 --> 00:02:13.055
you see the GUI on your end.

46
00:02:13.055 --> 00:02:15.372
You can run non-secure
protocols like telnet.

47
00:02:15.372 --> 00:02:17.382
And you can say I'm gonna run telnet,

48
00:02:17.382 --> 00:02:19.532
stick it in this tunnel that
will encrypt it, right?

49
00:02:19.532 --> 00:02:22.542
Maybe you've got some application
that you have to use telnet with,

50
00:02:22.542 --> 00:02:23.702
you're just required.

51
00:02:23.702 --> 00:02:25.352
Well that sucks, right, and it happens.

52
00:02:25.352 --> 00:02:27.670
And you don't wanna do that.

53
00:02:27.670 --> 00:02:31.530
So maybe you take that traffic and
you nest it inside of an SSH tunnel.

54
00:02:31.530 --> 00:02:34.330
Maybe your company has a firewall and

55
00:02:34.330 --> 00:02:36.840
they're just not letting you get certain
websites and you wanna get there so

56
00:02:36.840 --> 00:02:39.170
you SSH into your home computer and
browse the web.

57
00:02:39.170 --> 00:02:40.690
I don't know who would
do something like this.

58
00:02:40.690 --> 00:02:41.256
>> Not Don.

59
00:02:41.256 --> 00:02:44.619
[LAUGH]
>> Daniel and I, just kinda our history,

60
00:02:44.619 --> 00:02:48.985
we both worked for a insurance company
that, we had web filters there.

61
00:02:48.985 --> 00:02:51.179
>> We did.
>> And dammit, if I wanna get to ESPN,

62
00:02:51.179 --> 00:02:52.351
I'm gonna get to ESPN.

63
00:02:52.351 --> 00:02:56.043
>> [LAUGH] So maybe SSH out, I don't know.

64
00:02:56.043 --> 00:02:57.937
>> We gotta know who won the game,
man, come on,

65
00:02:57.937 --> 00:03:00.190
the highlight reels
are what it's all about.

66
00:03:00.190 --> 00:03:02.290
>> So there's any number of uses for it.

67
00:03:02.290 --> 00:03:05.270
The cool thing to remember is that
SSH is not just about shells.

68
00:03:05.270 --> 00:03:09.370
So instead of blabbering on about this,
let me show you what I mean, okay?

69
00:03:09.370 --> 00:03:12.699
In the first part of this episode
I showed you guys Telnet and

70
00:03:12.699 --> 00:03:14.306
how it just wasn't secure.

71
00:03:14.306 --> 00:03:17.548
And everything I sent via Telnet
was in plain text on the network.

72
00:03:17.548 --> 00:03:20.437
I used Wireshark to capture it and
read it.

73
00:03:20.437 --> 00:03:24.895
What if we nested that inside of SSH,
right?

74
00:03:24.895 --> 00:03:26.545
Let me show you how that works, all right.

75
00:03:26.545 --> 00:03:28.993
Step one, you start on your client.

76
00:03:28.993 --> 00:03:32.327
Right, your server just
needs to be set up for SSH.

77
00:03:32.327 --> 00:03:36.662
And like we said in the last episode, most
servers are set up for SSH by default.

78
00:03:36.662 --> 00:03:39.997
They've got the SSH daemon installed and
running and it's open on IP tables,

79
00:03:39.997 --> 00:03:41.147
the software firewall,

80
00:03:41.147 --> 00:03:44.500
so you're usually in business as
far as the server's concerned.

81
00:03:44.500 --> 00:03:46.290
You don't have to change anything there.

82
00:03:46.290 --> 00:03:50.060
On the client side,
we've got to establish a tunnel and

83
00:03:50.060 --> 00:03:52.830
tell it not to run any
commands on the tunnel.

84
00:03:52.830 --> 00:03:56.310
That's the tricky part cuz normally when
you use SSH it establishes the tunnel and

85
00:03:56.310 --> 00:03:57.080
it launches a shell.

86
00:03:58.100 --> 00:04:01.810
So it's a little bit of a variation
of the SSH client command.

87
00:04:01.810 --> 00:04:03.780
So here I am on my client, and

88
00:04:03.780 --> 00:04:07.700
I want to create a Telnet session
to this server on the other side.

89
00:04:07.700 --> 00:04:10.060
And I want it to be encrypted.

90
00:04:10.060 --> 00:04:15.220
Now, I know I can just do telnet and
point to that other system and connect in.

91
00:04:15.220 --> 00:04:18.164
Apparently I don't have the telnet,
well that's gonna slow me down, isn't it?

92
00:04:18.164 --> 00:04:20.585
>> [LAUGH]
>> If you don't have the telnet client

93
00:04:20.585 --> 00:04:24.130
installed, then you're gonna
have a little bit of a problem.

94
00:04:24.130 --> 00:04:26.607
So let me get that installed,
that'll be step number one.

95
00:04:26.607 --> 00:04:28.139
>> That'll be step one, that's right.

96
00:04:28.139 --> 00:04:31.148
[LAUGH]
>> So [LAUGH] I learned something new.

97
00:04:31.148 --> 00:04:35.114
In CentOS 7 apparently the telnet
client is not installed by default, so-

98
00:04:35.114 --> 00:04:35.755
>> They don't like

99
00:04:35.755 --> 00:04:37.087
those insecure protocols, Don.

100
00:04:37.087 --> 00:04:37.900
>> There we go, yeah, I guess not.

101
00:04:37.900 --> 00:04:39.090
>> It's a secure world we live in.

102
00:04:39.090 --> 00:04:42.360
>> So here we can see I can remote over,
I can connect.

103
00:04:42.360 --> 00:04:45.559
And when I connect over there I can see
that I'm now on this dplaptop machine.

104
00:04:45.559 --> 00:04:50.428
And if I exit out back here
I can see that I'm just in,

105
00:04:50.428 --> 00:04:54.095
whoops, I'm in, where the heck am I?

106
00:04:54.095 --> 00:04:55.005
I'm lost, that's where I am.

107
00:04:55.005 --> 00:04:55.825
There we go.

108
00:04:55.825 --> 00:05:00.135
Now I'm back on dplaptop,
am I on the wrong machine?

109
00:05:00.135 --> 00:05:02.247
>> That could be why you didn't
find Telnet installed on this one.

110
00:05:02.247 --> 00:05:03.919
>> That is probably true.

111
00:05:03.919 --> 00:05:06.629
All right, let's make sure I'm on
the right machine here, there we go.

112
00:05:06.629 --> 00:05:10.265
All right, so I know I can Telnet in,
and it's gonna Telnet across,

113
00:05:10.265 --> 00:05:12.385
and it's gonna do it unencrypted,
and then that's bad.

114
00:05:12.385 --> 00:05:14.250
So I know that part already works.

115
00:05:14.250 --> 00:05:16.340
Now I just need to do this
in an encrypted fashion.

116
00:05:16.340 --> 00:05:18.400
So, we can manipulate the SSH command.

117
00:05:18.400 --> 00:05:23.650
Now, remember in the last episode I said
I could do ssh, followed by my username@,

118
00:05:23.650 --> 00:05:28.440
and then the IP or fully qualified
domain name of the other system.

119
00:05:28.440 --> 00:05:31.130
So that's the command I'd
run to open up a shell.

120
00:05:31.130 --> 00:05:36.390
And when I do that, it's gonna connect up
and it's gonna launch a shell by default.

121
00:05:36.390 --> 00:05:41.350
That's the default function for SSH, is to
run a shell, and there we are, all right?

122
00:05:41.350 --> 00:05:44.408
But that's not what I want,
I want to run other programs over it.

123
00:05:44.408 --> 00:05:48.304
So I'm gonna modify this command line to
tell it not to do that shell, to instead,

124
00:05:48.304 --> 00:05:49.890
do some other stuff, all right?

125
00:05:51.110 --> 00:05:57.244
So I'm gonna say ssh -f and
give it that dpezet@10.1.230.238,

126
00:05:57.244 --> 00:06:01.193
so I'm providing it that
same basic information.

127
00:06:01.193 --> 00:06:05.930
And then I'm gonna add a little
more information to it, okay.

128
00:06:05.930 --> 00:06:11.830
What I'm gonna do is I'm gonna
create a TCP port on my system.

129
00:06:11.830 --> 00:06:15.386
So just a port number,
like SSH uses port 22.

130
00:06:15.386 --> 00:06:19.210
I'm gonna pick a random port and
I'm gonna create that port on my system.

131
00:06:19.210 --> 00:06:21.780
And I'm gonna map that to the SSH tunnel.

132
00:06:21.780 --> 00:06:28.292
And I'm gonna say any traffic that I send
to this port, send through the SSH tunnel.

133
00:06:28.292 --> 00:06:34.050
And on the other end, I need the tunnel
to map that port to somewhere different.

134
00:06:34.050 --> 00:06:35.101
I'm doing Telnet traffic so

135
00:06:35.101 --> 00:06:37.523
I'd need it to be mapped to port
23 at the end of the day, right?

136
00:06:37.523 --> 00:06:39.845
Telnet uses TCP port 23.

137
00:06:39.845 --> 00:06:46.075
So I'm gonna come in here and I'm gonna
say -L and I'm gonna pick a local port.

138
00:06:46.075 --> 00:06:49.593
Now your local port,
ports 1 through 1024 are registered, so

139
00:06:49.593 --> 00:06:51.400
you shouldn't use those.

140
00:06:51.400 --> 00:06:54.810
But really ports even up into
the 30,000s can be registered.

141
00:06:54.810 --> 00:06:59.585
So normally you want to pick a port that's
somewhere in the 49,000 to 65,000 range.

142
00:06:59.585 --> 00:07:02.020
So I usually pick a really high one.

143
00:07:02.020 --> 00:07:05.960
And my, I'll give you guys my secrets,
so here's the way I normally do it.

144
00:07:05.960 --> 00:07:10.200
Is, if I'm mapping a port,
I normally just take 60,000 and

145
00:07:10.200 --> 00:07:12.340
then I add whatever the normal
port would be to it.

146
00:07:12.340 --> 00:07:15.170
So if it was port 23,
then I'd do 60023, right?

147
00:07:16.190 --> 00:07:20.580
I know it's a nice high port number so
I'm not picking something already in use.

148
00:07:20.580 --> 00:07:25.230
And I can remember it because
it's just 600 followed by 23.

149
00:07:25.230 --> 00:07:29.910
Or if I was doing web traffic I might do
60080 just so I can kinda remember it.

150
00:07:29.910 --> 00:07:32.950
So that's gonna be the local
port here on this computer.

151
00:07:32.950 --> 00:07:38.020
Any traffic that I send to that port is
gonna get stuck under this SSH tunnel.

152
00:07:38.020 --> 00:07:43.570
And so then I say :, and IP address of
the other system I'm connecting to.

153
00:07:43.570 --> 00:07:47.308
And I know it seems kind of redundant
that I've already got it right here, but

154
00:07:47.308 --> 00:07:50.367
this is for authentication purposes,
this is for the tunnel.

155
00:07:50.367 --> 00:07:52.770
That's why we have to do it twice.

156
00:07:52.770 --> 00:07:58.670
And then I do another :, and I say on
the other end, what does this map to?

157
00:07:58.670 --> 00:08:01.070
Well, here's where we have
to understand our software.

158
00:08:01.070 --> 00:08:03.371
If this is web traffic,
I need to map it to port 80.

159
00:08:03.371 --> 00:08:07.160
